reviewText:
You can pick up a dumb cable tester for 10 dollars that runs current through the cable and lights up LEDs at the other end to prove that continuity is good down the cable, from pin x on one end to pin x on the other end. So why pay five times the price for this tester? For one thing, it is much easier to understand than watching lights flash. The LCD readout shows clearly how the pins on the near end map to the pins on the far end. It also does some thinking for you and can tell you if the cable has shorts, opens, or is wired as a crossover cable. But the real reason to get this tester rather than a dumb 10 dollar model is that it can detect split pairs. These occur due to the (somewhat non-intuitive) fact that a CAT cables twisted pairs are NOT wired like this:
(1-2) (3-4) (5-6) (7-8)
Instead, the twisted pairs actually terminate like this:
(1-2) [3-] (4-5) [-6] (7-8)

This strange wiring is a holdover from telephone jacks where the center two pins carry line 1, and the flanking set of pins carry line 2. A cable with split pairs will check out okay all day long on a simple continuity test, but will not actually carry data very well if the cable is longer than about 10 ft because the crosstalk is so extreme. Being able to detect split pairs is a pretty awesome feature for a tester at this price point.
summary: Semi-smart cable tester

reviewText:
I just finished installing a complete whole house water filtration system.  I used only pentek filters and housings.  I'm very happy with the performance of my system and how well it all went together.  Here's a breakdown of the all the components I used in my system.  I went to great length researching what works and found it wasn't easy going thru each pentek filter and it's function.  The goal was to reduce some sediment, iron deposits from old iron pipes and remove any chemical taste.  The water tastes great now and is crystal clear.

Components:

-Pentek Big Blue 20" Filter Housings
-Housing Bracket for Big blue 10" and 20" filter

Filters IN ORDER:
1-Pentek DGD-2501-20 Spun Polypropylene Filter 20 micron dual stage to 1 micron.
2-Pentek 155263, RFFE20-BB Radial Flow Iron Removing Filter
3-Pentek RFCC-BB Carbon Filter

you can add another Filter after the Carbon for media if you want.  Not necessary but is an option or run 2 sediment filters in beginning of the system.

-Various copper pipes and PVC pipes to build the system.  I highly recommend a bypass valve and a way to shut off the water to your filters if you need to change them without losing water pressure to the house.

-I experienced nearly 0 PSI drop thru the 3 filters and no noticeable change in flow rate.
summary: How to build a whole house filtration system.

reviewText: Didn't get this handheld vacuum from Amazon, but I did buy it from a local store and would like to share some info. This unit worked initially once charged for 24 hours after taken out of the box. All of a sudden about 2 days later, it would not work at all and the charge light would not even light up once set on the cradle. After reading many bad reviews about battery life I decided to actually open the unit to take a look inside instead of returning it(I am an electronic technician). I found a circuit board directly below the on/ off switch and what I found was interesting. A transistor on that board was not aligned properly when soldered at the factory. See attached images. After placing that transistor in place and re-soldered its connections, this thing works like a champ. I believe this can also contribute to the battery charging issues people have been experiencing. Hopefully this post will help some people repair their unit, being that their customer service department is horrible.
summary: I have a fix for this!

reviewText:
This Irwin 10232 Unibit is a high quality set step drill, made in the USA. While it does cost more than competing off-shore bits it is also significantly superior in all respects.

The Good:
Smooth, sharp cutting edges allows one to produce clean accurate holes with ease in thin metal, plastic and wood.
Pointed tip does indeed prevent the bit from wandering or skipping when starting a hole. No counterpunch or pre-drilling required to achieve accuracy.
The shank is formed to fit 1/4 hex drivers. The amazon product photo does not show these newer driver style shanks (at the time of this review).
Markings are highly visible and easy to read.
The quality workmanship of this product is obvious: sharp, finely machined, highly visible markings.

The Bad:
There really isn't anything serious to complain about, so consider the following list to be nit-picking
The bit fits standard 1/4 hex drivers, but the shank section before the groove is a bit shorter than normal (see photo). This is no problem whatsoever in magnetic drivers. In my non-magnetic Makita impact driver the bit had slightly more in-and-out play than usual, but it did not affect drilling performance. (I warned you I was nit-picking!).

Summary:
If you enjoy using top quality tools then this set is worthy of your consideration.

If you like short reviews - stop here!

On the other hand, if you like lots of extra information, then please by all means read-on

The bit has a hex shank for positive slip-free use in standard drill chucks. This #2 bit also fits in standard 1/4 drill drivers, impact drivers, etc. At the time of this review, the amazon description states they have a 3 flatted shank which is not accurate - mine has a six sided shank, also known as a hex shank.

Irwin Unibit #2:
Irwin Item #: 10232
Hole Sizes: 3/16 - 1/2
Step increment: 3/8
Number of steps: 6
Step Height (i.e. max material thickness): 3/8
Overall Length: 3-1/8
Shank Size Across flats: 1/4
Drill Chuck Required to hold shank: 1/4

I happen to own some low cost import step drill bits (a Neiko 10193A set, in near new condition). It is immediately obvious that the Irwin bits are better quality than the Neikos in appearance and legibility of the step-size markings. Ill post a picture showing an Irwin and Neiko side by side. In use the Irwin bits cut sheet metal faster, producing smoother edges (less burrs) and more well rounded holes. For rough work on a tight budget the Neiko may be a good choice. Otherwise Id recommend the Irwin bits.

When is a step drill better than a standard metal drill bit?

When drilling sheet metal. You get better formed holes, less burrs, and less grab as the bit exits the material. As hole diameter increases these differences become even more pronounced.
Less torque required. With wider diameter holes, a standard drill bit is engaging the entire diameter of the material at once. Whereas a step drill engages a fraction of that. This results in easier drilling, and less torque on ones wrists and hands. The workpiece is also less likely to be torn out of your hand when your grip is not firm enough.
When a standard drill bit is too long. Step drills are shorter than standard drill bits. For example a 1/2 (max) step drill is about half the length of comparable metal drill bit.
Its possible to de-burr holes with a step drill by just allowing the next step size to lightly touch the material before you stop drilling. It takes a bit of practice, but can save time especially when drilling a lot of holes.
If you need to enlarge an existing hole, and want it well centered on the original hole. This can work nicely even in wood, when drilling with Forstner (flat bottomed) bits - the Unibit can cut a 1/8 wider starter hole which is just enough to keep the Forstner bit centered.
Smooth cutting step drills - like this Irwin bit - cuts plastic sheet much better than regular bits, especially as hole sizes increase. I found it easy to produce clean edged, accurate holes with the Irwin step bits in my handheld drill. Trying to use standard bits often made a mess of things, unless the holes where small (say less than 1/4 diameter).
A single step drill bit might save one the hassle of carrying a set of standard drill bits, but of course only when all the material you are drilling is thin enough.

When is a standard metal drill bit better?

When you want to make no mistake about drilling too large a hole. A regular drill bit always makes the same hole size - no need to count the steps - which can be very reassuring when drilling into a valuable workpiece.
In thicker heavier material, or when you need non-through holes. Step drills just aren't designed to do this.

Other details and observations:

Use step bits to quickly measure the diameter of existing holes. Just insert the bit until its snug and read the diameter from the it. Of course the step drill needs to have high quality markings for this to be practical.
Enlarge an existing hole, while keeping the center of the hole unchanged.
You can (almost) double the effective depth of cut of your step drill if you are able to drill in from both sides of a hole.
I was able to produce accurate, clean holes in 3/4 thick fir plywood when I drilled it to the maximum diameter of the bit. So if you live with 1/2 holes you are not really constrained as to thickness of your wood. The bit cut quickly and cleanly through the material. Of course this is a very special case, but I thought it worth mentioning nonetheless.
One review claimed that these bits cut in two directions. To test this I tried making holes in hardwood by running my drill in reverse. It worked poorly, cutting action much slower and the quality of the hole was not as good as running the bit in a normal (clockwise) direction.
In hardwoods, I found step drills to be a quick and effective way to remove the ragged edges and slivers on the back sides of freshly drilled holes. You do need a light touch, and a bit of practice to obtain consistent results.

If you would like to see more images of bits, test cuts, and so on, please see my review of the Irwin 10225 Unibit set.

I hope you found this information useful. If so your feedback would be much appreciated.
summary: High Quality Bit, Works well in Plastic, Metal, Wood

reviewText: I wanted to make a coat rack that would hold all our jackets to go on the kitchen area in my house. I want good quality old style looking hooks. These filled the bill perfectly. They are made of good quality materials and very strong and durable. Very pleased with my purchase.
summary: Very pleased with my purchase

reviewText:
I am not sure how this compares to other sheets, I got two sheets (different orders) and they both seem identical. I really can't find fault with the product, just in how I use it.
For those new to this: the mat (dull) side has no reflection and has an awesome look to it, very fine texture.
Make sure you follow all the tips and tricks for use online.  Preheat oven, warm work piece etc.  It gets soft pretty quick, if it gets hot and cools too quick it will shrink.  Too much heat and it may look a little shiny on the surface.

In the pics I posted I show a 0.080" sheet
summary: Make your own tactical toy holder

reviewText:
Really do love the toothpaste (took away 1 star because of the size - small even for a trial!).

I have not and probably will not use the other items, but that toothpaste...! I will be ordering a full size of that asap. It's the best toothpaste I have ever tried. I take medications and infusions that dry my mouth out and I like to brush my mouth several times a day just because that's how I was raised. In the past, I have used Biotene and ACT products. They were okay but this one is better than both.

There is zero taste to this one. After I brush and rinse with water, my mouth feels very clean. There's no sweet (or any) kind of aftertaste or residue. My mouth didn't dry out as much even a couple hours after brushing.

My only complaint about this trial kit is that each item is so small that a user won't get to try much to decide! The mouthwash is the biggest item and I would rather have had more of the toothpaste. The trial won't last the time it takes me to order a full tube.

Attached photo shows the size against a standard Sharpie marking pen.
summary: Best for dry mouth!

reviewText: I order two packs (60 total leds) about 30% were a different shade than the rest.  Only those 30% of those were "warm white" like in the image, the others were neutral white.
summary: Received two different shades.

reviewText:
I felt bad using our lab glassware for my starters so I decided to purchase my own Erlenmeyer flask. I was a bit worried not to receive an original Pyrex flask as others pointed out. However, I was lucky and mine is the real deal. I have already used it for my starter once and it went through the autoclave twice. The opening is not as narrow as it sounds and there's little risk spilling stuff when either pouring wort and yeast in or out.
Grab one now and don't forget the stir bar!
summary: Perfect for yeast starters

reviewText:
We have a very active home with friends and family using our blacksmith metalshop, garage, and our barn full of horses. I don't want to use our fancy guest towels and have them ruined, and a roll of paper towels always ends up wet on the bottom or finger prints all over the top.  I do not want to drill into any walls for a dispenser or roll holder so I use a top load attractive sheet holder for these such as this one: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B078Z35CQ8
These are very sturdy but yet absorbent and comfortable.  Not crinkly and hard and like out of a gas station.  They have a lovely design imprinted into the towel as well.  Very happy!
summary: Perfect for our needs.

reviewText:
My husband starts many of his conversations with me by saying "On the last episode I saw of 'Monsters Inside of Me',".... and him telling me about buying this detector started out that way too. He saw an episode where there was a married couple who were chronically ill for years before finding out it was due to a small carbon monoxide leak that their "normal" carbon monoxide detector bought at a local hardware store wasn't detecting. So now we have this and we keep it in the basement so we can check on our gas appliances now and then and keep his mind at ease. Being able to see the actual number reading instead of relying on the potential amount of carbon monoxide leaking to be enough to set off a standard alarm is a very nice feature to have. We just moved into a new (but older) house and will be glad to have this tool to add to our arsenal when we start needing to use the furnace this winter and want to make sure everything is in perfect working order. We have only had this for a couple of days so far, so I can't speak to it's longevity but I will update this if it stops working at any point.

Also verified it actually detects CO by putting it in the stream of the car exhaust, causing it to go nuts rather quickly. This doesn't definitively confirm that it can detect the lowest of the low CO amounts that it was purchased for, but I am not equipped to do such tests. Can't find the aerosol cans filled with low PPM CO like I'd like to.
summary: Helps keep our minds at ease being able to see a digital readout

reviewText: I find this little magnifier useful when reading labels when shopping as many ingredients are printed in small letters. It is very light-weight and fits well in a shirt pocket. If you do carry it around, it is best if you protect the lens from scratches by using a pouch or equivalent item. It has an LED light operated by a button and helps in illuminating the area to be magnified (yes, it comes with two CR2032 button cell batteries already installed). Due to its compact size, good magnification and low weight and low price...I think this deserves a five stars for many users.
summary: Excellent tool for reading labels and other situations.

reviewText: Excellent quality, very accurate lab quality thermometer. Mine had a tiny separation in the column due to shipping that was easily fixed by tapping on a firm surface.

reviewText: Very useful for our homeschool science class. The slides are clearly labeled and there is a list included so you know what is what. The case is nice and durable. We like it because many of the slides we'd have to "make" are already done for us. Highly recommend

reviewText: Bought these for practice on a new microscope and they were great for that purpose.  Used them for practice with the eyepiece camera and later a Nikon adapter.  I didn't look at much beyond the plants  as plant ID was what  I bought the microscope for, but those slides of plants included were well done.  Slides were easily viewed and quality of the objects was great, even at x400.

reviewText: Great product ! I use it quite often .Great for pistol barrel work and many other gunsmithing projects!

reviewText: Very nice vise for the price. I too had problems getting the rotating ball to move so I took the suggestions from other posts and sprayed WD on it and loosened the ball screw. Hey worked like a charm. As I said a great little vise. There were no instructions with it so I sort of had to figure it out on my own. I have owned vices before but they were larger and not much to them. I must say Amazon thank you for offering this tool. I had looked at other small vices but the reviews for this one sold me. Amazon my life would be awful if I did not have you for all my shopping needs. Love Amazon Prime. Now back to my jewelry repairs! And anything else that requires a vise. reviewText: I've been putting these on some proto boards for raspberry pi projects as indicator lights.  Well they're crazy bright at the max (10mA) current using the included (200 ohm I believe) resistors and 5v supply.  I'm using my own 1k resistors to lower the brightness to a reasonable level that won't blind you when looking at the board, and in doing so they only pull about 2.5mA while still being plenty bright!  I haven't tried them at 20mA which is the max current they can handle, but I'm sure that would be ridiculous.  I'm buying some red/green LEDs from this company now, and another pack of blue.  Also they seem to come with as many resistors as they do bulbs, which is awesome.  Since I'm not using the ones that come with them I will have a nice supply of 200 ohm resistors.  The per unit price is so low when you consider you get a pack of 30, I was getting robbed at radio shack paying almost for just two LEDs!
summary: Insanely bright!!!

reviewText: At my home alone, I have Swiffer 360 dusters, regular dusters, dry and wet mops, etc.  Swiffer works great, no issues with me.... but believe me, this cleans better, dirt just sticks to it.. 3M cloths are very tacky, not like Swiffer soft cloths, which are not.  While I have had great success with my dry mop, I have not been able to efficiently wrap them around my 360 duster handle as others did, maybe they can upload pictures?  I definitely recommend for dusting floors.  Two pictures of my dry Swiffer mop with these cloths uploaded to amazon.

summary: Great addition to a dust collection system

reviewText:
I wish I would have bought this sooner! I am a home owner who loves woodworking, and I use my home garage as a workshop. With woodworking comes a lot of saw dust and wood particles. I got tired of dragging out my Ridgid shop vac and vacuuming the saw dust off of the floors, walls, and every surface. So then I bought the vacuum hose attachment for my vacuum to my compound miter saw. This was great at first, but I would end up forgetting to either turn off the vacuum or forget to turn it on while cutting lumber!
This got me searching the Internet for solutions and DGC Products I-socket came up over and over again! So, I ordered it plugged it in, and I will never have to worry about my vacuum again. This is how it works:
- plug it into 3 prong wall socket or extension cord
(IMPORTANT: this is for indoor/covered garage/shop use ONLY, it is NOT waterproof or water resistant)
-plug in your saw into the "TOOL" outlet (or whatever tool your using) on the I-socket
-plug in your shop vac into the "VAC" outlet on the I-socket
-turn the switch on your shop vac to the "ON" position and leave it there
-and that's it!

When you start or turn on your saw (or whatever tool you are using), the I-socket automatically turns on your shop vac. When you stop or turn off your saw (or whatever tool you are using), the I-socket will keep the shop vac running for about 8 seconds after the saw has stopped to clear any saw dust left behind, then it turns off the shop vac! The I-socket is very well made, it uses thick ABS plastic and all the seems are tightly fitted together.

Awesome product, I do recommend it to both professional and hobbyist woodworkers! I do not work for DGC Products, nor do I indorse there products, I am only writing a review off of my personal experience. Also, please, please, please remember SAFETY FIRST when working with electrical outlets, saws, routers, sanders, drills, and other equipment! I can not be held liable for your mistakes!

CPS
summary: Awesome product! A++++

reviewText: My cold water pipe leading to the water heater was already bonded but my hot water heater pipe from the water heater was not bonded. When I replaced my water heater recently and added a ball valve to the hot side, I also used a pair of these pipe clamps to add a #4 gauge solid copper wire from the cold pipe to the hot pipe. It worked very well. I'll use the 3rd one on a new ground rod outside.
summary: Easy to use and worked very well

reviewText: This paste is very sticky and exactly like tooth paste. It is very good for filling cracks and smoothing out damaged areas. Not easy to apply for the missing sections of the wood. You can use SculpWood Putty for replacing missing sections of the wood. Remember to apply Rotfix first then Epoxy Putty or Paste.

reviewText:
Very sturdy & well built crimp caps. Used them when installing a 4-channel amp to my OEM HU (I didn't want to loose my Navigation & other crucial stock features) w/ aftermarket speakers. I had to add two 20ft 9-conductors wires to the system & link them up w/ my amp in the rear trunk. With a combination of these crimp caps & the IRWIN Auto stripper, everything was a breeze. Saved me a trip to Best Buy (though they probs would have been overpriced over there) as always.

I recommend these for the dollar.

reviewText:
Reviewers who state this magnet doesn't stick to their frig or whatever are probably unaware that MAGNETS DON'T WORK ON STAINLESS STEEL.  This product worked perfectly for my application - covering holes and slots on 2 access panels on a SawStop tablesaw to seal air leaks in order to improve dust collection.

Pros:

Cons:

Recommended.

reviewText:
I wanted to use this magnet sheet to store spice tins on my cabinet door. See the photo for Two problems were experienced.

1. The magnetic strength varied all over the sheet. Some of the tins stuck well, and others did not and fell off, even when closing the door slowly.

2. The sheet started peeling away from the cabinet. I prepped it by cleaning it so there was no waxy coating, and it still peeled.

reviewText: These worked great at a children's science-themed birthday party. They were easy to use for little hands and looked great. They were featured at 2 different science tables. We used them at one table to pipette vinegar into a cabbage indicator solution in an acid base experiment and at another table we used them to pipette water drops onto a penny in a surface tension experiment. They worked great for both. Very pleased.
summary: These worked great at a children's science-themed birthday party

reviewText:
This vacuum is AWESOME. I bought this on sale at the store, but wanted to review it because I'm really pleased with it. I have an expensive big name stick vacuum that I've been using and the 15 minute battery life was KILLING me. My other vacuums were older and didn't have great suction so I felt like I couldn't do a good job. After using this and seeing how easy it is to convert for the stairs, I'm almost wishing I hadn't bought the stick vacuum. The only benefit to the stick is that it's a *bit* easier for going up and down the stairs with. I still think this does a better job of vacuuming though.

To address a few things about this vacuum:

1. If you're used to a bag vacuum, bag-less vacuums sometimes seem like they need to be emptied a lot. This one has a pretty large canister. I only use bag-less vacuums and this one seems huge to me. I like that it empties on both sides of the canister so I don't need to put my hand in there to grab all of the stuff out (like my other vacuum where stuff gets stuck up behind the filter).

2. There are labels all. over. it. I love this. There's a lot of neat features to the vacuum and I don't see myself remembering how to detach all of the parts correctly- but the labels tell you exactly what to do. It makes it a lot easier and faster than dealing with your booklet on the machine.

3. Suction is fabulous. Make sure you put it on the right setting- I was vacuuming with the setting for bare floors for a few moments because I didn't read the button. Whoops.

4. The easy to turn head of the vacuum makes it so easy to get around corners. Yay.

Video of it in action: [...]
summary: Love, love, love. Wish I hadn't bought a more expensive stick vacuum prior to this...

reviewText:
I have purchased a couple of these both came branded as BOMEX 1 liter flasks, and used profusely. They are an outstanding value! The glass is thick and consistent in quality. The rim is reinforced and the side arm is well constructed. I have used these under substantial heating operations, high vacuum, strong chemicals etc. The markings may not be dead on accurate, but remember that they are for estimation only. The trade off for the low price and reasonably high quality is that over time the physical size from one flask to another is significantly different. The height of the flask can vary quite a bit. All in all, these are a pleasure to work with, high quality, great value, and you don't have to be scared that you are going to crack them. More so, you should be careful not to bump other glassware with them, or you will likely break the other glassware, not this flask.

 Please see photos for reference. The flask diameter The flask with the red nipple protector, is 0.280" taller @ approximately 9.250" tall than the one with a yellow nipple protector, and has a deviation (out of round ) to the inside of the neck around 0.013". The flask with the yellow protector has less than 0.002" out of round inside the neck but contains one nearly microscopic void in the glass near the neck. The inner neck diameters range from 1.689" to 1.744" and weights range from 666g. to 672g. By comparison they are more than twice as heavy as a typical Karter brand 1L. flask weighs about 325g. The side arm outside diameter measures 0.393" at the height of the first barb, and 0.450" at the height of the fourth and final barb. The diameter of the base of the flask at the widest point is approximately 5.5" The side arms are substantially heavier than many other flasks of similar models.

I hope this helps some of you. Definitely a great investment!
summary: TOUGH! GREAT VALUE! RELIABLE! See review for dimensions and photos.

reviewText: This ZING video surveillance sign is a good size, is easily visible even in lower light conditions due to the strong contrasting colors (is not a reflective material, tho) and is made of a sturdy and lightweight metal that feels like it will last. The writing appears to be printed on in a lightly glossy paint, and seems well-made with no obvious chipping or distress. There are holes punched in each of the four corners, that will accommodate typical screws. The sign is not alarming, and is a good notification that should hopefully be obvious from a distance, w the graphic of a box-type CCTV type camera prominent, so that your property will be deemed to be too much trouble by bad guys scoping out the area. I'd recommend this sign whether or not you have actual video surveillance equipment running, but with camera set-ups being so relatively inexpensive lately, it makes sense to secure your family and property.
summary: Bold, Sturdy and Light Metal w 4 Screw Holes

reviewText:
The signs are everywhere, this is a good video surveillance notice. This is great for both its intended purpose as warning to those who might have criminal intent (on the premises of a business or private residence), or just as a gag for a man cave. Either way, it gets top marks for using a minimum of 70% recycled material. In this case it is aluminum and not plastic. Also, it is made in the USA.

If I had to nitpick, I would wish screws or bolts were included for the 4 pre-drilled holes. And while it is pretty tough, it feels like I could easily bend it in half if I applied enough pressure. The finish is good though and I expect it would last a while if posted outdoors.

~ Kort

reviewText: Mounts to a standard metal junction box (see photo), not included.  The dinky switch on a Shopsmith Power Station gave up the ghost 20+ years ago. reviewText: This paddle switch is mounted in my "breadbox" router table. The side wall of the table is 3/4" thick pine. The paddle switch is bolted to a weatherproof box on the inside of the router table, with a 3/4" box extension between them. I used some female spade connectors, crimped to 14 gauge Romex wiring, for connections. Start-up and shutdown have been flawless with this switch. I'm pleased with how easily it installed (once I had spade connectors and a crimper handy), and very pleased with how it's working. Suitable spade connectors: SOLOOP 50pcs Female & Male Fully Insulated Wire Terminals Connector Nylon Spade Connectors Blue Suitable crimper: GB GS-388 8-Inch Crimping Electrical Plier PICS: The internal view of the router table also shows a JessEm Mast-R-Lift II 02120 Router Lift, 9-1/4-Inch by 11-3/4-Inch, a Bosch 1617EVS 2-1/4 HP Variable-Speed Router, and the black back of a ParkPower 150BBIW.RV 15 Amp Power Inlet, White. reviewText:
This geiger counter is very simple to use for a lay person such as myself. The instructions are basically, 1) put the two included batteries in and 2) press the big "on" button. The detector starts automatically reading the radiation surrounding it, and will conduct four cycles of readings as it draws the four sides of a square (one side per cycle read) shown on the left side of the big number/ reading. This takes about 2 to 3 minutes, and the fully drawn square provides the most accurate reading.

I tried this in our living room for radon (and found this does not read radon), but the .10 micro Sieverts per hour reading was shown (pic). According to the included pamphlet section titled, "How much is dangerous?" a .10 reading "...is low, it does not get any lower" (see pic of that section below showing various hazard levels). I then tried this next to the tritium sights on my gun, and it also gave a negligible .12 reading.  finally, i tried it on our granite countertops, because i had read that many contractors working with granite or stone often used geiger counters to ensure they were not working with or placing dangerous slabs of granite in people's homes. Our countertop gave a .14 reading. I was happy to see that our place had low readings. i think if i was going to purchase a house in the future, i'd take this with me to check radiation levels inside and outside the property (top soils and such) before buying.

Beyond the basic reading, there is a menu with features including 1) changing from the default micro Sieverts per hour (modern units) measurement to the older micro Roentgens per hour (see backlit pic); 2) an audio threshold alarm you can set to ring at readings between .10-.90 micro Sieverts per hour (it's preset to a default ring at .30);  3) you can enable a separate background radiation function, which the Quarta manufacturing website introduces as the "new 'BACKGROUND' mode, the first such implementation into a non-professional device, [that] allows for simpler and faster inspections of premises (when it is necessary to know the difference between the indoors and outdoors background radiation values);"  4) audio and/or vibration alarm choices; and 5) service contact information for the Quarta company (see pic of Quarta-Rad, inc contact info).  There is also a backlight feature that turns on automatically for a few seconds whenever you press a button.

This is an excellent choice for home safety.

--btw, the batteries both face positive upwards. You can see the positioning drawn on the underside of the battery cover you take off, and in the instruction manual. it is not in the normal place most people look, at the bottom of the battery wells.

Update: There are watches from the mid-20th century (pre-1960s) that were made with radium dials- my husband collects many antiques. he tried this next to several of his watches, and one read in near the .84 "Alert" zone, which the manual says should be avoided. I insisted that we keep it in a far corner of our garage.... we put it in a steel box, and that reduced the reading to .16. yikes.

Update: radon gas needs a different device to measure, such as this manufacturer's SIRAD-MR-106n for $397.
summary: Great Choice for Beta, Gamma, X-Ray radiation (NOT Radon) and for General Safety- Check old Watches!

reviewText: Good assortment of 5mm LEDs.  LEDs arrived sorted into packages of 10 and each plastic bag has a colored label to indicate the color of the LED.  A full bundle of resistors (200 ohm tape strip) is included.  LEDs are bright and work fine.

reviewText: I only got this because it was listed as "frequently bought together" with the gel caps I purchased. I thought this would be really helpful in filling the caps but either end is too big for what I wanted. I thought the "spoon end" (as they call it on the product page) was a bit more rounded. It's not. Basically, I'd return this if it was worth the trouble but, seeing what I paid for it, it's less worrisome to just figure out something else to use it for. Really disappointed, though. They should show a photo of the item next to the opening of a gel cap (since they paired it in suggestions). because they didn't, I will.
summary: Spoon not really a "scoop" shape. Too big to work with :-(

Comes in resealable bag. One pound is a lot as you only use one teaspoon per gallon of Must. No problems and lots of great results.

reviewText:
If you are the sort of person whose feelings are easily hurt by things in life that make you feel like you are intellectually under-par, don't buy this product.

Just the reviews alone sound like from a parallel universe, where every adult automatically understands why electric motors work -- like brushing their teeth -- and kids and you are the only ones who do not, and must be trained.

I see the same sort of teaching is still alive and well that I had in high school -- I got straight-As in honors Geometry, Algebra 3/Trigonometry, Chemistry, Physics and Math Analysis, but I didn't understand a thing, because the teachers left out the things I needed to know first -- like we do not know why an electromagnetic field forms around an electric current -- it just does.

I'm down with that. I just needed to be informed that I was not the only one who did not know, for no one knows. It's all in a black box called "Nature." Physicists can cloak their ignorance by calling it "a fundamental force of the universe," i.e., "It's just there -- we don't know why."

Kids who can't get to first base in a subject because the opening statement is missing are told they don't have brains or "aptitude."

The instructions for this kit do some serious blathering, I presume about theory, if I could understand them. These instructions make sure to show you the formula for electromagnetic force (see graphic), they tell you that a drawing showing electromagnetism coming is really about electromagnetism going, and that a drawing of electromagnetism going is really electromagnetism coming, and that clockwise is counterclockwise, and counterclockwise is clockwise (see graphic). They show some doodles and say that one of the doodles is a magnet, but it is not labeled, and if it is there, it looks like any other doodle. Magnets can come in any shape or size. No doubt the drawing of this magnet is what an expert would recognize, but I thought this kit was for rank beginners. Draw a horseshoe, if you're not gong to label it. Then take a course in technical drawing or common sense.

So I skipped over to what looked like getting to the point. There were some ambiguous and sketchy instructions for constructing the contraption. Being a dummy, I had to look up several words.

So I ignored the beginning prose, looked up the words, then seemed to have the contraption built that the drawings in the constructions showed, which were not clear.

Then, for a final insult, the entire endeavor crashed and burned into my absolute failure with the following death sentence, the last instruction:

"6. Apply power by attaching 3 to 6 volt DC to the binding post."

No one said anything about any power. Where is it? Fews ads boast so much about including "all parts for assembly" as the ad for this product. All shoppers know the warning "Batteries not included." Wouldn't this ad have said that power is not included if it were not? Therefore, I'm still looking among the parts for this legendary power source. Furthermore, if you parse the term "electric motor," it could be understood to read that it creates power to drive an electric motor. How would beginners know that is called "a generator?" Where does it say that this whole contraption is not, in fact, the "3 to 6 volt DC" itself?

What's a binding post? The instructions won't tell you. I looked it up, and there was nothing like that on my "finished" motor.

The outfit that put me through this wringer -- and no doubt I am the only one who "just does not get it" -- is called American Educational Products.

In the immortal words of Jack Black (School of Rock), "Those who can't do, teach. Those who can't teach, teach P.E." So perhaps the point of this kit is the exercise I got putting it together.
summary: It's Not "Electric Motors for Dummies"

reviewText:
I bought these from Pep Boys because they had a 25% off sale and the "16,000 pound" models were $44 with tax. I picked them up locally. I did a lot of research on various ramps but looked at the smaller Rhino ramp reviews on Amazon, not the reviews for the larger "16,000 pound" set. The photos supplied by some Amazon customers of the Rhino ramps basically collapsing under load have me strongly considering returning them before I ever use them.

The stated "16,000 pound" load rating is very deceptive. On the bottom of each ramp, the following weight ratings are stamped:
"Do Not Exceed Rated Capacity of 4,000 pounds each, 8,000 pounds per pair or 16,000 pounds gross vehicle weight"
They are NOT rated for 16,000 pounds each or as a pair. I attached a photo of these ratings and the made in USA data but they might be hard to read.

The ramps are made in the USA and I saw some chatter about filling the ramps with poly foam to stiffen them up and stabilize them I think Rhino Ramps should be doing that, not forcing customers to do after market modifications to avoid injury. More to come when I decide whether or not to keep these particular ramps.

I'm looking at Race Ramps RR-56-2 ramps but they are a LOT more money - like $200 even with the 15% coupon. But given a choice between spending another $160 for ramps or getting maimed or killed by flimsy ramps really isn't a choice.

7/12/16 update - I took these back to Pep Boys and got a refund. They would not fit under 2 of my 3 cars because they are too steep and too short to accommodate the lower front ends. Add in the potential for the "smash factor" and I won't miss these ramps. They might be OK for a lawn tractor or an ATV but I'm not putting a 5300 pound truck on them. I ordered 66 inch all aluminum ramps.
summary: Bought the "16,000 pound" rated models but after seeing Amazon reviews of them collapsing, considering returning them unused

reviewText:
They look nice, are light weight, stack nicely, are wide and inexpensive and all that. But backing up on them with my 9740lbd truck squeezed them to death! They are NOT 16,000 lbd! reviewText:
Good glue. Didn't dry out.  But........

This large-looking bottle only contains 4 to 5 grams of actual glue.  In case you don't like math....you are paying at least $32.97/oz. for the glue that you get in this overblown packaging.

I bought a couple of these to use for assembling 3D plastic prints, and when the first one ran out rapidly, I took it apart to look at the actual packaging.  (I've attached a photo so you can see what you are actually getting before you decide.)  There's a little tube of glue in there with a big plastic squeeze device.

The epoxy shown next to it in the photo is only $9.99 for 4.5 ounces, or $2.22/oz.

So you are paying over thirty bucks for the convenience of not having to mix together the two components. You can make up your own mind if it's worth that to you. It IS good glue.....I'm just not sure it's fifteen times better than others. (And if you need more than a few drops, better plan on buying a dozen bottles.)
summary: Be Aware of What you are Buying

reviewText:
This is not for beer wort as advertised. It's for salinity, not Brix. I would like to return it, but just realized recently why my OG levels were all off the scale. If you got one that came with Brix, consider yourself lucky.

I'm not sure why, but the refractometer that was sent to me does not have SG Wort, nor % Brix. Mine measures Salinity, and shows what looks like a specific gravity of 1.000-1.070 something that shows a measured scale of 0-100 that I don't know what has any correlation to beer wort. This is not what I ordered, and now I'm trying to return it. Be careful, if you get one for salinity, wort measurements will be of the scale.
summary: Not a beer wort refractometer.

reviewText:
I bought this after having seen one used at a local "brew your own beer" shop where they walk you through brewing a 15-gallon batch on their professional-grade equipment.  I liked the fact that this device is easy to read and only needs a drop or two of wort to get a reading, unlike a hydrometer that requires several ounces of wort to get a reading.  A hydrometer will lead to you wasting several ounces of beer on each reading, which can add up in a small batch.

What no one told me, and I wish they had, is that this device starts to be come very inaccurate once there is alcohol in the solution.  So while it's great for measuring the original gravity of your wort, it is not useful once the fermentation process begins.  In order to use it beyond the initial boil, you need to gather readings with both a hydrometer AND the refractometer. Then you can calculate an adjustment factor that will allow you to use the refractometer from that point on.  I'm told that the exact adjustment factor varies with the specific refractometer, so you need to calculate your own.  If I gave you mine here, yours could be very different.

So if you buy this device and you don't have a hydrometer and test jar, do yourself a favor and order those too.  Then do an Internet search for relevant brewing articles to see how to calculate and use an adjustment specific to your device.

That may sound like a lot of extra hassle.  If you don't mind tossing out those hydrometer samples (or you are OK drinking the flat beer) then you don't need this device.  If, like me, you like the convenience of an easy-to-read device and the benefit of being able to get gravity readings with very small samples, get yourself a hydrometer, test jar, and this device.  Work out your adjustment factor, and you can put away the hydrometer from that point on... and only need very small samples.

When you look at the photos I've posted, bear in mind that the photo of the gauge was taken by holding a cell phone camera up to the opening and trying to get the device, camera, and light source all in alignment (which is a LOT harder than it sounds).  But the beer in question reads roughly 1.075 on the SG scale and 19 on Brix.  All I needed to get that reading was a tiny drop of wort from the tap on my fermenting bucket.

I'm also showing photos of extracting the tiny wort sample, using a pipette (included with the device) to get a couple of drops, the drops of liquid on the prism, and the case it came in.
summary: A nice device for measuring wort gravity, but be aware of some things

reviewText: If you like to keep your knives in good working order and clean them often, a drop of purple low strength loctite will do the job.  This way you'll still be able to unscrew them again in the future but they won't come loose on just day to day use.

reviewText:
great digital thermometer. was looking at other thermometers that 'seemed' to be better but decided to go with this one specifically because of the cord length. Its pretty darn accurate if I do say so myself.
even comes with certificates of testing and accuracy. I am currently using this to develop both color and black and white film. As you may know color film requires pretty precise temp. values and this works perfectly.
if your looking for some with great accuracy, solid build and pretty much infinite battery life your looking in the right place

reviewText:
I used this module to replace a mechanical relay module from Sainsmart for my Xmas light display outside. The mechanical relays didn't last long last year. So far this year the solid state relays are giving me no troubles. One thing to note however, mechanical relays can typically handle 10 Amps each. These solid state relays can only handle up to 2 Amps each ... enough power for approximately 100 LED lights on each relay, or 800 total lights per relay module. More than enough to dazzle (or cheese-off) the neighbors! No complaints about this board.

Update: Well, it's a few days past Xmas and not a single problem from any of the SSRs. I love that I can program the outlets to turn on and off at less than 25ms (the limit I found for mechanical relays). This allows twinkling effects that I couldn't do with mechanical relays. I'm purchasing another one for a 16 channel setup and adding a San Devices e682 to the mix for RGB LED control as well (my neighbors will REALLY love me next year). I use an Arduino Uno to control the relays however any microntroller with at least 8 digital outputs will work well with this relay board.

Update #2: I've redesigned my board to use two of these SSR boards for 16 outputs with an Arduino Uno. Works fantastic!
summary: I used this module to replace a mechanical relay module ...

reviewText: simple and effective! been using it for table saw blade angles, alignment, structural work - everything! great too!

reviewText:
Wow, who knew what a difference you could get just by changing your endmill. I had always used supplied by The Other Machine Co with my OtherMill and had just assumed that deburring the board with steel wool after cutting was a necessary step. Even though this bit was expensive compared to others, I ordered it from Amazon simply because it would come fastest.

I chocked it into the machine and cut my first board and I was surprised to find NO BURRS. The copper edges are perfect. This photo is showing the board still in the machine, immediately after cutting. It is clean and Ready to be used without any deburring at all.

I am going to use these bits for now on. The extra cost is well worth it for the superior results.
summary: Perfect for milling FR1 PCBs.

reviewText: As many other reviewers have shared, the actual product I received has no hex head, nor does it come with a washer. As such, if you don't need this part Amazon-prime fast, then you'd do well to pick up nearly the same thing at your local hardware store for less than a third of this price...with a washer. I do have to say that the diamond, knurled pattern that comes on this part is a little easier to grasp than the standard straight-line pattern that you'll likely find on your local-store part, and it's a little beefier to boot. I'm not sure it's worth another $5+, however. I added a photo of the part I received since the one shown here is so misleading.

It's glass which I like, but obviously the downfall is it is breakable. Ours seems to have fairly thick glass so I'm hoping it will last.

reviewText:
I primarily use this cylinder in home brewing contexts. It is perfect for measuring the initial SpGr of a solution when the sugar content is high (before brewing). When the sugar content is too low (anything below around 1.030), the cylinder is not quite tall enough to sink the hydrometer, so you'll need a taller test column. It's also good for measuring additives and nutrients.

Although the graduations are not as precise as a more expensive lab-grade or even general-grade cylinder, this column does a great job for measuring anything with relative precision of 1 mL.
summary: Good cylinder: Not tall enough for hydrometer testing.

reviewText:
Actually got this in a package with my Incra TS-LS positioner. Let me just say when used correctly, precise results are easily achieved!!

Although only used on a few simple projects (creating zero clearance plates, running dados, and creating half lap joints) this gauge takes the guess work out of precision, increases efficiency and cuts down on test cuts.

As an example; created a simple half lap joint on two 2x4s. First I took a measurement of the thickness with both my digital calipers and this little gem, then divided that result by 2, then took that result and dialed my table saw blade height  to it - VOILA, instant and perfect half lap joint:-)

For my zero clearance plate - I had some left over composite 2x6 material. Once again, took the thickness measurement of my OEM table saw plate, then took the measurement of the material I was creating the duplicate/zero clearance plate from, subtracted one from the other and that total became the setting of my dado stack height. Once dialed in, I shaved down the composite material and once again a perfect measurement which netted me an exact height match!!:-)

One thing I do wish, that the legs could open wider/have adjustability to accommodate more use, but, just the way it is, I find it to be very useful:-) The magnets also could stand to be a bit stronger, but not a deal breaker - I've actually got some strong rare earth magnets in my misc drawer that I believe are about the same size. I'll see if I can switch'em out.

I can see myself getting a lot of use out of this Wixey gauge; It's very functional, easy to use, takes up minimal storage space and is another GREAT tool in my arsenal of precision capable accessories:-)
summary: Another great accessory in the search for PRECISION results

reviewText:
I'm using it in my no-dry-ice TEC Peltier electronically cooled "Nuclear Cloud Chamber".

This is creating a seal between the cold plate (which is sitting on top of two Peltier cooler tiles) and a big old wine goblet. All of that sits on top of an Cooler Master 212X dual fan computer CPU cooler. Most of the aforementioned pieces are coupled with thermal paste. Power will come from an ATX computer powersupply I made into a bench top power unit. All of this is going on my 'Science & Optics' blogger...for no real reason other than I have more fun doing this than shoveling snow or mowing the lawn.

The wine goblet is filled with 99% isopropyl (rubbing) alcohol which gets supercooled and turns into a fog in the the glass goblet. Then you can see alpha, beta, gamma and muon tracks zipping through the fog: visible radiation! I have various radioactive sample sources, plus if you put no radioactive stuff in the chamber every 3 or 3 minutes you'll see a particle zing through and that'll be the result of a cosmic ray interaction: a muon!

My other nuclear cloud chamber is MUCH simpler: an upside down aquarium resting on a metal plate that sits on top of a block of dry ice. I want to eventually bring this into work (I'm a librarian) and while the radioactive stuff is safe (unless you swallow it) the dry ice is just annoying to deal with after the awesomeness of it gets old: it's cold, melts (well, sublimates), will explode any container it gets sealed it, burns, little kids want to touch it...all not so great for a science demonstration. Plus the only place that sells it is the Walmart that's like 15 minute drive. With this design I just plug it into a wall outlet and dump in a little rubbing alcohol: bam! Coldness.

Anyway, this rubber was REAL rubber. Good feel and that new car tire smell. I was able to easily cut it with a pair of scissors.

The sheet was really "floppy" and could conform to curves if needed. You could easily roll this up and line the inside of a coffee mug or something. Not sure why you'd want to do that, but it'd take zero effort: nice and bendy.

The only bad thing was that at the center of one edge was a retail hanger tag, the kind with the hole in it to hang off of metal rods in a store. It was STAPLED to the rubber sheet. Just a regular old small staple, and for my purposes it made no difference. Even if I were pulling a strong vacuum (which I'm not) the two staple holes would probably seal themselves up, plus they're at the extreme edge so it wouldn't matter anyway.

Well, that's about all the comments I can muster on a boring old piece of rubber, lol.

Michael Logusz
summary: Nuclear Cloud Chamber

reviewText:
This is a good well made hinge. I've used them before. There is one problem though. It came pretty bent up. Small fairly sharp bends in the middle of the hinge. I managed to pound it flat for use but I wish it was flatter. The strange thing is that the bent part is the result of too good packaging. The long cardboard box has no creases or holes in it. So it wasn't bend during shipment. But the hinge was multiple wrapped in bubble wrapped with tons of packaging tape. It looks like it was pulled and bent to get the bubble wrap as thick and tight as it could be before encasing it in wide tape in an effort to make it one solid bubblewrap unit so it wouldn't bend during shipment. Thing is, it caused damage while wrapping it. The two photos show the hinge after doing my best to straighten it out and the unbent box and a portion of the bubblewrap.

I'd describe packaging in the 'comment on packaging' area but this item is not listed there....
summary: Good hinge, Bad packaging

reviewText: These 3M fasteners are amazing. They are made for indoor use, so I put a strip on the back of a frame and then placed the frame on the side of a 7 drawer storage container. It works beautifully. When I enclosed my carport I realized  that I could not hang pictures on the brick walls. The 3M Fasteners worked on the brick like a charm. The adhesive makes it stick to almost anything. I would not recommend using these on painted walls. The hook/loop system works just like the Velcro strips. I highly recommend the 3M fasteners for your home projects, especially when you need to hang something.
summary: Amazing fasteners

reviewText:
The longest part of putting this up, is finding the right spot, and ceiling studs.
Also, I highly recommend enforcing the back of the ladder holder, to keep it from bouncing from front to back when under load. (See pics.)
summary: Work very well! Read my desciption please.

reviewText:
I need an adhesive to attach my new 3d printing bed and found this pack of 6 sheets of adhesive. The adhesive came in a padded envelope. The product itself was shrink wrapped between a sandwich of two cardboard cut out. None of the adhesive sheets were damaged during the shipping process such as foldes. This is great since my application need to the adhesive to be flat and not curled from being wrapped in a tube shape.

I had an easy time removing the adhesive from the backing sheet but had problems applying the thin adhesive layer to the build plate without getting pockets of air trapped. What I ended up doing was getting a needle and puncturing the large air pockets. The next time I need to apply this adhesive to something I will try the soap water technique that is used for applying car window tinting. When I get around to trying this I will probably write an updated review.

The adhesive seem to be very sturdy and strong as it is very hard to remove it from objects. This is good for my application because I cant have my build plate moving or warping during one of my 3d prints. Update from a couple of months of usage on my printer. With all the heat and stress of the warping abs that was done to the adhesive it seems to be holding up strong without any problems. I can safely say that it is a very strong adhesive that seems to be of very high quality. I will be changing my build plate with a new material soon and hope that it will be easy enough to remove it from the metal base plate. Update I found that using isopropyl alcohol helped me to remove the adhesive from my build plate but your experience will probably differ from my one.

Overall a fantastic adhesive that can be trusted through heating processes. I would recommend those who are looking for a double sided adhesive pad to buy this one. Especially if you want to use it for a similar usage as me for your 3d printer. This adhesive is very handy to have around the house because you never know when you would need it and when you do it will be hard to find something like this a places such as Walmart.
summary: Awesome Adhesive!!

reviewText: No bonding of product to center core = complete mess upon opening over-pack. Larger sizes may be fine, but anything of smaller size is a roll of the dice.
summary: Larger sizes may be fine, but anything of smaller size is a roll ...

reviewText: The tape performs as advertised. I wrapped a few strips around my black steel basketball pole in the driveway. The pole is hard to see when backing out of the garage at night which resulted in a few dings in the car bumper. With the tape at rear window height, I can now clearly see the pole with the reverse light reflecting off the tape. Much cheaper than the body repair shop. Be sure to clean the area well before applying the tape. It also helps to install when temperatures are 60 degrees or above as the glue is more effective. After a month of sun, freezing cold and lots of rain, the tape shows no signs of letting go. Once you find an application, you'll begin looking around the house for other places to use it and it could get out of control.
summary: Sticks well and highly reflective

reviewText:
This tape worked perfectly for my needs.
It is extremely strong and doesn't fade at all - it stays reflective and the stickiness hasn't decreased over time and through a harsh summer.
I did cover the ends with electrical tape just to be sure it would stay still because the tape is actually very rigid, and the ends are sharp and can stick out from whatever they're on.
The rigidity of the tape would make this not suitable for certain tasks... it can't be pulled or stretched and manipulated in any way. It also must be applied on a flat solid firm surface... it is too rigid to stick on fabric for example.
The tape itself is high quality and I'm happy with what I've used it for.
summary: Very strong for outdoor use

reviewText:
I use it around the house and in the garage for various DIY projects. In additional to DIY projects, I keep it in the kitchen when I'm cooking as I like to know the temperature of my skillet before I start cooking.

Another added benefit is having one in my fishroom as well to spot check the tanks.

The reason this doesn't get 5 stars? It's not as accurate as I'd like it to be. It'll give you a pretty close "ballpark" figure, but if you need something to be precise, you better get a thermometer that requires "contact".
summary: Five Stars

reviewText: I think this gun is a steal. It feels sturdy. I might pay more for one with bells and whistles if I needed it for work but this one is great for home use. I use it for crafts that require specific temps, not extreem temps. As you can see in the pics, its accurate within 1-2 degrees and I cant see myself needing to temp check anything over 716f or under -56f. Pull the trigger and it comes on within 1 second and starts reading right away. Let go and it turns itself off within 15 seconds.  Its easy to read, the blue backlight can be turned off, and the laser can be turned off too. The 12:1 ratio means that it reads a 1 inch area from 12 inches away. Theres no downside to this gun unless you need to read some extreem temps, but if thats the case you probably shouldnt be looking in this awesomely low price range.
summary: Has a sturdy feel, works well.

reviewText: Ac vents, engine blocks, summer asphalt, cookies and more. This thermometer is great for fast, accurate readings. I used it to locate an Ac problem in my home blowing warmer than usual and it worked flawlessly. It has a wide variety of uses and is a must for any tool box or kitchen drawer.
summary: Scan everything!

reviewText:
Likes:

 Pretty accurate within a degree or two
 Simple way to satisfy your curiosity of how hot something might be
 Excellent price point (even comes with the battery!)
 Great build quality, seems like itll last a long time

Suggestions:

 make sure you read the directions to get an accurate temp reading, obviously distance makes a huge difference
Overall:

This is one of those purchases that I made because I was interested in measuring couple different items around the house. The first thing I want to know was how hot the air was blowing out of my vents, then I moved on to my water temperature, and also trying to get a gauge of the temperature around my windows and sliding doors. Actually, I couldn't believe some of the cold spots in my home. This gave me an idea of where to insulate for the winter to ensure my heat was most efficient. I can imagine countless things you could do with this unit I think itll also be useful to measure temperatures for cooking purposes, hot water for a bath, manifold temp on a boat or car etc. Everything worked hundred percent from the time I open the box and popped the included battery in. So I would definitely recommend this and give it five stars. I hope this helps you make your decision.
summary: Great for finding "hot" or "cold" spots in your home

reviewText:
Has a nice, professional feel to it, first of all. The rubberized grip was very comfortable. Upon receiving it, I immediately checked my skin/circulation, cracks I suspected allow drafts in the house (such as door frames), and my PC hardware with great accuracy. My original purpose for buying this was to ensure custom cooling for my motherboard's VRM and Northbridge heatsinks were accurate on programs like HWInfo64. They were perfect, and only varied by a degree in a couple instances. But when taking into account the position of the sensors, it really performed quite accurately so far.

Granted this is the first day owning it, I feel it is a well made product and it should perform as they indicate it will for some time to come. I will update if any problems arise. Otherwise, it has been good for me.

 I would surely buy another (of this brand) if I required another or was giving a referral.
summary: Works great so far

I'll begin this review by saying,  Just a normal dad buying stuff online and writing honest reviews.

reviewText:
Ok, so it's the only sign I've ever bought, except for the http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000VY0HGM?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00 plastic sign I purchased at the same time. This is an exceptional sign - the perfect size, nice and clear black lettering on a white background, and there is a coating over the sign that makes the sign seem protected and waterproof. The printing is not reflective, but it is easy to read. (I'm not sure if the white background is reflective or not. If that's important to you, leave a comment and I will go outside and check.) The sign appears to be made like the signs on the side of the road, the quality is that high. I placed this on the fence on the back of my townhouse and it fits perfectly. I like how easy it is to see from the street, but how it isn't like this honkin' eyesore.

Bottom Line: Nice metal sign that is easy to read from a distance. Two holes provide space for nails. The metal is sturdy - it will not easily bend. I would absolutely purchase this again. I'm super happy with this whole transaction...well, as happy as you can be about buying a sign.

reviewText: I BIAB and used these in my control box for power distribution. They are plenty heavy duty enough for my needs (120VAC, 20 Amp.) I used 20 Amp jumpers Blue Sea Systems Terminal Block Jumper for 20A Terminal Blocks instead of pigtails. The jumpers are made for a different brand of block, so don't fit exactly, but it was a simple fix to clip the end and make them spade connectors. I also like they come with clear plastic covers to protect the connections from accidental contact.
summary: Really makes control project wiring neat and organized.

reviewText:
I absolutely love this all-in-one flosser and toothbrush.  It replaces two other brands we had been using, and the differences are amazing.  I like that Waterpik Orthocare comes with two different sized toothbrush heads (compact/standard)each are sizes my husband and I use, so both of us could use the unit right out of the box.  I thought my old Philips Sonicare did a good job, but the higher speed on this one is much more effective, and makes my teeth feel like they were professionally cleaned.  The toothbrush has a two minute timer, and also pauses every 30 seconds as a reminder to move on to a different section of teeth.  Replacement toothbrush heads can be bought at Waterpiks website.  A set of three costs about $20.

The water flosser is just as impressive.  The brand we used to use was very sporadicsometimes water flow was even, other times it was spotty.  This Waterpik model works correctly every single time and at every single pressure setting (there are ten speeds).  The provided tips cover every dental needorthodontic, periodontal and general use.  I used a Waterpik when I was fifteen years old and had bracesthat first model did a good job then.  Now Im 63 and our dentist recommends Waterpik for good gum hygienethis updated model does an excellent job keeping my entire mouth healthy and clean.  Replacement tips can be bought at the companys website as well.  A set of two costs about $9.

We have limited counter space in our bathroom, so I especially like the units compact size (about 8 tall/wide) and the ability to push any excess electrical cord inside the units bottom (see photo).  Both the tip/head storage case and water reservoir are removable from the base.  Im not sure why I ever strayed from that first Waterpik my parents bought me over 40 years ago, but am so glad to see the company still makes reliable oral health care products.  This unit is comprehensive, easy to use and compact.
summary: Compact And Comprehensive

reviewText:
The ones I ordered from Eclectic supply came in individual boxes to prevent breakage, which were then packed in another box.  The ends of the droppers are tapered.

I am using them for adding flavored extracts to coffee (cheaper and I can add as much as I like).  Extracts come in 2oz bottles which fit perfectly into these.

I have attached a photo for size.

reviewText:
Good quality meter, solid sturdy construction.  I'm not a professional electrician or HVAC tech, but I wanted a good quality meter that had, in one unit, the typical measurements that I'm in need of: voltage, current, resistance/continuity, capacitance, and temperature.  Previously I had a box of various and assorted meters, none of which had all that I wanted, but in combination did.  All were of standard (read: dubious) quality, and never quite seemed to agree in scale.  I junked them all and went w/ the 324.

It has performed to and exceeded my expectations.  The quality and construction seems substantial for contractor/tech work, but I can't comment on field durability, this will be a 'garage queen' for my occasional use.  The price point is high for my general needs, but I feel that I'd probably spent more than that on the bevy of meters that I discarded, not to mention the implicit costs associated with poorly calibrated devices and not having any sense of confidence.  I'm happy with my decision, and very pleased with my purchase.

I've attached some additional pictures of the product (taken from the Fluke site) -- these should be included in the main product pictures above, but aren't for some reason.  Product includes: meter, case, manual, probes (red & black with pointed tips and caps), thermocouple.  Manual available for download at: http://media.fluke.com/documents/32x_____umeng0000.pdf

Disclosure: I work for a subsidiary company of Danaher, of which Fluke is also a subsidiary.  Other than that tenuous relationship, I have no relationship with Fluke products, company, or personnel.  I was not compensated nor asked by Fluke, Danaher, or any other person or company to provide this review.

PS: Have a nice day.
summary: Good quality meter

reviewText:
This thing is pretty cool, especially for the price.  Sure, it has some slop, but for very basic milling tasks on a drill press, it gets the job done.

Not a bad idea to clean the goop off of it, and re-oil before use.

Don't expect to use this for precision milling work, especially not the kind of things to manufacture firearms or other items with very tight tolerances.  But hey, at the price point, one shouldn't expect consistent accuracy to over a thousandths of an inch.

But, for basic "down and dirty" milling work on a drill press, it does the job quite nicely.
summary: Don't expect super precision, but for basic milling tasks, it will get the job done.

reviewText:
works great!  like any vise you buy.  you have to take it apart and clean it but other then that it's great!  mines set up on my drill press and will accommodate just about any job i throw at it.  wilton makes the best vises!  I used this vice to mill aluminum and it worked great.

Take it all apart when you get it and clean it really good then lubricate everything and set it all up how you want.  I included some pictures of mine after a few years of use.

reviewText: I received the tape today and I immediately noticed it was way too thin to be 2.7mils so I measured it with a high precision micrometer and it's 1.1 mils. Even the original product description on the 3M site says 1.4mils (Attached screenshots). The thickness is NOT 2.7mil as stated so it's false advertising. I even paid same day delivery because I needed it badly. I'm so disappointed.

reviewText:
WOW!  Was not expecting this inexpensive filament to be the best I've used so far.
Suwit FM 02 (setup from factory for 1.75mm instead of 3mm), 230 nozzle and 100 tape covered bed printing at 40mm.
NO blobs, stringy hair, or warping yet!
I do wish it had a plastic spool though.

EDIT 01-24-2015:  I cannot get over just how great this filament prints.  Most others I've tried have taken try after try to get them just to print decently and some I never did find their, 'sweet spot' and simply gave up on them.

EDIT 05-28-2015:  Roll after roll, this continues to be the only black I use.
I finally got around to making a cheap and simple PVC pipe holder to rid me of the cardboard spool blues.

EDIT 03-17-2016:  Still using ONLY this black ABS!  Sure the cardboard spool is a weak point, but as long as it keeps printing great for each and every job, I'm sticking with it!

If you have not already, give Sainsmart a try!
summary: Happy!

reviewText: So far, I have no problems with it. I'll even say it's better than the Makerbot's one. I have had far less mishaps with this filament. Also did a print where the 1st layer was ninjaflex and the rest was SainSmart PLA. Came out perfect as well.
summary: It's pretty consistent. Color's pretty white too.

reviewText:
This was the first full spool of filament I've used when I bought my first 3d printer (Printrbot Simple Metal) earlier this year.  After trial and error I had it printing very nicely.  When the spool ran out I decided to try a different no-name brand and boy was that a mistake; I had nothing but problems with it and couldn't wait to run out of it (too cheap to just toss it).  For my third spool I came back to this exact brand and color, and couldn't be happier.  I have since upgrade my Printrbot to the official heated bed with kapton tape and the parts have been sticking TOO well!

The only minor issue I have with this filament is the spider-webiness of some areas when the hot end has to travel back and forth a lot.  This is extremely minor though, as the "webs" just brush off fairly easily.

I am sure I will continue to use this filament brand well into the future.

For anyone interested, I have good results with my Printrbot Simple Metal w/ heated bed with the following settings: Layer Height: 0.2mm, First Layer Height = 0.25mm, Vertical Perimeters = 2, Horizontal Top Shell = 4, Horizontal Bottom Shell = 3, Filament Diameter = 1.73mm, Extrusion Multiplier = 0.9, Extruder Temp = 200c, Bed Temp = 65c, Cooling = 100% after the first layer, First Layer Width = 110%, Top Solid Infill Width = 0.2mm, Retraction Length = 2mm, Lift Z = .35mm, Min Travel After Retraction = 2mm.

Update:
  The inner diameter of the spool (where the filament is coiled) is quite a bit smaller than I would like.  This causes the last 15% or so of filament to have a fairly tight constant curve that can make printing more difficult.  It was also surprisingly brittle at that point; I would come back to a print and find the filament had snapped, once in two different places (right above the extruder and right after the spool).  Despite that I'll still leave this at 5 stars, though I'm thinking it's more like 4.5 until they at least increase the inner spool diameter.
summary: After trial and error I had it printing very nicely. When the spool ran out I decided to ...

reviewText: Very well made and strong design. Size description is exact. Delivered promptly.
