reviewText: Great cheap pair! I like to have these everywhere i have a saw so i never have to look for them! This was a cheap solution and glad i did it! I guess a cheaper solution would be to buy one pair and keep your stuff organized, but i tend to fail at that!
summary: Great cheap pair

reviewText:
I posted a picture in the customer images section showing the light against skin from this otoscope compared to my LED flashlight.  The light from the otoscope has a blue tint and the colors appear flatter (lower apparent CRI - Color Rendition Index) compared to the LED flashlight.  With the flashlight, the skin looks normal and with the otoscope it looks cold and pale.  The LED bulbs with the higher CRI are newer and more expensive, so the manufacturer has slightly older LED bulb technology in this otoscope.  This is significant because it is harder to make out subtle signs of conditions if the colors are not as vibrant.

Other reviewers noticed the same blue LED tint, for example the previous review here from Kenneth S. Raper, MD where he writes "Also the LED is blue-ish instead of white. Very much like the first generation of 'white' LED string Christmas lights that had a blue tint. This makes eardrums and mucous membranes look odd. It makes it difficult to tell how red a throat is, or if an eardrum is a little red or not. Normal pink mucosa (in a blue-ish light) has a slight purple-ish hue. This is really the only disappointment with the product, but it is significant. I expected a white light."

I wanted to like this product because the price is good, but I'm returning this for a different brand with a halogen bulb for more accurate color.

The product package says "Designed in Texas and manufactured exclusively for Innovative Innovations Inc. in China."

Update: after I posted this review, the manufacturer posted messages trying to attack me on a personal level simply because I didn't like the blue LED.  Then I went through other 1, 2, star reviews and found the same rude behavior from the manufacturer in the follow-up comments to legitimate reviews from doctors and nurses.  A quick web search reveals that this company has highly aggressive marketing tactics for low quality Chinese medical knockoffs, with an F rating from the Better Business Bureau.

Some useful information on the Amazon Customer Discussion forums:

- "Always read the negative reviews. Many fraudsters will post hundreds of positive reviews, but the truth can be hidden in that one genuine negative review thread."

- "Always check the time frame of the reviews. Were the majority of positive reviews written over the course of a very short period of time? This is a red flag."

- "Compare the number of reviews with similar, well-known products. If, for example, an unknown company is selling vitamins with more reviews than Centrum or One-a-Day, this is certainly a red flag."
summary: Light is too blue, with flat color rendition

reviewText:
I own several Fluke meters--current and older styles.  I am happy with the measuring quality and trust the internal components when in category 3 and 4 environments.  The dial, clamp and clamping lever are made really well and function smoothly.  Nice in that regards.

However, I'm not too happy with the design alteration compared to some of the earlier 322 models, when it comes to the lead connection ports.  The older models had their port locations on the face of the meter whereas this newer 323 has the lead ports on the bottom.  This is problematic for a few reasons:

One, when meter is sat down there is undue stress imposed upon the meter's ports by the lead plug ends.  Doesn't seem like too much of an issue until something is nudged on top of within work enviroment or one accidentally places palm of hand on top of meter....then the extra little bit of weight will inherently damage those ports and plug ends in quick order.

For meter to sit flat, the test leads have to leave the ports to right and left side...Its just an odd arrangement and not very user friendly in that regards when working in tight electrical environments.

Two, you can't wrap the test leads around the meter as with the 322 version and place back into it's carrying bag or either sat on top of your work cart, electrician tool bag or whatever, because they are just splayed out there into the netherlands with this bottom exit arrangement.  This particular facet really wasn't thought out too well.

Other than that issue--the meter is well made.

See pictures for clarity.
summary: Not happy with lead connect port location

reviewText:
These beakers are functional and pretty good quality. They do what I need them to do and that's be heat resistant containers. My beakers take a serious beating getting bathed in 160-200oF water 3-4 times a week. Sometimes they even get microwaved for short periods of time. I've been using this brand of beakers since last year and like them. Just don't drop them and you'll be set. I've gone through at least 1-2 sets of these beakers plus a few individuals. They don't handle rough play very well. The beakers handled the trip from the Amazon warehouse to me very well. They however did not handle my 2 moves, braking suddenly with them in my car (happened 2 days ago), or being dropped very well. They clean extremely well and stay crystal clear. When it comes to heat, these beakers will have your back all day long. When it comes to physical shock, be prepared to buy new beakers. I don't use the measurements on the front as I have instruments that I use for measuring so I can't comment on their accuracy.

All in all these are a great beakers and work for my purpose. I would recommend these for the hobbyist or the scientist.
summary: They Will Have Your Back!

reviewText:
First day's use so I will come back and update if need be but... After reading all of the 1k+ reviews for this (it's the same as the model 6565A that is just another color) and going through all the answered questions, I'm pretty happy that I made this choice. Another reviewer called this "a beast" because of how well it cleans and they are so right!
PROS: 1 - This is not a quiet machine but it is not as loud as I expected from a couple of other reviews. My cheap little Dirt Devil is just as loud and doesn't pick up anything but surface debris. The suction is amazing. You only have to choose the correct floor height setting. My carpet was dingy from spot cleaning, then using a low power vacuum. After a year's worth of hidden dirt, this vac really dug down and grabbed all kinds of dander-like debris. I'm sure this will be good for my breathing. You can see in the photo what I picked up with the Bissell after already having gone over the carpet 3 times with the Dirt Devil. Basically, my carpets have never been vacuumed!
2- It's not as heavy as some reviewers mention. Even on the lowest floor height setting, I had no problems using this (and I have back problems and low strength).
3- The cord is long enough that I don't' have to unplug when moving around my small apartment.
4 - There was no "spit-back" of debris like with some vacs.
5 - That dust canister is awesome! So easy to take off, dump, then reattach. That was a relief because emptying the dirt is my least favorite part of vacuuming.
6 - This wasn't too hard to put together. (You can see the attached photo for what it looked like out of the box and unassembled.) I timed myself and finished in just under 20 minutes. The only problem I had was that my eyes are not great and I took a lot of time re-reading the steps in the instructions. HINT: turn your vacuum around so that it matches the diagram in the instructions!
7- This maneuvers well enough for an upright. I did have to be careful to use both hands to stretch the hose when using attachments so I didn't yank the vacuum over.
8 - This fits in my entryway closet very easily (SEE PIC). When you live in a small apartment, storage is at a premium. I like that this stores where I can just roll it out to use it and put it back out of the way.

CONS: 1- The power button is in an odd spot. Like I said, I have back problems and I had to bend to reach the button. I understand why it's placed there though because of how the hose and the release take up the spaces at the bottom.
2- The hose could be a tad bit longer. It's long enough when the vac is not running, but the suction compresses it and I needed to use both hands to pull it to full length.

I really love this on Day 1. As someone else reviewed that if this lasts a year, I will be more than happy.  One tip I want to pass along is that the Bare Floor setting is also okay for very low carpets. It says that in the manual, but I somehow missed it. I picked up a lot more dirt when I lowered the head.

I included some Before and After photos of the carpet so you could get an idea of how well the vac cleaned it. I took one of them last night and one today so they might not line up properly, but there is a HUGE difference.

By the way, I went for the Teal color but, to tell the truth, I don't really pay that much attention to it now that I have it. This is the best vacuum I have ever used and my brother has one of the famous high-end ones that I can't even afford to borrow lest I break it! This one works just as good - although it's a bit louder.
summary: Excellent! (Same model as 6565A just in a different color)

reviewText:
I love it and would buy it again. This was my first Amazon deal purchase like new grade I believe. The box was a mess, but it was brand new and never used. Great way to save money!

PROS: Great suction! It is a change for me because my old vacuum didn't stick to the hardwood like this one. It also has an easy to use barefloor/carpet switch on the floor thingy. It's very light. Bag change looks easy. I like the big off button on the top. It moves around nice or can be easily carried. Comes with extra bags which is nice plus one was already in it.

CONS: The handle you hold is an odd shape/thickness, the cord retractor will probably break eventually, comes with two tools and only one tool can store on it (as far as I can tell) and it usually falls off at some point so just put the tools in a drawer somewhere.

Overall very pleased for the price paid and a great deal! I customized my on/off and cord retract buttons with a Sharpie paint pen. (See pic.)

reviewText: We have two girls and being a bit of a neat freak, I run the vacuum daily. I was using a Dyson that seemed fine but I noticed it was not picking up quite as well as it had. It was time for a new vacuum but the Dyson had not bowled me over so I decided to buy a cheaper model and perhaps replace it more often. M. Browns review convinced me to give this vacuum a try. I was shocked at how much this picked up from my clean floors. I have attached the picture of what came up from just our 20 x 15 living room. My neat freak, germophobe self nearly fell over! This is definitely THE vacuum to buy! Thank you M. Brown!
summary: Never going back to Dyson!

reviewText:
When you buy a vacuum at this price point, you have to remember...it's at this price point for a reason.

The Bissell Cleanview Bagless Upright Vacuum arrived and I had it up and running it about five minutes. Assembly was simple, you screw on the handle. You attach the hose. You plug it in. It comes with a couple accessory pieces, nothing too fancy, typical vacuum hose attachments. Upon first use I will say I WAS impressed with the suction and amount of pet hair it got off my bedroom rug. Mind you, I vacuum in there every 3-4 days. I have to. This pulled up as much pet hair and other junk as my Dyson and Electrolux canister vacuums both do.

That said, as I am used to a Dyson {the twisty flexible ballerina of a vacuum who dances around corners with the twist of my wrist} and my Electrolux canister vacuum {which I can maneuver under my short modern couch with incredible ease as it has the profile of a plank when I get down low}--this Bissell was a CHUNK of CLUNK to move around.

I'll explain: It doesn't maneuver well. It doesn't go under things well. It doesn't play nice with furniture. It is not easy to push around, turn, and be in the same room with. A lot of more affordable vacuums are like this, however, and it is to be expected. You get what you pay for. My Dyson and Electrolux cost several times what this vacuum does. So as far as suction and pick-up, this vacuum was just as good, it just didn't get in all the nooks, crannies, and corners like my less affordable vacuums can. I tried going under my (high IKEA) bed and no...it wouldn't go under it, it just started tipping back and the front part lifted, which basically renders it useless as a vacuum when the front suction end starts lifting off the floor once you start to dip the handle.

So I think, at this price point, this is a great vacuum for someone who:

1) Is in the market for an affordable vacuum.
2) Doesn't need a lot of intense, deep vacuuming.
3) Doesn't have a large home, stairs, or tons of pets and furniture to get under and around.

If you're a younger person, setting up home and need a basic vacuum for a basic flat or space, then this will do just fine. It picks up well. It doesn't maneuver well. The price is great. I like the teal color and the clear canister, which is easy to open and empty, and oh-so-pleasant to see how much dirt and dander collects in there. That's always my favorite part.

I can't necessarily recommend this vacuum to everyone, you'll have to decide for yourself if it will suit your needs based on what I've shared.
summary: Will this work for your space and vacuuming needs? Let's see...

reviewText:
So glad our 20 year old Hoover broke. Had no idea how bad it really was. Check out the pics. The amount of crud that came out of our family room is insane.

Wish the extension wand was longer. Way too short. Plus its a major pain winding he cord with the wand stored where it is.
summary: This thing sucks!

reviewText:
There is no item that can do everything. I have a battery-operated stick vac which is super portable, lightweight, and easy to use. However, the suction is not great, and after vacuuming I often have the feeling that I'm not really sucking up all the dust and dirt. Additionally, rechargeable batteries crap out over time and now it holds a much shorter charge. I decided it was time to get a new vacuum; I wanted something that would have excellent suctioning power. After realizing I was not going to find the same performance in a cordless battery-operated vaccuum as in a corded vacuum, I decided to sacrifice the ease of use for better performance. I think this is an excellent vacuum with several pros and some cons:

PROS:
-has insanely strong suctioning ability. The first time I vaccuumed my small 1 bedroom apartment, I had almost a completely full dirt trap! The suction was so strong that it actually pulled up the carpet from the ground (even though it's wall to wall and tacked down).
-There is a bagless dirt trap that is easy to empty with a see-through plastic housing so you can easily tell when it needs to be dumped out.
-It's not any louder than other vacuums I've owned
-It really is ONE-pass. Unlike my cordless stick vac that I'd have to go over the same spots a few times, this really sucks up everything in one pass. No need to waste time going back and forth and back and forth.

CONS:
-There is no automatic cord retractor, you must manual wind up the cord when you're done. Not a big deal, but certainly not as convenient as stepping on a switch and having it retract automatically
-The cord tends to get in the way, so I have to hold onto it while vacuuming to prevent vacuuming over the cord constantly

There is a foam 'filter' that can be reused and also a paper air filter that according to the owner's manual should be replaced every 3-6 months. If the suction starts decreasing, it's time to change the filter. I'm not crazy about having to replace filters, and I might not have chosen to buy this vacuum had I known there was a filter that would need regular replacing. Just something to keep in mind.

Overall, I am extremely impressed with the suction power in this $63 vacuum - it's much better than what I would expect from a budget vac. Since my priorities were (1) strong suction, and (2) low price, I don't mind the trade-offs (annoying cord, bulkier/heavier machine compared to cordless stick-vac. Depending on what your priorities are, you may feel differently. For the price, I think the performance really can't be beaten.
summary: Insanely strong suction and an unbeatable price makes up for annoying cord and bulkiness

reviewText:
Got this Bissell OnePass vacuum to replace a Shark wireless vacuum that had a dead battery that cost too much to replace. I use this vacuum in my off campus apt room & on my medium pile carpet & bathroom bare floors this picks up anything & everything. I was surprised to discover just how much dirt was hidden inside the carpet after I was done using this vacuum the first time. Assembly was straightforward & I barely had to look at the instructional guide.

I also like the various attachments that come with the vacuum as it makes it much easier to get to corners & delicate areas such as seats & windows. Moreover, it really is lightweight & so moving it across the the room is a piece of cake. Lastly, the two filter compartments are easy to get too which is also a plus.

For the price, I think this is the best under $100 vacuum on the market. Save yourself $$ by going for this instead of the overpriced Shark Navigator vacuum.
summary: For the price I think this is the best under $100 vacuum on the market.

reviewText:
Not what was expected, I received a bottle filled with "BLACK GOO"
I'm not sure if I received the wrong oil or what, but I can tell you its not good for windup clocks

putting a drop on my finger and rubbing it it feels like a gritty penetration oil
summary: Not what I expected - I think this is penitration oil

reviewText: Asolutely amazed at how well this cheap vacuum works. The suction power is amazing. Best part is the clear canister - you can see with your own eyes all the dirt coming out of your floor. We have 2 cats, and the amount of cat hair it pulled out of our carpet is scary! After just vacuuming one room that had been regularly cleaned before with our old vacuum, the canister was almost full. My sister has a dyson and she thinks this one pulls out just as much dirt. Only difference will be on hard floor. The rolling brush cannot be turned off, so on hardwood floor you cannot roll the vacuum forward on the dirt. You have to start from the front, and then pull the vacuum towards you. If you are going to use your vacuum primarily for hard floor, I would suggest getting a cainster vacuum such as the Eureka.
summary: amazing suction power

reviewText: very good.
summary: very good.

reviewText:
I'm not sure what the sticker about really means. Are there applications where these need to be washed before hand? If so, wouldn't there still be unsanitary surface area under the sticker itself?

I don't know, I've been thinking about this for far too long, but all I know is that these work well as a discovery buzzer for a lost quad. Works well with my F3 flight controller and 3.7v battery. Clear and loud even in windy environments, especially when less than 50 feet away. Indoors it's actually a bit too loud, so maybe keep a sticker handy to shut it up while you have it inside.
summary: Recovery buzzer for quad

reviewText: Tough product.  Used to to fix rock guard / step on my truck.  this pic shows the product standing up to over a years worth of use.  I did take the rack bars off and use a wire brush on a drill to prep the area first.  A little elbow grease and time saved a lot of dollars.
summary: Tough!

reviewText: Waste of money and time to attempt a repair.  Maybe it was a defective batch or old (box had not "best buy date".  Followed instructions for a repair and it would not even stick to itself to be able to wrap.  I have written the manufacture and am still waiting for a response..
summary: Maybe I got a bad batch because it would not fix anything.

reviewText:
Purchased this to seal a copper pipe water leak, very small leak, about 1/4 cup per day. Anyway, turned off water, removed pressure. sanded surface with wire wheel and sand paper, clean area to be sealed with alcohol then let dry. Followed procedure to soak FiberFix, then wrapped tightly with many layers over a 4: area with the one inch tape. Covered FiberFix with plastic strip and let dry for about 15 minutes, removed plastic wrap then let FiberFix dry for another six hours. Everything seemed fine, FiberFix had hardened well. Now I turn the water back on and slowly but surely the water started coming through the FiberFix, now I have multiple drips along the 4 inch area where I applied FiberFix. Remember I only had a very slow drip, a drop every couple minutes from a copper pipe to T joint. Now I will have to cut out the T and pipe and do a real copper pipe replacement.

The product did not work as advertised for repairing leaking pipe.
summary: Copper Water Pipe Repair Kit

reviewText:
Handy grommet punch. I have plenty of grommet setup installers. From bench to hand held but none of my dies are for "self piercing" groms. So I got this for my collection. The bad, the head is off center but when you squeeze it it pulls it on center. The spot weld that holds this alongment is so tiny that I will either wait until this weld breaks or just cut the weld then re weld IN PLACE to align it. I wish at least one side of the head would have been magnetic (I'm not sure I can msg. The head myself, but will try). The "squeeze" facter is high so it might impact tight spot use. I'll keep it , if nothing else you get 500 pelf piercing nic-plated grommets. These alone are the price of this deal... the tool is just a bonus. So the tool is the ADD on part of this deal.
***UPDATE*** I apologize about the head not being magnetic it is and holds the furnished groms very good. The dies are wearing smoother but still off center. Over all, did pretty good. On 9mil poly tarp I did get some puckering
2nd UPDATE... I've been using for awhile now and am thinking of a second batch of these "self piercing" grommets. I've started using the 1" wide "two sided tape" for FOLDING my edges on my tarps and that has ELIMINATED ALMOST ALL of the puckering!  I'm really starting to Ike thiS grommet installer over my other hand grommet setters.
summary: I'm liking it more and more!

reviewText: Precision construction. Very happy with this item. Should last a lifetime.
summary: Very happy with this item

reviewText: This scope is identical to the V2 in "guts" and features, but has a metal case at about the same price as the 2. If you want all the dope on function and features, see the 20+ reviews on the 2 here: DSO Nano oscilloscope V2. There's a well done pdf users manual online too-- same for this and the v2. Points not made in previous reviews: 1. The metal case IS nice, and there were complaints about the plastic having range problems in the heat. I have both and both work great for single channel applications. 2. A GOOD two channel with all these features can cost as much as $500 on up. It would be better to get two of these, then compare oscillations -- AUC's without the overlay if you're not too picky about pinpoints and want to see general signal comparison trends, which work for 95% of checks. You're going to pay quite a penny (nearly 300 low end, 500+ higher end) for a good 2 channel unit like: Owon SDS7102 Deep Memory Digital Storage Oscilloscope 2-channel with VGA and LAN interface. The question to ask is do you really need the waveforms on top of each other, or can you just put these little units next to each other and get the same info? They're pocket sized! 3. Comparing this to my big brother lab units, measurements are within 3%, not bad for hobby applications. I use it with the raspberry pi and it works great! I've used the v2 on the Arduino forever and it's fine for nearly all checks and comparisons. 4. Other reviews have recommended you swap out the OS on some of these versions-- DO NOT do this on this unit or the 2 until you try it. It's been updated many times since those reviews, and you're likely to be happy with this out of the box. There are polarity issues for the signal generator, but an easy fix, see the fixes in the version 2 reviews mentioned above. Gabotronics has also just come out with their xprotolab portable, at about the same price. Sparkfun will likely put it on Amazon sometime late in 2013 when it ships reliably. We did a number of regressions of quality indicators by price for ALL current digital scopes, and the best price/feature fit was by megahertz measured. The y=mx+b regression factor is .1295 with a 99% fit to data, so if you divide megahertz desired by that factor, you'll get a close estimate of what you'll have to pay. We tried to put the full regression in this listing as a picture, but Amazon doesn't always get what we're trying to do and removes it! Just put your mhz in 50 mhz increments from 50 to 1,000, divide by the regression coefficient (.1295) and you'll get a good estimate. For 50, you get about $386, which is quite accurate. Happy measuring! This little devil takes your Multimeter to the next stage, and will impress your friends! ;=) Enjoy
summary: Quite Good for What It Claims to Be...

reviewText:
Am a tried using this DSO v3 device after installing a pair of Alpine amps (F300 & M500) hooked to a Pioneer AVH head unit. The device UI is horrendous (& I am a tech savvy person) & it doesn't help that the owner's manual that comes w/ was written by a someone that clearly doesn't know how to explain a lot of info to a newbie.

I ended up watching a YouT video of some1 using the device to tune their amp. After figuring it out, the distortion levels for my head unit & amps that it gave me turned out to be in correct. Moreover, the waves where extremely hard to read.

Luckily I also got the SMD DD-1 distortion detecting device & which was MUCH easier to use for an everyday joe like me. My car's audio now sounds awesome w/ the amp gains tuned properly.

If u are a DIY person looking to saves bucks trying to tune your car audio, I DON'T recommend this crap. I now see that the DD-1 is a great value (though $150 is hard to swallow) when compared to the other thousand dollar oscilloscopes on the market.
summary: Hard to use & gave me incorrect distortion levels for my car audio (probes are too sensitive)

reviewText: Saves so much time having the dilutions on the side! i use these for all my spray chemicals! Cheap and very durable!!! Bought these with a bunch of other supplies and have converted all my old spray bottles over to these now!
summary: Great product makes diluting easy

reviewText: Dupont has a reputation of great products and this does not disappoint. I've used it on a number of surfaces including my home gym and it helps keep the surface smooth and protected without the greasy buildup. Application is as easy as wiping it on with a old rag or spraying directly onto the surface. If you need a product that is going to protect and allow for smooth operation then look no further.
summary: Does the trick

reviewText: Just what I was looking for. I'm no machinist, but I do tinker quite a bit and these blocks will come in handy. Fairly well machined and solid. Recommend.
summary: Recommend.

reviewText:
A disadvantage of 3D-printed parts has always been their relative fragility compared with injection-molded parts, and their related tendency to de-laminate. With the introduction of Taulman 618 nylon, that is no longer the case. Parts printed with this material can be 80-100% as strong as injection-molded ones.

Changes to my normal ABS workflow on my Afinia printer were minimal. I purchased the recommended Garolite sheet and temperature-lowering attachment from Octave Systems. The Garolite is a lot thicker than the perfboard I usually use so I had to reset my initial platform height. I had to leave a bigger-than-usual gap (about 0.5mm) between the nozzle tip and the bed or else the feed stepper would jam, possibly due to the viscosity of nylon being different from that of ABS during extrusion. The temperature-lowering gizmo must be used if you're printing with an Afinia, since the 618 nylon likes a 240 degree C extrusion temperature and the Afinia doesn't have user-adjustable temp. I also opened my fan duct damper since the nylon seems to print better that way, whereas I've been keeping it closed for ABS lately for maximum part strength. I always print with a raft, so bed leveling is not super-critical for me; I didn't even bother re-leveling.

The material unfortunately does not come on a "real" spool, but rather in a sort of clamshell thing where the filament comes out of a zigzag seam between the two halves of the clamshell. OK, seems reasonable, by why on earth haven't they punched a hole in the middle to act as a hub?!? I cut my own hub hole, stuck a piece of PVC tubing in it, and it seems to be working ok, but I'd much rather have a genuine spool and I'd much rather buy 1kg of it than 1 lb.

The parts are unbelievable. Beautiful, smooth, even, glossy finish and incredible strength. It's not just that the raw material is stronger than ABS, but the layer-to-layer bonding strength is vastly higher, resulting in parts that do not de-laminate nearly as easily under stress. Another plus is nylon's flexibility, for things like living hinges. ABS gets stress marks and quickly cracks, but nylon is far more durable under repeated flexure.

Support removal from parts printed on the Up is only slightly more difficult than ABS; due to nylon's greater strength and flexibility; support doesn't "pop" off like ABS support does. There's also a bit of extra cleanup required due to nylon's "stringiness" - they do make clothing and carpeting out of the stuff, after all! Nonetheless, using the most recent (1.18 at the time of this writing) Afinia software, support removal is trivially easy.

Colors are not available, but the natural nylon can be dyed with Rit clothing dyes, either before or after printing. Maximum strength is achieved by dyeing after printing.

Update  - this material now comes on a traditional-type spool, hurray! The hub diameter is different from any other spool I have, but that's not a big deal. Much better than the clamshell thing.
summary: A Complete Game-Changer

reviewText: Worked awesome as a temp controller form my fermentation chamber. Was concerned about the 10 amp rating but so far so good. Gonna build another using this unit.
summary: Works great!

reviewText:
Celsius-only digital thermostat. Works great, price right.

I'm using it to turn a lightbulb on and off inside a warming box that keeps the box at a constant temperature, but for that it's perfect.

Has two 10-amp 120 volt capacity relays: one for heating, one for cooling.

The heating relay turns on (closes the circuit) when the supplied sensor reads 0.5C below the target temp. This setting is adjustable. The relay stays closed until the target temp is reached.

The cooling relay turns on (closes) when the desired upper temp is reached, to turn on a refrigeration compressor. To protect the compressor, there is an adjustable compressor delay value.

Four programmable values:
1. Target temperature (default: 10C/50F; adjustable from -50C to 99.9C) (-58F to 211.82F)
2. Difference (how far the temp falls or rises until the relay closes) (.5C is default); adjustable between .3C and 10C
3. Compressor delay time (1-10 min; 3 min default)
4. Temp calibration value

The box is small - fits in your palm. It's designed to be panel mounted. Fits in a 71 mm x 29 mm opening. The orange things ratchet from behind to snug the box against the panel opening. They can be removed if desired.

I posted a picture of the instruction/spec sheet, but it may not be readable.  Too bad we can't post PDF.

Relays are mechanical nonelectronic and audibly click when activated. No idea how many cycles they can take.

The sensor is at the end of a 2-meter 2-wire cable. The sensor itself is about 1/4" in diameter and about 3/4" inch long.
summary: Works well, easy to wire

reviewText: Great PLA! I was kind of done with PLA until Xperland advertised this more precise extruded PLA. Here is what I found.. First the bad. I think the cardboard box isn't needed unless Amazon requires it. The spool itself is made from plastic and vacuum packed with desiccant. That wrapped in an amazon box would have been enough packaging in my opinion. I have seen some spools made from cardboard. This might be a more eco option. I should mention the plastic used for the spool is able to be recycled. Now the good. The claim of uniformity seems to be holding true. I ran a few calibration prints and then printed a mount for my Sirius radio and spot measured the plastic as it fed in. I never measured more than 0.01mm thicker or thinner(1.74-1.76mm). The finish is shiny like PLA should be. The layers formed nicely and I didn't have any bubbling from the extruder. I ran my extruder at 220c(10c higher than recommended) but this is characteristic of my printer. Every material runs better 10c higher for whatever reason. I'm using a PEI covered bed and set that to 65c. All in all I'm happy with this PLA. I had stopped using it because of the bubbling I kept getting from other brands. Even name brands. If you want some reliable Filament for a finicky extruder or just some clean and honest PLA you can't go wrong here. Here is a video of the PLA in action on my CTC Bizer .
summary: Very reliable PLA.  Worked great in my printer. Xperland has a good product!

reviewText: This is a great variety pack of ABS filaments for 3D pens. There is a nice assortment of colors plus you get some fun glow in the dark filament. I just tried this with my first 3D pen and I had a lot of fun with it. It works great with my 3D pen which uses both ABS and PLA filament. The purple color in my video is from this assortment and the other colors are colors that came with my 3D pen. All worked great. Now I just need some practice using a 3D pen. Nice assortment. I'm very happy with it. Sample provided for review.
summary: Nice assortment of colors, plus some glow in the dark!

reviewText: It's a pretty decent place to start, it's nice that it fits in the slot for the FlashForge Finder. The plastic is a very bright lime green and is slightly transparent, doesn't look quite as nice as completely opaque plastics. It does print cleanly and the filament quality is very good, just be aware that it's somewhat transparent.
summary: Good place to start, be aware of transparency

reviewText:
Happy with the vice. Have only been using for a few months, but no complaints.

7/31/26
Update: I've had this vice for about a year now with moderate use. It's held up very well. I even made a few pads for gripping softer pieces. My tutorial can be found at the following link. [...]
summary: Five Stars

reviewText:
This stuff is great!  I tried MEK and pvc glue which gave bad results.  This works like a contact glue and works great.
I added an older TV to my patio.  I wanted to build a waterproof cover from vinyl.  The adhesive was easy to use and dried quick on a 77 degree February, Texas day.  Great stuff
summary: It works like contact glue

reviewText: I purchased this because of the othe brand cracking on me and I had to re make a few high end pens.  I normally use medium from r. Finishing work but they recommend the medium thin.  If you use medium like I have u will notice it's a bit of a learning curve on the number of layers to finish with.  I normally did about 10. With this product I burn threw it sanding so I have gone to about 15-2 layers.  No Big deal but it is pretty thin so go heavy with it. As for finish quality. It's on par with the rest but there 20 month guarantee made it worth a try.
summary: Good finishing product

reviewText: These work as advertised. Because they need to be powered from a totally isolated source, I wound up using batteries to power it. 6V NiCds worked, as well as 9V alkaline. Isolated, in this case, means no current path between monitored voltage and meter power source. Violate this and the meter will blow. Wire the meter according to the following schematic. You can't go wrong.
summary: Very Useful Voltage-Current Monitor

reviewText: I wired this up to a DC Power Outlet (cigar Lighter type) so that I could track how much/fast my CPAP discharged a battery so I could plan for camping.  The Instructions are almost unusable.  I made my own diagram, attached along with some photos.  I first had the + & - reversed on the power outlet.  My CPAP is evidently reverse protected so everything survived.  After 20-30 minutes of troubleshooting I finally realized my error & corrected it.  I checked with a CHEAP Volt Amp meter and the current reading is close enough for my use.  The voltage reading is lower than the CHEAP meter, however this meter seems closer than the Freebie meter.  I have a FLUKE multi-meter that will use for calibration if I decide that is needed.  I have only been using this setup for 2 days.  I plan to redo it to make a neater setup.
summary: Does what I wanted AFTER figuring out how to connect the wiring.

reviewText: I guess I should not have expected much for this price.  No problems with assembly, mostly just a lot of switches.  But the signal quality is poor.  While the frequency response is good, the amount of distortion and noise is terrible.  See the three attached photos of a 250 Hz sine wave.  The first shows the overall noise level and the second and third ones show the nature of the noise which seems to be not random at all.  Unless you are just wanting to play around, I would not suggest spending your money on this.  Go to Ebay and buy a older used but tested function generator and have something you can really use.
summary: But the signal quality is poor. While the frequency response is good

reviewText: The unit looks to be of good quality and good fit and finish. It's very compact making it easy to mount in tight areas. I did a quick hook up of the unit to check the voltage and it puts out a solid 6 volts DC (see photo). I will use this unit to power the 6 volt motor drives on my telescope mount so I can do away with the 4 - D Cell Battery pack that is currently on it. This unit costs about the same as a pack of batteries so it will pay for itself.
summary: Great Value for the Money

reviewText:
update:  IT BROKE.  CAN'T FIX IT. DYSON WONT TAKE IT BACK EVEN THOUGH ITS UNDER WARRENTY. I HAVENT HAD TIME TO TAKE TO DYSON AUTHORIZED RETAILER TO FIX.  TOTAL WASTE OF MONEY. DONT FALL FOR THE HYPE LIKE I DID.

Ok so I wanted to fall heads over heels in love with this vacuum but, honestly, I just didn't.  I have a Hoover windtunnel already but had an amazon gift card and saw this on sale so thought 'Gee now might be the time to get the dyson I always wanted'.  The truth is that it has some advantages to the windtunnel, some disadvantages.  The biggest disadvantage is that it gets clogged pretty easily.  Also, it doesn't pick up larger items (like popcorn or cheerios) unless you use hose attachments, but then it gets clogged.  Also it doesn't have that little hook thing to clip the cord into while you are vacuuming (a small thing I know but still, I like that hook).  Advantages are good suction and someone the design doesn't suck up the rope edges of my carpet and get all tangled.  There are three attachments that come with the vacuum and after much heming and hawing I figured out that they DO all attach - one attaches to the end of the power cord (when not in use of course) and the other two go on the sides.  (See pics).  So... at full price, I would not recommend.  If you get a bargain, sure- go for it - this is a nice vacuum but nothing amazing like I expected.  I guess next I will get a Miew  (or whatever that German brand is) and go back to bags.
summary: horrible!!  Not "AMAZING" like I thought....

reviewText:
PROS:  Tactile sensitivity and thickness so far is comparable to the Cranberry Aqua Source I was using.

CONS:  One of the boxes was shipped crushed and opened on one end (this didn't happen in transport).  I'm not confident in using the box since all of the gloves have been exposed to larger than normal particulate.
summary: As good as more expensive brands.

reviewText:
UPDATE:
* Just finished my THIRD BOX and ordered another.  At about $0.11 per glove the price seems fair.
* I often use these gloves for painting projects.  That means you paint for a while, then take a break before doing the next coat.  I reuse the gloves whenever I can.  Some of these gloves survived SEVERAL DAYS of painting, removing them, then using them again.  When they do rip--as all gloves will--it's usually the tip of the thumb or index finger.
* Photos show 2 gloves.  Both gloves are on their FIFTH USE.  Still air tight.
* Gloves have enough dexterity for keyboard typing this review update.  They are awkward when texting on a phone, but that's true of all gloves I've ever used.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:  I use these "medical" gloves for a variety of handyman tasks--painting, gluing, handling fiberglass batting, etc.  They go on easily.  They are reasonably tough in my situations--great in non-abrasive situations like painting and gluing.  I'm working through my third box.  I'm happy with them.
summary: Handyman helpers.  Just ordered FOURTH BOX.

reviewText: Great deal for 100 stainless washers. Their actual dimensions were approx. .751" OD x .341" ID x .046" THK. One side is a little shinier than the other. They are slightly attracted to a magnet.
summary: High Quality Washers

reviewText: Bought this as an open box item. Opened up the box and the vacuum cleaner with filthy on the outside there was dirt in the bottom of the box. Opened up the vacuum and it was filthy inside as well. It required quite an effort to wash my hands after just looking at the item. Not sure how well it works yet. Have to give it one star because 0 is not an option.
summary: Would not buy from warehouse deals again.

reviewText: I just purchased this from E-bay for $414,00 brand new still in box, it is an excellent mixer, the bowl is not hard to place on as I have read in some of the other reviews, you just have to know how to put place the bowl, see the pics. First you need to place the little notch on the back of the bowl into the hole of the metal thing on the mixer, then hold it in place and push the bowl into the mixer, lining up the sides and all will snap in place, just that easy
summary: it is an excellent mixer, the bowl is not hard to place ...

reviewText: I purchased the black model = KitchenAid KSM8990OB (unfortunately not sold by Amazon right now) I purchased it when I got fed up by the Hamilton Beach 63227 that Ive had for about 1 year. I was always eyeballing a KitchenAid, but when I found the Hamilton for just 60 bucks new I pulled the trigger. It was not a bad mixer, but it was never powerful enough, and regretted my decision every time I was using it. Well, time came to get a meat grinder attachment (the stainless SmokehouseChef one) and what a better opportunity to change my mixer? So I searched and researched and stumbled upon this commercial KitchenAid. What a great find! This mixer is similar in size to the Professional 600 that we also considered. It is almost 17 tall, so it fits perfectly under the cabinet (and it looks fantastic too, orange cord included - tucked away in the back). And because it doesnt tilt, I can keep it in one position and never move it (the Hamilton - a tilt head model - we needed to take out every time as we couldn't tilt it under the cabinet). Also, the 8qt bowl is big (or at least that's my impression after switching from a 4.5qt one), but it is mostly tall. It is so tall in fact that there are issues adding ingredients - when we use this bowl we always have to lower it to add ingredients. It seems (from what I read) that the pouring shield from the Professional 600 6qt bowl fits this unit. But we never bought the shield - instead, to mitigate this issue we purchased the KitchenAid KSMC5QBOWL 5qt bowl for about 40 bucks) and that one is perfect for our everyday mixing needs. We love the fact that all attachments are stainless steel. Very good quality too and NSF rated for restaurant use. They are BIG, and solid! We switched most of our small appliances and cookware to stainless, and this is one very important reason we chose this KitchenAid unit (the Hamilton aluminum-coated attachments started to chip after just a few uses). We have tried all attachments and all performed very well. But we needed to adjust the bowl height to get them to properly scrape the edges. There is one attachment that we considered (the KitchenAid KAFE7L) but didn't yet really feel the need for it. Using it is a pleasure! This thing is a beast. Nothing can stop it! It has so much torque! And it is do quiet too. It features a slow start - when it gets to the speed selected all you hear is a very quiet motor driving the gear drive (I cannot really explain it; it just sounds like a well-built, solid machinery). It mixes anything we through at it - pizza dough, play dough, paleo (sticky) dough, panettone dough, eggs, etc. - with so much ease. It also drives that meat grinder without any strain - almost as if nothing is there. The lift-bowl is a bit more inconvenient than the tilt-head model (as my Hamilton was) but the torque on this puppy would have probably torn that hinge apart. To see the true difference in the motor design please refer to the pictures I uploaded - the KSM8990 has direct drive, and the entire motor unit is actually cheaper to replace (about 50 bucks) than replacing all parts that could go wrong in the other 2 models. It is one of my best appliances (I try to purchase commercial quality as often as I can - I also have the Waring WFP14SC, the Waring MX1200XTX, the Weston 08-0801-W, among others) and I reach for it every time I have the chance. All in all, highly recommended!
summary: The beauty and the beast! All-in-one...

It has so much torque! And it is do quiet too. It features a slow start - when it gets to the speed selected all you hear is a very quiet motor driving the gear drive (I cannot really explain it; it just sounds like a well-built, solid machinery). It mixes anything we through at it - pizza dough, play dough, paleo (sticky) dough, panettone dough, eggs, etc. - with so much ease. It also drives that meat grinder without any strain - almost as if nothing is there. The lift-bowl is a bit more inconvenient than the tilt-head model (as my Hamilton was) but the torque on this puppy would have probably torn that hinge apart. To see the true difference in the motor design please refer to the pictures I uploaded - the KSM8990 has direct drive, and the entire motor unit is actually cheaper to replace (about 50 bucks) than replacing all parts that could go wrong in the other 2 models. It is one of my best appliances (I try to purchase commercial quality as often as I can - I also have the Waring WFP14SC, the Waring MX1200XTX, the Weston 08-0801-W, among others) and I reach for it every time I have the chance. All in all, highly recommended!
summary: The beauty and the beast! All in one package.

The measurements listed in the product description are the measurements from end to end -- the scissors are 4" long and the tweezers are 3.5" long. The scissor blades are about 1.5" long, so they wouldn't work for cutting off clothes, but they do a nice job of cutting bandage supplies. The tweezers are angled and very sharp, and they are perfect for tasks such as removing splinters. Overall, I am happy with this purchase, especially for the price.

reviewText:
I'm working on a DIY Homebrewing monitoring / automation system built on a Netduino Plus 2 microcontroller.  Being a .NET Developer by day, I was naturally drawn to something I could leverage my current coding skills / development tools with without having to learn a new language / IDE.  I bought these mostly to test the 1-Wire Bus and its feasibility for high-ish speed temp monitoring from multiple probes on a common bus.  These things fit the bill.

All 5 were within a degree or two of each other at room temperature, less than 1 degree off in an ice water bath, and less than 2 degrees off in boiling water.  Not bad for the price.  They each have their own unique "address" on the bus and can be queried individually with relatively little code (leveraging the Microsoft OneWire library and some simple addressing / conversion code).

See my photos for the tests I performed on these little guys.  I may eventually upgrade them to the PTFE-insulated version for high-temp applications such as in my boil kettle and/or add metal conduit to protect the wire, but these seem to hold up pretty well for lower-temp stuff.

I plan to solder XLR connectors to these to make them more modular and easier to disconnect for cleaning or replacement.
summary: Good for the price

reviewText: I like them a lot. very clean and ez to work with
summary: Five Stars

reviewText:
This is a very nice set of Dremel drill bits. They are made of tungsten carbide, and will maintain their sharpness much longer than steel. When my husband saw them (he's a tool guy), he was really impressed, and commented on the high quality. There are 10 bits in this set that are securely held in a hard plastic case. When the case is opened, the holder for the bits stands up so the bits are easily accessible. I have two Dremel tools, and these bits will fit both of them. I am very happy with this set.

I received these bits at a discount or for free for my unbiased, honest evaluation and review. All of my reviews are completely honest as I rely heavily on customer product reviews for my own purchases.

reviewText:
These are great! They were at my front door within 2-days of ordering. I used them to add some nail-head detailing to a small fabric tufted bench. (I realized I need at least 2 boxes so I will be ordering more soon.) They're super easy to place, although I didn't go through any wood or other hard surfaces (be sure to follow the instructions online if using it for this purpose). The brushed nickel finish is very classy- very modern but not overly shiney like chrome. All of the tacks arrived to me in perfect condition- not a single one was unusable! I'm going to buy more for an upcoming couch reupholstering project.

Note: This is my first attempt at upholstery tacking so they're a little uneven in the pictures. If you're unexperienced like myself, I recommend doing some research and following a trusted process rather than just "winging it" like I did. However, the tacks didn't damage the fabric so I've been able to easily make adjustments.

reviewText:
Disappointing! Just opened the sealed bag of filament and tried to print with the blue.  Even at the lowest setting (.4mm) the filament was stringy and would not stick.  Again, I just opened the sealed bag this morning (16 April 2015), so moisture should have not been a reason for the filament to perform so poorly.  I don't know if this one I got was just a bad batch, but it sure is BAD Filament!

Edit #1:  Just to make sure it was not user error, I am testing the filament by printing a Sample file which is included in the Davinci printer. Tried the Yellow color filament and got the same horrible results as with the Blue filament.  Now I'm testing the Red color filament, and when that one is done I'll do the same with the Green color filament.  I will post pictures to show the results of all four colors when all the samples are done.

Edit #2: Finished printing the Davinci Sample file with all four colors.  The Red and Green filament worked flawlessly, but the Blue and Yellow filaments yielded poor print results.  I have included a picture so folks can see the difference.  A shame because two out of four is never a good thing...
summary: Horrible filament!  Stay away...!

reviewText:
***UPDATE*** I went ahead and added the 5th star because I LOVE this sprayer. I'm about to order one for my sister-in-law and surprise her with it. She saw me using this on my plants and went gaga. I have switched to using this one on my hair and face (adding some essential oils) and need one for the plants again. So I'm ordering TWO more - one for the SIL and another for myself. By the way, I see where some people wonder whether or not you can use oils in this. I have used thin essential and carrier oils so far, but no heavier ones like olive oil or anything that might clog the sprayer. When I get the next one, I will risk experimenting with something heavier. This sprayer is so perfect or dampening my hair for styling or my skin for cooling off. My plants are probably mad that I quit using it on them!

I'm going to hold back a star just because there are no instructions. I was scared to open it because the top was not easy to get off and I thought I'd break it. Thankfully another reviewer (Robert G) explained it. He also warned that it would take several pumps before the unit was primed and would spray. Basically, I had to grasp the bottom firmly and twist the top piece just enough for it to come loose. Once it's open, you will see the unique spray mechanism. I filled with filtered water, re-attached the top (being careful) and then I had to pump about 10+ times before I got the first partial spray. A couple more pumps and the sprayer was misting as it should. When I sprayed my plants, I realized that I had to stand back a little or the water would drip from the leaves. I ended up holding the sprayer up in the air over the foliage and spraying so that the mist would fall toward the plants. On my hair, it was easier to hold the sprayer a little closer to the target.

As far as the sprayer itself, this is the first time I'm using it and, so far, so good. I was expecting a longer spray for each pump because the description made it sound like the spray would be "continuous". I love the extremely fine mist. With my afro-natural hair, I am glad to be able to moisturize for detangling without over-saturating the hair.

Back to the lack of information included, I still am curious about some things. For instance, can I put certain things in it without ruining the mechanism? I'm sure that thin fluids (essential oils, diluted conditioner, and other products) will spray all right, but I don't know if they will eventually damage the pump. I'm going to check around and see if I can get some answers.

Bottom line: as of this first days' use, I'm happy with the basic function but would have appreciated some kind of instructions or Do's and Dont's.
summary: ***UPDATE***NO instructions for a great product

reviewText: This is an easy-to-use hand-held radiation detector, simple for a non-professional like myself. I have also reviewed an earlier version of RADEX RD 1503+ RADEX RD1503+ w/o dosimeter: High accuracy Geiger counter, radiation detector as a comparison. Both measure Beta, Gamma, and X-Ray radiation, and, as advertised, this RD1212 is faster! The RD1212 gives an initial reading in approx. 10 seconds, while the RD1503+ gives an initial reading in about 14 seconds. The full readings, which appear to be within approx. .05 microSv (if that) of the initial readings in difference (just my non-scientific observation), are a more significant amount of time- about one minute apart, with the RD1212 finishing first. Both are ridiculously easy to use, in that you basically add the included batteries (2-AAAs) and press the ON (largest) button on the lower right hand side. That's it. Both have audio and/or vibration alarms pre-set to a threshold of .3 microSv, but are adjustable, and both have back-lighting options to see the screens in lower light settings. The RD1212, unlike the RD1503+, has the ability to record and store your data points onto a PC (comes with a Mini-USB-B plug- not Micro) using downloadable software from QuartaRad's website, and you can interactively plot and share your readings on a map with other individuals using the same software/ devices worldwide. The RD1212 also shows the threshold alarm level on the main screen itself (vs. inside the menu for the RD1503+), and has several language options (Russian, English, French, German, Japanese). The RD1503+ appears to be sold (in the US at least) with English only, but does give the option to use older micro Roetgens per hour as the unit of measure. I looked on the specs for both the RD1212 and the RD1503+on the QuartaRad site and there are minor discrepancies between the included paper technical specs that come with the devices and the specs listed on the website, such as some commas instead of periods for decimals, or minor discrepancies in energy ranges registered ("0,4 to 3,5" MeV for beta radiation on RD1212's paper specs vs. "0.25- 3.5" on the website), but i'm not sure how much that would matter to the causal user anyways. Perhaps the biggest differences I noticed in the specs between the two devices is that the RD1212 has a "Range of Indications" of 0.05-999.00 microSv/h (per website), whereas RD1503+ shows 0.05- 9.99 (also website). The uninterrupted operation time is no less than 300 hours for the RD1212, and 550 hours for the RD1503+. This RD1212 costs about $50 more than the RD1503+, but depending on your needs, either device is suitable. Another curiosity/ feature is that you can also use this RD1212 precision machine as a... flashlight....heh, maybe the engineers have an answer for this, but it seemed to me to be as random a feature as if this also doubled as an oven-timer or something like that. For fun, I looked up in Wikipedia, the "Banana Equivalent Dose (BED), [which] is an informal expression of ionizing radiation exposure, intended as a general educational example to indicate the potential dose due to naturally occurring radioactive isotopes by eating one average-sized banana. One BED is often taken as 0.1 Sv" To check this, i took a measurement using both the RD1212 and the RD1503+- as you can see from my pic, yep, the devices next to my bananas registered very much in that range- about 0.08-.11 microSv in my four trials. I mentioned this in my RD1503+ review, but check your old watches. I wrote that there are watches from the mid-20th century (pre-1960s) that were made with radium dials- my husband collects many antique watches, and measured one watch with a reading of .84 - in the "Alert" zone, which the RD1503+ manual says should be avoided. There is also an incredible story on the quartarad website where a traveler measured upper 90s-100s microSvs in his hotel hallway, to find that the guy in the room next door had just had returned from the hospital after a radioactive therapy treatment for thyroid cancer. Apparently, the ionized radiation levels emanating from such patients can last weeks, even after the end of treatment! The traveler asked for a different room. These are great devices, and they bring some peace of mind.
summary: Give Yourself Some Peace of Mind

reviewText:
While the intended purpose of this is for HVAC line tapping, it's hands-down the best carto punch available. Zero distortion of the casing, even when punching multiple holes.

It takes just a bit of time to learn how to use it. I started with a junk carto and practiced until I got a feel for it. I put some photos up to illustrate usage and the resulting size of the punched hole.

Basically, just loosen the three outer bolts, slide in a carto, tighten the bolts (they don't need to be real tight), then turn the center bolt with the included allen wrench. You'll feel the needle pop through the case. Back off the center screw, loosen the bolts, and done! After a couple of practice holes it becomes easy as pie.

Unlike other line taps, the Supco has a gasket that helps hold and protect the carto while punching it. Very nice construction as well. Note that while the Supco site says their products are made in the US, the one I got was made in China.

Make sure you get the model BPV31. Supco makes a variety of models for various size tubing. The BPV31 will fit a 510 carto.
summary: The best carto punch bar none!

reviewText:
I got the Lasergrip 800 two weeks back. Its an awesome instrument to have because you can use it to measure temperatures when you actually have a need for it (or you can play around with it by pointing it inside your refrigerator, on hot stove element etc to entertain!!).

I really like it and would like to break my review in pros and cons of the Lasergrip 800:
PROS:
1. First up, it feels good in hand. The plastic its made of is good quality, its ergonomic to handle and its pretty light-weight.
2. I tried it on multiple things (water at different temperatures) with a thermometer dipped in it and the temperature was with agreement with what was shown on thermometer (plus/minus 1oC).
3. It has a range of -50 to 750oC, which pretty much covers everything under the sun (but not the sun of course ;).
4. It show temperature in Fahrenheit as well as Centigrade, saving you the time to use an app to convert ;)
5. The display is big with huge, easy to read letters (photos attached). It can be backlit for easy reading, if using the Lasergrip at night.
6. It takes 9-volt battery (instead of a AA battery) that means it lasts longer and you won't have to worry about changing the batteries too often.
7. There is not off switch and it switches off after a few seconds of inactivity, thus extending the battery life even more.
8. One of the good things I liked is that it comes with a detailed manual (photos attached) and one can easily get to know how to use the instrument.
9. The price is worth for such an instrument.

CONS:
1. Size of the lasergrip is a bit on larger side. Would have been good to have it a little smaller, but that is definitely not a deal breaker
2. Since it uses laser, its advisable to have a cap on the end that emits laser light, for extra protection.

In summary, I am glad to have got this and I am enjoying using the laser grip. I would definitely recommend it for a handyman and also to have it at home for personal use if you regularly need it to check tempratures.
summary: !!!!!!!! WHY WONT YOU HAVE THIS AT HOME !!!!!!!!!!!

reviewText: Because it works just as it should. Literally you pull the trigger, hit whatever you want with the laser dot and you know the temperature. The LCD readout has a backlight option, switch from Fahrenheit to Celsius and lock in the last read temp. Comes with the battery you need to get going. For the price it feels really solid, the grip is nice and rubbery so you don't drop it when doing wet or greasy tasks. For the price, it is a great investment... I've used it on the pizza stone to see if it was up to temp, checking for freezing pipe temps and a host of other tasks that you can't really do with typical thermometers.
summary: It's hard to review this product...

reviewText: Very handy, use it for measuring all sorts of temperatures related to projects.
summary: Five Stars

reviewText: Perfect for my use! I have not done extensive testing to see how spot on or off the numbers are but they seem to work just fine and i always assume it to be more of a  general range more than pinpoint accuracy.
summary: Good Buy

reviewText:
I'm giving this 5 stars because it does what we expected it to do, but I don't feel confident in saying it is the most accurate measurer of temperatures.  It seems to work best if you hold it directly perpendicular to the item you are taking the temp of, if you hold it at any sort of angle it seems to skew the readings quite a bit.
My husband uses it to take the temperature of the grill before making things like pizzas and of course we also used it on all sorts of other objects for fun. I took the temperature of the deck in the sun, which read 106, and then the temperature of my cat sitting on the deck and it read him between 91-93. Cats are supposed to have a temp of over 100 plus he was in the sun so I'd think his fur would have been even warmer, which is why I say I'm not sure how accurate this is. I'm sure it's more accurate on flat objects than on furry/textured things (though it also didn't measure the heat of the reflective grill lid well so I think shiny objects are a problem as well). Anyways, overall it's just a fun thing to have but I wouldn't recommend using it for an actual scientific report or anything serious!
summary: Fun gadget but maybe not for scientists

reviewText:
Etekcity Lasergrip 1022 Non-contact Digital Laser Infrared Thermometer

I am very impressed with this Etekcity infrared thermometer. I was expecting it to be good but it stood up to my test. First the thermometer comes packaged in a clamshell  pack that thankfully opens by separating the sides, you don't have to cut it apart and wind up cutting yourself. The first thing you notice is a tag informing you that a battery is packaged inside the device. There is a 9V battery and its wrapped in cellophane so it won't discharge. I unwrapped it hooked it up and set about testing it. There is also an instruction sheet for more detailed knowledge.

My first test was I pointed the Etekcity (blue/gray) thermometer and my yellow thermometer at my carpet and saw a one degree difference. Not bad at all for a thirty dollar unit, pretty accurate. I upped my testing with my oven set to 400 degrees. I did learn in this test that pointing at my pizza stone yields a higher temperature than the air temperature the oven is set to. At that level I did get a 14 degree difference from yellow. I won't say what yellow is but it would be a fluke if you guessed. I took pictures of my tests with both units pointing to areas next to each other so the temperature would be as close to the same as I could do. I'm very impressed by the closeness at low temps and respectable difference at the higher level.

I like the rugged feel of the thermometer. It has a very clear screen too. My photos don't capture the clarity as well because of the coloration of the screen. It is a very good quality product at a very reasonable price point.

This product was provided at or nearly no cost for the purpose of evaluation and review.
summary: Stood up to my tests pretty well, a bargain.

reviewText: I love this little unit. It helps me when I am feeling cold to re-assure me that I indeed don't need to cut on the heater, and that I just need to wait for my body heat to normalize to the environment. Also, it has helped when I accidentally leave the heater on during a nap. I can say that, thanks to this unit's Low Temp / High Temp recording feature, I was able to find out that I had left the heater on by mistake and achieved a whopping 95 degrees (F) out of the space heater.
summary: Information is power

reviewText: We have for humidifiers in our house and have four of these humidity and temperature detector is in the opposite side of the room as the humidifier. It helps us to know when we need to turn on the humidifier.  My husband was having bloody noses because of the dry air.  we bought more humidifiers and now no problems
summary: We have these in every room where there's a humidifier

reviewText: Purchased two of these in May of 2017.  Having owned these for almost a year now and in side by side comparisons I'm finding there to be a one point difference for humidity between the two units ( close and certainly not a deal breaker) and temperature tends to read equal for both. On the back is a white button to change from Celsius to Fahrenheit as well as a magnetic clip. The readout is a nice legible size with 24 hour highs and lows recorded for both humidity and temperature. What I don't like is these units cannot be calibrated. Also, I puchased two and one arrived with a damaged clip. Not the fault of AcuRite. A suggestion I have is to check for accuracy by conducting the salt test. Place salt in the bottle cap (or other small container). Dampen the salt with water. Place both the hygrometer and the bottle cap full of damp salt in a ziploc bag and seal. Keep it like this for  8+ hours.  After 8+ hours the humidity inside the bag will be 75%. Compare it to your hygrometer which should read 75%. If it's off, note how much and in which direction then be sure to add or subtract that amount when reading the hygrometer. Hope this helps.
summary: Check for accuracy. Here's a simple way.

reviewText: worked fine for about a month, but hasn't kept accurate temp for at least a week. now some portions of digits not displaying. and reading 10F indoors. actual temp is about 70F. tried new batteries. same exact result. can't return after 30 days - i tried. also, the INCREDIBLY SMALL DISPLAY on this thing isn't much larger than a book of matches. definitely wouldn't buy again. i tend to like Amazon recommendations, but ended up with a real dud, this time.
summary: a dud...

reviewText: I don't know why it would say 45% humidity is low and 29% humidity is ok this don't seem very accurate to me.
summary: Not very accurate

reviewText:
Purchased in early April 2016 (almost two years ago), and put to use when received. Ive changed the Amazon Basics AA battery once, which I do with most of my battery-operated products every 6 or 12 months (especially with smoke detectors/alarms). I don't wait for batteries to die. I appreciate how quickly the readings are available. For instance, I can walk from one part of my first floor home to the other, and see the difference in temperature and humidity readings within seconds. The digital numbers are easy to read as long as I have on my glasses and Im not in the dark. Theres a tiny white button located on the back that les you choose Fahrenheit or Celsius. I would definitely buy this Acurite model again*. I paid $3 more in 2016.

HOW ACCURATE ARE THE READINGS? I can tell if the readings are accurate by comparing different areas of my home where it is obvious (see messy images) that the humidity is really high. In Miami, FL, I doubt Ill ever witness a really low humidity reading room in my old home.  I have a large window that needs to be replaced (the whole darn thing, glass and frame). It allows outside weather conditions (heat and more heat) to seep right into my home. Yep, already added that ugly and cheap plastic sheeting over the frame, but its not helping enough.

WHY I BOUGHT THIS: I use this meter, mostly it seems, just to annoy myself. LOL!  Im not using for growing indoor plants or any other casually scientific reason. I just like to know why I feel like crapnothing escapes the effects of dampness in the air, the dampness that can easily make me feel miserable, the dampness that requires me to cleanly wipe down even more crap. On a positive note, its easy to turn on the air conditioner (sometimes using the free air circulation) to help reduce these issues. Until I can find a person willing to empty bins of water for me every single day, I cant be bothered with dehumidifiers. Nobody in their right mind leaves stagnant water in Miami (mosquitos will find it).

For those trying to learn the most basic humidity examples: Very low humidity can cause dry skin, nosebleeds, and who knows what else. Very high humidity can help improve plant growth, improve mold growth (you don't want that), but can also cause a person to feel uncomfortable and/or sweaty.

(*) AcuRite 00613 Humidity Monitor with Indoor Thermometer, Digital Hygrometer and Humidity Gauge Indicator
summary: 1 year and 8 months later, maintains accuracy.

reviewText: Great little accurate device. Love that its mobile...can take it anywhere.
summary: Five Stars

reviewText: I bought this AcuRite monitor to help safeguard my daughter's expensive wooden string instruments. We live in the Mid-Atlantic region, so outside humidity fluctuates greatly with the seasons. This monitor helps warn us when it's necessary to use case and/or room humidifiers for the instruments due to harmfully low humidity. It's inexpensive and has proven to be very accurate when compared to other hygrometers and thermostats. I even tested it against other hygrometers among different rooms with varying humidity levels. It was always consistent in both humidity and temperature with the other devices. I included a photo of one test against a ThermoPro TP55 Indoor Thermometer Humidity Monitor with Jumbo Touchscreen and Backlight Digital Hygrometer with Temperature Gauge Humidity Meter. You can see the readings were virtually identical. In fact, by the time I took and uploaded the photo, both devices registered the same exact temperature and humidity. They were already so close, it wasn't worth replacing the pic. The historical highs and lows are different because the two devices are normally used in different rooms with different temperatures and humidity levels.
summary: Accurate and inexpensive

reviewText: I have had one of these for many years and assumed it was accurate. I moved into a townhouse and I have excess moisture in my basement and had to buy a de humidifier to get rid of the moisture. I bought two more of these and have the three of them side by side. The temperature is the same on all three but there are three different readings for the humidity. I don't want to invest in another dehumidifier for my other floors if I don't have too. It is important because if it is 55% or above there is an issue. The three readings are 53 56 and 59. My first one on the left is the only one within the normal range. Does anyone know why this may happen.
summary: Not accurate

reviewText: I recently moved into a new apartment but felt the air was too dry inside and with it being mid winter, opening windows did not help at all. I bought this to see how dry it was and to test a humidifier just recently purchased. Long story short it works. my first reading about 10 minutes out of the package was reading about 30%. I boiled water + had a humidifier running, and almost simultaneously as i can feel the change in the air the meter also was going up in percentage! great product to get an idea of  humidity in your home!

reviewText: It worked great, for exactly 34 days.  Then the numbers started disappearing.  See photo.  Makes use impossible.  New battery did not help.  Frustrating, because I did like it.
