reviewText: I'm using this in a homemade incubator to hatch eggs. The temperature and humidity have to be very precise in order for the chicks to develop. So far this gauge has been spot on. It updates quickly and records highs and lows.  Perfect for my needs.
summary: Great for an Incubator

reviewText:
I bought two of these to compare humidity in two apartments. I thought I would sit them together so I could callibrate any differences. See the photo for how they are right out of the box.

Probably just a case of one bad unit, but that doesn't help me today, when I was counting on using them. And, I don't even really know which one to send back, or if the one that's more likely right is close to actually being right.
summary: At least one is way off out of the box, or maybe both...

reviewText: I got this for my room to monitor temp/humidity. I seem to get reasonable temp/humidity. I have to complain about the magnet though, it seems to fall off real easily.
summary: Monitors Room

reviewText:
Performed a 24 hour salt calibration test. Reading 74% vs the 75% Calibration.
I'd say 1% accuracy on a $10 electronic instrument is pretty darn good!  As they say, a picture is worth a thousand words!
summary: Pretty Darn accurate!!

reviewText: I bought this because I built a "female cave" in part of our basement.  I love crafts and sewing so there is a lot of paper and fabric.  I also have a pet iguana that resides in this room.  I have to maintain a temperature suitable for him, but that won't destroy my things.  I have taken several precautions while building the room - including the installation of a reversible window fan in the wall.  His cage has a Monsoon that makes it rain every 12 hours.  He has a waterfall for drinking.  And a pool (litter box) that he uses as a litter box.  I cannot have dry heat because of him, but I can't have it too humid because of my projects.  This little gizmo is awesome.  I set it by his cage and it will tell me the high and low for both temperature and humidity over a period of a couple of hours.  Then I move it to the other side of the room (the room is 20 x 20) and it will tell me the information there.  It's very basic, lightweight, mountable (but I like it portable), and very easy to read.
summary: Bought for craft room / iguana room

reviewText: I got this to use in my classroom because sometimes it would get SO hot and I was curious to see. I LOVE that its magnetic and I can stick it on the board. It turns out that most Mondays my classroom was 91 degrees! I also really like how it shows the high and the low so I can see how hot it is getting in the building over the weekend (so I don't leave certain things there that could be damaged or melt). My students also love looking at this and seeing the temperature. I will probably order one of these for home too.
summary: Amazing!

reviewText: This hygrometer works great and has a nice large display. I can boil water from across my apartment (to humidify the air for my guitar) and easily see the reading go up. Consistent humidity readings, plus the high and low memory + temperature features are a welcome addition.
summary: Consistent readings, nice large display

reviewText: The LCD on this item has gone faulty after a month of sitting in a normal room. As you can see in the photo, the Humidity value is now un able to be read. Yes it can be implied, but that is not the point. Do not buy this item.
summary: LCD Display goes bad after just a month. Cheap piece of junk.

reviewText: Bought this to monitor humidity in my new Bighorn 19ecb gun safe. seems to work perfect for me and looks cool when in the safe ... easy to read from the door and you don't have to lean in or anything to see the large easy to read Humidity % number.
summary: Works fine in my new gun safe

reviewText:
Really good budget tweezers. They are all aligned quite well. The paint job is not great, but for the price, they can not be beat. Size labels on handle, covers for each tip.

The tips could be made a bit better by sanding them down a little. There are no grips/serrations inside of the tips, they are all smooth inside.
summary: Great tweezers!

reviewText:
Doesn't work well for me (using Flashforge Creator Pro with PEI bed). First layer doesn't stick well and lamination is not good. I tried different temperatures (up to 240c) but still not good. I had better success with other non black filaments from Hatchbox and  IC3D. I recently gravitate more and more to Hatchbox ABS filaments, better price and so far they all gave me very good printing results.

Edit: added a picture with sample prints with Hatchbox yellow, IC3D red, IC3D blue and IC3D black (the subject of my review). The IC3D black I got underperforms consistently, except for very simple models.
summary: First layer doesn't stick well and lamination is not good. I tried different temperatures (up to 240c) but ...

reviewText: This filament is just about perfect.  I've used it on a Printrbot Simple Metal with heated bed and a Rostock Max V2 and have had great results with both.  No clogs whatsoever and the prints come out very strong and very aesthetically pleasing.  The spool is very sturdy and the packaging leaves nothing to be desired.  Great stuff.
summary: Fantastic filament.  My new goto brand for ABS.

reviewText:
I purchased the filament along with the LulzBot Mini 3D printer and got printing within minutes. The filament has delivered consistent and great results every time.
For the price, the quality of the filament is surprising, so much that I bought additional comments.

I bought the filament and have more than half left even after printing over 10 large prints and numerous small ones.

In the pictures attached (both files from Thingiverse), Grumpy T-Rex is the IC3D 3mm ABS 3D Printer Filament 2lb Natural default colour. The Pacman and Blinky are IC3D 3mm ABS 3D Printer Filament 2lb Natural painted with enamel paint (used for model aircraft/Airfix painting) which the filament takes well and has good results.
summary: Reliable and great results

reviewText:
These are good-quality syringes. They have a solid construction, are clearly labeled, come individually wrapped in sterile wrappers, and can survive re-usage/cleaning for eJuice. They are also the perfect size to refill many of the 3ML carto tanks. I did not expect these to be nearly such good-quality given how inexpensive these are. I use them for filling with eJuice and I can use these over and over and over again and they keep working flawlessly.

With that said, the product I was sent is NOT a blunt tip, but rather a sharpened one. As another reviewer noted, blunt tip implies that the outer tip itself is not sharpened (but the needle end is still angled & pointed.) However, the tips on mine are without question sharpened with a "standard bevel." For my usage that isn't an issue, but it does require careful usage because the lightest touch against skin and these will go right into you.

Multiple sellers are offering the same product in this listing, and I believe this presents a problem because the maker/model that is being sent may vary by which seller you purchase this listing from. The images shown here and the text description contradict each other. The image used for this listing shows a "blunt end" (that is, the end is flat). The text used to describe this product says "blunt tip" (that is, the end is angled but the tip is NOT sharpened.) The needles I got were sharpened (that is, they are angled on a standard bevel and the tip itself has been sharpened.) Therefore, while I can say that the needles I got were excellent quality, I think there is a potential for variation in what product you will receive.

I have attached a few images showing the the product I received. While not the greatest quality, hopefully they are good enough to show that the bevel itself is sharpened.
summary: Good quality, hold up great for eJuice, excellent value, but NOT blunt tipped - mine have a sharpened standard bevel

reviewText: Beware!  These are not the size that is advertised on Amazon or as stated on the packaging.  The holes for the [3/16"] terminals are actually 5/16" and the [5/16"] terminals are actually 3/8".  They appear as expected but much larger than they are supposed to be.  I will be returning them because they are much too large to work with the DC power studs on the AC inverter I had intended to use them with.
summary: Much larger than advertised and not in a good way.

reviewText:
I cannot say enough good things about this printer.

I have been using this for the last few months making production parts for a small startup. It is incredibly reliable and I consistently print for 10+ Hrs between bed swaps and run two of these batches daily.

The perf-board beds make all the difference. They require no maintenance and are easy to remove parts from. You get 3 and this allows for rapid swaps. The printer software even has a "print again" command that simply repeats the print. You need a computer to do send the command, but you don't have to re-send the file which means less time spent near the printer.

From what I gather this printer works best with ABS. The only negative reviews seem to be with PLA. I don't print in PLA ever, but can imagine problems arising when switching between the two filaments, especially when the perf-board is considered

Ive used a Lulzbot Taz 4.0 and have to say, without this printer I would have thought ABS was impossible to print with. This situation is more of a complete failing of lulzbot with their hot ends (purchased January 2015 and it is incapable of printing in ABS). That printer is over $2k so I was sure it was a failing of the material. If you get the UPmini, say goodbye to wholesale delamination and parts detatching from the bed or preparing the bed in whatever way.

ABS printing IS DANGEROUS in terms of fumes. The enclosure seems to cut down on some of the smell. I added a little carbon scrubber on the top of the machine (See picture) This seems to help a lot in reducing the smell. I still don't print in my home and instead print remotely in a small work trailer with an exhaust fan. Do not use this in a place where people spend a significant amount of time.

Will likely add more details but overall I highly recommend this printer.
summary: Insanely good

reviewText: Just right! I purchased these for my emergency kits (home and car) but will toss one in the bag for camping as well. These individual Disposable Thermometers are so thin and light that they would work great for backpack camping with kiddos when space and weight matter most. I have tried one and it works as noted. As you can see from the pictures, the degrees noted are the typical range needed (which isn't much of a sway). It will  definitely clue someone into whether or not you're running a fever or another extreme.
summary: These individual Disposable Thermometers are so thin and light that they would work great for backpack camping with kiddos when

reviewText: I purchased this for my home emergency kit not to long ago. All in all it seems to be a good product for the price. I have used it once now after having touched a cookie sheet on accident (So i wanted a quick taste!) and I can say it did lessen the pain caused from the burn. However, I did have to keep applying it every few minutes to keep the pain away. Eventually I stopped using it for the burn and later that day and the next, you couldn't tell where I had been burnt from touching the sheet. I will say this, there is lots of advice out there which states you should not use burn creams or sprays in certain burn circumstances. I'm not an EMT or medical professional and wouldn't know when to not use this spray. Most likely, though I'm no pro, it shouldn't be used for extensive 2nd or 3rd degree burns. That said, this item is included in many emergency kits online.
summary: All in all it seems to be a good product for the price

reviewText: Just what I needed although the price is a bit high. After having purchased these, I happened to go into my local dollar store and see the almost exact same thing (different brand), but for a buck instead of $9. Do yourself a favor, look around first. If you cannot find these elsewhere, these appear to be a great product.
summary: these appear to be a great product.

reviewText:
I own both, the smaller basic meter (BAFX3370 dBA only) and the larger (BAFX3608 dBA/dBC) advanced meter.

PROS
1) Gets you some good data for how loud your neighbor's really are, and whether or not you should evacuate before the loudness causes hearing damage.
2) Has a nicely and easily readable lit display, including light sensor for usage within dark or dimly lit areas.
3) For the ADVANCED BAFX3608 dBA/dBC meter: Although Windows only, the software is made by "Sound Lab" and titled "Sound Level Meter", and is a nice simple tool, and easily comprehensible or easily utilized tool, as well as apparently being packaged without bloated software and/or software features.
4) For the ADVANCED BAFX3608 dBA/dBC meter: When connected via USB ports, the device is automatically powered through the USB port.
5) For the ADVANCED BAFX3608 dBA/dBC meter: If you so desire, you can stand at your window or outside your door holding this very large meter for the next door neighbors to readily see you're have issues with their noise!  (I wonder if anybody also sells any flags stating a person is going to file a civil complaint?)
6) For the ADVANCED BAFX3608 dBA/dBC meter: This dBC capable device performs much better than the dBA capable devices, and significantly notices the lower-frequency noise range displayed by small 4-cycle engines.

CONS
1) Familiarize yourself with the peak level button, else you may find you're not getting the results you desired.
2) No adjustment for auto shut-off power saving feature.  (ie. If you plan to leave this device for more than a few minutes, the device auto powers off.)
3) For the ADVANCED BAFX3608 dBA/dBC meter, the unit does not allow the users to specify the initial on state of the readings.  For example, the unit defaults to dBA and fast reading when initially turned-on.  I prefer to always take readings using dBC and slow, mainly dBC as this tends to detect the lower frequency range better than dBA and selecting slow/average readings to average in anomalies versus readily seeing a distracting spiked sound anomaly.  Likely when recording, the slow reading option maybe more desirable unless you're trying to monitor for very short bursts of sounds such as gun shots, and then faster readings are desired in order to capture the short bursts of sound.
4) For the ADVANCED BAFX3608 dBA/dBC meter, although already heavily specified Windows Only software, such a simple device should be able to output using libUSB (and likely does so already) simple streams of data that can be easily piped into a text file for graphing by other open sourced tools.  (I'll have to use WireShark to further examine the protocol used, whether serial or libUSB.  USB Vendor Device ID is 64bd:74e3 "SM".)
5) For the ADVANCED BAFX3608 dBA/dBC meter, the hardware manual states possible to  sync the time with the computer when connected via USB, but no option appears to exist.
6) For the ADVANCED BAFX3608 dBA/dBC meter, a pamphlet packaged with the device gives a download URL for downloading a copy of the software (eg. SLVersion2.exe), but this is really an old copy of the software dated 2015.10.07, and the newest version (as of this writing) is already packaged inside the box of the device, using a small mini CDROM.  (The version on the mini CDROM is SoundLabSetup20160720.exe, or dated 2016.07.20)

Would really be nice to have a USB feature for computer logging, or memory for logging, and easily transferring (regardless of operating system) to a computer for hard copy.  (This feature is now implemented within the larger Advanced BAFX Decibel Meter.)

NOTES: The ADVANCED BAFX3608 dBA/dBC meter contains a usb SILICON LABS C8051F320 8051 8-bit Microcontroller hub chip, with the firmware registering the device under Windows' Device Manager as both, a HID-COMPLIANT DEVICE and USB INPUT DEVICE.  The device's USB product vendor and model USB id's are 64bd:74e3 "SM".  The device contains a likely closed soure firmware, likely incorporating some minimal addressing with arguments commands to initiate retrieving recorded records, ordering the device to start sending live data, and commands for getting the current time and sending the current time.  If I had more time, I would provide some C code to perform these functions, but this is tedious work versus having the specifications or already written code.  The hardware manufacturer should be providing the firmware specifications (eg. PDF) for communicating to the device via ASM/C programming code. (eg. Uniden provides specifications for their firmware used on their hardware products, although sometimes difficult to find.)

ATTACHED: Attaching an image comparing an apparently older basic BAFX sound decibel meter alongside the newer larger BAFX sound decibel meter.
summary: Works for me!

reviewText: Great wood screws!  Self tapping with a T25 head is hard to beat.  This was my first purchase of the WoodPro screws, and I plan to order quite a few different sizes.  Used these this weekend to put together a round kitchen table base!  These came packaged well in a clear plastic container with a small baggie containing a T25 screw bit!  Overall, very pleased!
summary: Self Tapping, T25 Head ~ Great Wood Screws!

reviewText:
Wow, really nice and heavy. Not something easily found these days. Robust and with real non-slip pads on the bottom.

However, although it is rated for 250 volts, it only has the ability to connect (normally open - NO) or disconnect (normally closed - NC) one electrical connection.

Unless there something I don't understand, there is no way this could control a standard 240 volt circuit (e.g., a 240 volt drill press) in the US, which would require a DPST (double pole, single throw) switch inside to handle both hot wires.

[EDIT: It appears 'normal' to only switch off one of the legs in a 240 volt circuit. The other leg is energized, so one has to hope that doesn't ever short out. This seems 'risky' to me, but apparently the experts/code allows for it...]
summary: Impressive for 120 volts, questionable for 240 volts

reviewText:
After using this tape for my recent head unit install, I can't go back to using electric tape again. Although electric tape can be useful in many automotive applications, I have found in certain applications -- such as wrapping wires under the engine bay -- it gets very gooey easily and is a pain in the you know what to undo. This Tesa tape is heat resistant (221 F) and wrapped around itself very easily with no gooey mess left behind. It has been useful when wrapping the amplifier power wire under the engine bay that I ran from the (+) battery terminal post to the vehicle interior. Moreover, it gives the installation a professional look.

** Note **

There are different models of Tesa tape so make sure to to get the one that fits your usage. For example, if you want to predominantly use this under your engine bay, then the Tesa 51026 or 51036 would be great as they are heat resistant up too 302 F. But if you want to use this mainly in cooler temperatures -- such as around the home or the passenger area of a vehicle -- then the Tesa 51608 or 51606 (which are cheaper) would more than suffice as they are heat resistant up too 221 F.
summary: Can't go back to electric tape after using this

reviewText:
After using this tape for my recent head unit install, I can't go back to using electric tape again. reviewText: Added this to a EMB I put together. As a former Firefighter and EMT, this is a must have item. All in photos were purchased from Amazon
summary: Added this to a EMB I put together. As ...

reviewText: For the price, this is the ABSOLUTE best 3D printer.  It  handles pretty much any material, it's quiet, relatively fast, SOLID, made in the USA, and is backed by a top-notch company who knows how to provide customer service. Here's an example.  I had a small hiccup with loading the filament.  I shot them an email and they responded in 5 minutes! In the attached photo, I'd since added the optional LCD display with SD card reader. This is an optional add-on I got from the manufacturer's web site.
summary: If you're wondering which 3D printer to buy - BUY THIS ONE!

reviewText:
Great printer so far.  I have had it going 2 weeks straight and working almost constantly.  The latest V4 hotend is great!  I was going to make my own until I took a closer look and realized it would be difficult to improve upon outside of special applications and without a lot of effort and cost.

May I strongly recommend to all who own this excellent printer a very useful upgrade:

Used this: http://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B005RTGDKU?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s02

and a http://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B00A9N1D5E?redirect=true&ref_=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_71

for a z-stop upgrade to make it much easier to adjust.  I thought of other ways to do it but this works so well and was so so easy!  That little default z-stop bolt and I did not get along.  I hated it.  I get the point of it's placement and design but it was a pain to adjust, access, and do anything with.  That is just my opinion and like I said I get it and don't blame Makergear for the design decision.

  I measured this to be similar/slightly shorter than the stock bolt it came with.  I put this product with the larger head upward to contact the switch and I used the other product I linked below the tapped hole in the aluminium plate.

Just in case you are doing unusual stuff with your print bed:  You Probably can't use more than a 3/8" thick bed if you ever tried to replace the glass with something that thick.

This printer deserves is reputation!  It is solid, reliable, and well designed.  Most of all aside from the reviews what made sense to me is that if you are going to adjust a printbed and calibrate your prints where distances of under .1mm can matter.  (Or a fraction the width of a hair) do you really want to even try to do that with a wooden framed, cheap, low quality printer?  I don't!  Getting the software/slicer settings dialed in isn't a walk in the park and there are plenty of other little tasks that are frequent to 3d printing and I don't think it is worth anyone's time or frustration to deal with any more than they absolutely have to!  I have hundreds and hundreds of hours on this printer and it has been reliable, not jams, clogs, blockages, or other issues.  I have heard and read very good things about the company's support but I have not had to ask them for any help with anything so far.  (I bought mine directly from Makergear and it shipped quickly and was packed well.  )

One more well intended and hopefully helpful product tip for M2 users:  It isn't the cheapest thing but I can't imagine not having a "zebra plate" print bed.  I ordered it directly from the OEM from their site.  I don't think it is available from Amazon but I could be wrong or that could change.  The stock glass is best for some things but I needed to print some larger 7+ inch diameter round rigid structurally stable prints in ABS and other materials and the zebra plate is so perfect.  I have been gentle with it and tried to dial in the proper 1st layer reduced height sometimes to squish things on there when I need to but wow....it is so worth it's rather comparatively intimidating price.  Things stick on and they come off wonderfully when you get the hang of it which is fast and easy.  The stock glass is great, the zebra plate was just different.  I will try other plates and update if I find something I like as much as I like those two options.  I haven't tried it with nylon yet, so I have no idea if it works for that.

I hope the other product info is helpful, I have always found extremely helpful reviews and user tips on Amazon and wanted to contribute what made my printing experience much better in combination with this printer.
summary: If you think the z-stop could be easier to adjust and want to upgrade it read on!

reviewText:
This is an excellent machine for you if you are just getting started in 3D printing.

The M2 is solid as a rock. The supports are all steel and the rails are heavy aluminum, it's built in the USA, and although some of the plastic covers and knobs are actually printed on the machine, they are quite sturdy. The machine weighs in at about 30 pounds or so, making it very stable. If you are a mechanically-minded sort you can buy the kit for a few hundred bucks less, but I do recommend letting them build your machine for you.  They will test it completely and use it to print out (some extremely excellent) samples before they send it to you, so you are assured of having everything calibrated correctly, and they do a much better job of wrapping wires up and making everything look tidy than a beginner would be able to do. The packaging is excellent, there was no need to adjust anything out of the box. Just check the calibration and get on down the road.

On the minus side, it's rather a noisy little thing. (Not a dealbreaker though. Earplugs.)

When I spend this much money on anything, customer service is a critical component, and frankly it's part of what I'm paying for.  The MakerGear support is superior, period. I had two questions/issues after office hours, but I got a response on each of them, not the next day as I was expecting, but once within a couple of hours, and once within about five minutes. And they actually followed up. These guys REALLY care about their product and they want their customers to have a good experience. It shows.

(They also carry all of the parts for their machines in-house, and don't have to wait for delivery from beyond Timbuktu.)

The MakerGear Forum is a goldmine. There are guys there who have been doing this from the get-go, and they are very patient with what must be the thousandth time that they've had to answer the same questions. That kind of resource is invaluable, and again, it's part of what you are paying for.  I highly recommend checking out the forum for more information on the M2.

(Couple of samples of the output are shown in the photos.  Quality of the prints is excellent, even from a complete beginner.)

Update: 3/7/2016

Coming up on a year of ownership now, and you wouldn't recognize the initial machine.  It's been upgraded twice, and is now a Dual Extruder M2, which increases the pure "fun" level exponentially.  I tend to print with PLA (or other low temp filaments) out of one nozzle, and PETG (or higher temp filaments) out of the other, so it's like having two printers set up and ready to go, with the space requirements of one. (I can also run dissolving filament as support if I want to, or just print a two color print with the same filament type.  Many, many additional options with the dual setup.)

In all that time, I've only "had" to level the machine once, (with a couple of small tweaks as I switched to different plates).  I've never even had any of the printed ABS parts break, after hundreds of prints.  It still puts out "near" perfect prints, and the qualifier there is on me, not the machine.  This was definitely one of my "chose very wisely" calls.
summary: Fear not, Beginners!

reviewText:
These are decent probes.

The trim pot on the BNC is the weakest part of these probes. I had to exchange a pair due to the low quality of it on two probes. On one probe, I could not adjust it enough to get a decent reference signal. On the other probe, it adjusted crazy high and was really hard to set, and it would only adjust clockwise. I suggest you test this and make sure it is not faulty on the pair you receive.

After receiving a replacement, I was able to get 2 probes that adjust adequately. One adjusts quite nicely, the other has less range for adjustment, but does well enough.

Included adjustment tool is garbage, a screwdriver will do much better. It's not like you're going to hit anything crucial with a screwdriver on the BNC housing...

Alligator clips are removable, and provided ground spring can be attached on the tip instead.
The spring wire clip is a little on the flimsy side, through it gets the job done. There are two little caps to be used along side the grounding screw, but their design is a bit odd. You can punch a hole in them and feed the spring through, and it will work a bit nicer... Or just make your own spring and cut it to length with some old leads/wire.
Color rings are not fancy, and are not long enough to completely snap around the probe, but they get the job done.

2x switchable 1/10 probes for 13$ is a crazy good deal if you get ones that work properly.
summary: Decent probes for the price

reviewText:
One of the most useful pieces of test equipment I own. The ability to display watts without doing the math is great.  - the three channels are all within spec for my unit. Changing parameters is easy. I have not used any of the more fancy functions, but just the general power supply features are worth the price.

One nice thing is that the screen does not have to be red, you can adjust the colors - its just not fancy multicolored. I have mine set to white.
summary: One of the most useful pieces of test equipment I own

reviewText:
This is a very flexible power supply and has a decent UI.  The rotary keypad is odd, as others have commented and I'm not sure why Rigol chose this since there other stuff has a normal layout.  You might see some complaints on places like the EEVblog about overheating but in my unit (made July 6, 2015, this is not a problem.  This unit also has firmware 1.14 which corrects some other issues you might read about.

Why not 5 stars?  Simple, this supply arrived with channel 1 significantly out of calibration.  That is the voltage you set using the keypad was neither the voltage you got or the voltage you read on the display.  There are calibration procedures available in a manual you can download from Rigol NA's website.  Have a 5 1/2 digit DMM available and be prepared to spend some time with the 40 point procedure.  Now the instrument is correct for all three channels +/- about 15 mV.  If you do this, the password for the manual calibration is "2012"  It was odd that only channel 1 was off.

Another issue that most likely will not bother most users is the presence of a 12-14 Vrms AC voltage between each of the output terminals and chassis ground.  Most of the time you would not care since you would want the DC output to float with regard to ground (be isolated) but this is still odd.  See the attached scope output
summary: Good power supply with some quirks

reviewText:
best 50 $ ive spent all year sure it doesnt have a fine and coarse adjuster thats separate so just be careful when changing the voltage that you don't over do it like i did and fry your LEDs. i recommend getting the banana mini grabber as well for only 5 dollars more.
ive been using it for two months without any problems.
summary: best 50 $ ive spent all year sure it doesnt ...

reviewText:
It's a couple of weeks before Memorial Day and my canopy rips in the backyard.  One of those easy setup models.  I'd rather wait for Memorial Day sales to buy a new one, so I thought I'd check out Gorilla tape as a fix.  Since it's clear, it really doesn't look bad for Southern engineered.  Put it back up and wouldn't you know that the West Texas wind got up, blew the whole canopy with screenhouse around.  But, the tape holds!
Impressed so far!
August - Trip to Ruidoso I made the mistake of leaving the canopy up at night. (I thought mountains, no wind.)  Next morning, the canopy had been picked up and moved about 6 feet, landing twisted the metal poles.  BUT, the canopy with repaired with Gorilla tape still holds.  Not touched by the wind and the landing.  I'd give this stuff 10 stars at this point.
summary: Impressed so far!  Really impressed now....

reviewText: Love this tape- it's like the Duct tape gods decided to give people a new lease on life. Great stickiness, thick and strong. I used this to laminate some cork as a airtight seal on my 3D printer bed. Also tape random stuff just because I can. reviewText: Tried to use this to patch an Aerobed with a *ridiculous* sized hole. It definitely helped a LOT, but there's no way it was going to patch it sufficiently once weight was on the bed. But it was a HUGE difference from having no patch vs having the patch so I imagine this might be useful for other purposes. I'm just not sure any inflatable that is going to have weight on it would work for this.

reviewText: Great vacuum it gets all kind of dust and everything you need off of carpet and hardwood. The detail kit helps a lot with vacuuming curtains Shades and stairways. The one thing that I don't like about it is that it is very top-heavy because of this it falls frequently, other than that it is a great vacuum I have a large dog and it does a great job getting hair off of furniture and carpet.  I do love this vacuum other than its weight distribution issues

style.Style Name:: VT04 Infrared Imager with Soft Carrying Case

reviewText:
I've been using the HVAC Load+ iPhone app to enter a detailed list for the block load to figure out the heating and cooling.  Walls, ceilings, windows, internal gain, etc.  But this calculation is always a little bit theoretical.  Now with this Fluke FLK-VT104 I can actually see the regions contributing to heating or cooling losses from across the room!

I posted a couple saved images to the customer photos section.  Here you can actually see where the attic beams are in an uninsulated attic.  These beams provide a tiny bit of insulation so the ceiling directly below the beams appear as blue-purple lines on the VT104.  I wonder if I could use this as a ceiling stud-finder!  This is great in case there are any gaps in the insulation, this tool will find the insulation gaps (easiest to find on the very hot or cold days).

Don't just leave this on the default settings.  Play around with some of the menu settings because you can get dramatically different views using the color palette and image blending %.  Some settings that you can adjust that affect the measurement include the emissivity of the materials and the background temperature.

The included CD contains the SmartView software to download captured images from the micro SD card.  Don't install the CD but rather download the latest version from the Fluke website (Support / Software Downloads) so that you get the very latest version of the SmartView application.  This allows you to change the color palette and blending (and other image manipulation) after the image capture so you don't have to worry about getting these settings perfect in the field.

The first thing to do after you open the box and fully charge the device - update the firmware on the Fluke website (Support / Software Downloads), since the device ships with an older firmware.  This is a simple download that you copy onto the micro SD card and then the VT104 will prompt you to update when it powers on.  The firmware contains various improvements to the device features.

I highly recommend the VT104 for pinpointing actual heating and cooling loss locations rather than relying on theoretical data or guesswork.
summary: Excellent for HVAC trouble spots

reviewText:
As expected. Excellent scouring pads.

Finest pads available, one notch finer than 0000 steel wool.
summary: Multiple Uses- Mighty Fine

reviewText:
It heats up very well up to 120 degrees in less than 10 minutes, however, the coating on the outside is very thin and slightly clamping it to your printer may cause the paint to rub off exposing the copper traces.  Depending on your design, this may cause your 12V or 24V to run through your entire printer and burn out some of your electronics.  It melted my USB cables, my USB port on my Macbook Pro and and fried the communication chips on 3 of my RUMBA boards before I found out where the short was coming from.

Based on the damage this product has caused me I wouldn't recommend anyone buy it.  If you do buy this, however, I would highly recommend isolating it wholly with Kapton tape.

I would recommend an alternate supplier for this board but make sure that the resistance for 12V is between 1.0-1.5Ohms MAX.
summary: BE CAREFUL!  CAUSED over $500 WORTH OF DAMAGE

reviewText: Works great. Made a RIMS controller with this unit. So far it's solid. Kinda like the STC 1000 however this does not have 2 separate relays like the STC unit. Not an issue for me as 1 relay was sufficient. I paired this with a SSR as this is only rated for 10 amps and my heating element draws more current than this unit is able to handle on its own.  Manual is pretty bad, but if you have used PID controllers this is pretty elementary.  Quality seems identical to the STC unit and the probe seem to be accurate enough, it is NOT submersible, you need a thermowell if using this for measuring liquid temps. You cant beat the price.
summary: Good simple controller for various projects.

reviewText: Using this for a 7' motorized camera slider.  Works great.
summary: Works great.

reviewText:
This is a pretty good filament and I had no issues extruding it using my GStar Dual Extruder Printer. The temperature I used for the extruder is 235C with a heat bed temp of 80C. During the print I randomly used my caliper to measure the filament and it would range from 1.71mm at the lowest and 1.82mm at the highest which would put the tolerance at  0.07mm which is pretty decent. Otherwise it would be pretty consistent from 1.73mm to 1.75mm. My first print with this filament I decided to print a controller holder. During the print I did notice some popping and noticed a few air pockets on my print from air bubbles within the filament.

Print settings and tested tolerance
3D Printer: GStar Dual Extruder
Slicing Software: Simplify3D
Tolerance:  0.07mm
Temp Used: 235C
Heat Bed: 80C
Print Time: ~ 3 hours
Filament Length used for print: 16231.3mm
Measured amount: 20 readings at random times of print
Lowest number read: 1.71mm
Hight number read: 1.82mm

Pros:
+  0.07mm tolerance
+ Nice black color
+ Extrudes easily on the

Cons:
- Does have a couple of air bubbles within the filament in roll I received for the length printed.

Overall it is a pretty good roll and comparable to other 3D filaments available. Despite a few air bubbles within the filament in the length used for the print, it is still a pretty good filament. I will update this review if I have any future issues.

Disclaimer: I received this product at a discounted price in exchange for my honest unbiased review. All opinions are 100% my own.
summary: This is a pretty good filament and I had no issues extruding it ...

reviewText:

Both units when adjusted & correctly used are very accurate checked against a thermocouple probe. I'm not associated with this product

reviewText:
this is much closer to the LP record Vinyl. Stiff, VERY stiff.

Don't get me wrong, this is a VERY useful, handy, tool to have around.  Does exactly what it's purported to do.  I'm going to order a second one 'cause it's easier to carry a balanced load/pair of batteries when I can.

I modified mine a bit to make it more comfortable to use (strap material comforms to my hand so it's not like holding some medieval inquisitor's torture device) and easier to store in my tool box with other battery-related paraphernalia like a post/clamp brush and hygrometer.

Just used some 1" nylon braided strap I had on hand, a soldering iron to melt holes for military-surplus "cherry max" rivets, and now it's exactly what I would expect I'd be buying.

I'll keep the vinyl strap though; I put it on a heating mat I'm using for starting seeds and flattened it out so I can use it as a pry bar for removing truck tires or something.
summary: Vinyl.  The stuff of pool mattresses and 33rpm LP records.

reviewText:

reviewText: High quality, and work exactly as described. I used this to monitor a water storage tank to shut off circulating pump if the tank drains all the way down. Remember, you need to use a relay (cheap enough to find) to actually control the device. In my case I was using a pair of 12v mini circulating pumps. I mounted the sensor in a removable, threaded plug in case I need to service/replace it. See photos. Works great!
summary: Great Water Level sensor

reviewText:
I actually purchased the 2X for work (2 head, 2 color) 3D printer for work. It was such an incredible tool I bought a Replicator 2 for my house. What can I say? This thing can make almost anything. Well, there is a learning curve to do that. First, this is a revision 1 machine and that means it comes with all the problems a first release will have. Some issues can be as simple as not leveling (tramming) the build plate correctly to machines that are DOA. This is a complicated device with both electronics and mechanical devices that can be knocked out of alignment because of rough shipping. They (Makerbot) were also having teething issues with both machines. Loose screws, random items installed incorrectly, an extruder with a problematic tension system. Here's the thing that I found out when I got mine. Some people have a problem with "X" and yet other people never have a problem with "X"....the only thing that was repeatable was the Delrin Extruder needed to be upgraded..it was so apparent that Makerbot now sells the upgrade (but aren't putting in the machines yet probably because they need to get rid of parts inventory). There is also a learning curve on the software. You need to be able to use basic CAD. That's the reason you want a 3D printer right? Various CAD out there..some free (Google SketchUp OpenScad) but I like Cubify Invent. $50 is cheap for a full CAD and Invent is great because it was built from the ground up for 3D printing...not designing houses or modify Ford engines. Then you have to have a mechanical bend to you....you can't just sacrifice a chicken and cool parts fall out of the printer.

Now, after all that you're probably thinking "Wait..he gave it 5 stars?"

Sure did...I own a machine shop with large CNC equipment...but the Replicator is an entirely new way of producing goods. Not only that but I work with CAD all day...so, for me, it's easy to sit down and design art...or print out scanned works of art...or make small parts for around the house...you are (almost) only limited in your imagination. There is also soft rubbery filament you can get, wooden plastic filament, and nylon (STRONG!) filament you can buy. Even though this tech has been around since the 80's and there are professional machines out there that can do incredible things, only within the last few months has their been a product/price point like this. Yes, the kits have been around for a while (2?3? years?) but I wanted something I could take out of the box and learn on. My 2X was making parts from the minute I turned it on. I have sold 2 jobs at work on it and produced in house test jigs for several products we make.

Again, this is not a magic box that you wave a wand at and loving goodness falls out. This is a tool every bit as useful and complicated as a minature CNC machine. You need a certain skill set or the willingness to learn. If you're an artist you'll need to learn some mechanical skills but I know of 3 people on Google Groups who are already selling original artwork from theirs.

"Tea, Earl Gray, Hot" (if you get the reference you need to go order one right now....)
summary: Makerbot Replicator 2...a creative persons dream machine....

reviewText: Not a bad oscillator for the price.  Remember, most oscillators start at about $300 or more for the hobbyist level and range up into the tens of thousands of dollars.  Comes with two probes and the middle tab between the probes can be used to test the oscillator--it produces a square wave.  The accuracy for the price is fairly good and the software if pretty intuitive to use. If you are a hobbyist that doesn't have or want to spend $300 + for an oscillator, I think this would work.  I've included a screen shot of the oscillator software with the oscillator connected to the tab located between the probes that produces a square wave.

reviewText:
Free product provided for evaluation and review.

These scales are great for measuring herbs, or very small amounts of scrap metal, chemical powders, or small gems.  The LED is very easy to read.  They are easy to balance out and are accurate according to the 20 gram weight as well as comparing against my other small scales.  They weigh in grams, grains, and carats.

They come with a small 'pan' to place powder or jewels in, but I do find it is a bit small.  For instance, it was a bit difficult for me to weigh a 5 gram earring that was just made large and rigid because it would not fit.  The whole top surface of this scale doesn't weigh- just the small circle that is under the 'pan.' They only weigh up to 30 grams and they take 4 AAA batteries.
 The pan does have a nice little point on it for pouring material into a container after weighing.  It does come off, so it can be cleaned.
I do find them to be precise and easy to use.
summary: Easy to calibrate and use, I find them to be accurate and good for weighing small weights

reviewText:
PERFORMANCE
Ok so I'm reviewing the performance first so people won't get the wrong idea by my other observations.
It prints nearly as well as PLA and is nearly as easy to print with, on the exception of a few quarks. First off, it is very stringy. Complex parts or, parts with lots of holes (like say if you were printing a model of  swiss cheese) are riddled with strings. Iv'e heard printing hotter will help fix this. But I find that many of my pieces look like they've collected cob webs in a attic for 20 years. I've also had some discoloration issues with red. White works really well for me.

STICKING TO THE BED
If you're printing on glass, do not use blue tape. Just use a glue stick straight on the glass. Very important with longer and larger parts to print with brims. After the PVE glue and the brims, simply use a nuclear bomb to separate your print from the print bed.

OTHER THOUGHTS
It's expensive, nearly 4x what I'm paying for PLA or ABS. It's very strong. A bit heavy, which also means you get less out of the 1lb spool than a normal 1lb spool. Make sure you visit the made solid PET+ printing tips page.

WHY DO I USE PET+?
I'm an engineer, I use PET+ because PLA is nearly useless to me as it cannot withstand hardly any heat. ABS prints like junk, so this is sort of the best of both worlds.

COMMENT IF YOU HAVE THE SAME PROBLEM
Ok so shortly after blowing through a couple of spools my printer was having huge extruding issues. I'm not sure if it's my printer, or if this plastic has jammed my extruder beyond repair. IDK
summary: Anyone else with this problem?

reviewText: Tap is completely defective, there is 0 lead angle on the threads (there is NO helix, see the attached picture) which basically turns this tap into a roughing end mill. I ended up destroying an expensive intake manifold trying to tap it. Upon closer examination each of the 4 lands is cut exactly the same, which instead of making 14 threads per inch, it would make 14 equally spaced grooves per inch.
summary: Tap is completely defective, cut wrong!

reviewText: This filament has both pros and cons. The biggest pro is that it is quite rigid yet shows no signs of cracking or shattering even when I manhandle it a bit more than I should. The biggest con is that the uniformity of the diameter is somewhat high. The uniformity however is not so high that it messes too much with the tolerance of my printed parts. I've not had a chance to use up the entire reel of this filament, but I have printed a good 40-50 hours of projects using it, and have had less failures than most of the other brands of filament I've used in the past.

reviewText: Fairly small, plastic foot switch without rubber grip pads on the bottom. Seems fine for basic usage, but not for heavy duty use. Soldering required to replace the pigtail at the switch. The switch is only good for 110 volt use in the US, as it is a SPCO (Single pole changeover), NOT DPST (Double Pole, Single Throw) as needed in the US for 240 volt use.
