reviewText:
I bought this for my pedal board (guitarist) actually. Every time I move my board in a soft case my pedal settings get whacked. This stuff is amazing. Does my board look unattractive? Perhaps, however my settings are locked down. There is a company that makes locking knobs for pedals but 4 of them are like $40+ dollars with shipping. I have far too much invested in my board already and this was a simple, easy, inexpensive fix.

Update: 8/26/15 Stuff still works great however over time it can become more difficult to peel up as it adhere's to the surface. So for musicians like me I would suggest using this as a temporary fix as I did until my flight case came in. While it has not caused any damage or residue in the short time I have used it on my pedal board, the increasing adherence as time goes on makes it harder to peel up to make fast adjustments on the fly.

Not to worry however, as I have let everyone know I have this marvelous tape in my gig bag for use if and when needed :)
summary: Even works on guitar pedal boards!

reviewText:
See my 2 Year, 1 Year and 6 month. Now a 5 star.

Monday I received my long awaited printer. I thought I would wait a couple of days until I had some experience and then post my thoughts. My first impressions were quite good. The unit looks good, well built with all wiring cleanly aligned and secured. My unit would not feed the filament at first so I sent an email to support and received a phone call within an hour, not many companies will do that. The support rep Charles and I went through a process of trying some things and finally found the problem with the extrusion head had been knocked off center during shipping. Once that was snapped back into place all worked as it should. My first print (white ABS filament comes with the printer) was their demo part, a miniature bird bath. It came out excellent. I then tried one of my SolidWorks parts saved in STL format and the printed parts came out terrible. Again, I emailed XYZ and received a prompt reply back from Charles to try and correct my STL files with this online free service, SAVE THIS ADDRESS you will need it if using STL files NETFABB CLOUD SERVICE. My parts were uploaded and emailed back to me within 5 minutes. It must be an automated process. You can also download a free program and do your own file corrections, no special talent needed. I then retried my parts and they came out great. This is for a product I am developing for one of my clients and the parts will be made from ABS. I have found standard stereolithography material (STL laser generated parts) are very accurate but 7% heavier than ABS. This product I am designing is very weight sensitive. So I now have all my prototype parts and will be building our first test unit. Here are some things that are not clear in the printer description:.

1. The replacement filament comes in a cartridge not rolls as shown on Amazon. The cartridge is single use and cannot be refilled.
2. The software does NOT have any drawing capabiliies. You will need a separate program to draw your parts, I use my CAD system SolidWorks.
3. There are no good instructions on how to use the printer software and what the various options will do to the printed part.
4. My experience with the support staff was quite good, quick return call and knowledgeable steps.
5. You will need a set of jewelers files if you want to do detailed touch ups.
6. Your STL files will most like need to be reformatted by a service such as this; NETFABB CLOUD SERVICE.
7. My OS is XP (now Win7 Pro). I had difficulties downloading, installing and then running the printer software due to my virus program. I use WebRoot and I had to spend quite some time to finally get it to allow the software to run. If you have problems try disabling your virus software and then enable after loading the printer software.

After I ran more parts and received some of the replacement filaments I ordered I will update my review. Right now I am quite pleased with the product. I took a star off due to the lack of operational instructions.

7 Day review:
I have had my printer for a week and it has run nearly non-stop. Many dozens of prototype parts have been produced for the models I am assembling, all with excellent results. I received a pre-ordered cartridge of black filament and went through the process of removing one filament (the white that came with the printer) and installing the new black cartridge. The process is smooth and without difficulties. To answer a question that had been posted, the printer ships with a 300 gm sample roll of white filament and the replacement cartridges are 600 gm. The printer tracks the filament use by total capacity in meters compared to amount remaining. The 600 gm equates to 240 meters.

The software has several different settings and trying them all in various combinations would take forever. There should be a manual on what the different settings will do to the finished part, again this is why I took the one star off. From my experience the default settings produce great parts. I have found that when I need more than one of certain part all that needs to happen is click on "import" as many times that you want a part and your parts will be staged on the table at the correct distance and placement. This is very helpful to not need to make multiple copies of the part in the original CAD or drawing program. I have made up to eight parts at once from a single design and all came out perfect.

Microsoft also sponsors a STL file correction service: netfabb.azurewebsites.net/.

Excellent product for the price! If I were still in engineering R&D management I would want one of these for perhaps every 3 engineers. This is a fantastic tool for trial and error and to learn what works.

One Month review:
Last one, I promise unless something goes terribly wrong. The printer has been running almost daily with absolutely no problems. I have gone through one and half filament cartridges with no binding, clogs or control issues. As I use the software it has become easier to configure the part for printing. I have needed to tighten the X belt (single screw) once and recalibrate the table perhaps four times. It is a fairly straight forward adjustment but can sometimes take several minutes due to the slow process for the automatic measurements to be read. I would recommend checking calibration before each big printing process. The system needs to heat up anyway so the check is well worth it.
One of the components I am making is a thin semi, square tube about  inch per side and 6 inches long. The walls are only 0.06" thick. The table is usually set up to print four of these at once. We are testing for various length configurations. I am finding the tubes come out absolutely straight for the entire length, no warps, bends or contour issues - as good as stereo lithography. I have also not used glue for the last 4 or 5 dozen parts. Once the bed cools down the parts pop right off. I am very happy with this purchase and it has paid for itself more than two times.

6 month update:

I would like to pass along some things that I have learned and solutions to some issues.
The printer has been run hundreds of hours since receipt. I have not experienced any failure, clogs, incomplete prints or any malfunctions - it has worked perfectly. The more I have used it the more I become familiar with how a part must be positioned to avoid warps, slippage or out of round situations.

I have recalibrated the bed many times, usually every 20 or so hours of runtime. The calibration is tedious and time consuming. I have found that many "999" error codes are due to the contact on the printer head missing the contact plates on the bed. This is where the "jog" command is needed and usually just the X direction. Watch the printer head and contact pin closely during your first calibration to be sure everything is in alignment. I have had to re-tighten the X belt once. If you notice circular parts becoming slightly oval your X belt probably needs to be tightened. XYZ has the procedure on their site.

Positioning of your parts is critical to a good part. Something that may be shaped like a cup should have the open part up even though the original position when imported will place it down.

An issue that began during the first set of parts is an accumulation of fibers sticking and then hardening on the extruder head. I first used a Dremel tool with a soft wire wheel to remove the hardened filaments but found a better solution.  I have silicone mold release (I use the Sprayon brand, found on Amazon but I am sure others will work as well) to coat the print head once it has been cleaned. The mold release is sprayed onto a Q-tip and coated onto the head. Try to avoid the contact pin but if you do coat it it is easily cleaned with a nail file using a light brush stroke. I have not had the problem since our first coating last March. I first tried a high temperature cooking oil that also worked well but decided on the mold release since it was on hand.

Occasionally I wish to make another part without waiting for the entire cool down cycle to complete. I let the finished part sit on the bed for about 5 minutes, pop it off and then simply turn the machine off, wait for 30 seconds and turn back on to start the next part. I usually do this while everything is still hot and the platform is in the raised position as this also reduces the heat up time. This technique has saved hours.

I have now found that I can get great parts directly from the SolidWorks STL cad files without going through the online correcting process I documented earlier. A lot of this is due to correct positioning of the part. I have seldom needed the "raft" or "supports" features when setting up the print routine.
If you plan to make multiple parts at once you will most likely need to add the "raft" call out, particularly if the part foot print is small, i.e.  " round or square. I have made up to 36 of same part in one run using the "raft".
I am extremely pleased with how this inexpensive machine has performed. If it is still functioning at one year I will update again.

One Year Follow-up, now 5 stars

I now have a year of use on my machine and the first thing I can say is following hundreds of satisfying builds, nothing has gone wrong. I have not had to replace or repair a single part. The initial setup required technical assistance for resetting the print head but since that simple task the printer has worked perfectly. I have calibrated the table several times and have gotten to a point where I can do this fairly quickly. After a few times you get a better feel for the adjustments. I have tightened the belts once. The parts I have fabricated go from complicated, proprietary prototypes for my clients to simple things used around the home for repairs/replacement of broken or worn out parts.
As an example, a close friend has an older home with vintage blinds. The blinds have complicated, plastic end caps that after years had started falling apart. He had one remaining complete part. I scanned the part (both sides) on a paper scanner and saved as JPEG photos. If using a standard scanner with a 3D part you need to do both sides and then combine to provide a complete pattern for your drawing program. I then brought the photos into Photoshop and combined them as one part. The photo was then brought into my CAD system where I merely drew lines and circles shown in the photo to make a 3D part. Obviously some height measurements are added the saved as an STL file. The part was not perfect in the first runs but could easily be modified until the final part is actually better than the original and he could chose colors. We made eighteen beautiful parts. I also made some new hangers for the blinds and increased the thickness where his had been broken and glued several times. (see CAD photos)
I continue to use the original software, 1.1.29.3 and firmware 1.1. G as I want to use other filaments that XYZ do not offer such as translucent by Zen ToolWorks or the beautiful colors from HatchBox. These require using the XYZ cartridge material with the new material. The technique is quite simple and can be found through a search.
The product has proven to be an extremely satisfying experience and has more than paid for itself supporting my consulting business. I highly recommend it. Should you have questions please ask and I will do my best to provide an answer.

Two year follow-up
After two years the machine continues to run perfectly. I have not had a single part fail or clogged nozzle, amazing. The only negative has been that XYZ secretly changed the software and now I am unable to use filaments from other manufacturers, disappointing but the printer still performs flawlessly. For the price it has been a great purchase.
summary: I have made many usefull parts.

reviewText: If you're looking at the XYZ Da Vinci 1.0 customer reviews just keep in mind to take reviews at a gain of salt. Yes this product is 500 bucks and yes there are two types PLA and BAS. Whether you're a innovator or whatever and you are contemplating wither to get this - I say go for it! It has less issues than negative reviewers say. When you unbox the product be sure to re-read the instructions and make sure to take out the supports, the tape and everything else the instruction says. Also be sure to make sure when you load the filament go to the Utilities -> Change Cartridge -> Load Filament - if you see filament oozing into the drop box then you're good to go. If you don't try it again and see if you see the filament oozing out. Again just follow the instructions - it doesn't take a brain surgeon. Very easy to use, very easy to set up. Another pointer to point out - make sure you get the latest drivers and software from the website just to be sire. Just Google up the brand name and you should be pointed to their website. Now let's talk about getting your measurements correct - I printed out a door stopper which I took a picture of and hopefully I can share with the rest of you. Whether you're in Autocad or 3DS Max or what not - if you're measurements is in inches - make sure it's in inches when you convert the 3D model to stl file format. When you open their software make sure you right click over the object and click on scale up from mm to inches. It's going to be huge and over the borders giving the object color being red. Now click on the scale transform tool and you can easily adjust to the dimensions of how you desire it to be. It wouldn't hurt to also go to settings in the software and click on printer then make sure the metrics are set to inches. Another thing that may get people twisted in the knot is the coordinate system - when their in the scale dialog - they may notice Z is up and Y is away. If you're a programmers or a 3D artist for a game company or what not - you would probably know some software has the y-z flipped. So the X is to the right, the Y is towards you and Z is up. I think I pretty much covered the basis of this review. It's ultimately your decision to purchase. Also keep in mind - the box is huge when it's delivered; so be sure you ate your spinach. :)
summary: Da Vinci was known for his creativity!

reviewText: If you are looking for a 3D printer and don't mind paying extra for proprietary filament, then this is the printer for you. There are ways to bypass using their proprietary cartridges, but this would void the warranty. Da Vinci is spending lots of their time, updating these printers, patching the ways to bypass using their filament. The support isn't the greatest. I made a support ticket 3 days ago and never had a response. I also called during hours and they said they were closed. If you have problems with your Da Vinci, you are going to have to rely on someone else besides XYZ Printing. Thankfully these prints are high quality because otherwise, I would be returning this printer. Minus one star for proprietary filament and another for poor support.
summary: Expensive Proprietary Cartridges and Poor Support

reviewText:
Great oscilloscope! So far I've used it to test the MAF, IAC, and CPS sensors on a Ford Explorer.  Trigger works great and is easy to use.  You can set the trigger in a menu or by sliding a cursor on screen to the desired voltage. You can also freeze and the save data displays.  Has a wide variety of features.  Attached is a photo of the MAF sensor output at lo rpm.
Update:  Someone asked about the Math function.  Initially it didn't appear to work.  I used a sine wave and the internal square wave and added Ch1 and Ch2.  I found that you had to fake out the V/div scaling and use 10nv/div for 10V/div for the math to work out right.  Below is an image of the signals that I added.
summary: Super scope!

reviewText:
All tests pass:
  1. Static disapative surface measured in nS
  2. Conductive and highly resistant bottom layer measured in MOhm
  3. Provided grounding strap and wrist strap @ 1MOhm each
  4. Left an acceptably small mark when burned with soldering iron @ 260F

Sorry for the sideways pictures, I'm not spending time to flip them...
summary: All tests pass

reviewText:
First let me say if this is going to be your first 3D printer you should familiarize yourself with how 3D printers work.  The instructions are really good in places and in others are very bad or worse they are simply not there.

For example, there are no directions on adjusting the Z axis home position or how to level the build plate.  It isn't hard at all to do so I don't know why they left them out.  For me it was easy because I am already familiar with 3D printers.

Also the board has a microSD card which allows you to print offline.  That's great but there isn't any instructions on this.  I found someone wrote something up on makezine.com about how to do it and it isn't just "plug it in and it works".

Second, if you order this printer go out and buy some M3 20mm screws with caps.  One is missing from the kit and other people online have complained about it.  It is a very important piece because it holds the extruder in place.  Why do they leave it out?  Also invest in a rubber mallet.  It came in handy a couple of times.

Third, this thing's frame is wood and not a terribly strong wood.  It isn't balsa but it certainly isn't oak either.  Be careful with it.

The build itself was fun and not terribly hard.  It took about 6-7 hours straight.  The biggest challenge was just reading the instructions; they can be confusing at times and sometimes the accompanying picture isn't for this printer but for the earlier version.  That can be a bit scary because often times you depend solely on the images and seeing a new item on the printer that you don't happen to have makes you wonder what step did you miss.

I've only printed a couple of things so far and they have come out well so I can't say much about it.  If I don't update this review assume it is working well otherwise I will write an update.

Update:  So far so good.  I've printed out about 30 items with this and posted some in the pictures. This is a great beginner printer IF you are good at DIY stuff.  There are some upgrades to this printrbot that allows you to upgrade from fishing line to a belt system.  I might do that someday but so far the fishing line works (and yes I am still amazed it does).
summary: A Medieval design but kind of cool.

reviewText:
I needed a replacement for my Aprilaire Model 400 Humidifier and this matched the specs that were printed on the OEM one that was on the furnace:
24/60  2.3 W  125 PSI  Orif 3/64
It looks to be made well, came with all the fittings, and had a good stand-off so that it could be mounted on the humidifier in the same location as the original one.  I've attached a picture, so you can see that the stand-off is a little more than an inch (obviously the ruler does not come with it).
summary: Replaced the one that came with my Aprilaire Model 400, and its working fine

reviewText: I am still experimenting with this filament.  So far, the things I have printed with it came out well, though they are not as squashy as I thought.  Some reviewers posted that it has a gummy bear like texture which was not the case for me.  Frankly, the objects printed with this NinjaFlex feel exactly like TPU which makes me wonder if I got a roll that was mislabeled.
summary: Feels more like TPU

reviewText:
A lot of people are asking about printing with a Bowden Extruder.  My printer design (www.innovo3d.co) uses a Bowden setup, however, I have reduced the distance between the filament drive and the extruder greatly by placing the filament drive on the top.  I've printed a few parts at 30mm/s as suggested by the Ninjaflex vendor and it is printing fine with no problems.

The 30mm/s print speed doesn't seem to have much to do with the Bowden setup, but rather the fact that printing at a higher speed will jam the nozzle and cause the filament drive gear to skip.  This is my experience with it so far anyway.  This is the only downside so far.  I have since increased the temperature up to 230 degrees Celsius and it seems to help the filament flow better but it still needs more testing.

The filament diameter is a bit smaller than 1.75mm.  I measured it at 1.65mm.  For this reason you may notice that when you are printing your first layer the lines seem very thin.  You can compensate for this by increasing the flowrate to 105% to 110%.  This has helped with my prints.
summary: PRINTS WELL WITH BOWDEN SETUP BUT NEEDS MINOR ADJUSTMENTS

reviewText:
I have used this tape for three purposes, and it has excelled at each:

1) iPhone charging cables tend to show a separation of the cable insulation from the silicone boot at one or both plug ends. Wrapping the cable end, overlapping the boot, with a few turns of this tape stabilizes this break and also acts as a strain relief. Looks ok, too.  That used the first 6" of tape for all the iPhone cables in my household.

2) A basement sump pump with a 1 3/4" diameter poly hose suffered a direct lawnmower hit, opening a sizable gash. In the middle of the winter (I had wrapped with duct tape in warm weather, but it did not hold well), with icy water spraying from the break, I wrapped with this tape. The leak was very effectively stopped. That used up the rest of the tape, so I am ordering a second roll.

2) A Miele vacuum spring-return power cord developed a break in the outside insulation. It is both expensive and time consuming to replace the cord assembly. As an alternative, I wrapped the break with this tape, and it has now been functioning well for ~6 months; the flexibility of the tape is key to this application.
summary: Works as advertised, and very well

reviewText: Great silicone rubber tape. I use it for electrical insulation but also for protection of mini USB connector cables.
summary: Five Stars

reviewText: I make my own herbal tonics and essential oils. These are the work well to store them in. Amber bottles are the best, imo. But these were a great deal, and I keep them in a dark cupboard. Sunlight can damage oils. I purchase quite a few times every year. The dropper works well and is easy to clean.
summary: Essential Oils

reviewText:
I was really worried that all these bottles were in pieces.  It really sounded like a box of broken glass. I'm happy to say - NONE of them were broken. They were packaged with little pieces of cardboard between them, but, they still clinker together some. They are also super dusty.  I'm not so happy with that, but, they wash.

Beautiful colors. Holds a little more than 2 Oz if you fill them to the brim. The dropper doesn't go all the way to the bottom - BUT, tilt it a bit and you can get it all.

I got this for essential oils, fragrance oils, blends, etc. I'm really glad to have come across these. Fantastic product,  fantastic price, and beautiful color. Did I  mention the beautiful blue color? I love it... ;-)
summary: Beautiful blue bottles

reviewText:
Worked out of the box.
It took about an hour to set up but could be shorter as I took my time in leveling the bed.
I purchased some hatchbox PLA and printed a test cube with the default settings. Found that I was printing too hot as I had warping.
Dialed the extruder down to 200 and the bed to 50 which fixed the problem.
Using Simply 3D and have created a few prints for my Mavic and a whistle that actually works.

Very impressed with this printer. it has been running almost non stop for the past 24 hours.
One note, the Hatchbox spools do not fit this printer and will end up sliding off of the spool holder. You can print one that works from Thingiverse.

I have not tried ABS yet as I figured it was best to start off with PLA. I've never done 3D printing before so taking it slow.

I did reach out to the vendor to ask a question during set up. I received a response in 10 minutes. Very fast customer support.
I would highly recommend this printer.
summary: I have not tried ABS yet as I figured it was best to start off with PLA

reviewText:
I am happy I chose this for my first printer, so far I have learned quite a bit about 3d printing.  I haven't yet attempted printing PLA plastic, but I have used the ABS that came with it and matchbox has with good results.  I didn't like using the rafts so after playing around I have been printing ABS at 222-225 on the 110 bed.  Finding I get great prints using Elmers washable school glue on the blue textured platform cover.  I have some pictures of stuff I have made, but the kindle fire doesn't appear to have a while to upload pictures so I will do it at another time on a computer.

Also Flashprint, which should be on your SDcard included, works great for this and provides many more options for printing.  I recommend using this software in advanced and slowing down your first layer, this allows you to avoid using rafts, also you can make the first layer height different then the rest.  You can also set when the extra cooling fan turns on.  I also recommend getting an active cooling fan mod form thingiverse, you can remove the old extra cooling fan it comes with and install the new cooler and a 24VDC fan using the connector that is there.  You just need to connect to it with a 2 pin JST connector.
summary: great printer so far

reviewText:
I LOVE this printer. I upgraded from a DaVinci 1.0A which was my first 3D printer. It was time for something else so initially I tried a different design and went with a kit 3D printer of the delta design from Geeetech. It was a terrinle printer which required LOTS of tweaking to make a decent print. I gave up fiddling with it after I realized the bearings etc were all garbage so I decided to go to the Flashforge Creator Pro since it was recommended on many reviews.

I loved the "out of the box" printing this printer has given me. I unpacked the printer and all the stuff jammed inside it, loaded up the filament and I was printing. The first thing I printed was the traffic cone so I could see what a dual-extruder was all about. I am amazed at how nice it turned out.

The next thing I printed was a new filament feed assembly for the back of the printer since the design from Flashforge is completely useless and will cause the filament to come off the spool and wind up around the spool holder as it feeds into the tubes. I knew this was going to be a problem since I did my research and went with the one people seem to like the most :  [...]

The next thing I printed was a test part to see how good a 3D printer is and WOW! it came out amazing. So much better than my DaVinci 1.0a ever did, and way more better than the Geeetech delta "tried" to print.  I have attached a picture of the test print and here is the file: [...]

I plan on printing many things with this printer and it has already been running for the last 20 hours on many prints back-to-back.

One tip:  I still apply a thin layer of glue stick to the print surface otherwise the PLA does not want to stick very well. When the print cools, I need to pop it off with a little spatula.  Without the glue, the first layer was not sticking very well.
summary: Awesome Printer with Amazing Quality

reviewText:
We have been using this for about 5 months now and this printer works great!  The print quality is very good and strong. It came with two big rolls of ABS, one white and one red.  We save the sliced files on a  sd card from one computer then plug the sd card into the printer and print from that. It is kinda loud with the fans and the servo motors make noise when they are printing. We put the printer in a cabinet made for old huge television sets. We close the doors on the cabinet and this cuts down on the noise big time. Sometimes the prints stick to the platform. Heating up the platform makes it easier to remove.
Overall we are very pleased with this printer.
summary: We love this FlashForge 3d printer!

reviewText: I got this printer because I was fed up with tinkering with my PrintrBot Metal. I could not have been happier with the result. The setup was very fast. In fact, the most difficult part was switching the power on the the bottom of the printer. The switch is kind of buried under there. Once it was up, I leveled it within a couple minutes, and was successfully printing test prints on the first try. Since then, I have a great success rate with all kinds of prints. I love having the dual extruder as well, although I'm still learning how to incorporate that into my designs. The only improvements I'd really like to see are a larger access door (it can be cramped when you have to work inside it) and a faster bed heater (it can take quite a while for that to come to temperature). I can't say for sure how this printer stacks up against the others, besides my Printrbot, but I don't see how it can be beat for the price. The quality of the prints seems very good.
summary: I could not have been happier with the result

reviewText:
Short Story:  I purchased the FlashForge 3d Printer Creator Pro in mid December 2014 and started using it on December 25th.  I have printed ABS things that came with it, an ABS bicycle I created with SketchUp, and a wrench using PLA glow-in-the dark filament.  Everything works great.  This is a fantastic machine and technology.  And I had a couple of questions and the legendary Tang answered the first email within an hour on Christmas Eve and the second email within an hour on Christmas morning (Central Standard Time).  Great product, great service and the concept of 3d printing is really cool.

Long Story:  I got interested in 3d printing about a year ago and began shopping and reading web sites.  I noticed that the machines were getting less expensive and per the reviews, more reliable.  In early December I decided it was time to buy one and I suggested to my wife that I was going to do this and it could be my Christmas present.  She said that was fine, but I could not open it until Christmas day.  That was not what I intended but it turned out to be a good thing.  For the 3 weeks or so before Christmas I read everything I could find about how to set up and use this printer.
The first thing I discovered is that there is a lot of software involved, and three ways to get objects to the printer.  First, you can download files from the internet.  Second you can create an object then print it, and third you can buy a scanner, scan an object, and then print it.  And you can combine elements of all of those.  You could download a file, merge that with something you scanned, and then import that file into a 3D modeling software like Google SketchUp and modify it.

Im a baby boomer and we all learned things by reading the manual.  Kids today never bothered with manuals so when they started inventing all this stuff they don't bother writing manuals.  You have to figure everything out by reading Customer Reviews and researching on the internet.
Scanning.  I purchased a Matter and Form MFS1v1 3d scanner.  I wrote a review about it, so won't repeat that here.  It works.
Create a Model of your own design.  You have to learn to use a software program to do this.  I selected SketchUp because there are good reviews and it is free.  But there are no manuals.  You load it on your PC, then work through 4 training tutorials provided by Google, then you just have to do google searches to try to figure out everything else you need to know to create an object that you can print.

Here is what I learned about SketchUp essential to 3D printing:

1. Build your object in a large size, then let the printing software (more on that later) reduce it in size.  SketchUp was developed as a 3d tool for architecture and lacks the ability to make very tiny parts.  But you can make a big part with high detail then reduce it.

2. Every time you create an object on SketchUp  you must select it then make a group.  Then you right-click and look at Entity Info.  If you see volume you have created a solid that will print on a 3d printer.  If you try to print something that is not a solid the print software will discover manifold problems, and the print won't work.

3. After you create solids, you join them together using a tool called outer shell.  This is the tool on SketchUp 2015.  I think tools on earlier versions had other names.  You get to this tool by: View, Toolbars, Solid Tools.  A bunch of solid objects joined together with Outer Shell result in a model that can be printed.

4. When you first download Sketchup you get the Pro version (for 30 days).  With the pro version you get other Solid Tools and you can output object files.  I got so frustrated that I could not get objects to print properly (just using the print preparation software  see below) that I bought the Pro version.  I now don't think you need it.  The free version will output STL files and the Print Prep software can use either an STL file or and OBJ file

5. When you are finished building your object  export it as on OBJ file or Export it as an STL file.  To export as an STL file you have to add the STL functionality to your SketchUp program.  Again, just Google: Add STL to Sketchup and you will discover how to do this

Convert your File to a Print File:  Next  you prepare your file to print.  This is required regardless of whether you download a model from the internet of use a model you created from SketchUp.  You must have software that is capable of creating a file in the format expected by your printer.  The Print File provides all the info the printer requires heat the extruders, move the print bed, move the extruders, push out the plastic, and so on.

The directions that come with this printer instruct the user how to download free software and install it  along with other programs and drivers and so on.  I found this baffling and for $140 bought Simplify3D, which is an alternative to the free software.  Simplify3D has about 9 tutorials that explain how to use it.  Remember, Im killing time until Christmas and working through these was very helpful.

When you first launch Simplify3D you tell it the brand and model of your printer.  Then, as you import the model you either created or downloaded, the software has preconfigured processes to facilitate printing.  You can change all these but I found the defaults to work great.  When you are ready to print the software shows you an extruder suspended in space above a print bed and it prints your model, on your computer screen.  You can watch it and use the repair menu to find all the problems  before even using the actual printer.  When you have the model printing correctly on your PC, you move the file to the actual printer.

But this is the cool thing  if you are thinking about buying a 3D printer  get SketchUp and buy Simplify3d.  Make some models; see how they print.  You can learn an awful lot before making the leap to buy the printer.

Now to the FlashForge

It came, from Amazon, in two days.  It was packed well and everything was in it.
The instructions for assembly are clear  but I also found a video of how to assemble a slightly older version that was helpful.
This version includes an acrylic cover and front door that help keep the temperature constant which is useful for ABS printing.  The instructions that come with the printer provide a web site with a video that shows how to assemble the acrylic cover that goes on the top of the machine.  Hint:  Take all the protective paper off the acrylic, use some of the painters tape that comes with the printer to tape the acrylic pieces together, install the screws, and remove the tape.  This is a lot easier than the process in the video.

It took 20 minutes and a lot of patience to get the print bed level.  I finally settled on this procedure  Launch the Level Build Plate on the printer, push the extruder assembly until it is right above the leveling wing-nut closest to you.  Adjust that wing-nut until paper just barely slides; move extruder until it is above the other wing nuts and do the same thing.  You just push it with your hands.  Keep moving the extruder and adjusting the wing nuts until paper just slides, anywhere on the bed.

Printing was the easiest part.  First, I printed the objects that are on the SD card that comes with the machine.  These printed fine.  I was a little impatient getting the first print off the print bed, which has a layer of Kapton tape. I used a sharp knife from the kitchen to pop the model loose and actually cut into the tape.  So on every subsequent print there is a little flap of Kapton tape sticking up.  Note, however that when you use the Printing Software (in my example Simplify3D), you can check a box for Include Raft.  When you do this, the printer creates a lattice of plastic under your actual object.  That lattice just peels right off when finished.  And the lattice covers up the Kapton tape tear and minor imperfections in levelling.

Then I moved to printing from my PC.  I could not load the driver necessary to connect my PC directly to the printer  but just copied ready-to-print files from Simplify3D to the SDCH card that came with the printer.  Then put the SDCH card in the printer and it works fine.

ABS.  First 10 prints were using the ABS filament that came with the printer.  I had studied all the settings and variables available to control the print  but when it came time to do it I just told the Simplify3D software that I was using ABS and wanted a raft and everything came out fine.  NOTE regarding Supports.  The reason I bought a two extruder printer was because I thought you needed a second extruder to generate supports for parts with a big overhang, using one of those soluble plastics that can later be dissolved.  It turns out that the Simplify3D software (and probably most others) can print supports just using the same ABS spool as your model.  Somehow the supports are printed so they don't stick very much and they just break off.  The only time you would really need soluble supports is if they had to be printed inside your model where you could not easily remove them.

PLA.  Same story (almost).  I backed out the ABS filament and loaded some PLA (that actually glows in the dark!).  Everything had been printing so smoothly on the Kapton tape that I just told Simplify3D I was using PLA  and printed! I did not bother to use the Painters Tape as instructed because that would require re-leveling the print bed.  The PLA print on the Kapton tape worked fine for about 10 minutes then the entire RAFT pulled loose and got caught against the extruder and I was not watching closely and a LOT of PLA got gummed up on the end of the extruder.  Cleaned it up, installed a couple strips of painters tape, re-leveled and it prints fine.  LESSON:  follow the instructions.

This machine and all the software are really fun.  About the equivalent to a two hour college course, I think.  I highly recommend this machine and the company that backs it up.
summary: Excellent Machine

reviewText: Excellent wall timer, reasonably priced, and excellent customer service as well! I installed these switches in all 3 of my bathrooms. I wanted the option of leaving the fan running after getting out of the shower and exiting the bathroom, without worrying about having to return to the bathroom to turn the exhaust fan off. This greatly helps in reducing mold and mildew in the shower! The switch does have little blue LED's that remain on at all times. I initially didn't think I would like this and thought it may pose a problem. I actually really like the fact that these blue LED's stay on! I even removed the night light out of my master bath, because these blue LED's are enough to illuminate the bathroom in the middle of the night. Yet they're not bright enough where they would keep me awake all night, you actually barely notice they're on. But in the middle of the night, when it's pitch-black they do provide just enough light to use the facilities without having to turn on any bright lights. I absolutely love these wall timers! Would highly recommend these.
summary: Excellent Wall timer!

reviewText:
Worth every penny! Always use to be stuck with a dilema...
A) shut fan off right after shower and let moisture sit in bathroom and risk mold
...Or...
B)leave it on and forget to shut it off and it ends up running for hour.

Not Amy more! Start this bad boy before you hop in the shower and you got nothing to worry about! Every time someone vists they are always amazed and ask where I get it. I had no idea how big of conversation starter a fan could be. Also comes in handy to fire up when someone stinks up the bathroom. Instead of smelling poopery for half hour can just run the fan for 5 min.

Bottom line you won't regret it. Really easy to install. I replaced a normal 3 gang box of toggle switches with 2 decora switches and this one.
summary: Greatest thing since sliced Bread!

reviewText: This timer switch works just as it should. I was afraid I would need to do additional wiring since it specifies that it requires all 3 lines, the hot, the neutral and the ground, but in my case (and I believe in nearly all cases) the wires were readily available in the existing electrical box of the standard switch I was replacing. The 1, 5, 10, 15, 20, and 30 minute timers all work properly and the big button ends the cycle early if you want. The blue LED lights tell you which cycle is active. They give off a bit of light, so if you want a room to remain perfectly dark for some reason, you should be wary of that.
summary: This timer switch works just as it should

reviewText:
This media works WONDERS! I pick up some truly nasty brass from the gun club I belong to, and it is unbelievable how well this cleans up the brass, making it look absolutely brand new! I deprime my brass before tumbling, and the pins even clean out the primer holes to the point you would never know it was fired brass.

One catch is to make sure you run the pins for a few hours just by themselves with some water and dawn dish soap, to round off the sharp cut ends and remove any manufacturing residues. After that you can begin shining up your dirty brass with unbelievable results! I typically add my stainless pins, dirty brass, and then fill the drum up with lukewarm water. At that point just add a teaspoon of dawn dish detergent, and a dash of lemi shine and its ready to tumble! After about an hour and thirty minutes of tumbling, the brass looks brand new.

After tumbling dump out the dirty water, and give a few rinses with cold water. Then sift out the pins, let the brass dry, and your ready to reload.

I will definitely be buying more now that I have two more tumbler barrels I built.
summary: Best Brass Media EVER!

reviewText:
Partially tapped holes limit you to only top mounting. The wholes are not square on all blocks. Some of the bushings are missing 3-4 ball bearings making them jerky. I guess for $8 you get what you pay for.

EDIT: Bought a second set because the 1st ones were useless. These came with the bearings on the outside! Loose in the bag, so... again completely useless! The seller NEVER response to emails and shipping to return them costs more than they did.
summary: Too cheap!!!

reviewText: Mounting holes are drilled all the way through, but only partially tapped.  M4 taps.  M4 bolts will go in about 11 mm before bottoming out.  I broke a screw off figuring this out during mounting (I assumed the error was misalignment of my mounting holes).  So a thru-hole of about 17.6 mm is tapped just over halfway.  While this may be OK for some mountings, I had to tap out 16 holes just to mount a bed along these rails.  Buyer, beware--another example of Chinese quality....
summary: Mounting holes only partially tapped

reviewText: So much have been said about this caliper that I don't think I can add anything new. No sure if this have been mentioned before here in Amazon or someplace else, but mine came with a "Calibration Certificate."  This is really good. Look the date when the calibration was done, this item is brand new out of the factory, mine was still warm when I got it on my hands  :)
summary: 5 stars well deserved.

reviewText: I've had my Roomba 880 since the end of 2015. At first it appeared so random and brainless in it's cleaning routine I doubted it and my purchase decision. Over time I have grown to love this addition to my hardwood and oriental rug first floor, basement below needs it's own. Roomba runs every day for about 1 to 1.5 hours and picks up sooo much dust from my normally dusty house! It has been a godsend to my and my housekeeper (every 2 weeks). It continues to have areas where it gets stuck and stays stuck till I can find it. A favorite spot is under the edge of the dishwasher (plan to get that raised the 1/4" needed for clearance..it will also sometimes close one of the bathroom doors and thus locks itself in, forever. I recently had a problem with Roomba returning to home base for charging, finally got a new battery and it's running like new. I have both floor and portable Dysons but Rooma runs every day and I'm not having to do the job myself. Bachelors generally hate to clean :(. If Roomba passes on, I'll get the newer model that has a cleaning pattern I can understand. You'll learn to love your Roomba, as I have with the 880. Highly recommended....
summary: Love my Roomba 880

reviewText: The printer prints good but its design has a flaws that allows a connector to become unplug during printing and then shorts the printrbaord and Printrbot will not fix this under warranty as well as their support is all but useless for this problem and their sales site does not function currently as the California tax calculation is incorrect so my attempts to purchase a new board are not successful so I have a dead printer I can not fix. I do not recommend purchase of this product till there are some serious changes to this product and Printrbots warranty which claims to cover material and defects but actually they do not cover a bad selection of a wire that has open metal pins with no protection from shorting if it becomes disconnected during use on a product made of metal especially this is not a common design feature with most manufacturers and the connector is not locking to prevent unintended disconnection as well as the male and female connectors are not of the same type so they could be locked. look at the included photo and you will see the open metal pins that have no protection and this coming from the Printrboard and carries power and signal from the board to the auto leveling probe. but remember they choose the compenets but this can not be a material defect on their part, normally a power providing cable would be femal on the supply side and male on the component side so I concider this a defect no matter what Printrbot calls it.
summary: Prinrbot failure to honor their own warranty for material and defects

reviewText: These magnets stick really well, in fact I tried one on our french doors to get a feel for whether or not they could hold the blinds on our doors and I had to get a knife to pry it back off.  My wife made some shades for our 3 sets of french doors and used these to hold them up, they work well and we can even pull the string to raise them without pulling them off.  We are using two magnets per blind, one on each end.
summary: Great for holding blinds to a steel door

reviewText: The magnets shipped in a small white cardboard box. Inside the box the magnets were just loose but obviously all clumped and connected. So the random nature of this led the magnet to scratch the white paint on other hooks. Basically they all had black/gray scrapes and marks on the white paint since no separation or padding was put between each hook. While they "work" technically as magnets with hooks, the whole point of nicely white painted hooks was to look nice when used and this completely failed.
summary: Horrible packaging, ruined finish.

reviewText: I use three of these to hold up the drip tray/pan on my kegerator. The only modification needed was to put some tape over the magnets to give then a little more "traction" on the door so they wouldn't slide.  The added benefit is I don't have to drill any holes in the fridge door!
summary: Works great for holding a drip tray!

reviewText:
This is the de facto 3d printer for beginners and more experienced users alike.  Once I was over the learning curve I was producing some very impressive prints.  The assembly instructions were not great, though sufficient, but that was when it was first released; I hear the instructions are much much better now.

I especially think this is a great printer for someone new to 3D printing because of how solid everything was; I never had to worry about sloppiness in the moving parts causing any problems, I could just focus on learning how to print.

The only real problem that I had was with the print bed not being perfectly flat; it had a bit of a concave curvature to it which I heard was not entirely uncommon.  The reason this was a problem was because the auto-leveling mechanism produces a perfect plane for the hotend to follow, but the bed was not a perfect plane.  So some areas around the bed on the first layer of a large print might be too close and others too far away, causing difficulties in bed adhesion.  I have heard that Printrbot is very good about replacing these beds if you ask, but others have simply fixed it themselves or upgraded to the heated bed which includes a new and very flat bed plate.  I took the route of upgrading to the heated print bed and have been very happy with the results.

Pros:
  Extremely solid machine
  Very simple and easy to understand design
  A great community and plenty of other owners to lean on for advice or tips
  6x6x6" is a very decent build envelope; a lot can be done with that size
Cons:
  Assembly instructions left something to be desired, but I hear they're much better now
  Slightly warped print bed
summary: This was my first 3D printer and I am glad it was.  You won't regret this purchase.

reviewText: Just a sample of one and I am pretty new to printing, but my spool worked great with my printrbot simple metal. haven't quite eliminated warping, heated bed recommended from my experience so far. Adheres well to painters tape at 210, I drop the temp to 185 after .5mm z. Make sure you get the tape down as good as possible and clean with alcohol with a non-heated bed. Used a brim or raft a lot as well. It helps but does not eliminate warping. Lower infills (under 30%) also help. On denser parts it often would pull the tape up during the print with warping on larger prints.

reviewText:
The physical quality of the filament is top notch as always from Hatchbox. It extrudes beautifully, and is a breeze to print with.

The red is not very red , however. It has a quite distinct orange color to it (photo attached)

It's also fairly translucent compared to some other filaments I have used. I noticed the top looked a little splotchy on one of my prints, and initially thought it was a consistency issue in the filament. Upon closer inspection, it turns out that I was seeing the infill pattern through the shell (2 layers). It's not a huge issue with most prints, and adding another perimeter to the shell should fix it. It is disappointing to notice at the end of a 5 hour print though.

That's why I took off a star. While this translucence may be desirable in some cases, It's not a quality I particularly want in an opaque filament.
summary: It extrudes beautifully, and is a breeze to print with

reviewText:
Purchased this filament for my Flashforge Creator Pro and found it difficult to work with at first.  I had finished the spool of red ABS filament that came with the printer (Flashforge brand?), and found it to be much more superior to the black Hatchbox material.  I had little to no issues printing with the Flashforge filament at the recommended settings.  Starting layers and overall print quality were better with the Flashforge material and the Flashforge material handled varying temperature settings very well.  After a little tinkering (extruder temp 230, bed 80, with raft) I started to get better results from the Hatchbox filament. The smell from the Hatchbox material also seems stronger than the Flashforge material.  For the price, the filament is good.  I will probably go with the Flashforge filament on the next purchase, but for general printing and what I have read from others, this filament isn't bad at all.

Update 1/25/17  After working with the Hatchbox material and switching back to the Flashforge material, I found that the Hatchbox ABS was just as good as the Flashforge.  The initial issues I was having with the Hatchbox ABS was due to a printer alignment related issue vs the material.  Still good stuff!
summary: Satisfactory results from a low priced filament!

reviewText:
I don't review products often, but I'm so pleased with this filament that I wanted to share my experience.  I've been having excelant results with this filament.

In my case it prints just as well if not better than a popular American-Made brand that I also use.  My printer is a Prusa i3 with an E3D Lite6 HotEnd, Bowden extruder, and MK2b heated bed with borosilicate glass substrate.

I print this filament at 230C with a 100-105 deg heated bed on a film of Elmer's glue stick and have not experienced any shrinkage or curling of any kind.  The odor is practically non-existent, especially when compared to cheaper imported filament, and zero moisture/air pocket pops.  I've also tested with acetone and it completely dissolves, so it doesn't appear to be blended with any fillers.

From now on this will be my go-to filament, especially since it's available with 2-Day Prime shipping.
summary: Excelant Filament

reviewText:
This review refers to the Endoscope model TD0310 with the 5 m cable.  A specialist accessory received for evaluation and review.  There are a whole range of uses for this versatile tool, but in a nutshell, it allows a thorough investigation of small, dark, hidden, out-of-range spaces.  The idea is the same as the medical version, a long flexible tube with a camera head (8.5 mm in this case) and some strong LED lights to illuminate the way at one end and a standard USB connector at the other.  The camera resolution offers a very useful quality range: up to 600 x 1200 pixels, and the images we get are really sharp, especially after a little experimentation.  The ability to regulate the light intensity is a definite asset.  This unit is waterproof and appears to be very tough and fit for the its intended applications;  some examples: investigating the state of a location out of reach of fingers and eyesight; locating an obstruction inside a tube or conduit (even full of water); verifying the condition of the back of appliances that cannot be moved; car repairs.  It's the sort of thing that, once you own it, you will find many uses for, that are not immediately apparent.

We initially tested it by photographing the inside of a Hummingbird electrified guitar.  The output jack had worked loose once again (it had already been sent back for professional remedial action once).  Due to the very limited space inside the guitar body, just enough for a slim hand, it was essential to know the exact situation.  We had already spent a lot of frustrating time trying to screw the piece back on.  Once the Endoscope head had been put into position, we were able to view the whole area and identify both the problem and the solution.  We fixed the guitar in under one minute.

In the box are the endoscope itself, some small tools that attach to the camera head (a hook, mirror and magnet), software installation CD, and a manual (also on the CD). The software loaded without problems on a laptop running Win 8.1.  Manoeuvring the photo head was easy enough (it would be even easier inside a tube), taking still photos and especially video were intuitive and successful.  The other option is to simply view the camera's progress on the screen, but recording the images may be useful.  I was quite blown away by the quality of the images, and the performance of this brilliant diagnostic tool.  I'll be making a video as soon as I have a moment, but for now I'll just post some photos and a screenshot taken from video footage.
summary: Brilliant diagnostic tool for those small, dark places

reviewText: It was easy to put together. Instructions are clear and only a few parts need assembly. A small screwdriver is required but not included. It was easy for my eight year old son to build it, but he needed my help to tighten screws. Changing the battery requires unscrewing one small screw. The quality seems OK. The antenna (for looks only) is made of very soft nin-springy wire and came bent. Legs and claws snap in easily but also fall out easily. Overall quality seems reasonably good. As far as play goes, the toy does not fall off the table just like a Never Fall Wind Up Mouse. It has two wheels that push it forward and a roller in the front as well as a smaller wheel in the front that rotates perpendicular to the direction of the main movement. As soon as the front roler falls off the table edge, the small wheel engages and turns the toy 90 degrees to the right so it stays in the table. Legs and claws shake for looks only. There are no additional functions. The toy gets stuck when it hits an obstacle. Occasionally it falls of the table depending on how it approaches the edge. My son was excited to build it and to play with it for a short period of time. It also served an educational purpose when I explained how it works. I think this is an OK toy.
summary: It was easy to put together
