reviewText:
My order arrived faster than promised from Dcolor but compared to 5 other different purchases from China, this took the longest.

I have several DIY projects in line. In a few minutes, I made flashlight bulb for 6v-4 cell, and a HF head light mod. I used Arctic Silver Lumina epoxy to mount to any copper or piece of aluminum plate for heat sink. There's a lot resistor calculators out there that are helpful to get the resistor you need for your project. For my 6V flashlight bulb, I used 3.3 ohm resistor, and for HF 2 headlight --it didn't need any since it is only 2 cel or 3v.

UPDATE: 6/21/2016: I measured it with my meter and it is only registering at 1w (4 watt for 4 emitters in series). It is bright but I bought the 3W for a reason. I hacked a quartz light using four emitters in series (12v without resistors mounted on heat sink). I guess, I just need to add 8 more emitters. I just placed an order of the 3W from a different seller this time just to test. Three stars because of the price and still a good deal for 1W and only about a couple of bucks more.
summary: Great for DIY'ers (1W?)

reviewText:
I have been using my FlashForge Dreamer for over a year now. I purchased it directly from the manufacturer before most people were able to buy it here. This printer is fantastic. The print quality is better than a MakerBot Replicator 2 or 2X (both of which I also use).

I like the fact that the filament is located inside the printer. This helps keep dust off the filament providing a cleaner print. This is quite important as dust and other foreign objects like bits of hair, etc., can build up in the extruder over time, and can lead to clogged nozzles.

The way this printer handles prints sent over USB is different than a lot of other printers. This printer allows you to disconnect the USB cable immediately after sending the print job to the printer. Once the printer has the print job loaded the printer then prints the object on its own, no USB connection is needed while it prints. The MakerBot Replicator 2 and 2X cannot do this over USB. They must be connected throughout the entire print job when using USB to print. It can also print over WIFI. Which is great if your printer is not near your computer.

I love the fact that the build platform is very sturdy. The MakerBot Replicator 2 and 2X have a plastic based build platform which bends and deforms, and even tilts a bit while you print your object. They often requiring re-leveling after many prints. Their plastic build platform arms are also known to break. The build platform on the Dreamer has arms made of aluminum, not plastic. It feels very solid, and doesn't bend or deform. I only leveled my printer 1 time, and it's been working perfectly since. The only time I would ever need to re-level it is if I installed print nozzles of a different size, or if I changed the print surface to a different material (i.e., changing from blue painter's tape to glass, or PET tape). It never goes out of alignment on its own.

Another thing I love about this printer is that every filament type I have tried on it works great. The MakerBot Replicator 2X can't print normal PLA without jamming because it uses an old out dated print head. The MakerBot Replicator 2 can't print ABS and similar materials without it warping because it doesn't have a heated build plate. This printer handles everything, ABS, PLA, you name it. It can do it all and do it very well. I have printed ABS, PLA, HIPS, PETT, PETG, and exotic filaments such as CopperFill, Zen Toolworks Wood, and even flexible filament such as NinjaFlex, and ASAPTech TPE. The flexible filament required a modified print drive block I made which is found here for free (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:431115). Apparently the newer Dreamer printers don't need this modification. FlashForge keeps improving the design. Note that printing CopperFill will wear out the print head after a while. Be prepared to have a second set of PTFE tubes and nozzles if you're going to be printing anything with metal in it like CopperFill.

The touch screen is great. I can't stand the cheap rubber buttons on the MakerBots. They are hard to press, and I feel like I'm going to break them, and I'm never really sure if I've pressed them properly or not. The touch screen on the Dreamer is so much nicer. It's bright and easy to read at angles. I get very clear visual feedback when I touch the screen.

The FlashPrint software is about the same as MakerBot's MakerWare. There are some minor differences. Both produce about the same quality slicing because they use the same slicing engines (Skeinforge and Slic3r). The software is very decent. And all you really need. But I do like to use Simplify3D most of the time. Simplify3D is far superior in terms of printing options. Simplify3D works directly over USB with the MakerBots but doesn't work directly over USB with the Dreamer (but does work with the FlashForge Creator directly over USB). Simplify3D can however be made to create G-code that's compatible with the Dreamer if you create your own custom profile for it, like I did (you need to modify the start G-code, and make a few other changes to get it working).

I am very happy with the prints it produces. It doesn't require nearly as much maintenance as a MakeBot Replicator 2 or 2X. The Dreamer is definitely made better. The Dreamer belts even have tension springs on them to help keep the proper belt tension. This is not found on the MakerBots. On them, you need to manually adjust the spacing to tighten or loosen the belts. Also on the Dreamer, the filament never jams on the rolls, a problem I had a lot on the MakerBots (the filament tends to unravel off the rolls and get twisted around the spool holder and get stuck). The filament guide tubes also never come off like they do on the MakerBots. It's just all-in-all a much more well thought out machine. FlashForge did a great job on this printer.

I have printed hundreds of things so far. In the entire year of use I've only experienced 1 major filament jam. With the MakerBot Replicator 2 and 2X I've had dozens of jams.

I have recently started comparing prints at 0.10 mm and 30 mm/s between the Dreamer and the MakerBot Replicator 2 and 2X I also use. The quality of the Dreamer at 0.10 mm is much better than the MakerBots. There's far less rough areas. The prints are a lot cleaner. At lower resolutions, the three printers are comparable, with the Dreamer only printing slightly better. But at 0.10 mm, the Dreamer really out performs the other 2. Of the three, the worst is the MakerBot Replicator 2X, which isn't surprising because of the older head it has. For the tests for all machines I'm using the Simplify3D slicer with nearly identical settings. So software slicer differences don't account for the Dreamer having better quality prints at 0.10mm.

One negative I've noticed when comparing to the MakerBots. The Dreamer is louder than the MakerBots are when they are printing. Even when you aren't printing, the fan for the CPU can be heard when it's on. The MakerBots don't have a CPU fan. They make no noise when they are on if they aren't printing.

In comparison to the MakerBot Replicator 2X, the Dreamer doesn't appear to have nearly as much edge curling problems when printing ABS. This has always been a problem when printing large ABS objects on the 2X. I have printed objects that take the entire build area of the Dreamer and saw very little detectable edge curling and no cracking. On the 2X, large ABS prints always have a lot of edge curling, and an occasional thin crack on them.

I believe the main reason for a lack of curling when printing ABS on the Dreamer is the aluminum build platform (which is covered with some black coating making it look like plastic, but it's actually aluminum). Aluminum conducts heat very well, ensuring a very evenly heated build surface. On the MakerBot 2X, I've noticed that the center of the build platform is hotter than the outer regions. This isn't the case with the Dreamer. The heat is very even across the entire build platform.

After so many prints and ordering new filament, I've found that the main negative about the dreamer is also a positive: THE FILAMENT HOLDER IS INSIDE THE DREAMER. This is great on one hand because it keeps the filament away from dust, and makes it feed flawlessly. But because commercially available filament varies so much in spool shape and size, it's tough to get filament from different companies that fits inside the dreamer properly. I didn't see this as such a big problem at first until I started ordering a lot of filament from different companies which work fine on the external MakerBot's filament holder, but won't fit inside the Dreamer's internal filament holder. I'm going to need to print an external spool holder for the Dreamer so that I can use filament of any size for my Dreamer. Being limited to certain sizes SUCKS. But it's not the Dreamer's fault that there's no standard filament size yet. Some filament also doesn't fit the MakerBot's filament holder (such as Shaxon brand filament which doesn't fit the MakerBots or the Dreamer). The lack of a standard filament roll size is a serious problem that the industry needs to address.

I have made a few free printable filament spool stand which allows me to use pretty much any brand of filament with the Flashforge Dreamer.

My free printable OmniStand Adjustable Filament Spool Stand for inside the Dreamer is found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:652415

My free printable OmniStand Top Mount Filament Spool Stand is found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:704631
summary: Great high quality low priced printer.

reviewText:
I am a proud owner of flashforge Creator Pro, Flashforge Finder and now Dreamer first let me talk about Flashforger support and company, no ,matter what is your problem and how long you own your printer flashforger support always there to support and help you solve your problem that's why I have all the 3 printers by them and any new printer release they will have I will own too, thank you Mr. Tang.
all printers has issues and will have issues from nozzle jam to extruder movement issues, and be sure that flashforge team is there with you.
now my review for the printer, I gave it 4 star rating and 1 star extra for flashforge support lets get to the pros and cons
Pros:
1. sizable build volume with the price you pay.
2. 100 micron and can really go to 75 micron at slower speed no problem I tried it, and give good quality resolution
3. Flashprint software that come with it is great slicer, I my self love Simplify3d but the flashforge print is no less.
4. low price for a good quality printer good looking and ability to use all types of filaments to your heart contents.
5. active cooling system and heated bed and wireless connection, SD card print and USB port printing, easy to use menu.
6. bed leveling is easy, not automatic but as easy as it gets for such printers.
7. Dual extruder, although I find the use of dual extruder limited, but its an option, and this printer do it very will, other dula extruder printers you would pay double the price and many failed at it.
Cons:
1. spool size and location inside the printer, it the worse feature of it but you can always overcome it by printing upgrades like I did or use external spool holder, flashforge filament is not bad at all but lacks the colors I like and there is much better quality of filaments if you have the money for it, also printing with exotic filaments such as laywood, laybrick, brass, copper, ...etc they have spool sizes that won't go to your printer, but the problem is solved if you have the patient and don't mind to print from outside
2. the plastic frame of the printer, I really not a fan of this plastic frame, creator pro and finder has a better quality frame, although this printer look good but come on the frame makes it cheap and I am always worried it melt from the heat although I know its unlikely.
3. the touch screen has an SD inside the printer some times it move out of place when it shipped, this happened to me and it renders the printer touch screen to be white and not work, I had to open the bottom cover and fix it, and now it work great but its not fun to open a new item you just bought to fix it, I wish this issue be solved in future versions of this printer.

here is links to spool upgrades that I love and helped me use 3rd party filaments:
1. [...] my favorite which I am currently using and its working great
2. [...] another great for PLA or ABS external spool holder my second best
3. [...] just a spool holder which is good really good holder idea

I hope my review helps and please comment for questions
 Update 7/30/2016
this printer proven its worth, I have 5 printers and yet this one never gave me a clog or a problem its running like a charm attached pictures of my printers.
Ultimaker 2+ is $2500 running at same if not less as Flashforge dreamer.
I love this printer its good, look at the dual extruder quality!
summary: $1099 for great printer is a win, no regrets!

reviewText: Wow!!! Great product!!! I actually had a Dremel Idea Builder before I bought this. Dremel is definitely the knockoff! I wish I had two Dreamers now. You don't need Meshmixer to build your supports!! Flashprint is gives you way more options. I'm definitely staying with this brand!
summary: Dreamer crushes Idea builder!!!

reviewText:
I purchased this printer trough the official Flashforage amazon store last year. First off I have to say that the Flashforage dreamer is a high quality and reliable 3d printer. There is a large learning curve when you first get this printer, you will need to play with the bed leveling and slicing settings. Once you figure this out the prints that you make are highly likely to succeed. The printer also is able to print with many different materials because of the All metal hotend. I have successfully printed with Nylon, PLA, ABS, TPU, Metal, and PETG without a single clog.

Don't get me wrong my experience with this printer was not without problems. When I first used the printer I found that I was not able to use the wifi connection or update the firmware of the printer, also the PLA cooling fan was not working. But all of these problems were fixed tough contact trough the excellent Flashforage customer support. Mr Tang the Flashforage Amazon support representative quickly responded to the problems that I had. Through Mr Tang I was able to get a fan replacement for no charge. If you experience any problems, I will highly recommend contacting Mr Tang for assistance.

The high quality printer with Mr Tang's support makes this printer a very good deal. The price of the Flashforge Dreamer may be slightly expensive, but you get what you pay for. In the end if you want a reliable reliable 3d printer for a reasonable price then the Flashforge Dreamer is for you.
summary: High quality and reliable printer once you get past the learning curve

reviewText:
This is one of my favorite printers to use on a regular basis, and the quality is great for the money.

Pros:
1. Really nice to have an extruder fan and case fans on a dual extruder printer. This is incredibly important if you're trying to print PLA or Ninjaflex.
2. The touch interface is much easier to use and more aesthetically pleasing compared to many of the button-style menus other printers use.
3. Overall the printer is fairly compact.
4. It is able to print flexible filaments from the factory, no upgraded extrusion block necessary.
5. Not sure why, but programs seem to post/save quicker on the SD card for this printer from Simplify3D than it does on my other printers.
6. Printer seems to be stackable, but I haven't tried it myself.
7. After ~1000 hours of printing I had one extruder fan go out, and the customer support actually responded in only a couple hours, AND they sent me a new one the same day free of charge. With so many printer companies now charging for any type of support (looking at you Makerbot) this is a breath of fresh air.

Cons:
1. The power supply is cooled by a fan so it's louder than many of the other printers in standby. While printing it's comparable in noise.
2. The internal spool holders work well for Flashforge's filament, but not well with other 'standard' filament spools. I ended up printing my own spool holders that replace the 'windows' on the sides. I'll post the thingiverse link as soon as it allows me to publish it.
summary: One of the best printers on the market for the money.

reviewText:
I'll be comparing this to an Airwolf XL which is the only other printer I've worked with. Make sure you do your RESEARCH if you've never worked with a 3D printer before so you know what to expect as this thing is not a toy! Many things can go wrong its not even funny...So expect issues because 3D printing is not perfect even if you buy a makerbot (aka the Apple of 3D printers -_-)

SETUP:
The printer comes mostly assembled, just requires some plug n' play. The most time consuming part of the setup is leveling the bed. Definitely take your time doing this and keep the Z-axis pin stop very high at first. Sparkfun has a nice setup video that is very helpful. Was not a fan of Prontoface host software so I used Repetier (does the same thing). Overall I was up and running in about an hour or two.

DETAILS:
Make sure to use the Slic3r config files that Lulzbot provides, then you can tweak those to your satisfaction. This printer is very fast! and quieter than the airwolf. I love how the bed is held down, very little do the clips holding the glass stick out onto the glass. The Airwolf and many other printers use those black binder clips to hold the glass down -_-

The extruder can heat up to 240C which is more than enough for ABS (which needs 230). Follow the temperature guides from Lulzbot and the filament manufac. The bed actually is a lot hotter than what the controller says it is, so for ABS keep it at 85C and not 110! you can damage it.

Another great thing is that I rarely have to interfere during the print process. On the Airwolf I would always have to pull off excess filament that oozes out or it may mess up the first few layers. This is rarely the case with this printer. In terms of the spool holder, it is very universal so I would say pretty much all filaments can fit on there. The Airwolf had a larger spool holder that didn't work with half of the spools out there. The feeding tube is also very useful for keeping the filament from tangling which can ruin both you print and printer.

The LCD control is pretty much the same as what the Airwolf and other printers uses. The knob that allows you to cycle through the menus requires you to turn it a few clicks before it registers but you get used to it. I don't like to leave my computer on so I used the SD card feature pretty much ever time.

I only use IC3D filament for ABS, the filament that Lulzot sells is honestly too expensive (plus shipping). The PLA I use is from MATTERHAKERS. Both companies have some of the best filament you can get.

SUPPORT:
This is crucial for me because I don't want to be stuck with $2,000+ machine with no support for WHEN things go wrong. Lulzbot has amazing support, i've already spammed their emails multiple times and they've responded within 24 hours with a fix. The forums have a lot of helpful posts as well, so use and abuse it to your advantage.

EDIT 09-2014: One of the motors (extruder) stopped working, Brent from support helped me troubleshoot the issue which ended up being the controller (RAMBo). I was slightly out of warranty but they were awesome and swapped out my entire electronics box ($200+).

Highly recommend this printer over many in it's class. Its cheaper, easier to setup and just has so much more to offer.

IM3D.org
summary: Pure Awesomeness

reviewText: VERY good. VERY sticky, gorgeous color. I used this to refurb an old channel marker sign that washed up in our yard. See the photo ... what a fun project! The adhesive on this tape stuck very securely to the new outdoor paint I used. LOVE the prismatic reflecting quality!
summary: wonderful high quality reflective tape

reviewText: This is an amazing product and I was surprised that this wasn't recommended more enthusiastically at my local hardware store when I asked for Water Proof tape. My surveillance camera went out! It took me a bit to trace the problem to a rusted out connection. I replaced the wire on the rusted side and wanted to wrap it in water proof tape - if there was such a thing (you would think there wasn't with the answers I received at the hardware store). When this tape arrived I was stumped by the lack of adhesion. No sticky stuff anywhere. One reviewer explained that you roll it on itself while stretching it pretty taut. Sure enough, there is a beautiful "Stick to itself" process that occurs and it stays tight and I read that I eventually bonds to itself. I wrapped my two cables effortlessly and could just look and tell it was sealed tight (see pictcure). What's even cooler is the camera picture instantly improved. I tucked this inside Hot Headz Extension Cord Safety Seal Water Resistant Cord Cover, 8.25 x 3 x 3-Inch, Green and am fully confident that I'm waterproof!!
summary: Great product, not messy and Great Value!

reviewText:
We run a shellfish company and we have some fairly expensive Klein Tools IR thermometer guns.  I have to calibrate our coolers and thermometers every week to make sure everything is accurate.  The department of health recommends using ice water.  Our digital stick thermometers are always slightly above 32F.  I calibrate the analog sticks to 32F if they are off.  Our Klein guns always show around 32.2-32.6 on ice in water.  This Etekcity gun shows 32.7 at EMS .95 (default).  That was the lowest temp it showed on ice.  The manually recommends .96-.98 EMS for ice, so I set it to .96.  At .96 it reads 33+ and the higher I set the EMS the more inaccurate it reads.  Either the EMS settings in the manual aren't accurate or this gun isn't as accurate our Klein Tools guns with a single laser.  It's close enough for our purposes.  Other than that issue it seems to be about the same durability, if not more durable, as the Klein guns we have.  It would be nice to have a case included as our guys tend to be pretty rough on our stuff.

Update 6/6/18:  Our last Klein finally bit the dust.  It started showing temps +/- 10F what it should have so I ordered another one of these 630s.  Both of these guns show very similar temps to each other.  After using the first one for a while now and now the second one, I can say they do seem more consistent than other IR guns I've used and the temp ranges just seem more accurate.  The dual laser must help in that respect.  The included battery in the first gun went dead within a couple months.
summary: Accuracy seems slightly off, but close enough for most purposes

reviewText: OK so I just reviewed these in the 14.5x19 size. I bought multiple sizes of this so my review is essentially the same as the other one since they are essentially the same product. (Just different sizes) I picked these up because I run a small Boutique style business online & I use these mailers for shipping out my products. I purchased 2 sizes of these & both are exactly what I was expecting. I have purchased from this company in the past & never had any issues with these envelops. I love using the colored mailers because they add a little extra pizazz to my shipments & It makes it easier for me to describe my package to the customer or if I have issues dourine shipping. These mailers are nice & strong & come in a verity of sizes making them great for mostly all of the items I wind up shipping out. reviewText: Good mounts for LEDs. The LEDs are a bit loose fitting. I would suggest that the plug be increased in length just a tiny bit to reduce play, a dab of super glue can alleviate the wobbling LED . Otherwise they seem to be good mounts. As a note, the end plugs are translucent so you will have some glow on the back side, but not a problem for most projects. Pictures shown with red 5mm LED in place.
summary: Good mounts for LEDs

reviewText:
This is an excellent thermometer. It is accurate, easy to use, and provides temperature information in seconds. The unit is lightweight yet seems very well constructed and durable. If you are looking for a baking thermometer of this style, then I recommend it to you.

Upon receiving this thermometer, I read the package materials thoroughly to gain an understanding on how to use it. The instructions on the back are clearly written and easy to understand, though my one wish is that the text was written in black ink instead of in white ink (black ink would provide better contrast against the package's gray background). Still, the content of the instructions is perfectly fine.

The thermometer came with one CR2032 battery installed, so all we had to do was push the power button and begin to use it. Right out of the box this thermometer was on the mark. We tested it with ice water, boiling water, body temperature and the ambient room temperature in our house... and this thing was dead on every time. Nice to see quality gear still available out there!

There are several features that really add value to this thermometer: It responds quickly - the advertised 6 second read time is no joke, it really was at least that fast every time; The IPX7 (water resistant) rating is very nice so we will worry less when washing it off after each use (but still would not place in the dishwasher); The range is amazing (-52 to 572 degrees F) and the ability to calibrate the temperature is great, should the need ever arise; and the 10 minute auto shutdown feature will probably save us purchasing a few extra CR2032 batteries over time.

The look and feel of this unit is very nice. If you would like to see pictures I took of the thermometer, please navigate to the unit's main sales page, scroll down to where the "Most Helpful Customer Reviews" section starts, and look to the right of that area for the "Product Images From Customers" section.

There was no reference to a warranty on the Amazon sales listing page, and the package provides and email address to contact for warranty questions. While I did not contact Measupro via that email address, if an issue arises I will return here to update the review and let you know what the issue was and how resolution was handled. I did receive this thermometer gratis from the manufacturer and have put it through its paces to objectively find out how well it performed. My statements here reflect that testing.

If you are looking for baking thermometer of this size and style, for use as I have described above, based on our experience I would recommend this one wholeheartedly. Very worth giving it a try.

Go for it.
summary: MeasuPro TF5000 Thermocouple Digital Baking Thermometer - Wide temperature range - Large LCD readout - Accurate - Works well

reviewText:
Great set of wire piecers for the price. My local Frys store wanted an arm & a leg for one of these. I decided to pick them up from here & the quality is superb. Helps me test wire voltages when working on electrical equipment in my car without having to cut up the whole wire.

Using them with my INNOVA 3320 multimeter with no issues.
summary: Using them with my INNOVA 3320 multimeter with no issues.

reviewText:
I was able to connect to both MacBook and Dell laptops (eventually). Only real problem is attachments (mirror) are too-wide for standard spark-plug hole, but camera itself will fit (see photo). Camera is 0.335"-diameter, attachments are 0.575"-diameter, spark-plug hole is about 0.520'-diameter.

It took me 4-computers to get the software installed, because small-diameter CD doesn't work in self-loading drives (only in "tray-drives"). Software isn't needed though, as there are no drivers on the CD (it's a "USB Camera", compliant with Windows7 and my OS-X). But the software has some nice features, if you're using in a PC-environment (software not Mac-compliant).
summary: One major-flaw, otherwise decent

reviewText:
This review refers to the Endoscope model TD0310 with the 5 m cable.  A specialist accessory received for evaluation and review.  There are a whole range of uses for this versatile tool, but in a nutshell, it allows a thorough investigation of small, dark, hidden, out-of-range spaces.  The idea is the same as the medical version, a long flexible tube with a camera head (8.5 mm in this case) and some strong LED lights to illuminate the way at one end and a standard USB connector at the other.  The camera resolution offers a very useful quality range: up to 600 x 1200 pixels, and the images we get are really sharp, especially after a little experimentation.  The ability to regulate the light intensity is a definite asset.  This unit is waterproof and appears to be very tough and fit for the its intended applications;  some examples: investigating the state of a location out of reach of fingers and eyesight; locating an obstruction inside a tube or conduit (even full of water); verifying the condition of the back of appliances that cannot be moved; car repairs.  It's the sort of thing that, once you own it, you will find many uses for, that are not immediately apparent.

We initially tested it by photographing the inside of a Hummingbird electrified guitar.  The output jack had worked loose once again (it had already been sent back for professional remedial action once).  Due to the very limited space inside the guitar body, just enough for a slim hand, it was essential to know the exact situation.  We had already spent a lot of frustrating time trying to screw the piece back on.  Once the Endoscope head had been put into position, we were able to view the whole area and identify both the problem and the solution.  We fixed the guitar in under one minute.

In the box are the endoscope itself, some small tools that attach to the camera head (a hook, mirror and magnet), software installation CD, and a manual (also on the CD). The software loaded without problems on a laptop running Win 8.1.  Manoeuvring the photo head was easy enough (it would be even easier inside a tube), taking still photos and especially video were intuitive and successful.  The other option is to simply view the camera's progress on the screen, but recording the images may be useful.  I was quite blown away by the quality of the images, and the performance of this brilliant diagnostic tool.  I'll be making a video as soon as I have a moment, but for now I'll just post some photos and a screenshot taken from video footage.
summary: Brilliant diagnostic tool for those small, dark places

reviewText: This is a really neat little gizmo! It works really well. It is pretty accurate, good enough accuracy for hobby and experimenter/technician use. And the price is good. It comes just as you see it in the manufacturer's picture. I added a battery holder clip and used some standoffs to mount the board and battery to a piece of hobby wood just so it wouldn't sit on the backside of the PCB and the battery wouldn't be floating all over the place.
summary: It works well is pretty accurate, good enough accuracy for hobby and experimenter/technician ...

reviewText:
Fairly easy to wire and will 'sorta' fit into a standard US box. I finished up the re-wire of my 1989 Craftsman Flex-Drive 10" table saw by replacing the original switch that was difficult to use.

Pros:
Works well.
Start button is nicely shrouded to prevent accidental starts.
Really like the large STOP paddle.

Cons:
Is not a magnetic switch. Switch will remain on if power is interrupted then re-established.
Needs to be partially dis-assembled to mount into box. Depending on box design, you may need longer screws.

I used a non-metallic box designed for conduit. It had two 1/2" openings in the bottom. In order to secure the power cords, I used two press fit cable locks. Switch was mounted to a piece of steel, secured to the table extension with 2 1/4-20 button heads. I needed to make the mount long, with the possibility of swapping the rip fence from right to left.
summary: Good Upgrade

reviewText:
I finally used this to print up some small items. As a structural material, there are some drawbacks. The feeling, and my guess equivalent strength, is balsa wood. Very light material, but not as strong for compressive forces as regular PLA. It also doesn't have a lot of layer strength, so I'd suggest using more infill than you would normal. For example, the barrels you can see in the pic have been printed in both grey PLA and this wood filament, with the exact same settings (10% Infill, .1mm layers). The PLA filament is surprisingly strong. I'm not certain at this size that I could break them with my bare hands, while with the wood filament I broken one in half just touching it on the print bed (wasn't even trying to take it off yet).

But that's not why I bought it. I wanted to simulate wooden objects at small scale for D&D, and for that it works incredible well. I've very happy with the results. I tore out some of the infill from the broken barrel to use as straw packing material in the crates and it looks pretty realistic. I've sanded them a little, and that seems to work okay, though I haven't tried it extensively yet. The resulting models are noticeably lighter than with PLA. Overall it is pretty easy to work with, and adhered to the bed well (heated glass bed, 80C, 205C for the extruder, and using washable glue sticks).
summary: Useful material, but be mindful of the weaknesses

reviewText:
Every AmScope product we've bought has been a winner in the value department.

Years ago we got the kids (ok, really a gift for myself) an Amscope "Compound Biological Microscope", and I was impressed with the quality of the construction and optics for the price.  A lifetime ago I worked in a biology research lab using name-brand microscopes costing 4 figures, and for 10% of the cost we were definitely getting far more than 10% of the capability.  We even submitted some images to the Nikon "Small World" competition -- of course we didn't win, but sure was fun.

At that time we also got boxes of AmScope slides, coverslips and a couple sets of AmScope prepared slides.  Again those were all excellent quality for the money and provide endless fun and education.

So finally, about this product, these slides and cover slips: the same excellent value and for the money, great for student use.  We had finally used up our original stock, and was very glad to find these on Amazon at this price.
summary: AmScope always delivers fantastic value.

reviewText:
Im a librarian who has used Amazon since 1998 (when they only sold books and magazines) and this is the FIRST item Ive ever returned! Amazon lists me as being a customer "only" since 2000, but I used them before that for work/personal items.

THE SHORT REVIEW:

I plugged it into the wall AC after checking that it was set to 110 AC. This units specs are up to 30V / 5A.

I turned on the power switch and immediately the fan kicked in and the Voltage shot to 50.2V and the current went to 6.65A and the knobs had no effect of any kind.

I snapped a photo and typed a quick note to the seller (By4Easy) about the problem. The CV light was also on. The low switch only changed the current down to 3.3 amps.

A few seconds after sending the email I heard a large BANG and something blew up inside the unit.

This power source lasted less than 3 minutes.

After multiple emails over a couple weeks, and driving around town a bit I received a FULL refund.

THE LONGER REVIEW IF YOU'RE INTERESTED:

Youre supposed to use the supplied leads to short out the unit and make adjustments to the current / voltage but it was at 50v 6a and I was a little leery about that. I hesitated, but again, the unit was on for less than 3 minutes (more about that down below).

I emailed again and asked for a refund saying the unit blew up and won't turn, they asked for a photo of the problem.

I sent them the photo of the readouts at the super high levels (glad I wasted a few seconds taking the photo, or else Id have had to send just a photo of the unit turned off/dead).

They emailed back and said theyd send me a shipping label. It was a self ship. I paid $35 + $15 for this unit. The shipping from the Post Office was $39 BEFORE any insurance. The UPS store was just a little less, but still more than the unit cost me. That in itself shows that if you get a working version of this item it really is a DAMN GOOD DEAL! If

So, I wasted a day driving around to shipping companies, having them way this thing and measure the box and then quote some outrageous price. None of their weights, measurements seemed to match each other, but every single one wanted about $40 to ship this thing back home.

Having never returned anything in my past 18 years on Amazon I thought that was the end of it and itd just pull some of the heavy and nice seeming parts off this thing, but someone told me to re-email the seller. I did and a day later they emailed a new shipping label that was pre-paid. Cool!

They received (and signed) for the package after a few days. About a week later I emailed and asked about the refund. They emailed back and said theyd issue me a refund. Um, okay. Obviously they got the item back but did nothing about it. The next day I got a refund notice from Amazon and a few days after that the refund appeared on my credit card.

I am a librarian. Ive been using Amazon since 1998, back when they only sold books and magazine subscriptions. This is the FIRST ITEM IN 20 years Ive tried to return. I think this is only my SECOND 1 star rating since 1998. You can go see some of the items Ive reviewed/rated beforeI research and am generally very, very happy with my purchases. If the product is what is was supposed to be they get a 5 star, if  kinda sucks or I hate it for personal reasons it's a 4. I'm an easy grader, even though this review will sound run-of-the-mill whiney to many, that's not my style.

I knew this purchase would be a gamble because of all the reviews saying the power cords arrive with short circuits in them. I figured if that was the case I could just use a spare computer cord and throw away the one that comes with the unit. I would have rated it 5 stars if that were the case, but this just went to a deadly 6.6 amps (albeit, the promised 5 amps would be just as deadly I suppose-but not deadly to the actual unit).

The instructions say: turn on unit, THEN short out the terminals and quickly make adjustments. The supplied banana plug fell off the wire lead upon opening the package. Even if this thing didn't blow up I don't feel good about attaching (AS AN INTENTIONAL SHORT) cheap, thin wires to a RUNNING power supply blasting out 50v 6.6a. Yeah, I know people say that even cheap leads are good up to 10amps, but Im thinking: these people cant build a power supply, they cant attach the banana plug to a lead so it stays attached in shipping, Im going to trust my life/fingers to them? Anyway, there wasn't time: the thing just blew up sitting on the shelf with nobody touching it, thankfully. I supposed an experienced electrician would have immediately leaped across the table, shut it down and diagnosed the problem while disassembling it and simultaneously drinking a cup of coffee and doing a crossword puzzle. Um, yeah. Maybe. But with 50 volts at over 6.5 amps they/ I / we shouldnt have to and I'm more of a Lissajous Figure/Oscilloscope mellow type of guy. New to the higher voltages, lol.

Ive watched YouTube videos of people unboxing and using this SAME MODEL unit and they plug it in and it doesnt go past zero (let alone 50v) and explode. They plug it in, marvel at the cool red digital readout and then go on to whatever project their doing. Many owners weren't sure if the unit had a fan in it, yet my fan screamed on start up louder than my Dell desktop running Vista. Mine was special.

After unplugging the now dead brick I noticed 3 of the 4 screws holding the transformer to the bottom of the unit were loose. These are the screws sticking out of the bottom of the unit: I did NOT open the unit up. Did the transformer shift and short out something inside? I didn't want to peak inside since I was going to return this defective unit. I did notice the paint was flaking off the case near the almost all the screws that hold the case on. Had someone been playing inside this unit before or was it just a lousy paint job?

I knew that and gambled it would be a simple power switch, AC cable, AC to unit interface joint problem that people other were experiencing and then fixing. A fun, cheap way to get a power supply that you kind of fixed/modified yourself. Or heck, maybe Id be in the chosen few and get a unit that actually WORKED like promised.

Nope: I guess I got the NEW AND IMPROVED version that is shorted and runs at twice spec for a minute or two then explodes. It was LITERALLY less than three minutes by the time stamps on my photos and emails. Bummer, but for what I paid theres some nice parts I could have scavenged in the worst case scenario.

I noticed the instruction manual covers a bunch of different versions of this unit, including ones that go up to 60v. Maybe some 60v parts snuck into my unit-not enough to keep it from exploding thoughthat awful snap of an electrolytic capacitor (Im guessing) going off like a firecracker.

Honestly, 17 years on Amazon and there was a batch of cheap camera lens covers that fell off because they weren't true Canon size (which I gave a 3 star review); a bipod that arrived missing one of the two mounting pins that were supposed to be WELDED on (which I gave a 1 star review and repaired myself kinda sorta; and then THIS hunk of electric danger. [Edit: I have now made a SECOND return in 17 years on Amazon, because I was shipped a Counterfeit item-confirmed by manufacturer when I tried to register it-but that was not from this seller].

Thats about it for bad experiences in 17 years of buying for myself (tons of weird gadgets like spectroscopes, fancy telescope and camera stuff) and for libraries (books and office supplies). I wasn't even going to buy it and deleted it off my wish list, but I recently had an incredible run of some big, expensive and boring life purchases (mattress, car repair parts, medical bills, etc.) and wanted something fun.

Oh, you can see through the vent holes the less than stellar soldering job the boys in the FlingDung factory did. Its not horrible (what I can see) but you can definitely tell a human did the soldering and not a machinein a not so great way. To be sure, if you look inside the Elenco kit power supply that *I* soldered together a couple weeks ago youd probably laugh at a few things as well, but then again, you don't HAVE to look inside mine because mine WORKS.

Also, Ive only soldered 5 kits in the past few years and Id say the best of their soldering is better than the best of mine, but the worst of their soldering is way worse than the worst of mine. But then: I do not get paid to solder things and again, MINE WORKS! This does not.

My self-soldered capacitance decade box works fine! Along with the Geiger Counter in a coffee can (it raises the voltage when my ionizing uranium/uraninite test source is near, but does nothing with other rocks in my mineral collection and tallies pretty well with my real store-bought Geiger counter).

Are you looking for cheap parts or a possible mystery problem to figure out? Well, this unit is for you. Its very, very heavy and looks really cool. The digital meters wold look kinda cool hooked up to another (working) power supply if you want this thing for parts. There are course and fine adjustment knobs, which if ordered by themselves would probably cost as much as this unit.

The banana plug leads seem nickel coated, which is why the factory workers were unable to successfully solder the banana plugs and alligator clips to each end. DANGEROUS because theyll pull out and youll have a live wire dangling somewhereif your unit actually works. If

I opened the bag with the wire leads and a banana plug just fell out on its own. Ugh!

MAKE SURE TO CHECK OUT THE KOOKY PHOTO I POSTED HERE (sometimes the Amazon phone/tablet apps don't show customer photos so you may have to use the browser version or a desktop computer). It shows 50V / 6.5 Amps. They were both a tad higher, but remember, a few seconds after snapping the photo something inside this thing literally exploded.

I suppose I could be angry/upset/indignant/etc. but I just chuckled. Also: THE SELLERS WERE REALLY POLITE in their various emails to me, and DID get me a FULL refund. However, this product is obviously junk and they really shouldnt be selling it until they fix the multitude of manufacturing problems they're continuously encountering in their factory for the past few years ago to some of the other reviews here.

Save yourself trouble and look elsewhere. Never buy anything that isn't PRIME / shipped by Amazon themselves / Fulfilled by Amazon if it was worth returning upon receipt of a defective unit. I lucked out and (after multiple prodding emails along the way) got a successful refund of ALL my money on this item.

Ive soldering up my own working power supply that is still working just fine. All I did was plug this unit in and it blew up. This was my first ever Amazon return in 17 years. I am jealous of people who just had faulty power cords, etc. that were easy fixes.

-Mike from Detroit
summary: SELLER IS AWESOME - BUT THE UNIT IS NOT

reviewText:
Up to this point every similar model of battery operated under cabinet light has shared the same negatives  they are cheap plastic, they look ugly, they need to be screwed down or attached with hard-to-use clip mounts, they throw uneven light and they are expensive.

The Bliss model is the best, hands down, I have seen so far. It looks and feels substantial, being primarily brushed aluminum. It is much smaller than competitive models and will win as best looking every time. The mounting system is genius  press it in place and the super-strong tape holds it there. Want to remove it as a portable light or to change the batteries? Simply grab and go, it is held in place by strong magnets. The lighting pattern is wide and smooth with an even falloff at the edges and this is one of the lowest price LED under-counter lights I have seen (except for a few that were really junk).

Bliss makes the identical light in two models. Ive included photos showing them side-by-side (they are identical looking). But when they are turned on there is a (excuse the expression) night and day difference. The warm white that this review is about looks like the illumination in a typical home. It is a soft color of lighting that you hardly notice. I am using mine under a cabinet in my kitchen which has halogen track lighting and the light from the Bliss blends right in. I love that it turns on only when human hands move under the counter and then turns off about a minute later. Why turn an entire track-light of halogen ceiling lights on just to go pour a drink at the counter?

I also included a photo that shows the twin model that produces a cool light color. This color is more in line with daylight and works better in the shop, office or outdoors.

IMPORTANT: this is something you will want to know when choosing between the two models. The warm while light is MUCH brighter than the cool white, like about 10 times brighter. There are times you may want that brightness and other times where you would prefer a more subtle light. I have the cool white mounted subtly under a counter lip in the guest bathroom so it illuminates the toilet bowl. It throws just enough light without glaring and being a nuisance for the guest. I have also mounted one in a cabinet where we have a printer installed  the status screen and buttons are on the top of the printer and almost impossible to see. This little LED light gives it just enough illumination to be able to see the display.

This is the best of this type of light I have seen and I recommend it.
summary: The Bliss model is the best, hands down, I have seen so far

reviewText: Good for certain applications - A peek inside the valve reveals an .089" orifice with a coil-spring loaded rubber seal. The solenoid is quite powerful and the coil spring could probably be replaced with a stronger one if needed to overcome higher pressure, but the rubber seal might be a problem if used with certain solvents. Also the orifice is pretty restrictive if you are planning to use for high volume applications. The good news is that it can be disassembled if you want to tinker with it.
summary: Good for certain applications -

reviewText: These work as expected.  I am using them in my craft room to hold paint and glitter, but they could work equally well in a garage or pantry if you had pegboards in those areas.  The large basket is large enough to hold peanut butter or cooking oil in the pantry.  It's significantly sized.  I am not sure what you'd use the small one for in a pantry, but it about the width of a sharpie.  I use it in the craft room to store glitter glues.  I added some photos so you could see the size.
summary: Great for the Craft Room

reviewText:
I am really torn on how many stars to give this product.

These baskets are very sturdy. In fact, they are, by far, the sturdiest peggable baskets I own. I love that. I also love the coating on them that lends a bit of protection to anything I place in them.

But, a couple of factors work strongly against them.
1) They don't work on any of my pegboards. The prongs are just too long to place properly without a good bit of distance between the pegboard and the wall upon which it is hung. All of my other pegs and baskets hang beautifully from my pegboards. These just won't work.
2) The coating is easily damaged by an initial attempt to insert these baskets into a pegboard.

Having said that, I want to go ahead and mention that I quickly discovered an even better use for these baskets than the pegboard. In fact, the length of the prongs make this usage possible!

I have a wire shelf that I like to hand things from. These baskets hang perfectly on the edges of that wire shelf! So, I'm actually kind of excited that they didn't work on the pegboards in the garage or in my daughter's bedroom. They'll be very useful in my kitchen.
summary: Didn't Work on Pegboard - but Still Useful!

reviewText: Great buy and it can be used in a variety of creative ways. I had received a garden hose to try out, so I purchased this nozzle to use with it since the one I owned was very old and leaky. I love this nozzle! It has so many different settings that I was amazed. Any task you could possibly want to do . . . there's a setting for it. A very high quality piece of workmanship, this nozzle looks like it will last for a very long time.
summary: Works Great!

reviewText:
**7/8/2016 update- a few more projects were completed...
The Sonicrafter has completed each task quickly, easily and because of that great help the noise level doesn't bother me any longer. The Rockwell 4.0A Sonicrafter has earned its 5 stars for being all around effective tool making life easier and worthy of recommending to others.

The sander works great sanding down unpainted wood (pallet wood that was being re-purposed for outdoor stuff)- I had no issues with the pad slipping off (it is velcro adhesion- just place it on the sanding pad,light press, and sand). It smoothed out the general unfinished surface of rough saw cut wood, leveled off the uneven cut marks, and removed splintering wood.

It was great for resurfacing by sanding away the weathered gray black discolored wood down to the "fresh" brighter wood surface in preparation for staining. For some reason I did not think it would because it looked so small, so yes, I was impressed that this small triangular sanding head can really get a lot done.

The photo shows the heavy duty metal hinge the Sonicrafter easily cut through when I replaced the hinges that rusted off an old custom sized screen door. The metal semi circle saw did the job quickly without issues or heating up. It was a simple task to make it fit without having to undo the screen and trim I had just replaced.

--------------
I am happy with my purchase so far it seems to be fine serving its purpose thus I feel I got a good value.
However I must point out something that I was not prepared for when I purchased this: I had no idea about the ear drum blowing volume of the Rockwell 4.0A Sonicrafter F50 with the sawing blade when working and doing its thing.

It is screaming LOUD, so loud that it's almost ridiculous that such a level of noise is coming from this small tool and small blade.
I will harp on a bit longer about how loud the Sonicrafter F50 is because I was shocked when I used it. It is so loud that, seriously, all of the neighbors on my block will know when I am using this tool each and every time.
To compare the sound level, circular saws are loud but it is a bigger tool bigger saw blade etc, but the Sonicrafter F50 is about as loud but with a screeching higher pitch.

Since this is my first oscillating multi-tool, I do not know if perhaps most oscillating multi-tools are the same way concerning the volume. I think that it is just the way this tool works not that there is anything wrong with it.

Aside from the noise, YES this tool performs well for cutting through and notching wood, metal nails, and plaster. Use ear protection for the noise level and eye protection because you never know and our eyes are precious.

I have yet to use the sander functions but the cutoff blades work satisfactorily leading me to believe that when I get better name brand blades this tool will work that much better- as in less time to saw through something.

The blades held up well - nothing warped, broke or fell apart. I was worried about the blade failing after reading what happened to other reviewers. Luckily this did not happen to me using the blades that came with the Rockwell Sonicrafter.

The unit does warm up after using longer than a few moments- such as few times in a row working a few minutes each time. My first project was using this was to cut through some small wood pallet slats and rusted nails. Did the job.  The second project was cutting out a few areas in old plaster. It got dusty, so I made sure to keep the air vents clear and free of debris and the Rockwell did the job.

The Rockwell Sonicrafter F50 did each task without fail but I wonder if the heating of the unit (something I noticed since the first time using it) is a sign of the eventual demise of the motor.

The speed control is easy to access and use. The LED light on the unit does not really do much for illuminating a marked guideline, but if I was working in a dark corner or recessed area it should would work well to light up the blade cutting area.

Attaching and releasing the blade is not difficult and secures very well but it is not intuitive. Once you got the flip the lever up, to the side and then crank it around, it is very easy. The instructions could be more descriptive but for good measure I looked up more information  on how to that is provided above by the seller and read other reviewers' pointers.

I like that it comes with its plastic carrying case that fits the blades and tool with room for extra blades and sanding pads.

Conclusion: I am happy with my purchase, it is well made and very useful. It is a good value in comparison to other oscillating multi-tools on the market. I am also glad that I have proper ear protection to use to muffle to noise of this tool. *I will update if the heating up of the unit becomes a fail or a cautionary flaw after more projects and when I test the sanding functions.
summary: Good but Loud

reviewText: Amazon keeps removing my bad review of this product. Not sure why, but trust me this stuff is total junk. Got three rolls and two of the three had major issues, If you look at the uploaded photos you will see major issues with blobs every few feet. I just tossed it all in the trash. I would never buy this cheap junk again regardless what the last user says. I buy PLA all the time. I have purchase over 50 rolls from various companies and this stuff was by far the worst I have seen. I guess the truth hurts which is why Amazon keeps removing my review. This stuff clogged my extruder so bad I needed to replace it.
summary: Total junk do not waste your money or time.

reviewText:
Update #5
After trying get support from XYZprinting, they refused to honor my warranty.  At this point, the printer is paper-weight. The hardware is decent so I've decided to swap the control board with Arudino & Ramp 4.1.  Wish I've gone with another printer. But will have to make lemonade with with lemon I guess.  If you intend on getting Da Vinci, get the cheaper 1.0A and NOT this 2.0A.

Update #4:
After nearly a 9 months of usage, left extruder stopped, then filament gear stopped working. It's become an expensive paper weight in office.  Their XYZprinting support is terrible.  Regret in this purchase.

Update #3:
Found this CALIBRATION PROCEDURE works best with less calibrations need between prints:
Start a demo print. As soon as it warms up and begins to print, watch  extruder head moves over the side print bed and begins the purge line. TURN OFF power before begins purge line.  With printer off; move the extruder head carefully over print bed by hand. Grab towards the top where the filament feeds in to avoid the hot extruder head.
Move extruder head back left corner. Lay piece of  paper on the bed and slide it under the nozzle. Once the paper is under the nozzle adjust the bed height so you can just feel the paper being grabbed by the nozzle as you slide the paper around. Repeat on all four corners.  Once you are satisfied, move extruder head by hand back to home position (back right corner over the white drip pan).  Turn the power on, go Utilities and select "Home all axis".

Update #2:
I had to remove the SD card due to "0040" lower memory.  DaVinci support said to re-seat the SD card.  This was not easy to do (had to unscrew circuit board in back panel); but in the process discovered a Class-4, 4Gig SD card.  I replaced this with a Class-10, 8Gig SD card. So far the 0040 error has disappeared.

Update #1:
It's important to CALIBRATE printer bed before attempting to print; or it will fail. The instruction says the printer was "Factory Calibrated" but the bed is still off.  You need to calibrate close(but not exact) to X,Y,Z axis of: 100,100,100.  After EACH print select "Clean Nozzle" and brush off excess filament on the metal extruder. If you don't do this; the tiny piece of melted filaments from last print will mix with your new print: resulting in fail. Also, if printing something w/ lots of details or arches; select "support" and "raft" in Advance print option on XYZprint software.  Orientation of item is also important for successful print. Have sharp razor to pry the model after it's finished; the plastic spatula provided is worthless!  For comparison; a friend who has DaVinci 1.0 said the print quality on 2.0 is better.  This printer unlike alot of other 3D printer comes with a door; what this means the smell of ABS melting and noise from printing is kept low. I can't help but stare at the thing printing for first few minutes; it's almost like baking watching anxiously for your creation to "rise" of of nothing.  Finally, I found tinkcad and meshmixer very helpful for modifying and creating 3D model for novice.  My 7yr old was using tinkercad to create army tank with squares and cylinder.

My first package was lost in during shipping. Amazon sent another next-day only after I sent complaint.
Now for product review.  The manual says not to calibrate since it's factory-calibrated; but mine would not print and "Filament Jam" error until I had to calibrate it several times and had to remove and re-insert the filament.  After that it printed the demo figure fine.
So far; I am impressed with printer in its look and print detail.  Only cons: use of proprietary filament cartridge, and XYZ software.
summary: Good 3D printer

reviewText:
I used to use the test strips to test my drinking water, along with other things (aquariums, etc...) but  after using this handy little gadget, I wonder why I didn't find one of these sooner. I suspect that as time goes by, I will be finding more uses for it. The instructions were pretty basic and easy to follow. I got a gallon of distilled water from the local Walmart for .88 cents. (I also use it in my steam iron, and in the old car battery, so I always have some around). The meter comes in a plastic case which is not very durable (I had loose pieces of it rattling around inside when I got it) but it does give you something to keep it in along with the calibration screwdriver, calibration buffer packets, and instructions.

 The instructions called for a 250 ml. glass beaker to mix the calibration solution in. I, being more of a hobbyist rather than a chemist, decided to use a Pyrex measuring cup instead, which worked rather well. I calibrated it using the 4.0 pH.buffer mix after thoroughly rinsing out the cup with distilled water. I then tested the distilled water @ 4.7

Other test results included;

White vinegar 5%  2.45
Kroger Big K diet cola  3.1
Brewed coffee  5.65
Almond milk  7.15
Loveland, CO city water  7.86
Baking soda and water  8.0
OxyClean and water  10.8

All of these results were within the expected range. And I am satisfied with the operation of the meter. After testing these samples, I rinsed the bulb with distilled water before placing the meter back in the calibration solution, and had it reading 4.0 once again. The instructions did not state the need for storing the unit with the bulb immersed in any kind of solution. They merely state that you should rinse the bulb in distilled water before putting the protective cap on. I also do not anticipate the need to calibrate often.

The green back lighting on the display is a nice touch, and really helps make for easy reading. I see another aquarium in my future, and plan on putting this unit to good use.

I was provided with a free sample in return for my unbiased evaluation.
summary: Handy little meter for a great price.

reviewText: Totally inaccurate and could not be calibrated.  This device uses a single potentiometer or calibrate the device, which means it will only be accurate at one point along the 1-14 pH range.  The use of the term High Accuracy is highly inaccurate.  The accuracy is barely 0.8 units, and only if calibrated immediately prior to use.  Mine worked poorly for about five days, and then the Devil took control of it.  When I turned it on, it displayed 666 (see picture), and after a few seconds, displayed a very low pH value nowhere close to that of the solution being measured.  I worked with it for nearly an hour trying to get it to recover, but 666 kept showing up.  There is no 666 in the instructions, so I assume my meter was possessed.  I returned it the next day.
summary: Highly Inaccurate and then it became possessed

reviewText: really? look it is missing a tooth it failed as expected - as the weld was not good.  No good!
summary: look it is missing a tooth it failed as expected - as the weld was not good. No good

reviewText:
I purchased this caliper to use with my 3D printing endeavors.  I needed something to accurately measure when designing 3D models to print.  For the money, I'm pleased with this caliper.  There is a little bit of slack in the tool so if extremely low tolerances are important to you, this is not the caliper for you.  But I'm not designing surgical instruments so a 0.5mm or so tolerance is quite acceptable for my needs.

The photos in this review include measurement of a printed puzzle that was 20mm wide, and filament at 1.75mm.  Both measured exactly as expected!  The caliper comes in a sturdy case which I appreciate!  A spare battery is also provided, which is a nice bonus!

I try to write helpful, concise reviews for all of my Amazon purchases.  If you found this to be helpful, please let me know by clicking yes below.  Thank you!
summary: Good value for the price!

reviewText: the description's picture displays radial diodes. These are axial. Although the actual product is displayed before purchase so I purchased them for replacement of the same type. Only problem is they are very small and difficult to install by hand.
summary: Tiny

reviewText:
I had a hard time finding a translucent blue PLA filament with any reviews so I decided to give this one a shot.  I'm glad I did because this stuff prints surprisingly well.  On a Printrbot Simple Metal with official heatbed, at 65c on the bed and 200c on the hotend all of the parts I've tried so far came out very clean.  It also oozes less than some other filaments I've tried, which is nice.
The color comes out sort of aqua blue/green at first for very thin layers, but the thicker the object being printed the bluer it becomes.  The end product is only slightly transparent, but good enough for what I wanted it for.
summary: Great translucent blue PLA for the price.

reviewText:
Prints well on my PrintrBot Simple Metal.  I find all the Hatchbox filament to be very consistent - packaging, filament diameter, temperature.  However the different colors do print at different temperatures.  I print white at 195C, and this blue at around 190.  Black prints best at 185.

Remember that since the filament is transparent, it's only really useful at 0% infill, or 100%.  Otherwise, you will see the internal structure produced by the slicer (see image.)  The robot is printed at 0% infill, the others at 20%.

The color is a bit lighter than blue painters tape.  Not really my favorite blue, but it's OK.
summary: good filament, but I wish the blue were darker.

reviewText:
Not bad on specs, the diameter is actually fairly tight, but that's where the positives end.
This is not black, at best it is silver, grey, pewter, platinum, white gold ish.
I did a photo that i sent to Hatchbox and got no response what so ever. I have added that photo to this review. there "transparent black" is the lower left step pyramid, opaque black top left, opaque white top right, transparent white lower right. decide for yourself if you consider this (the lower left) transparent black.
The color problem is a shame actually, because i kind of like it as a silver/pewter,.. but what i wanted was a transparent black, and when i think transparent black what I am thinking is dark tinted car windows, this is nowhere near that. keeping it only because its probably the closest to a real silver iv ever printed with.
Oh and the half spools at nearly normal full spool pricing is just ridiculous, not doing that again, ever..
summary: Not bad on specs

reviewText: Unlike the other Hatchbox filaments, this one had large impurities in it.  Buried down in the spool were chunks of black burnt nasty stuff that messed up my print.  See photo.
summary: Unlike the other Hatchbox filaments, this one had large ...

reviewText: It prints very nicely. I have not had any problems with clogging. Thickness is very consistent. The filament is pretty transparent on the roll but once printed is more of a shiny grayish color.  You can see the infill pattern on some things depending on your settings. I found I like it best when what ever you're printing has a high infill percentage or has a thick shell so you don't see as much of the infill pattern.
summary: It prints very nicely. I have not had any problems with clogging

reviewText:
This filament works nicely, certainly better than the filament I was using first. As others have said, it is not a noticeable blackness, it looks more silver, crystal, or light grey than black. Personally, I find that to be a minor gripe. The filament produces some great results, and can look amazing. If you are looking for a noticeably black filament, then this isn't the best choice. If you are curious, or like the results, then don't hesitate to try it out.

It is the second filament that I have tried, but possibly one of my favorites. It definitely convinced me to get more Hatchbox filament. The difference in quality is evident. Keep up the good work.

As for the seller, everything went smoothly. The item arrived quickly, with no problems. I have nothing bad to say about them. I just wish they would make it available with Prime, like many of their other filaments. That is really only a minor gripe. I have, and will continue to buy more filament from them.
summary: This filament works nicely, certainly better than the filament I was using ...

reviewText: Used this to print Windows on a model a friend asked me to make on my printer.  Worked great with the led behind providing light for a night display.  Printed well on a creator pro at 200C bed 50C
summary: Used for to print Windows on a model

reviewText: This is one of my favorite colors because it has an almost metallic flake look to it. Really happy with the quality and price.
summary: This is one of my favorite colors because it has an almost metallic flake look ...

reviewText: Fun to have on hand, especially making figures for kids. As with any glowing filament, it is of what you make of it, others say some are weak etc .... you have to learn how to charge it, and what to realistically expect. Hatchbox knocks another out of the park. :) HATCHBOX PLA 3D Printer Filament, Dimensional Accuracy +/- 0.03 mm, 1 kg Spool, 1.75 mm, Glow in the Dark
