reviewText: awesome!!!!
summary: Love Hatchbox

reviewText: Bought this to print some stuff for my niece and nephew. Tried the T-Rex skull model by Makerbot and it printed great on the first try with regular PLA settings on a PEI bed.
summary: Great glow in the dark filament

reviewText:
This isn't terrible filament, but it's the worst I've found of the five spools I've purchased so far. My biggest complaint is that it's not really red. It could look red under the right light, but I've just started describing the color to people as orange.

Please see the attached picture for an example of two things printed with this filament, it makes the color really clear.
summary: Transparent red isn't red

reviewText:
In my Makerbot 2X, this works great.  I print at 210 - 215C using the Makerbot Desktop software and have had 100% success with it.

The glowing of the material is pretty good.  I built a Overwatch Loot Box with the glow panels and it glows for hours at night.  The glow retention is based on how thick your object is and what infill you use.

The B9 Robot has 100% infill and glows all night long.  The glow will be super bright when you shine a flashlight on it, but to get the longest glow, just let it sit out in a room with bright lighting and let it soak in.  It will release the photons for much longer if you do that.

4 Stars because it does take some fiddling to figure out what works best for your printer.

I will be buying this again
summary: Pretty dang cool!

reviewText: I saw the mixed reviews on the brightness of the glow effect and was very disappointed at my results with this filament.  I also have the Solutech glow in the dark filament and the effect is MUCH brighter.  Please note that in the attached image, the Hatchbox print is on the right and the Solutech print is on the left.
summary: Poor Glow Effect!

reviewText: I use this glow PLA all the time, the only problem I've had is it being in stock when I need to re-order. This stuff must be popular and for good reason. The glow doesn't last very long but gets the job done. The diameter is consistent ever time I've measured (usually around 1.77mm). As with all the Hatchbox PLA I've purchase I haven't had a problem with it. I will buy this again.
summary: This stuff must be popular and for good reason. The glow doesn't last very long but ...

reviewText: Used to print a clip on ram cooler mod I designed, turned out great at 200C bed 50C, added a little elmers for additional bonding.
summary: Worked great for a fan mod

reviewText:
Prints amazing on my M2 printer by MakerGear.
Wish it glowed a bit bright and a bit longer, but it's good stuff and works EXCELLENT under blacklight!
The picture is from my Millennium Falcon printing with the filament in the Webcam view.
I love it!!
summary: Prints amazing on my M2 printer by MakerGear

reviewText: Love this filament, default PLA settings in Simplify 3D work great. I only take one star off because you have to blast this with light to get it to glow brightly.
summary: Love this filament

reviewText:
This is probably one of my favorites - it glows beautifully at night and prints well with no tweaking from my usual settings on other PLA's.
I wish I could take a picture of the glow but my camera-phone just can't do it.

My only issue with this is that you can see through it more than I expected from bright light sources, but since I mainly want this to look at in the dark I don't mind.

Edit: New phone, glow picture included.
summary: ... is probably one of my favorites - it glows beautifully at night and prints well with no tweaking from ...

reviewText:
I have always had great experiences with Hatchbox filament and this spool was no different.

I printed with this at 215C on an E3D V6, running at 60mm/s at 0.2mm layer height.

There was some minor warping on my unheated bed, but as far as I could tell, it didn't affect the overall quality of the print.

Layer adhesion was great at this temperature. I haven't tried it at any other temperature yet though, because 215 is my default for PLA and seems to work well with most brands.

Now for the part everyone is wondering about; How well does it glow? It works great. I have only tried a sample of 1 other brand of glow filament, but comparing the two, the Hatchbox blows it out of the water. This stuff is hard to show in a picture, but it glows as good or better than those sticky glow in the dark stars that kids put all over their ceiling. I was pleasantly surprised with the glow quality of this filament.

Overall, this is great filament and holds up Hatchbox's reputation. I would highly recommend it for those in the market for glow filament.
summary: Glows great, flows great.

reviewText: Item arrived promptly and works very well. I've already used it to print parts for a light switch plate.
summary: Very good!

reviewText:
I love this filament, I am definitely getting more once this spool runs out. It prints beautifully, and basically has a bit of a white look to it in the daylight. Shine a light on it, and enjoy the glow. Sure, it doesn't glow too brightly for long, but it still looks good.

I tried providing some pictures that will help give an idea of what it looks like when the lights are on or off. It was challenging to get a decent picture with the lights off, but I think I got one.

It may have minor stringing, though it may be caused by my inexperience. For the most part, it prints as smooth and beautiful items. I really can't recommend this filament enough! :-)
summary: I love this filament

reviewText:
This was my first ever PLA print on my 3D printer, Son of MegaMax.  It was easy to set up, printed very smoothly, the parts had a great glossy sheen, and they glow in the dark.  Sticks to blue painter's tape on a room temperature print bed.  I printed at 190C extruder temperature.

The vase in the photo was printed using slic3r's spiral vase mode so the wall is only 0.4mm thick.  It is quite translucent, so an LED inside will shine through it, and a UV LED will be visible and cause the vase to glow, for a very nice effect.
summary: It prints!  It glows!  What more do you need?  What more do you want?

reviewText: Pretty cool stuff.  I took off one star because the glowing trait is so weak; I put an 800 lumen flashlight to it for 60 seconds and then turned off all the lights and it only glowed weakly for less than 30 seconds.  Otherwise it prints well and looks like translucent white with a tinge of green filament.
summary: Pretty cool stuff

reviewText:
Dremel sent me their Idea Builder to review for Amazon and they have a proprietary filament that was brittle and thready.  I almost gave up on their product, until I decided to break away from their filament and try a different on.  Based on the various reviews I found online, I chose the Hatchbox 1.75 Glow in the Dark PLA here.

I made a celtic skull that I found on Thingiverse.  I had made a few with the Dremel filament, and they had empty spaces and thready finishes.  The skull made with this filament is awesome!  The finish is much smoother, the iridescent finish is really pretty, and the fact that it glows in the dark is amazing, especially at Halloween (two weeks away).  I'll be making many more of these!

Because Dremel makes it impossible to use others' filament without modification to the unit, it did negate the warranty.  I had to create a homemade filament spool, and hang it outside of the unit, and wire it into the feeder tube through a "custom" hole in the side. :)

The temperature was about 217 degrees for the build.  It stuck beautifully to the 3M blue tape, and came off without a problem.  I am VERY happy with this filament!
summary: Smooth finish, beautiful build, and it glows!

reviewText:
I occasionally see several negative reviews on Hatchbox filament. This one in particular was rated lower than the others and I hesitated buying it. After trying it out, I have to say that either I am just lucky, or my printer is less picky about filament than others. I'm using an HIC Technology Prusa i3 (which uses a direct-drive extruder) and I have had zero problems with any ABS or PLA Hatchbox filament. In fact, the only filament that I have had any problems with is some silver ABS that I purchased off of Matterhackers.com.  It was more expensive than Hatchbox and so it should be "better", but it is definitely not. I tried printing several parts with it today and finally gave up after fighting constant feed issues.

This filament says it is "transparent white", but the filament itself is almost completely clear. Just with the way that a 3D printer prints, it's not going to print parts that are completely clear, of course. But it's about as close to clear as you can get without using clear polycarbonate filament. I received this  filament today and proceeded to print several parts and I was more than satisfied with the results. I'm attaching a few pics so you can see how printed parts will turn out. I shined a laser pointer and an LED through it on two of the pics so you can see how much light gets though. I've also attached pics of the new lid that I made for the 3D-printed case that I made a while back for the CC3D flight controller on my QAV250. The previous lid was black and it was very difficult to see the LEDs on the board. Making it with this material actually makes the LEDs easier to see than it would if it was crystal clear acrylic, due to the way it disperses the light. The whole thing pretty much lights up!
summary: Works great, love the stuff!

reviewText: I was excited to find a transparent filament, but it's not quite as transparent as I thought it would be. I found that the orientation of the layers has a huge impact on the transparency, so if you have problems try rotating the object 90 degrees.
summary: I was excited to find a transparent filament, but ...

reviewText: Ive been using Hatchbox Filament since I bought my ROBO 3D R1 back in May 2015 and I generally like their filaments. Ive read quite a few negative reviews on specifically on this Silver ABS filament and decided to try it anyway. I agree with certain things others have said such as, the print quality of this filament is lower than that of Black ABS or most PLA rolls. There was some blotting on the outer shell, and the layers seem to have trouble melting together, multiple prints ended up separating in the middle of the print, getting stuck to the extruder which dragged it around (separate from the other half of the print still stuck to the bed). Thats an issue I've never had with other Hatchbox Filaments even ABS filaments. I feel like it has something to do with the Silver color, possibly whatever is mixed in it to make it look metallic. I wouldn't really recommend this color, black prints very well. The only reason I wanted this color is because I wanted to try to print a miniature rim for a model car, and it would have been very convenient to have it print the color I want rather than painting it.
summary: ... 3D R1 back in May 2015 and I generally like their filaments

reviewText:
I bought these for use on my extremely tight back teeth, and I have to say that they actually DO work well for tight teeth. I also have some dental work that makes flossing in the back of my mouth nearly impossible and these Go-Between Cleaners have made a huge difference. The last time I went to the dentist for a cleaning, I was told by the hygienist that it was obvious my dental work was impeding my teeth cleaning, because there was a lot of tartar build-up specifically in that area. Not being able to floss that area or even use a traditional pick, I wasn't sure what I could do (I use a Water Pik, but apparently it can't get those hard to reach trouble spots).

So, I took a chance on these Go-Betweens and I'm already seeing a huge improvement. At first, my gums were a little swollen after I started using them because I was poking them with the tip of the device (there was a learning curve), but now that I've been using them consistently I perfected my technique and this problem disappeared. In fact, a few days ago I noted that my gums were no longer bleeding in that trouble area after cleaning them, and overall feel much better.

Not only do these work well with tight teeth, but they are also good for awkward positions since the head is flexible and can be bent to an angle that makes accessing difficult to reach areas much easier. I'm happy to help if you have any questions, and if you found this review helpful, consider leaving me feedback below, I'd really appreciate it!
summary: Yes, they actually are great for tight teeth and awkward trouble spots!

reviewText: This filament has handled everything I've thrown at it so far, from benchy prints to fan ducts to a hobby paint rack. It prints beautifully and is a gorgeous color
summary: Easy to print and nice color

reviewText: Really good color, a bit harder in construction filament then a normal color so initial feed was a little harder to start but extruded very good and smooth. I am starting to love this compaines products more every day.
summary: Nice color

reviewText:
They were out of grey so I bought this, knowing I could primer it to the same grey color as the rolls I normally use.  I needed a little more filament to finish a Gothic Cathedral for D&D.  It works just as well as the pigmented filament - which is to say perfect.  The primer stuck well and you cannot even tell which pieces were grey and which were clear.  Take note that I did not push the floors down hard onto each other - to make it easier to remove them when I need access (which is why there are spaces seen between the layers).

Note that clear means translucent, kind of a slightly pearly whitish color that passes light (unlike the white PLA which is opaque).
summary: Prints smooth and is wound perfectly - a translucent filament for when you need it.

reviewText: 3D Solutech Natural Clear 1.75mm 3D Printer PLA Filament, Dimensional Ac curacy +/- 0.03 mm, 2.2 LBS (1.0KG) Pretty good filament for the price. The Natural Clear doesn't really print clear and it took me a little bit longer to dial in on my printer but once I got my settings down I didn't have any issues. In my case it seemed to require a bit higher nozzle temperature then a standard PLA to get a nice layer flow. This of course caused any support material to be a pain to remove. I did find some interesting post processing qualities with this particular filament. When you apply a bit of heat it almost creates a satin finish.
summary: Not Really Clear When Printed But Still Fun To Create With!

reviewText: I Have had nothing but trouble with this roll. I should have returned it after the first problem.  The roll was wound up incorrectly constantly stopping prints and getting Tangled Up. Also noticed some color differences  throughout the roll.
summary: Bad roll?

reviewText: Prints well, decent clarity, nice sparkle.  Comparable to Inland Gold and eSun Crystal Blue as shown in this picture.
summary: Prints well

reviewText: I got this PLA just to try it.  I just finished my first "Low Quality" print (215C, .2mm layer height, 2 shells,  25% infill, and 1mm top and bottom layers) and it turned out amazing.  The layers blend nicely and the surfaces ended up very smooth.  I highly recommend.
summary: Like it a lot.

reviewText: so far I have had excellent results printing this, running at about 210 head 60 bed, almost finished my first spool so I ordered another, been making small car parts and getting excellent results, works great for dome light covers and inspection light lens for classic Datsuns,
summary: Five Stars

reviewText:
I bought this specifically for my new Fabricator Mini v1.5 printer, and it has printed beautifully so far. Over the next week or so I'll be printing a bunch with this filament and will update this review if anything comes up.

But so far it's been printing with the same quality as the more expensive ColorFabb filament.

Highly Recommended.

Update (3/7/2016)
Well, I'm getting pretty close to finishing off my first roll and I gotta say, I don't need to look around for a Clear PLA anymore, I found my one and only supplier for this. The stuff printed awesome on my little printer. Added a few pictures, one of a set of support feet I made for my new Fabrikator Mini, Part for the Mostly Printed CNC I'm building, and the last is a comparison between the Ultimaker Natural Filament (yellow piece) and this one.

I just can't say enough good things about this filament.

reviewText: I'm a huge fan of this filament so much so that I'm using it for my entire AM8 build. Beautiful vibrant color and consistent quality

reviewText: I like the color but the 2 rolls I tried were garbage. It's like the filament is being twisted as it is rolled onto the spool because the issue I'm having is that  the filament is twisting as it is pulled by the extruder motor causing the gear to make a clicking noise as it pulls the filament, and in turn causing gaps in my prints. This is also causing print to be brittle. I have oriented the spool in many different positions (mounted on top of printer, spool on table next to printer, ect) Some parts of a print will look smooth while other parts look bad. My bed is leveled,  I have every upgrade on my printer there is I have been 3D printing for close to 2 year and I have never had an issue like this with any other filaments I have tried. I have not tried any other colors from them but if it is anything like this green I got I definitely will not be purchasing this brand again.
summary: Worst stuff I ever used.

reviewText: One of my favorite colors and great print quality. Really smooth and bright, crisp color!

reviewText: Great filament and I really like the color
summary: Five Stars

reviewText:
I have no complaints over the print quality of this filament. It seems to print okay with the same settings I use for the other PLA filaments. I have 12 different colors of 3D solutech, and most seem to print good so far. It's the colors that are sometimes incorrect.
I would not call this "Purple".
It's more of a Hot Pink.
See picture and judge for yourself.

I ended up buying a different brand in purple because I needed something in purple, not pink. I'll still use this because it prints well, but it's not quite the color I was looking for.
summary: Good stuff, It's just not purple.

reviewText:
When I got into 3d printing, I asked a friend who has already 2+ years in 3d printing, what is the best filament to use. He recommended Hatchbox brand. I bought some of Hatchbox and he is right it is a good brand. However, I was having a hard time getting all the colors I wanted from them, so I read some review about this brand. I liked some of the reviews and decided to give it a try. My first print was on Hatchbox settings and I did have some messed up prints. I tweaked the extruder heat and the bed heat and got now the perfect setting. I have a Qidi Tech (Flashforge china duplicate) and love it. Set the extruder to 197c and the bed to 62-64.

My prints came out awesome. The feel is soft and the colors are bright, but not over shiny. Love all the colors. Just ordered more.

This review is repeated for all colors I bought
summary: what is the best filament to use

reviewText: Lovely filament. Good and consistent prints and looks good when ironed
summary: Good and consistent prints and looks good when

reviewText: Tolerable performance, but nothing more. I wouldn't use it for anything other than prototyping. This brand is one I just can't dial in settings for. I don't have these issues with anything else. Sure I get a bad print every so often of I make a bad setting here or there, but 3D Solutech is always bad.
summary: Good for drafts, but nothing more.

reviewText:
This filament is out of spec with some areas at 1.9mm and has jammed in two distinct printers.
In both cases it was necessary to bring the printer up to 225 degrees to clear the jam.
Worse yet, this vendor is playing the Amazon ratings game by paying for good reviews with a free roll of filament.

reviewText:
The color seems more like a blue/ black ink.
3D Solutions on the left and 3DMars on the right. Hatchbox also is a smoother black then the blue tint ink color of 3D solutions.
I also had numerous tangle issues where the filament wanted to jump off the spool which i had ran into on low cost filaments. So nothing special about 3D Solutions and i would Ultimately not recommend.
summary: The color seems more like a blue/ black ink. not something I would recommend.

reviewText:
This is a VERY black PLA filament.  Not slightly grey like a lot of them are, but really black.  I had to run it hotter than I do the grey, but I suspect that is due to the heavy amount of dye needed to make it so black.  If you are looking for a low price, but high quality PLA in black, look no further.
I have used many other colors by them and all of them have been great.  Highly recommended.
I dry brushed gray onto it which really makes it pop!  A GREAT base color!!
summary: Deep rich black PLA for a low price.

reviewText: So far it's a really nice filament, the color is nice and glossy and it printed really good with only minor strings and fuzzys but nothing that can't be cleaned off easy.
summary: Good price and quality

reviewText: I have been printing for a year now and 3D Solutech's filament line is one of the best filaments I've used, when dialed in there filament has minimal stringing and sticks to the print bed with zero lifting. I highly recommend this product! My settings for a E3D style hotend are 190C Extruder, 50C Bed with 4mm of retraction at 50mm/sec. All three colors in the picture are 3D Solutech.
summary: Great filament, no complaints!

reviewText: Great filament for the price! Some of the best and hands down the smoothest printing stuff that I have ever used.  Running it constantly on 2 cr10's at 210c. Buy this you won't be disappointed.
summary: Buy this!

reviewText: Another great roll of PLA by 3D Soulutech!!!!!
summary: Excellent company

reviewText:
This is an honest review, I did not receive anything for providing it.

I am a very active and heavy 3D printer, which is a  Prusa i3 MK2 with an E3D-V6 hotend, and I have tried most of the top well known PLA suppliers from MatterHackers, MakerGeeks, Hatchbox and more and I can say with complete confidence that once I tried 3D Solutech it has been my #1 go to PLA filament. They are in the top of all that I have tried in quality and among the lowest in price! I have used their white, grey and silver metal (does not contain real metal). Their silver is by far my favorite between all of the different brands, it actually is the closest matched to the type that Prusa uses and sells.

About the filament:
Packaging: every roll comes in it's own box and vacuum sealed and a pack of silica gel to make sure any moisture is removed. They also include a few branded stickers, which I actually really enjoy as there were two roughed up patches on the plexiglass I used to make my filament enclosure and the stickers have done a great job to "cover" them.

The filament:
I have used 7 rolls since this past August and there have had absolutely no jams, snags or any noticeable deviations if any at all in dimension, and every spool was neatly rolled with no crossovers. I've had great success printing at a nozzle temp between 210-212 degrees (depending on the ambient temperature and if I have my AC running in the room), with a bed temp of 60 degrees. Their filament bonds really well and creates very strong and durable pieces. I have noticed that at .1mm height I do need to adjust my settings a little bit and slow the print speed down and increase the hotend a few degrees, but that can be more an issue with the printer and not the filament itself.

I've included a few photos of my assortment of PLA rolls and their stickers, a handful of pieces all printed with their silver PLA and the final piece that was made with them. The final piece was just showcased at ComicCon and everyone asked if it was a resin cast because of how strong it felt. I hope this review has helped you make your decision and happy printing.
summary: My #1 PLA Filament - Prusa i3MK2 Printer

reviewText: Filament is very brittle & glossy. Printing at 210C, the filament doesn't blend together at all, comparing to the blue filament from 3D Solutech. It's good for thick 3D print job at 100% fill. Here's picture comparison to the skin tone PLA from another vendor.
summary: Filament is very brittle & glossy

reviewText:
Black seems a good choice for a noob like me. For somethings it is and others it is not. Decided to try so I ordered this. It had good reviews and rightfully so.

Add to cart
Amazon prime
2 days later here we are

Setup: I ran this at 200c to 195c and it came out great. Laid down nice and really didn't have issues. No jams or breaks with my direct drive and no Bowden rigs.

Quality: the prints came out clean, and if it didn't it was a setting I had made. No inconsistencies in the material that I can see and fit withing the specified tolerances.

Material: this is black but what I have noticed is whatever you print comes out glossy. I didn't expect that it would be so shiny. Someone said hotter temps make it glossy so I tried going down and the same. So.. in the end that's what it was, a glossy black. Not so neutral. See my pics. Batman - yes it looks good, Dino skull yes, magazine belt clip yes, Animated movie characters  no, kakashi - no.

This is not a print anything material in my opinion and more of a specific purpose for black, and glossy at that. Make sure to print an a higher resolution because you can see the layers so easily because of that shine.
summary: Can also be called shiny black 1.75mm PLA

reviewText: Great filament prints really nice will definitely buy more of 3dsolutech apple green prints nice also
summary: Five Stars

reviewText: Good so far! This is my first FDM type of 3D printer so still getting the settings etc on this machine, but it seems to be working just as well as the hatchbox filament I also got at the same time. 210 is my temp settings with a 60 heat bed and painters tape to stick onto the bed. No lifting or burning etc.
summary: Good so far

reviewText:
I have to revise my previous review, dropping it from 5 to 3 stars. It's still usually a good filament, but of all the filaments I own, it's definitely the worst. It doesn't stick to my print bed well, it warps and bends mid-print, and I've had more failed prints in this white than any other color I own. Stick to Hatchbox.

Photos: The skull printed great, but the robot dog completely failed, the unicorn chin screwed up (and I had a proper support structure), and I canceled two large prints after the first layer for significant warping.
summary: It's alright, but there are better options

reviewText:
Prints smoothly, no clogs or stringing (12 hour print@195F on ROBO R1+).
The color is bright white. Maybe it depends on the lot. It definitely wasn't a cream color like others have commented.
There is a slight amount of gloss.

UPDATE: I had to reduce my rating from 5 stars to 2. Quality went downhill after the initial successful print. I've tried a variety of settings and temps (195-210F) but the quality is poor. I've experienced several partial clogs and jams with this filament. I've switched back and forth between this filament and Hatchbox to confirm. The attached picture shows the quality difference between Hatchbox (left) and 3D Solutech (right).

reviewText:

reviewText: Very consistent filament, most of my filament has been 3D Solutech due to successful prints with very good results. Highly recommend
summary: Great results with good strength !

reviewText: Love this filament. Prints beautifully, great shine- not like a metal shine, maybe more glittery but not chunky or cheap glitter- that pretty dusty kind. I hope that makes sense. I have flashforge creator pro, printing at 210 degrees for this filament. My pic doesnt show the color very well- it was still running and the shadows/led from the machine messes with the pic. Its like a light graphite silvery color. I will most likely be purchasing again!

reviewText: Very nice print quality and silver color. Not quite metallic very much a silver plastic look. Great for the price!
summary: Not metallic, silvery plastic

reviewText: I highly recommend ordering 3D Solutech! They are by far the best priced and have been amazingly consistent in color from spool to spool, dimensional accuracy, and filament production + the resulting print quality. There is no detectable odor whatsoever (HatchBox, MakerGeeks and a few others have def odor). I print with a Prusa i3MK2 at 210 degrees and have the heatbed at 60 degrees. Also, the spools are perfectly vacuum sealed (I have received a few from other manufacturers where the seal had been broken) and I love that they include stickers in every spool order!3D Solutech Silver Metal 3D Printer PLA Filament 1.75MM Filament, Dimensional Accuracy +/- 0.03 mm, 2.2 LBS (1.0KG) - 100% USA So far Ive tested; - Hatchbox - AIO - MakerBot - MakerGeeks - MatterHackers - few others cant recall
summary: This is the PLA You Want to Use

reviewText: I had been using Hatchbox, this is a great alternativ at a great price.  The orange is a little creamy - not a Lamborghini orange but good enough for what I was doing. No issues with it feeding smoothly, and the print came out great - printed some skid plates for a friend's drone (see pic).
summary: Great alternative at a great price

reviewText:
I have used pretty much only Hatchbox filaments in my Flashforge Creator Pro 3D Printer, and this filament definitely surprised me. The first object I printed came out perfect, there were literally no imperfections! The exterior of my prints are shiny and very uniform. I did also upgrade my Extruder nozzle to an all metal nozzle which might have something to do with the improved print quality.

I think I have found a new supplier for my filament needs and as long as the other colors are the same quality I will definitely be purchasing more rolls in the near future.
summary: Get smooth and shiny 3D Prints with this material!

reviewText: This filament is consistent and prints so smooth! I usually print around 200* with my bed at 55* around speeds of 40mm/s and get great quality prints from my little Monoprice Mini V2. This filament has a bit of a sparkle to it, similar to the Real Gold PLA filament. It isn't necessarily shiny like metal can be.. but has a sheen to it. First layer goes down great for me! This filament is great quality, as I own several of their colors! I have had zero issues.
summary: No issues! Nice color and great quality

reviewText:
Prints well.
The only issue I have found with this is sometimes it's slightly out of spec and measures 1.69mm and results in a little bit of under-extrusion.
Beyond that, no tangles, it prints well and does an overall good job with the prints.
The silver is a good color. It's got a bit of a shine to it and looks nice.
Figured this is a good one to print the Fillenium Malcon with. (See Thingiverse)

So far, the biggest issue I've run into with 3D solutech is their products are becoming more and more out-of-stock. If you want to rely on having their filament in stock for making prints, it may not be available when you need to re-order. In fact, the silver is out of stock as I write this review.
Good stuff so far.
summary: Prints well, would buy again.

reviewText: Are usually only buy 3D Solutech but this has been the worst roll of filament Ive ever used. The quality is good the prints come out fine if you watch and untangle it every 20 minutes. Its kind a like the filament is super twisted and all it wants to do is Come off the roll or get tangled up.
summary: Tangled up

reviewText: I have been a fan of 3D Solutech's filament after switching from Hatchbox. Usually their other primary colors print out really well (except their red, its too light in my opinion). As quality is concern, I had trouble printing with thier Silver Metal color. Even though the packaged was sealed, the pla was still very brittle. It keep on breaking during my prints. I contacted the company but still awaiting a response.
summary: Usually great filament but not Silver Metal

reviewText:
pretty good pla. i like the color.

I have made several great prints from this stuff and the spools are better quality than other brands.
summary: Four Stars

reviewText: I had a good eperience with this filament, I printed a little hotter than normal maybe 212 to 215 on my Creality CR10s (bed on 60). The prints turned out great as far as the filament and the color are concerned. The easter eggs in the pic i attached are grabbed from Thingiverse turned out eggcellent and were very strong, printed with 4 and 6 layer walls and 50% infill. I was using one as a dog toy to play fetch and it was super durable. Highly recommend. The spiral bowl in the pick has a weird color because of the LEDs on my printer frame.
summary: Durable, no issues and the color was exactly what I wanted.

reviewText: Review of 3D Solutech Silver PLA. Good quality prints with nice silver metal look. It is a little brittle (like most silver PLA) so I was worried, but it prints really well. After a few test prints that came out great, I had the confidence to run at 26 hr print with this and it completed without any issues. Wound well. Packed well. The only negative is they do not print a recommendation for printing temp on the package so had to go to their website to find it. Turns out it the standard 190-210 range. So good, it is now my standard metal-look silver PLA. Just got another roll delivered from Amazon 5 mins ago.
summary: Excellent results and good price

reviewText: Prints nicely at lower temps (190) for me. Consistent width and flow with no issues of snagging due to tight winding.
summary: Prints nicely at lower temps (190) for me

reviewText: I have bought filament 4 times now and it is simply amazing.
summary: Awesome stuff.

reviewText: Nice PLA. First time I ever changed out for new color, was a little tricky but got it figured out. Color is more like a medium to dark grey after it prints (looks more silverish on the spool) it looks way more like titanium or tungsten than silver. At the right angle and light, it could pass for metal. Packaged very well and looks like high quality PLA. Happy, just wished it looked a little more like silver.
summary: More like grey then silver but still nice PLA

reviewText: Very consistent & a pleasure to work with.
summary: Another great spool

reviewText: I really like this filament.  The color is awesome, its almost a direct match of Atomic royal blue PLA, and the filament prints great.  Its bonding strength is good, it is consistent in diameter with no problems to speak of.  Here is a benchy done on my rostock max v2 @ .2mm layers, 195C nozzle, 55C bed, 4.8mm retraction with 100% fan after the 2nd layer.
summary: Good Stuff

reviewText:
When I got into 3d printing, I asked a friend who has already 2+ years in 3d printing, what is the best filament to use. He recommended Hatchbox brand. I bought some of Hatchbox and he is right it is a good brand. However, I was having a hard time getting all the colors I wanted from them, so I read some review about this brand. I liked some of the reviews and decided to give it a try. My first print was on Hatchbox settings and I did have some messed up prints. I tweaked the extruder heat and the bed heat and got now the perfect setting. I have a Qidi Tech (Flashforge china duplicate) and love it. Set the extruder to 197c and the bed to 62-64.

My prints came out awesome. The feel is soft and the colors are bright, but not over shiny. Love all the colors. Just ordered more.

This review is repeated for all colors I bought
summary: what is the best filament to use

reviewText:
This is my 4th spool of Solutech PLA filament. It prints at a bit higher temperature than my previous product but that is in NO WAY an issue.
The color is exactly what I wanted. More gray than what I would call silver (I am a silversmith). The "silver metal" is misleading to some people. I would use the term dull silver with a little sparkle...  and leave the word "metal" out. Printing was near perfect. Here is a sample.
summary: Good printing, not exactly silver metal...

reviewText: I have not printed with this color yet, but have tried the black and clears with great results
summary: but have tried the black and clears with great

reviewText:
The product was vacuumed sealed.
The spool was very sturdy and included a filament clip (nice touch).
The filament itself printed very nicely @195 with no blobs or stringing.
I didn't measure the filament so I can't comment on the dimensional accuracy, however I used the entire spool with no issues.
The color itself was more grey than metallic. If you look closely at the filament you can see metallic flakes, however this effect was mostly lost in the final product.
summary: High quality product.

reviewText: I love its metallic look. It has a great shine to it without appearing glossy. Prints very nicely at 212 degrees and does not need a heated bed when printing on BuildTak or a Zebra Plate.

The filament is consistent and spooled well. Not a single snag or jam in 6 different spools (2 of this color and 4 of others.  Orginally brought this brand when my regular hatchbox was always out of stock,  but i think I may have just found a new regular brand.

I did not firmly click the floor together to make it easier to remove them.  Have to have my D&D players move about inside it!  :)

reviewText: I like this color but be warned that it's more of a dark magenta than a purple. No problem printing with the filament.

reviewText: I've been using several different colors of HATCHBOX ABS filament with my XYZprinting Da Vinci 1.0 and this purple filament works quite well. The default heat settings of the Da Vinci (90'C bed, 210'C extruder) have no problems with it. The only thing as some others mentioned is the color isn't like purple, more magenta-like, although I don't mind the slight difference.
summary: Great filament at a reasonable price.

reviewText:
I truly believe that this filament is cursed.  I have used a ton of Hatchbox PLA without any problems.  But, this spool of PLA has been trouble from the get-go.  First off, and the reason for only 3 stars, is that it's not purple: it's pink.  There's no way around this.  Some might argue that it's a very light purple, but it's pink.  As far as the cursed part goes, I have had numerous issues with this spool of filament that I have not had with any other Hatchbox PLA.  It seemed to need different temp settings for proper extruding.  When it's finally extruding correctly, I've had it bind up on the spool multiple times during long prints.  This is the deal where the windings get on top of each other and then it doesn't feed correctly.  I never had a successful print from this spool.  So, therefore, this PLA is cursed!  Avoid it like the plague!  Avoid cliches, too!

Update: I'm increasing my review by a star for Fire Sale Merchant's excellent customer service.  As you can see from the comment on this review, Fire Sale Merchant asked me to contact them about the PLA.  They offered to replace the spool free of charge.  But, I didn't actually buy this filament from Amazon:  a friend purchased this filament for me in exchange for some items that I printed for him.  Otherwise, I would have exchanged the spool immediately.  Nevertheless, Fire Sale Merchant said that they would still replace the filament.  Fire Sale Merchant cares about their product reviews and will apparently do about anything to make things right for their customers.  Kudos to them.

I'll re-appraise this product again upon trying the replacement filament.  But, it's still not purple!  :-)

(I included a photo of one of the failed prints to show what the color actually is.)

Update2: The replacement spool that Firesale Merchant sent me works fine.  I did several prints with it with no problems.  So, the first spool really was cursed.  That being said, this still isn't purple!
summary: Cursed Spool

reviewText: Hatchbox filament is the filament of choice around our house.  It just seems to work best with our Duplicator and you cannoy beat the bargain.  I only give the Purple PLA a 4 star review because it just isn't really purple.  This is a very pinky,  lilacy purple at best.  If you are looking for a true purple (think LSU Tiger purple or Vikings purple)  this is not the purple for you.  I really hope Hatchbox can make a true purple soon.  Other than the shade of the filament being off on this one,  the filament itself is great.
summary: My "go-to"  filament

reviewText: Awesome PLA, prints great, easy setup, minimal errors and the finish is awesome.  Will order more as soon as we get close to running out, good amount of PLA for the money.

have used this before and its excellent. My only issue with it on amazon is that I pay a subscription to amazon Prime and they cant get this product to me in the 2 shipping days. (need my filament). SHouldnt be posted as prime.

Will always purchase hatchbox. Not stringly does not pop or bubble like the cheap brand filaments. Take the head ache out of crappy prints and bed adhesion and just go with hatchbox.

reviewText: Easily the best and most versatile filament I've ever used.  The filament looks grey in neutral light, but catches light SO well and looks so faceted and metallic in bright or direct light.  It shows small detail unlike anything else I've printed with, and is completely opaque and smooth.  I like to print 3d landscapes from satellite data, and this shows the high complexity of the terrain in so many different lights.  It's incredible, and very forgiving, easy to use, and problem free.  This is my absolute go to filament for anything where I want to show detail and catch light.

1st Purchase - Was fairly brittle. End of roll was almost useless as it kept breaking before it would even get off the roll.

reviewText:
Hatchbox is my go-to filament.  Ive printed through several rolls of their PLA filament on both my Printrbot Simple Metal at home and my Flashforge Creator Pros at work  a middle school classroom.  It prints well on both machines.  I find 205 degrees Celsius to be the optimal temperature for most prints.  Not all prints are perfect but I often find that the issue is more in the model than the filament.  In other words, if my print has flaws when printed with Hatchbox, I can reprint using a different brand and the new print will have the same flaw.  When this happens,  making adjustments to the print settings (layer height, print speed, temperature) often helps.

I've included a photo of a 3D prosthetic hand that my students and I printed as part of the hand challenge.  We chose Hatchbox Gold and Blue because we thought they looked a little bit "superheroish"! :)

I recommend storing all PLA filament in zip loc bags or other airtight containers, with the silica gel packs tucked inside.  Ive had some rolls for close to a year and they still print flawlessly.

I try to write helpful, concise reviews for all of my Amazon purchases.  If you found this to be helpful, please let me know by clicking yes below.  Thank you!
summary: Prints flawlessly on both Printrbot Simple and Flashforge Creator Pro!

reviewText:
I've only printed on model so far (an altar from Dragonlock set) but compared to the same model, with the same settings (205C extruder, 80C heated bed, 2 skirts, no raft, Flashforge Creative Pro) there was less warping compared to the grey PLA I printed the model with a few hours before. Stuck to the glass bed perfectly (maybe a little too well) just using washable glue stick to improve adhesion in both cases.

The color is a nice golden yellow, though less shiny that I'd want to really represent "gold". I'd have no problem buying it again if I run out.
summary: Good, consistant golden PLA

reviewText:
This gold PLA from Hatchbox is my go to filament. The diameter is consistent and it prints like a dream. The spool is properly wound so no tangles. It's just great stuff.

I have a Monoprice Maker Select (Wanhao i3) with an upgraded, all metal hot end. I print this at 215 with a heated bed set at 60 degrees. Because of the hot end upgrade, I must print at about 10 degrees higher so if you have a stock Maker Select, 200-205 is a good temp to start with.

I'm using borosilicate glass with Aquanet hairspray on my heated bed and have had no issues at all with adhesion. Sticks perfectly every time.

The color is a light gold with a metallic sheen depending upon the light. I've included a pic of a gear cube I printed with this filament. Every piece is printed with the same filament at the same time but as you can see, some of the pieces look like a completely different color because of the way the light hits them. It's unusual and beautiful.

I really like Hatchbox because it's consistently great filament at a good price.
summary: My go-to filament

summary: Five Stars

reviewText:
Having tried 4 other brands of filament this week. I am happy to say Hatchbox was the best of the bunch.
I was amazed at how much variance(measured with a caliper) I was getting on other brands. I was getting measurements from 1.7 to 1.79 in less than a foot. That is is crazy!

The Hatchbox seems to stay much closer to the 1.75mm core size than others. Even though the tolerance on all filament is +/- .05mm, you shouldn't get wide swings in thickness over short lengths of filament. This makes it harder to dial in your settings and get consistent prints. The Hatchbox doesn't swing as far from 1.75 as much or as fast. Very clean and consistent.

Hatchbox will definitely be my first choice for filament on Amazon from now on.
summary: Very Clean and Consistent!

reviewText: It looks fantastic as a print, it works really well with filament swapping as a secondary color, I used it as the side of the cradle for my Pebble, and as a material to make a fun novelty wineglass for a friend.

reviewText: From the name, Real Gold, I expected something brighter, more resilient yellow like yellow gold, but it's not quite that. reviewText:
Beware! Tip broke off!

In all my years using these kinds of plugs Ive never had one destroy another piece of equipment.
After 2-3 uses, the tip of this broke off inside a jack.  I was stunned.  It is impossible to remove the tip, now I must attempt a repair on that gear and replace the jack.

reviewText: These are not premium quality by far but they get the job done. The screw-on connection cover is all plastic and only contacts a few threads on the barrel. It stays on during normal gentle use but can easily be pulled off if the wire is yanked to the side (when you forget you are connected to something and walk away with the headphones still on your head). The strain relief webbing on the back is made for thicker wire, not your average small headset micro wire. The connections inside provide a clamp to grip the insulation but you will have to find your own solution to fill in the extra space around the wire. I used several layers of shrink tubing to make the wire thicker. Nothing melted inside when I soldered the wires. If I were repairing high quality headphones, I would go with something better.
summary: Okay for a quick fix

reviewText: I have three of these sensors, right now they are hooked to the breadboard,  yes they are slow reacting to temperature change,  but for a home hobbyist such as me,  they are just fine.  Normal temperature don't change that quick anyway. Now,  for a lab or industrial environment is another story. I compare them to the Sparkfun  HIH6130 which cost 4 times one of this sensor, and these guys  reports basically the same reading. They are slow compare to the Sparkfun  HIH6130 like I said, but not really that slow.
summary: Excellent  temp/humidity sensors!

reviewText:

Works quickly for removing weld spots and beveling, and about anything else of the sort that you'd want to use it for.

The disc is of high end construction and design, and fits Bosch and Dewalt 4 1'2" cordless grinders = as is = without an adapter.

Long lasting =  recommended.

reviewText: I've been using the Norton flap discs prior to this (here's a photo of them next to each other, the Norton is the used-looking one).  Although they look similar in design and construction, this 3M grinds a bit faster with less pressure.  The grit has sharper cutting edges than the typical sandpaper.  These 3M Cubitron discs are assembled in the US from "globally sourced materials" and the Norton brand is Made in Mexico.

reviewText: Used to clean up an old anvil and did a fine job.  Even took out some of the pitting.
summary: Used to clean up an old anvil and did a fine job.  Even took out some of the pitting.

reviewText:
INTRO:
This is a good printer for beginners just getting into the 3D modeling/crafting world. Im 4th yr Industrial Design student at UL Lafayette and this was my first 3D Printer. I had experience in 3D modeling but our school didn't have a working 3D printer so none of us could print anything, so I decided to buy my own and I'm so glad I did. Its made completing projects MUCH easier and convenient.

FIRST IMPRESSIONS:
Pulling the printer out of the box, it felt sturdy and well built, it was simple to hook up and install the software. The plastic shell was surprisingly thick making the printer feel nice and solid. When you turn on the printer you will hear the sound of the small fans powering on and see the blue LEDs illuminate the inside of the printer (I believe the newest model comes with white LED which is better).

THOUGHTS:
While this printer does technically come plug and play, there is a learning curve, both digital and mechanical, in order to really get quality prints. When I started my first print I was super excited at how easy it was to start, then was disappointed because the print looked terrible. Luckily ROBO3D.com has a good user forum that is very supportive and they walked me through troubleshooting and the problem ended up being some loose screws that only needed to be tightened. This printer is definitely not perfect, and requires some care, but I haven't had to do anything major to it, so thats understandable in the ever growing 3D printing market. As I said earlier my printer came with blue LED lights inside which look cool, but it doesn't really make for great lighting so I've recently added bright white LED's inside and that made a huge difference and I believe newer models come stock with white LED's. Overall its a good printer for someone who doesn't want to spend $2,000+ but I wouldn't recommend it for anyone with more experience. I would like to upgrade in a few years once the 3D printing market has perfected their models a little more.

ROBO 3D CUSTOMER SERVICE
The warranty part replacement program has been great to me. Sadly I've had to call upon them to replace a few parts, but I got response within 24 hours and it was completely hassle free, they just shipped the part I needed without issue.
summary: Good printer for beginners

reviewText:
So far printed 62 large items with this without a problem.  After about 30 or 40 prints I changed to another sheet while re-calibrating the printer (it had drifted after 217 hours of printing non-stop).  The old piece looked well used but I think it's still good.  I'll keep it as a spare.

At the moment I'm only printing PLA on a heated bed.  I haven't tried ABS yet, but I don't have any problems getting ABS to stick to glass so I don't really care if this works with it.

The photo is the used piece.
summary: Works great

reviewText: Good affordable ABS. I mostly use PETG these days, but when I need to print something in ABS this works great.
summary: Good affordable ABS

reviewText:
Really don't know whether to like or dislike this cleaning filament!

1. When I first used it and extruded it as instructed, I didn't see any dirt or old filament strings or whatever coming out of the nozzle as I thought it would like really cleaning stuff. I extruded 300mm of the cleaning filament at various temps (from 210 to 190) followed by a standard PLA filament, the latter being a disaster as explained below.

2. For couple of days later, all of my prints were failing, because the cleaning filament stuff was mixed with my standard filament. Like a PLA filament that used to extrude like butter at 195 degree, now only extrudes at 215! Still couldn't print however, as once I start printing, filament jams.

3. The black stuff, dirt I guess, started to come out of the nozzle after 3 days of trying to extrude my standard filament at very high temp, flushing basically the cleaning filament. (attached photo)

4. After all that hassle, didn't notice any change in extruded filament, except that it was working against the law of gravity, i.e, extruded filament started to go up towards the heatblock not down!

Well, I ended up changing my nozzles, that is 3 nozzles as I have 3 extruders all messed up, and yes all of them challenged the law of gravity.

Perhaps seeing that black stuff eventually coming out of the nozzle was worth giving it 3 stars despite what it caused to my printer, my nozzles, and me emotionally :)

Would I buy it again? NEVER
Would I recommend it to a friend? NEVER

Concept is great, just keep on improving it eSun... love your other filaments though.
summary: Mix feelings!

reviewText:
I purchased this last November, but it got put into a drawer until today.  I have one of those XYZ Junior printers which can only use the XYZ Junior filament, and some of the XYZ filament is pretty crappy in my opinion. The printer was jammed up with XYZ PLA. Normal cleaning was not getting the nozzle unclogged. I pulled this stuff out of the drawer and ran some through the hotend with the hotend removed and heated up. Basically running some though, then pulling it back out. It has a rough surface, as I've tried to show in the photo. Pull it out of the hotend as it starts to cool pulls the other crap out of the nozzle and barrel. It will also extrude out the nozzle if you push it through while the nozzle is hot.

I was surprised at how well it cleaned the hotend.
summary: Cleans the hotend nicely.

reviewText: My first thought was "Wow that is a lot of webbing". It is a giant roll of webbing, but I have already begun to use it. I plan to make personalized key chain fobs with names embroidered on material and the material sewn to the webbing. I also plan to use the webbing for purse straps on several purses I am making. This webbing is very strong and well made. It also holds up and does not stretch when making purse straps. It is a quality material and I highly recommend it for crafting.
summary: Great webbing for crafts.

reviewText: Very well made and great quality! Comes in case with instructions and is made in Israel.
summary: Great item

reviewText:
Printer pays for it self. I've been printing the day I bought it. I've printed quad racers, you name it I've printed it. Mind you I've had this for about a year now and have had nothing but a blast I fully molded this printer the way I wanted it leds you name it.

I even built one manufactured buy this very printer and sold it. Honest that was just for fun didn't even think I'd sell it.

Check out my photos speaks for itself

I've gotten a induction sensor working on there for 15bucks

New nozzel tips .4 for fine prints (detailed)
Upgraded power supply for faster bed heating
The rest I 3d printed from this machine

I've also had the privilege of getting a full graphics display working with the printer board I've did some sprucing with marlin.
summary: Amazing learning experince

reviewText:
As long as your printer kit includes all of the necessary parts and it all works when you start it up, this seems to be a decent kit. The frame and acrylic parts are nice and all fit together well.

However, I've had several issues with mine and the customer service has been slow to help me resolve my issues. One of my parts was warped when I received it and I have gone back and forth with them for the last 5 days and it has been difficult to convince them that I have a bad/warped part. I spent the time to make two youtube videos showing the what the issue was: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LNtHlmY-9l0 and https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eHESM9cUK24.
I sent them the links, but they say they can't access youtube from China. No problem, I'll send them via Gmail... they can't access that either. So, I sent a bunch of pictures and waited and waited so they could show them to their technician. They finally said they would send me another part to replace my warped one.

I also had the heating element for the print head/extruder just die on me for no reason. I've had some intermittent issues with the LCD screen.

This might be a good printer IF I can ever get the parts I need for it to actually function correctly. If customer support can ever get me the right parts to get the printer working, I'll update this review to reflect that.

EDIT: 2/22/15 10:49 EST - Customer service replied back and it looks like they will be shipping me the parts that I need to get this thing going. I will update the review once the parts get to me.

EDIT: 3/4/15 11:59 EST - I received my replacement parts yesterday. Everything is now working except the LCD screen. I can print parts via USB with my laptop, but the LCD is still unusable. The parts printed have been decent quality so far. I e-mailed HIC about the LCD issue that is still occurring and have not heard back from them yet.

EDIT: 3/18/15 EST -  Overall, this is a decent printer for the money. There have been numerous reports of people experiencing the same issues with warped parts as I experienced. Other that this, my only other complaint is the acrylic y-axis carriage. Being made of acrylic, over time it will warp downward due to heat from the heat bed. I am currently waiting an an aluminum y-carriage that I purchased from ebay to replace this part and then I think I will be fairly happy with this printer. (Link to aluminum y-carriage upgrade: http://www.ebay.com/itm/291388405026?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT)

UPDATE 8/14/2015: Although I have had several issues with this printer, support has been quite helpful in trying to fix my issues and sending me new parts. You just have to be patient with them and try the things they ask you to try, and then insist that they send new parts.
summary: Seems like a decent kit overall. But mine has had a few problems and customer support has been a bit slow

reviewText: Prints Great! I am liking 3D SoluTech more and more. Good colors.
summary: Prints great, good color!

reviewText:
This filament is potentially out of spect by a whopping .2mm;  you are going to get jams here
Pictured is a 1.75mm measured at 1.95mm!  For sure a filament this out of spec is going to jam.

This same roll of filament jammed two different printers!
summary: This filament is potentially out of spect by a whopping ...

reviewText: I have been printing for a year now and 3D Solutech's filament line is one of the best filaments I've used, when dialed in there filament has minimal stringing and sticks to the print bed with zero lifting. I highly recommend this product! My settings for a E3D style hotend are 190C Extruder, 50C Bed with 4mm of retraction at 50mm/sec. All three colors in the picture are 3D Solutech.
summary: Wide Range of Great PLA filaments!

reviewText: High quality PLA for a low price.  Never had a badly wound reel.  The green is an mature grass green (not an unnatural neon green), exactly what I needed for printing grassland tiles.  I would buy again, highly recommended.
summary: High quality green pla for the price of crappy stuff!

reviewText:
I just recently decided to get into 3D printing and I'm glad that I went with the Dremel brand, and this particular printer model (3D20). In my opinion, this model is great for beginners, tinkerers, hobbying, and great for general small parts/accessories around the house. Sure, there are some areas for improvement as far as quality (print quality, precision, etc), but overall it's a great 3D printer to start out with.

I have had ideas of things I wanted to build and with this, now I can actually make them! Aside from making misc. items, I often find items on Thingiverse to make my wife. She enjoys waking up in the morning and waiting to see what I left her from the 3D printer. If you had kids, I'm sure this would be a blast for them as well.

One downfall is that Dremel doesn't seem to want you using other brands filaments. However, there are plenty of spool holders on Thingiverse, and I actually made my own spool stand replacement to accomodate other larger spools. Search Thingiverse for Dremel 3D20 Spool Stand/Holder, as I will be uploading it now.
summary: Awesome, fun, easy to use 3D Printer! Reliable brand!

reviewText:
If you are not an avid 3d printer person, this is the unit to get, why? Dremel has the support infrastructure to assist you.

I purchased the Dremel after much trouble from a leading manufacturer's product and I am very happy with it. I rarely rate a 5 so there you go!

You will see others complain about the model not sticking to the mat, that's because they never learned to level the build platform correctly. You just have to play with it. Too close and the model will mushroom out as the plastic flows outward under compression. Not close enough and the model doesn't stick. Also, ditch the little plastic scrapper thing for getting the model off the platform. Look at my photos for the Teflon scrapper I use. Use it upside down and the model comes right off, no fuss.

I would also highly recommend downloading all of the Autodesk tools. They all serve a purpose and they all work really well.

The Venus De Milo rendering still has rough marks from the supports. Angles 45 degrees or greater require supports so that is why there are rough patches on her face and nose. There is a line mid-way on her face caused by the PLS fiber getting tangled on the spool which is a common occurance on all 3d printers. That is why you should never leave the unit unattended.

Anyways, much more fun than my Siegel X3 CEC conversion! No, it doesn't do metal, yet but I think Dremel is on the right track. They should make their own unit though. The re-branded thing is ok to start with but this is where it's all headed so they should start making it a priority!

Notice Milwaukee and Ryobi haven't got a unit out yet? Dremel is a head of the curve!

**UPDATE: After printing for 500+ hours now with this unit I have to say this; The printer is generally good but the included software is crap (and I'm being generous). Believe it or not but the quality of the prints is nearly 100% in the software. I would HIGHLY suggest you spend the extra $150.00 at[...] and truly open the Dremel 3D Printer up! I was putting 0.25mm or greater tolerances in all of my parts because the dimensional shifts that would happen before using Simplify3D. After I got Simplify3D all of my parts turn out as they are in the CAD program (in my case Rhino3D). Another thing is after a while when you get comfortable you can open up the advanced settings and start tweaking things you simply have no access to in the Dremel branded software. Simplify3D has a section on their Web site where you can see images of print problems with a list of suggestions for changes in the parameters to solve them. Customer service was great and the community seems very active and willing to help. When I imagined what a 3D printer was and then saw the original output from the Dremel branded software I was disappointed but happy I was "close." Now I'm spot on and it is like having a new printer! [...]
summary: Easy to use, great Dremel support, Needs Better Software! (see update)

reviewText: Good for wrapping brisket halfway through the cook.  Works as expected.  Attached is a picture of the width of the product as it arrived, it's in a 3" cardboard tube for storage, the roll of paper is just less than 3" wide.
summary: Good for wrapping brisket halfway through the cook

reviewText:
Used for the first time today.

It's heavier than I expected considering it's name contains the term "Ultra-Light". I guess it's no heavier than a regular vacuum but it's heavy at the top instead of the bottom. It will take some getting used to.

It won't stand up on it's own so if you need to stop, you either need to disconnect the top from the bottom or lean it up against something. That might not sound like a big deal, but to me, it is.

I really like the way the head swivels, they way it goes right up against baseboards, and the way it easily gets under desks, tables and chairs, etc. My old vacuum was old school so this was new to me. That I really liked.

No bags, I like that.

I vacuumed the kitchen floor and its throw rugs with ease. I liked that.

I attached pics. I vacuumed with my old vacuum 7 days ago, this is what the Shark picked up today (living room, one bedroom, hallway, family room and kitchen rugs). I have two cats. Pencil is just for scale. I was impressed.

Not giving it 5 stars yet because the clunkiness of it bothers me (the fact it's heavy, the fact it won't stand up on it's own). I think I'll get used to it but for now, 4 stars.
summary: Used for the first time today

reviewText:
These seem to be made of solid nylon webbing. They have a 300 pound capacity.  The protective cover over the metal is nice to prevent it from damaging whatever you're hauling. They're really good length to be useful while not being too long. Metal latch feels heavy duty. My only complaint is that there isn't anything to tie down the slack once you pull them taught. You'll have to tie it on itself or rubber band it.

It also didn't come with instructions but only took me a couple minutes to figure out how to properly thread the strap through the metal piece. I've included a picture for reference.

Since you get 2 straps for $13.50, these are great value for the price
summary: Great value, good straps

reviewText: These work, have adhesive that seals watertight. Heat shrink tubes are underrated. Buy best, spend extra, only thing keeping solder joints wiring from corroding in a year & losing trailer brakes, lights... Get picked up at worst time because of tail light... Nothing as fun as tracking an elect. short half across the country on shoulder...
summary: Spend the money, have watertight/adhesive joints.

reviewText: This is great stuff! I had been struggling with a method to secure wires coming into a small box through a tube. I just learned about this product and it works perfectly. I run the wire through the tube into the box, slip a short piece of this over it, hit it with the heat gun and it is firmly melted together and tightly sealed. It is very strong and secure after cooling. The 3:1 shrink ratio is a nice bonus as well. It will work sealing items that vary in size and you are can cover a greater range of sealing needs with a smaller number of tubing sizes.
summary: Excellent heat shrink tubing

reviewText:
This LED endoscope is attached to a sixteen foot cable and has a USB plug on the end. The length of the cable creates the capability to access many hidden or hard to reach locations so the back and interior of a variety of things may be easily viewed. It also comes with a small group of accessories to help view and retrieve lost items and obstructions.

With an ingress rating of IP67, the camera is completely protected against dust intrusion and is immersion protected for short periods of time in water. The information I found elsewhere which explained the definition of this rating defined pressure and time limitations of up to 1 meter (just over three feet) of submersion with a test duration of 30 minutes measured at the bottom of the cable, and at least 15 cm (about six inches) measured at the top of the device. I did not have a clogged pipe to thread this camera through but I won't hesitate to do it next time it happens.

After reading the included User Manual I copied the enclosed 3 inch CD to my laptop hard drive. The disc contains three applications and when I double clicked on the first one it said no capture device available so I plugged the endoscope into my USB port and the message went away but the screen was blank except for some menus. So, I closed that window and double clicked on the second application and it was also a blank screen with some menus, so I closed that one too.

When I double clicked on the third application the screen opened and the picture from the endoscope was in view. From there I tested the camera in a variety of locations and followed the instructions to capture snapshots which I have attached to this review. The software can also be used to create videos.

In addition, there was a .rar file on the included disc that when uncompressed contains a program called ViewPlayCap which can be installed on a PC by running the setup file. It is much easier to use than the other three applications on the disc. If interested in loading this program the user will need software to uncompress a .rar file such as 7Zip.

The LED lens is bright and has a wheel adjustment control on the USB plug so the light may be set for best advantage in different conditions. I removed a floor vent cover and saw bug remains in the ductwork. Then I checked behind the dryer for dust, and found some (and cleaned it, of course) but it did not make a very compelling photo so I took a picture of the label on the back of the dryer to show the clarity of the image. And finally, I took a picture behind some audio video equipment. This area is always difficult to get at and the endoscope provided a way to check empty ports and confirm tight connections.

The cost is modest considering many 16 foot cables alone are priced in this range. This endoscope has many uses and the only limitations I noticed were minor. When used in a large space the cable was difficult to precisely direct so time was required to maneuver it into position. But, it is perfect to thread into tight spots, like a car engine, and with patience, it works just fine in larger openings. Review sample received.
summary: Six LED Endoscope Borescope on a 16 Foot Cable with USB Connection 5M Camera

reviewText:
