reviewText: These are heavy duty.  I attached with screws and washers.  These do block sound, but only a few decibels.  Easily cut with scissors. I was disappointed that my roll was bowed, which caused each strip to hang in a curved manner.  Otherwise they seem high quality and durable.
summary: Heavy duty and durable

reviewText:
I purchased my SEEK Thermal camera through Amazon on November 19, 2015 and it still works fine.

I also purchased the FLIR ONE from Amazon September 22, 2016.
The FLIR ONE has a better interface/app and arguably better hardware.  However it is not a reliable tool.
The FLIR ONE worked great for fall 2016 and winter 2017 and will no longer function, even with external power.
This makes the FLIR ONE the most expensive disposable camera ever.

Save your money and purchase the SEEK.

I have attached a photo shot with the SEEK checking the insulation I put up on our apartment terrace last night.

Given my experience with both IR cameras, I can easily endorse the SEEK to the Amazon community.
summary: Works great years later - unlike FLIR ONE

reviewText: The imager itself isn't bad. It's sensitive enough to read a handprint off a hand placed on bathroom tile for just a few seconds. However, the app on the iPhone is absolutely horrible. First, on iOS 11 it constantly gives you an error that you don't have enough space on your phone even though my phone has several gigs free. Fortunately, the image is actually stored in Photos properly so it's a super annoying bug but not a killer one. The main reason I'm disappointed with this is that the imager doesn't read values below 20C.  See the photo of the insides of my freezer attached. It should be reading -5C (23F) but it says instead, 20C (68F).
summary: Imager not bad but app on the iPhone is incredibly poor, temperatures not read properly.

reviewText: So much fun to look at things in the IR spectrum during the day or at night there is a whole different world out there or indoors.  Everything ran up right away the only niggling thing is that the micro USB connector seems to be intermittent and I cannot tell whether it is the phone of the camera jack.  Apart from that I have bee able to look through walls seeing the wood frames inside, see animals outside in total darkness, and find mysterious places in the garden that for some reason stay warm until late at night!  On the technical side the images are low resolution but for the money this can be a great toy or equally useful.  The high temps spot readings are quite accurate but the low end scaling is way off. That is a small thing because it is usually the spot temperatures you are interesting in.  The camera is educational for my young children as they understand it is seeing heat and not visible light.  Attached pics: a kettle, south facing insulated wall, a guinea-pigs head
summary: Lots of fun at a good price.

reviewText: Excellent camera, exactly what i was looking for. If your device only has a USB type C, like my HTC 10, you need an adapter, I used AUKEY USB-C Adapter Type-C to Micro USB Adapter Aluminum (2 Pack) for MacBook Pro, Nexus 6P 5X, Google Pixel, LG G5 and More . Range on the normal version is pretty good, I could easily see someone about 600 feet away.
summary: Excellent product

reviewText: The new app shows the temperatures really nicely, with a vertical scale at the left of the picture. But they're meaningless. See attached pictures showing a near view of a washing machine drum, and a medium distance view of the same machine. Temperatures are wildly different. This device is fun to play with, and may be reliable for showing variations in temperature, but you can't take the temperatures seriously, at all.
summary: Measured temps vary greatly by distance

reviewText:
UPDATE 9/23/16:
Enter the USB-C port on my Note 7. I could not get a single USB-C Male to Micro USB Female adapter to work with this... Even the one from Samsung. What has worked for me, were a generic set of USB-C Male to USB-B 3.0 Female + a USB-B Male to Micro USB Female. It makes the system look a little goofy, but who really cares, I'm using a thermal camera on my phone! I've attached pictures.

Original:
I couldn't help but buy one of these! Thermal vision for $215? Yes please! Here's the good and bad as I see it:
Good:
*High resolution sensor compared to similar thermal cameras (206 x 156)
*Capable of great range of temperature measurement (-40F to 626F)
*Sensitive enough to see the wooden studs in my walls on a warmer day (68F inside, 83F outside)
*The unit is compact and doesn't require separate charging

Bad:
*THE SOFTWARE IS VERY BASIC, it will get you by, but don't expect too much
*Can't measure temperatures after a picture has been taken (I can interpolate by pixel value, but that would be an easy software addition)
*In the previous version of the app, you could have the phone camera and seek camera images side by side, this is no longer possible. I'm wondering if it's a patent issue with Flir. If they tried, I'm sure they could find some legal way to overlay or at least compare a normal and thermal image...
*Scenes where the temperature is fairly uniform are very grainy (put something even 10 warmer in the scene and the image clears up significantly)
*Won't plug into a phone with a heavy case on. My Note 4 with Unicorn Beetle case needed an extension, and my Note 7 already needs an adapter, but still. I don't know why the frame wasn't made just a little longer. Most people put cases on their phones.

Middle Ground:
*There's a focus ring on the standard Seek now. I'm not sure if this is great or terrible. It's nice to be able to focus, but focusing with such a low resolution image is a guessing game... I'm not sure if an infinite focus would be better or not.
*The camera calibration clicking isn't a problem for me, though it does seem to have trouble when the camera is pointed straight up (it's much better than a manual calibration!). This click is audible on videos shot with the camera, but if you're shooting a Hollywood movie, you probably want other audio sources anyways...

In conclusion, I would certainly buy this again! For what it is, it's amazing, but it has potential to be more. I do hope the app continues to be improved. I've seen that the SDK will be released soon, that's another opportunity for improved function!
summary: Excellent camera, less than amazing app.

reviewText:
This is a really cool gadget. It is very, very small - much smaller than what is pictured. It's about the size of a book of matches. Just download the app, connect this into your phone, and you're good to go.

This detects subtleties in heat changes, which is fantastic for electricians. I used this to get pictures of commercial electrical equipment to show the owner where he had some issues. It's better than using a heat gun, as you can take pictures and actually prove what you find.

Hunters would find this useful out in the brush looking for critters. I suppose spies would like this while hidng in the brush.

The usb connection is backwards which is a little annoying. But besides that, I love this thing!
summary: Perfect for electricians, hunters, and spies

reviewText:
This is one of my FAV Vine products.

This camera is small, but packs a punch. It's also easy to use.

First, download the Seek Thermal app. Open the app and plug in the camera. That's all it takes.

I've used this during the day and night and was able to see everything. The picture was crisp and more defined than I expected. I was really impressed.

You can choose the color scheme you need for the photos and video. I just use the default, but play around and see what you like.

Temperature settings are Farenheit, Celsius and Kelvin. You ca change the picture aspect ratio, remove the Seek Thermal watermark and add date and time stamps- which is essential for law enforcement.

The video on my iPhone 6 Plus had no sound and I couldn't find a setting for it to work. It works on video without the camera. This wasn't a big deal to me, but might be to others.

This is a must-have for cops or hunters or digital enthusiasts.
summary: Quality, crisp picture.

reviewText:
This is an incredible value compared to an industrial FLIR unit. I could see entire issuing these as standard a standard equipment for maintenance or engineering groups at industrial facilities--even if the only use is to flag trouble areas for someone to come back out and inspect with the $10k thermal camera.
I am using this with a Samsung Galaxy S5 and because of the waterproof flap on the USB port, I sometimes have connectivity issues. It would be nice if the plug was slightly longer to accommodate more phone cases.  One major thing missing from the software is the ability to  extract data from the image after the fact (as of date of this review).  The software that comes with professional thermal cameras allows you to check temperatures throughout an image after the fact. As far as I can tell, you can only get the temperature at one or two points at the time the image is taken.
summary: Incredible value!

reviewText:
You can check your phone for compatibility at their website, they maintain a list there that is easy to use. But also your Android version must be 4.3 or higher. (Note that AT&T has stated they will only add up to 4.2 to their HTC One X ROM.) The application to use the camera can be found at the Google Play store, just search for SEEK THERMAL and it is easy to find. It will let you know if your Android version is compatible or not as well if you want to check it before purchase.

The case is very hard to open and WILL break long nails. I need a flathead screwdriver to open it. It's very protective, it just shuts too tight. Too tight. It comes with a small keying in case you want to keep it on a key-chain. I leave my keys in my grocery shopping cart while shopping too often for that.

The unit itself is very small and very light. It is secured to the phone only by the micro-USB port. It seems a weakness in the design, it would be nice if it were a replaceable snap-in module in the design should that connection fail. It would be even nicer if it could be taken out,rotated around, then put back in, so that it would fit more phones.

On my HTC, it fits on the side of my phone but the port faces wrong. I had to get this extension cable to make it work: YCS Basics 6 inch USB Micro male to female OTG extension cable It works, but makes it a bit more difficult to juggle. While I was waiting on the cable, I was able to use it with a couple of USB extension cables and USB to micro cables I had. I do find that the shorter cable is easier. Either way, it's inconvenient and makes the device harder to juggle with the cable. I find I have to use two hands.

The thermal imager works well. The images don't have to be gray scale, they can be changed to several different color schemes. The temperature point can also be set, so if it is 70 degrees at room temp, you can set the device to that, and then it will read anything more cold, or hotter, than that. All the settings are in the application itself and nothing has to be done to the camera unit itself. Paranormal researchers could use this feature to find cold spots.

The camera can be used to spot wildlife, leaks in pipes, areas where there are energy leaks, or electrical shorts. If you point it at a grill or baking stone, it can tell you the approximate temperature, but it does better at a more distant range.

I like the camera and what it does, and the application is VERY nice. I just think the camera has several design issues that could be improved to make it more easily compatible with phones that have ports that are `backwards' and a few other little things. For instance, I think a lens cap would have been a nice addition to include. There are no paper instructions with the unit, but just playing with the application, it is easy to learn.
summary: Some smartphones will need an extra cable, check compatibility, nice application

reviewText:
This neat little thermal camera is ideal for troubleshooting or monitoring electrical systems. It's resolution is sufficient to identify several issues. Please Note this not a simple toy camera. It is intended for professional use and an operator must have the training and experience to use it. I am a level 2 certified Thermographer and at the price of 300usd, what a bargain!

FYI almost every thermal camera will make a clicking noise to refresh the image on its sensor.  Those reviews which complain of this noise and the low resolution plus other petty issues not related to the field of thermography please find a Thermographer to donate this amazing tool. You all need to stick to playing with your cell phone visual camera and leave thermal technology alone.
summary: Excellent entry level thermal camera

reviewText:
Great mat and using it for a small electronics/hobby bench now.  Came rolled up but the nature of the product allowed it, with time, to unroll fully and while I had to add a few weights to the corners to get them down completely; nothing that would deduct points from.

Using this with a Hakko fx888D Soldering Station and works great!  I've dropped a few solder balls here and there and leave no mark or heat marks on the mat.  I have mine run to the ground of a plugged socket in the wall and I seem to have no noticeable issues with static; which was the products intent!

Great peace of mind after having it and I'm working with hobby, small electronics and single board computers (Arduino, Raspberry Pi, etc)
summary: Great mat and using it for a small electronics/hobby bench ...

reviewText:
outstanding deal on an SSD1306 OLED - works with Arduino, Beaglebones, Raspberry Pis - even a Zero!

this is a great way to have a low-power, readable display on one of these fun little micro-controllers or SBCs

use rm-hull's Python lib and code (search GitHub)... after you do an install, here's a little routine to wrap a long line of text output (i use it on my Beaglebone, but it also works as-is on my RPi3):

# display uptime stats with text wrap
 def get_uptime():
  uptime = os.popen("uptime")
  ut = str(uptime.read())
  # strip out trailing chars for cleaner output
  return "%s" % ut.rstrip('\r\n')

 font = ImageFont.truetype('/home/debian/Downloads/ssd1306-master/FreeSans.ttf', 17)
 draw.text((1, 1),  '  UPTIME',  font=font, fill=1)

 # now smaller font needed and wrap text to show info
 font = ImageFont.truetype('/home/debian/Downloads/ssd1306-master/FreeSans.ttf', 11)
 import textwrap
 lines = textwrap.wrap(get_uptime(), width=25)
 # what 'line' to start info
 y_text = 20
 w = 1 # we'll always start at left side of OLED
 for line in lines:
  width, height = font.getsize(line)
  draw.text((w, y_text), line, font=font, fill=1)
  y_text += height

 oled.display()
 sleep(4)
 oled.cls()

enjoy your display!
summary: a most excellent OLED

reviewText:
With its crystal clear display and easy I2C connection, this little OLED  went easily  into my project and looks terrific.  The link provided to the library worked well.  It is I2C address 0x3C, so don't get confused by the markings on the back of the board.  I did, but used an I2C scanner and sure as heck, their docs were correct!

Adafruit's library is what makes this great, and making bitmaps for images is very easy using the tool at: [...]f you are using it for Arduino (or Particle Photon, as I am in this project).  I bought one to see how it would look for my project and it is going into 7 more that I am making; I just bought 8 more.

Seller shipped fast and it arrived in a nice padded envelope, perfectly packed for the journey.
summary: Very Nice Display, Easy to use Bright, Clear, and VERY high resolution

reviewText: Fantastic Screen and very sharp and bright. It's compatible with Arduino UNO. It uses the I2C bus. The CORRECT I2C ADDRESS is NOT 0x78 as marked on the board's silkscreen (see picture) but 0x3C. The Adafruit_SSD1306.h header file has it correct under SSD1306_I2C_ADDRESS as 0x3C though so you can substitute the 0x3B in the "ssd1306_128x64_i2c.ino" sample program with "SSD1306_I2C_ADDRESS" and it works. The other thing is you need to uncomment the "//#define SSD1306_128_64" line and comment the other two so it know what screen size is. The wires used are from this product link: Kalevel 120pcs Multicolored 40pin Male to Female, 40pin Male to Male, 40pin Female to Female Breadboard Jumper Wires Ribbon Cables Kit
summary: Fantastic Screen and very sharp and bright but careful with I2C address

reviewText:
excellent little display... using rm-hull/ssd1306 instructions at git-hub i was up and running with this display in less than 10 minutes... as a bonus, the code ports easily to the Beaglebone (i use a Green Wireless)

and this little display will be a perfect companion to my new Pi Zero! it can also be used as a nice system monitor for a headless ARM SBC!

it took just a single afternoon of hacking with some Python code to craft a nice little output for this display - will be quite handy! (i've attached a couple pics)

extremely sharp and bright lettering - just be aware that is a *tiny* display (which is good for a number of reasons: low power draw, inexpensive, fits on small cases)
summary: Beaglebone or Raspberry Pi display - excellent and easy to get working!

reviewText:
The default (Iron) color gradient is sufficient for almost anything, but there are others for more specialized work.
The high/low temperature readings are dead on. I checked several areas with other temp guns and it is exact.
Onboard memory is huge and should last a long time. Connecting to a computer is easy and quick.
Charging is about standard (3 hours for me).
There is a WiFi setting that I haven't used yet, will update late.
The MSX setting is a bit offset, maybe it's intentional, but it provides a visual reference and works for me.
Attached are two quick examples of things we overlook. Electrical and Mechanical.
Of course, I cannot show pictures of readings from a server room, but taking heat readings can save lots of money on mis-installed hardware. Cooling is a big deal in IT and yet it is assumed that everything functions properly. Providing a clear picture of where hardware is improperly installed can make fixing it easy, and give management something to use.
I've been wishing for something like this for years.
For HVAC techs, or any other site survey kind of work, this FLIR tool provides solid and accurate information needed to make big budget decisions.
summary: Must Have in Today's Tech

reviewText: This thing is literally perfect.  I actually used it for only white LEDs!  One of the areas I lit is a longer wire run than another area, so I was having issues with the far area being more dim.  I put four different areas of white LEDs each on different color channels. reviewText: First of all, I would have given this a full five stars without any reservation except for how appallingly dirty the toothbrushes were when I opened the package. You can see the photos at the end of the photo sequence below. Hopefully mine is the only exception. The top side was clean, but rotating them over 90 degrees was an entirely different story. A simple firm wipe didn't remove that debris either. It took soap and water and a rough washcloth to get it off. It's okay now, but there is absolutely no excuse for filthy toothbrushes this expensive or any other price for that matter. Philips, wake up and get your factory clean! I have owned a different model Philips Sonicare toothbrush since December 2014. I liked it, but it just didn't seem to have the cleaning power of a rotating toothbrush like the Oral-B Pro 5000 I've owned since May 2015. I've used both of these toothbrushes daily, using the Oral-B in the mornings and nighttime and the Philips Sonicare in the daytime. However, everything has changed with this new model with the addition of a new high power mode. When I first used the older Philips Sonicare it felt like a surprisingly strong sensation, but I grew accustomed to it quickly. Then I wanted something more powerful and the Oral-B satisfied that need. Philips Sonicare 2 Series Plaque Control Sonic Electric Rechargeable Toothbrush, HX6211/30 By the way, the Sonicare above is quite good, but just not as intense. When I went to the dentist for semi-annual cleaning using the above toothbrush, the hygienist didn't seem to notice any difference. I don't normally accumulate much plaque anyway, so I suppose that wasn't a big surprise. I attribute that to flossing three to four times per day without exception after each meal or snack. I'm 73 and my teeth are still quite healthy whereas both my parents had false teeth in their forties. Fluoride was a major factor. So I've adopted a strict regimen of high fluoride toothpaste, dental flossing and within the past several years, electric toothbrushes. Prior to that I thought a regular soft bristle toothbrush was fully equivalent. But there is a shortcoming in the lower jaw that the dentist pointed out. Right handed people miss a location and left handed people miss on the opposite side. Interesting. So I bought into the electric toothbrush. I started with the Philips Sonicare in the link below. I really need to replace the brush head, but now I am going to use it for my Invisalign retainer tray cleaning task. Yes, I finally got my teeth straightened at age 68 and it worked - $4200 well spent. I am pleased to get two of these for sure. My wife is 44 years younger and she has just finished her Invisalign sequence and will pick up her permanent retainers next week. Between cavities and Invisalign, I have a major investment to protect - for both of us. Now that Philips has implemented the high power mode, I can put the Oral-B toothbrush aside and use only this new Philips Sonicare toothbrush. I never did understand the need for Bluetooth on a toothbrush anyway mostly a gimmick in my opinion. And Im a technologist, too. So I know how to connect Bluetooth easily. My wife may want to start off in the Sensitive Mode and graduate up to the maximum setting. It is her first experience. For me, I want all the sonic power I can get. So about the only difference I can see between the $39.95 model I have owned for a long time and the new one is the two other settings. So why is that worth tripling the price or worse? So weve come from dollar toothbrushes to $10 electric rotary battery toothbrushes to suddenly $128 toothbrushes? It can't be the lithium battery. Look at the huge lithium batteries on my lawn equipment for far less money. Im confused about the model Im reviewing. I received a two-pack and it is referring me to what looks like a single toothbrush link. Something doesnt seem quite right. You should shop and do some research to find the best price. But I can say with certainty you need the third speed or intensity to do the best job. Look for the three small lights one above another on the front below the big green on-off button.
summary: Beyond Excellent.  Major Improvement in Sonic Intensity.  Oral-B Pro 5000 Beware. New Game in Town.

reviewText:
Shark Rotator Powered Lift-Away Canister

I am initially posting my preliminary review and first impression which will be followed later by more extensive thoughts and observations.

I've seen plenty of these new higher-end canister vacuums in the stores (Dyson, Miele, etc.) but had yet to have one in my home. I've always been fan of shop vacs (for their raw power) when it comes to heavy duty cleaning needs and cordless uprights/handhelds for convenience and every day use. I wondered if this Shark could come anywhere close to the suction power of small sized shop vac or have anywhere near the convenience of an upright.

Upon it's arrival I was immediately intrigued by the marketing tout right on the box-- the proclamation that Shark vacuums have "More 5 star online reviews than any other brand". That really piqued my interest and I couldn't wait to find out if this machine was going to live up to the high expectations that the Shark company was setting up for it.

If looks could kill, taking this machine out of the box could be a fatal affair. Is this really vacuum cleaner? It looks too good. With it's jewel-tone metallic paint like finish and giant spoked looking wheels this thing evokes a futuristic souped-up hot rod you might see in a Star Wars film. After looking it over and enjoying it's sharp looks, I began some knuckle tests and feeling & poking around, looking for weaknesses. It was initially impressive, even an engineering marvel in it's overall design. The hose, which sometimes is the weakest link in a vacuum, is nice and sturdy. Although there is obviously a lot of plastic used, it felt pretty solid and not cheaply made.

One of the first functional things that I noticed were the two large rectangular buttons on the top of the canister, one for power and the other to withdraw the power cord. I really appreciated the size and placement of these. I then tried the removal and replacement of the dirt compartment a few times and found that to be a smooth and simple procedure. Of course then I just had to try the "Lift-Away" feature. You simply step on a lever at the back of the canister and lift the main part up by it's handle and away it goes. It's very simple and clever. As soon as I did that I spied the crevice and brush attachments which are stowed in the base (that bottom part with the wheels). My initial impression of this Lift-Away feature was that while it is nice, you really almost feel like you are not really leaving much behind. Most of the weight of the unit is in the motor and and such. It becomes a little more portable as you leave behind the wheel assembly and small attachments, but not in a dramatic way.

I moved on to the "click" assembly/dis-assembly between the parts, those being the hose, wand and three cleaning heads. This is where I encountered one issue. All the "click" connection between all of the parts worked smoothly, except for the connection between the wand and the motorized head. I expected it to require a bit of extra force to lock in since there is also a power connection involved, but I sensed that something was wrong. At first I could not even get it to lock in. I inserted it with a push just like the other connections, the motor was powered up and it appeared to be in place but it slipped right back out when trying to use it. After some effort I found that it took a LOT of force to make the connection so that it would lock in place. I thought that this was perhaps a quality control issue, since I could not imagine it being designed to require THAT much force (I had to use some body weight or even pick it up and sort of hammer it in).

I decided to call Shark to inquire. I tried to convey to the rep that it seemed to require much more force to attache the motorized head than the other connections. Initially she told me several times that this was normal and that it was due to the power connection. I tried to better emphasize the amount of force that it was requiring, but she still seemed reluctant to think that it was a QC or manufacturing  issue. I thought back to the quip on the box ("most five star reviews') and thought something was wrong here, so I pressed further and sensing my growing irritation she finally relented (albeit with a reluctant and patronizing tone) and said that if I REALLY wanted it, they would send out a replacement wand and motorized head. I asked for the replacement head alone, since the wand worked just fine with the other pieces. I am currently awaiting receipt of that replacement head and will update on this issue and perhaps put up a short video.

In the meantime, I am putting the vacuum through it paces around the house. I have to say that so far I am impressed with the suction. It is no wimp.  More to come as I become more familiar with this interesting machine.

Update: I have since received the replacement motorized head and have discovered that the initial head that came with my vacuum did indeed have a defect. The replacement clicks in quite easily and I am very happy with it's operation. I had even received an automated message from Shark letting me know that the replacement part had shipped and it's tracking number. The initial unfortunate customer service phone call experience is all but forgotten from my mind.

As I use the vacuum more I am discovering that there are a lot of small details that I've really come to appreciate. One that stands out is the notch the back of the canister for hooking the wand onto so that it stands upright. It is so simple but it works and is super convenient.

If you have any questions about this vacuum before I can fill this review up with every detail, please ask and I will do my best to answer.
summary: My First Encounter With a Shark

reviewText:
When I got into 3d printing, I asked a friend who has already 2+ years in 3d printing, what is the best filament to use. He recommended Hatchbox brand. I bought some of Hatchbox and he is right it is a good brand. However, I was having a hard time getting all the colors I wanted from them, so I read some review about this brand. I liked some of the reviews and decided to give it a try. My first print was on Hatchbox settings and I did have some messed up prints. I tweaked the extruder heat and the bed heat and got now the perfect setting. I have a Qidi Tech (Flashforge china duplicate) and love it. Set the extruder to 197c and the bed to 62-64.

My prints came out awesome. The feel is soft and the colors are bright, but not over shiny. Love all the colors. Just ordered more.

This review is repeated for all colors I bought
summary: what is the best filament to use

reviewText:
This product prints very well, and the color is phenomenal. The only issue I've encountered is that at lower temperatures (190-200) the filament will stop printing at certain spots in the spool. I haven't had this issue printing at 210. The width has so far been very consistent. Using BuildTak and a gluestick, I am able to get good adhesion at .1mm base layer with no brim or raft. I will be buying more filament from 3D Solutech.

reviewText:
Unlike others I received the correct 3/8 hose BUT this stuff is GARBAGE.  I flushed my lines before hooking up my new carb and even with gas just flowing through this line ( NO pressure or sitting in line at all ) this line turned the gas BROWN.. there is no way anyone can tell me that poluting gas with whatever is turning it brown in the line is good for jets or injectors SEE PICTURE.  I sent this back , got line from the local parts store and my gas is now crystal clear.

I am so glad I thought to flush the line AND use a glass filter to catch anything in there and actually see what was flowing through. I will NEVER use a Thermoid product again

reviewText:
This eSun PETG prints at 240C and requires a slow print rate (<40mm/s) to get good results. Also required the fan on all the time with a hot heatbed (75C).

By comparison, I sourced PETG from a US filament maker, and it prints at 260C. The US PETG can print at PLA speeds (>40mm/s), regardless of heatbed temp or fan (can be on or off, worked the same). So while I was able to get decent results with eSun, it took a lot more tweaking and it is  temperamental compared to other brands I own.

reviewText:
As the photo shows, I purchased the complimentary handle that goes with this mop head for the sake of reviewing.
I'm very happy with both pieces. If you have a lot of hardwood or tile flooring, or you are responsible for the janitorial duties of a company, this set is a wise investment.

This mop head, in particular, is a hard-working product that brings results. The fibers grab onto dirt and release it into your bucket.
Because it is wide and flat, it does not get bunched up, and therefore covers more area in a shorter length of time.

 Although I'm showing it on a swing type head, a clamp head can also be used with this.
After heavy use, I put it in the washing machine, and let it air-dry. It's now ready for the next big job.
