reviewText:
I highly recommend this 7.9 gallon/ 30 L Slim Jim Step-On trash container. It fits snugly and unobtrusively next to my island in the kitchen, and looks great next to the stainless steel on the fridge. The Slim Jim is a nice solid weight when empty, and does not have even a hint of tipping when you step on the sturdy feeling and large foot lever, which opens the two top slat covers smoothly outward, like you would expect on some kind of spaceship. Even better, when you release your foot, the covers slowly float downwards to their original position with barely a sound.

On the backside of the Slim Jim, opposite the foot pedal, is an oblong shaped release plate (see pic) that allows you to access the opening mechanism on the inside, in case it gets stuck for some reason, and that's a thoughtful touch. The dark brown inner one piece trashcan part is seamless and completely removable, which makes it very easy to clean. The trashcan also has an ingenious cut-out slot on one side, which allows you (see the directions on the sticker in pic), to twist/ tighten the loose plastic of your trash bag and hold down any excess in the narrow portion of the slot, preventing the bag from falling down into the can off the sides.

btw, the big sticker on the front came off readily, without any nasty goo residue. nice.

Rubbermaid's design team really put a lot of thought into this product, and it shows. If you're in the market for a foot-pedal operated trashcan that looks sleek and that you'd be proud to have out in the open, look no further. This Slim Jim can is excellent.
summary: Excellent space-saving trashcan that looks like a spaceship and opens (and closes) like one too.

reviewText:
They call this a "Garage Dolly", but I really consider it a "Household Dolly" since that is what it is perfectly suited for. It looks better that I expected. This may sound strange but I do admire the form and function of this simple piece of equipment. It has a modern utilitarian aesthetic that would not look out of place doing duties in the home (or even just sitting idle).

It is made of heavy gauge plastic that has a shine to it. It is stamped maximum weight of 200 lbs. If I stand on it with on foot right in-between the wheels I can see the plastic 'give' a little bit, but anything more evenly distributed would be just fine. The five wheels roll around fine and easily in any direction.

This is the perfect size (15 5/8" X 10 3/4" exact measurement) for a filing cabinet or similar sized storage boxes. It is also small enough to be portable and has two openings on either end for easy carrying. It is also available in red.
summary: Hello Dolly

reviewText: This is the best investment I made into my 3D printer.  The photo is a calibration cube using clear PLA on bare glass.  The finish is glass like. Other materials require a thin layer of glue stick. Over time the glue will loose it's grip and needs to be cleaned off. Just wash it off with water, clean with glass cleaner, reapply a thin layer and enjoy.
summary: A must have.

reviewText:
I love this glass bed, everything is perfect. The glass arrived in perfect condition, no scratch or chip. The bed conducts heat nicely so PLA stick well to the plate, no warping so far.

This bed is definitely worth in the long run, much better than using painter's tape.
summary: I love this glass bed

reviewText:
I use all sorts of rubbers ..... gloves.  Professionally for over 20 years I relied on "rubber gloves" as I came into contact with lots of people with stuff on them only a seasoned coroner could describe in educated terms.  I, being of simple origin, describe the stuff I came into contact with as crap.  Not in the fecal sense of the word, but you know - stuff we touch, smell or taste and then say the word "crap" as in; WTF is this stuff?!?  But you don't say "What is this stuff..." out loud because your survival instinct is whispering in your ear "You don't want to know."

So about these gloves.  It's made from it's nitrile which means nothing to me because I'm not a scientist either.  Could be made from cow udders for all I care.  But since I mentioned cow udders - has anyone tried that yet?  It's got the built in fingers and all.

Think about how strong a glove made from a cow's udder would be.  Until they come up with that invention - this is the best we've got.  And it's really good stuff!  I have average dude hands in that I when I buy winter gloves I buy mediums. The large size fits me snug and secure with a nice forming feel. Important with rubbers.

And talk about tough and not too bulky!  That's important because sometimes you don't get to see the crap you just touched.  You rely on your tactile senses to determine level of "Ah S*#T" you're gonna feel like at any moment.  Having gloves on that will give you a sensory heads-up is much better than a total shock when you finally see what it is your clutching.

I could list off all the specifications but if you are reading this - you can take the time to read the description.  It's accurate and the details do matter.  Ask anyone that's ever said to them selves "What is that crap..."?

My Mom would have slept better knowing I wore these when I touched some of those things.  So if you have a son/daughter that works for some cheap jurisdiction that insists the lowest bidder supply is good enough - buy them a case of these for Christmas.  It's like giving them a bullet proof vest, you'll sleep better knowing when they touch that stuff - they don't have to live with whatever it was the rest of their life.
summary: Remember that stuff you did not want to touch but you did and said OMG WTF is that!  Wear these next time.

reviewText: I've tried a lot of different brand nitrile gloves and they just don't compare to these ones. I'm not talking about me trying cheap ones and expecting them to be similar. I've tried the Venom Steel, Growers Edge and quite a few other disposable gloves that aren't cheap. The Dark Light is noticeably thicker and does seem to run smaller than other brands. Large from other brands is slightly loose on me but these large fit snug. Highly recommended!!
summary: Hands down the best Nitrile gloves I have ever used!

reviewText: I've ordered a dozen of these and they have all come ready to use. Real time saver. Pin label is a nice plus also.
summary: Perfect. Bootloader correctly programmed and straight pins .

reviewText: Should have been listed as a transparent filament but otherwise my first hour print went ok. I attached a photo for comparison to my Hatchbox PLA-T transparent red which is actually a little more opaque then the Cutequeen red PLA.
summary: Not bad but not opaque

reviewText:
Unusable filament

The first 2 prints I ran failed in minutes. The next small print I ran at 20mm/s (half the speed I run my other filaments at) was successful and I would have been fine if the only drawback was just having to print everything at half speed, but then the next print failed and I couldn't get anything to come out of my extruder after that, even at 230c. At first glance, the spool just looked like it was badly wound, but with a closer look, I can see bits of junk mixed in with the filament and the diameter varies wildly. I don't see how the spools I normally print have been tangle & junk-free in the dozens of spools I've used up, yet this for $2 less can't go 5 meters without a jam.

This picture shows the bits of junk and bulges from just one section of the spool.
summary: Unprintable, printer head damaged.

reviewText: I bought it because of the first reason plus the price was right. Upon receiving the item, the protective screen wasn't properly secured. Fixed that in a few seconds and now it's solid. It looked extremely cheap on amazon and feels even cheaper once in my hand. I love this thing! So many different uses for this - I have it in my doctor's bag!
summary: Looks cheap and feels even cheaper!

reviewText: These are perfect for my project.  They work great at as little as 3.0v only consuming 9 mA.  They produced a clear laser dot across a brightly lit room when powered at 4v and 19mA.
summary: Work great, can't beat the price

reviewText: Product was as advertised, quality seems good as does the reliability. In order to prevent junction over-driving I wanted to add a series resistance and still power with standard 1.5v batteries, using as few as possible. A quick measure the IV-characteristics indicated that with a voltage in the range of 4.5 to 6.0 volts with a 47 ohm series resistor gave me excellent laser output (brightness). I have attached the IV-curve chart if anyone is interested.
summary: Product was as advertised, quality seems good.

reviewText: Works great very stable on the table.  Very easy to mount on wall and remove when not in use. Has keyhole holes so it can be removed from the wall so I don't have to see spools of filament on the wall
summary: Works great very stable on the table

reviewText:
I ranked this with a four because of the rather high price and mediocre quality. That being said it is still cheaper than printing out your own in both time and money. I mount them on wire shelving. I face the tabs away facing out and secure them with plastic ties.  I tried the four spool rack and found that it bowed in the center and it was difficult to change a spool in the center.

I have a couple of spools that are wider than the spool slots be between the spacer. I found that by putting the spool in the center, straddling the center spacer, it worked well. I have a large diameter spool of filiment for the Maker 3D printer. With this spool holder, it would drag on the shelf. I printed out an insert meant for the FF Pro that slides over the spindle and inside of the Maker spool. It now feeds right without dragging on the shelf.
summary: Good and almost a 5

reviewText: Works good.  Originally, i was on the fence about purchasing one of these since it goes against the idea of having a 3D printer (You should make it).  I am pleased with the quality of this though.  It was well worth the extra $10.  It feels rugged and heavy, plus the rubber feet won't mar the surface it sits on.  I know some would rather print one out, but I found for my Prusa I3, this works very nice and looks great.  I believe it will work for many different spool manufacturers, not just Hatchbox.
summary: Was worth the money, vs printing it.

reviewText: I am using this spool so I can use third-party (Hatchbox's) filament in my Dremel Idea Builder 3D Printer. I placed the spool outside the printer and fed the filament through a hole on the exterior and it works perfectly. Now I can save a bunch of money by using non-Dremel brand filament. It even comes with rubber feet to keep it in place if used on a tabletop, or you can wall-mount it. At under $10 at the time of my review, this was a great buy!
summary: A great buy - allows me to use non-OEM brand filament in my Dremel Idea Builder

reviewText: Really good value in a basic scope, but compared to my original Eico 460, it is an exceptional instrument. The cost of test equipment has, like most electronics, just gotten better. The Hantek is easy to master, once you run through the settings, and it has many to understand. The form factor fits well on my small work bench, and the fan noise is low.
summary: Nice value in a scope

reviewText:
This is one amazing instrument!  I am still learning all the things it does!

I was worried that maybe 8-bit resolution would not be enough, but it works just fine or everything I need it for.  Think of this as more than just a DSO (Digital Storage Oscilloscope).  It is a multi-tester - you can get realtime readouts of many many different measurements right next to the waveform, such as Vrms, Vp-p, frequency, Mean volts, max volts, min volts, etc.  So kind of like having a DMM right in the scope.  The screen is extremely clear, bright, and easy to read.  Many trigger modes, acquire modes - like I said, still learning how to use it.  FFT built-in, I could go on and on.  The spec sheet does not give this unit justice, because it is difficult to describe all of the things it does.  You can even trigger on the width of a pulse!  Set a width (time), and it can be set to trigger for smaller pulses, larger pulses, or pulses within 5% of your setting.  While I have not needed that, I can imagine that might be extremely useful!  Catch a 5ns glitch!  Set to trigger for less than 6ns width!  WOW.

Yes, you can see some digital artifacts but they are down in the noise - like 24 dB down.  In other words, working with 1 volt full scale (that would be 8 major divisions) you would have digitization noise at 4mv - which is 1/32 of a major division.  This is so small, it is not really an issue for almost all cases.

I included a photo of the scope showing it reading the built-in square wave for testing the scope probes, and showing the "measurement" display next to the waveform.  This measurement is accessed by pressing a single button, what you want to measure can be changed with a single button (F6), and the panel can be removed with a single button (F0).

I love it!

And yes, I realize that this level of technology is only available from China because of the extremely low wages...  Sigh.
summary: What an amazing instrument at a rock-bottom price!

reviewText:
I am a rookie in the 3D printing world. So I must say this filament works as proposed, I already used the whole cartridge and no drama. It went smooth and I didn't have any issues.

I am using it on a XYZ pro and it works great, the quality of the filament is very good.

In the photos, some of the stuff I printed using this filament.
summary: Recommended

reviewText:
I absolutely love almost every piece of this printer, from the quality of their customer service, to the quality of the prints. I have put a few hundred hours of use on this 3D printer and have managed to print some pretty high quality objects. This is my first entrance into 3D printing and was struggling to decide between all the different options out there. The thing that locked in my decision was the quality of the responses on the company forums to issues, as well as the auto bed leveling feature of the printer itself.

One other notable feature that this printer excels above it's counterparts in the market is the heated bed. I'm not simply talking about the fact that it's heated (that's quite common), but instead I'm referring to the PEI surface coating that the bed has. Bed adhesion is big issue among almost all 3D printers, and in forum after forum people discuss the use of hairspray, tape, and glue to ensure proper bed adhesion. I have had to use NONE of these methods and have been able to print both PLA and ABS perfectly directly to the bed's surface and have experienced no warping.

I have used this printer both connected to my computer, as well as a Raspberry Pi running OctoPi and both have performed admirably. The open source Cura software that is available for download from their site has been really fantastic to work with. I have moved on to using Simplify3d as my slicer, but only because I wanted some of the advanced features such as manual supports and Vase mode, but the printer has been producing superb quality prints with both slicers.

I did run into an issue once where I had been feeding 1.75mm filament for a job that I left unattended, which ended up failing due to "Heat creep" which is when the temperature is set a bit too high and the filament gets heated a bit too high and causes kinks in the filament. This ultimately led to a deep PLA blockage in my hot end. A quick email to customer service got me a response within 30 minutes that helped me clear the clog without any further issues.

The one issue I do have with this printer is that it's designed to use 3mm filament which is not as readily avaliable locally, and although I've ran quite a few successful prints with 1.75mm filament (many people run it without issue), the rate of print failures is still a lot higher with it. Since I've mostly been printing lately with 3mm filament, I've not run into many issues with the printer's performance. The print build area is a bit smaller than some more expensive models, but I knew that going in and wanted to stick my toes into the 3D printing arena without spending too much money. That being said, when I'm ready to move up to a bigger print area, I will most definitely be looking at their higher end TAZ line of printers.

Pros:
Auto-bed leveling
High quality metal frame
Fantastic PEI bed surface for great adhesion
Fantastic customer service
Compact enough to fit on my desk with both a monitor and my Network storage box
Mesmerizes my cats for hours on end

Cons:
3mm filament not as common as 1.75mm
Cats refuse to play with the cat toys I print out for them
summary: I absolutely love almost every piece of this printer

reviewText:
Oh god were do I begin.
I only tried PLA 3mm I wanted to try ABS but now with the bad results I got I don't have the motivation, I am going to review this filament on my Youtube channel and live print and compare it with other PLA as well but for here this is my review:
1. its inconsistant with its diameter, the tolerance of error is very large it can go from 2.90mm to 3.5mm at times, I hardly had consistency with this PLA.
2. it does not print good quality and warp as if it was ABS, I found that weird but I have pictures to back me up.
3. it variate very quickly to temperature change, I usually set 210 for PLA and this brand either don't flow good less than 205 or at 210 it start stringing.

I printed examples, 2 different brands, white is IC3D and Green is ColorFabb and you can judge for your self
I don't advise you buy this PLA its expensive for the bad quality.
and it causes jam in my printer and I have pictures of that as well
summary: PLA is at poor quality, it inconsistent and will jam your Extruder

reviewText: Product description for the White 1.75mm PLA is a lie. The tolerance for the filament is not +/- 0.03mm. It's .1mm... I would never have bought it if I knew that. The filament is oval shaped as well. 1.72mm one side, 1.78mm the other end. I bought this in April and haven't used it until today. I didn't think I needed to double check since the reviews where so good, but I guess we got to double check everything.
summary: Incorrect Product Description. Caution

reviewText: This was my second purchase of the IC3D brand and I have found this product to be superior in quality and accuracy.  The black PLA prints are clean and less far less glossy than the standard PLA prints I have created in the past.  I highly recommend the IC3D high quality black PLA.  I printed a black motorcycle cup holder that has been my best PLA print to date with this filament.  Printing at medium settings (.2mm, 35 infill at a speed of 50) it produced a great looking product.  This is my second filament purchase from IC3D and I am really satisfied that this company produces quality filaments.
summary: It really is that good.

reviewText: This is a nice assortment, with a decent overall quantity for the price (I paid <$14 for it). My biggest issue is that this filament seems to expand slightly while being heated. I'm using it with a 3D pen, and each and every time after I stop the pen, about .75" slowly extrudes from the tip accompanied by a popping sound (see picture). I confirmed it happening with 5 of 5 colors I have used so far. I went back to the samples included in the pen kit and they did not have the same issue. The actual waste is minimal, as it's not 3/4" of the stock material, but of the reduced diameter of the nozzel, but it is annoying and adds time to the process. I will probably try another manufacturer if I can find a similar price.
summary: Nice pack, but material is questionable.

reviewText:
Well, I just got this today and haven't actually used it yet, but I wanted to just give a Heads-Up if you get one.  Mine came with Zero instructions/manual.  These "K" type thermo-couples DO have a polarity, but is not well indicated on both the instrument, or the individual probes.  So put on your Opti-Visor and get your thinnest Sharpie to mark it up.  Each probe has a very small "+" sign on the plug .. just graze the "plus" with your Sharpie.  The plug well is also marked very faintly .. Plus goes to the rear .. Minus facing you.  I also numbered them on the plugs .. to reduce some confusion as I place all four probes.

As to accuracy, it's gotta be better than what I get with either of my infra-red hand-held thermometers.  At ambient temperature .. about 72*f, all four probes are within 0.9*f, which is certainly adequate for my application.  My application is a 10KVA 440vac transformer converted to an 80 amp 60 volt battery charger .. running off of 220.  The hand-helds show temps that are way high between the coils, and for $33 bucks, this instrument should put my concerns to rest, or prompt some additional thermal modeling.  Lost a star due to lack of a manual/instructions, but it's pretty simple/intuitive, as long as you plug in the probes with their correct polarity.  Cheers!

and .. $7 bucks for http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0044NI2M2 .. non-hardening

UPDATE on 4 April 2016.  I'm raising this review to 5 Stars, as I've had time to put this product under test, and not dinking around with some "mobo" rework, as used by another reviewer.  The photo is of a 10KVA "bucking" transformer converted for use as a 5KVA battery charger.  The probes are measuring inside and the outside of left coil, the base of the bridge heat-sink on 3, and the 200A fuse on probe 4.  Probe 4 was later simply placed inside the blast cover, without tape or thermal goop, for a much more accurate (and dramatically higher) reading.  In following instructions for an $800 unit, I found that by holding the Backlight Button IN, while powering up, the unit will stay ON, until you intentionally power it Off, which for me in my application, was my complaint.  I'll continue to use it for thermal modeling/placement of 4 x 80mm fans for forced air cooling. 5 Stars
summary: Temps show within 0.9*f at 72*f ambient .. Updated .. 5 Stars

reviewText: I've owned the Replicator 5th Gen for about 2 years and now simply love it.  There had been issues with the original smart extruder and I had gone through several of them, but the new generation of Smart Extruder + seems have fixed all the issues and my Replicator is running smoothly now better than ever. You can simply ignore those negative reviews about the old extruder. I also own a number of other 3D printers and made myself a Prusa i3. The replicator does have finest print quality and is the easiest one to use. Minimum adjustment, print-and-forget. It does not have heated bed, so I used it strictly for PLA project. The printer has enough onboard memory to work independently once the print job is uploaded. The iPhone APP allows me to keep a visual on the print job and will alert me if there's anything wrong or the job is finished. The filament jam alarm will pause the printer if the filament ran out, and will resume from where its left once new pool of filament is loaded. This feature saved me a lot of headache especially for large print jobs which often takes overnight.
summary: Best 3D printer for home and small business, thanks for the new Smart Extruder+

reviewText: I am thoroughly enjoying this printer with the Smart Extruder+. I have owned it for over a year now, with over 300 hours on it.  Although it was difficult at first with the original Smart Extruder, now it works like it was meant to.  I never have any jams, and it stops printing when I run out of filament like it should.  Leveling the bed is a snap, the camera is great for keeping an eye on your prints when your not there, and the software and firmware have finally matured to a point where I feel confident in what I ask it to print, it will print, and print well..  One trick I have used to make sure my prints stay stuck is to utilize kapton tape for a first layer on the print bed, then lay blue painters tape on top of that.  It works great!  I have other printers as well that I utilize regularly, but if you want a printer that you can count on, this is your printer.  (Smart Extruder+ is highly recommended for a care free experience.)
summary: Loving this printer now!

reviewText: With the new Smart Extruder+ I'm able to successfully run long prints time after time - 16-24 hour prints are now a breeze. I printed 3 of these bird houses in a row - see the attached picture - you can find this on Thingiverse.  I even had an out-of-filament error which the SmartExtruder+ gracefully recovered from after sending me a notice on my phone to reload.  MakerBot continues to improve the firmware and the desktop client software making this a very reliable and solid printing experience.  I only wish we had some material options other than PLA (which could be on the horizon with other models of the SmartExtruder?)...
summary: With the SmartExtruder+ this is a terrific 3D printer

reviewText:
I have a two year old Replicator 2 which has served me well; not without issues with the feeder and some Makerware hiccups- but overall it has been very solid.  With almost 1000 hrs of print time, it seemed like a good time to look for its replacement, since I assumed technology has advanced.  While reading the reviews of the Makerbot 5th gen, a very disturbing trend emerged.  One third of the five star reviews occurred on just a single day (10/14/2014)- while not one day of one-star reviews- of which there are twice as many- had two reviews.  Similarly, the positive reviews were brief, and often by Amazon users with no or very few other reviews, opposite of the one star reviews. I created a chart (hopefully it makes it through) to show the distribution of 1 and 5 star reviews by date- it speaks for itself.  Draw your own conclusions- but I'm staying clear of this product.

UPDATE: I initially only looked at five-star reviews for "tampering"- but the four-stars are off as well.  3 of the 8 four-star reviews were done on Oct 22nd (the same day as two five-stars), and 1 of the 8 four-stars was on the same day as the ridiculous "big day" (Oct 14th, 2014) for five-star reviews.  That almost definitely makes many (most?) positive reviews false.  If the suspicious four and five star reviews are discounted, the 5th Gen gets a total score of around 1.6 stars (vice 2.36, as of Feb 15, 20015).  Most seasoned Amazon shoppers would not buy an very expensive product with lots of detailed reviews averaging less than two stars- thus the tampering.
summary: Review patterns are weird- five stars are mostly on one day.

reviewText:
I purchased this printer a few years ago, so I've put it through the ringer. So far it's worked absolutely great; I've got hundreds of hours of printing time on it (maybe thousands) and it's always been super easy to use and yields some very good results. I've used this printer to print replacement parts for things that have broken, add-on parts to make things more functional, toys, decorations, tools, stands and docks, even cable runners to keep my desk tidy. I highly recommend this printer whether you're new to 3D printing or have been doing it for a while. =)

I've attached some images of a few things I've printed with it so you can see for yourself!
summary: Great easy-to-use affordable 3D printer!

reviewText:
I purchased mine from Newegg, NOT amazon, but they are a great re-seller. I have a Prusa mk2 i3 so I have tasted quality, and I am an RandD large format printer engineer (so I know about the mechanics of printers! I wanted a good device for my kid. I plumped for the 1.0a, as most of the reviews seem based on sheer ignorance and an inability to be self reliant. I so wanted this thing to not disappoint me and while the print quality and ease of use is excellent, the build quality is just not good. I was able to calibrate out of the box with the old paper trick, and I was able to print ABS without glue (get the right bed height and it is really not needed). However, after printing two or three objects (which printed great), I decided to poke around the mechanics of it, that was when I noticed the belt pulley on LHS of the head chassis, was actually sticking out by 3 - 5mm to the left, while the belt was running outside the barrel lip. Now while it was still printing, I know from experience that pulleys need to be parallel to each other on both sides (yes they made ride left and right, but mine was curled almost 70% upwards !!!). Sooner, not later this will cause the belt to slip etc etc. I know I can take it apart and adjust it, but why should I or anyone else have to do that on a brand new device. Yea, adjusments should be made, but this is simply shoddy workmanship. I was rooting for XYZ, and infact I will be getting a minimaker for my kid, but I should have believed those reviews...................

update: As suspected the bracket was broken on the pulley. The XYZ support was actually excellent. They told me I could print the part on my other, send me it (1 - 2 weeks !) or return. Kudos to the support guy, but it does sound like their build QC is not too hot !
summary: but they are a great re-seller. I have a Prusa mk2 i3 so ...

reviewText:
I was very hesitant to buy this printer but am very glad I did. This machine is amazing value for what it does. I mostly print parts related to machine designs and have been blown away with the quality of the prints. Sure there have been some minor issues with belt tension and a broken glass plate, but these are easily resolved and I still have the "I can't believe I got a 3D printer for $499" feeling.

I have printed many parts from complex to simple, all in ABS. I have never had parts curl up off the bed or warp or twist after printing. The software is very restrictive in terms of fine tuning extruded temperature, bed temperature etc. but that turns out to be totally unnecessary for me anyway. The manufacturer has dialed in a set of parameters that just work. And work well!
The slicing software is not the fastest on the planet but it gets the job done. I like the fact that I can treat the printer like a 2D paper printer. Just hit the print button, choose a quality setting and you will be rewarded with a great part. You don't need to be a 3D printer guru to use it. I have had no issues with extruded jams either. This machine is solid.
I had issues getting a printer cartridge recognized and had the painful experience of dealing with some very poor customer service in this regard. But, the engineers behind this machine did a great job with a machine that produces great print quality. I have no issue with the proprietary print cartridge either. Quality is high. No regrets here!
If you would like to experiment with different materials like ninjaflex or bamboo for example, you will need to hack your machine  - there is plenty of advice on google for doing this.
summary: Great value for money!

reviewText: I am a little disappointed with these Taps as the openings where you place the fuses are defective in 3 of the 5 that were sent to me.  It makes it  extremely difficult to push in the fuse.  I managed to move it a little and did get the fuse in but other people may not be so lucky.  I tried to take a few photos but may be hard to see this.  The quality of the area that holds the fuses is not good :-(
summary: Very difficult to push fues in

reviewText:
These are great when adding new equipment to a vehicle. They take one fuse location and turn it into two. They also provide a crimp connector for adding the new wire.

I used these when I installed several new upgrades to my old car. It resulted in a nice clean install
summary: The right way to add a new powered device to a car

reviewText: These casters easily lift the weight of my saw's outfeed table, which has a modified 2x4 base and two layers of 3/4" melamine for the top. They lift upward about 1/2' to 3/4" off the floor, depending on how you affix them to the legs. Urethane wheels roll effortlessly on my polyurethane-painted concrete floor. Two #8 or #10 x 1-1/2" screws attach them to the legs. You can bolt them if you have metal legs. The screws are more than enough in wood. I paired them with Heavy-Duty Leg Levelers, Small Foot (4). These leg levelers allowed me to adjust the table height precisely to match the table saw's height and to assure the outfeed table was in plane with the top of the saw.
summary: Just Right For Table Saw Outfeed Table Mobility

reviewText: Mine will be the third review of this product, there's a 5 star mentioning studio testing and a more typical user and his three star review. What's fascinating is that I can agree with both reviews, and if you've got the time I'll tell you why before I tell you about the Sanskrit. Or you can just jump to The End. The studio review tells you a lot about testing it with high end products and such that to most of the public must mean little more than: Hey, that sounds impressive! Don't do this type of thing when the club is closing down for the night, or you'll rarely get lucky guys. But I can agree with him. The 3 star review is from a more typical user, and what he tells you is that it hardly wowed him, and I can believe in his lack of wow, wowness? Wow factor! There we go. Let's talk about this to determine the reason for both reviews being valid to me. For those who haven't noticed my many audio product reviews on amazon, in which I expel my own brand of BS about audio until I should probably also link to baby wipes, here's the deal. As a kid I managed to get trained in a recording facility, I did a couple years in TV production and triumphantly heard my own national broadcast radio commercial aired in 1990 from my own facility while still using 2 inch tape, and things improved after that. So nearing 51 now, I'm at times referred to as an old, but wise man in this industry,....Do I get the job! I was asked by a reader who seems to like me instead of just putting up with me, to review the SMSL M6, and I said that I have no need for such a device and would think about it, because I really do try for you guys, it was just that I have so many unused headphone amps already and I'm not really a headphone guy, although I have about 80 of them. So instead, I concocted a plan to smooth talk Gemini Doctor into a 50% discount on this Sanskrit instead, pleading with them that because of my previous product purchases from them and reviews on those, combined with the fact that I was down to my last can of soup, really made it the only fair thing to do. The Sanskrit is the M6 without the headphone amp it includes, and so this is still relevant to it anyway. I've got to tell you though, it's because for the past 25 years I've been offered free and discounted recording and musical products from both manufacturers and dealers for testing or just as gifts, but not for reviewing purposes. Because until about 6 years ago when my health problems caught up to me, I've just been a working man and I while had no need for this particular product, how does that help you guys out? So paying $52 and testing it for a couple of weeks is no big deal to me. I have no idea if I'm suppose to declare or whatever that I purchased this at half price, but I did, and yet it was more expensive than the last $500 piece of audio gear that was given to me free from a manufacturer to test as a prototype before it being offered on the market for sale, which is something that I've done many times. Tell me to shut up now, really I'm embarrassed by it all and will likely purchase one just because I am, and so that I can edit all this out. Let's talk about digital to analog conversion, which started long before my own era, and I started with a 1/4 inch 4 track reel to reel at only 7.5 ips. I point that out because I owned products in the 70's using ADA (analog-digital-analog which was a guitar stomp box brand) and it's not so new today, this stuff is as old as me which surprises many who are my kids age. The Sanskrit 6th anniversary edition will convert your digital audio files to analog audio and you can connect to it optically at only a 16 and 24 bit depth and asynchronous USB or using coax at a 16-32 bit depth with all sampling at 32k-192k per second determined by it's input stream using the Wolfson WM8740 chip and that all sounds impressive, very impressive doesn't it? Not much about this page seems to be focused on it's analog stereo output from it's RCA/phono jacks though, it must need it's own numbers advertised! Because everyone loves numbers and the bigger the better, unless it's your waist size. Where the real problem lies is that advertising loves numbers too, the incarnate of Satan upon Earth loves numbers too. In order to combat this Beelzebub you must try to understand those numbers displayed by advertising for all electronics, so,.... All of you who have recorded the same analog signal at 44.1k/16 and 48k/24 and then played them back through the same equipment listening for the difference in digital quality, raise your hand,...I thought so, and it's because mostly only a studio owner would do this. But why test when there are numbers to go by? Wait, I think you could play a song on a movie track and then switch the playback quality in Windows to 44.1k/16 to hear it again to perform this test, right? I'm not sure, but try it and see what you hear if this works. When tested with very nice equipment, there can be a very slight difference between the two, but only when the recorded audio signal itself allows for hearing it, because most signals won't go from silent to max output and this is why it became the standard for the cinema, where it will more so than music. So 16 bit theoretically only allows for a 96.3 dB range from the quietest sound to the loudest and 24 bit raises that number to 144 dB. So that's why you need it! A bigger number! Um, no, not really. Because in order to hear that increased dynamic range from the file the rest of your equipment will need to provide a matching dynamic range of 144 dB. Which you won't have because your amp is most likely between 100 and 110 dB which being next in the signal path it will determine the dynamic range of what you hear. Then you'll need to listen the right type of quiet and loud dynamic tracks from your file in perfect silence without any ambient sound to hear the increase in the dynamic range from that equipment that you don't have to reach the possible 144 dB from your file. Most of today's popular music is only loud and louder anyway and probably uses only a fraction of the 96.3 dB dynamic range normally from it's quiet to loud passages. If you do try testing as I suggest that you do, you'll need a good headphone setup to have any hope of hearing the difference between 44.1k/16 and 48k/24 through the same equipment with only the conversion rate changing. But what about the 48k to 192k instead of 44.1k, those bigger numbers must improve the audio quality, right? After all, bigger numbers are better. Think of a sideways S and how it can represent an audio waveform. Now we will sample that audio wave 44,100 times each second to recreate it in a digital file and that's a lot of times, but it can't be a perfectly smooth sideways S when recreated, can it? Well no it can't, but we have a hard time imagining the universe as we know it too. By increasing the amount of samples per second it has to become a smoother reproduction of the original, however again most would never hear that as a change in their audio reproduction. Since each sample is also a bit of information stored, the file size increases and there is a point of diminishing returns in this quest for perfection in rebuilding the original analog waveform. The industry decided on 48k for that reason and no one can hear the difference between 44.1k and 48k when at the same 16 bit depth, but creating an imaginary improvement was okay with the cost of storing digital information decreasing and since 24 bit could slightly improve dynamic range, why not include 48k with it as the new standard, 48k/24. But when playing back these two different standards using very nice gear, few would ever notice any difference and this standard is a huge jump in the possible improvement of the audio reproduction over 44.1k/16, and that's what is important to understand. If you understand that, and that this digital conversion process is just one tiny part of the whole involved in digitally reproducing analog audio and that it alone can't make a huge difference, you'll understand why a much smaller improvement like doubling or tripling the amount of samples to recreate the waveform doesn't wow any studio engineer, much less our three star reviewer, who most likely never made use of above 48k samples per second anyway. Will you? So it only makes sense that using above 48/24 should really be left to the multi track recording professionals in most cases. where it will eventually be mixed to a final track to be played on the public's players, or worse, within a compressed file. Because any potential gain above 48k/24 would be noticed 30x more when combining 60 digital audio tracks into the two for stereo in the case of what this product uses, to be played back at 44.1k/16 or 48k/24 through consumer equipment. The first standard being almost perfect and the second being better digital reproduction than what you're able to play back with today's amps, unless you happen to have incredible equipment that you listen to in an anechoic chamber. While there are amps that reach 135 dB for around 3G's that you can purchase, I don't think that many shopping on this page own one. So then using a 32 bit depth really doesn't even make sense and I rarely waste my storage space using above 96K when recording, but in my case I'm charging money for using it it. There is more to all of this and I'm using theoretical numbers and I'm not looking to write a scientific paper here, so spare me any arguments. When listening in a studio control room using expensive gear like at my recording facility, these numbers above 48k/24 really mean squat to this engineer. Factually, the average Joe listener can't hear the difference between a 256k MP3 file and a CD quality file so how can they hear the difference between a 48k vs a 96k file? So I'm saying it straight up, don't make this purchase because of the big numbers that it has above 48k/24 or you'll be thinking that it's 3 stars too. But earlier I mentioned the RCA/phono outputs that the Sanskrit uses without any headline numbers or boasting at all about them, and I think that even Joe might hear the difference with good or bad output amps, because they can make a pretty big difference in the audio reproduction. The End Here we have something really worthy of testing, the output amps. The Sanskrit output amps have a dynamic range of 113 dB,...Excellent, but not 144 dB like 24 bit. The rest of the specifications all look excellent also for an inexpensive converter. It uses the common unbalanced output of 2.0Vrms, with the same THD+N as the pro gear often used in recording your music and a signal to noise ratio of 115 dB and all the specs on the Sanskrit outputs are great numbers worthy of a headline. So I just listened to the Sanskrit quite a bit for over a week connected as you see in my photos. I connected it USB from one of my audio towers and to a SMSL Q5 to power a pair of Polk Monitor 40's, and if that sounds familiar it's because I purchased 3 pair of them on sale at $100 a pair. I also plugged the cable into a Win 10 laptop and just started listening, no hassle and trouble free. Unfortunately, as nice as the Q5 sounds with it's FFX output stage it has only a 100 dB dynamic range that doesn't bother me at all. I'll give studio tracks a second or third listen in this room, so it has some conditioning work done to it to reduce the worst of the acoustical problems so it's a real good average listening room and that's my whole design idea here. I normally have a Focusrite Saffire 6 audio interface connected for USB output from the tower to another Q5 connected to Alesis 6 inch two way passive studio monitors. Now I have a good place to check the tracks mastered in the studio, not high end or low end, just good and average. I have a few of these rooms to critique tracks in, well, maybe 8 of them all together. It also makes it a good place for comparing the Sanskrit to a good home recording DAC like the Saffire though. I'm able to switch USB audio outputs from the tower into each interface and both are connected to Q5's to listen to the same file and also physically plug into either amp from the same interface. Now I'm able to verify that the output amp on the SMSL sounds every bit as good as what the $250 Saffire uses, maybe better but my equipment in this room is making my judgement unreliable, but I'm not done testing yet. I was able to insert it into a nice recording system where it could be connected optically. This was inserted as two of 32 digital to analog playback tracks that go into a mixing console, where the other 30 are from very expensive studio equipment, several thousands of dollars worth of DACs all from my workstation. I could listen to any of them through two different sets of near fields and one pair of mid field monitors, besides a couple pair of headphones from the headphone out on this expensive console to make comparisons between the different DACs, while using the same file and input type at the same 96k/24 resolution. The Sanskrit can hold it's own in this demanding situation. 16 of these would make a fine 32 channel studio playback system for me and probably does in another companies pro gear, using some of the same electronics used within the Sanskrit. So after all that I've told you about buying this or any DAC, here's the bottom line on purchasing a Sanskrit of your own. I chose to purchase a better, longer, more noise free ferrite cable to connect this USB, but what it comes with, will work just fine for you, I wanted it longer. I always recommend using external DAC's because of all the electrical noise inside a computer's case, so just physically doing that will improve your sound quality. My own 20 something year old/young ears found 44.1k/16 to be just about perfect at reproducing an analog signal way back in the early 90's when much testing was going on against reel to reel and I was a part of it, and one time with 9 other engineers in a room trying to tell which was which, it's not easy giving up your $20k reel to reel except for the cost of 2 inch tape. So the hype of the larger conversion numbers doesn't work on me because you can't get better than perfect, which I consider 48k/24 to be. But all output stages in DAC's or audio interfaces aren't equal after the digital conversion takes place, and whatever the Sanskrit is using for analog output amps, is very nice sounding to my ears today. And yes, I'll pull it apart and see if I can tell you what it's using, I'll update. I've just been very busy. It only has a switch for it's three inputs and no separate power switch, you hold the Select switch to power it on a off and when I plugged it into a TV optically it just worked, but not all TV's are the same and you might have to change some settings on yours. Honestly, I mostly watch internet TV from bed, which then lulls me to sleep. I also plugged it into an Android 4.4 tablet using OTG cable and I needed a USB app to make it work, my Mac Mini is at another home, sorry guys, but I'll try it when I fly over there, but we know that it will work anyway with OS X 10.6 or newer. iOS 5.0 is listed as well as Linux. The Sanskrit is an excellent choice as an external converter from Win XP through 10, because it's analog outputs sound very nice, but it might not be much of an upgrade from another external converter. So any review claiming that this sounds and works great, is absolutely correct from my own testing. If I can't tell a difference from it and a $3000 piece of gear playing back in a studio control room, it sounds good. But the guy who wasn't impressed is right also. It's hard for a guy like me with years of training my ears to hear a real difference using a setup like the Q5 and Monitor 40's in a decent room playing uncompressed files tested against the Saffire. So when used in any lesser situation using just any file quality and heard with average ears, I predict nothing but shoulder shrugs about it from most people, and why not? I think that he would feel the same about This One, except that his savings would drop even lower, but to me the Avid is worth every penny. It's really about choosing a DAC for your new system and how much you should spend with them starting at under $50, I happen to have a $50 Creative 5.1 DAC that I use in stereo with near field studio monitors connected and this DAC will be an upgrade, although it's mostly used as a normal computer for me which includes video editing and watching TV and movies occasionally on it's Samsung 2560x1440 monitor. While it will be an upgrade in every sense, I believe the only real upgrade will be it's clean output amps from the conversion and they will improve the sound quality minimally, but having a choice today I would purchase the Sanskrit for the system instead. It's desktop small and good looking gear, it uses close to pro equivalent electronics and features a good noise free output from any of it's three inputs. It's a big jump up from what's on your computers motherboard, but can really shine when you're feeding it good signals for it to convert and using a good playback system to have the ability to hear it's improvement in audio reproduction, this is what I proved to myself in my studio. So if you're creating a new system that you'll need a DAC for, I'll recommend this one without hesitation. Just remember that in order for you to give it a 5 star review you need to understand how it's able to improve your audio reproduction and that there will still be times that you won't hear the difference. You will need a good amp and speakers and when plugging the Sanskrit into inexpensive equipment you can only imagine being impressed. Using it with a good headphone amp and headphones will be the easiest way to hear it's improvement that it's making, because it's just like the difference when using a really good CD player vs a cheap one which is an old argument that's over, it's not about 192k/32 like advertising wants you to think, it's about it using better than cheap output amps. My first reaction was that the Sanskrit is too expensive, but it tests out so well that I've softened on that. If you're looking for a step up from the cheap DAC's sold at 45 to $60, this is all you need at only a bit more cost, I know that I wouldn't spend any more on one for general use myself and that was my worry at just over a Benjamin. Above the price of this, you might start spending something like $250 per each 1% improvement in audio reproduction. If you do, you had better spend enough to least get some Low End Pro near field monitors or spend many thousands on the gear all setup in a quiet, conditioned room to ever hear that 5% better audio reproduction that you might achieve when listening with with trained ears. Unless you just want it to feed a good headphone amp that you already have, in which case you should like it a lot having such near perfect audio reproduction and the ability to hear that it is. You may have already figured this out, but also take into account that I'm more of an objective listener of audio reproduction. I like authentic audio reproduction, I don't like the gear or prices or what it does to the sound, in my world it shouldn't 'do' anything. It should accurately reproduce the waveform that came from the electronics before it in the signal path, outputting it to the next amp that will legitimately duplicate the signal at a higher power level to the speakers. That's why I have no descriptive words for you about how this sounds, it's good or nice or pleasing to listen to and rates about a 9 of 10 at doing it's job that it's designed to do. To Mark who wanted me to review the M6: This may not be the M6, but it's truly a great starting point for the headphone amp in the M6, and I'll bet that you'll like it if the price is okay with you. I originally didn't think that this Sanskrit would be worth it's cost, and now I'm a believer.
summary: Fascinating

reviewText: This is a decent DAC with multiple digital inputs. Build quality is very good with a hefty case for its size. Driver installation CD is provided but was hit and miss as far as it being usable. At the end, I did manage to get it installed and working both as a Windows Sound device and WASAPI. I performed a set of measurements on it and it lost out to the cheaper Behringer UMC-204HD but outperformed others. See my detailed review at ASR Forum.
summary: Pretty good quality although it does lose to a cheaper DAC

reviewText:
I am a quilter, and I use dozens of little things that I need to keep close at hand. I keep a magnetic board next to my sewing machine so I can reach out and grab what I'm looking for quickly, and I need strong magnets to hold my stuff. These rare earth magnets are extremely strong and are made with a lip so you can easily pick them up and replace them on your magnet board, refrigerator, or other metal surface.

They are really nice looking, too, made of smooth clear plastic that surrounds the magnet itself.  I love them--they're very useful.  Five stars.
summary: Strong and Good Looking Magnets

reviewText:
I should've bought this sooner!  I do have Steelex precision square as well as other tools including Mitsutoyo digital caliper but I was still off by 0.2 for the table saw.  It makes the process simpler and the magnet that's embedded on the unit (which is pretty strong by the way) allowed me to calibrate different surfaces.  And it does indeed work really well.  Storing is easy and of course being so small and using one AAA battery (using rechargeables as always) doesn't involve buying less commonly used battery.

So many uses I'm finding just going around measuring things and realizing how anal you can get because it's off by half a degree.  Obviously it won't always replace a long level or depending on the application but having this, traditional level as a laser level I think you're set as far as getting things nice and square every time.  For woodworking tools this is a must have!
summary: A must have for woodworkers and DIY'ers!

reviewText: Great filament! Prints come out smooth and accurate, but of course not transparent, more of skim milk white.  Very pleased.  I always vacuum seal my filament when not in use and keep the I little absorbent bag that comes with it.
summary: Great!

reviewText: I'm a 3M fan, but I couldn't find the 80 grit sandpaper made by 3M so I tried this brand.  The sandpaper is pretty good (I use it primarily for woodworking) but I do not like the adhesive; I find it difficult to remove the backing paper and prefer brands that don't use it.  Time is precious, and I feel like I waste a lot of time fumbling with that backing paper.
summary: Pretty good

reviewText:
FLIR - You got two strikes so far... Unit #1 - Horrible Back-light Bleeding.... Unit #2 - Dead Pixels!... Unit #3 is on it's way... Any bets on the next issue?!?!?

UNIT #1:
Right out of the box, upon power on, I see a big yellow pressure point on the display assembly. For the price you're paying, this is unacceptable!

At minimum, the display shouldn't have a big yellow pressure point in the top right corner. Basic movement of the product causes the display to discolor, which indicates either A) display quality issue B) design issue  or C) Assembly issue ( i.e. FLIR's factory that got torque happy when assembling).

Upon adjusting the the brightness, it's only worse. What makes matters worse - you rely on contrast/color with this tool, yet somehow this made it out of factory.

UPDATE: Unit #2 - Dead Pixels (a little bearable back-light bleeding. Dead/Defective Pixels Unacceptable!

- Defective Pixels galore....See pictures attached.
summary: 2 of 2 Units Defective - Display Issue (#1 back-light bleeding, #2 Multiple Dead Pixels) - Another example of lackluster QA!

reviewText:
This is an excellent compact thermal imaging camera! Right out of the box it was easy to start using and functions beautifully. We recently had out 1950s home insulated. While our home was well-built, back then they didn't put insulation in our walls and there wasn't much in the attic, so having that done to our home has made all the difference. Even then, this camera has helped make it obvious where our home is still lacking in spots and where it isn't.

Considering the price, I'm not surprised it works so well. I would expect an excellent product at this price point, and I feel FLIR delivers. Each time you power on, it takes a moment to calibrate. Then you're ready to start shooting and viewing. This would be a particularly excellent product for someone in the home building/insulating businesses and similar industries, obviously. We are a DIY family whenever we can manage, and don't mind getting our hands dirty with home projects. As we work on making our home more energy efficient and replacing the old windows, I expect this thermal camera to be a gem of a gadget to us. We've already noticed the difference in our home's energy efficiency since the insulation was done. In that way, I think this camera could be especially helpful to those focused on creating lock tight seals and weatherproofing.

It is about the size of your average smartphone, the outer plastic has good grip and seems like it could survive a drop (though I won't test that theory), and finally has a nice long strap so you can keep it convenient and safe. They seemed to put a lot of thought into this design. I'd definitely recommend it.
summary: Get a grip on this great gadget!

reviewText:
The FLIR C2 Compact Thermal Imaging Camera comes with a lanyard, USB cable, power supply/charger and plugs for the EU, UK, US, CN and Australian, USB memory stick with documentation, and printed getting started guide.

My camera came half charged and can be charged with the USB cable and a computer, or use the cable and your own adapter or one of the included plugs and power supply/charger. The included power supply/charger and the included plugs are not great quality and I couldn't even get the appropriate US plug end to go into the supply/charger. I charged mine from the USB cable and my computer.

The camera itself is thin and lightweight. It definitely doesn't feel like a $700 camera in your hands, although most cameras cant see heat so Ill let that slide.

When you first turn it on, it goes through a start up but is ready to use within a minute. After the first use, it starts up within seconds. The buttons are very straightforward, an on/off button and a large save button for saving your image as a picture.

I ordered the camera because we are a general construction company and many times we need to know where heat escaping or where plumbing is located. We have used and played with it to where we see what it is capable of doing and what it is not. This is the first camera of this type for us so we were new to it.

The camera easily picks up things that are outward. What I mean is if you open the cabinets, you can see the water pipes under the cabinets but you cannot see the pipes through the cabinets. The cabinet doors may look somewhat hotter where there are pipes behind them compared to ones where no pipes exist but its just a slight shading to it, no definite outlines. Because of this, you really have to train yourself in how to spot subtle differences in the camera screen. Where it really excels is the obvious light and dark areas around doors and windows, etc.

It was even eye-opening to see items like the cable box and coffee maker that were glowing bright orange in the screen even when it was not on. Remind me to unplug my appliances when not in use, I think my electric bill would really go down.

It did not show much if you are trying to spot heat spots from the outside of the home, the exterior construction is too thick. You pick up the heat that is all over the building from the sun and not individual things. It does have advantages but it is limited to what it shows. It just gives you the general area of heat many times and its up to you to find where the heat is coming from.

This camera can be really handy for contractors like us, homeowners who are wanting to spot where they might be losing heat, and for hunters, etc. who want to spot animals.
summary: Useful But It Does Have Limitations

reviewText:
Very easy to use system that works as advertised. This is a very nice FLIR camera for the money. FLIR cameras are expensive by nature, but this camera does everything that one would expect from an entry level FLIR camera.  I looked through the included USB thumb drive, where the instruction manual and countless other PDF resources can be found, but I didn't see anything useful besides the instructions and the warranty information:
If you register your camera within 60 days of making your purchase, youll get a 2 years camera warranty and a 10 years detector warranty for free!
Simply go to: http://www.flir.com/thg/warranty and enter in your contact information and serial number. Your serial number can be found under: settings>device settings>camera information or on a sticker next to the USB port on the camera. Enter in your devices serial number along with your account info to activate your extended warranty. I would highly recommend that you do this immediately before you forget!

NOTE: DO NOT POINT YOUR FLIR SYSTEM AT THE SUN! The sun can damage the sensors and cause permanent damage to your unit. Its a good idea to never point your FLIR system directly at a powerful energy source such as the sun or lasers.

Things I liked:
Easy button placement: The larger (nearly 2 camera shutter button/bar) is very easy to press in any orientation you happen to be holding the camera.

The profile: This camera resembles a very slim smart phone, so I don't think anyone will know this is a FLIR camera unless you told them. To the untrained eye, its just another smart phone.

Protective Lens Guard: Both the camera and FLIR sensor are located in a receded crevice that protects the cameras delicate optics. This means you can place the camera down lens first on a table, without worrying about scratching the optics.

What I didn't like:
For a $700 FLIR system, they really could have included a higher quality charging adapter. The included USB wall adapter was very cheaply made, and I was not able to get the AC power adapter working with the generic charger. However, I was able to charge my FLIR system with my cell phones 1A USB wall charger.

Ive included some pictures that I took with my new toy. You can actually see the heat from my footprint on the hardwood floor. The second picture is of my tea cup Yorkie. As you can see, his nose is cold
summary: Great FLIR System for the Price! Be sure to register your device for the extended warranty!

reviewText: Excellent I think. my first TPU and i used it on bowden set up and it worked amaizing
summary: Five Stars

reviewText:
I am not happy with the performance of this filament. I have three machines with bowden extruders. I have printed with flexible materials without problem for long time. I have extruders designed to use flexible.  I have successfully printed with Inland flex,  Hatchbox TPU and ninjaflex. So i like to say that i know what i am able to tweak and change to make things work.

Problem is this filament IS VERY FLEXIBLE. Too flexible if you ask me. Is so soft, that it bends and kinks too easy. The roll isn't even wound tightly. The filament has this wavy pattern to it, and as it goes thru the  bowden PTFE tubing, those kinks act as brakes and creates too much resistance.  Halfway thru the PTFE im unable to even feed it by hand  with all the resistance the filament creates.

Simply put, there should be a very clear disclaimer that this filament its technically intended to be used on direct drive setups. I have tested a new ptfe tube,  and various machines, and the resistance is so great because the filament kinks inside it.  Havent been able to successfully print, and now i am sitting on a roll that cant use.
summary: Dont bother if you are bowden.  Only works on direct drive extruders

reviewText: Prints with my Monoprice Select Mini 3D, also purchased here on Amazon.  I love the color and that I can print TPU with my sub $200 printer!  You will need to do the flex filamnet mod to the extruder and i'm printing to a glass bed but this is no different than you'd need to do on pretty much any other 3D Printer.  I'm currently printing at 227 degrees, 30mm/sec and 50% fan with combing enabled.
summary: Great TPU!

reviewText:
Updating this review -- up from ** to ***1/2.  I made a new extruder plate to try and prevent the binding issue, and I've been respooling the filament before printing.  This helps a lot and I was able to successfully print about 30g for an OpenRC tire.  it's still a lot more work to print, but once "dialed in" (which for me included printer mods and respooling filament) it does OK.

It's not as stretch as ninjaflex, but for tires it'll do fine.
---------
I don't care for this product.  It's very inexpensive, but so far I've got one good print (my own little benchmark for tuning this filament) and two failed ones, both because this jammed in my extruder.

I am using a modified Monoprice Select Mini, maybe a direct-feed extruder will be more generous.  I print great with Ninjaflex, which is softer / more flexible, but I think the problem is that this filament is jumbled onto the spool and comes out kinked.  The kinks seem to catch in the extruder, even when I've disabled any retraction.

I've been warned against using cheap filament, and this stuff definitely counts.  I was trying to print wheels for an RC car; they work well in PETG, but I was hoping this TPU would do better.  So far I can't successfully print a straight meter of this without a jam.

APART from the jamming issue, the stuff seems to be of reasonable quality.  It's definitely harder than the 85A ninjaflex, so I can't question "95A".  it seems about like a skateboard wheel.  It comes off very shiny, moreso than Ninjaflex.  Adhesion between layers is excellent, but I did some tuning.  It prints relatively cold, around 210, and sticks well enough to a glass bed.

If I could get this to print I think it'd do great in my application.
summary: Kinky, jams in the extruder; otherwise fine

reviewText:
Haven't used any of my prints long enough to have really tested the layer bonding but so far it seems fine. I've used Ninjatek TPU exclusively because it's extremely reliable, and in all the countless spools I've been through have never come across an anomaly like this (see photo). This would not feed into my extruder around 30 meters into my first spool but after checking the rest of it I'm sure it's just anomaly... I hope. Most likely I still check the entire length of future spools as well. I'm convinced this drip got on the line during manufacturing because it's shape suggests it was traveling away from the hot end against gravity.
All in all I'm not discouraged from this band. It's got it's perks in being cheaper and offering a wider color selection. I'll have to give it some time before adjusting my rating up or down.
summary: It's not Semiflex quality but your not paying Semiflex price either

reviewText: I don't normally leave reviews and when I have they have never been a low review. This is great product but it's knotted throughout the roll which requires refilling the entire spool. I've had knots before but nothing like this mess.
summary: This is great product but it's knotted throughout the roll which requires ...

reviewText:
After a while of playing with PLA and PETG, I decided to take the plunge with flexible filaments. Starting off, do NOT try to print this without support between the extruder and the hot end. I figured that since this was not full on flexible filament, it may do just fine if I printed it really slow. Unfortunately the filament started to bunch up between the extruder and hot end. I stayed nearby, just in case, so I caught it before it became a major issue.

After a little digging on the Robo forums, I discovered that a pen's ink tube could be used in a pinch. Some others suggested some small brass pipes, and others suggested PTFE tube. No matter which, I highly recommend having some method to fill the gap. I also printed quite slowly, and around 240C for the temperature.

I printed a small vase, which came out pretty nice. It wasn't amazing visually, but it was cool to have something that could be squashed, and spring back. It also took quite a while to print, compared to some of the other items that I printed. Really, that is what I expected, so it isn't that big an issue. I also printed a gasket, which worked out quite nicely.

Something you should keep in mind is that this is Semi-flex filament. This is not stretchy, it simply is flexible. Which definitely has its uses. It did just what I wanted it to do. After trying this out, I am looking forward to trying fully flexible filament.

Why didn't I give 5 stars? Well, I can't say that I love this filament. I definitely like it, and will keep using it. If you are looking to try semi-flex, then I highly recommend getting this filament. I just don't currently plan to use it too much, since it is a bit of a hassle to use it right now. The ink tube works, but I would really like to upgrade my printer so that it can use this filament without any trouble.
If you want to try it, then research ways to make it play nice with your printer. Well, unless you already have a printer that can use this already. Either way, if you can, I would recommend trying this filament.

A little extra Info, I use a Robo 3D R1+. It can be made able to use this filament, it just requires minor modifications. If you find a more permanent solution, let me know. :-)
summary: it may do just fine if I printed it really slow

reviewText:
Finally got around to printing this with my Rostock Max V2. I am running a hanging extruder and employed Guanu's mod to that the filament wouldnt bunch up at the drive gear.

My first test print went very well. I printed a lego with supports. There was some stringing, which is to be expected, but not an excessive amount. I ran the default profile for Ninjaflex in the SeeMeCNC flavor of MatterControl. The only thing I changed was filament diameter. I printed at 20mm/s, but will be trying faster speeds later. Overall I'm quite satisfied with this filament, though it's unclear to me whether this is TPU or TPE.
summary: Printed well on my modified Rostock Max V2!

reviewText:
Title of item is "SainSmart Flexible TPU 3D Printers Filament, 1.75mm,1kg/2.2lbs (Yellow)".  I clearly see "1kg" in that title.  Does anyone think to themselves "awesome, I am getting a .2 kg spool!".  Very misleading.  It is industry standard to label items with the weight of the product you are buying, not the weight of the entire package including packaging, etc.  I am making this a one star review to call this out in hopes that people look at it and determine can you trust someone you clearly cant trust.  Also, one other issue with this filament is that the diameter is very inconsistent.  I have typically found at least 50-100 feet of unusable filament on every roll I have purchased (diameter of less than 1.5mm).  The normal diameter is about 1.65mm and I have never measured it to be over 1.7mm.  So here again the title is incorrect.  Otherwise, the quality of prints when you have consistent diameter is great.
So in summary:
Title of listing - 1kg, what you get is .8kg
Typical diameter of filament is 1.65 to 1.7mm
Inconsistent diameter - Often run into spots where it will drop below 1.5mm and as low as 1.1mm. Usually have to trash 50-100 feet per roll as it simply stops feeding.  Of course you only have 30 days to discover this and unless you are a commercial printer you may not discover soon enough to get a replacement.
Quality of prints - Great provided you don't hit a thin spot in the filament.
If you cant live with the limitations you may want to consider other brands.
summary: Note the issues before purchasing
