reviewText:
I'm really glad there's competition in the marketplace because now you can get a good flexible filament at a reasonable price. This stuff works just like the other *flex materials and prints very nicely.

Of note - If you are using a PEI bed, you will have serious overadhesion. This stuff sticks like it's part of the bed. You actually have to do the opposite of every other filament and put something in between the bed and the print to make it *easier* to get the stuff off. I've been using a spray on cooking oil. Spray the bed and wipe it down with a paper towel so that you have a thin layer of oil coating your PEI. Your print will peel off without a nightmare of scraping or damage to the bed. Cleaning the oil off so that all your other prints don't slip off is another issue altogether. :-)

I bought the blue and gray versions on this filament. The blue is mostly transparent and has a jelly like look when done. The Gray is gray. Both are pretty cool. Like with all the other flexy filaments, you have to print slow. 30mm/s or slower. But the results are good.

Worth it.
summary: The Stuff Works.

reviewText: I got this to make medals for student achievements. While it's certainly not metallic, it gets close enough to give the impression. It is the best of the brass/bronze colors I've tried so far. The print was a little more difficult than some filaments I've used - I may need to tweak the settings a bit. But I didn't have any real problems, just a little more seepage than usual.
summary: Pretty good bronze color for medals, statues, etc.

reviewText: Does not work. Filled test tube up with store bought wine and it reads 0. I will return and buy something different.
summary: Does not work.

reviewText: I'm a lot more impressed with this thing than I had been just from looking at the picture.  I thought it was going to be just some overpriced plastic, but the reality is, it's a precision tool with a lot of heft to it.  It won't take your fiber down to the glass, but it gets through just about any size jacket super easy without damaging the cladding.  Glad to have this.
summary: Precision

reviewText: Wonderfully easy to install and use...at a great price too! No instructions came with it, but there are only two wires red (+) & black (-), and a temp probe. To make it read Fahrenheit, simply remove the little jumper on the back. I installed this on my Electric Brew in a Bag/Basket (EBIAB) controller and used the probe to monitor the mash temperature. It was always within 1F of my ThermoWorks DOT Professional Probe Style Alarm Thermometer with Pro-Series High Temp probe (White), so I know it's accurate. If I could do one thing to make this better, it would be to increase the probe cable length by one foot.
summary: Love it!

reviewText: I'm pretty happy with this indicator for the price. The base is solid and the magnet strong enough for my purposes. The indicator is made from metal and seems to be descent quality. I can't comment on the point set. The adjustments are a bit cheap but with a little jimmy rigging I think they will work just fine.
summary: I'm pretty happy with this indicator for the price

reviewText:
I have made a few prints with the purple Sienoc PLA 1.75mm using my Monoprice Select Mini V2 and they have turned out fantastic! Carefully packaged in sealed plastic with a manufacture information so you know that it's not old and moldy. I found the filament to print the best at 205 degrees and bed temperature at 60 degrees. (That is also using the stock bed covering) I recommend and give it 2 thumbs up!

*Update on Jan. 8th, 2018:
Been using the filament more for making some RC parts and am finding that a flows best at 185 then the 205. Sticking good to the stock bed (Monoprice Select Mini V2) at 50. Am just over half way through the roll and have had a few prints mess up but I think it was from the Slicer hic ups more than the printer or filament...
summary: This filament works great with the Monoprice Select Mini V2

reviewText: Works great but at higher temps than I normally use for PLA.  Took a chance on this filament.  One of my kids asked for a cat and wanted it in purple. :)  Figured I'd give this one a try with it being so cheap.  Turned out great after running a temp tower to figure out the optimal temp.  I've uploaded the print which was done at 205C, 50mm/s, .2 layer height, 150% of original size.
summary: Works great but at higher temps than I normally use for PLA.

reviewText:
As far as price and expectations go, I'm satisfied. It's flexible and takes a pretty decent sharp bend without kinking.
I'm having a strange issue with it turning my fuel orange, and leaving behind a non-volatile residue.
conditions:
Plastic tank (IMS motorcycle tank)
Aluminum Petcocks
Inline filter kept turning orange, but flushed out clear. Fuel delivered from the petcock directly is clear. I placed a two inch piece in clear gas, and in one week it looked like orange cool-aid. That indicates to me it's got to be the line. Attached a picture.
summary: Turning my fuel orange

reviewText:
I own more than a few consumer 3D printers so I know a good value when I see one.  I just received this model and I am very pleased with the build quality and ease of use.  The internal frame is extruded aluminum rail and the unit is sturdy and quiet when building.  It has an SD card slot for building directly from files, and As for the first reviewer, it looks like the Z height was not adjusted properly at the factory - mine wasn't either.  The starting position was too close to the build plate causing a jammed extruder.  So I'd highly recommend you check this first - as it is, the Z height offset can be set but the menu doesn't provide a way to move the Z axis to the bed to check the gap. It was obvious from the start that it was too low - the painters tape was getting ripped off the glass!  So I stopped the print and immediately raised the offset - it took two tries, but I finally got it working.  BTW my set at the factory offset was .9mm but the working number for mine was 2.2mm.  Also, mine needed a firmware update fresh out of the box.

It took no more than 15 minutes from box to first print, even given the Z offset problem.  The filament autoloading process was easy.  The extruder does have an all-metal hot end, so while it could do ABS the bed is not heated.  Perhaps a future model will add these things, but at $349 this is an exceptional unit for a teenager or student looking to own their first machine and get in to 3D printing.  The client software, while better than when first released with the DaVinci 1.0, is still kinda ugly and slow for slicing.  It does work and there are alternatives, though they are not free.

So why not 5 stars?  Well, I'd like to see a heated bed even in this size.  I wish the client software would be more developed and not so utilitarian.  And the Z offset was clearly wrong out of the box.  Even so, these are tolerable for the price.

A more complete review will appear on my additive manufacturing blog soon at www.renaissance-engineer.net
summary: Great value in a PLA-only machine!

reviewText:
I considered cheaper units before purchasing this unit. I actually bought a cheaper unit, canceled the order and purchased this as a Christmas gift instead. This unit is very quality engineered and built. Simple and I mean super easy to setup even for novices and you can be printed in minutes.

It includes everything you need, including sd card, spatula l, tray tape, cleaner. And all the small details. All this stuff adds up. Ive printed large and small projects.

It is super quiet. It has a light inside. The display and menu controls on the unit has more options than any other brands and makes things super easy

It self adjusts for x y and z axis. Loading the filament is super easy. The box itself of the unit is self enclosed and looks nice on any table or shelf. There is an sd card slot on the unit or it can be connected to a pc

The software it comes with will automatically scribble some lines before starting any project so the start will not be ruined by improperly heated material. The software will build supports when needed.

The unit came well packaged in a large box, and styrofoam, so there was no damage from shipping. It has an high quality ac to dc converter and an usb to pc cable is also included

Nothing has shifted or failed yet. It takes projects in stl or create your own.
summary: Easy to set up. High quality. For novices or pros.

reviewText:
Since this is probably the cheapest printer around I wasn't expecting a lot from it, the reviews on amazon also weren't that good, but I still bought it.
I've been printing a lot of stuff on it, it does has a learning curve but also any other 3D printer around, the quality of this printer is amazing and it doesn't feel cheap at all.
The video tutorials on XYZprinting website are very helpful.
Thanks XYZprinting for making 3D printing easy and affordable.
summary: Amazing and affordable 3D printer

reviewText: I like it, but.... I ordered this 3D printer in and it arrived a couple of days later. This has been the 2nd 3D printer that I have ordered through Amazon in the last couple of months. My goal is to produce some toys for my grandchildren for Christmas. The 1st 3D printer came as a RepRap kit which I assembled. However, I am still trying to get it to work. Hence, I ordered the XYZ Printer Junior. I will simply describe the chain of events, since I am sure that many people go through exactly the same process. I un-boxed the XYZ Junior and had it printing a couple of hours later. A few minutes after that, I had my 1st successful 3D print. The 2nd 3D print was printed overnight and took 13 hours to print. I'll get back to those prints in a minute. The instructions say to connect to your computer and install the software, which is on a micro-SD card, which comes with an adapter for a full size SD card. This card should work in most computers. I found it best to copy the software onto my hard drive and install the software from there. My security software blocked it from installing from the memory card. There are only versions of the XYZ software for Windows and the MAC. But not for Linux operating system. (I have one computer that uses Mint Linux.) I installed the software on a Netbook which is using Windows 7, but could not get the software to run successfully on that computer. The netbook has limited memory and has a slower clock speed. So I installed the software on my main full-size notebook computer, which has expanded memory and an expanded hard drive. I connected the printer to my main computer and the software installed fine on it. At least, it did up to the point where it downloaded an updated version of itself. In updating, it also updated the firmware of the printer. My security software objected and the Update froze up. I later updated the software on my computer without the printer attached. The printer seems to work fine afterwards. The software gives you the option of watching demonstration videos online. Regardless of having watched them before, it's a good idea to watch them with the printer in front of you and going through the motions with the videos. I had previously watched the videos, and I still learned some new things while watching the videos with the printer in front of me. One thing that caught my attention was the amount of filament that you get with each spool. I compared the filament spools for this printer with the spools my other 3d Printer (The one that I have not gotten to work yet) and the special filament spools for the XYZ Printer Junior are a lot smaller. The Junior only uses PLA filaments. OK. Now I made 2 prints with the Junior. I simply downloaded a couple of objects from the Thingiverse.com website, and ran them through the XYZ software. Then saved them to a memory card in the XYZ file format. After that, I placed the memory card in the XYZ Printer and choose which one to print out. The printer does the rest. Nice and neat. The 1st was the penguin in the photos. Not as detailed as I expected, but it was also a lot smaller then I expected. The 2nd item was the mug. It turned out to be a lot larger then I expected. And I ran into an unexpected problem with using the mug afterwards. I filled it with a carbonated drink and let it sit on my table for about an hour. After awhile, I noticed that the color of the liquid drink was spreading into the color of the mug. The mug had been printed with a translucent white. As I watched, I realized that the liquid was seeping into the cell structure of the mug and the bottom was becoming moist. It also seemed as if the plastic was softening up. This may relate to the nature of the PLA plastic, I don't know. And this problem could probably be cured with some sort of coating. Again, I don't know. Final: This printer was pleasure to setup and use, compared to the kit printer that I had previously purchased. But the XYZ Junior is going to cost far more to use on a day-by-day bases. Plus the issue of the plastic material becoming mildly porous has me questioning the idea behind this technology. All in all, this printer is easy to setup and start printing with, and is fine for casual printing. Anyone should be able to set this printer up and be printing 3D objects shortly after opening the box. But you need a different printer if you plan on printing things every day. Update Nov. 11, 2015 I've had the printer for a few days. I can honestly say that it's a please to use. Run your object .sti file through the XYZ software, save the resulting .3w file format to a memory card, put the card in the printer and print it out. But it's no speed demon. I am uploading a photo of a coaster that I printed out. Each coaster too nearly 3 hours to print. I printed out a set of them. It's easy to get carried away in printing things with it. I am also uploading a photo of one of the coasters I sitting under one of my mugs to show comparative size. I either downloaded the sti file from the XYZ gallery or thingiverse.com. Not sure which location that the file came from. Both have an extensive galleries of files. When printing things. it's good to be around the printer when it is finishing up printing your object. The LCD shows a countdown until the object being printed is completed. If you remove the item just after it is finished, then you object is easy to remove from the base. But if you wait awhile until it cools down, then it becomes very difficult to remove your printed project from the glass plate. (I discovered this the hard way when I let it print a project over night. I figured that it would be ready for me when I woke up in the morning. It was, but I had to remove the paper from the glass to get it off without breaking the glass.) Speaking of the glass base plate. It is covered with a peel-&-stick paper from XYZ. It is also expensive, running about $1 per sheet. 3rd parties sell similar peel-&-stick paper for about the same price. The paper can be reused for additional projects up until you removed it from the glass or it becomes torn. I plan on experimenting with alternatives. The paper appears to simply be a special sized sheet of masking tape. One other thing to watch out for. The vents to this printer are on the back. If you are like me and planning on setting up the printer up on a cabinet located against the wall, then you will have to leave some room between the printer cabinet and the wall so that air can flow through the cabinet. (I am also uploading a photo of the vents on the back of it.) No doubt about it, this thing is addictive. I am finding all kinds of things fir it to print. But this printer could also end up being expensive too. Update December 23, 2015 The printer has not been working for about 3 weeks now. Suddenly the prints started to fail. After a lot of time trying to check it out, it seems that heating element was no longer getting hot enough. This resulted in a clogged nozzle and barrel. Nor would filament go through the nozzle afterwards. After multiple phone calls and messages with customer support, (with Customer Support saying that parts were on the way to me, then amending that to say that the parts were not on the way) it is starting to look as if my printer will be out of commission for 2 months, at the earliest. And that is only if they actually send me a replacement part. (Something that I am skeptical about now.) So I have a 1 star opinion of the XYZ Printing Customer Support right now. My opinion has dropped from 5 stars to 1 star. Update: October 19, 2016 I sent the bad Print Head in to XYA for repairs on Dec 28th. About 6 weeks after sending in the bad print head, XYZ sent me a new replacement print head. The printer started working fine again, for awhile. 2 months after receiving the new print head, I started running into issues with the printer printing only part of an object, then stopping the filament feed. I made sure the bed/nozzle clearances were correct. I took the print head apart and cleaned the nozzle completely. I made sure that the feeding throat was clean. And I finally tried feeding filament through without any connection to the print head. Here I found out that filament was not even feeding filament through the tube. I then pulled the extruder off and replaced the filament extruder motor. This did not help. XYZ asked me to ship the printer back to them for repair, at my own expense. The local UPS store quoted me $189 for boxing, packing, and shipping. At this point, the XYZ Jr. went into the closet and was replaced with a Wanhao I3 3D printer. I haven't had any problems with the Wanhao printer. Bottom line, I received about 3 months of usage out of the XYZ Jr. printer. After that, it became an expensive paperweight.
summary: My opinion has dropped from 5 stars to 1 stars due to customer support. Printer is worthless after a couple of months.

reviewText: I knew a 3d printer that worked right out of the box was too good to be true, especially with it being so inexpensive.  The printer arrived with a multitude of problems that I have been working with their support staff to fix. The main problem is that the extruder just stops working a quarter of the way into the print. I didn't expect this printer to do wonders, but I did expect it to work. The support has been alright.  Although, It has been over a week of the issue not being fixed and no offer of replacement or refund. I am extremely disappointed with this product.
summary: 350 dollars well wasted

reviewText:
Have used this inside a wall to find a burst pipe and separately to identify the cause of storm drain blockage.  First, on my Dell laptop, when I plug this in, Dell camera software launches.  The camera also comes with software, either software is fine.  For the burst pipe, we only had to make a small hole in the wall, 5/8" diameter and fish the camera through.  The image of the break, rather than a separated pipe was enough for the insurance adjuster to take over.  In that case, the camera worked without building any guiding attachments.

In the case of the drain pipe, just taping the camera to the fish tape didn't work well so I cut a pop bottle and mounted the camera in the center (see picture posted) and pushed it into the pipe.  The lights in the camera are sufficient and the image on the laptop screen is sharp enough.

It is a USB camera so you need your own viewing device.  The cable doesn't support the camera.  The one I have has been under water and worked fine, though I will follow another reviewers suggestion and apply silicone sealant front and back.

Great bargain.
summary: Amazing Price, Great Value

reviewText:
Others say it won't work with Vista... but my Media Center PC running Windoze Vista recognized it immediately. Didn't have to install any drivers or any software. Roxio recognized the camera and would record from it. Windoze seems not to know it's there... so I just copied the executable AMCAP.EXE from the mini-CD and ran it. Done (no need to install, it just runs). Can see real-time preview in a stretchable window, can record to AVI disk file, simple and no hassle. Haven't found a way to store snapshots yet, but I have a movie player that can do that so I just record and capture stills later.

Video quality is just fine for a $34 item.... if there is plenty of light. The shutter speed is slow so the image blurs if there is movement. It's not a multi-megapixel point-and-shoot, and the image can be a bit hazy due to the plastic protective cover, but there's a menu in the viewer to adjust brightness/contrast/white balance, etc. It probably won't last very long and the plastic cover will probably scratch, but if I use it 2 or 3 times I figure I've gotten my money's worth.

The same product seems to come with many different length cables. Cables longer than this one apparently have a repeater box which means they won't thread through small pipes and that box isn't waterproof. This one has a brightness wheel on the USB connector and nothing but cable to the camera.

UPDATE 1: Just had exactly the same experince on a Windoze 7 laptop. Plug it in, let Windoze install drivers, copy software from the mini-CD, run the software without installing. The mini-CD software can also access the laptop's built-in webcam.

UPDATE 2: It survived being pushed down a driveway drain pipe with standing water, taped to a tape-style snake, but to my dismay I discovered that cranking up the LEDs causes reflection inside the plastic cover. Bad reflections! If there's really no light at all where you're using it, your range of site is extremely limited because the internal reflections wash out the image unless you turn the brightness down on the LEDs. This took it from 5 stars (cheap but you get what you pay for) to 4 stars (cheap and you need external lighting).
summary: cheap but worth the money! (needs external light source)

reviewText: This is a great unit to get ! And it has a great forum and you get answers but it takes a day later as they are on the other side of the planet and reverse hours there . . .  .Now that I have it up and running I wil have to learn a few Graphic Drawing programs to make the things I want for me and then off to the races to make things for sale . .
summary: Good unit to get

reviewText:
First off the product is excellent  in workmanship, and the service is excellent  . If you have a problem you can go on line to chat with an live Rep.. They are so willing and able to help you with anything you have with the Geeetech I3 Pro C  Printer.
The build went flawlessly with the exception of a few typo's like the wrong size bolt / nut but was easily fix in studying the problem a little. The instructions were easy to follow and were fairly clear to understand. The only problem I had was the placement of two cables that came from the LCD / Controller both cables are identical in every way , the instructions was clear as to were they were to go on the mother board but not clear were they came from on the LCD Controller. After chatting live with a Rep. the matter was resolved very quickly. Turns out it did not matter were they were to go, it would of worked ether way, but I did not know this and was not going to take a chance on doing something that could damage the product. So I investigated it in the material that I had at my disposal as to no avail. Went to live chat on line and bam, the problem was resolved.  OH forgot to add the printer arrived 15 days earlier than the delivery window.
I will update this review when I do the calibration and the software installs. Till then so far this has got to be the best printer for my money.
Well it's been 20 days and I have got to say that it has been a learning experience and I am glad I did it. The drivers and software installed with out any troubles at all. I have Windows 7 on a Dell laptop. After leveling the heat-bed and setting the home positions for X,Y,Z, my first print went without any problems except for the glass was not clean enough ( my fault ) and the print started to come up off the bed, so I had to abort. Then I had put down some blue painters  tape on the glass and problem solved. I have since then been printing anything and everything. Like I had said earlier and I will say it again " this has got to be the best printer for my money " ,So I had to get a second one. Hope this review helps you in making your decision your next 3D printer.
summary: First off the product is excellent in workmanship and the service is great!!!

reviewText: Used to hook up patio lights. Those hooks are pretty strong and not easy to bend. Would say good quality. Insert it the direction you want to face the open, after screwing fully in it will face same direction. Use a screw driver horizontal (like the cable in the picture) through the hook and turn if screwing by hands get to difficult.
summary: Good quality hooks

reviewText:
Item in image is not what I received.
It comes in a big spool, not like normal Taulman fillament that comes in small spool.

It is a problem because I have a custom spool holder that keeps moisture out, so now I have to make another that fits the large one...
Also labels look cheap, not like other Taulman filament I have bought.

On the picture you can see on the top the two new spools, and on the bottom an old one I have laying around
summary: Now I have to make new spool enclosure

reviewText: in my short 4 print experience, this is just epic filament.  As easy to print as PLA, very strong, extrudes really well I suppose due to the strength.  It doesn't grind off, when other filaments would have sections in between the drive gear teeth separate this is so strong they stay attached and keep pushing the filament, so higher retraction speeds and extrusion speeds are possible for my machine.  It's just 'fun' to print with and brings joy of great quality prints, for a DIY printer that is crucial to show what the machine is capable of and what is due to the filament quality.  This filament made me feel so good about my machine's abilities, I honestly love it.  Buying more, much more.  Wish it came in a variety of colors it's all I want to use.  It's cheaper if you ask me, to buy filament you know works nearly every time versus less expensive by weight but fails to print and makes one wonder about their printer's mechanics and firmware.
summary: Will purchase again, for sure!

reviewText:
My first impression is not favorable.

It will hook up to the camera just fine but only without a case. If you have a case you will have to get an extension for another $20. FLIR could have done a much better design by having an extended lightning connector with an adjustable bracket to keep the camera tight up against the phone. This was very disappointing. Until I get the adapter, which is very small and likely to get lost and cost even more money to replace, I have to take the case off my phone every time. FLIR could have added on an extension with an tether to keep the extension from getting lost. It's clear that the engineers tested this in a lab and not in the real world. Engineers need to get out more often and experience real life.

I realize that a longer connector is subject to damage from having more leverage on it but they could have come up with a much better solution that they way it is. An extension will cause the same damage and leverage. To me, it might have been better to use the stereo plug but that may have not had enough ports to make this work. Or to use both ports that would have given it more stability.

The images are marginal even in room light. Resolution is very low and while it does okay for some situations it will not work well in the dark. That is a huge problem because to get accurate images in some cases there can't be any other IR radiation. I took some images of my house when it was pitch black and the image was so bad that it was almost unusable. It was just a blur around warmer spots.

If one were to take an image of a house, to look for heat escaping, in the sun it would show lots of heat escaping from the roof. That's because the sun is heating up the roof and in reality there may be very little heat escaping from the roof.

It did show some areas were the contractor didn't insulate a few areas and he will be coming back to fix that problem on his dime. I am also calling the city to complain about the inspector because he signed it off that the insulation was installed and installed correctly. So that is a benefit.

I did find several areas that I need to add a few pipes for my floor heating which is why I got this in the first place. The spacing between pipes is too much and I will add a third pipe to get more consistency in floor temperatures.

I am struggling to decide if I should keep this or not. The connector issue is a real deal killer for me. I can't believe that the engineers/designers actually let this get out on the market. It really shows some bad decisions along the way. Even a Bluetooth connection would have been a better option.
summary: Read this carefully before buying it.

reviewText:
This is a great reading or work lamp. I intend on using it for hobbies so I can see better when working with smaller items. The flexible head allows you to point the light in any direction. You can hold down the power button while it is dimming and then release it when you are at the brightness level you want.  At its brightest setting, the light is quite bright and pretty much pure white in color. Assembly was easy and took about 5 minutes or so.

(Sample provided for testing.)
summary: Bright white light, dimmable, and a sturdy base help make this a great lamp

reviewText:
I have a Monoprice Maker Select 3D which is a rebranded Wanhao Duplicator i3. I was having a very difficult time printing the purple and black Hatchbox PETG with the factory nozzle, so I decided to upgrade the Swiss-Micro MK10 all-metal hotend because the PTFE tubing in the factory nozzle is prone to failure.

In any event, once I switched to the new all-metal hotend I put this filament in to print a test Marvin. It came out fantastic. It's the first PETG Marvin I've printed with no globbing, no stringing, no issues. It's difficult filament to photograph, but I've included a couple pictures of the Marvin as well as a larger model I made (Any Final Fantasy X fans?).

With my particular printer with this particular hotend, I found the following settings to produce great results:

.4mm nozzle
.2mm layer height
.8mm wall thickness
0-100% density (the big piece has no infill, I printed thumbwheels at 100%) has been great.
30mm/sec print speed
240C nozzle temp
70C bed temp
2mm retraction at 50mm/sec
30% cooling (this is important)

Overall, cooling was a huge factor. No cooling and PETG just oozes everywhere. Too much cooling and it has poor layer adhesion.

I was most impressed with the bridging capabilities. I was able to print a 5cm bridge with no noticeable sagging. I was completely surprised as I was sure it was going to fail at that part of my print.

Overall, 3D Solutech is my favorite PETG to use. I'm not crazy about everything I print being in this see through blue that sparkles but for things that are going to be lit up, it's going to be fantastic.

5/5, will be buying more soon.
summary: The most consistent PETG I have used so far.

reviewText: This has been one of the best PETG filament brands I've printed with. The filament density has been great and not changing. No clogs, hardly any moisture changes. It prints great, you can see the inside wall fill patterns.
summary: Great quality filament.

reviewText: I simply love this PETG. I have never printed in anything but PLA until today. I received the spool today and went to printing. I am using a CR10 with a Micro Swiss hotend. Wow, it is printing fantastic. I am printing it at 200 and 50mm speed. The color and shine to it are amazing, I couldn't be happier with my purchase and will certainly print more of Solutech's filament. I took some sample measurements of the spool and it was 1.74 with a very minor variance. I have always heard PETG can be very stringy and somewhat difficult to dial in, but either I hit it lucky or it is just that good. No issues what so ever on my first print. It is still printing can't wait until it's done. I would definitely recommend this filament. I am printing a spiral vase in the photo.
summary: Great Stuff

reviewText:
I finally got a working printer which can use PETG. So, I ordered this for my new Wanhao i3 V2.1. It works great!
I am still dialing in the settings for a perfect print. But I am not having any problems with the filament.
A plus is that it is made here in the USA.
summary: USA PETG filament works great in WanHao i3 printer with stock nozzle.

reviewText:
These bags are great for holding standard-size sewing patterns (Butterick, McCalls, Simplicity).  The larger ones (Vogue & some costume patterns) must be folded a little to get them to fit.  I docked a star because the bags are a little hard to open the first time.  The zip seal is pretty tight, and it's easy to tear the top above the zipper.

A note on the picture: I punched the holes to help them compress better when I put my patterns in their storage case.  The bags did NOT have holes in them when they arrived.

My only other problem with this order has nothing to do with the product itself.  Amazon shipped the bundle of bags in one of their shrink-wrapped packages, which (of course) requires melting the plastic shrink packaging using heat.  Umm... Hello?  Amazon?  YOU MELT THE PRODUCT PACKAGING THEM THIS WAY.  Fortunately for me, only the bag containing the bags was melted beyond use.  The bags themselves are fine, so I just relocated them to a larger ziplock for storage.
summary: Good product, but Amazon needs to learn how to pack it for shipping

reviewText: I bought this in August and has no problems with this device what so ever. I use it often to check the temps of my oils while making homemade soap. I've checked this against the old fashioned glass thermometers and this one is spot on temps. I'm still using the same batteries that came with the unit. It fits into my hand nicely and it has small ridges in the handle so you have no slip from your hands when your oils has slopped on them.  I would highly recommend this unit. It's well worth the money invested at a reasonable price when comparing to other devices. This one is fantastic.
summary: Five Stars all the way!

reviewText:
Ok before I continue, please note my review is for PLA filament only, and this trick applies to all printers that can fit these sheets (i.e. Flashforge Dreamer, Qidi, etc.), not just the Dremel Idea Builder. Most of you are aware that PLA has a hard time sticking on bare 3D print beds; be it may aluminum, acrylic, glass, etc. What happens is that somewhere along the printing process, the objects either warp or slide off completely, causing a failed or ugly result. Many solutions surfaced over time to attempt at solving this, including using 3M painters tape / sheets, heated beds, slurries, glues, etc., and of course these Dremel Build Sheets.

Now by themselves, these sheets are just OK. A brand new sheet sticks well like 3M painter's tape, but unlike the 3M tape, these sheets last for about 20 to 30 large prints instead of 1 or 2 prints with the 3M tape. After that, the prints start warping or sliding off, and it's time to change the sheet. Right now you might be wondering, "how on earth is this worth $30?" I'll get there, please read on...

So the trick is that before each print, you must level your print bed, and then rub 2-3 thin coats of Elmer's School Glue Stick on the surface of the Dremel Build Sheet (until it's pale white). Now I don't know what the chemistry is behind this, but something amazing happens... Not only do the prints stick 100% to the surface with perfectly straight non-warped results, but you can do this again and again and again using the same sheet! I printed out big 5x5" objects with the Dremel Idea Builder printer OVER 200 TIMES using the SAME SHEET! All you have to do is wash off the glue after every print, and repeat the process. Not even my heated bed Robo3D printer gave me this kind of performance; not even close! Note, you'll need to use some kind of thin spatula, or whack your object on a hard surface, because these babies will stick like a weld if you use this trick!

So TL;DR - The trick is before every print, level your bed and then apply 2-3 coats of Elmer's School Glue Stick on the Dremel Build Sheet; Wash off the glue after each print; repeat; Will last for 100s of prints.
summary: BETTER than "heated beds" for PLA prints, MUCH CHEAPER than 3M painters tape! Please Read!

reviewText:
I was going to wait a bit until I posted my opinion of the PolyMax PLA but as I am printing with it now for the second time, this stuff is really worth the extra cost.  It is every bit as good as advertised and makes printing with my 3d printer an absolute dream.  I have to say that there is no doubt I will be buying more of this stuff in the future. My first attempt at printing with generic PLA was truly abysmal; I didn't figure at the time that I'd ever try printing with PLA again unless it was one of the custom PLA's.  After using PolyMax, I have yet to find anything that prints as great as this stuff.  Layer adhesion is incredible and the finished look is phenomenal.  I don't know how they've managed to get this stuff so strong but frankly I don't care.

Way to go Polymaker!!
summary: It just keeps printing, and printing and printing.

reviewText:
I am a very experienced Thermographer. I've been handling these tools just about as they hit the markets in the 1980's in the Fire department when Scott came out with a bully black and white version.
I've have personally owned 2 other IR cameras and Extech i5 and currently own a Flir Bcam 40.
 I review items as I work or have used them for some time. So this review comes with over 25 years of real world use.
 I have a loaded a few pictures to show this small Ir-camera is well worth the $$.
It does have some draw backs but the cost most definitely out ways the draw backs.
 Good; Cost, size for ease of storage or to carry around.  Easy set up, started right away and ease to change settings.
Poor points; App fails and crashes frequently, usb pin length. usb orientation.
Major Bad point; Battery goes dead. You will need a supplemental back up battery.
summary: Works just a little better than my $3800 Flir Bcam Hand held.

reviewText:
I use this syringe to feed my cat LINK CATSURE. (Liver failure causing him not to want to eat) It is pretty good for feeding 50ml at a time. I am still able to push the plunger down with my thumb at 50-60ml. Feeding him enough of the liquid with a smaller syringe takes a long time and this allows me to do it all in one shot and make the experience less stressful overall.

The syringe end is also large enough to fit a mildly watered down pate. So it allows me to feed him more solid food as well so that he gets the nutrients he needs to help combat his liver issues.

The plunger will move around a bit from side to side if it is drawn out fully to 150ml. I wish the fit was just a little bit tighter.

Dimensions can be seen in the photos I have uploaded.

Included is the syringe and around 3 ft of plastic tubing (the type you would see on IV's)

Pros:
*Cheap
*Holds more liquid than smaller syringes. Allows me to feed more without having the plunger too high to reach one-handed

Cons:
*Plunger fit is a tad loose (-3/4 star)

Additional Considerations:
100ml or 75ml syringes may also do the job when it comes to giving 30-50ml at a time.

Overall: 4.25/5 stars (>=.5 rounds up, <.5 rounds down) => 4 stars

If you have any further questions regarding the product in my review please leave a comment below and I will get back to you as soon as possible.
summary: A good syringe for feeding sick cat liquid food.

reviewText:
So far this is my favorite filament for my Da Vinci Junior. There's only a limited number of colors available for the Jr right now (black, natural, yellow and green), and I'm liking the results I get with the green the best so far. My spool loaded just fine and prints well. Note that each of these spools of filament also come with a sensor chip that works with the printer. So be sure you change out that chip as well, when you load your new spool of filament.

The photo I added to my review is a (working) duck call I made for my husband with my printer. To make this project I used the green PLA filament available in this listing, as well as black Da Vinci Junior PLA filament.
summary: Works with my Da Vinci Junior

reviewText:
I replaced the PEEK hot end on my Craftbot...this was a drop in fit. (Mostly). You unbolt the old hotend. Trim filament tube (the hollow metal screw) slightly...then reassemble....aaaaand...you're done.

My only complaint is everything had to be heated before final tightening....which means you have to be careful about keeping the faces of the parts aligned (and it's at 220*C)....and I still had a tiny leak.....re-heating and re-tightening fixed it and it's worked like a champ since...

There are cheaper versions of this kit out there....but this one came with all the bits and then some...worth the money...

Jay
summary: It squirts when you get it hot enough... :)

reviewText: Wanted to answer a frequently asked question as someone who was wondering the same thing. Great for setting amp gains on a budget. If you're setting amp gains on an amp with an output above 200w per channel you're gonna want to get a probe that will do 10:1 attenuation like the one I have pictured, mine was about $10. Very easy to use and read with good enough adjustability for making sure the peaks are round. I also recommend getting a 9v battery adapter for good mobility.
summary: Amp gains

reviewText:
Pretty good shrink tubing. It could be a bit thicker, but I suppose in that case you could just go over it again with slightly larger tubing. There is a lot  provided here.

It shrinks down to around 60% the original size and gets much more rigid. Should work for most applications. I had no trouble using hot air set at ~ 150c.
summary: As advertised

reviewText:
I am a fan of Printrbots.  I've built Printrbots in the past and like how economical they are.  However I experienced some issues with the Play 1505 Assembled.  Some of these may be Amazon's fault but most I believe are Printrbot's.

1.  Printer came without any power adapter or any other accessory listed in the BOM (power adapter, usb, delran spacer, test print) except the spool holder.  I contacted Printrbot and they got right back to me with an apology and immediately shipped the power adapter on same day.

2.  Printer is pre-assembled but it was not properly built.  The 1/4" acme coupler to the Z axis was installed way too high on the drive shaft.  The extruder could never get close the print bed because the X axis switch was hitting the acme coupler.  (This might explains why there was no 'test' print that the BOM said was included with pre-assembled Printrbot Play's).

3.  The auto-leveling probe was supposed to be set properly.  The probe was set way too low and I eventually had to re-adjust it (no biggie).

4.  The printer I received from Amazon appears to be an "older" model.  The directions for removing the fan guard to adjust the auto-leveling probe showed thumb screws but the screws on the fan guard are hex heads.  The direction states that some of the older printers did not have thumbscrews but hex screws.

5.  The wiring for the extruder hangs down in such a way as to interfere with the print bed when the y-axis is moving.  I will need to adjust the wiring.

6.  Sometimes the X axis doesn't seem to recognize when it moves to the home position.  It will start to grind trying to push the X-axis home switch.

The good news is I am able to get a decent print after resolving most of the issue above (see photos).  I luckily had a spare power adapter (12V/6A) from my other Printrbot so I could get right to printing.  Printrbot sent me an email within a short period of time telling me they will ship me a new one.

I've built both the Printrbot Simple 2014 and the Simple Metal before (both very good economic printers).  I ordered the Play assembled simply because of a lack of time (and I've done it before).

So it wasn't that I could not fix these problems but I think some of these would confuse (and upset) someone who expected it to be fully functional out of the box.  Especially the lack of a power supply that's just flat out wrong.

If this printer works well I'll up the review to 4 stars and update my experiences with printing.
summary: Some Issues

reviewText:
I have purchased at least 10 printrbot printers in the past, and I currently own 8 Printrbot printers.  I have purchased Play becuase I can easily move it around.  I got 2 printers - both assembled.  I was going to cut down on assembly time.  Both of the printers weren't assembled properly and required tinkering to get them going.  On the first printer, the wires weren't installed properly, so Z axis was stuck at 100mm, instead of 130.  I needed to cut zip ties, and then I was able to get the printer to work - goes up to 130mm (makes angry noises when it gets close to the 125mm mark).  On a second printer, hot end wasn't heating up - I checked and the wire was broken.  I removed the bad wire and replaced it with a new one.  Had to solder the wire to the connector.  Decided to replace the entire wire in case there are more breaks.  At least 2 hours of time wasted instead of 15 minutes it should take you to print on a brand new printer.  Complained to Help Desk, and got banned by Help Desk, because I logged a lot of issues in the past (20+ issues in 2.5 years).  Contacted Brook and he confirmed that Help Desk decision is right.  Avoid buying this printer if you are a first time user.  You will get frustrated, and your printer will sit untouched.

Otherwise I like Printrbot printers because you can buy upgrades.  Installed Y upgrade with heated bed on my simple.  I was able to print ABS, and PLA, and didn't have any issues with getting filament to stick to the printbed.  I am using kapton tape, and some glue, to help with adhesion.
summary: Great printer, not assembled properly, warranty voided by manufacturer after contacting support

reviewText: Good overall construction. The cables seem to be heavy duty for what they are. The clips seem to be strong and I don't see any problems with them. The only reason I gave them 4 stars is because I have yet to try them out. American made product.
summary: Just what I was looking for. Good buy

reviewText: loved it so much i had to order a second one  to finish the print THAT BEING SAID ... they need a 1000 gram spool not just a 500 gram spool so i am putting it at 4 stars for that ... here are also some pictures of how the prints came out
summary: loved it so much i had to order a second ...

reviewText: I bought these little baggies for my fashion jewelry and for other small items. There are six assorted sizes and all close rightly with no issues. The plastic isn't super thick but it is fine for my needs. I will never use all of these but the price is excellent for so many and for such a variety of sizes. I keep my fashion jewelry sets together so I can grab a bag and have coordinating jewelry all in one place when I am in a rush.. I also have all sorts of little things that I would lose in these bags. They are great for organizing. I will probably pass along some to my sisters to use as well. Can't beat the price and the quality is good.
summary: Great for jewelry and all sorts of little things!

reviewText: Works exactly as advertised. I bought this to power a tiny novelty Tesla coil for my desk. It actually worked when I powered a mock up. Makes a nice little corona off the torrid with 1" streamers when I bring my hand close (powered off a 3.7 volt Li-ion). The product itself creates a blue spark (obviously it has a voltage multiplier inside). It produces snapping sparks kind of like a tazer but obviously much smaller and slightly quieter. Maybe 2-3 mm spark gap maximum when powered off a 3.7 volt lithium ion battery.
summary: Awesome little high voltage supply.

reviewText:
Update: I've made a mini Jacob's Ladder; an alpha particle spark detector and a couple other neat things. It's still going strong! Search michael logusz on utube and you'll see this thing in action. Sometimes after a long day I come home and turn this thing on and let it spark for a little while. At first i feared it, now I'm mesmerized by its possibilities.

I have a huge, heavy neon sign transformer  (NST) that puts out 5000 volts (5kV) at 18 milliamps (0.018A) and this little box puts out a much scarier spark, although the this doesn't seem to travel through stiff wires so I couldn't make a mini Jacob's Ladder out of it (yet). I'm thinking that means it has very low amps...I haven't measured it yet (use a high voltage divider probe or else you'll wreck your multimeter).

One side has 2 white (or red) wires: those are your outputs. Mine has 2 white outputs.

The input side will have two DIFFERENT color wires (1 red and 1 white). You have to hook positive input to the red. Hook negative input to the white.

In my photo the tips of the output wires are exactly 1/4" apart. The input voltage was 3.3 volts DC. The spark was loud, blue and awesome! Very crackly like a stun gun in the movies. I built a demo fusor (and made the Plasma Club) yet this seems scarier!

You must input DC voltage. You probably shouldn't go over 4 volts or so, although I did momentarily and got a huge spark. The specs say 3 volts. I needed 3.4 to get a steady spark. I'll update if I blow it up and I'll include the final voltage.

If you have the wires farther than 1/4" then either it won't spark or you'll crank up the voltage really high to get a spark: either way you might destroy this device.

If you apply voltage and don't provide an escape for it (a spark or powering something) you can destroy this unit. That's another danger of trying to make a bigger spark gap: you'll be powering this unit but if there's no spark you can destroy this unit apparently. I think that's what the seller means by "don't let the pressure build up".

For about the price of a single firework you can play with this. I haven't destroyed mine yet. It fills the room with ozone quickly (toy train / slot car smell).

Gets a sturdy holder apparatus for the output.
summary: Wow!

reviewText:
Ive had a lot of hose nozzles over the years and have reviewed several.  This, however, is my favorite.  That its metal instead of plastic is a big factor, but that the different spray patterns click cleanly into place, and that the patterns are varied and useful are even more important for me.  The metal loop that locks the nozzle in the open position works well, and it has a good feel overall.

The only negative is that I had to use some thread sealing tape (not sure that "plumbers tape" is actually the correct term) to keep the nozzle-to-hose connection from leaking.  That seems to be a common problem, and its a pain, but at least its easily remedied.

Ive got other nozzles that have some spray patterns that are either almost redundant or not very useful, but with this nozzle the patterns are varied, useful, and don't dribble or otherwise not work properly.  The soaker setting isn't something youll want to use while holding the nozzle because in diffusing the spray you're likely to get wet, but if you want to set the nozzle on the ground to soak a plant it works well.  All of the patterns work as they should.

I received this nozzle in exchange for testing and writing this review, but I always list the negative as well as positive attributes of whatever Im reviewing.  Please check out the photos to get a feel for the variety of the spray patterns and how clean the spray is.  (Not all the patterns are shown in the photos but they all work very well.)  What the photos cant convey is how nicely each pattern clicks into place, which I really appreciate.

Bottom line is that I like this nozzle and can recommend it, just know that you might need to use some thread sealing tape for a leak-free connection.
summary: Good feel, with varied spray patterns that click into place nicely

reviewText: These arrived super fast, love prime shipping! in a sealed plastic container. The strips have 4 color boxes, once submerged for a second or two you can compare it the chart provided. I am only just learning about the importance of having a good PH balance and tested this on several things (coffee, shampoo, my tap water) which is how we caught that we needed a new water softener filter doo hickey for our tap. These results are very accurate when compared to my husbands professional work set. Very happy with this set. I received this discounted to test and provide a genuine review from my personal use and experience.
summary: These arrived super fast, love prime shipping

reviewText:
This filament seems to print quite nicely. The transparency of your finished product really depends on how many shells you use and the infill. If you want a really transparent part it's best to use a low number of shells and no infill, a vase with only one or two shells would probably look great. The photo shows the color vs Hatchbox white for reference.
Overall I really like the 'transparent' filaments because they have a cool sheen to them. Almost like they were acetone polished without actually being polished.
summary: Looks great, prints nicely.

reviewText: I've been using this for a year on my fish tanks and it's pretty accurate according to the liquid kit I use to confirm the results. The 2-part  liquid test kits are a pain, and the test strips aren't always accurate, so this saves a lot of time.  The only drawback is no "hold" feature - as soon as you withdraw it from the water, it loses the reading.  Reading it in-tank is difficult and would be easy to drop, so I use a cup. To calibrate I just use white vinegar, which is 2.2 ph.
summary: Seems pretty accurate.

reviewText:
We have a swimming pool and I bought this "[PH Meter], JellasTM Pocket Size PH Meter Pen Water Quality Tester for Aquariums, Swimming Pools, PH 0-14.0 Measuring Range, 0.01PH Resolution With ATC and Backlit LCD (Yellow)" to help my son doing his swimming pool job easier.

This meter is a rather complicated yet accurate piece of equipment. In order for you to make it work right, you need to go through a tedious process of turning a small screw in the back while dipping the meter in two different liquids. Once you've calibrated it, you're ready to go. The readings claim to be accurate to the plus or minus 0.1 pH. The meter comes with a glowing and easy to read display, a battery, two powder packs for calibration, and a screwdriver also for calibration. All in al,l if you're willing to go through the process of calibration, this is the tool for you.

I received a discount on this product for providing an unbiased and honest review. I review this product as if I had paid full price. I don't have any affiliation with this seller and my opinions are from my personal experience with it. I hope my review can be helpful for a future buyer.
summary: You should calibrate it to use

reviewText:
Although I will never do a DIY like this again, the product works great. If I were to do it again, I'd spend the extra money on an assembled product. I thought it would be fun to assemble, but I had trouble reading the part numbers and some of the solder joints are very small. I have a precision tipped soldering iron and I am no stranger to soldering or electronics, but this took me 4 hours to assemble. I saw videos of people putting it together in an hour, so it comes down to your skillset. I'm 42 and don't wear glasses, but maybe I should. You'll probably want an Ohm meter to figure out what resistors go where, but if you're ordering this, you probably have at least 3 already.

I attached a picture of the speed sensor signal from my 96 Dodge Viper at about 15 MPH.
summary: Although I will never do a DIY like this again

reviewText: I've bought and used several of Inland's rolls. Update 5-20-18, I've used over 7 rolls of different colors and I've NEVER had a tangle, Jam or any problem. Its out done name brands that I've paid more for. I also like the heat range. I've tied at different temps just to see how it works and it works with quite a range. I've build aircraft cosmetic parts, scale falcon 9's and many other things. There natural one is incredible for the price. Black, white, etc have all been very consistent. I've attached some sample builds.

reviewText:
So, you'll note the other reviews that say they aren't sure if this is ABS or PLA. My roll seemed a little weird for PLA - it liked higher temps, I needed to dial down retraction, I needed to keep the bed at 60* the whole print. Once I dialed in the settings of .5 mm retraction, 215c for the whole print, and the bed at 60c - it prints great. It's strong, stringing is low, and the prints come out remarkably clean and shiny. It really is a great value for the money.

It does have a bit of an ABS odor to it when it prints, and other people review it say it's not PLA. One look at this small label and mystery solved "PLA+". This is allegedly the same material as eSun's PLA Pro. It's a slightly different blend of materials than regular PLA. It generally has improved characteristics. In so far as I can tell, it's melting point is a little higher, and it's "globbier", which assuredly gives it better layer adhesion but means its a little more sensitive to under extrusion and retraction.

Now that I have the settings dialed in, it is a great filament at a very low price - however, I'm obligated to knock off a star since I didn't get the material I expected. The main label just says PLA - but it isn't like my particular roll is just mislabeled, as it indicates print temperature of 205-225c - the same print temps as eSun's PLA Pro. For regular black PLA, eSun indicates standard print temps of 190-220c.

Allegedly, Inland (Microcenter store brand) filament is OEM'ed by eSun - so the temperatures lining up here seems to corroborate that.

It wasn't until I noticed this little + sign on this little label that I realized what was going on. It's just better filament than they said it is. Tweak your settings accordingly and prepare to be pretty impressed with the quality for the price. I'll be buying more and hoping I get the PLA Pro.
summary: It's good stuff: But check your label - I received PLA+ aka PLA Pro - NEED DIFFERENT SETTINGS

reviewText: Like most inexpensive filaments, it works for some things but not others.  I've had several rolls of Inland PLA (they are using PLA+ now despite the item title) in several colors and they all perform pretty much the same.  Don't expect it to work for quick low resolution prints - across every roll of PLA from Inland that I've tried, it performs between horrible at greater than .2mm layer height to acceptable but poor at .18mm - that said, if you can get your printer down to .04 to .1mm layer height, and can stand waiting, you're in for an excellent print with great adhesion and consistent layer quality.  The "sweet spot" for speed vs resolution seems to be around .15mm for a layer height.  Inexpensive filaments have their place in prototyping, but this one doesn't cut it for fast prototyping.  If that is what you need, you'll actually save time=money by budgeting for a higher level filament.  If budget is your biggest concern, print slower and higher resolution and you will achieve good results.
summary: Like most inexpensive filaments

reviewText:
This is an excellent filament and the price is awesome (paid about $17).  It's very easy to print with excellent bed and layer adhesion.  Decent bridging, etc.

My prints with this material have ended up being quite shiny and great-looking.  No complaints.
summary: Great

reviewText:
Great filament, prints very easy for me on a Creality cr10s with stock nozzle. The color is solid bright white and a medium shine. It does however have completely different characteristics than the dark colors I normally print. Thus, I still need do dial my machine in more for perfect prints. But this is looking good. I have attached some images, the prints aren't perfect but are suitable for my needs, none of the issues I faced while printing these models were the fault of the filament. The dragon skull was the first print with this filament straight out of the box. No adjustments made from the previous filament which was Hatchbox black.

I will say that this filament once printed feels nice in your hand, I mean its just PLA but it is almost a matte or satin feel instead of the high gloss filaments. It has alot to do with print temp as well. Lower temp will give a less shiny finish but also be weaker. a higher temp will give more shine and be stronger. Normally I print at about 210 -215 and this worked best at around 210 for me.

 I am pleased and would buy this again. I think I originally paid $15 for a 1kg roll.

Pros:

1. Lays down good at 210 temp
2. Diameter was consistent
3. Color is accurate
4. Sticks to bed at 60 degrees with hairsrpay or painters tape.
5. Has a nice finish
6. Incredibly affordable.

Cons:
none that I can see as yet

My Machine
- Creality CR10s
- Stock .2 nozzle

reviewText: Awesome filament for the price and quality.  If you have an problem its with your print settings. Highly recommended awesome filament with awesome results.

reviewText:

I usually buy this at a local store where its $15/1KG spool. Absolutely the best color spool I've seen!

reviewText: I absolutely love the color and quality of my prints from this filament, my printer settings were 215 for the hot end, and 55 for bed, printer speed 60, and for layer height I used .2, it arrived quickly and with good packaging. reviewText:
A couple things about this heat shrink. This is NOT HEAVY DUTY high quality heat shrink. If you were expecting such a thing from a 410 piece set for 8 bucks, Sorry... That being said, you need to go into this purchase with the right expectations. 400 pieces for 8 bucks, Ok well I'm not working on the space shuttle, so it should work right?

The tubing does NOT shrink as much as they say it does. It would be nice if it did, but it is just not the case. So to get around this, you need to put the smallest possible piece of tubing on your wires. It should be a snug fit, before shrunk.

Because of the lower quality of the tubing, using a lighter is also not recommended. Use a heat gun if possible, and hold it further away then you might normally, or else the tubing will burn before it shrinks.

Honestly that's about it for this tubing. If you go in to it with realistic expectations, you should be pleasantly surprised. If you are expecting 3M quality, you should look elsewhere.
summary: OK, NOT GREAT QUALITY, Nice Price and HUGE Size Assortment

reviewText:
Why did I try PETG, Because I was told it is more flexible and stronger than PLA and less "Smelly" , No toxic fumes and no lifting off the heat bed.
I decided to give it a try. Now my hot end has a PFE tube in it so I had to be careful about going about 250-260c on my hotend. This was the material I ended up on.

BAM! 2 Day amazon prime and after a few prints here are my thoughts.

THE BEST! Ive printed with ABS and I hate it. I do not have an enclosure and the fumes where so bad I think it was making my Dog sick. I have not had a failed print. I love this stuff and I will print in PETG on this printer more often if not all the time. The price is nominal compared to PLA and man the quality that comes out is spot on, and strong! If you want to try different materials PLEASE try this but not if you don't have an all metal hotend please shy away from 250c plus temps. Works also on my ANET A8 and Tronxy X3. Note: PETG is FDA approved for direct food contact :) Thats a plus.

SPECS: Printed on a Creality CR-10, Mirror Bed at 70c with a thin layer of standard glue stick and a hot end of 245c. No enclosure and pretty much everything else is stock. I've included a shot of a live print with Octoprint. I did try to print with NO glue stick and that was the only fail.
summary: PETG has replaced ABS for me!

reviewText: Yes it prints. Yes it sticks. This ESun White PETG is very sensitive and really likes to be dialed in perfectly. Be prepared to spend 1/2 a spool just figuring it out.
summary: Great Once Settings Dialed In

reviewText:
Its been good so far but the filament was cut halfway through which luckily ran out after the print was done, if that had been a larger print it would have ruined it.

update: we'll it finally ruined a print, a long print, heres a picture of where they made the spool so that it formed a knot that ultimately caused the filament to snap out of the extruder from being grounded down on for so long. Filament is great, QC is what you would expect of the chinese.
summary: needs better quality control, not for use on multi hour prints

reviewText:
Was about 75% through a 19 hour print and found out the printer was printing in tin air. Found the cause. The filament was tangled on the spool so obviously lacking in quality control.
No more of this product!
summary: Terrible product

reviewText:
I've used about 1/4 of the spool of the black PETG, and found it to be consistent and reliable on my Prusa i3 MK2S. I'm sitting right at the edge of recommended print speed (60mm/s) and getting amazing results. The finished prints are extremely tough and durable. If you're used to PLA, you may be surprised by how shiny this material is.

I was glad to see that the package includes specific instructions from eSun about what to expect with this material and how to go about using it with your printer. My personal recommendation is to study those guidelines carefully before you even load the spool up on your printer.

For those that may have issues with this or are new to PETG and use Simplify3D, I use an initial retraction of 0.54mm before the print starts, then 0.8mm retraction thereafter. No cooling fan or keeping it at 50% speed. Printing at 240C for the hot end and 90C for the heated bed and not had a single problem with adhesion or bad layers.

Please note that this stuff can be really tough to get off the bed. Do not start a print with this and let it finish sometime overnight while you're sleeping! You'll have to tear it off the print bed with a prybar at that point.
summary: Works amazingly well if you follow the guidelines

reviewText: eSUN PETG is great. Once dialed in this prints better than PLA and sticks to clean PEI sheet like glue without any additional prep. It is a bit stringier than other filaments but, no lifting or warping and it's heat resistant.
summary: Prints Great!

reviewText: I have been very happy with eSUN PETG filament.  I purchased a second roll of the black filament to help my girlfriend with a kids craft history teaching event.  I printed nearly 75% of the spool in the first couple of weeks and had no issues with tangling or a single failed print.  The eSun reels feel much more durable than some of the other brands I have tried.  The material printed very well and was very durable.  PETG does tend to string more than ABS but the prints are usually easy to clean up.  The material adheres and releases well from the bed build tape.  If you have issues releasing the prints from the durable build tapes, heat the bed slightly and it should come off easier.  I have used this material successfully on a Flashforge Creator Pro and an Anet A8 printer.  I have had great results with both printers.  The canon(s) in the photos was printed in three parts and the treasure chest in two parts.
summary: PETG hasn't let me down yet!

reviewText: This is the filament that got me hooked on PETG. On a whim I added a spool of eSun black PETG to an order of PLA and ABS and now it's basically all I use anymore for functional prints. Layer adhesion is excellent and parts come out looking wonderful.
summary: Layer adhesion is excellent and parts come out looking wonderful

reviewText:
The filament prints nicely, though it is a bit tricky. You have to find just the right settings in order for it to come out good. Well, it still comes out quite good looking , even if it isn't a perfect print. It is also quite sturdy. Make sure to fiddle with the settings and you will get some great prints. Right now I am trying to limit the thin strings that PETG seems to leave behind. It really is a minor gripe, it is not a reason to avoid this filament.
I have also had some issues with the filament getting stuck around the extruder tip, though I am pretty sure that is my inexperience showing. I don't think these minor issues are any reason to avoid this filament. If you want to give it a try, don't hesitate to buy some.
summary: The filament prints nicely, though it is a bit tricky

reviewText: I love the translucent filaments, and the fact that this is orange makes it even better. I am tempted to print a lot of items with this filament, since it looks so pretty. It has some minor stringing issues, but I suspect that is mostly a calibration issue. I have not spotted any discolorations, or had any jamming issues. It is another great filament from Hatchbox. :-)
summary: I love the translucent filaments

reviewText: This has been one of the most popular colors I've used yet. While not actually transparent, it does a pretty good translucent. It has a kind of sparkly quality to it that makes it very nice for artistic works. A light inside definitely glows nicely through the material as well. Printing was just like any other Hatchbox filament I've used - very reliable. I'm using a FlashForge Creator Pro, and extruding at 220-230 C.
summary: Great sparkly color!

reviewText: Works really well. I've made 6 spool adapters, and a D&D miniatures with great results.

reviewText: NO RETURN/ NO REFUND. The machine I have has yet to print anything usable, it makes a loud metal slapping sound, and the parts fall into the vat during printing and become lumps of resin. Talked to tech support for a week before trying to return it, when I did they said, NO RETURN/ NO REFUND on used machines. How was I to know it was junk until I used it? now they won't take back a faulty machine, and I'm stuck with an expensive hunk of junk.
