reviewText: Thoroughly impressed with the attention to detail with NatureO bottles! I love, love the packaging - the box it comes in and the label provided. I, in fact, repurposed the box as a gift box, it is so pretty. The glass bottle is top quality. Very thick with no noticeable seams. I dropped this, tripping over pup, and it didn't even chip. I mix up filtered water and simple green as my floor cleaner. The mister is a nice even mist, but I use this on stream. It sprays out a good amount, making mopping easy. Attention to quality is apparent with this brand. Love! I received this bottle free to test and provide a genuine review from my personal use and experience!
summary: I love, love the packaging - the box it comes ...

reviewText:
This filament smells pretty good. It does smell similar to a wood shop when your printing it. The only downfall is that I had a lot if little stickers and burrs that had to be filled/sanded down on most of my prints. Some of them it even strung the filament all over the place, sort of like a thin spider web effect. I still use it, I do get some good prints out of it.

As far as staining goes.... Yes, you can use stain on this. No, it's not going to work out quite like you think. It will take more than a day to dry. Your basically trying to stain plastic with tiny wood particles in it. It works about like you would imagine if you think about trying to stain plastic. So yes, you can do it, and it works (I did it), but it's not what you think.
summary: Smells nice, prints OK. Get used to sanding!

reviewText: Very easy to print with. I did a temp tower test on my cr-10 and it seemed to print with little difference regardless of what temperature setting I used within the specified range. I typically like to print around 200
summary: It just works

reviewText: prints great, looks great. I love this filament. I did get a clog using it, but it was worth it.
summary: prints great, looks great

reviewText:
Love it. Easy to print with my home built printer. More cleanup than PLA but it is easier. Sand and stain just like soft wood.
The attached model is after sanded and clean before staining it.
0.2 mm, 195 deg., 85 speed for the first 30 mm
0.1 mm for the rest.
summary: Love it. Easy to print with my home built ...

reviewText: I'm really happy with this Hatchbox PLA filament!! It prints SO SMOOTH! Although you WILL has minor stringing with this filament (very common), but it's comes off with no problem when you do your post processing finish work. The PLA sands very easy. I start with a 220 grit sandpaper, and use fine grit each time, to remove scratch marks. It develops a semi-polished surface with a 1000 grit sandpaper. You can use wood stains on this PLA, but I've yet to try it. The small vase in the picture, was done in spiral mode. The picture was taken RIGHT AFTER  it was removed from the printer. NO post processing work was done to it.
summary: Awesome wood pla!!! Love it!

reviewText:
I used this wood filament with standard PLA settings on my PRUSA i3 MK2, 205 extruder & 55 bed temp with somewhat poor results. The surface had a lot of smearing and indentations (see pic) whereas a standard PLA filament prints just fine. My guess is that the nozzle temp is way too high and it's way too soft, and I've read other reviews where they were printing in the 180's and it worked fine. (It is a softer material than PLA - noticable when you flex/bend it by hand).

So net-net it looks like wood and probably prints just fine once you get the temperatures dialed-in correctly.
summary: Looks like wood but likely needs some temperature tweaking to come out right

reviewText: My first batch of wood filament.  Worked like a charm.
summary: Got wood?

reviewText:
Prints very nice, I use a heated bed at 60 c and a extruder at 220 c with a 7 mm retraction at 35 mm/s and printing at a 40 mm/s.
It has a slight wood smell while it prints not like a wood shop but not like super cheap would smell either. Nor does the smell last long once it's done printing. It's quite easy to sand after and smooth out. I just had some oil wood stain lying around and it does take a lot of coats to get it the right color, other reviews have recommendation for stains that will probably work better than oil based. Once it's stained people find it hard to believe it was 3d printed.

Also please note this filament absorbs moisture from the air rather quickly so it's best to store it away in a air tight bag and heater it up a bit to dry it out before using it else you'll hear steam and popping noises.
summary: My favorite filament by far!

reviewText: Hatchbox is great filament, period! But their wood fill PLA is by far my favorite material to print in; it WOWS everyone that has seen anything I print in it. It is easily sanded and can be finished with stain and sealer to produce wood-like objects. I've tried 2 others that could not produce similar results. The heft is still similar to any PLA, perhaps a bit lighter, like a balsa wood. You won't be disappointed in the finished products that you make.
summary: Best Material in the Universe

reviewText:
I had no troubles printing this at all (Though I preemptively increased my retraction settings as many recommended to prevent stringing) and found the finished result to be really nice even before attempting to stain it.
Retraction settings: 4MM Length on Move, 60mm/s retract speed
I printed between 190 and 200 and didn't notice a color shift between these two temperatures (Drats) but didn't notice any difficulties at either temperature either.

I've never stained or finished wood before, so while my finished print doesn't look as nice as many of the others on these reviews, I'm still proud of it.
I tried to include a basic idea of what I did. Hopefully that helps someone out there.
summary: Easy print, staining seems to give nice results even to someone whose never woodstained before.

reviewText:
Printing this at 200C with a 0.4mm nozzle and I couldn't be happier. This stuff prints stupidly well with near perfect bridges *without* a cooling fan. No excess stringing and it smells delightfully like maple syrup while printing.

While I haven't had the chance to try to stain it yet, I'll definitely tell you that it sands REALLY nicely. And after said sanding and a quick wipe with a damp rag, the finished product looks and FEELS like pine.

Great stuff. This is by far my favorite filament after 10 years in the hobby and I'll keep buying it as long as they make it.
summary: Prints like a dream, feels and looks like pine when sanded.

reviewText: I was surprised at how smooth and accurate this printed. Was a bit worried that it might clog with a 0.4 mm nozzle, but it went down like butter. Haven't tried finishing it yet with stain or varnish, but it feels, sounds (when thick enough), and smells like wood.
summary: but it went down like butter. Haven't tried finishing it yet with stain ...

reviewText: Hatchbox is my go-to PLA of choice but this one is very disappointing. Prints rough between 180 - 195C.  Any higher and the nozzle clogs with a brown tar/sap kind of plaque.  Difficult to bond to the print bed (slow to 10mm/s and +10% extrusion for the first layer), tons of stringing (increase retraction to 3mm or so), and lots of spider webs (I can't print at a lower temp than 180C).  When the print does complete it has great layer bonding, very wood-like texture, and a great smell while printing.  I really want this material to work for me as I have plenty of opportunities for a good wood product in my 3D printing, but I continue to struggle with only some success.
summary: Very difficult to work with

reviewText:
LOVED this stuff. it prints SUPER easily. WITH EXCELLENT Results!!
I lowered the temp a bit, normally I run PLA at 220 However for this I turned down to 210 and it works like magic.
Used my MakerGear M2 and did a wonderful job!!
Smells good while printing too, much like hot sawdust when ripping wood or using a router.

I found its bed adhesion WAY too good for my zplate, I turned off the heated bed entirely and it still sticks REALLY well!!
Uploaded is my chopsticks holder bear I printed in this filament, I lightly hand sanded him and he turned out amazing.
Smells like wood, feels much like wood, sands like wood, stains and paints like wood.
I could not be happier!!
summary: LOVED this stuff

reviewText: This stuff prints great. I've tried several other brand's wood filaments and have been disappointed with all but this one.
summary: One of the best wood filaments you can get. period.

reviewText: There's a reason this stuff is always sold out.  Prints great.  For finishing I sanded it down with 80>120>400 grit sand paper, then apply a walnut finish to it and seal it.  Looks just like wood.

I had been reading about wood filament for a long time, but had never tried it. The Hatchbox filament is a bit more brittle than regular PLA but it prints very nicely and the appearance of printed items, while not completely wood-like, are definitely not shiny PLA and the texture is quite attractive.

I've attached a photo of a hippo model I printed in the Hatchbox Wood filament.
summary: Prints very nicely, delightful appearance

reviewText: I do like this filament, but so far I haven't gotten the wood look that some others are getting.  I made a bunch of stuff for people for Christmas with this thinking I could sand and stain, and make it look like wood.  Nothing really worked.  My guess is that your best experience is with fairly flat pieces. The stuff I printed was too brittle to sand and didn't accept the stain very well.  If you're printing something with some dimension, it's probably going to look at act just like PLA.  It does smell like wood, but it doesn't feel like wood.  I still like it.  It's a nice color and it doesn't feel as dense as PLA.  Plus, it floats, at least the capybaras did. I'll probably try another wood filament next time, but this isn't a total fail.
summary: Not Really All Purpose

reviewText:
not a lot of experience printing... but between the demo stuff that came with my printrbot, some matchbox orange PLA and this stuff it is by far my favorite. Not as easy to print with as the orange filament but you can sand and stain|paint the results much easier. Surface finish seems to be nicer as well but the layer bonding is much weaker if that is a concern. bridging may be a bit weaker but in the comparison shot the orange calibration target was printed with a thicker layer which helped with the bridging... think this would have done fine at over a .1mm layer. Believe I did that orange one at .125mm.

Settings for the print:
Printrbot Simple Metal
Cura, Cura slice
Octopi Print
Layer = .08
Shell = .8
Bottom Layer = .4
Fill = 20%
Print speed = 50mm/s
Print temp = 200c to start, tweak at z hight .5mm to 178c (less ooze... but still there)
Adhesion = brim (prints fine without, helps with warping... cleanup  is a pain
nozzle = 4mm
Retraction speed = 40mm/s
retraction distance = 2mm (still stringing... may go a bit further)
Bottom layer speed 30mm/s
infill speed = 50mm/s
min layer time = 15 seconds

If not listed values are default from printrbot starter ini file for the simple metal.
summary: some matchbox orange PLA and this stuff it is by far my favorite. Not as easy to print with as the ...

reviewText: It feels like wood, it has a grain to it, it's great. Turn off retraction to use this stuff, though. I attached a picture of my first calibration block, and the top half of my phone's case after some sanding work done. It looks great, but you have to feel it to believe it.
summary: yep, it's wood.

reviewText: This stuff is great! Printed using my standard PLA settings, I just upped the temp to 210C. This stuff sands and stains so well.
summary: This stuff is great! Printed using my standard PLA settings

reviewText:
This is a great product. It extrudes perfect at 220c and sticks to my bed at 65c with hairspray. It has a very wood like feel.
It bridges very well. In the first picture the bottom of the print is on the left side. The other picture is just a stand with a cutout. Left a very nice finish going 30mms. You could go faster, for sure, but my printer fails least often at that speed for me.
summary: This is a great product. It extrudes perfect at 220c and sticks ...

reviewText:
Excellent results if you use it right. This does have the real feel of wood. You do need to use it correctly. When printing with a .35mm nozzle, I had a number of clogs, but with a .5mm nozzle, it prints beautifully. I am able to go 4000mm/min (Simplify3D uses /min settings) -- which is pretty fast.
It bridges really well. I designed and printed a few things with the goal of using this filament. First is Tommy The Trailer for my 2 year old daughter. He is from the Tec The Tractor TV show. 2nd is a letters to put up on the wall in my son's room. The Trailer was finished with Shellac, which worked beautifully. The Letters were stained with Minwax oild based stain and sealed with Polyacrilic finish. When you compare with unfinished material, you can see this product takes normal wood finish techniques very well. I could have spent hours in my shop to cut the letter out of wood stock, added the bevel with a router, and done the keyhole mounting on the back with the router again, or design all 6 letters in my son's name in a hour, and set up the printer in 6 2-3 hour prints and have full set of beautifully made letters.
summary: Printing wood -- awesome, buying more

reviewText:
Im not an expert caulker and I like things perfect so when I was done I knew Id have a place or 2 to fix. It dries pretty quick.... I was caulking around the tub... I wasn't even going excessively slow, Im talking within the minute it was drying up. Normally that would be a good thing, not in this case. After applying and waiting a couple days one of the spots looked like it had a thin overlay on it. I rubbed on the flaky spot and it peeled off and just kept going and within less than a minute the whole thing and all my work was gone. Back to the regular silicone for me and is now perfect and sticking the first try.
The only thing I liked about this caulk was that it dried a bit harder than the silicone and wasn't as shiny. It kind of just blended right into the tub and tile.
This is the first Gorilla product out of many that I have been disappointed in.
summary: Doesnt stick!

reviewText: very good.
summary: very good.

reviewText: I took a chance on this product, and I am super glad I did. I've tried many brands, but this one is incredibly easy to work with, low fuss when altering settings (I wasn't using a heated bed, and set my machine to 215 C), had perfect prints from the get. The ONLY problem I could see anyone having is with dirt. Be sure to use a filter, Maybe it was a one-off, but I'm less than halfway through my roll, and I've had to change my filter sponge out because it is absolutely filthy. Photo included. This is a non-issue if you use a filter, as I said, and I still recommend this product 100%
summary: Amazing product! Highly recommend it!

reviewText: I have been using nothing but Hatchbox PLA because I have had issues with other brands of PLA, while this brand is a little more coarse in texture on the spool, it had 0 problems printing and the prints all came out really nicely. The spool is nicely wound and had no hang-ups. Though the spool does have an annoying hub where it is flat to the face of the spool on one side and recessed about an inch on the other side, this makes it difficult to use it on some spool holders, I would like to see the manufacturer offer a spool insert or use a different spool(this is the only reason for the 4 star review). I was printing at 208c on a Robo3d R1+ with E3Dv6 hotend. I will be purchasing more from this brand in the future, it is tied with Hatchbox as my favorite PLA
summary: it had 0 problems printing and the prints all came out really nicely. The spool is nicely wound and had no ...

reviewText: Prints quite nicely but isn't very dark for being "dark" green.  I'm printing at 200C on a FlashForge Dreamer with high lubricity nozzle upgrades, with the bed heated to 60C.  I printed about six hours of this filament with no feed issues, which is important to me; I tend to start long prints and walk away from them.  I picked up some of the MeltInk light blue filament as well and am really liking that; it does have a very nice color that does fit the name.
summary: Prints great, more medium than dark shade.

reviewText:
Filament is relatively cheap, but time is valuable. I had 3 consecutive print fails when I first tried to use this filament. I finally stopped and looked at it, the filament was riddled with bulges and thick spots, causing jams, and twice it jammed bad enough that I had to disassemble the printer to get the filament out of the feed mechanism. QC needs to be improved!!!! Wasted much time, which is more infuriating than wasting filament.

Edit: I received a new Meltink replacement package, in cool grey. This time the filament was of uniform width and did not jam in the feed mechanism at all. From the prints that I tried - admittedly small, difficult ones - I must say that this filament is very interesting. I have been using Hatchbox filament, and I notice that this filament is significantly stronger than the former. I also watched the printer perfectly print out three vertical rods half a millimeter wide, about 3mm apart, something that I have been having difficulty with when using other filaments. no wobble at all, just perfectly straight thin, vertical sections. In its molten state, it seems a little more viscous than other filaments, maybe it's just me. But bed adhesion was pretty good on glass. Sometimes it of course tended to peel up, but if you put a layer of tape down it sticks on there like it's welded!
summary: and twice it jammed bad enough that I had to disassemble the printer to ...

reviewText:
I had never heard of this brand before.  I normally use eSun and Hatchbox.  I was in need of something to get an order to the $35 point for free same day shipping and couldn't find any of my regular filament I needed.  This showed up on the search so thought I would check it out.  A web search for them didn't find much in the way of reviews, but the ones I found were all pretty good so figured it was worth the risk.

I printed a small model with it and the quality was great.  It has a glossy finish.  No problems with it at all.  Going to add this brand to my list.  It is also listed as Made In America.  So that is another plus for me.
summary: Good Quality Inexpensive Filament

reviewText:
This is a compact, well designed multifunction tester. Although it's not equipped with all the best and whistles other *more expensive devices* have, it's perfect for entry-level testing. Both functions network line tracer and cable tester work as advertised. Meaning that you can troubleshoot the main connections you'd find on a regular household with ease: coaxial cables, telephone lines and ethernet cables. I find the cable tester particularly accurate, even when working with really thin cables.

Both the emitter and the receiver are fairly portable and lightweight, built quality is "ok". The specifications indicate it can be used up to 3,000 mt (>9,000 ft). I didn't test it to those distances but it worked well around 2,000 ft.

As seen in the picture, main components are included (batteries, cables and even headphones) in addition to a carrying pouch (although the quality of that latter is not the best).
summary: Good multifunction tester for main cable connections at home.

reviewText:
UPDATE: As I had feared, the heat break ended up breaking inside the heat sink. There were 2 conditions that contributed to this failure. The first, is that the inner bore was drilled way too far down the tube, right to the neck. The neck being a smaller diameter, this left a paper then layer of metal to support the top of the neck (notice the bore in the picture goes right to the neck where it broke). The second, which was probably exacerbated by the 1st condition, is that it arrived slightly bent at that weak point (likely during shipping). I only hope I can get the broken tube out of the heat sink so it isn't a complete loss. I highly recommend that 3D CAM shorten the bore to e3d spec, and maybe add a shipping support collar to the heat block so it doesn't get bent during shipment. This would have been 5 stars without the heat break issue, as I really liked the rest of the product.

ORIGINAL:
I did an analysis of the item I received vs. the e3d specs for the V6 hotend as soon as the package arrived. Overall, I am very happy so far with the construction. A few improvements, and it would be perfect. I haven't printed with this unit yet, but will update my review with performance stats once I get some prints done. Here is what I found:

The item I received is indeed modeled after the V6. Below is an analysis of the quality vs.the e3d:
* The heater cartridge is clamped in with an M3 screw instead of just using a set screw. E3d did this to improve heat transfer.
* The thermistor is embedded in the heat block and also clamped with an M3 screw. However, there is no washer included that would cover the hole (part of the e3d spec), though I don't see the thermistor falling out easily. Also, the thermistor uses PTFE insulation instead of the stronger braiding, so the clamp screw could short the thermistor out if tightened too much. I will change the insulation as a precaution.
* The nozzle matches the v6, having 2 transitions of narrowing instead of one, which is a great improvement due to less required nozzle pressure. Haven't had a chance to check internal finish, but I can  say the hole is round and centered.
* The heat break had some major issues, which prevented a 5 star rating. My heat break came slightly bent at the thinner neck area, probably due to bring shipped fully assembled in a soft pouch. I very carefully corrected by bending with a nail, but am unsure of the strength now (well, it just broke...). The heat break matches some of the design of the V6, but the PTFE liner is allowed to move all the way down near the cold/hot boundary instead of just a few mm like the V6. It's still in the cold end, so we will see.
* The heat sink is well machined and the shroud and fan were tight and straight. I haven't powered up the fan yet to test.
* Threads in the heat sink appear to be decently cut. They are a little on the loose side, so I will put thermal paste in to allow better heat transfer.
* All wires were neatly attached and fastened together with kapton tape.
* Hydraulic clamp for PTFE liner was nice and snug.

In summary, here are the areas that could be modded to bring this very close to e3D quality:
* Braided fiberglass insulator added to thermistor wires where screw clamps it down to prevent short.
* Add washer to thermistor clamp screw to cover the hole and keep it nice and tight in there where it will get a better reading.
* Just buy a new heat break for 5-10 dollars to be safe if yours is bent. I did.
summary: Item I received appears to be well built, heat break needs to be improved.

reviewText:
eSun "Green" is awesome!  This is some of the best PETG I've tried.  It prints great:  Minimal stringing (for PETG), excellent bed and layer adhesion, great bridging, etc etc.  It also just *looks* amazing.  Check out my attached photos--it looks like straight out of the Emerald City!

Seriously, my spool is almost empty and I'm definitely going to order more soon.
summary: This stuff prints and looks amazing

reviewText: PETG is now my go to filament.  I believe this is my 4th or 5th purchase of eSUN filament (White PETG, Orange PETG, White ABS, Black ABS x2) and I have been happy with all of my purchases.  Filaments print well on my Flashforge Creator Pro and Anet A8 Printers.  The PETG will take a little tinkering with the settings to get it right but the stuff sticks great to the bed and the prints are strong and clean.  Haven't had any tangle issues with the filament (be careful when pulling off the tag end of the new roll, and use caution when placing the tag end back on the roll if swapping out).  There is a little more stringing with the PETG but this is very easy to clean up.  The transparent orange looks really good and would probably be great for any type of back lighting/shade designs.  The photo is of a project tube printed on my Anet A8.  I believe the layer height was 0.25mm for this print.
summary: Thumbs up for this PETG

reviewText:
We've fallen in love with eSun's 'transparent' PETG - it's translucent, but still.
Epic material. Pain in the butt to get right initially - hours spent tuning and adjusting until everything was just right. But once it's dialled in, as so many others have said, it's rock solid. Hydrophobic and strong, yet flexible. Almost never cracks (you have to print it wrong), and visually *very* appealing. I'm using it at the moment to print replacement and upgrade parts for my Prusa i3 MK2, and though I love the Prusa Orange, this shiny/glossy/transmissive color is an excellent upgrade tone and material.
summary: Favorite Material, Epic Color!

reviewText: Excellent kit, good documentation. Perfect for my printer build.
summary: Five Stars

reviewText:
Ever since I saw a FFF 3d printer I wanted to try to build one. Ever since there I have been doing some research on how to create a custom 3d printer. This led me to this product. I was looking for a cheap but working arduino mega with a ramps. Because of the low price for what is provided in this kit I decided to try this one out. The components for this kit came in nice anti static bags and also the pins were placed in foam blocks to protect them. But it seems that they did not work as intended, the pins on the boards were slightly bent so I needed to take time to strengthen most of them. Also the anti static bags were also punctured during the shipping process. But this what I expected for the price that I payed.

Besides the bent pins on the board the soldering job on my boards were a little sloppy but there were no misconnections. Assembling the boards together were easy after fixing the pins. I installed Marlin on the arduino mega and it works perfectly. I have used the boards for my 3d printer for 2 months and so far haven't had any problems. Over all this kit is very useful for building a 3d printer although it might be cheaper in the long run to buy a full kit such like a Prusa i3 that go for around $200 at the time of my review. This is because you will need to add in the cost of the power brick, stepper motors, linear rods and so on.

I truly like this kit since its a good value for what you get. But if you are planing to make your own custom 3d printer I would highly recommend you buy a cheap mass produced 3d printer kits since there are around $200 and use the parts to make your own design. Even if you don't complete your custom printer design you can still make the intended 3d printer.

[Pros]
1. Nicely packed (They used anti static bags for all the parts.)
2. Everything works (Tested for around 2 months)
3. Marlin works on the board.

[Cons]
1. Anti static bags were punctured when I received them.
2. Board pins were bent (You will need to strengthen them)
3. Slightly sloppy soldering job (Expected for an arduino clone)
summary: Nice Kit (But...)

reviewText:
It works great without any issues. I'm able to see the pressure, temperature, and humidity around my area. Big props as well to Matt, author of the python script given in the "link" provided in the FAQ section. He did the heavy work with the programming part in Python. See question "Will this work with a Raspberry Pi?"

Pros:
* It works as promised
* Quality product
* My soldering skills aren't that good yet, and even with my "noob" soldering skills, the product still works surprisingly.
* BME280 libraries are available for Python (see response to question "Will this work with a Raspberry Pi?") and also from Adafruit,

Cons:
* It would be better if it's soldered.
summary: Good sensor for reading pressure, temperature, and humidity!

reviewText:
update #3: these sensors are inconsistent, poor quality, are not reliable, and do not return reliable readings... a replacement bme280 from the same vendor, DIYMALL, returns even worse (i.e., incorrect) readings than a previously bad sensor!!!! for example:

2016-09-24 08:59 83.1 30.1 65.7 <- first bad sensor
2016-09-24 09:01 88.3 30.0 60.3 <- replacement sensor

this is a variation of 5F and more than 5% RH... barometric reading seemed OK... *but* keep in mind, the *actual* wx conditions were:

81F with 87% !!!!

*avoid* these sensors from this vendor!!! they are not good, repeat, not good... they will fail intermittently and do not return results anywhere near ambient

i tested these again bmp180s, which were spot on in temp and barometric pressure... and i tested them against DHT22s - one of which was extremely accurate - while two others were bad sensors sold by a bad vendor - UPGRADE INDUSTRIES (avoid that seller)

Diymall generally sells good stuff, but i would highly recommend that you avoid these bme280s - they just don't work

Latest UPDATE: a second of these sensors, bme280, from Diymall, failed after 48 hours outside... apparently both couldn't handle high temps (90F+) or high humidty (80%+) - another inside is running OK... have ordered another batch to see if there's an anomaly..

UPDATE: i ran some comparison tests against other devices and found that the bme280 will read about 4F too high when used outside in 90F temps... barometric pressure seems to track with with bmp180s on hand... i will next run the bme280 against a DHT22 on hand

excellent device... using Matt Hawkins' excellent bme280.py script, i was able to quickly integrate the output of this sensor - attached to a Beaglebone Black and a MediaTek wifi dongle - to quickly build a wireless ambient weather condition monitor - i'll install a few around the house (inside, outside, in garage) and have the data bleeped to a local web server on the home lan - could also be used to set alarms or monitor the reefer storing my beer - for testing, i ran this sensor on the i2C bus with an ssd1306 oled - i will run some tests with other sensors to gauge accuracy
summary: avoid: replacement was bad and two original sensors failed

reviewText: I got these to use on a white board.  I knew they needed a handle so I printed some on my 3D printer.  It was a good project and the magnets are plenty strong for this purpose.
summary: fun project

reviewText: I used these magnets on the back of wooden cabinet knobs that I painted sunflowers and tomato's on.  I used some heavy duty glue and they stay put.  I just ordered more.  Arrived in perfect condition.
summary: Good strength for craft projects

reviewText:
This 3D pen set is awesome and we (2 middle-aged adults, no kids) have been having a lot of fun playing with it the last two days.  Even after reading the included instructions, we were a little confused on how it worked so we went online to Youtube and the AtmosFlare site and watched videos and then it was easy to understand.

I am the type who has trouble drawing anything beyond a stick figure...I can see it in my head, but I can't recreate it when drawing.  This picture is my attempt at a bicycle.

The pen set is 5 strong stars, one of the most fun things I've tried in a while.  We spent about an hour last night creating and almost used up one of the ink containers that were supplied with the pen.  It doesn't list the price of replacement ink yet, but if those are not affordably priced, that is the only thing that would make me lower my star rating because as fun as the pen set is...it's no good to me if I can't afford the ink replacements.
summary: A lot of fun to use (for adults too)

reviewText: This pen is a different take on 3D pens. Most 3D pens use a solid plastic filament, melt it, then squirt it out, just like most 3D printers. This pen uses a reservoir of a very thick "ink" that is really a UV cured resin. This is a nice idea because nothing has to get hot and make it horribly unsafe for children. I was able to create some crude 3D drawings with a little practice. It definitely takes some getting used to. The "ink" cured nicely and was pretty plastic like and brittle when cured. Following the directions helps prevent nozzle clogs. A few things of note: The Good: * No heat required * Can quickly get going * Fun and safe for all ages The Bad: * Refills are not currently available and the price is unknown * The resin remains very slightly sticky after cured. The Ugly: * It is designed rather cheaply, but the loading/unloading of ink cartridges could have been much improved with small modifications to the retention mechanism. Attention to detail please! * If you use the pen on a reflective surface, the intense UV will quickly get to your eyes and bother them. Not sure how safe that is. For the price, if you're interested, give it a whirl, but don't expect a long term supported product.
summary: Interesting Idea - A Beta for Early Adopters and the Curious

reviewText: This is fun! As a thirty-something that remembered all those stupid toys like various putties and tacky art stuff with some gimmick, this has the feel of those things, but with a more modern and adult touch. Drawing up into the air and seeing the line stay quite firm feels strangely magical and satisfying, and as wobbly and bad as my "artistic creations" look, it is terrifically entertaining. Worthy of an adult-sized macaroni frame, what I make will probably never look beautiful, per se, but life's about the journey, isn't it? And the journey with this strange little pen is fun!
summary: Don't expect to make the Mona Lisa, but...

reviewText: As an artist, parent, and educator, I can envision all kinds of possibilities to use the AtmosFlare 3D Pen.  The set includes the pen with 4 tips and a cap, along with two ink cartridges (red & blue).  The cap has a pin to clear the tips after use, but a paperclip works quite well too.  There's supposed to be an AA battery included in the set, but the one I received for review purposes did not include one.  The set up was very easy, with the illustrated instructions included.  There are a couple of models to look at on the package, but you can find others on the company's website.  Although I'm very good at sculpting realistic figures with various types of clay, working with this pen will take a little more practice.  However, the human figure I made on my first attempt looks like a piece of abstract art, so I don't think that is bad.  (I recommend that you work on a smooth surface, and that it's not bright white, since the shininess could cure the ink inside the nozzle.)  I also found out that the refill cartridges will be available on Amazon for around $10 for a set of 3, and are available in a variety of colors, which pretty good.  I know I'm going to have a lot of fun playing more with it in the future!
summary: Fun and Easy to Use

reviewText:
We have owned Seville wire/metal racks for more than ten years.  We have taken them through a number of moves (including halfway across the country) and they still work great.  The only problem is that in packing for various moves, we have misplaced the sleeves that hold the racks to the poles.

When I found these Apex Sleeves, I bought the 24 pack so that I could use all of my racks again.  The sleeves work great and look pretty much the same as the original.  The only differences are cosmetic with the word top on my original sleeves, etc.

While another reviewer mentioned that these fit loose on Seville racks, I did not have that issue.  It may be because my racks are older but they fit on snug with no slipping.

Of course, things being the way they are, now that I have purchased great replacements, I'm sure the originals will turn up in the next few weeks!
summary: Great for replacing lost sleeves for metal racks

reviewText:
Let me start by stating that I'm an active outdoor homeowner and gardener.  I use at least one hose every single day during most of the year (it was 96 here today), and I have three.  I have a very simple standard to which I hold my equipment:  It has to work, every time, all the time.  I have no time or patience for poor quality equipment, because when equipment fails, it costs time and effort to repair now and replace later.  And it usually fails when I'm in the middle of some project that I want to get done on a deadline.  Faulty hose equipment also costs even more money and wastes water.  I prefer to spend my money once, for quality, sturdy merchandise.

I have to say that I really liked this until it broke.  I've had it less than one season (a little over 60 days), and it just plain broke.  Initially it felt very hefty and sturdy, and today I was spraying fertilizer on the back yard when it simply snapped.  I was stunned.  Now that it's in two pieces, I can see that the main body of the valve is metal (the green and black part).  When you look at the hose threads on the orange part, they are made of metal.  However the piece that held the orange threaded section to the green/black body is made of plastic.  Cheap, weak plastic where you can't see it until it fails.  Oh...and the window to return it to the seller ended just under two weeks ago.

I'm glad that I did not write a rave review that I would have had to retract.  In my opinion this is not Tuff, Outback or otherwise.
summary: VERY disappointed

reviewText:
I decided to take on a project for my 4th of July vacations and I chose this printer to be it. I chose RepRapGuru's kit since their reviews looked good and they are a USA manufacturer, and their website seems good, they have documentation, firmware download and forums. It's the first time I've actually tried to print on a 3D printer and I had no clue what it would take. After I finished assembling it, understanding how the technology works and doing all the calibration, I was able to print some cubes, which to me look pretty fine.

Documentation:
Their website contains all you need to assemble and program your printer. They provide two documents, assembly and programming/calibration, plus a zip with the firmware and a zip with the Repetier and Slic3r program. All the documentation seems to be kept up to date, there were some comments on some steps saying what things might be different on newer kits, which happened to be the case on mine. The instructions include high-res pictures and detailed explanations, really helped this newbie to put everything together.

Customer Support:
Right after I placed my order I received an email warning me about some printer kits that left their warehouse with a missing manufacturing step on the smooth rods that caused rust, telling me that if this was the case, to contact them. My kit was one of those and I emailed them and immediately they shipped the new rods, 2-days shipping at no cost. The new ones arrived in perfect conditions. I really appreciate their honesty and giving me the heads up, you can tell they really care about customers.

I also emailed them about an issue I had with Y axis skipping in the middle of my prints, they replied a few hours after I sent my email (on a Sunday!) and suggested to verify the tension on the belt, which I thought I did, but I tightened more and now it's printing perfectly.

Packaging:
The main box came with a lot of padding and inside there were smaller boxes with more padding. I was worried about the glass bed and the acrylic frame breaking during shipping, but everything was in perfect condition, no cracks or broken pieces. Every part came in it's own bag, numbered and labeled according to the instructions manual on their website, which made it really easy to identify the parts for each step. All the electronic parts came in anti-static bags. They even include a bag of extra screws/nuts/washers, and there are some extra parts (1 extra stepper driver, 2 extra ball bearings).

Issues:
I only had 2 issues during my build. The rods for the X axis wouldn't go in all the way on the holes on the carriage, I read that someone else had the same issue and decided to cut the rods, but I was able to identify that the issue was not the hole's depth, which was more than enough, but with some extra plastic in the whole that prevented the rod to go all the way in. I shaved it a bit with a drill bit and was able to get them to the proper depth. The other issue was with the Arduino Mega, the socket that goes from pin 14 to 21 was soldered incorrectly, shifted by 1 pin, so it started on 15 and ended up in the screw hole, but it is not the first time I've seen this happen on an Arduino clone board, and nothing a soldering iron couldn't fix. To me these 2 issues are minor and not enough to take a star off my review, and it's all part of the DIY experience.

Recommendations:
As someone else recommended here and on their forums, I swapped the Y end stop switch and put it on the left side of the frame since it sits too close to the front right bed leveling screw. I also had the issue they mentioned with one of the screws that holds the ball joints on the bed was hitting the back of the frame, I just added some of the extra washers on the top of that screw and problem solved.

Final Thoughts:
Overall this is a really good printer, especially for the price and a USA backing manufacturer. It looks really nice, just love the black acrylic finish. Since this is new to me, for validation I just showed my first prints to some colleagues that have been printing for a while and they said overall the quality was really good, especially for being my first prints.
summary: My first 3D printer and I love it. Customer support is awesome.

reviewText:
I had some extra money and i always wanted to buy a 3d printer for my personal use and to keep at work for the occasional prototype.  I have an engineering/machining background.  I also have experience in 3D printing due to a course i had in college.  Our machines were much higher-end machines (Stratasys and OBJET) so i knew about file formats and slicing. This is my first experience however with a consumer grade machine and i am deeply enjoying a challenge.

The Problems:
When i first received the package, i took an inventory and i found nothing was missing.  I did find one of the support legs of the main frame had a chip out of the plexiglass.  Quick email to support@reprapguru.com and the part is on its way.  These things happen and i am more than satisfied with how it was handled.

Another problem i had was when i plugged in the Ramps 1.4 board, the Arduino would shut off and would send an alert to my computer that it was drawing too much power.  I double checked that my limit switches were oriented correctly (Manual makes this perfectly clear you can destroy a voltage regulator on the Arduino Mega if you have them backward.)  I located the problem on one of the switches itself.  The switch had a solder bridge on it so it was shorting two pins together.  Thankfully my board wasn't destroyed.

Finally, i wish the printer came with tech-flex so that we can tame the medusa of wires after all the connections are made.

The good:
This machine is infinitely adaptable and if you understand the process... quite capable of excellent print quality.  I bought it hoping it wouldn't require too much tweaking (i don't like unnecessary tweaking) but understand it is a necessary evil sometimes.  This machine has brought it to a manageable level.  If you have no desire to troubleshoot or find it hard to think critically to why a problem has arisen, maybe try another machine.  If you follow the directions though, you will be very close to what you need to get up and running.  I am very glad i purchased this machine vs. a davinci jr.

Setup:
It took me about 8 hours total from unboxing to printing.  Again i am an engineer who understands how limit switches, controllers, and stepper motors interface.  The instructions are thorough enough for a beginner, just don't be in a rush or get frustrated if you have a couple quirks to work out.  I will be buying another if i find i need more machine capacity.

Update: 5/13/16
This review was done of my own free will to help others make decisions on going with this seller and printer.  I did receive a roll of Black PLA after it was written from the company.
summary: Glad i bought this vs. Davinci Jr.

reviewText:
I went to college back in the mid-90's and received my BSEE degree. However, since then I've been in IT. I'm getting back into electronics again, mainly as a hobby due to the IOT revolution. Let me tell you.... This thing is FANTASTIC. The quality seems great and the features....well, I will never use all the features. Numerous math functions including FFT... I've used expensive analog scopes in college and massive spectrum analyzers that probably cost a fortune back in the day. This is not as good as a dedicated spectrum analyzer, however for a hobbiest, I can't see ever needing anything more. It has basic logic anayzer functions. The features are too numerous to mention. Look at Dave's youtube review (guy from EEVBlog) for most of the details.
I still have my 20MHz analog scope, but don't think I'll ever use it again. I remember back in college using a Polaroid camera to take pictures of waveforms to add to my reports. Lol, this is like dream compared to those days.

It's hackable to 100Mhz and ability to unlock all the features via software. I would buy this again without hesitation. If I was using this to make money, maybe I would spend the extra cash for a Tektronix or HP/Agilent. Maybe...only because those are trusted name brands that have been making these devices for half a century. But, Chinese test equipment manufactures are eating their lunch on the budget end!
summary: A model T Ford is to a Tesla as my 20MHz analog scope is to this Rigol DS1054z

reviewText:
This is VERY good duck tape indeed ("duck" is correct, although nothing wrong with "duct"). It has a vinyl layer and a fabric layer as usual. Tearing is easy despite its strength. Adhesion is superior to any other duck tape I have tried, second only to Gorilla tape. When you stick it to itself it is very difficult to pry apart.

See Photo below. I stuck tape to the sides of a 20 lb weight. I used regular duck, T-Rex tape, and Gorilla Tape. Here is how long before the weight dropped, Also ran same comparison with weight and tape immersed.

-Duck tape: 6.5 minutes. Wet: 3 min.

-T-Rex tape 2 hrs. 17 minutes Wet: 2 hrs. 26 min.

-Gorilla tape 4 hours 26 minutes. Wet: 6 hrs. 30 min. (?)

So: great tape.
summary: The Best Duck Tape... Except for Gorilla Tape

reviewText:
I've tried the Gorilla duct tape and also the Iron Grip.  They held fairly well, but the most challenging application I have is in the garden - lots of dirt and water.  I was using some gaffers tape on some bucket handles and it wouldn't stay stuck more than a season. This stuff is working well so far, will update at the end of the summer.

The picture is this tape at the bottom of a 25 gallon tub - we use it in the garden as an overflow from a rain barrel.  Holding up, leak-proof so far.  I did clean the surface well with both detergent and rubbing alcohol.

As far as I can tell, the tape is as strong as the Gorilla and a little bit better than the Iron Grip, adhesive is at least as good as the Gorilla.
summary: T-REX beats Gorilla, Iron Grip...

reviewText:
I've added some photos for comparison.  The adhesive sides look the same, so there's an edge shot to show thickness and a front shot.  Also a photo of my duct-tape wall.  Yea - I use a lot of the stuff.

The obvious comparison for T-Rex tape would be Gorilla tape.  Apart from the fact that they both have annoying commercials, they are the same thickness and extra thick design.  I'd say both T-Rex and Gorilla are identical thicknesses.  The adhesive on the T-Rex does seem more grippy, and the material a little stronger. Gorilla tape has a slightly rubbery feel to the surface, while T-Rex is slick. T-Rex is also gray. The tape color is very close to the adhesive color.

The tape sticks and grabs very well, and because it's so strong and thick, it can take a lot more tension and tugging than regular duct tape.  Burnishing the tape (applying back and forth pressure to it - an old spoon works great) really makes it stick, even to wood.  As with any duct tape, it can rip when you tear it at the edge.  You really don't want to use scissors - the adhesive will stick to most blades.

I'd say this is a step up from Gorilla tape, and Gorilla tape is many steps up from regular duct tape.
summary: A step up from Gorilla Tape. Strong and has plenty of grip.

reviewText: I got this mini float valve to install inside my Keurig water tank so it would automatically refill itself. This little valve works perfectly. The valve itself needs a 5/8" hole through which the mounting shaft fits. I drilled the hole easily with a step drill similar to the Vastar Titanium Step Drill Cone Drill Bits, High Speed Steel 10 Steps 1/4" to 1-3/8". They work great when cutting holes in thin plastic as they gradually cut the hole with very little stress on the plastic. You tighten the valve body into place with a plastic nut that compresses a silicon washer on the inside and a hard plastic washer on the outside. This leaves a threaded hole exposed in the valve. After wrapping a generous length of teflon tape over the fine threads of the 90-degree elbow (I had to do this three times, increasing the teflon each time until the threads no longer leaked) you screw the elbow into the valve body. I stopped when the elbow faced rearward. At this point you can insert standard 1/4" polyethylene tubing into the elbow until it reaches its stop. If you need to adapt to 3/8" tubing, you'll still need a short length of 1/4" tubing to use the included 1/4" to 3/8" adapter/coupling. I didn't need that. You really only need 1/4" tubing to feed the tank as you're only replenishing the 10 ounces of water used to make a single cup of coffee after each brewing. A trickle is all you need. But the valve refills the tank almost immediately. I'd highly recommend having a main valve further down the line before the float valve. This allows you to turn the water off if you need to clean or decalcify the coffee maker or otherwise stop the water flow. I had already installed a $6.43 plastic 1/4" to 1/4" ball valve John Guest PPSV040808WP Single Straight Shut-Off Valve, 1/4" Tube OD x 1/4" for an earlier coffee maker that I had plumbed with a different float valve. The water comes from our reverse osmosis system that supplies water to the sink and refrigerator icemaker. This valve works well because as you can see from the pictures, the valve has to come through the top of the tank lid. This means the float arm needs to articulate. A stainless screw allows the plastic knee joint to adjust the float to suit the desired water level. The float fits easily inside my particular Keurig with about 1/2" to spare on either side of the float as it rides up and down on the water surface. The indicated dimensions of 45mm diameter x 74mm long appear to be accurate. I did put a piece of Scotch tape on the lid to hold the lid onto the tank. If someone were to remove the lid, it would bring the valve out with it, the float would lower and water would start flowing. Best to lock the lid onto the tank with a piece of tape. My previous mini-float valve worked flawlessly for more than ten years. I only retired it because the coffeemaker failed and its design called for a float that mounted on the back of the tank. This valve has to come in from the top. The valves are very simple with no parts to corrode. I hope to get the same service from this valve.
summary: Perfect For Plumbing a Keurig Coffeemaker Water Tank

reviewText: The Esun petg prints fairly well. It does like to be printed at a lower temp than normal colors. I've had best results at 220 for the hot end and 70 for the hot bed. Printed in a Prusa i3 MK2 and adheres to the pei sheet well. Allow to cool and the print will come off easily. There was some dots of filament when extruder moved to another model on the bed, I offset this a bit with random start points. You can altogether eliminate this by printing one object at a tome for very clean prints

reviewText: An OK set. After careful inspection, 3 of the burrs have issues. Larger cylindrical burr can cut with about 1/4 of the circumference; the other 3/4 of the circumference have inadequate cutting edges (which I tried to photograph and highlight a bit at random) from the off-center forming process, so 3/4 of the edges will end up rubbing against the material instead of removing it. Smaller cylindrical burr will cut with about 2/3 of the circumference for the same reason. Larger ball burr has an air pocket at the brazing. It's probably on there well enough and won't fly off, but who knows until that happens... Got to wear protection! Other burrs in the set have good cutting edges.
summary: 3 burrs have issues.

reviewText:
When you live in a house with all hardwood floors throw rugs become a fact of life. And keeping them from slip-sliding away becomes a hard reality.  Most of the throw rugs I buy don't have rubberized backing, as they tend to be handmade or craft rugs, so long ago I started getting those sticky waffle pads that are supposed to keep throw rugs from slipping. They are not easy to find as few places sell them and if they do their stock is very limited. And they cost far more than they should, in the range of ten bucks for a small size. But the worst part is they only stay sticky for so long and then they become useless.

So when I saw this as a featured item I figured why not, one roll is about the same as only one waffle pad. There were some positive reviews and some at the other extreme but I gave it try.

The good news is that it does what it should. I had no problems with it sticking to a variety of rug backings and to my dry-mopped but not otherwise specially cleaned floors. The tape is very sticky and it conforms to the irregular surface of handmade rugs. But other than that, its hard to get very excited about it; its only a roll of tape that does what I expected it to.

I had to do some serious thinking though about how to rate it. Should I rate it only on the physical product or should I include customer service, which many people consider to be an important part of anything they buy. Frankly, if I included the seller in how I rate it I wouldnt even give it 1-star. I don't know who advised the company it was all right to send not one, not two but THREE unsolicited spam emails (so far) starting with one I received even before I received the product.  This stuff is only a roll of tape, not some groundbreaking new technological miracle, but their emails nagging for a review are like small novels.  Whoever advised them that this is okay is wrong  only one seller in 200 or so sends review requests and even then they only send one email and it is short and sweet. If you don't like to get on a spam list you may want to consider this when deciding on this brand.

Rated on the product doing what it is advertised to do, it meets expectations, hence an average rating of 3-stars.
summary: It is sticky, but

reviewText:
Hello everyone,
Well, I have had the Robo for a few months now, and I am pretty happy with it. As many will say, 3D printing is not quite consumer ready yet. That said, it is great for people who are willing to take the time to tweak the settings to get things just right. You can come out with some pretty impressive results.

Starting off, my printer didn't move right, just after getting it unpacked. It would go up, but it wouldn't move down very far. After talking to some people on the forums, I discovered that the X axis was not level due to not being level on the Z axis threaded rods. I used a digital caliper to level them, and it printed beautifully. My best advice, go to the forums, and ask for help. Even if they don't point out the exact problem, they will help figure things out.

MatterControl, the default software, works well with the Robo. It is great for getting started, or if you don't want to tweak the printer very much. I don't despise it, unalike the people on the forums. That said, it does have its limitations. I don't blame the devs for these limitations, it is great free software, I have no room to complain. It works right out of the box.

After reading some of the suggestions on the forums, I decided to try out Simplify 3D. It is not exactly plug and play with the Robo, unlike MC. That said, its ability to add and manipulate supports is second to none (as near as I can tell). It also gives you access to pretty much every setting you could want access to. You will have to tweak the Z axis offset, and possibly need to print with the SD card. The firmware on the printer occasionally stops communicating with the software, so that can cause problems. No one knows the exact reason why it happens, but we have found ways to work around it.

As a bit of a side note, only use the starter filament (the stuff that comes with your printer) for a little while. It is kinda cheap filament, that has some issues printing some items. I would recommend Hatchbox filaments, they seem to print quite nicely. I have yet to try anything other than PLA, so I won't advise anything there.

The Robo's firmware has temperature limits built in, so you may have to change them if you want to print at higher, or lower temperatures than the default limits. It is pretty easy to do, so don't worry about it. Just take a look at the forums, and ask for help if you can't find what you are looking for.

Over all, the Robo is a good machine. Yes, people have had problems with it. You will have problems with virtually any of these complex machines. Remember, you are getting in at a time when hobby 3D printing is really just getting started. The Robo can provide very good prints, it can also have problems. Usually, it just takes carefully thinking through the problem, and troubleshooting it. Just like the early days of computers.

Please see some of my prints below as examples of what you can get.

Update 12/12/2015:
I am updating this to warn people that the 6 month warrantee is pretty much worthless. The company really doesn't cover much, so don't expect much actual assistance from the company.

Basically, during normal operation, the print bed chipped. There is now a chunk of glass embedded in one of my prints, and a sizeable chunk missing from the build plate. Robo's warrantee doesn't cover this at all. Buying a replacement print bed is about $100, so it isn't cheap.

I am moving from 4 stars to 3 simply because I don't like how deceptive the 6 month warrantee is. It sounds like the company will help you out during that time for standard wear and tear, that isn't the case.

I have not gone lower than 3 because the printer has worked great until this point. So far, this is the greatest knock against it. I may suggest thinking of one of the other printers if you are on the edge. Printrbot "might" be a better choice. I have not tried them, so I don't know for sure. I just might suggest taking a longer look at other printers.

Update 12/15/2015:
I need to correct my earlier statement of the replacement print bed costing $100. The person I have been talking to through Robo has offered a replacement for $40 + shipping. This minimizes the sting a bit, but I won't put my rating higher. I still think that this should be covered under the warrantee. What is the point of it being 6 months, if it only really covers damage during shipping?

I am less ticked, but I still recommend not expecting much from the 6 month warrantee. The printer works great when it works, which was most of the last few months. This is the first major issue to pop up. So, get the printer for its merits, and forget the warrantee.

Update 4/2/2016
I was able to set up the replacement print bed pretty easily. I decided to add a quick release, which made it pretty nice for completely removing the bed, without having to open the machine. I decided to up my rating for the machine simply because it is still working. As a few people have pointed out, the company's warrantee does cover several key components.
I will admit that I was being a bit petty about the print bed, they did discount it. Generally the machine has been solid. Most of my problems have been caused by my inexperience. I have had no real problems with the machine since the printed bed. I bought some blue painter's tape, and have that applied over the bed. To the best of my knowledge, I have not had the bed chip since. I miss having glassy bottomed prints, but the matte look has its own appeal. :-)

Update 7/21/2017
I have had my Robo for around 2 years now. I recently switched out a bearing that went bad on the hobbled bolt. I also have upgraded it to a dual extruder printer, using the E3D Legends pack, particularly the Chimera setup. It is still a bit rough, but it works. :-) I had to switch from the custom RAMPS board that came with the printer, over to a standard RAMPS 1.4 board. I also had to print out a new X-carriage, along with a few other parts. It was challenging, but quite a learning experience.
Though, like many on the forums, I would suggest buying a dual extruder printer pre-made if you can afford it. I only did it because I had the Robo, and dual extruders in my price range didn't have a build area nearly as large.
summary: A Quality Printer (Look at Latest Update)

reviewText:
I purchased the ROBO 3D R1 Plus printer from a local electronics store. Spent a couple of days including hours of interaction with the Robo 3D support before I was able to get the printer properly calibrated and running. Here is a summary of my experience and impression of this budget 3D printer.

Overall appearance and packaging

- the printer comes in a nice attractive box packed in heavy foam materials. The package includes a tool box with the necessary tools for doing our own maintenance and lubrication. It also comes with a glue stick for the heatbed and a sample 300g spool of PLA filament. This is nice as this would get us going without having to buy the parts and materials.
- what surprised me a bit was that the movable parts (x-axis and z-axis motors assemblies) were not well secured by taping materials to avoid shipping damages. For my other color laser printers which have similar weight and sizes as the Robo 3D printer, they came with all the movable parts secured by tapes with clear instructions on removing and unpacking them. To no surprises, I found that the Z-end stop brackets were popped out. A couple of wiring connectors and a 5-pin motor control connector all came loose probably due to shipping and handling. I had to contact Robo3D support and receive a video instruction on putting the Z-end stop brackets back into its place.

Installation and software

- The printers comes with a third-party software (MatterControl) on a SD card. Installation was pretty straight-forward. It also comes with a video instructions on assembling the printer.
- The software comes with a load of features for controlling the printer quality, materials, and tuning / calibration. It also comes with a library of 26 ready to be printed 3D-models. The software shows the approximate print duration based on the materials, quality and complexity of the model. However, it does not show the remaining print time which could be very useful for monitoring the print status,
- Once the print job begins, it would preheat the extruder and bed temperature before the actual printing starts. We can also pause or cancel the job anytime via the control panel.

Operation
- I started with printing the calibration circle model. To my dismay, the printer head's z-axis position was way high up from the heatbed and the printing turned out a messed up pile of dispensed filament. After searching on the web and support web site, I figured that the problem probably had to do with the Z-axis calibration. I also found that the wire connectors to the motors assemblies were not well secured and came loose quite easily
- Fortunately Robo 3D had a nice support structure which allows us to book a 45 minutes appointment with a technician. The support personnel turned out to be quite knowledgeable and walked me through the calibration process over the phone. After the calibration, I was able to print the calibration circle perfectly. The calibration process was a bit tedious which should have been documented in the user manual or on the website.
After the proper calibration, I did a couple of test prints which all turned out nice. Finally a happy camper.

Overall
- the Robo 3D is a nice budget 3D printer which can handle nice print volumes. There are quite a few rooms for improvements in their packaging, wiring assemblies, and calibration procedures. However, the support team is great and knowledgeable.  If you are mechanically inclined and don't mind to work through some tedious process to get the printer properly calibrated, this would be a good product to consider.
summary: Nice budget 3D printer with rooms for improvement

reviewText:
Update: I built a Scanning Tunneling Electron Microscope using this as a feed to the X and Y axis, with a piezo feeding the Z axis. Also, I got the sonoluminescence project to work: glowing water :)

I have a few really old oscilloscopes, but to this is my first signal generator that wasn't Synthesizer musical keyboard.

Other reviewers mentioned the cool stuff you can do, like hooking this to a computer and drawing your own arbitrary waveforms.

I'm using this for sonoluminesce: feed 25kHz to a piezoelectric transducer glued to a round distillation flask filled with water. A standing wave is formed that will trap an air bubble. The bubble will collapse and GLOW!

Anyway, for my purposes at the moment this is awesome! I plugged in the two BNC cables. Each has two alligator clips at the other end. I clipped those onto the leads of a piezoelectric speaker disc (also tried it with RCA cable hooked to an amplifier and two stereo speakers) and I heard the sine wave!

I turned the knob and the tone got higher. The cool part: I hit "shift" and selected the amplitude parameters. Turning the knob increased the voltage which made the wave I could hear get louder! Big deal: a volume knob? Well, in my electron microscope, sonoluminescence, piezo, oscilloscope experiments voltages can be important and the ability to set them is very, very nice.

So: in a pinch you could put the two alligator clips onto a headphone's jack and actually hear the tone. A very nice high output, that you can turn up louder. Of course, humans only hear about 20Hz-20kHz.

My goal is around 25.1kHz which will trap a bubble in a standing wave because it will be the resonant frequency of the glass distillation flask.

This is also easier to use for calibration than a synth keyboard.

You can apparently set a sweep range and speed, so I'll be able to set automatically sweep from say 25kHz to 26kHz so I don't have to turn the knob while I watch for cavatation in the water.

This device is super lightweight, but it works. It's light meaning that if you go to press a button it will slide away from you on the table. I just found a heavier piece of equipment to jam on top of it: problem solved.

All devices like this are best left running for a few minutes so they can stabilize. Some online instructions also said not to move the unit while it was running...which is why you should anchor/wedge it somewhere so it's not sliding around.

Michael Logusz
Science and Optics
summary: Sonoluminesce

reviewText: This desiccant is excellent for 3D printer filament. I was having problems with my 3D printer filament absorbing moisture. I added two of these desiccant packets to my zip lock bag and the filament is now dry. These packets are a nice size. I also use them in my custom filament canister shown in the photo. I'll be buying more to match my increasing collection filament rolls.
summary: Excellent for Keeping 3D Printer Filament Dry

reviewText:
I wanted to try a non primary color. I am very new to 3d printing and silver seemed to intrigue me. So I got recommended Inland so I picked this.

Add to cart
Amazon prime
2 days later here we are

How well did it print on the first try? It was great. This PLA runs hotter than my first roll of white. That ran at 190-195. I leveled the bed and it stuck to the glass with no glue or hairspray with a bed temp of 60 deg c. I guess I am just supprised how well it laid down. Oh yea also I am using a 0.4 tip printing at .2 resolution (for the majority)

As for the color it looks kinda like silver. More like a crayons crayon silver rather than sterling. About 2 out of 5 people have called it grey. There is a shimmer to it.

The one thing I did notice is that if you print it with a brim let it cool down cold before you try to rip it off. If it's still an it warm it doesn't peel off clean. Same with supports.

Overall : This was a good buy for the price and the quality. I will buy this again and I will try other colors.
summary: PLA that lays down right.

reviewText: So far so good, I've gone through 2 1/2 spools of Hatchbox PETG without serious issue. It does string a little more than PLA but it is so much easier to finish. It easier to sand and file, is more flexible.
summary: My new goto filament

reviewText:
First use of PETG, I've only ever used PLA. The roll was perfectly sealed with a large desiccant. I had to up my normal PLA temp from 210 to 220 to get good adhesion. The biggest difference is how flexible the prints are (not rubbery though) compared to PLA and the filament itself is much less brittle. I do not have a heated bed and just print direct to glass with Gluestik and it worked just as good as PLA. Removing the print was easier than PLA since the part flexes and peels off instead of popping off.

So far so good and I will continue to update my review as I gain more experience.

Update 4/16/2016: Here is what I've discovered with the material and this particular roll.
1. The PETG likes higher temps (235C is what I'm using now
2. It's easy to clean up prints I like the feel (sort of waxy)
3. I want to try clear next

For this roll;
1. It's heavy and takes more force to unwind - not a big deal form my extruder (EZstruder) but I could see issues with lesser ones. The good news is that the filament is so tough that it doesn't stretch or snap like PLA.
2. Two 4+ hour prints have been ruined by kinks in the filament (see image). I'm deducting 1 star since these kinks ocurred in back t back prints. I still like the material but keep this in mind.
summary: So far so good - update, some issues with the roll

reviewText:
This was my first PETG purchase, but not my last! I love PETG, it prints well with virtually no smell and the prints are very durable with just the right amount of flex. I don't have any other brands to compare it with, but i'm sure it doesn't get much better than this.

Getting it figured out takes a little bit of getting used to (not much.) The temperature will depend on your conditions (print speed, ambient temp, and accuracy of thermistor.) For me 245 is what got me my best results on my MP select mini with E3D hotend. There is some oozing that needs to be dealt with when the printer sits preheated at idle. I just make sure to prime the nozzle and start the print immediately. With retraction enabled in Cura I have not had any issues with stringing. I use blue painters tape wiped down with 91% isopropyl alcohol for bed adhesion with the bed temp around 50. My bed heater is weak, so I use a raft when printing for extra adhesion.

Once all of your settings are dialed in, you will love PETG if you haven't already had the pleasure of using it before.

Attached photo is my 3D Benchy printed in Hatchbox blue PETG.
summary: I love PETG.

reviewText:
I've been using PLA exclusively since I began 3D printing a year ago. I've mostly been using it to make models and mockups, nothing really with a structural or high mechanical need.  I'm currently printing out a D-Bot on thingiverse and it said that PLA will crack and not be able to adequately support the machine.  I have a reprap prusa I3 printer (Reprapguru) and my hot end can do ABS.  ABS stinks though and may be too rigid for a project like this.  I decided to print the pieces I needed out with PETG due to it being strong and slightly more flexible.

Printing:
-Prints just lovely.  I have not tried other manufactures of PETG but it prints just fine with some slight tweaks. Make sure your bed is PERFECTLY leveled and it will take right off.  I had marginal success with printing it directly to glass, but with blue tape it stays dead flat.

Settings:
Extruder:260C
Bed:80C
Bed Covering:Blue Tape

I like this material and will be buying more in the future. Happy Printing!
summary: Good Material, Prints Great in RepRap Prusia I3

reviewText: A nice filament for multiple uses. This is easier to use than ABS (no heated print bed is needed so make sure you turn the heated bed setting off or way down) and more flexible than PLA. I found that it prints with very sharp detail when the printer is set for the highest resolution. This Hatchbox "RED" color was actually red and not an orange shade like others I have used. Overall a really nice plastic.
summary: My new "go to" filament!

reviewText:
I had all kinds of problems trying to print with this PETG. I thought it was just me for awhile, but after a little bit of testing and changing to a different brand of filament, I realize it wasn't me.

For whatever reason it seems to be brittle and breaks easily with poor layer adhesion. I'm going to try a different color of Hatchbox PETG, however for now the silver is just unusable for me. I would have returned it, but I used so much of it just trying to get a good print that I'm about halfway through the roll.
summary: Two Stars

reviewText:
These tie downs are ESSENTIAL for my workshop.

My "workshop" is outside on my deck.  My larger tools are all on mobile carts.  The wheely carts help keep my wife happy because we can "use the deck as it was intended."

But back to OUTSIDE.  Carts with wheels--even locking wheels--may need to be securely tied down.  We live on the top of a ridge with fairly high wind exposure.  Storm gusts of 60+ mph will happen several times in a summer.  I depend on these Pro Grip tie downs to keep my carts where I put them.

Each cart gets four 1200 pound tie downs to use when needed.  They have proven adequate for this purpose.  I usually use 1/4" lag screws with a split washer to fasten the tie downs to the wooden frames of the carts.

Photos show my clamp cart, planer cart, and router table cart.  Two tie downs are visible on each.  (I have ways to keep everything dry but the wind, the wind, the wind.  Can't stop the wind.)

Really glad I started using these tie downs.
summary: DEPENDABLE and ESSENTIAL for my workshop.

reviewText:
Ugh,

Cut the existing thermostat out of my deep freezer, checked all of my voltages and whatnot with my multimeter, went to hook up this new thermostat.. oops, bad solder connection on the 'cooling' side of the terminals. The whole block just fell off inside the case before I even got a wire into it. Ugh. Guess I have to order another one, since my new freezer is massacred in the garage now.

Ordered a second unit to replace the faulty first one, powered on just only the 110vac input, and the display will only show nonsense characters. Can't do much with no readable display, or perhaps I should learn to read Klingon. Plus the unit sits there and clicks on and off while displaying dots and lines. I think I'll try for a third unit. I guess.

Update: Okay, I plugged in unit #3, with just power and the temperature probe. Wow, no gibberish! I setup all of the settings (which were not at their default settings by the way). Then powered off the unit, hooked up the two switched lines (hot/compressor), then powered back on. Finally! Success! The unit works exactly like it was supposed to, after two other bad units. I'm giving one star, because the first two made me that mad. My freezer has successfully been a 47F fridge for three days now.

Final update: I spoke with the company that sold the two defective units to me, and they went above and beyond to rectify the situation via email. I had already ordered a third (working) unit, and I am happy with that. So the company refunded my money for the other two purchases, without me having to re-label and resend the packages back. I changed my star rating from one to three stars, because of the customer service I received.

The unit has been running fine for five days now, and I check the temperature of the compressor and unit itself with a laser thermometer, just to make sure they aren't overworking themselves, and they are fine. Had I received a good thermostat right at first, I would have easily given five stars - and a shorter review.
summary: Third time is a charm

reviewText:
Worked great

This is the 240vac version being used with all 12v equipment to cool some SONOS amps

For those that can't get it to work - The unit does not supply power to your device - it is a switch and need to be inline with the + side
summary: Worked great This is the 240vac version being used with all ...

reviewText: Worked awesome as a temp controller form my fermentation chamber. Was concerned about the 10 amp rating but so far so good. Gonna build another using this unit.
summary: Works great!

reviewText:
Summary: Super fun, ideal for ages ~9 and up, though good for as young as ~6-7.

I missed out on the Kickstarter for the 3Doodler 1.0, and in hindsight that was a good thing.  From what I can tell, the 3Doodler 2.0 is a much, much improved product.  That said, its still not perfect, and so takes some tuning / getting used to.  I managed to score my 2.0 on Kickstarter this time, and have been playing with it nonstop for over a week.  It does take some getting used to - the first ~2 strands I used didn't amount to anything, but I've just finished a cool mechanical sculpture.

>>>Starting up the pen
First of all, you have to realize that the feed mechanism has a long lead-in.  This means that from when the pen grabs the strand to when you start to get extruded melt takes time  like a good minute or so.  Take a look at where the strand is feeding into the pen, and if you can see it moving in, continue waiting.  Only if it appears stalled should you start to rotate the strand (gently) clockwise.

>>>Shutting down the pen
If Im planning to start back up with the same strand, I will back the strand up 10 blinks, then unplug.  ODepending on what I plan to do, I will either remove the strand

>>>Adjusting the pen temperature
For now I am finding it easier to work in 2D, then assemble the pieces into 3D.  This means its easier to work with a higher temp  about half a rotation on the adjustment screw.  If I want to extrude a thread which stands, I blow on it gently as it comes out to cool it faster.  As I get better, I will likely turn the temp back down.  One plus of the higher temp is better welding and faster feed, though there might be a higher risk of jamming.

>>>Jamming
My theory on the distance between the feed gears and the melt chamber is that if the strand gets soft in the feed gears, it jams.  Note that the instructions indicate that you may need to let the 3Doodler rest from time to time.
