I suspect that this is because the pen gets too warm - my observation is that this tends to happen more when you let the pen sit.  If you keep drawing and feeding more strand in, it doesn't have time to get hot inside the feed gears .  If the pen stops feeding while you're using it, give it a good few seconds, then back the strand out (press fast and slow feed simultaneously) then clip off the melted portion and start feeding again.

>>>ABS vs PLA
They are not kidding about ventilation, though its much more with the ABS.  I ran about 3-4 strands through in the kitchen, which has decent airflow, but I got a bit of a headache from the smell.  Will set up a small fan nearby next time.  PLA on the other hand in our kitchen was no problem.  ABS does better standing structures though as it cools faster due to the higher melt temp.

>>>Coil stock
I bought a ~1 lb spool of 3 mm PLA - it works perfectly except that you do have to straighten it out a little before you use it.  As the strand does rotate as it feeds, you need to also cut it to a managable length.  I've been cutting mine to perhaps 15" then manually unbending it a little.  This also softens up the PLA so its not as rigid.  I cut off a bunch at a time and re-vacuum seal the spool so it doesn't absorb moisture.

>>>Tips:
1) Use a fine tip sharpie to mark the strand when you're feeding - that way you can tell if it's moving or not
2) Get yourself a set of small diagonal cutters - much easier to snip the strand
3) Toss the larger silicone heat cover - it's useless and just gets in the way
4) Double press the slow feed to start up a new strand and go read a book.  Seriously though, it takes a lot longer than you think it should.
5) Get a clear flexible piece of plastic - I use a 5 mil empty laminating pouch.  I can then draw a pattern with pencil on paper, then use the 3Doodler to draw on the plastic - it sticks enough that you can work, then it pops off cleanly when finished.
6) Get a small fan to keep the area ventilated, and also to cool your projects as you are working on them
7) If you 3Doodler sketch is warped or bent, draw on it with some new material - this typically heats the part up enough that you can bend it a little, then hold it until it cools
8) Don't be afraid to incorporate other materials in your sketches - PLA in particular sticks very well to paper, toothpicks, wood blocks, etc.

If you have questions, comments, or found this review helpful, please let me know!
summary: Practice makes perfect  key tips for using, including coiled stock

reviewText:
AC Power Adapter for LotFancy Upper Arm Blood Pressure Monitor,UL Listed (6V 1A Adapter)

If you have one of the LotFancy upper arm blood pressure machines and want to save on batteries, getting this A/C adapter is a great idea. It is designed for this series of BP machines and if you aren't moving the machine around a lot, it lets you just keep it plugged in and ready to go. The quality of the adapter is just fine and will serve you well and save money on batteries.

This product was provided at or nearly no cost for the purpose of evaluation and review.
summary: Save on batteries, get the A/C adapter

reviewText:
I was able to connect to both MacBook and Dell laptops (eventually). Only real problem is attachments (mirror) are too-wide for standard spark-plug hole, but camera itself will fit (see photo). Camera is 0.335"-diameter, attachments are 0.575"-diameter, spark-plug hole is about 0.520'-diameter.

It took me 4-computers to get the software installed, because small-diameter CD doesn't work in self-loading drives (only in "tray-drives"). Software isn't needed though, as there are no drivers on the CD (it's a "USB Camera", compliant with Windows7 and my OS-X). But the software has some nice features, if you're using in a PC-environment (software not Mac-compliant).
summary: One major-flaw, otherwise decent

reviewText:
This review refers to the Endoscope model TD0310 with the 5 m cable.  A specialist accessory received for evaluation and review.  There are a whole range of uses for this versatile tool, but in a nutshell, it allows a thorough investigation of small, dark, hidden, out-of-range spaces.  The idea is the same as the medical version, a long flexible tube with a camera head (8.5 mm in this case) and some strong LED lights to illuminate the way at one end and a standard USB connector at the other.  The camera resolution offers a very useful quality range: up to 600 x 1200 pixels, and the images we get are really sharp, especially after a little experimentation.  The ability to regulate the light intensity is a definite asset.  This unit is waterproof and appears to be very tough and fit for the its intended applications;  some examples: investigating the state of a location out of reach of fingers and eyesight; locating an obstruction inside a tube or conduit (even full of water); verifying the condition of the back of appliances that cannot be moved; car repairs.  It's the sort of thing that, once you own it, you will find many uses for, that are not immediately apparent.

We initially tested it by photographing the inside of a Hummingbird electrified guitar.  The output jack had worked loose once again (it had already been sent back for professional remedial action once).  Due to the very limited space inside the guitar body, just enough for a slim hand, it was essential to know the exact situation.  We had already spent a lot of frustrating time trying to screw the piece back on.  Once the Endoscope head had been put into position, we were able to view the whole area and identify both the problem and the solution.  We fixed the guitar in under one minute.

In the box are the endoscope itself, some small tools that attach to the camera head (a hook, mirror and magnet), software installation CD, and a manual (also on the CD). The software loaded without problems on a laptop running Win 8.1.  Manoeuvring the photo head was easy enough (it would be even easier inside a tube), taking still photos and especially video were intuitive and successful.  The other option is to simply view the camera's progress on the screen, but recording the images may be useful.  I was quite blown away by the quality of the images, and the performance of this brilliant diagnostic tool.  I'll be making a video as soon as I have a moment, but for now I'll just post some photos and a screenshot taken from video footage.
summary: Brilliant diagnostic tool for those small, dark places

reviewText: ***Added a short video of the ottoman lid closing using these shocks*** We found an awesome ottoman we really liked four our babies room so we bought it to hold all of his books. Once we got it home and loaded with books we realized the top was really heavy and closed hard. I knew that as soon as our kid was standing and walking he would smash his fingers. I had some cabinet soft close hinges that I tried to add but they weren't enough so I went on the search for shocks and found these. Glad I did as they work great! Not the original design for these but nonetheless did what we wanted. The only slight complaint is they work well until the last inch or so and then close quickly. I didn't remove any stars though because these weren't designed for an ottoman top to not smash a kids fingers so I don't tbink thats a product shortcoming. I went ahead and still used the soft close hinges as that helped remove that last little bit of force when closing. The other positive is now the top stays open much easier. Before it didn't stay open very well but no issues anymore. Included a couple pics. Took a little fiddling around with gas shock positions to work best. Essentially installing it one way the shock pushes and the other way it pulls. So I flipped them around a couple ways to find the best combo which turned out to be having one pushing and one pulling. Let me know do you have any questions as this was a little out of the ordinary but we are very happy with the results!
summary: Great hinges, used for ottoman to hold books in babies room

reviewText:
I got the unit and was skeptical, but could see that it is of pretty decent quality for the price. Being that i am from the world of precision machinery, I got out my dial indicator and started taking some measurements. Everything was good, accurate to within tolerance for excellent 3d printing except for the bed. After leveling the bed with a dial indicator to less than 0.001" between each of the 4 corner posts adjustment screw locations), the bed was "bowed" towards the center upwards about 0.012" at its middle (not so good for large prints). This was completely unacceptable to say the least.

 I was not going to be so easily defeated, as i had heard the same complaint from a lot of other 3d printers with this same type of bed. I removed the bed, an aluminum plate with heater elements embedded into its under side held by 4 screws and a connector, and rolled 2 medium sized bath towels onto a hard floor, and placed the bed so that it was suspended in the center (high area). I then used my hands to press it downwards and "flex it" the direction it needed to go. I spent an hour or so progressively flexing the bed a bit (a little harder each time), then re-installing it, leveling it, and checking it. It took about 200 pounds of force (spread fairly evenly) to flex it back the other way, and about 8 or 9 progressive attempts while being careful not to over-do it.

  Needless to say, I eventually got it to less than 0.002" "flex" and a tolerance of about -0.001" to +0.002" across the entire bed. Personally, i don't think is was a manufacturing flaw form when it was built not so much as it appeared to be a settling of the bed because of the heating elements embedded into its bottom side. it simply took some patients and persuasion to get it right again. Other than that, there were no other problems with it.

I have a backgorund in machining, automation, etc. but I have never used, owned, or even seen a 3d printer up close before getting this thing. I am a complete 100% n00b,.. and my first printing challenge was to print a complicated gear that went bad on my blend door for my A/C on my big-rig truck. I made a drawing in blender (linux) and after a few hours, i figured out that I needed the "cura" software for the printer. it was on the memory stick that came with it, but i downloaded the free (basic) linux version off the web instead. i followed the instruction manual (on memory stick too) on the settings to use and sent the gear as an "STL" file to cura. It refused to load it,..

After more frustration, I learned that in blender you have to convert your mesh to triangles only (ctrl-T), and ensure there is no non-manifold, no loose geometry, mm scale, and I had to scale the finished part by a factor of 10x before exporting it. Once I did that, it worked and cura loaded it right up.

This gear had very fine teeth (0.3mm tips) and was 34mm in diameter. Difficult for any 3d printer to get right,.. but it printed like a champ and the gear looks fantastic!. I used PETG material on 240c and 20mm/s with 100% fill. i had to set fill speed manually (was a hidden setting) in cura to 20mm/s as well, it was going too fast in the middle first time I printed it. As you can see in the photos, the old gear, and the new one. i made the new one in 2 pieces with a "snap-fit" dimple so that it would not have to be glued. The new gear works absolutely fantastic and my A/C blend unit is like new again.
summary: Seriously impressed... but had to fix the bed when I got it.

reviewText: This thing is very impressive and the support I've received is also impressive. First off this thing arrives in a very study cardboard crate. The most heavy duty cardboard box I have ever received through the mail. It's also 99.9% assembled. You will need to screw on a rather small spool holder in the back and load some filament. Tada you're done. The construction is amazing no seems, it's pretty much just one solid piece of steel. The rods are chromed steel and the z axis is running on beefy 10mm rods with nice bearings to match. I have a wooden frame flashforge creator that has been my work horse and this thing right out of the box beats it no problem. The bed was even already leveled. I printed a 150% scaled marvin at 1.2mm layer height and WOW looked perfect. If you email support they will send you a simplify3d profile as well. I printed a 40mm cube to see how accurate the dimensions it prints and right out of the box it prints well enough for 3dhubs new FDM guidelines, nice. The only con I have with it is that there is zero documentation on the board or the firmware. Which means if the board dies and the company is no longer around... better bust out that soldering iron and say goodbye to the lcd display because you are going to have to hack something else that will run on 24v together. Also even though I knew the dimensions of the build area when i bought it the machine doesn't use all of the print bed and that just kind of bothers me. Anyways, as someone who has a decent amount of experience with both using a plug and play printer and building my own I feel very confident recommending this guy to anyone who asks. Also just as an FYI makerbot sells a "hood" for the replicator 2 that fits this pretty well using some magnets if you are looking for an easy solution for a top cover for ABS.
summary: Super Impressed for the Price

reviewText: I have 4 inkbird temp guages. 1 for a fermenter/fridge, 2 for small areas, and 1 with a waterproof sensor for a res. They are very easy to set and easy to read. I've had no issues with inkbird products. There is 1 plug for a heating element, and 1 for a cooling element. You can set your temp in c or f and set your deadband also.
summary: Solid temp guage

reviewText:
InkBird does it again!! I purchased their 308s to keep my DWC water temps in check, and also purchased this one for my gardens ambient air temps.

I plugged in my AC (old window unit sits on floor now) and my space heater (both are analog, not digital), set my desired temp, set my high and low  4deg from desired temp, reset my exsisting temp reader in room (to measure my t-dat the next morning) and walked away.

Woke up and my t-dat is 6!!! Worked flawlessly. Not only is my room temp perfect now (all year long), you are saving me money yet again! Much better to have blasts of heating or cooling than to continually run one or the other.
summary: Works flawlessly! Very happy, AGAIN!

reviewText: Hatchbox continues to be my go to brand. They're not the cheapest, but they're the most reliable for mass printing in my opinion.
summary: Hatchbox continues to be my go to brand. They're ...

reviewText: Having used many hatchbox filaments previously, it was a no brainer to continue.  I am not sure if I got a bad batch or if the gray just doesnt print well, but I have had an extremely hard time getting to print well with this filament on the same printer and models that print perfectly with other filaments.  Attached is a picture of a Lego compatible piece I printed that printed beautifully with other filaments.  Not sure of the problem, have tried many other resources to fix the printing; new slicer, different temps, etc.  Nothing worked 100%.  By slowing the speed down to a crawl and using the slicer to fill in gaps, I was able to get what I would consider a 90% quality print.  The other prints in the picture are 3d Solutech.  All printed on a Maker Select v2.1 with best quality coming at 200/50.
summary: Good, but not great

reviewText: Hatchbox's pla's are usually top notch when it comes to quality and color, this filament is no different! Prints went smoothly and came out beautifully. This filament like most pla filaments produce a sweet smell while it prints. There were no stringing or bridging problems while printing. If your looking for a reliable roll of pla filament then this is for you.
summary: Reliable PLA!

reviewText: In person, the green looks just like the photo. It works great with my Dremel Idea Builder 3D Printer, even though they recommend their own (more expensive) brand only. Since it wasn't going to fit on Dremel's spool, I bought the HATCHBOX 1 Spool 3D Printer Filament Tabletop Wall Mount Rack and fed the spool through one of the holes on the exterior of the Idea Builder and it works great. Prints are nice and smooth. I like it much more than Dremel's filament. Great filament at a great price.
summary: Works great with my Dremel Idea Builder

reviewText: In person, this is a great looking hue of blue. It works great with my Dremel Idea Builder 3D Printer, even though they recommend their own (more expensive) brand only. Since it wasn't going to fit on Dremel's spool, I bought the HATCHBOX 1 Spool 3D Printer Filament Tabletop Wall Mount Rack and fed the spool through one of the holes on the exterior of the Idea Builder and it works great. Prints are nice and smooth. I like it much more than Dremel's filament. Great filament at a great price.
summary: Works great with the Dremel Idea Builder - quality filament at a great price

reviewText: For right now I am going to give this filament 5 stars, simply because it looks great, and prints without any noticeable flaws. It is a beautiful blue that is between light blue and dark blue, just what I was looking for. If you are looking for a blue of this color, then don't hesitate to get this. It is definitely a good addition to Hatchbox's selection of filaments; with the same level of quality that I have come to expect from their other filaments.
summary: simply because it looks great, and prints without any noticeable flaws

reviewText: We received the copper filament for Christmas this past year and have finally gotten around to using it.  We are glad we saved it since it worked beautifully for printing our favorite Guardian character, baby Groot.  The filament printed perfectly at 195/50 and we slowed the print manually to 50% speed to avoid any underextrusion.  Baby Groot was printed in two pieces with no supports needed and is an amazing piece of art by Byambaa who has graciously shared him with the 3d printing community.  We were amazed at how the copper filament really adds a sense of dimension to the detail in the print.  Our next print with is going to be jewelry so it will be interesting to see how realistic the copper makes it look.
summary: Copper filament has impressive results on prints with great detail

reviewText:
I looked at various 3D printers for weeks before settling on the Prusa i3 made by HICTOP. I chose this printer because of the frame being made from extruded aluminum, the heated aluminum bed, the integrated controller, and that it has mostly metal parts. I had my doubts about the quality of a printer built from a kit but those doubts were unfounded. This printer kit is made from quality parts and the assembled printer is equal to printers that cost $2000. I have seen some of the expensive printer's output and this printer is as good. I'm extremely pleased with the assembled printer and I am very glad I took a chance on this vendor. In addition to a great printer kit, the vendor has answered two of my questions promptly. One of the questions was a request for the controller firmware. They gave me the source code which even included the Arduino Environment. This company deserves much praise for putting together such a fantastic 3D printer kit. I do have to warn you that this kit takes quite a lot of time to assemble and parts of the process are difficult. It took me 12 hours of careful work to assemble the kit. If you don't think of yourself as mechanically or electrically inclined, this kit might be frustrating. After 12 hours assembling the kit and my wife getting a little irritated that I was in the garage all weekend, I turned it on for the first time. The motors whirred, the display lit up and it was ready to go. The first object I printed came out great which does not usually happen. HICTOP is thoughtful enough to supply a G-Code file for a Shamrock Cup all ready to go for this printer. You copy the file to a flash card and print from the card. I have run this printer for no less than 40 hours during the last week. It is tough, it is good looking, and it holds its calibration. Below are some details about the various parts of the printer kit.

Frame - The frame is made from 20mm x 20mm extruded aluminum. This frame is stiff and straight. You can't even compare printers with plastic or wood frames to this industrial like chassis. The extrusions are held together with aluminum brackets that are beefy and hold each corner and the uprights true. It does take a bit of fiddling to get each corner flush so that the frame is square. I also had to work on getting the upright frame in the correct position and locked down by the side panels. The side panels are made of heavy gauge steel and hold the controller on one side and the power supply on the other side. I was expecting cheap screw hardware but was delighted to open a bag of hex cap screws which are all nickel or chrome plated. The hardware is so shiny that I can't tell if it is chrome or nickel. The kit includes tools to assemble the kit but I used my own. Almost all screws are cap heads which require various sizes of Metric Allen wrenches. The frame does not include end caps for the extrusion but I was able to print them from files found on Thingiverse. This kit is nearly all metal. The frame, the bed, the motor mounts, and the extruder are metal. The parts that are not metal are mostly thick black laser cut plastic. Really thick. The plastic parts are top quality including the few 3D printed parts.

Plastic Hardware - Almost this whole printer kit is made from metal but there are some plastic parts including a few 3D printed parts. The 3D printed parts are the two X axis end pieces, the extruder feed, and the extruder fan shroud. Thats it. Those parts are nice solid 3D prints with no drooping or distortion. The laser cut parts include the bearing rod mounts (X, Y, and Z axis) and the Y axis pulley mounts. The laser cut parts are of beautiful with smooth edges and very precision. I am happy that there are more laser cut plastic parts than 3D printed parts. The quality is a bit better on laser cut parts.

Metal Hardware - All of the motor mounts except the X axis are made from heavy gauge steel.  The LCD display and filament spool rack are metal as are the side panels and most of the extruder. The extruder is mostly metal but it does have a plastic feed mechanism which is one of the few areas I consider a little on the weak side.  All of the screws and various bits of hardware are all top quality. They in fact are nicer than I expected. Many of the metal pieces which attach to the extrusions use special slot fasteners. They are difficult to use at first but once you get the hang of installing them that are easy to use for attaching corner brackets, side panels, spool holder, and LCD display. All bearing rods were cut to the exact length and are chrome polished smooth and straight. The bearings (6) are all house in aluminum holders with threaded holes are beautifully made. I added a little 3in1 oil while assembling the bearing structures and everything moves silky smooth. Many printer kits use 3D printed bearing holders with tie wraps to mount them. The bearings on this printer are far better than many of the kits.

Electronics  I was doubtful of an all in one controller where the motor drivers were on the board. One bad driver and the whole board is useless. So far so good. The controller is very nice quality. I especially like all of the JST connectors for stepper motors, end switches and temperature sensors. You cant plug them in backwards and each of the connectors is a different size based on function. The controller is actually a standard design called the MKS V1.3 and is made by multiple companies so replacements are available. The motor drivers run cool without a fan and I was able to easily get to communicate with my computer with the supplied drivers.

Software, CD, and Example Files  Wow! They supplied a CD with everything you need. Cura is the slicer and control software.  They included the driver software. They included assembly documents, Cura setup document, bed leveling instructions, and examples. I found everything I needed. I requested and received the controller firmware. These guys did a great job. There are also videos on YouTube showing much of the same things as the documentation.  I really like Cura. Its fun and easy to use.

Documentation and Assembly Instructions  The main assembly document is 95 pages long and is very detailed. It depends on CAD drawings to show each step. There is little text but I was able to figure it all out without too much trouble. I did not print the document. I placed it on a laptop and flipped through it from there while completing each step. I actually had a lot fun putting this printer together and would not hesitate to help a friend build one.

Tools and Extras  HICTOP supplies a bag of tools needed to assemble the printer and they include all kinds of supplies including masking tape for the heated bed, wire ties, extra screws, and a small amount of filament. You can tell they really want you to be successful. Everything needed to build the printer is in the kit.

Packaging - The printer arrived in a sturdy box with all parts wrapped in plastic and placed in foam pockets. There are two layers with the parts and minimal instructions on the top with a CD with the full instructions and software. I was very glad to see the CD. I was quoted a 4-6 week delivery time but much to my delight, the printer arrived in 4 days!!! Dont count on this happening but its nice to know that they aren't putting kits together after they get an order. I was so happy to open the kit and to see the great quality parts.

No product is perfect including this printer. I really like this printer and would do it all again. I did run into a few minor problems which I will mention so you can avoid them if you decide to buy this printer. The bearing that provides the idler end to the Y axis belt was too tight between its mounting ears. I had to leave the screw loose so as to not bind its action. I consider this a minor issue.  All of the sheet metal that connects to the extrusions uses M5x8 metric screws which are just a bit too long. They bottom out in the extrusion. The solution is to add a washer. I had some washers so this was only a minor hindrance. The manual fails to remind you to switch the power supply to 110V for USA operation. I knew about this issue from reading other reviews so I wasn't stumbled by it. This is very important to not if you live in the USA. The wiring section of the manual is a little terse but they do supply a great diagram that is enough to get you through it. My extruder nozzle was a 0.8mm not a 0.4mm. This caused me some problems because I entered 0.4mm per the instructions for Cura. Once I installed another nozzle which was 0.4mm, everything was OK.  Thats it. If you read the reviews, you will know about the power supply and now about the correct extruder nozzle issue from me.  Last, the USB cable is 6 long and is useless so you will need your own USB cable

Im printing all kinds of things as is typical of new 3D printer owners. I am amazed at how solid this printer is and that it does a great job on prints that run for hours. I successfully printed the MakerBot articulated robot which is used for testing printers. I couldn't be happier with this printer.

Update: Jan 12, 2016
I have downgraded this product by one star because there are design flaws which must be addressed for this printer to be reliable and accurate. I have addressed the flaws to my satisfaction but others may be expecting a more turnkey experience. This comment explains how some people are happy with this kit and others bash it. I can't emphasize enough that this kit requires a significant investment in your time and that it requires a lot of tweaking to make it a reliable and accurate printer. If you are willing to invest that time, you can make a $400 kit into a 3D printer that equals assembled ones that cost $1500-2000. If you decide to buy one after seeing the comments that people have made, join our group to get information and help with building your new printer. [...]
Update: June 24, 2016
I pleased to tell you that HicTop has added the upgraded Z axis lead screws to their aluminum fram 3D printer kits. This upgrade will provide a needed boost in print quality. If they are reading this review, the next thing they should upgrade is the 3D printed filament feed with an aluminum one. Users can do this upgrade but it would be better if HicTop provided it in the kit. My HicTop Prusa i3 is still going strong with many hundreds if not a thousand hours of operation. I'm still running this printer 4-5 hours per day on average. It has become a stable and reliable tool for my business and hobbies. If you decide to buy this printer, please consider joining the Yahoo Group for HicTop owners. We have lots of good suggestions and will help you to get your printer running.
[...]
Update: March  2017  My printer is still going strong. I used it to print the 45 parts needed to build a CoreXY printer. My HicTop and the CoreXY support my business needs of printing electronic enclosures. I recommend HicTop and commend them for the continuous upgrades they have made to their 3D printing products.
summary: Excellent 3D Printer that Prints as Well as a $1500-2000 printer

reviewText:
BE WEARY.  I would give zero stars if possible. I'm returning it. Nothing but problems. Customer service won't return emails at any acceptable speed. Again, nothing but problems. I have at least 6 parts that are defective or broke including the hot end wires with absolutely no abuse. I also found burn marks on the inside of the control board cover. I had to remove the cover to prevent it from happening again. As a firefighter for 5 years I know if there are signs of arcing there's a solid chance of fire. Unacceptable.

UPDATE: Hictop has contacted me multiple times to resolve issues but i have already returned the printer. They expressed interest in relaying information to their team to improve the printers. I respect that. I hope they improve on this machine because it has alot of promise. Bumped to 3 stars for good faith that they will resolve problems.
summary: Problems from the beginning.

reviewText:
Update, I am still really impressed with this printer. However, after some use, the extruder heater element came loose during printing and was glowing red hot!. So, be careful and make sure the heater doesn't come loose. This could be a significant fire hazard. And, as far as I can tell, there is no safety on this product to turn it off if something wrong happens. Be warned.

This is a good 3d printer for the price. If you need any minor missing parts, order them. It will be faster. I had some missing xbeam nuts and the belt material was too short for both x and y axis. As soon as I discovered issues I ordered parts. As I expected, I emailed HICTOP with the address in the documentation. They wanted photos etc. I still do not have replacement parts from them. So, expect poor customer service. I had an issue where the x and y pullies wouldn't tighten. The allen wrench didn't fit right. The new belt kit came with pullies and they worked great. I did have to drill out the holes to the parts that captivate the Z axis nuts for the screw drive. I still have a squeek, but it works. So what. Over all, this is a good value for the money. Take your time putting the kit together. Pay attention to the details. Especially the wiring. I used many extra zip ties. The instructions don't tell you how to harness the wires. It will become obvious once the wires are properly connected. I recomend labeling the wires at the connectors so you know what they are once harnessed. I ended up zip tieing the exdruder z-axia cable to the middle of the top bar. Previously, it would snag. The y axis plate would snag too. I used several rubber bands to pull it up so it wouldn't jam.  Hopefully the photo will help.
summary: Good beginner 3d printer for the price, missing parts

reviewText: The vise shattered on its first serious use. Clamping the barrel of a Mini-14 rifle to secure a loose flash suppressor and POW! the piece shown in blue, below the rifle barrel in the photo, broke off. This caused the vise to flop around unsecured on it's base, making it difficult to complete my task.
summary: Brittle, weak metal. Do not buy.

reviewText: Put these on a 5 inch vase. Work good. Firm for grip. NOT too squishy.
summary: Work good. Firm for grip

reviewText:
I bought this screen with my REPRAPGURU Prusa I3 (running ramps 1.4) with the hopes of eventually not having to use a laptop to print something.  I am still tweaking and learning to understand the printer, but I am confident that one day it will just be me using the SD slot on this to load a part into the printer.

The good:
I was able to make some brackets to hold it neatly on the printer which helps keep it in a nice spot.  I also like just having an extra screen, telling me how long the print has been going.  I also love that since i bought the printer from the same company, the screen was plug and play.  Everything worked as it should, i didn't even need to change the Arduino code.

The bad.
This may just be the screen, but when I don't have a computer plugged into it, the contrast drops and I can barely read the screen.  When I plug the computer into the arduino, I can.  I'm sure once I just go to using the screen, I can adjust for that, but I understand how it makes such a difference.

Overall, I am happy with my purchase and believe with some tweaking, I can get this to work as it should.
summary: Good screen, Some small annoyances with contrast

reviewText:
I wanted a way to control an Arduino/ DDS (direct digital synthesizer) project without having to use a USB port on my computer so using a rotary encoder came to mind.  From the description I assumed I would have to use an external push button to set the frequency range but when I got the parts I found that they do have push button capability.  However, you have to install a 10k pull up on the board for it to function.  Unfortunately the board is laid out for surface mount parts but since I have a stock of surface mount resistors and experience with precision soldering it wasn't a problem.  So be advised.  I suppose you could put an external 10k pull up but that is an inelegant solution, imo.  Anyway, I connected it to my Uno, slapped together some code and the unit worked perfectly.

There have been some of complaints about the boards that I'd like to address.  First off, all of the boards I received all are threaded.  The diameter is .267 inches.  They may be metric so the closest metric equivalent is 7 mm.  I would have taken off a half of a star for not providing mounting hardware but considering the price they are worth a trip to the store for a nut and washer.  As for accuracy, most encoders or even switches require some sort of  debouncing in a high speed circuit.  The simplest way is to debounce them is in software with a short timing delay.  I had no problem with accuracy for the ones I bought.  Finally, for those out there without experience using rotary encoders go visit howtomechatronics.com and click on the rotary encoder tutorial.  Since I don't believe in reinventing the wheel I copied his code and built upon it.

Update 27 Nov. 16:
I've added a schematic for a hardware implementation debounce interface.  All the parts are readily available on amazon and other electronics houses.  I've based this circuit on suggestions online and built and tested it to make sure it works.
summary: Great value and great quality.

reviewText: It pains me to write this as black magic 3d has given me some really cool plastic in the past. but this last spool I just got into it and it's not the same color as the last spool of it I got. more over it's not as responsive to black light. overall the quality is just worse. it seems brittle and prints kinda spotty at times. I'm sure they just didn't properly clean out some black pla or something from their spooler before hand but because I ordered it so long ago and just now opened it i'm unable to return or exchange it now. so I guess i'm stuck with cosmic bleh. in the picture you can tell they are pretty different. ironically because I had such a strong light on them the one that is no good actually looked lighter but it prints with more of a blackish brownish hue then the other spool did.
summary: COSMIC BLEH last spool was better

reviewText:
I've made numerous prints with this material and had little to no difficulty getting this to work at recommended settings. This has worked just like any other PLA filament I've used.

As far as the glowing I hold it up to a bright light for about 10 or 20 seconds or so and it glows brightly as shown in the mocked up image for a good minute or so after which it continues at a moderate glow for longer than I've cared to sit around and watch.

I feel ridiculous writing this - but you should note that you DO need to "charge" this plastic up with a bright light in order for it to glow. It doesn't just glow on it's own with no charging.
summary: ... little to no difficulty getting this to work at recommended settings. This has worked just like any other ...

reviewText:
Been using this product for many years .  Initially on RC aircraft but have found scores of uses around the house. It starts to thicken in about 3 minutes , by 4 minutes you better have it in place. After 15 minutes in  70 weather it's firm enough to sand.  Never turns brittle , retains some elasticity  which makes it resistant to cracking & fracture. Mix with microspheres for a tough light weight filler.
Not crystal clear but definitely not yellow, slight warm tint.
For 10 years It's worked for airframes to rear view mirrors. 3/25/17 Had to grab the epoxy to fix my wife's shoe & noticed there's not much left so it's time to reorder.
A good quality fast setting epoxy is a must have IMO, there's just so many uses. I might add that the "mid cure" is great for coating & sealing as in small fiberglass and carbon fiber projects.
I'm not associated with this product
I received nothing in return for my review
I recommend this product
summary: Multi Use fixative ,firm but flexible.

reviewText: I've been using these for a few months now for Arduino project prototyping, and I think they are awesome!  I found some how-tos for using 30 awg coil wire for prototyping, and what I do now is lay out female headers on this board for my components (typically an arduino nano, components for using LIPO batteries, and a soft-latch switch that's really useful for letting the Arduino turn itself off), solder the headers onto the protoboard, then on the reverse side, use the coil wire to solder the circuit underneath.  I use the pads on each end of the board for connecting external wires/connectors.  I'm not at the point where I'm ready to have one of the Chinese mfg sites make PCBs for me, nor do I have the knowledge yet to create the right drawings to support that.  This method is quick, easy, and I end up with a high quality prototype that is solid and easy to work with, and easy for me to scavenge parts when I'm done while still saving the circuit if I want to revisit that project.
summary: Great board for building quality prototypes for Arduino projects

reviewText: Just finished a print of Benchy using this new filament and it came out great.  My printer had been out for several weeks now after using a very cheap of brand filament.  It's so nice having one that just works.
summary: Great filament, great color

reviewText:
How good is this filament? Pretty darn good. Here's a print that just came of my Creatlity CR-10 that is bone stock. This was a 16hr print. It's the cylinder head of a 1/3 scale LS3 Chevy motor. I took the photo about 3 minutes after I removed it from the bed. No post processing, not a single thing. There were zero strings, no blobs, no zits; it's as close to perfect as you can get from a FDM that's as cheap as a CR-10. Layer was 0.2, speed 40 mm/sec, bed temp 60. Sliced in Simplify3D. The silver streaks you see are not layer imperfections they are the silver flake in the filament - the camera makes them look streaky, but trust me there are not streaks in person; it just looks great.

I'm very impressed with the stability, smooth printing, and just all around fantastic result.

Now if they would just change their silly name and silly packaging because this is some seriously good filament and the cartoon package doesn't do it justice. But maybe it's suppose to be fun, but when I'm printing for 16 hours, I want pro filament and this is stuff is the bomb - or the bam...whatever.
summary: How good is this filament?

reviewText: I initially thought that this filament was stringy and hard to print well, but after I used it some I think it is a beautify iridescent color with lots of depth.  I still think that its a bit stringy, but it looks so nice that I will overlook that little issue.  I will be getting more of this stuff.  And have!
summary: Stringy, but beautiful!

reviewText:
I got pretty good results from this.  I typically order hatchbox PLA but went out on a limb to try something new with a better price :).  At first my prints were stringy but then I got eveyrthing dialed in nicely.

I printed these at 215 w/a heated bed temp of 60.  I do have a rather thick silicon pad so actual temp of bed may not be as hot as I'm setting it.

I'm printing with a maker select v2 (wanhao i3 clone) w/upgraded micro swis hot end and nozzle.  Also printing onto glass plate.
summary: I got pretty good results from this

reviewText:
Wow!  Great stuff so far, super well packaged, first print with it came out phenomenal.  Very consistent flow with this stuff!

Love the yellow-gold, great color.
summary: Great stuff so far

reviewText:
The silver works just like PLA.  Not real sparkly, but a little shinier than grey.

Brown is a nice color, but I've had a hell of a time actually using it.  It's not sticking well, strings badly, and i've managed to discard more than has actually printed successfully.  SAD.
summary: Fourish Stars

reviewText:
This is good filament.  I was originally using Hatchbox filament but I couldn't get grey fast enough.  I decided to try this company and I'm glad i did.  It prints very consistently and i'm happy with the quality of the prints when im done.  I did have a couple air pockets in it, but overall, I still think its an incredible value for the price. Buying more from them.

Printer:RepRap Prusa I3
Filament Temp:200C
Bed Temp:70C (Bed Ambient on first layer)
Infill 35%
summary: Bought in a pinch, glad I did.

reviewText:
Works well with my Makergear M2, I printed it at 210c the first time and it left real fine spiderwebs
 ( did not effect the print in anyway) so the second print I lowered it to 190c and it was perfect. I will say the black is slightly lighter in color and less gloss then the Makergear PLA. Measuring it in several places before feeding it the accuracy was +/- .01 mm, I will be buying this again. In the picture i printed the large Batman tumbler first at .2mm and didn't realize I had it printing at 200mm/sec with an untested filament until about halfway though. The second second small was printed at .1mm and 60mm/sec with PVA supports ( first time trying the PVA) the PVA stuck well to the kapton taped glass bed but did not adhere well directly on top of the PLA, as you can see at the back top, so more PVA tests to conduct. Bottom line this Bamtack PLA is worth the print.
summary: I printed it at 210c the first time and it left real fine spiderwebs ( did not effect the print in anyway) ...

reviewText:
I bought a Flashforge Creator Pro last week that came with one spool of black ABS and one of White. I started printing with that, trying various models from thingiverse.com with varying success. I also bought this BAMtack! white PLA at the same time, but didn't start using it until yesterday. I can't compare it to any other PLA (yet) since this is all I've used so far, but after printing the Celtic Skull in White ABS and then using this PLA, I can say the differences are pretty amazing.

It isn't an exactly fair test, since the ABS was printed at .3 mm layer height, which likely caused the layer splitting as the part cooled and the PLA was printed at .1 mm layer height, allowing more detail, but the important thing is the color difference. The one on the left was made with the BAMtack! White, and to paraphrase Spinal Tap, "How much whiter could it be? The answer is none... None more white." I thought the ABS was white before I printed with this PLA, now I can see it is really more of a greyish off-white.

The print quality and detail is really good, and it stuck to the build plate perfectly using mostly default Simplify3D settings. I bought this because it was among the cheapest PLA I could find on Amazon (I just wanted something to test PLA printing at the time) and I'd happily buy it again, the quality for this spool has been perfect so far.
summary: "None more white"

reviewText: Update 10/17/17 : Just installed on a Q3D Threeup prusa i3 style. Made my own bracket of course, can email the image to whoever needs it. AMAZING extruder. This is my first direct style extruder all ive had prior is bowden setups. Retraction is great, spring works great. Very pleased with how this is running. I bought 2 so I could install it on my 3ft printer too.
summary: Runs Great on Q3D Threeup Prusa i3 Style.

reviewText:
First, I received this as a free replacement to an older model Endo from Crenova. I'm giving this a 4 star rating even though it has quite a few issues. The reason for this is that most of the things I've found won't affect it's use for the majority of people.

Pros:
*The flat cable is easy to roll up and store but it's also stiff enough to be beneficial when needed. The picture quality is very good for what it is, it's an Endoscope not a camera.
*The USB adapter to change from type A to a Micro works very nicely and it will keep you from losing it.
*It works with the built in Camera software in Windows 10

Cons:
*It gets very hot at the tip with the LEDs on and I don't see anyway to turn these off.
*The attachments are totally worthless, the magnet isn't strong enough to lift anything other than a very small screw. The mirror is too small, most of what fills the view is the outline of the mirror itself and not what you're trying to inspect. The hook I received won't even attach to the Endo, it's slightly too small to fit around.
*The included software can't be run from the CD, if you do it won't let you exit the program since it can't save a file. The only way out is to use the Task Manager in Windows to end the task. I consider the Windows Camera software to be easier to use so this shouldn't be a problem. If you do decide to use it just copy it to your hard drive first.
*The focal distance is about 1.5 inches, and it wiggles around a lot while trying to insert it making it difficult to get a good, in-focus, picture.

Attached Pictures:
*Two of the pictures are inside of a Bose Sub-woofer and show the harsh brightness in one while I changed the exposure setting in Widows Camera app for the other one which I prefer.
*To give you a relative idea of size, I've included a picture of some Micro SD Cards
*Finally, the Jabra picture was taken at an angle to show a little bit of the Depth of Field or how much will be in focus and how quickly does it drop off.

Hope this helps you make your decision...
summary: Better than before but not perfect

reviewText:
Very cool. Though the instructions admonish you from "personal inspection" several times, you'll find yourself inspecting all kinds of creepy things. Just because you can. What do fillings look like up close? What do your tonsils really look like?

On a serious nature, the very next day after I received it I wanted to inspect the innards of a chair leg to see how water got into it. A quick scoping later I had my answers.

The included software makes it easy to take high quality video, and or stills (though the video files, mov format, are huge!).

There's not much color in the attached pictures from the chair leg (I'll spare you the tonsils), but the device is full color and includes a good ring of adjustable LEDs for lighting.
summary: All around bargain, the same as those costing many times as much until recently.

reviewText: I followed another reviewers directions to get this to work with my MacBook Pro.  It worked exactly as advertised using VLC.  This is an incredible bargain for the price.  The tiny LED lights put out a lot of light.  This is a fixed focus camera so don't expect to make movies with it, but it works very well for it's intended purpose.  I plan to make a little stand so I can hold it steady to look closely at small print.  It is like a camera on macro setting as it focuses very close.  Now I can look into those dark scary places!  The attached photo captured by VLC was hand held so there is motion blur but you can see how closely it focuses.
summary: FUN!

reviewText: Great for small projects. Each board measures 1.85 x 1.37in. Cool that it fits exactly an arduino micro or metro mini. Nice for testing small modules. Contacts are smooth and firm and interconnecting the boards to get a larger footprint is easy.
summary: Great little boards

reviewText:
Edit: over a month in, and everything went to pieces. My success rate dropped from a wonderful 99% to 10%. The first issue came when prints would have a random or specific layer just get completely messed up, no bonding, and the rest of the print infill would be messed up entirely. Using different filaments, different Gcode files, different .stl files, the problem is really bad. So I updated my program and firmware, had an immediate jam with FlashForge red filament. Had to disassemble the entire print head to extract the piece. The same day had another jam with Hatchbox filament. Then I couldn't manage to get the build plate level or the extruder in the same place reliably, it would make an unholy grinding sound and sometimes, randomly, the build plate would be entire inches away from the head when it starts extruding.

I got in touch with FlashForge support, who were mildly helpful but never got any of the severe issues resolved. Every time I tried one of their fixes, it either didn't help or got worse. It drives me mad because it WAS working amazingly well, and now is almost unusable. Entirely disappointing, I'll be returning this shortly.

Notes: I have gotten successful prints, I do know how to level the print bed, I'm good with troubleshooting devices. It's my job to fix smartphones. The photos include all my recent failures, and this doesn't include the innumerable times the print just extruded into thin air, didn't stick to the plate, or was jammed so hard into the plate that it didn't print 3 layers.

-end edit-

2 weeks in, so far, so good. Been really enjoying using it so far, I've been printing near nonstop with it. I'd say without a shadow of doubt that this is the most newbie-friendly printer on the market. I did a huge amount of research on which printer to get, since this is my first endeavor into 3D printing, and this seemed like the best blend of simplicity and affordability. There are cheaper printers, yes, but they're usually DIY which seem very finicky and time consuming. This printer is very simple to set up, I had my first print completely done in under 45 minutes from receiving the UPS box.

Setup
When I received the printer, it came well packaged with a lot of styrofoam and clips. Be sure to get all the packaging off. After plugging it in and setting up the packaged spool of filament (mine was red), I leveled the build plate (which in itself is a easy and guided process) and printed the included 20mm cube. It printed the cube in 11 minutes, and it was extraordinarily difficult to get off the build plate. I had to mangle the poor cube to get it off the plate. Maybe I goofed up or something, but since then I've been using 3M blue printers tape. I use a pocket knife to pry prints off the build, which works well. Side note, turning down the temperature to 210c (from my experience) helps keep the prints from fusing to the plastic.

Filaments
I tried to get a pretty wide range of colors when I initially bought the printer. I was guessing that I'd get red with the printer, as other people have, so I ordered: (not sponsored just recommendations)
-FlashForge Green, 0.67kg
-HatchBox Yellow, 1kg
-HatchBox Blue, 1kg
-ProMolt Professional Black, 1kg
-Solutech Real Wite, 1kg
I've had great success with all of those filaments. You can use the 3rd party spools no problems, but I'd recommend a spool holder. I got a cheap one from Hatchbox, has worked great for everything I'd needed. The only filaments I've had any issues with (and they're minor) have been the FlashForge filaments, they work good on a technical level but they're fairly transparent. If that's what you want, great, but just be aware that it doesn't look as nice for figures or statues (in my opinion).
Loading and unloading filaments has been a bit unusual, I haven't figured out how to pull the filament out of the extruder head so I just cut the filament off right at the input, then select Settings > Filament > Load, wait for it to heat up, then extrude that inch or two of plastic out. It works pretty well and takes under a minute, you just feed the new filament in behind it. Haven't had any issues with the filament clogging or anything, though at high temps like 220c (where it preheats to by default) it does slowly drip out in little strings. Be sure to clear those before you print.

Print Bed
Print bed seems a bit small in terms of other 3D printers, but I've made due. Usually you can scale down or slice models to fit on the bed. Be aware that 5.5" cubed isn't massive, but can get the job done for most things. I haven't tried printing directly onto the print bed since my very first 20mm cube, and I had a heck of a time getting that cube off. I've been using 3M blue painters tape since then, and have had a lot more success with it. Be sure to turn the temperature down, 220c is a bit too hot and will want to fuse with the painters tape. If I get lucky I can pop the print off the tape and reuse the tape, though usually I replace the tape every print or two.

Software
The bundled software is great. It's not a 3D modeling program, but it's great to taking models and quickly converting them into printable models. It's a requirement, as far as I know, before you can print something. I use a MacBook Pro, and the software works pretty great. I'd recommend changing some of the default print settings, like turning infill down to 10% or 5%, and turning the temperature down. I'm running at 210c, though I want to experiment with 200c. The tree-like auto supports are great, they're usually pretty easy to remove and help keep complex builds nice and secure. However, I really don't like rafts. They rarely come off in one piece and are frustratingly strong to remove. Especially on models that have a solid bottom, it just fuses with the bottom. I've had no issues printing the supports directly onto the print bed, so that's what I'd recommend.
The on-printer software, accessed via touchscreen, is great too. Very user friendly and easy to operate, it's nice to be able to access a bunch of settings right on the printer. Plus preheating and selecting a print is easy too. It copies the print to the printer's internal hard drive, so once the print starts you can unplug your computer or unplug the flash drive with no problem.

PLA Plastic
This printer only prints in PLA. Some would consider this a negative, I don't have a problem with it though. Personally speaking, as a newbie to printing, PLA is the only plastic I'm interested in. It's very easy to work with, you don't have to deal with a heated print bed or finicky fan speeds or anything like that. PLA prints don't tend to warp if the temperature isn't perfect. Not to mention that PLA is cornstarch based, so it is eco friendly and smells nice while printing. The smell is very subtle, though I keep my room well ventilated. PLA isn't as tough as ABS, and may not perform as well in high-stress or high-heat environments, but I haven't found anything to print that needs to be stress-tested. I printed a very thin support for an herbs plant, and the supports were amazingly flexible. For beginners, I'd highly recommend PLA over ABS.

Prints
Since this is a PLA printer, it can print at 4 resolutions: low (draft, 0.3mm), standard (0.18mm), high (0.14mm), and hyper (0.08mm). I do the vast majority of my prints in standard, and they come out looking very nice. You can clearly see the print layer, but they're subtle and very uniform. I've also printed at high definition, and at that point the layer lines start to fade. I haven't yet printed in hyper, but the time it takes to print in hyper is unreal, so only save that for when you absolutely need to.
The prints usually come out very nice and clean. Sometimes there will be little strings or webs between pieces, but they can quickly be cleaned up with a knife or just your hands. Usually print problems are things I could have fixed, like an overhang that should have had a support but I forgot to add it. The printer has not EVER completely failed a print on it's own. All of the failed prints were either because 1) I forgot to add supports for an overhang greater than 45, 2) there was a raft that fused moving pieces together, or 3) the power went out and canceled the print (consider a UPS battery backup maybe). I haven't had the printer go haywire and screw up a print on it's own yet. It helps that the software it uses is pretty solid and good at detecting problems.

Issues
The issues for this have been minor. Once I added the blue painters tape to the print bed, no amount of releveling would get the print head to get the right height. It would drag the print head through the tape, and wouldn't print the first layer of plastic at all. To get it working better, I releveled the bed with an additional piece of paper or two, to get the extra height I need. I've contacted FlashForge about this issue, and I haven't heard back yet.
Besides that, the only other issue is the on-printer screen is sometimes a bit janky. While scrolling through my flash drive full of files, it might act like I tapped twice and select something two folders deep. Some people might consider the PLA only or the print bed size problems, but I've managed no problem.

In conclusion, the FlashForge Finder is just about the best printer I could recommend for a beginner or someone looking to get into 3D printing for the best time. It's no the most flexible, it's not very upgradable like a DIY printer, but it's also very stable and very easy to use. PLA plastic is beginner friendly, and I've had wonderful success with it.

PROS:
Very affordable
Simple to setup and use
Minimal tinkering required
Accepts 3rd party filaments
Removable build plate (easy to put tape down on it)
No print failures due to the printer itself so far
Nice bundled software
On-board 4gb hard drive, to prevent interruption
Quite and low-smell

NEUTRALS:
PLA only, depends on your goals
Build plate size, once again depends on your goals
No major upgrades or tinkering potential

CONS:
Build plate size can be a bit restricting, depending on your goals
On-board slot for PLA spool is proprietary only and only 0.67kg

(side note about photos: I have printed more than just Pokemon, it's just what I had on hand)
summary: Great at first. Catastrophe in the making.

reviewText:
This is my first 3D printer.  I have been gazing at them on Amazon.com for a long time, mulling over the alternatives and weighing the benefits of spending more or less.  I guess my trepidation was the cost and if I spent a lot of money and it eventually just sat in a corner, well I'd feel guilty for spending.  When I saw this new printer from FlashForge, and considering all of the favorable reviews regarding the seller's customer service on its other products, well it made me jump in.  (I used Amex points to buy it so wow that made it affordable! Thanks Amazon and Amex).

I can tell you when I received the email from FlashForge's Tang, I got excited.  I can tell you that I have bought a lot of things from Amazon and I had not received such an email.  It was kind of fun to be able to read the manual while I was waiting that last day for delivery.  Plus, it made me an educated customer, so I believe I was more restrained during the carton opening.  I knew exactly what to expect and what to do.

After completing the setup, my kids and I wanted to get printing, so we printed out the cube demo.  My Finder came with a translucent white spool of PLA, and that was great because it allowed us to watch how the print included the hexagonal fill and when completed, you can hold it to the light and see the internal detail.  Knowing about that fill option is an advantage to someone not experienced at 3D printing, like me (see later here).

Too excited to end the evening, my daughter (7years old) asked to print out something for her.  We went to Thingiverse and printed a little kitty keychain (props to somethingc on Thingiverse).  It took 45 minutes and my daughter watched the entire time.

Then, my son found Horrible zombie! by BOBUSMALUS on Thingiverse and we proceeded to print that.  Well, that was going to take a while so we started it up and we put the kids to bed.  Waking up the next day was like Christmas morning for my kids, they ran to the printer and voil it looked great.  Getting the tree supports off the print revealed its fragility, but my son thinks it looks cool without an arm, but we just put it in his other hand and it looks more gruesome.  I printed it with grey PLA which I bought at the same time as the printer.

So far it is a blast.  I can say that it is easy to set up (almost no set-up and no assembly) and super easy to extract the print files from an STL file to get it to print.  You will want to check out all of the print options (remember the honeycomb fill) so that you are educated on how it will print and consume the PLA.  I started a print of my own later and mistakenly filled what I wanted to be hollow.  But once I noticed, cancelling the print and starting over is a breeze.

I'm pretty good with computers and with 3D design (started out in engineering) but I can say it all still seems quite easy to use.  I expect a lot from Software, and I think that the FlashPrint software (I'm a mac user and it installed easily) is pretty good.  If you have used 123D Design, well you will feel at home in FlashPrint.

Overall very great experience so far:
1: Easy to set up
2) Easy to use
3) It WORKED
4) fun as heck for the kids to see/learn/use
5) Initial quality VERY GOOD (will update in a few weeks, if I remember)
summary: Exceeded My Expectations

reviewText:
Update January 2017 - Printed with Ninjaflex filament, no issues.  The latest FlashPrint software incudes presets for a few different types of filament now, including flexible PLA.  This printer just keeps amazing me!

Update October 3 - succeeding with large, complicated prints, attached a picture of the skull model I found on Thingiverse. They key is getting the print bed truly level over a large area, which I explained in my June 9th update below. Still love this printer!

Update August 17, 2016 - Email support from FlashForge is outstanding.  They always respond in 12 hours or less, and whether it's tech support questions or replacement parts needed, they have the right answers.  I'm still very happy with the print quality and overall capability - adding a picture of the most recent and very complex print of a skull I downloaded from Thingiverse.  I'm also getting better at designing my own parts and decorations using 123D Design, picking up skill from various videos and articles online.  What a great hobby, and this printer never lets me down.

Update July 31 2016 - I've lost count of how many prints I've done, and this thing is still going strong.  Since my last update, I've had a few interactions with tech support - once to order additional blue tape covers and an additional print bed (cheaper than I expected and shipped fast from China), and more recently I had a failure with the board that's installed on the print head and controls the stepper and heater block.  I sent a picture and a description of the failure, they responded right away and shipped me TWO replacement boards under warranty.  I swapped it out and this thing is printing great again, I printed a Barbie doll chair and table for my daughter.  Since my last review, I also printed with Hatchbox PLA filament and that worked really well as well.  Overall still very happy with this printer!

UPDATE June 9 2016 - after about 30 prints, I'm even more thrilled!  You MUST get the printing platform COMPLETELY level to print larger models, and the built-in automatic leveling routine doesn't quite get it there.  What I do is this - set the extruder gap with a piece of paper, then use the leveling utility.  Then set the extruder gap again, but use the FlashForge print utility from your PC to manually move the printhead around to various points on the print surface, rechecking the gap with a piece of printer paper and adjusting the height knobs to get it fully level.  Since doing this, I have had zero issues with one edge of the raft lifting.  Yes there is still a small learning curve, but this thing prints AWESOME when it is dialed in. I added pics of my most recent printout of the self-watering plant pot from thingiverse.com to prove it!

UPDATE June 6 2016 - after about 20 prints, I stand by my review.  Maybe 4.5 stars - it's not quite plug and play over time, be prepared to fiddle with how you print to get more complex designs to print.  I have installed a BuildTak stick-on printing surface, and I've had to figure out how to take apart the extruder print head to clear a jam, and I've had to totally disassemble the extruder to clean the print nozzle.  However - for the price, it still beats everything else out there.  You just can't quite assume yet that you don't need to know anything about 3D printing to use this.  But it's sooooo easy, you'll be hooked!!!!!

ORIGINAL REVIEW:

This is my first 3D printer.  I have looked at them for a while, and I have a friend who did a ton of research and bought this intense hobbyist printer, took him all weekend to set it up, and it seems that every other print doesn't come out right for some reason - he is slowly becoming an expert at the entire science of 3D printing.

I have plenty of hobbies, and while I wanted a 3D printer to support those hobbies, I didn't want to have to learn a lot to use it.  I also didn't want to spend a fortune.  When I saw the price drop on this printer, read the other reviews, and watched a few youtube videos, I figured I'd give it a shot.

Everything worked exactly as expected!  Right out of the box, following simple setup and calibration steps, my first four prints have been a total success.  I'm still learning about rafts and supports and fill, but it is just as easy as downloading a model from thingiverse, loading it into the FlashPrint software, and sending it to the printer.

And the print quality on the default settings was MUCH better than I'd expected, after seeing what my friend printed on his super hobby machine.  Keep in mind that I mostly want to print toys and utilitarian things - shelves, hooks, etc. - and I'm not sure what others expectations are, but mine were blown away.  I attached a pic of a toy elephant model I printed - legs and head move.  My daughter loved it!
summary: Updated after more than 50 prints - Easy and Powerful - great tech support!

reviewText: This printer is amazing.  Before I received it Tang e-mailed me a more detailed version of the manual than what you find in the box.  Within an hour of opening my printer I was printing a test cube, then a "Benchy" boat.  They looked amazing, not at all stringy or textured like I have seen bad 3D printers make.  My 6 year old, with supervision, was able to print himself a Benchy boat and 6 die (dice) as well as bracelet (picture included) which we they spray-painted with copper.  It looks incredible.  On day 3 my filament stopped extruding and Tang got back to me within hours and over a dozen e-mails later he had walked me through clearing out a clog in my printer's nozzle and then re-calibrating my nozzle (the z-axis).  All of these e-mails were sent between 9:00pm and 10:30pm Eastern Time, I do not know where Tang lives but I was not expecting any response that late at night and he sent me videos and look at my photos to make sure I knew exactly what to do.  If I ever want to upgrade my printer I will stick with Flashforge because their customer service is amazing.
summary: Amazing customer service and great, easy to use printer

reviewText: This little device helped me track down a hot water leak in my slab. The spatial resolution is not as good as a regular optical camera but it's plenty good for locating hot spots. Temperature resolution is very good.  Temperature accuracy is "approximate". This device will detect your foot prints where you were standing barefooted on the carpet. Detects animals at night. Easily detects wall warts dissipating power. The unit takes about 20 seconds to stabilize and reads temperature incorrectly during the 20 second power-up period.  Can also "see" leaks around your doors and windows. Find the cat in a dark house!
summary: Useful tool for heat hunting.

reviewText: These are AWESOME! Very strong, amazing how magnets so small can be so strong. I put them on my grill to hold utensils, and they are perfect! Very pleased with this purchase.
summary: These are AWESOME! Very strong, amazing how magnets so small can be so strong.

reviewText: works well enough for up too 180ipm sfu1605 and 60lbs table w/ 60lb swivel vise.
summary: surprised

reviewText:
Worked for my 6 wire unipolar nema 23 stepper motors.
I have 3 now, connected to the SainSmart 5 Axis Breakout Board and powered by a 24v DC PSU (EAGWELL 360W)
All being controlled by the StarTech PCIe desktop parallel card Model: PEX1P.
Helpful Info:
1  I personally was unable to get the Rosewill Model: RC-302 PCI Parallel card to play nice with Mach3  So, I don't recommend it.
2  Don't use 6-wire unipolar motors unless you are given 4 brand new units for free like I was. Annoyingly. They must be connected in a halfway functional 4-wire configuration with nearly all stepper drivers, including this one, plus you have to deal with this half or full winding crap that is basically a choice between a weak motor or a slow motor.

In any case, this driver will work for either mode as long as the dip switches are set correctly, but will likely perform best with a 4-wire bipolar stepper motor.

This is a review of the ABN 180 Piece SAE Rubber Grommet Assortment.

You will receive the following all in a hard plastic case. The case dividers in mine seemed a little flimsy as they would not stay in place properly unless I messed with them. I do like how the grommet sizes are marked on the lid so you can easily see what size is in each compartment.
In terms of the rubber, this is a hard rubber. So if you are looking for a grommet that has more give and flexibility, these may not be the best for you.

5 of 7/8
5 of 5/8
40 of 5/16
25 of 7/16
40 of 3/8
40 of 1/4
20 of 1/2
5 of 1

There is one thing you need to be prepared for and that is a terrible horrible strong petroleum smell. I opened the case and the smell just hits you in the face. I had four out in the open for a short amount of time and the entire area smelled. If you need to use a lot of them or plan to use indoors, just be prepared for a strong smell.

As I only use these here and there for odds and ends, they work and I got a lot for a cheap price. One star off for the smell.

As with all my reviews, I will update this review if they develop any issues with ongoing use.
summary: I do like how the grommet sizes are marked on the lid ...

reviewText: This a good set to have. You get plenty of different size grommets. The only reason I gave it 4 stars is because I have not tried them out yet on a project.
summary: Great buy. Just what I was looking for.

reviewText:
I only needed to drill both a 9/16 inch and a 5/8 inch holes in plastic.
Total twist drills: $25.33 | Total spade bits: $10.57
I got all these (and the super aluminum case) for $15.30 on a price drop. [ HAPPY CAMPER ]
summary: [ HAPPY CAMPER ] INEXPENSIVE WAY TO DRILL LOTS OF DIFFERENT SIZE HOLES

reviewText:
This 'Ridgid Vac5000 Wet/Dry Vacuum', is well designed for it's purpose. It has a mountable wall bracket that installs with 3 included screws, located within the canister, which keeps it off the floor in my rather cramped garage. It was easy to put up and it's designed to hold the vacuum, hoses, and attachment caddy.

This vacuum has 2 filters but comes with 3: one circular, pleated, that can be used for wet or dry pick-up, and a much larger dust capture filter (with a replacement for it). The pleated filter can be cleaned rather than replaced and both filter types are very available for replacement purchases. There are 2 hoses provided, a 7 ft. and 14 ft. that can be interconnected to provide 21 ft. in length. And the power cord is a convenient 20 ft. long.

I've wall mounted this toward the front of my garage and the hoses will reach anywhere within as well as extend from the garage for limited vehicle vacuuming. Of course, the vacuum is easily removed and reattached to the wall mount and can be carried about with or without the accessory caddy attached (as the photo shows I've elected to wall mount the caddy). In addition to the wall mount, hoses and filters, there are an additional 6 attachments; one of which is a brush and another that, depending on where attached to the vacuum, will enable suction or blowing.

The VA5000 Wet/Dry Vacuum has a 5 peak hp motor that I've found more than adequate for either suction or blowing and, employs a unique snap & attach design. For me, it's an incredibly versatile and useful machine.
summary: An Excellent Shop Vac.

reviewText:
Wow! This 'Ridgid Heavy Duty Wet/Dry Vac' with it's 12 gallon capacity will take on just about any job. For wet clean-ups it has great suction from it's 5 peak horsepower motor and there's a conveniently placed drain.
It comes with a pleated filter that's washable and replacements are readily available, too. The 4 casters provide this Vacuum with great mobility and there are attachment holders, unusually, situated above each wheel.
Included with this heavy duty wet/dry vac. are, in addition to filter and hose, 6 attachments: 2 ext. wands, a wet and a utility nozzle, and a male to male adapter for connecting a car/blower nozzle attachment to the detachable blower.
And that is what I find especially useful, and unique, it's detachable power head which adds to its convenience for use as a hand held portable blower.
The accompanying photos show it all.
summary: Great Versatility and Heavy Duty.

reviewText:
I purchased this item about a year ago as a black Friday deal.  This was my first ever Ridgid brand tool, and I couldn't be happier with it.  I use my vacuum regularly as a dust collection system/regular shop vacuum and have had zero issues with it.

The power of this vacuum is amazing... I was using a craftsman brand shop vac before I bought this one and there is no comparison.  The filters can be a little expensive (around $25 for a two pack), but I've found that they can be cleaned multiple times before they need to be trashed.  The cord is long and can stretch all the way across my two car garage which is very convenient.

I would have no hesitation purchasing another Ridgid brand item.
summary: Great shop vac

reviewText:
This shop vacuum deserves a five star rating based on performance, but the company has managed to save money by having no quality control system.  Mine arrived with two incorrect parts and had I noticed the problem at the early stages, I would have packed it up and returned it.  But I was well into assembly by the time I recognized the problems.  The most serious problem involved the factory installation of two left wheel locks in stead of one left and one right wheel lock.  As one can see in the pictures below, both wheel locks have the step plate going in the same direction.  I did not notice this problem until I completed installation of the left wheel and upon adding the right wheel noticed it would not go all the way in because the wheel lock had the step going towards instead of away from the wheel (see the second picture below).  I solved the problem by cutting off the section that extends towards the wheel and it still works just fine.  But the consumer should not be required to do remanufacturing to get things to work.  The second problem was that only one of the wheel nuts that was included was a lock nut.  The others were all regular nuts and a lock nut is required to hold the wheel on as a regular nut, if tightened down, would prevent the wheel from turning.  A lock nut can be tightened just enough to keep the wheel on while allowing for free rotation.  I solved the problem by using a thread sealer that served to hold the nut in place.

After suffering through assembly, I then used the Shop Vac to clean the basement floor and the work room.  It worked beautifully, and was very impressive in terms of suction and the extensions and attachments were of high quality.  Indeed, the 8 foot hose is the best vacuum hose I have every seen.  Thus, I gave the unit 5 stars for performance and 3 stars for pain and suffering during assembly.

My strong recommendation is that you carefully check all the parts including the installed parts and if anything is missing, return it to Amazon for replacement.  It is very hard to tell through the plastic whether you have a lock nut or a regular nut, however.  But the lock nuts are a lot thicker and have small round marks on two faces which are indentations to make the nut hard to turn on the screw.  The company should be dinged for using such a cheap lock nut, and dinged even more for not including the right number. Fortunately, if you or going to buy a shop vac from a company with no quality control, Amazon is a great place to buy such a thing because replacement is so easy.

It is unfortunate that something that works so well once assembled is shipped without paying attention to the details, but I still recommend this item because it works so well.  It is very solidly built, and moving it up and down the stairs is quite easy because of the design, excellent handle and large rear wheels.  Storing all the attachments inside is also very convenient.

In summary, just make sure you have all the parts before starting to assemble.  And for the cretin who will invariably add a comment that I am the fool for not checking the parts before assembling, I was indeed partially to blame.  Let this review prepare you for the fact that this company seems to lack quality control during assembly and parts preparation.  But once you get the thing put together, this is indeed a 5 star shop vac.
summary: Works Great but Terrible Quality Control can make Assembly Challenging

reviewText:
