I really like the vacuum.... It's very large, about the size of a mini-fridge, but all accessories pack away nicely and the hose stores out of sight. It has done very well with any job I've tasked it with. The suction is incredibly strong and has worked for all my workshop messes. The front of the orange debris drawer does flex inward when pulling a hard vacuum, so it would be nice to see slightly thicker plastic there. This unit is VERY quiet. It's about the noise level of a normal stand-up vac which is very unusual. Nice for people like me that are apartment dwellers.

The reason this isn't five stars is attention to detail. My unit came with the brake levers installed on the wrong sides, making wheel installation impossible. After swapping them, it was no sweat. See the attached photo of the manual diagram and what I received. I also didn't get the dust bags in my box. The shipping carton was not very sturdy, but for such a beefy product it worked without problems.

Overall, if you're looking for a powerful shopvac, this is a good option, but for the price I do expect the manufacturing problems to be fixed ASAP.
summary: Great vacuum, manufacturing/shipping needs some work!

reviewText:
I must say, I didn't experience any quality control issues some have had with the RIDGID VAC1100 Smart Cart Wet Dry Shop Vacuum with LED Car Nozzle and Dust Bags.  I initially thought I did as you can see in the pics but not enough to warrant any tangible points with this shop vac.

I received all assembly parts.  The two brakes were installed opposite to each other and when I was putting the wheels on, I just didn't think the "wings" rubbing up against the wheels was how it should be.  Now I don't know if other people received wrong parts or didn't try to swap pieces but that is what I did.  I unscrewed the securing panels on each side and merely swapped them.  Voila, wheel brakes fixed.

The RIDGID VAC1100 Smart Cart Wet Dry Shop Vacuum with LED Car Nozzle is awesome.  As the complete name implies, you get an led lit car nozzle.  This is so very much needed when we are cleaning our vehicles and especially near the seat crevices.  The Vac1100 is so well designed.  All of the parts and accessories for the shop vac will remain with the shop vac.  There are storage compartments for the attachments and the extension poles are stored in the back corners.  The handle can even be pushed down for more storage options.

On top of all the accessories you get, the well designed nature of the Vac1100 and the quality construction you get the blowing function that doesn't seem all that well advertised.  I haven't had the opportunity to test the blowing function yet other than blowing dust out of the garage so perhaps the Vac1100 isn't strong enough to blow much more than that but such a feature is a bonus.  For me it is also surprisingly light as I pulled it out of the shipping box.  The only drawback I could potentially see is how the item is shipped.  It's shipped in the box it came in, a plain brown shipping box.  There is not much cushioning provided but perhaps luckily it is light enough that delivery people can handle without much problems.
summary: What an awesome shopvac.

reviewText:
I've been using a large Ridgid wet dry vac for years and am very happy with it. It can be inconvenient to clean out and take places though. This hand held is great. It vacuums as well as the larger one I have and is perfect for cleaning my car and portability.

There are a couple draw backs though. My vacuum came with a claw piece and a round small brush for attachments. It did not come with the flat square attachment in the pictures. Also, the claw doesn't stay in well. It slides in and out of the hose easily. (The ridges aren't wide enough. I'll post a picture.) If you don't hold on to it you'll lose it when you try to reach between seats or other tight spaces. Also neither of the attachments fit in the holder by the handle - see picture. You also can't see it in the stock pictures here, but there is a large diffuser that fits on the back of the unit. I'll post a picture.

Overall I'm happy with this unit but for the price is expect the attachments to fit better.
summary: Works Well / Attachments Don't Fit Well

reviewText: Love this printer.  Had to resolve issues with wires and Boden tube catching on frame and also adjust z offset sice I print on glass plates, but after that the thing prints beautifully. I would recommend buying esun pla pro and printing the external reel holder from Thingiverse. Check out my photos.  The black box is the controller for a core xy Im building but I printed it on the XYZ.
summary: Best printer for the money.

reviewText:
Being new in the 3D printing world my main drivers to choose a printer were:

How easy it is to use.
Around the 500 dollars price range.
Printing quality (not looking for the best, but a decent looking)
Reviews.

This da Vinci Pro had all I was looking for and I am not disappointed. So far (4 months) I have been printing a lot of small things, from downloaded to created ones and I had no problems. If you follow all instructions and user manual you should be able to get this printer to work in less than 30 minutes. I used all original filament cartridges and had no issues whatsoever.

Keep in mind this is a big printer, I think they could have used the space better since it does have a lot of "unused" spaces.

I didn't think it is loud, I print with it overnight and can barely hear it and it is very close to my house.

If you are a beginner looking for an easy, affordable printer for hobby and small stuff this is a great buy.
summary: Recommended

reviewText: I am within my 30 days and am returning this item.  XYZ has some great printers out there - this is not one of them!  Mine was poorly constructed (the feed tube will not stay in place) and even though the box was in perfect shape it has not printed anything except the demo projects.  the one project I tried to print has failed every time about 2/3 of the way into a 8 hour build!  Now the XYZ software is shutting down when I try to send a design to the printer.  I am hoping I just have a bad printer and some conflicting software drivers but even after removing the printer and all drivers and software from my pc and reinstalling I cannot get anything to load.  The downside of this is I really enjoy using the XYZ printer at my college lab.  I was really looking forward to the laser engraver addition but now looks like separate 3-d printer and laser engravers.
summary: Hopefully Just 1 Bad Printer.....

reviewText:
A friend of mine bought this and at first he was happy with it, he got it on a Tuesday, and told me how amazing this were and that he thinks its a good printer with good quality, I myself is a proud owner of 4 3d printers 3 of them from flashforge (creator pro, Dreamer and Finder) and the forth is M3D Mini and I think very highly of these printers and my favorite is creator pro its a beast, you can check my reviews on these printers.
Anyway I decided to try a different brand printer and as my friend told me this was the one, since Tuesday I have not talked to him all I knew he was happy with his purchase, so on Saturday night I ordered this, on Sunday morning told me not to buy this as he didn't got 1 print since he got this printer, so here I am writing a review since its something I enjoy and I believe it helps.
as my friend told me and explained his issues:
1. the first issue he ran into is the wires in the printer and under the heated bed, they are not fastened and lose one of the wires were off its location and rubbing on the moving parts he had to put some tapes and bundle them as they are not bundled properly I added some pictures.
2. the sensors on both the top door and the bottom door were bad as it kept giving him a message on the LCD top door is open and he was locked out from the LCD screen while printing.
3. Jog mode was not working properly he had issues moving the Z axes
4. he had leveling bed issues hence not one print would stick to the bed, and that was due to the metal parts in the extruder than has to touch every corner of the bed was not touching the bed for some reason.

I understand this review is what I have witness not what I have experienced but I won't buy this one yet and I would change my review if I had first hand experience if it was better.
I hope this helps
summary: I dodge a bullet not buying this

reviewText:
2 days in and I am still printing! This comes pre-calibrated from the factory...plug in, update and then select file and watch it go. I am very happy with this printer. The filament that it comes with is 120m ABS (blue), I also purchased 2 PLA (250m) which should print a lot better.

Working temps on the ABS: 230 for Extruder, 80 for Bed. I am still playing with the temps and may go to 235 on the extruder.

Once you place the bed's tape down, rub a glue stick on the tape for your object to stick. After it has completed, it will be somewhat difficult to get the object off but go slow and steady for the win.

UPDATE: So today I was having an issue with a filament jam and was unable to figure out how to remove the nozzle. I contacted XYZPrinting and asked how to do so and the lady was able to tell me over the phone in detail how to do this! I am back to printing and am thankful I purchased this printer. Do NOT base this 3D printer on the people with ratings of lower than 4 stars.

I will update this as I go.

UPDATE 3/20/16 - Today the printer broke! I have added photos of the break and also contacted support to see if they can replace this in a timely matter. We will see how this contact goes.

I ended up contacting Amazon and will be receiving a replacement on Wednesday.

Update**** 1 yr later!
I love this printer so much! I print miniatures for dnd style games, I printed a recorder (that really works and plays hot cross buns :) ), cars, boomerangs, etc. if you have any issues XYZPrinting will help you resolve it quickly. Great product and I have over 600hrs of prints done.

Sept 2018 Update....
I am still printing amazing things and this printer has so many hours on it. I highly doubt that its end of life will be anytime soon. Keep it clean and show it some love and it will do the same for you.
summary: Best purchase I have made in a while.

reviewText:
This has been really useful to measure leather thicknesses for me.  I'm sure other random uses will come up too.  It works surprisingly well.  Make sure you close it all the way and tighten the screw at the top to prevent it from turning on in the case.

Attached pictures show the length fully closed and fully open.  It comes with 1 battery installed, and 1 extra battery.  A warranty card and brief user manual sheet as well.
summary: Super Useful!

reviewText: I initially had troubles with the reading accuracy of this, but the seller quickly resolved my problems.  Thanks!
summary: Works great!

reviewText: Good quality and great price. Precision is within what you would expect, I had no problems with it. The package included is nice and neat.
summary: Good quality and great price

reviewText:
For the price these are very good calipers for any average person who doesn't need super accurate measurements. These calipers are very easy to use and are simple to read with its large display. It can convert to in, mm, and fractions with one simple button. Each part feels very solid and well build and will not break on you.

The display is very large and it makes it super easy to read the display and what the numbers say for quick readings. It is also very bright and wouldn't have any problem using them in the sun. These are multipurpose measuring with outside, inside and depth measuring which all seem to be very accurate for each part. It comes with a hard case which I love because it will keep it protected from drops with the foam and hard case around it and makes it very easy to just throw into a tool box and pull it out and crack it open and use it with no issues at all. It came with a battery already inside and it came with an extra one also which is the best thing ever. This is a great little add on that can make a product that much better.

Pros
- Large display
- Very accurate
- Durable
- Hard carrying case with lined foam
- Multipurpose
- Extra battery

Cons
- None at all
summary: Great calipers!

reviewText: This thing knows every measurement right away, without any averaging time.  The electronics are great.  But the jaws on the front and back are not thin AT ALL.  The thin area is so thick I can't measure the same groves my old pair will measure.
summary: Great electronics, insufficient machining. (Picture)

reviewText:
Well I have a long long history with this printer filament now. About 50 + rolls of random colors in both abs and pla by this brand.  This pla have very tight area of settings where it runs very nice.  but once you find sweet spot like all filaments yu will have nothing but great results!  This pla will break if it gets around 70f and is flexed so just fyi.  But currently I have used this brand in over 200 projects and had great results with this pla.  very dead on size wise and it tends to actually run tad over weight listed on roll.  Never had bad section in roll i purchased yet.  Or a kink.  This pla will suck up water in super humid areas if left open to air few days. But what pla does not? Ziplock bag solves the problem.

Here is few items all in pla made by this company! Yellow and orange is this pla your buying in black!
summary: great stuff!

reviewText: Good PLA Actually I find it to be great PLA.. Average shrinkage so batten down your high fill prints but overall consistency and colors (except Purple but that's a personal observation) The only reason this review was not 5 stars is the first two spools were perfect the second two have bad crossovers in them.. In order to print with it I had to tighten down my extruder pretty good to keep from slipping. I tried to take them out but they run deep. Other than that a 5 star product.
summary: Good PLA Actually I find it to be great PLA

reviewText:
I bought this brand at first because I was new to 3D printing and wanted the cheapest stuff I could get to play with while I learn. Fortunately the cheapest stuff turned out to be very good stuff.. I do not have a lot of experience with other brands.,. I have used some makers, and hatchbox but that I borrowed until this came in but very little so they are my only comparison points. However, straight off the reel this product works well,, Good table and layer to layer adhesion, good color and color consistency, great prints all the way around with almost no strings and or layer lines. This really does work well. Everything about the plastic is excelent. My only gripe and reason for the 4 star is there are several areas on the role where the plastic is lopped under itself. This did concern me but hasn't caused and issue so far. I just know if you teeth on your extruder are a little worn out the extra pull to free the plastic could be an issue. Other than that an all star product

See print below for examples
summary: Fortunately the cheapest stuff turned out to be very good ...

reviewText:
I have used 3 rolls of this filament now.  It has a super tight bond on layer to layer.  I have used this in two different 3d printers now each with different setups.  One with a glass top and the other with metal plate and tape.  Both printing at .2 high layers at 196c heat and 60c heated bed.  Both ways stuck great to the plates.  60c temp on plate through whole print stops all the warping and popping off perfect with this filament.  I printed 982 parts for all different rc parts and they all have held up perfectly. If you print a 8x8x200mm part it will hold 8 pounds before it snaps.  which is just crazy for pla to hold up like that!!  Also my one printer has a filament gauge on it.  Not one time did it ever go over  .02+ or - out of 3 rolls.  This filament is not that china crap stuff you find on amazon.  It is high grade filament with very good price.  I have bought 50$ rolls not as well made as this product is.  So I will be ordering many more and you should to!

Few photos of things made with this filament and all of them have held up very well!
summary: Super good quality!

reviewText:
I have used 3 rolls of this filament now.  It has a super tight bond on layer to layer.  I have used this in two different 3d printers now each with different setups.  One with a glass top and the other with metal plate and tape.  Both printing at .2 high layers at 196c heat and 60c heated bed. reviewText:
After a lifetime working in science and high tech. you'd think I'd get jaded about new technology- but I never do. I'm still constantly astounded at the progress in making electronic devices smarter, faster, cheaper, and more powerful. Case in point: This new hand held thermal viewer from Reveal.

The first Thermal imager I ever saw was on an M1 Abrams tank, and I think it cost around $250,000. Some years later I saw industrial thermal viewers that could be had for only $10,000 or so. Bu the last year has seen an explosion in inexpensive devices. Now you can get a real, working thermal imager for the price of a cell phone.

There's no manual included with the reveal for the simple reason that you don't need one. Push the big button in the middle and it turns on. Everything else is done via simple menus. The first time you turn it on, it'll step you through setting the time and date, date display format, and automatic time out setting, and after that, it just turns on and goes immediately into view mode. Controls in view mode are simple- just two buttons. One will step you through different filters, from which you can select the one that gives you the most detail in what you're viewing, and the other stores the image you're viewing on the included micro-SD card.

After scanning the room, my computer, body parts, handprints left on walls, and other things around me I thought I should try something practical, like looking for home heat loss, so I put on a warm coat and headed outdoors. I didn't expect any surprises, as I had made a point of improving and updating all my insulation some years ago during a home remodeling project.  Even so,  I was immediately rewarded with some very surprising and useful information. Take a look at the photos, and you'll see a bright band of yellow right at the bottom of my house, where the basement extends above ground level. That's called the bond, and while it's often a major source of heat leakage, I'd made a point of insulating this area during the remodel after consulting with a contractor friend who specializes in energy efficiency. Yet even with the added insulation I've obviously got major heat loss here- something I can now address and then check with this imager.

Seek, the maker of this imager, has a number of suggestions for using the Reveal, like tracking downed game, looking for your pet, checking your yard for intruders (human and otherwise), checking tires for wear, looking for electrical problems, tracing clogged pipes and a whole lot more. I suspect I'll be pretty busy this week exploring everything it can do.
summary: Amazing (and useful) technology for not a lot of  money.

reviewText: This filament works great with my Dremel Idea Builder 3D Printer, even though they recommend their own (more expensive) brand only. Since it doesn't fit on Dremel's spool, I use the HATCHBOX 1 Spool 3D Printer Filament Tabletop Wall Mount Rack and feed the filament through one of the holes on the exterior of the Idea Builder and it works great. Prints are nice and smooth. I like it much more than Dremel's filament. There is a slight gloss to the final product. This is great filament at a good price. A free sample was received for testing and an honest evaluation. The manufacturer/seller was not promised a positive review, and no compensation was offered or accepted.
summary: Great filament, glossy and smooth prints

reviewText: very good filament will be ordering more soon
summary: Five Stars

reviewText: Prints quite nicely.  Actual color is more toward pink, while this image shows more toward violet.  But, the print is good and comparable to JustPLA Pink and eSun Blue as shown in the picture.  Prints well large or small.

reviewText: At the beginning of the roll, this filament printed beautifully. But after a few prints, the width of the filament changed drastically. Going from 1.75 to 1.95. I have attached photos of the white 3D4Use filament, next to grey Monoprice filament so you can see the difference. I have also attached a photo of the filament as measured by my digital caliper.

reviewText: The product arrived in a nice vacuum sealed bag and was smaller then I was expecting. I was a little skeptical about if the metal in the filament would improve the qualities of the material. After testing this filament it seems that the aluminum made the pla more flex then normal. I was not able to polish my prints, but the color of the pla is very nice by its self. Overall its a very interesting filament that all 3d printer owners should try.

reviewText: A unique look and feel for PLA, I really like it. It prints with no problem and the parts are no weaker than plain PLA. The only negative I can think of is that I read it could be buffed and polish to a shine. If that is the case I have yet to pull it off, not for the lack of trying.

reviewText: The listing calls these economy grade terminals but these are very sturdy and high quality.  The only thing economy about these is the price.  They crimp nicely and the shielding is thick and durable.  This is the best price around and most definitely a sturdy as nd reliable product.

reviewText: I tested this Star brite Outdoor Furniture Protectant on my polymer-type storage bench, which has been outside over two years, and was starting to look kinda ratty w the rains, pollen and general wear. I sprayed this milky white liquid onto my bench and wiped up w a paper towel, and the finish looks 100% better, as if I had just waxed it like a car. The surface feels smoother, looks glossier and seems like it would repel water better. This product is easy to use, and comes in a spray bottle that's fairly ample in size- I barely used but maybe 10 or so sprays for the entire bench, as a little goes a long way.  The directions say to spray the cloth, actually, but there was no damage from my spraying directly onto the plasticy material my bench is made of. I like the finished look, and would recommend this spray to give new life to your old outdoor furniture.
summary: Looks Like I Waxed My Patio Furniture

style.Size:: 25 Oz Bottle = 20 Gallons of Cleaning Solution

reviewText: I have a Hoover steam cleaner and since this can be used in those type of machines, I decided to try this cleaner in comparison to the Hoover Cleanplus steam cleaning solution and the Hoover Platinum Professional strength, which is what I normally use for my light colored carpets. In this case, I used roughly one ounce with hot water in the container for the machine. This solution doesnt seem to create as many suds as the Hoover solution. The instructions indicate that you also have to rinse the solution with clean water which I don't do with the Hoover solution. This has a light pleasant citrus-y smell and I like the fact that is it a natural cleaner. I don't have pets and the dirt in the carpet is just normal daily people traffic. Cleaning wise, the water was dirty and the solution did clean the carpets without affecting the carpets color at all although I think both Hoover solutions do a better job overall at cleaning as the water is blacker and the carpet looks a bit cleaner, with the Hoover Platinum doing the best overall job. For a natural carpet cleaner this does a decent job, although I prefer the Hoover Platinum for a deep carpet cleaning. 4 stars I was provided a sample for review and I do not promise a good rating in return, nor am I affiliated with this company or compensated.
summary: Decent for a natural cleaner

style.Size:: 25 Oz Bottle = 20 Gallons of Cleaning Solution

reviewText:
I have not one, but two dogs, people who don't remove their shoes at the door, plenty of dirt, and mud, a combination that makes for a nasty carpet.  I do have a carpet cleaner, but in close quarters at this time of year, I don't want to use it.  Its not recommended that one use a carpet cleaner on wool rugs, but I do as part of my spring cleaning regimen.

My predominantly ivory-colored wool oriental was a poor choice given the type of dogs I have.  One of them can swoop through a door and track mud all over the floors and that oriental in no time flat.  I have used an all-natural carpet cleaner before, primarily as a spot cleaner.  I decided that Id give Puracy a try, but not in the carpet cleaner, but by hand.  I hauled out a bucket and gave it a try.

I poured about three quarts of warm water in a bucket along with a single ounce of the Puracy (1 oz. Cleaner:  100 oz. Water).  Mind you, an ounce isn't much cleaner and this container is going to last a very, very long time.  It hardly looked as if I used much, if any of it.  Once I had my formula ready, I began to work on the rug.  I did used a sponge, working the formula into the top layer of the rug.

In spite of having vacuumed through, I was still pulling up quite a bit of dirt from the carpet.  By the time I got through, I had a pretty grungy looking pail of dirty water, as expected.  I didn't have to scrub like crazy, but rather a gentle, but firm circular motion seemed to do the trick.

What I liked was that I didn't have to saturate the rug to get results.  I was easily able to clean the rug without having to go through a lot of cleaning formula with more than satisfactory results.  I also like the fact that the Puracy is a plant-based formula.  Granted I do use plenty of chem-laden products, but if I can I do like to use chem-free, especially if the results are satisfactory.  Im very pleased with the results and would definitely spend the asking price (around $20) to keep this product on hand.

INGREDIENTS:

Purified Water, Decyl Glucoside (Plant-Based Cleanser), Octyl Dimethyl Amine Oxide (Plant-Based Cleanser), Lauramine Oxide (Plant-Based Cleanser), Tetrasodium Iminodisuccinate (Biodegradable Water Softener), Zinc Ricinoleate (Natural Mineral-Based Odor Removal Agent), Sodium Citrate (Plant-Based Softener), Pink Grapefruit Essential Oil, Benzisothiazolinone (Biodegradable Preservative)

Sample provided for review.
summary: A great chem-free carpet cleaner that worked great for me simply using the bucket / sponge method ...

reviewText:
I like this dolly. Make no mistake; this is not a refrigerator dolly, or even a garden dolly. This is a convenience item with a strong emphasis on being light weight and compact over being a rugged workhorse. This is the dolly for a business person who picks up a couple of reams of paper from the membership club store and has to schlep it from their car to the storeroom. Its a back-saver for me for those weekly trips to buy a few cases of bottled water. It folds flat and opens VERY easy and is well suited to carting case-sized boxes around. On the downside are three notable cons:

1. The wheels are small and narrow. They work fine on hard surfaced floors or commercial grade no-pile carpeting but bog down in any carpet with a deep pile and don't make for a very stable ride across uneven asphalt pavement like found in most parking lots. The wheels do ok over curbs but not for stairs. If you don't use a bungee (one is included) you're likely to be stopping every few feet to load your cargo back on the platform.

2. The construction is light duty. Too much weight will bend or break the handles. If you have to tug hard to tilt it back to lift your cargo it's probably too heavy to haul on the cart.

3. The price is out of line with competitive models that state a higher load capacity but have a lower selling price.

I attached a couple of photos that give a little clearer look of the product. It seems the seller is using black & white pictures, the actual product is yellow, black and silver.

As I said I like this dolly for what it was designed for and I rate it as such because I find it handy, helpful and reasonably well made. But it falls short of being as good as it could be.
summary: A handy convenience item for light loads

reviewText: I was looking forward to the 100 each of 1/8" etc balls, sorted into nice little bags (as many reviewers have indicated). Instead I received quite a different story. As you can see from the photo what arrived was a small plastic flip-top container with the balls all mixed together. I'm not saying I'm unhappy with the actual balls, but I really needed them separated into sizes. As a remedy I fired up my 3d printer and made a handful of incrementally bigger plastic "sieves" that I could use to sort the balls. Once separated I put them into a multi-section parts storage box. Also please note that the assortment also included 10x 1/2" balls (nice!). In my package I ended up with a lot more than 100 1/8" balls, just about 100 5/32 balls and I didn't count the rest. I'd probably buy this again, but I thought future customers should know what they're getting. I will put my sorting boxes up on ThingiVerse if anyone wants to make them.
summary: Not sorted, comes all mixed up.

reviewText:
~7 hour print ruined by tangles and stuck to itself in the spool.
Tangle was so tight, my extruder pulled the spool & holder forward to fall over!
Feel lucky my printer was not damaged.
See attached photos.  Stay away from this stuff!!

Was going to return; but, have just missed the return date.
I will have to re-spool this roll to use it & baby sit it for every print.
I didn't have to do this with that "H" brand that is out there, get what you pay for.
summary: Tangles and stuck to itself in the spool! Stay away from this stuff!!

reviewText: Ive been printing for over a year now I have printers both at home and at work. Until now, Ive stuck with the same 2 or 3 brands of filament that had received high recommendations from colleagues and online reviews. Since there are so many brands on the market now, how will I know if the new (to me) names are as good as my tried-and-trues if I don't give them a go? The IXCC white PLA Filament arrived quickly and well packaged. The vacuum seal on the roll was nice and tight, with no leaks, so that was a good way to start! As I unrolled the filament, it had the same look and feel as my other brands: smooth surface, fairly stiff and straight but with enough give to unroll evenly. I took a few measurements with my caliper. The filament should be 1.75 mm. My readings were on the low end around 1.70 mm or 1.71 mm. The expected tolerance is +- 0.05 mm so the filament just made it. I have printed quite a few small items with it so far and am happy with its performance. No gaps, no stringing, no air pockets. Just nice, solid prints. Im happy I took a chance on a new brand of filament! I wouldnt hesitate to buy more! I received a discount on this product in exchange for my honest opinion. I try to write helpful, concise reviews for all of my Amazon purchases. If you found this to be helpful, please let me know by clicking yes below. Thank you!
summary: Im happy I took a chance on a new brand of filament

reviewText: My normal "go to" brand of PLA has always been Hatchbox, however iXCC is the first brand I've tried that can truly give Hatchbox a run for its money.  This filament printed smoothly, heated and extruded well, adhered to the printing bed well, and produced nicely uniform layers.  I'm 100% pleased with the quality and outcome of this product and I highly recommend it for any PLA printing requiring results of good and fine quality. So far, I have only tried iXCC's black PLA which was provided at a reduced purchase price in exchange for my honest review after testing and using it.  The black color is consistent and dark and very much like that of the familiar Hatchbox brand.  It is in my opinion, a worthy filament to invest in.
summary: and produced nicely uniform layers

reviewText:
I had a couple issues with stringing when printing small objects but I had more issues with dimensional accuracy when using this filament. It seemed to shrink more than some of the other brands I have used.

Also the red is a little more muted than in the pictures. Was hoping for a deeper red.

But overall was great value ($14.00 is what I paid).
summary: Easy to print but a couple minor issues but good value.

reviewText: Excellent filament.  I have so far never been disappointed by any of eSUN's filament I have purchased.  The decreased amount of warp compared to traditional ABS is noticeable.  With regular ABS, I would always print to an aluminum bed with a brim, Kapton tape, and "ABS juice" brushed on to prevent edge warp.  With this ABS+, no ABS juice needed and I can print directly to the Kapton tape.  This filament sticks extremely well while the bed is hot, but amazingly easy to remove once the print has cooled completely.  I'm printing with my hotend at 250 and bed at 100.  Polishes nicely with acetone if desired just like plain ABS.  The smell is drastically less, although I still print in a bathroom with the outside ventilation fan on high as with any ABS, I'm sure the fumes are still there whether I smell them or not.  Very pleased, I've attached a picture of a digital sundial I printed as the first test print.
summary: Excellent

reviewText:
My experience with eSun ABS+ Blue has been very positive. In fact, I decided on this particular filament to create my products. I have printed very successfully with three nozzle sizes: 0.4 mm, 0.6 mm, and 0.8 mm. I have printed two reels so far and ordered several more. I am printing on a Rasie3D N2, bed heated to 80C, print temp 260C, speed 60 mm/s. retraction 0.4mm. I find very good layer adhesion and a semi-gloss finish. I have been able to use acetone to polish it.

I first decide to try this filament as I needed ABS but, because of the shrinkage, was worried. Then I found this product which claims very little shrinkage. And that is what it delivers. I've included a photo of a tool I made and another of a prototype run of one of my products.
summary: Works very well for me

reviewText:
This is my go to when complicated projects need the strength of ABS with low warp.  It does shrink but not as much as normal ABS..  This stuff is amazingly strong and great for quad copters..  With the right print settings,  the frames become almost crash proof.

With over 3000 hours of printing ESUN has never let me down.
summary: The stuff dreams are made of.

reviewText: eSUN filament has never disappointed me and I have tried about 7 of them.  My first experience with ABS+ was with eSUN's black filament which I love.  This white ABS+ prints great, has very little warping, excellent strength and is not over priced for a premium filament.  I printed an extruder (pictured) for my Bowden set up and it is solid. Also pictured is a bottle handle/holder and can handle.  I have found with the ABS+ filaments from eSUN, higher extrusion temperatures are required for the best layer adhesion, however, lower bed temps to get great base adhesion.  I print with my hot end at 255C and bed at 90C.
summary: Great Filament

reviewText: Meh it scans. The quality is pretty crappy to be honest. But if your looking for a toy or you don't need much detail it's ok. Probably will give mine to brother and get something better eventually. Attached is a scan I did the blue lines were where the scan failed and I had to patch in separate scans.
summary: Its more of a toy and less of a tool.

reviewText:
Over the course of about 5 weeks, this printer has been printing a TON. I mean, my printing time is 20 days and 10 hours.  Has it been perfect? No.  I've had a couple of clogs that required taking the extruder servo / fan off.  I've had to clean the nozzle a few times.  I've had to re-level the bed here and there.  But for the price I paid it's been amazing.  If you're willing to LEARN about the machine and how to take care of it, it'll be fine for you.  I print mostly with PLA, but I've done some PETG and a little bit of ninja-flex.  All of which has turned out great.

I haven't run in to the problem others have mentioned with their power supply, but I'm keeping an eye on it. I figure if it were going to go, it probably would have by now.  Also since buying it I've installed the Swiss Micro all metal hotend for the MK10 type extruder and that's been awesome. Another thing I did that I think is very beneficial is I made a wood platform for it that I strapped it down to (with printed braces, of course!) and a vertical board attached to the mount surface to keep the tower nice and rigid.

Bottom line is that I very strongly recommend this printer for anyone who wants to get in to the hobby and isn't afraid to take a few screws off to troubleshoot the machine.  Being a flavor of the i3, there are TONS of mods and videos about taking care of this machine.
summary: Very glad I chose this as my first printer

reviewText:
So this machine has driven me crazy and I have a love/hate relationship with it.

What I love:
Cost - This thing is cheap as can be for a i3 design
Set up - This thing has like 4 or 6 wires you simply plug into matching labeled plugs.
Quality prints - Once you dial it in (takes a fair amount of work) it's amazing.
Print your own parts - If you can get to printing rather quickly you can easily print your parts to get the machine patched up rather well.

What I hate:
Bend carriage plate - I've had amazon send me 2 now and both have bent carriage plates. First was very noticeable and I did everything I could to put a bandaid on it but I couldn't do it. Second wasn't as noticeable until I started playing with settings and noticed an area where the lines got thicker than the rest of the plate.
Bent rods - The Y rods on the first one were bent and out of alignment causing the bearings to be bad as well.
Alignment of rods - Both printers had they Y and Z axis out of alignment and I had to adjust them. After you do this once it's not so bad but still a pain.
Bearings - Holy hell have 4-6 on hand to replace these with as 75% of the time you get bad bearings so where on the machine.
Spool holder - I've only came across one brand of filament so far that fits well on the original spool holder and the filament was terrible. You'll be printing one ASAP to add length.

Summary - I know there's a lot of things I hate but even after seeing all that myself I'd still buy it again. The only thing I would do differently is, I'd buy all the extra parts needed at the same time as the printer.  Buy the Carriage plate drilled with the 4 guides for the Wanhao style i3. Buy 6 bearings to replace the 6 on the machine. Buy some hardened rods in case you get one with bad rod, or they bend over time, because eventually they will. There's also a Mosfet upgrade that needs to be done to the machine that costs maybe 20 bucks, I've not done it yet but I plan on it in the next week or 2.

3D printing isn't plug and play, you have to be a tinkerer. I knew that buying this and that's why I'm giving it 5 stars. The only way to avoid the tinkering and problems is to buy a $900 dollar machine and if you had that budget, you wouldn't be reading this review.
summary: Amazing cost, NEEDS tinkering to be amazing machine.

reviewText:
Printer itself is good however has some issues and mine came with broken navigate button but print quality is pretty good for the price
edit: after 2 weeks of use printer started to restart in the middle of print and i have some burning smells comes out from the unit.

reviewText:
Very nice printer.  I've had it for a week and have tried PLA, PETG and ABS without problems.  I made the thumb wheel modification right off the bat to make leveling the bed easier.  Other than that, I haven't had to change much.  Put some glass on the bed to print ABS.  In order to do that, I needed to print off a z-axis endstop  adjuster ([...]).  I've been really happy with my results.  Would definitely recommend this printer.

The aluminum bed came with some dents/scratches.  I emailed customer support with photos and I had a replacement bed within a week.

After 4 months it's still working great.  Highly recommend.
summary: Great value, nice prints!

reviewText: I've used more expensive borescopes, and this one is similar quality, but with better features and easier to use interface and form factor. The 3 meter length and compact screen/power unit is simple and versatile, much better than 'gun' type borescopes in my opinion. I like that you can use a standard microUSB cable for charging, and if I ever need to replace or upgrade the rechargeable battery, it's a standard 18650 cell in a compartment accessed simply by opening a screw- I wish more electronics had such accessible batteries! You will also need a standard microSD memory card. My only complaint is the same one I have with every borescope I've seen- the built-in LED light is far too weak. I use this as an energy auditor to inspect roof cavities, inside of walls, etc. Sometimes the light is enough, if the camera is very close to what you're looking at. But for use in a large open space such as a roof cavity, I've modified this by zip-tying a small but bright (130 lumen) AAA flashlight (see photos). I've done this same modification to another borescope at my last job.. I'd much rather pay more for a borescope with a brighter integrated light, since my modification about triples the head diameter, though I can remove the light if I need to. But I don't hold that against this product, since as far as I can tell, every borescope on the market has this issue. It comes well packed, and even with clear instructions. The padded box it comes in is nice enough to keep and use for storage and transport, but a more compact and convenient solution is the AmazonBasics Fixed Zoom/Compact System Camera Case, which fits this borescope and all the accessories pretty much perfectly. It also fits the Bosch Daredevil DSBS5003 3-Piece Stubby Spade Bit Set in a side pocket, which is great to keep with the borescope, so you always have the right bits to fit it either with or without the added light. By the way the light I added is the 'Titanium Innovations Illuminati CA1-AL LED Flashlight with 132 Lumen Cree XP-G', available for about $30 on battery junction (google it). I've looked at many flashlight options (I'm a bit of a flashaholic..), and this is currently the best I've found for this purpose (and a bargain, considering the quality, size, and output). So in summary: Buy this borescope, a microSD card (if you don't have an extra one lying around), the Amazon case, a set of spade bits, and a bright AAA light, and you will have the perfect borescope kit for less than even the cheapest model of one of the more 'professional' or well-known brands. I'm the kind of person who believes you get what you pay for, and usually I'll spend more for quality tools, but in this case, you probably won't get better quality by spending more (unless you go really high end, as in $1,000+..)
summary: Surprisingly great borescope

reviewText: This is a pretty darn good magnet for the price.  No, it is not neodymium and they are not "super magnets."  That being said four of these expoxied to the back of an LED light strip 4' long will hold it solidly to unistrut forever.  I have used almost 100 of them now holding light fixtures up in my shop and they have never let me down.  The surface is a little rough and accepts epoxy very well.  And they REALLY stick to each other!  The breakaway force for one magnet, tested in the manner shown below, comes in at .8 to .9 pounds, and this number is remarkably insensitive to the thickness of the metal surface.  I even measured this force level on 400 grade stainless cabinet.
summary: Hard to beat the performance/price of this magnet

reviewText:
These don't seem to be as strong as some sold as "rare earth" magnets, but they're still quite strong and stronger than other regular magnets of the same size I've bought.  (I like magnets; the entire front of the 'fridge is covered with an array of things!)  For the price they're especially good from a bang-for-the-buck aspect.  I got lucky and paid only $14.99 as an Amazon Lightening Deal, but I think at several dollars more they would still be a very good value.

I'm not sure exactly how to quantify how much they can hold.  They're not, for example, difficult to pull off the refrigerator as some I have are, and as in one of the photos I'm posting, they're strong enough to suspend a full canister containing 8.11 ounces of gas (plus the weight of the canister), but only when three magnets are ganged together.  In the photo I'm using more magnets, but three does it, fewer won't.  One magnet will leap up to join another from a distance of about 1".

Bottom line:  these seem to be stronger than average magnets at a very good price.
summary: Quite strong (but not as strong as some expensive rare earth magnet) and at a very good price

reviewText:
This is a review of the Slip Guard Non  Slip Tape 12 Pack.

Summary  I have a wooden front porch and after replacing the front steps and painting, I found those steps are very slick when wet and could not imagine how bad they would be when icy. These are a perfect solution.

Each of the 12 tread adhesives is 80 grit in roughness and measures 6 deep by 24 wide. What I like about these are they are the perfect size for steps and require no cutting or measuring. Simply pull off the back protective cover to reveal the sticky adhesive and press onto your surface. I used a roller to ensure they were affixed the best they could be. (If you are looking online for a roller, I found they are called a brayer.)

To obtain the best results, do not expose these to water for at least 12 hours after install and make sure the surface is clean. A roller is also recommended to ensure you get the best bonding between the treads and your surface. Also, no issues with memory result from the product being rolled up for transport. They laid flay without issues.

So far would recommend and I will update this review should these develop issues with ongoing use.
summary: I found those steps are very slick when wet and could not imagine how bad they would be when icy

reviewText:
Good. But not great.

1) I had 6 failed prints due to clogs on a .4mm nozzle across the entire temp range with varied speeds and retractions. This was with the MicroSwiss all-metal hotend on a Wanhao di3. No joy. Printed fine for a few hours then borked up. Finally had success with a .5 nozzle.

2) Print quality is good - but definitely a little more plasticy than comparable product from hatchbox.

3) Spool size is very strange. Had to make a new holder to accomodate it. Very wide, only spindle contact is spool edges, so a holder that is too short will give you headaches.

4) I have questions about purity. All of the clogs output a sticky goo when unclogged that didn't cool like pure PLA. Wondering if there's not some kind of glue or binder in the sawdust they sourced. Didn't have any problems printing with a .5 nozzle but at .4 I had zero luck.

5) It does seem to handle overhangs better than the hatchbox product I had gotten used to.

-- photo is straight off the bed, no sanding or finish applied --
summary: Not - quite - as good as hatchbox wood - but generally cromulent.

reviewText: Bought this instead of the hatchbox as it was sold out.  So far so good.  It printed great on my MP Maker Select Mini with my regular PLA settings other than reducing the print speed from 50mm/s to 40mm/s.  210 extruder/60 bed.

reviewText:
Of course, as soon as I got this, I tried the Groot bust. It came out nicely - I ran it at 212c and everything went well. I took away a star from what would have been a 5 star review because of the spool - the inside diameter is too small to fit on my Printrbot Simple Metal spool holder and I had to rig something with the handle and a clamp. Otherwise, fine stuff. No clogs yet :)

Edit: OMG strings! For Groot, it worked fine but as soon as I started printing something with supports (by Meshmixer) STRINGS! I've dropped the temp back down to 207, but it's still starting its own cat's cradle. The photo isn't a failed print, it's the strings from this filament! At this point I would not recommend this. Hopefully I'll find the right settings and it won't be a complete loss.

Final edit: Nope, I'm just not up to experimenting with this stuff. I have things to make, and if they can't give settings for their specialty filament, I'll have to use other that works right without hours of tweaking. Returning the filament and getting another.

reviewText:
This is a kit of parts, not a 3D printer.  It takes several hours to assemble the printer.  The instructions are good enough.  The parts seemed to be good at first but as I assembled the printer I found some defects.
1) One of the guide bars had some deep grinder or  machine tool marks so the bearing did not slide smoothly.  I'd say about 1mm deep in multiple places along a 10mm length of the bar. (See photo)
2) One of the four linear bearings was broken, loose balls and non-round hole.  Would only "slide" over a bar if force where applied.  They should glide with very little friction.
3) there was a dead-spot on the LCD.  The LCD screen works fine except for a 5 x 30 mm box near the top. (See photo)  I can still use the menu system, just can read part of the screen.
4) A short on the main board prevents use of the z-limit switch.  The switch itself is fine.  The main board works except for this one problem. (I was able to repair it.  It was a solder bridge under one of those micro size surface mount capacitors)

The seller does respond to emails quickly when I use the Amazon web interface to send messages.  Replacement parts however use a slow shipping method from China (not Prime shipping)
I will update this review as I receive replacement parts.
I was able to assemble the printer with the 3 good bearings and defective rod, the Y axis wobbles but replacement parts will fix this.  The electronics works, and I can guess what is printed on the defective part of the screen.  But the inability to home the z-axis means I have to turn the motor by hand and listen for the switch to click then edit out the auto-home command from the g-code file I want to pint.  Quite a lot of effort to make a test print on a wobbly bed.

UPDATE:  All four replacement parts arrived. (main board, LCDD, Y-Axis rod, Linear bearing)  As I type this I have just used my first spool of filament and the results are good.  You MUST check and level the bed if needed EVERY print.  When using the sample PLA filament supplied with the kit set the bed fo 60C and the nozzle to 215C print at 60mm/sec but the first player at 30mm/sec or slower.  use LOTS of glue stick on the aluminum bed.  Correct nozzle height:  Find thin paper, high quality inkjet printer paper is why to thick, place it between nozzle and build plate, You should just be able to slide the paper with friction.  You need about 0.01 mm gap.

I am getting good quality prints but.  It is not automatic.  You must pay attention to every detail and experiment with the setting in your slicer app.  Keep good notes about what works and what does not.  This printer is capable of very good prints but requires much car and attention and adjustment

I added photos of parts I made, three are printer upgrades and one is a robot "gripper".

I gave 2 rather than 1 star because the kit is still a good value and I have faith the issues might be resolved eventually (it might take a month).  I can change to 4 stars if this is resolved.
summary: Good value, well designed but many defective parts, still waiting for replacement parts.  UPDATE: Parts arrived.  Now 4-stars.

reviewText:

reviewText:
EDIT: 17 months later this machine is continuing to produce quality prints!

I just wanted to share my experience with everyone regarding the Alunar M508 3d printer. First thing to point out is this is a DIY kit and requires some build time, I was able to fully assemble and begin using within 6 hours. That being said you can expect nothing but the best performance from this amazing machine once set up, and should you need assistance during or after the build Alunar's support is lightning fast to respond.
Personally I have printed no less than 14 successful models all of excellent quality in the week it's been running, and flawlessly I might add. Honestly I believe that within a short period of time 3d printing in the home will be as common as game consoles yet far more rewarding and educational to both young and experienced. Do yourself a favor and search the internet on the subject if you're still unsure about the technology, I'm confident it will surprise you.
summary: That being said you can expect nothing but the best performance from this amazing machine once set up

reviewText:
Update: please read COMMENTS and view 2nd picture. I like ir BUT...
Original post was 5 star, but there is a recently discovered design flaw after four months heavy operation.

Outstanding bang for the buck if you are a competent builder I am 70 years old and have been assembling kits for 60 years. This took me 15 hours to assemble and get operating. I had no need to call support or test any of those types of service so I can't rate that aspect. This is not a "HeathKit" instruction set if you know their style. Google it and see.

Very complete set of parts and includes tools and spare hardware. Dropping one of the tiny nuts which disappears into dark outer space corner is not a game ender. Laser cut acrylic is outstanding quality. Yes, the "wood finish" on the acrylic is protective and needs to be peeled off. Probably one of the hard things to do but just part of the build. Tools are reasonable quality but I also used a few tools of my own. Pocket knife, etc.

Instructions are minimalist but valuable. I viewed the video (which does match my machine) before purchase.[...] This is a new updated version of this printer. If this intimidates, do not purchase the kit. If you have all thumbs, do not buy because of the low price. Things like end switch lever position are hard to ascertain but can be seen in different views. The kit build in the video is not sequential as sometimes assembled parts appear early (like the Z stepper motors) before assembly is shown later. Exploded views would be nice too but I take the cost into consideration. None of this derates MY opinion. Certainly important negatives to others. I wish my 70 year old fingers were as fast as in the video... :)

There is NO Printing INFORMATION other than a video for leveling the bed on how to do 3D printing. this is an open source RepRap style machine. Other software will run this machine. No operational information included in kit. A course in 3D printing will need to be obtained elsewhere, like from the software provider. Honestly, this is a good low cost open source XYZ machine. There are better hardware designs as I consider belt drive minimal. I have rated this kit and not the design. For the investment MY opinion is it is a great way for an experienced builder like me to get started in 3D printing at lowest cost.

The low sound level is comforting. I have three CNC milling machines in my shop (I also built) and this machine is no worse that a standard office printer. The side material cooling fan that discharges under the nozzle makes the most sound and I have not yet discovered if I can control it with software. It runs continuous. So after the lengthy but not impossible build, I am enjoying a new learning experience.
summary: Prior Experience Usefull

reviewText:
I bought these to split up a big batch of cuticle oil. It took me quite a while searching to find the right ones, and let me tell you the criteria I discovered matters:

1. Glass that is actually blue vs just painted blue. Yep, found many that were just painted flaky fading blue. These are actually blue glass.
2. Length of droppers. MANY that I first considered had droppers that only went hardly past the halfway point. Garbage! These ones have a dropper that goes all the way down to the bottom and can be wiggled around to get every last drop.
3. Leak-proofage. Many apparently leak, and these don't, at all. Did plenty of tests... filled the dropper, pushed and pulled at it, even sideways, while upside down... no leaks at all in any of the 8 that I've filled so far.
4. Regular sealed lids included? These ones don't. These only have droppers. Some also include a set of regular caps but they were more expensive so I stuck with these. I'm working with mostly carrier oils, so it's totally fine to leave the dropper lid in there at all times. With harsh (real) essential oils, the rubber dropper might interact badly with the oils. It just depends. But I'm happy with these for me. It was definitely worth the savings.

They look great and impressive! My oil is a bit golden yellow so it caused a green tint in the light. That looked pretty cool and I was happy to present them to the few people I gave them to. (Btw... my cuticle oil recipe: unmeasured lots of silky jojoba oil, a bit of grapeseed oil, a little bit of sweet almond oil, a littler bit of avocado oil... and a little bit of lemon essential oil for the scent and shine).
summary: Droppers go all the way to the bottom

reviewText: These 15.1mm x 10.1mm +/- 0.5mm M5 T-Nuts are just like advertised!! I order 100pcs and got 100 :)!! reviewText:
I purchased the 2" x 24" strips option of anti-slip tape (best value at time of purchase) shortly after purchasing a very tall and fancy new ladder. My boyfriend's foot slipped off one of the ladder rungs when he was about 18ft in the air despite wearing appropriate shoes and being careful. (He even has a lot of experience with climbing ladders after years of helping his dad with various construction projects.) Needless to say nobody is getting back on that ladder until my safety-proofing attempts are complete (this tape on every rung). My plan (not yet finished - see below) is to cut each strip in half vertically to make 2" x 12" safety strips, which will cover the majority of each rung. (I also implemented a new rule: no ladder use unless a second, responsible person is present to hold the ladder & ensure that it is stable.)

I felt that the quality of each strip was good based on similar/comparable products at local home improvement stores. The grit feels very thick and coarse, and it should last through an extensive number of supervised ladder uses. I have a pair of very heavy-duty kitchen shears that work well to cut through the strips, too. (Smaller everyday or desks scissors would really have a tough time trying to cut through the strips.)

However, each set of strips is packaged in a "rolled up" bundle, and the bundle seemed to be very resistant to straightening, which is certainly not conducive to proper application. (This is the main reason behind my 4-Star rating rather than 5stars.) My other main suggestion to the seller/manufacturer would be to add measurement markings in a standard grid format so that making straighter.  Currently, the backings to the strips are all plain white paper.  As of now, I've had the strips laying flat on my kitchen floor with stacks of textbooks sitting on top of them for about 3 days. The strips are now almost complete flat - I'll give them a few more days and then install maybe this weekend. Over, I do still think that this is a good product and safety measure.
*Complementary product received from seller for testing and review purposes.
summary: Great Product w/ 2 Minor Flaws
