reviewText:
SOME OBSERVATIONS TO THINK ABOUT:

1. At the selling price at time the review was written of just over one hundred dollars, it is overpriced. There is a PowerSmith ash vac that is virtually identical selling for about $30 less that comes with more accessories and has over 1200 reviews.  This product is not worth the asking price which is the main reason it only earns 4-stars.

2. The hose is only 3  that is a problem for a product designed to clean ashes. If I place it on the floor in front of my fireplace the hose has to reach over the hearth and all the way to the rear of the firepit. That distance is between 4-5. And to clean the ash from my kettle barbecue the distance from the ground to the bottom of the kettle bowl is over 5. I would have to lift the entire vacuum and hold it in the air to reach inside my barbecue.

3. It only comes with ONE tool (a crevice tool with a very large open end). There is no reason this should not be a multi-purpose vacuum but the seller has targeted as something designed for ashes only. Thats a lot of money to spend for a dedicated ash vac that offers no other special features over a standard shop vac

4. The LED hose is fluff. If you expected it to be powered from the vacuum you would be wrong, it gets its power from tiny hearing-aid batteries inside the wand. The light is located where the hose connects to the wand extensions and any light that gets thrown onto the work is insignificant and useless; the LED feature is nothing more than a gimmick.

THE PLUS SIDE

This vac is not without its virtues though. For one, the tank is all metal and the ashes are deposited directly into the tank, not a bag or any kind of removable container. That does require that the entire vac be lifted and dumped into the trash (which may be a bit of a challenge for some people because it can get quite heavy once full of ashes) but I would say it is relatively easy to clean. After dumping the ashes the container can be brushed out with a soft duster-type wand. I also like that the nozzle and its extension are made of aluminum so if they do come in contact with ashes that are still warm they won't melt.

The hose has a non-crush spiral spring inside, another plus feature. And the hose twist-locks into the canister so it won't pull out during use. These are all reasons this product was rated generally positively (Amazon defines I like it as a 4-star product)

The replaceable filter appears to be a different size than other models used by the same company and does not appear to be readily available. Based on the price of other filters sold by this company though you could buy a whole new vacuum at the hardware store for about the same price. Compare that to the PowerSmith which uses a washable filter, keeping the overall cost of ownership down.

All things considered the biggest concern about this product (other than being overpriced) is the too-short hose which cant be extended. That plus the metal canister can get quite heavy and must be lifted and turned upside down to empty it. There are no handles to grab it or hold it so you end up having to wrap your arms around the whole canister or grab the plastic wheels which can pull out of their sockets.

Armed with these points to consider I hope this evaluation has been helpful.  A dedicated ash vac as a nice (but not mandatory) accessory to own but I would put its real-life value closer to about $50-60 rather than over $100.
summary: Several important things to consider

reviewText:
I've owned a lot of tape measures in my life, which have ranged in quality from the free ones they give away at Harbor Freight to fairly expensive stainless steel Stanley tape measures.

Out of all of them, this is my new favorite.  It is by far the heaviest tape measure I have ever owned.  The case is fairly rugged plastic but the extra weight is from the tape itself- it is at least twice as thick as the tapes in my other tape measures.  It is also more rigid when extended-- I was able to extend this tape measure over 7 feet without the tape folding over or bending.

This tape measure also has three other features that aren't seen on most other tape measures.  First, there are two strong magnets on the foot of the tape that hold it in place against any magnetic surface.

Second, when you pull the tape out, it automatically stays in position until you push the button atop the tape measure to retract it.  Most of the other tape measures I have used  required me to depress a button to "lock" the tape in place after I'd pulled it out.  That this one automatically locks the tape to wherever you've pulled it and then waits for you to push a button to retract the tape makes much more sense and makes it easier to use this tape measure when you have something else in your hands.  Also there is no risk of the "lock" button slipping and causing the tape to retract just as you are marking your measurements.

Third, the measurement markings on this tape measure are more clear than on most and, when set against a precision straight edge, appeared to be slightly more accurate.  I don't tend to use a tape measure when needing extremely precise measurements but having a more accurate tape measure has to be a good thing.

Despite its increased weight, this tape measure is the same size as my other 25' tapes.  It includes a belt clip on the back, which is pretty standard for tape measures.

Ironically, what makes this tape measure great is also its only shortcoming-- because this is noticeably heavier than other tape measures, it may not be the first choice if you will be doing a lot of measuring over your head.  For any other application, this will be my go-to tape.

I received a discount on my purchase of this tape measure in exchange for my honest and unbiased review of it.  The opinions and observations I have shared are my own.
summary: Heavy duty, built to last

reviewText:
The tape measure is something that is quite hard to improve on.
The basic design has not changed much over the years. There are, however, some designs that work better than others.
To test this tape measure I put it up against a very similar spring action Stanley tape measure that I have been using for years and a relatively new Harbor Freight tape measure I got for free with a coupon.

--Test Setup--
Standard of Comparison:
- A 1-2-3 block (accurate down to .0001"): http://amzn.to/1r7eMXX

Products Tested:
- This Trust Tape Measure: http://amzn.to/1r7dmwG
- A Similar Stanley Tape: http://amzn.to/1SnRsB7
- A Harbor Freight Tape: http://amzn.to/22FxyRy

--Tests--
- Inside Measurement (Butting the end of a tape up to an object):
  The Trust tape and Stanley Tape Read Right on in this test. The Pittsburgh was a 32nd strong.
- Outside Measurement (Hooking the tape onto the end of something)
  The Trust tape was a little over a 32nd under in this test. This is the main reason why I'm subtracting a star. I think over time it might fall into place as it loosens up a bit, but out of the box it reads a little short on external measurements. The Pittsburgh also read a little short, but only a little under a 32nd. The Stanley was right on. It should be noted that the Stanley has been used and abused and may have developed a certain slack which lent to it's accuracy here.
- Maximum Reach Test (How far can it extent supported only by the body)
  The Trust has a heavy end with the wide hook with it's 2 big magnets on it. This caused it to lean down throughout the whole travel of its reach, however it extended a whole 7.5ft before collapsing. The Stanley did about 6.5ft, but again it has been abused and I'm sure it has many weak points along it's reach. The Pittsburgh gave only about 6'2".

--Marking Comparison--
- Trust: 32nd marks on both sides without any extra fraction or other markings to distract the eye. Inches are marked between feet after the first foot. 16" markings are red and easy to see. The tape is very simple and clean. I think this does it justice. All of the info is there on both sides and is simple and easy to read.
- Stanley: Has only 16th inch marks on both sides(No 32nds). Fractions are marked on one side but I never looked at those markings and I think they kind of distract the eye. Inch increments after the first foot are missing. 16" centers are clearly marked in red.
- Pittsburgh: 16ths on one side and 32nds on the other along with fractional depictions. Fairly clean and easy to read with inch markings between ft after the first ft. 16" markings are small with just red letters and not as easy to see as the other 2.

--Conclusion--
  Despite reading a little shy on outside measurements, I think this is a good overall tape measure. I think as it breaks in and ages those readings will fall closer into place. I love the smooth nylon coating. It gives it a nice feel and keeps it from reflecting light. It will probably also help keep the blade from rusting and scratching and keep the markings good. The extra wide hook with magnets is both a good thing and a bad thing. Good in that it is easy to catch and grab things, bad in that it adds a substantial amount of weight to the end, reducing reach. I would love to see how far a non-magnetic one could reach. I only subtracted a star because of the reading slightly shy on external measurements. a 32nd isn't going to mess you up in 99.9% of jobs. This tape will replace my Stanley in my tool belt.
summary: Pretty Good Design. I like the Soft Nylon Coating.

reviewText:
I keep hoping to find a bronze filament that's bronze, and this one isn't it. At best it's a yellow ochre color - no metallic properties and certainly no actual bronze. Disappointing. May be good for a poop emoji though.

And after the poop emoji it made a nice loofah sponge out of what should have been a sculpture with 20% fill. Unfortunately iy decided that clogging the nozzle was more fun, so is getting returned to Amazon innediately. Crap filament.
summary: Not bronze

reviewText: This filament prints very, very well.  I print at 210 degrees on an unheated bed.  I was nervous to use it for support material but it broke off easily.  It has a bit of a sheen and looks great.
summary: Looks and prints awesome

reviewText: I used one of these as an endstop for the Z-Axis on a 3d Printer. Has worked great.
summary: Has worked great on a 3D printer.

reviewText: Perfect for my Littman 3200 Electronic Stethescope.  I also put my Maxwell, my hammer, my portable ottoscope w/ ophth attachment, pen light, and a small tuning fork in there with my badge.  It's a tight but neat fit with nothing being unduly bent or stressed.  Good construction but still quite lightweight.  A great product. The second photo is showing the product closed. The last 2 picture "under the dollar" is just to help give an idea of the size. I took a picture both of the height and width.  So, if you are like me and have trouble conceptualizing size with actual numbers, maybe that will help.
summary: Light, tight, just right. And under a dollar!

reviewText: This is fantastic.  I use it every day, and I would highly recommend it to a friend.  The action is smooth, the light color and intensity so adjustable, the glass so clear that it makes me happy each time I reach for it... except that flipping up the lid to the mag.  Well you put the light buttons a bit too close to the thumb slot where I lift the lid.  So I often hit the up or down as I'm trying to lift the cover.  There is a con here, but it's far outweighed by the overall quality, and that is the existence of a steel bar that must be extended to widen the foot so the light doesn't tip over.  Picture three on the product page is a lie.  You would never be able to extend the light over that girl's bed without the foot extended.  Every picture avoids showing the foot, but I'll show it.  Also I suggest that someone is present when the package arrives, because the light, when folded, has a pointed part that can come through a box even though it's protected by foam.  Once again, I do love it tremendously.  So 5 stars.
summary: A terrific upgrade from my old tube magnifier

reviewText: This is a nice stand that compliments my clear M3D Micro printer. It was easy to assemble and spool changes are a breeze. I have a competitor's filament stand as well and because of its design, it comes apart every time you change the spool of filament. It would be nice if this came with rubber feet.  I ended up putting little felt pads on the bottom.
summary: This is a nice stand that compliments my clear M3D Micro printer

reviewText: Finally got this thing working.after months of messing with it it was a simple intermittent break in a wire on the endstop(not the firmware). However it is still a pain trying to get firmware that will even compile for this thing.
summary: finally working

reviewText:
This is my second Kossel printer from Anycubic if that tells you anything.  I really like their products compared to some of the others I have seen and/or purchased.

The printer arrived in a nice heavy corrugated box inside of a padded amazon box.  Upon opening the box, everything was packaged in thick foam that looked just like the photo on the item page.  Everything was well protected.

The first thing I noticed in unpacking the box was a nice card stock Kossel product manual.  The included manual is head and shoulders above what I've gotten with other DIY kits.  The images were nice and clear and in color.  Everything about assembly was well detailed and it appears they had someone with English as their first language write it up to the point where you install the electronics.  Even then it was still easily understandable.

The plastic parts are injection molded instead of printed with the exception of the print blower nozzle.  All parts went together very well with no gaps or struggles to assemble them.  There's extras of most of the hardware included. The only hard part of the assembly is installing the motors in the frame (my advice, install the motors before you install the 20x20 aluminum extrusions).  Everything else is easy. If you can turn a wrench and follow instructions you can put this kit together.  This kit took a little longer to put together than the pulley version but it was still an easy build.  I would recommend getting some good 12" calipers and a nice set of hex wrenches.  The wrenches included are adequate, but it was much easier this build having bought a magnetic ball end set.  Measure and set everything like the end stop mounting blocks to the dimensions in the manual as accurately as possible to make calibration simpler. I would also measure the carbon fiber diagonal rods before installation too.  Mine were actually 2mm longer than what they were set at in the firmware.  This really helps with the flatness when printing.

The motors are better quality than the NEMA 17's that have come with other kits I've bought and the stepper wires are not hardwired into the motor for a change.  The item description says to download the driver, firmware and software from their google drive.  The board I received had a sticker on the anti-static bag stating the firmware had been uploaded (it had been).  The included SD card had all the software loaded on it, as well as pretty much any info you'd want know about the printer in .PDF documents.  The website does have the Marlin firmware from 02/28/2017 included in that package if you know what you're doing and want to use that release instead.

Upon commissioning the printer, I ran the bed level test and it was almost perfectly level.  After a little tweaking, this has probably become my favorite printer to use.  All in all, I am very happy with this printer so far.  I feel it was well worth the price and a worthy addition to the growing printer farm.  The photo attached came off of this printer using Colido's wood PLA filament at 0.2mm resolution.  It can print at 0.06mm resolution as well if you need really fine detail and don't mind long print times.  I reprinted this a second time at 0.06mm and it took 16 hours, still faster than the 26 hours my reprap clone took though.

Updated 03/21/2017:
I contacted Anycubic to inquire about purchasing the build surface that sticks to the glass bed since they are not listed anywhere.  They asked how many I would like to purchase and I responded three.  They came back with they are not available for sale as of now, but stated that they would send me three of them for free from China.  The next morning I received an email with a tracking for them and they are now in transit to me according to the USPS website.  Anycubic has been a great company to buy from so far.  No issues and the customer service has actually been helpful.

Updated 03/30/2017
The build surfaces arrived today as promised free of charge.
summary: Great printer and great company to buy from

reviewText:
The accuracy of the Delta printer is very good. It prints with far less ringing than my Cartesian printer. Very impressive smoothness of the outer printed shell. The Delta prints much faster than the Cartesian. I have mentioned that before. Its all about the mass and inertia thing. Less weight moving means faster and smoother printing.

On this Delta, the print surface is 200mm in diameter. The printing area is claimed in writing to be 180mm diameter. Thats 10mm short of the outside edge. The measured maximum round printing area is only 140mm when built following the kit instructions. (See pictures) There is a design problem.

I discovered the problem when I could not print a 120 x120mm box with a corner diagonal dimension near 155mm flat on the bed of the printer. An axis trolley hits the stop at the bottom of its column.

The reality is the available print area is NOT a round circle. The tern "diameter" led me to believe the 180mm printable area was round. Not true. It's a "puffed"-up delta area. The corners of this delta do reach to within 10mm of the edge at the columns, but the sides are 30mm from the edge. (see pictures) The effective ROUND printing area is ~140mm.  200mm - (30mm x 2) = 140mm

I first thought I need to lower all three of the existing side rails by about 35-40mm. That requires loosening all the rail and end stop bolts and sliding them all down the proper distance. Then I may get the 180mm claimed base print area without hitting the bottom stops. I am concerned as the print head already hits the axis drive belts as it is now. It would be disastrous if the print area is expanded more.

The software print limit needs to be set to 140mm (round) printable area. The largest  Square that can be printed is 99mm on a side.

But for now, it sure does print nicely in its 140mm sweet zone in the middle. The overall diameter of the print bed is marketing hyperbole. The important information is the size of the printable area. Depending on the printer design or in this case, an engineering decision, it can be far less than the bed diameter.

It can be noted as the Z height increases off the bed, the trolley can use the gained space from the stop and widen the print zone above the base without hitting the stop.

I had a bigger (300mm) version of a delta printer on my desire list but it was three times the cost of the 180/200mm version I chose. Its claimed print area is the same 300mm as its base diameter. I assume its printing area is also a puffed delta.

No big deal. The Cartesian can do the bigger projects and the knowledge from using, and nice printing of the Delta is an excellent experience. Just what I was looking for with the costs involved.

Now that I am smarter about Delta style printers I can see the better geometry design features in the larger machine I was investigating. It has much longer arms to the print head. Proportionally more than would be required just because of the larger print area. The outer edge of the print area is not close to the corner towers. Much better design thinking and print surface positioning.

There is a big difference in sound level between my two printers. The Cartesian is (now) almost silent in its operation. It has become quitter the more it has run. The Delta has significant whine as it is operating. Its too soon to say it may quite down with use. The linear glides are not the noise. It is the constant high speed operation of the stepper motors but it seems mostly to be coming from the extruder. Slowing the movement may abate the noise level of the whining, but then that is losing the advantage of the high-speed movement the Delta can manage.

Its the old adage, You pays your money and make your choice. The more you want or need, the more it is going to cost. Right now, I have all I need and I am not complaining. Just sharing the knowledge gained from hands-on experience.
summary: Not exactly as advertised

reviewText:
I read a review stating they had received a set that would not stand straight, but figured that was over 6 months ago. Well I decided to try this set considering all of the good reviews. I had a specific plan in mind that I would test them against a known source and make accurate measurement marks myself.
I don't expect perfect accuracy based on this price point. But the problem is I can't duplicate a measurement if the tilt results in fluctuating readings depending on which way the cylinder feels like tilting that day. Depending on what you plan to do with this set, it still may be a viable way to go. But unfortunately for me, it just won't work. I posted a quick phone picture to show how much it tilts. Hopefully I just ended up with a defective set, which happens to even the best of manufacturers.

Update: The seller contacted me and refunded me in full. They also contacted the manufacturer on my behalf to let them know about the issue. This was very unexpected and proactive of the seller.
I can definitely recommend a seller that handles situations with such integrity and diligence. I would not hesitate to purchase from the seller "Idealship" again. They make sure buyers are happy with their purchase or they take care of it quickly. I'm adjusting the stars of this product to reflect the fact that the seller will assure it is up to standards.
summary: Unfortunately the ones I received were not straight.

reviewText: The 860 is my first Roomba and I didn't quite know what to expect. I've been very pleased so far, but have found some things that I hope may be helpful to first timers and maybe some more experienced users. I'll put highlights at the top and the details for those who want more as this has turned into a long review... HIGHLIGHTS: +Setup is simple. Just follow the simple directions to remove the battery tag and the cardboard in the dust bin compartment. (I missed the latter at first - oops). iRobot has a great support center on their web site with manuals, FAQ's and helpful videos to show how to use the Roomba 800 series. +The Roomba seems to use the "drunken sailor" method of covering the floor. There was no obvious pattern to me in how it moved around a room. There was one corner it seemed to really like and it's probably the cleanest it's ever been! +I did not use the virtual wall other than for a quick test. it worked perfectly and was respect by the Roomba. +The Roomba is quiet for a vacuum but noisy enough to wake me from sleep. I have a small home and sleep on the main floor. I like my bedroom door to stay open. With the door closed or sleeping further away I expect this would not be a problem. I will probably get used to it. +The Roomba needs periodic maintenance beyond emptying the dust bin. This is important and iRobot brand parts are not inexpensive, but 3rd party parts are available for much less. +Compared to the 50% more expensive 880 package I think the 860 is a better value. I don't feel the need for a remote and don't need the virtual walls. If those are important to you, then it's probably better than getting these accessories separately. Bottom Line: The Roomba 800 series (based on dust bin contents) cleans better than my upright. That may be from going places my upright cannot. Easy setup, scheduling, and automatic operation help keep my floor cleaner than depending on me and my upright vacuum. Maintenance is needed for continued good performance but is not onerous. For The Detailed Review, Read On ABOUT THE ROOMBA 860: iRobot packages Roomba models based on included accessories. All Roomba robots in the 800 series are the same. The different "models" are different accessory sets. All include the docking station. The 860 also includes one dual-mode virtual wall to help contain your Roomba in your home and one spare HEPA filter. The 880 model by comparison is the same Roomba but adds 2 virtual "lighthouses" , an extended life battery, and a remote control to the 860 package. It does not have the dual mode virtual-wall of the 860. It's $200 more than the 860 as of this review. The Roomba requires regular maintenance and a iRobot kit with 3 HEPA filters, 2 Brush sets, and 1 set of rollers is available on Amazon but is much less directly from iRobot. 3rd party kits are available on Amazon for much less. SETUP: iRobot has VERY helpful information section on their irobot.com web site. You can find a quick start, detailed information, instructional videos (I liked these), FAQs, Manuals and other related information. I would have benefited from visiting the help center before setting up my Roomba. This is NOT to say setup is difficult: It's quite easy. Having an engineering background I jumped in and winged the setup. I missed removing the cardboard from the dust bin before the first run. When I pulled out the bin, there it was, no harm done. Moral: at least look over the manual or the excellent support pages described above. First steps include setting up the docking station, pulling the battery tab, removing the cardboard from the dust bin, and setting it on the dock to charge fully. Mine appeared to have about 3/4 charge out of the box. When I turned mine on with the center button I was prompted to set the time. Setting a cleaning schedule was just as easy after reading the instructions. OPERATION: Since this is my first robotic vacuum I was very curious how it would work. I used the center button to turn it on (after fully charged) and watched... The Roomba wanders around my rooms like a very drunken sailor! It's kind of entertaining the first time. It did find its way out of every corner or cage of table legs eventually. There is one corner the Roomba seemed to favor; a LOT. I think it's the cleanest corner of my home! I have not seen any obvious sign or learning intelligence in how it meanders around the room. After watching for an hour I think it probably covered the whole floor. Obstacles were handled pretty well by the Roomba. It found its way out of every place it could get into. Sometimes this took a long time, but it did find a way out. Other obstacles like throw rugs were handled pretty well but sometimes got pushed up rather than be rolled onto. The Roomba treated these like furniture and just changed direction. I have not used my Roomba where it would be exposed to stairs or drops. One thing that impressed and amused me is how the 800 series Roomba handles jams. I noticed it picking up a hair tie and then a napkin. I thought "Oh boy, now I learn how to clear a jam!" A few seconds later the Roomba "threw-up" the napkin and hair tie on the floor and moved on. I didn't see that coming and was duly impressed. Well done iRobot! I so not feel the need for the remote control. If I'm going to spot cleaning I'll be picking up the Roomba anyway. Once a schedule is set I think I'll rarely change it. My expectation that with rare use I'd spend more time looking for the remote than it would take to walk over and use the buttons on the Roomba. RESULTS: I have a smallish Electrolux upright and I have been very happy with. After using the Electrolux in another room I set the Roomba lose. I was impressed by how much it got compared to the Electrolux. In the very best sense I think the Roomba really sucks and it cleans better than my upright. It's important to regularly empty the dust bin of the Roomba. I know this sounds obvious, but I'm subject to the out-of-site/out-of-mind mindset. It's easy for me to forget to empty the dustbin and check the filter. The spinning brushes and rollers also require regular maintenance. Information on all this is in the manual as well as on the iRobot web site. CONCLUSIONS: I was first fascinated by the Roomba 860 when I got the chance to try it. After using it for a while I've come to like it quite a lot. It cleans better than my manual Electrolux and saves me time. The $500 price seems expensive to me. But how much is it worth to get back that manual vacuuming time? Over a year or two I think it should be enough to seems a fair to good value on just that basis. The Roomba has become enough of my home background that I don't think about it too much anymore. In fact I need to set reminders so I keep up with the maintenance and remember to empty the dust bin. The Roomba 860 has been a time saver and cleans better than my trusty Elextrolux upright. It's just a pretty cool new thing for a tech loving person like me and still simple enough for the non-techie. It's a very well done robotic vacuum refined by years of experience in the marketplace. I am confident the Roomba will continue to improve. This is a solid 5 star performance to me.
summary: Easy To SETUP, Cleans Very Well, Self Clearing, Pay Attention To Maintenance

reviewText: I had read about PETG and thought it would be a good material for several projects in my personal queue. Results with another brand were disappointing (they gave me a full refund, so I can't complain).  I've had good experiences with other solutech filaments & this is another example. Dialing the settings took 6 iterations. A 0.4mm nickel plated nozzle at 230C, glass build plate at 87C coated with glue stick, full cooling fan after the first layer, very slow rates of 28mm/sec and over extruding of 110% produced really good builds.
summary: Great stuff, requires patience

reviewText: Received this filament as a gift for my birthday (it was in my wishlist, hehe; Grandma knows what's up!). It LOOKS AWESOME! It prints great too. Not too stringy, strong layer adhesion, etc. To describe it I would say it's, "super bright day glow transparent yellow with hints of green". Kids in the 90s would be so jealous of other kids who had toys in this color! I uploaded pictures of the filament under different lighting scenarios: Fluorescent (kitchen), sunlight (through a window), and a video demonstrating how it looks in a hand (in a kitchen).
summary: Love this filament

reviewText:
I have tried a lot of those clunky metal caulk guns as well as the tapered (like toothpaste) tubes where u just cut off the tip for small projects around the house, and have always had a hard time w an even bead due to the difficulty in getting the pressure consistent for an even flow.  i was a bit wary of this kit, cuz it seemed so flimsy with the plastic, and because you have to buy specialized caulk in Adtech's proprietary tubes that fit the gun. Well, after trying this out, i'm a convert. I've never been one to rave about caulking guns, but, this is a keeper!! If anyone as amateur as me can make a clean line and smooth(ish) finish, regularly skilled people (or pros who want better tools) should have no trouble at all. i had cracked and irregular caulk and paint all around an old window, and was able to get a fairly smooth look in no time flat (ok, maybe not the smoothest, but this was a huge step up for me....).

The caulk tube is easily uncapped/ recapped with a snap for a tight seal, and the caulk itself was very smooth and washed off the custom tip and my hands easily (i did need to use a toothpick to plumb the tip) .  Because the flow is precise and very responsive to your finger pressure, i barely wasted any at all.  i actually think this will save me a lot of money in caulk compared to those big tubes that don't come out smoothly, and which often cannot be recapped well after being cut. This device is really handy, and i love it.
summary: Amazingly easy to use, w precise squeeze control- nice gift box

reviewText: I just received my 3D print removal tool and I can confidently say that it is not worth the price. The handles are made of incredibly cheap plastic that is very dull and scratched. Also, the handles are stamped with a 4 and 17 for no apparent reason. It does an okay job of removing parts as would any other removal tool. Basically, there is nothing special about these, so don't waste your money.
summary: Nothing Special

reviewText:
This is redundant but please research this product completely before buying like other reviewers suggested. I recommend watching a video on applications.
- Don't use with aluminum, it will corrode and eat away at it.
- Don't glob it on like regular thermal paste, this is conductive and will reek havoc on any exposed electrical contacts(its in the name of the product after all)
- Do enjoy ridiculous drops in temperatures
- Do turn the fans down low and enjoy the silence now that you don't need so much airflow
- Do enjoy the headroom in overclocking
summary: 8600k OC to 5.2ghz

reviewText:
I received a pair of these trimmers free of charge for review purposes.

Affordable utility loppers. Big curved, deep jaws. Handgrip is comfortable and nicely ribbed with soft-ish plastic for a good grip. These fit my large hands comfortably. These are lightweight loppers. They bit through everything up to about 3/8" stems, at which point they felt a bit unstable. Brilliant packaging, a blister pack with a front and back cardboard panel, beautifully designed, really sophisticated looking.

These loppers are not the same quality as my elderly but beloved anvil style Felco garden shears, but this is a tremendous bargain for a nicely designed pair of loppers. The curved jaws make it easy to slip between leaves and cut where you want to cut, you can see where the blades are more easily than with straight blades IMHO. How long they'll stay sharp and how long they'll last remains to be seen.
summary: Inexpensive but powerful bypass loppers

reviewText:
I received a sample product at no cost for evaluation and review.  We already have something like seven or eight pruning shears, ranging from heavy-duty and expensive to cheap and cheerful, and we try to keep them professionally sharpened.  With over a hundred roses (some huge climbers), they get a lot of use.

When these secateurs arrived, I thought they looked small, but in use they perform like my heaviest, sturdiest ones.  The light weight and ergonomic profile are noticeable advantages after hours of continuous use.  The blade is extremely sharp and capable. I was surprised at the size of cane they can handle, both living wood and harder dead branches (easily 1 cm in diameter), although I will keep these strictly for fresh wood to avoid dulling the blade.  Also they cut cleanly instead of crushing. The blade metal seems to resist dirt and it's easy to wash the sap off it before storing.  I find the handle really comfortable to hold, the spring is strong and the locking catch works, although the design didn't look terribly secure at first.

I also love the bright orange and black colour, I wish the handles were all orange.  I have lost sight of my green shears several times, and even my black ones can be difficult to spot if carelessly dropped on the ground.  But orange does stand out and the rubber stays fairly clean.  I am delighted with these secateurs and now they are the first ones I reach for when I have some serious pruning to do.
summary: Stronger than they look!

reviewText:
These are good garden clippers, and if you figure in bang-for-the-buck, even better.  That said, they can't compete with the much more expensive clippers I have (the brand that starts with an "F").

These are small clippers, which is a nice trait in some ways but not in others.  They fit in a back jeans pocket easily (although I'm not sure the manufacturer would want you to do that!).  They're sharper than a more expensive one I reviewed recently, and while they work well I see these as being my secondary rather than primary clippers.  However, those primary clippers cost considerably more, maybe three times as much, and as they're constantly being temporarily misplaced I like the idea of having an extra set or two that are less expensive alternatives at hand when I need them.  I can also use these for general work rather than wear out or damage my premium clippers.  These are the set to use when you need clippers you can jam into the the soil to cut roots!

The only design flaw I see is in the locking mechanism.  It locks nicely (on the right side of the clippers which is different than every other pair I've owned), but the lock tends to become engaged during use.  That is, whatever is being cut has a tendency to push the lock into the locked position.  That happens so frequently that I got into an automatic habit of using my thumb to unlock (or confirm that it is unlocked) after at least every two or three cuts.  That was a nuisance initially but now that it's became a habit I don't mind.  It is something that needs to be corrected by the manufacturer though.

Bottom line:  a nice, and nicely compact set of clippers that while not premium quality are a good bang for the buck.  As a secondary set, or to use for routine or tasks or those likely to damage your premium clippers, they're fine.

I received these clippers in exchange for testing and writing this review.  As you can see though, I've noted all the negative as well as positive attributes I could identify.
summary: Nice clippers for a very modest price.

reviewText:
These are packed in a cardboard box which contains a pine block. In my case the block was nothing like the nice block shown in the photo and it had a giant knot in it (not the tight grain shown). But I don't count that pro/con for stars in this review. I compare the set to a 2-flute set from Grizzly (a larger set), but comparable bits.  In the photos the shorter of the two bits is the HHIP bit. The longer bit is the Grizzly bit. Looking top down the bit on the right is the HHIP. I compared the two 1/2" bits from the two sets. I cut mid-piece into a light mild steel plate at about 470 RPM. Easy cut, fairly clean edge. Cutting was just as smooth as the grizzly set when moving the table in any direction.

As you can see in the photos the expose flute is very short ... perhaps 7/8" of an inch. Enough really for any work I'd say less than 1/2" (although I certainly did not try to mill out anything 1/2").  When on the mill it is really evident how short the fluted section is (see the photo).

I think this would be a great starter set or perhaps a set to use when you know you are going to heavily wear the bits down and don't want to damage a nice larger set.
summary: Short fluted section

reviewText: We have the 2 and the 4 flute bits. Going to get him the metal lathe for Valentines Day. Hes super excited and loves these. Still cant believe he has every machine you could every imagine but a metal lathe. He just completed his his welding certification and hes really excited about working with metal. He already plays with the laser cutter so this with be another tool in his collection to work on some thinks for the backyard and his man cave auto shop. Yes, I marked the blocks, as the assistant (lol) makes it easy to hand him tools when he ask.
summary: Nice set, get both 2 and 4 flute ones.

reviewText: I have been looking for a small, portable vacuum system for my room, bathroom, and adjacent workout room. The Anker HomeVac Duo is a great choice that I received at a discount for review and fits the bill pretty darn perfectly! It is essentially one of those hand-held dustbusters, but on steroids (much stronger suction, with reusable and washable filters, clear dust bin so you can see when to clean), and can be hooked onto the larger frame to make into an upright floor-vacuum! Numerous features on the vacuum cleaner make it extremely attractive: 1) adjustable speed: both on the handle of the handheld vacuum AND the upright frame has a power button and a speed adjust button, so you can choose how strong a suction to use (easy maintenance of floor vs. dirty carpet). I love the fact the buttons are on both locations so you can use them no matter what mode you are in. 2) The handle of the upright frame is foldable for easy storage. The floor module can also be removed for easy storage. 3) You do NOT need to remove the handheld portion to charge it! The included charging stand, in fact, is designed specifically for use with the vacuum in its upright floor vacuum configuration. On the back of the vacuum is a small hook that will latch into the charging stand for stability. The charging stand has a tall backing to allow docking and holes/screws are also provided, should you decide to affix the charging stand against a wall. And the bottom of the charging stand has molded-in storage compartments for the 2 suction tips! 4) The floor vacuum module can twist and turn to fit into tight spaces. There are also LEDs on the front of said module to illuminate the floor space being cleaned! 5) Included suction tips, 2 of them, can be used with the handheld portion to get a wide area lane going, or to get into smaller areas. I ended up taking off one star for one major reason: 1) I'm not sure if the model I received has a loose joint or something, but the floor module of the upright frame does not seem to want to stay locked in the perpendicular position, meaning 9 times out of 10 when I pick up the vacuum, the floor module slams straight down. The whole thing is light enough that I'm not worried about it damaging the floor, but I AM worried about it snapping the joint and rendering the upright frame inoperatble. Of course, this COULD have been a design feature to save on weight (as in to not have a stronger locking mechanism) but I would honestly sacrifice some weight to have the floor module lock into position more securely. Overall, I am very pleased with this small yet powerful vacuum cleaner. Would certainly make cleaning up my cat's litter much easier without having to drag out the central-vac hoses!
summary: The Anker HomeVac Duo is a great choice that I received at a discount for review ...

reviewText: I find this pH meter useful for different fermentation projects I have including brewing and vinegar making. The meter is first calibrated with calibrator solutions included in the set. A screw on the back of the meter is used for adjustment. The reading comes across fairly quickly and is accurate to two decimal places. After using the meter for a week the calibration seems stable and the meter itself appears to be of good quality and construction. Much nicer than strips because it can be reused and allows for more specific readings. The pH of a solution can also be micro-adjusted while the meter in in solution.
summary: I find this pH meter useful for different fermentation projects I have including brewing and ...

reviewText: I love this filament! It prints perfectly and looks wonderful. I did discover that I need a tad more retraction than I usually need with solid PLA. Once I got that dialed in I haven't had any issues.
summary: I love this filament

reviewText: Prints well.  Comparable to Inland Gold PLA and Solutech Clear PLA shown in this picture.
summary: Prints well

reviewText:
NOTE: My test was done with the 4-inch version of this tape but the 2-inch is the same thing, just not as wide.

It works and it works well. Very good quality and the adhesion seems very good as well (but ultimately only time will tell how well it holds up).

The hardest part was cleaning & drying the area before application. Cutting it to length and removing the backing to expose the strong adhesive was very easy.

If you have a slippery surface then give this tape or its 4-inch version a try. See my photo of the 4-inch version of this tape on some painted steps that can get pretty slick when wet.

NOTE: I was sent a free product sample for review. I was not paid or told what to write.
summary: Does the job and does it well; very good quality

reviewText: Came very well packaged. The seal was tight enough, air rushed in when I punctured it. Loaded and printed very nicely. Adhesion was so strong, I ripped the buildtak removing the print. Other black PLA I've used showed white whenever there was a stress point or any friction. This does not. The design i selected was to test the complexity and potential for failure. The filament performed better than expected. Even with the temp set too high (235C) the material didn't string badly. The result is a very solid piece with some decent heft to it.
summary: Very nice, strong, and versatile

reviewText: Pros: Works with both ABS and PLA, variable speed, comfortable in the hand, easy to use Cons: Feels like plastic; not "aircraft-grade aluminum", short USB cable, no English manual I own a couple 3D printers and purchased this 3D pen mostly for repairing prints, "welding" them together, or making small tweaks to them after printing. I was also curious to see what I could do with just the pen itself. I was pleasantly surprised to find it did, in fact, work with both ABS and PLA filaments and printed every filament I threw at it. It was easy to use as there's just a couple buttons to press to adjust speed. It certainly felt comfortable in my hand though it did feel a bit cheap. The description claims it's made of "aircraft-grade aluminum". I can't attest to it's actual construction as I've never handled aircraft-grade aluminum, but the 3D pen simply felt like plastic. This is subjective and I don't consider it worth subtracting a star for as the pen itself is very affordable. A couple other subjective cons; the USB cable is really short and, unless you have a power source close by, needs to be plugged into an extension cable. Also, the manual I received contained no English instructions but the device was easy enough to figure out without them just by looking at the Amazon page. It was quite easy to use this pen to "weld" 3D-printed parts together by extruding the filament slowly and moving the pen in a circular motion; similar to actual welding. It also worked great for repairing pits, separating layers, and other minor imperfections in my 3D-printed parts. I've never used a 3D pen before but I found it easy to use and work with and was even able to make some "artwork" with it. Overall, I definitely recommend this pen. The only downside I found was that it felt like it was made of plastic but I hardly consider that much of a con due to the pen's price and the fact that it performs very well. I've attached some pictures of 3D prints I've repaired or modified with this pen, as well as a separate video review of the pen and a couple pieces of "artwork".
summary: Easy to use, great for repairing 3D prints, and very affordable!

reviewText:
My Thoughts:

With the wave of 3D printers and I wanted to see what it was like to freehand 3D printing. I found this pen super easy to load and use per the instructions. The actual skill of creating something that isn't a glob of plastic goo takes some time. You will also need some more colors which you can find on Amazon. This pen will give you an orange filament that is good more making anything in completely orange.

A tip that helped me was to trace out what I want to create and follow those lines. Also you can change the speed which helps a lot when trying to stay within lines. See video.

The Bottom Line:

If you like crafts or want to build up an artistic skill, you can have a lot of fun with this pen.
summary: Takes some time, but Cool!

reviewText: these are geat for wiring up lights and things on your boat see pic
summary: Five Stars

reviewText: Nice LEDs, bought for a UT fan to light up a license plate me and my friend made for her Jeep from my home built CNC. So far all have worked and can in a bag with specs. 3rd time I have bought LEDs from CHANZON and have not been disappointed yet. Thank you for a great product.
summary: They make my projects shine

reviewText:
I had reviewed this before and my review seems to have disappeared. This is about Harbor Freight quality. Not bad for small jobs but you will want something better if you run cable for a living.

The cable tester came really scratched up. Overall it is OK for the price but nothing to scream about.
summary: Acceptable

reviewText: I do a lot with wire in cars and houses. I have been using black tape and butt connectors for years. My mechanic showed me these heat shrink tubing and i was HOOKED! I have been using the hell out of them. I just have to remember to slip them on before i combine the wire and i have a small torch to shrink them up. They make the connections water resistant and they look so much better. It doesn't take much heat and you will not need open flame to do it. Even a light works in a pinch, i have used this method but its not fun and i got burnt fingers:(. Just be careful.
summary: Whatnot Widgets 600 pc 2:1 Heat Shrink Tubing Wrap Kit 27 Total Meters

reviewText:
Bought these to replace the thermistor that was in my Monoprice Mini with e3d v6 head.  One problem is they are about 1mm bigger than the tiny ones that fit in a normal e3d v6 heater block.  My first attempt at making this work was to cement the thermistor in to a motherboard standoff and then screw that in to the screw hole on the block.  Glued it in, let set for 24 hours and then tried to screw it in.  Wrong threads.  I believe the stock screw has coarse threads.  Oh well.  Next I just took my Dremel out and put a grinder bit on it and made the hole slightly bigger.  Slid right in.  Mounted it using the screw, did a test print, magnificent temp reading.  Much more stable than the stock thermistor.

Overrall, great quality, looks very well put together, lots of wire and a plug.
summary: Works great in my Monoprice Mini....but read on....

reviewText: The first time I printed with this filament I had great success! My extruder temp was at 200* and bed at 55* with my first layers printed at 35mm/s, it laid down looking like silk on my Monoprice Mini V2. The rest of my print was at 40mm/s. The Ultra PLAs tend to act a little different for me when printing, so I slow my speeds down and that has worked for me with this color. I think it is a beautiful filament and packaged nicely with dessicant.
summary: Very smooth, silky looking texture

reviewText: nice PLA filament for the price looks nice and prints well. i used it on my Cr-10 and things are looking fantastic. keep in mid that the filament is shiny .i found that parts of my prints are shiny and some parts are not. it is not the filaments fault but rather the the way the prints are being printed my your printer so don't be alarmed melted perfect with my cr -10 s4 on 185 but i like to set it at 200 for a smoother flow . my prints in the photos may look like there are mistakes but don't blame the filament... it is bacuse the model has some issues and my slicing software did not do a good job
summary: great!

reviewText:
It's got a great pearlescent color like I haven't seen anywhere else. This stuff prints just like PLA, except it is way smoother. Like, it has a good deal of lubricity. Nozzle temp 210-230C depending on you.
The printed surfaces feel slick and smooth and the plastic glides easily through the nozzle. Bridges successfully and overhangs about as well as other PLA. Smells vaguely of PLA waffles.

I just ran an 8 hour print with it last night and ordered a second roll.
summary: superior color and smooth feel

reviewText: A vivid, shiny blue filament.  Printed well at 210 C.
summary: Very shiny!

reviewText: Absolutely one of the best filaments that we have used to date. Color is spot on. Prints beautifully and is as shiny and shimmery as the advertised photos. Will use this product again for sure! Decent price
summary: One of the best PLA Filaments made! Straight out of the box near flawless print.

reviewText:
Yeah, It's OK. This is the first ULTRA PLA from Solutech that I have attempted. It isn't melting or extruding at all like standard Solutech PLA.. When running a long filament out of the extruder in free air, the UPLA skins over immediately and forms a small balloon that gets filled with the hot UPLA flowing out the nozzle. Little bags or balloons of hot UPLA hanging from the nozzle. Not a long continuous strand. When actually printing, flow seems normal.
But I am having problems with zits and white heads on the surface of printed objects. With this color it looks like the surface of a strawberry with little seeds. I keep adjusting retraction and all the other associated printer settings (Simplify3D) Got one good print.  Seems to be very temperature sensitive. Trying to determine if there is a problem in the printer or the product. My printer is a Delta with a Bordon tube filament feed.
I'll get it working, but for now I'll rate it as just OK. Picture is both Solutech "Hot Pink" PLA left, UPLA right, the Strawberry Owl.
summary: Printing Strawberries

reviewText:
This color I really liked a lot when it flowed out of the nozzle and stuck. Being the first I tried from this company I was ready to not use the other colors I got from them. This was from losing a lot of jobs from another company backing out on me and killing all the momentum I had to get a really great launch on YouTube as a 3D printing page, still haven't got back to where I almost was but that's another topic for another day.

This stuff is beautiful and I made a lot of things I gave away to various Autism Awareness functions and while I managed to get what I said I would deliver to these people completely out of pocket, the amount of failed prints was extremely high. I literally am left with very little on a spool and I didn't get much done with it.

Looks is on par with the 2 others I've used 10/10 beautiful, ease of use very very low 3/10.

I have had worse but they didn't look as good as this, the bags had holes in them, and they snapped constantly. This stuff looked great and flowed well but wouldn't stick without glue and gobs of it. With as good as their filament has been to me, I'm hoping this was just a bad roll but I probably won't buy this color again and it sucks because I've had a lot of requests for it.
summary: This color I really liked a lot when it flowed out of the nozzle ...

reviewText:
Again a color from a company I love more than I can put into words. I've printed quite a few things with this and everything comes out looking beautiful. If you need a nice luster on a green get this one. So far best look on a green I've found.

I really liked this green and looked for things to print with it. Everything came out beautifully. Showing you the things I can show.

I used this from 190 to 200 just like the yellow from the same company.
summary: Beautiful green, buy it now.

reviewText: I wasn't so sure of this filament at first.  I got a little caught up on the fact that on the underside it looks a little rough, like it never really stuck to itself.  But after printing a little over half the spool away, it's now one of my absolute favorites.  Let me just say that this is a GORGEOUS color.  As for the bridges / overhangs, I'm not sure if I need to heat it up, or what... but it's still fantastic.
summary: Great blue color with a pearly kind of shine.

reviewText:
I have used Gorilla products for many years, they've got great adhesive power. This is the first time I've used this particular productconstruction adhesive in a tubeand It's almost caused me to swear off using this brand entirely. The consistency of the adhesive and the size of the tube opening means that it is nearly impossible to get and keep the product flowing. Don't think for a moment that you can dispense this adhesive with one hand while you hold anything else with the other: I had to squeeze with both hands just to lay out the bare-minimum thin bead for a marble vanity top.

This type of adhesive needs to be sold in a caulk-gun tube only, there's no other way to get enough force to lay it down properly. Shame on Gorilla for putting this in their line, and making DIY shoppers think this is an easy-to-use glue for small household tasks.
summary: You'll need a gorilla's hand strength to squeeze this tube

reviewText: I wanted so badly to love this stuff, but sadly I can't I used it with a hardened steel nozzle and a brass one, at every temperature in the advertised range and this stuff came out looking horribly every time. I tried in 5 degree increments from 190 to 230 and still no joy. The product might work on large flat surfaces but it is far too fibrous to work on any other surface. It does not do well with gaps and never evenly extrudes, I have used filled filaments before, everything from bronze and aluminum to wood, there is a trick usually to all of them to get the best out of it. I stopped trying to figure the trick out after 12 nasty looking prints, save your money and don't even try to go down that rabbit hole unless you are desperate for a large flat black cube that is surprisingly light and crazy expensive for what it is. Then this stuff is perfect. On to the quality issues. the diameter was spot on everywhere I tested it but you will need to rebuild your extruder drive system if you had setup to run TPU at some point. The brass feed teeth have a groove in them after very few uses and you would be better off with steel or at the very least have spares The steel extruder teeth that are best for this will cut the TPU but with withstand the abuse this filament puts them through. The spool however was junk, cardboard garbage that was made to look like you are getting a lot more than you are my spool weight was .41 kg upon arrival the cardboard must be 60+ grams so that means really you are getting .35 kg and a poorly wound .35 kg at that. It does produce a very cool look but it is not any stronger in my experience than PLA in fact in my tests the fibers run only one direction so if commonly failed at layer lines with 20 lbs of pressure on .5" solid peg. The Hatch box black PLA weighed in at 41% more and 1/5 of the price per KG and broke in the same hanging test (at roughly the same point of failure) with 78 lbs of strain unfortunately not flat black and no where near as cool to look at.
summary: I wanted to like it so bad

reviewText: I love this stuff. 210 / 50 degrees and you get the cleanest most perfect print with a lovely matte dark grey finish. Slightly brittle but super strong. If you print a part with a triangle inner structure it will really take pressure and stress. Here is an automobile pedal I printed.
summary: Tuff Stuff

reviewText: Love this stuff, will definitely be ordering more. Printing at 210 and 40. It is brittle before being extruded so handle with care.
summary: Love this stuff

reviewText: Prints very nice once you get everything set.  Replaced metal nozzle throat with one with a ptf liner and that fixed my jamming problem.
summary: Great filament the matte black color looks great

reviewText: I was skeptical at first because this stuff seems a bit brittle off of the roll but once it's extruded, it's solid as a rock. This is the by far the best filament I've printed with. I'm not one of those dudes that has printed with a thousand different types of filament. I'm more interested in functional parts as opposed to exotic designs. I needed something strong and functional.  This does both plus it's finish looks like a flat black textured surface. What really surprised me is how amazingly smooth my prints came out with this. I'm talking zero flaws and it blends together really well between layers so stuff doesn't even look like it's 3D Printed.
summary: Cool Flat Black in color and crazy strong

reviewText:
I needed something to move a bunch of dirt in my yard and decided on getting this as opposed to a regular wheelbarrow because it looked to be easier for me to use and better for my back.  For those curious, these carts appear to be made in China through a company based in Minnesota.

Although the instructions could be a bit better, the assembly is fairly easy with just a few bolts to attach the basket onto the frame and the handle and 4 pins to attach the tires.  Assembly took less than 10 to 15 minutes.  I don't particular like the cotter pins to attach the tires to the frame as I think they are easy to lose or break.  I would have preferred a more secure method.

For my use, I am using this cart in my yard that I would not consider to be rough terrain.  My biggest concern for the cart in rough terrain would be the tires that I can see being easily punctured in areas that have heavy thorns or sharp rocks.  For my yard, I am not concerned with that and this cart suits my purposes pretty well.  The cart is heavy duty for sure and weighs about 60 pounds but to my surprise it really does not feel like it as it is very easy to pull around and maneuver.  It has nearly a zero-turn radius and is very easy to turn around in tight spaces.  I loaded the cart full of dirt and found it still pretty easy to move around through the grass and soil.

The first thing that I do think needs to be added to these carts, I discovered after taking the first load of dirt to the back of my house which is down a slight decline.  The cart has no hand brake and can be difficult to stop or slow down when fully loaded going downhill.  For this price, a hand brake should be on these carts.

The cart release near the front handle is easy to use and allows you to easily lift the cart back for emptying.  The cart doesnt completely empty though and it would be nice if there was a back gate that assists in emptying of the cart instead of having to wiggle or shovel the remainder out.  This cart is supposed to have a 1-year warranty, but that is not clearly indicated on the instructions, packaging or the manufacturers website.  I do think the cart is a bit expensive.

Pros:
Easy to assemble
Seems to be sturdy, durable and well made
Stable and doesnt tip like a wheelbarrow
Easy to move and turn
Carries heavy loads
Easy cart release
Easy to empty (well mostly empty)

Cons:
Instructions and warranty information could be better documented
Tire pins easy to break and loose
Tires may not hold up on rough terrain
No hand brakes
Doesnt fully empty
Expensive

4 stars
summary: Needs brakes but otherwise pretty good hauling cart

reviewText:
I was surprised how small the magnetic base of this unit was... looking at the photo, it looks like many other such bases, but is much smaller than any I had seen before. It certainly has adequate magnetic power to hold an indicator rigid, as designed. The bottom has a shallow V-block form, to hold onto round surfaces better, and the base can attach to flat surfaces by both bottom and back sides.

I had been using an old push-button Starrett unit with rigid rods and a couple clamps, and this thing with its one-knob locking is a real joy to position by comparison. Once you have the notches in the rotating ball-joint collars turned the right way, it is very supple to position. Then tightening the one knob makes it all rigid as can be, comparable to my old Starrett. You want to support the indicator as you loosen the knob, because everything goes limp at once.

This base does not have any provision for holding indicators that mount by a small round stem. They say it will clamp a 3/8" stem but I never had an indicator with such a fat stem. It clamps dial test indicators which mount with a dovetail rail, and works with both Mitutoyo and Peacock indicators that I have.

As a "simple is best" type of guy, I could have lived without the fine adjustment feature, as the overall ease of adjustment of this base (plus the dial-zeroing feature of my indicator) make it mostly unnecessary. But it does work well. I was surprised there is practically no sideways slop in the fine adjustment joint.

I own a 3 inch milling vise made by HHIP about 15 years ago, and it is far sturdier and far better quality than another 3 inch vise I have with the Phase II label. They seem like a good brand, as far as modern import tools go.
summary: Works perfectly.

reviewText:
This stuff works.  We here in southern Arizona are already in fly and skeeter season (a bad omen this early in the year) so I was glad to buy this and try out.  It comes out as a smooth white liquid; not as thick as 110% sunscreen, but along that viscosity.  The lotion absorbs fast.  There's no noticeable scent, no burning sensation.  Active ingredient is 3-[N-Butyl-acetyl]-amino propionic acid ethyl ester 10% aka IR3535, aka Avon's Skin so Soft at a weaker percentage.  Repels skeeters and ticks for up to eight hours.  Keep out of eyes and off plastics.

This is marketed as a repellent, so that means some persistent mosquitoes will get on your skin.  In that case, <SLAP!>
summary: It's like Skin-so-Soft, only weaker

reviewText: Not sure what I expected but this epoxy is kind of impossible to work with. It took 18hrs till it was not longer tacky and continued to slowly run the entire time. I followed all the directions for the proportions. It is not something you can undo either sanding it doesn't really fix the globs because it is so high gloss. lost several prints. Might be a bad batch I know the box looked like it was hit by a truck but other than that kit seemed fine. IT DOES NOT ELIMINATE 90% OF FINISH WORK LIKE IT CLAIMS. you are far better off increasing your perimeter layers and getting a good rubber sand paper product. much better every time. might work to seal your flat surfaces. DO NOT TRY TO SAND THIS STUFF!!!!!
summary: Save your $20

reviewText: I've been disappointed with past purchases of similiar calipers but this one is FANTASTIC!  This one is better made than the one I recently purchased at Lowe's.  You can actually FEEL the quality when you pick it up.  It's solid.  There's no play in the movement.  The digital readout is dead on.  It's a breeze to use the thumb roller guage your measurements precisely and this one actually holds it position without going wonky.  Yeah, I really dig the large display,  especially since my eyesight is aging faster than my mind, but the really impressive features to me is the quality of the instrument and its accuracy and precision.  I feel like a fool for wasting my money on the other three I purchased this past year...compared to this one they are mediocre at best.  I paid full retail for those, but was offered this item at a discount for my unbiased and honest review.  I thought I'd be disappointed, but this one is the real deal.  I wish this had been my first choice.  That would have saved me so much frustration, time and money!
summary: I've been disappointed with past purchases of similiar calipers but this one ...

reviewText: So far so good, but I noticed that the 7408 AccuMASTER is pretty much the exact same thing as my iGaging IP54 Electronic Digital Caliper 0-6" Display Inch/Metric/Fractions Stainless Steel Body which I purchased for about $5 less. Yes, there are minor differences in the body of the unit itself, but I wonder if these are really the same device internally. When I lay them one on top of the other they are basically identical from the metal to the plastic body. (see photo) I have been noticing more and more that there are identical products being sold online here but under different names. I am guessing these are being mass produced in China and rebranded by savvy online retailers, unfortunately, it really makes it difficult to find the best product out there.
summary: Same as my EzCal?

reviewText:
As a hobbyist woodworker I generally don't need the accuracy of a micrometer or a set of calipers. I don't even use a ruler for most work; instead, I scribe from one piece to another to make cut lines, as most woodworkers prior to the industrial age . But there are some occasions where a set of calipers that can take precise measurements can be helpful, like sizing drill bits, measuring the depth of a hinge mortise, or setting the depth on a router plane. For those cases I do have a set of dial calipers that are accurate to a claimed .001 and don't require batteries. The problem is that they read in tenths and hundredths of an inch, and woodworkers like to work in fractions.

These calipers do read in fractions, as well as other user-selectable dimensions, which means they're handy for woodwork as well as for things like gauging guitar strings and more traditional machinists uses. It comes with a lithium button cell already loaded (you have to remove the insulating paper tab to activate it) and a spare, which is handy. I think itll be very useful in my home shop.
summary: Easy to read, multiple measurement units, good quality

reviewText:
To me, aerosol air freshener cans are a necessary evil, with emphasis on the word evil.  My biggest dislike is that they either don't spray enough to cover the smell or they spray too much and overpower the room. And when you have numerous people using the guest room, like at a party, it can get pretty unpleasant in there after a while.  Plug-ins or any other type of continuous fresheners are usually worse because they don't know when to stop overpowering the room with scent.

This dispenser is designed for public rest rooms and its main feature is that it releases a microburst of scent at periodic intervals, so it never overwhelms.  Rubbermaid Commercial has had such products for many years; however the one being tested here is a new version not yet listed at their website that is fully powered by ambient light. There are  a wide variety of scent refills available and they are large cans compared to what you would usually buy for the home. The dispenser itself is designed to be 100% maintenance free (other than replacing the scent refill occasionally), it powers itself from the normal lighting in a bathroom using solar cells.

Note that this dispenser is designed and intended for commercial use (as is made extremely clear in the product description).  Most of the reviews for it are from consumers who tried to use it in their homes.  A product like this would typically be installed by a contractor who has installed dozens, if not hundreds of them so there is zero need for a long, detailed instruction manual  once the trained installed has done it once they have no need for instructions.  Therefore, the inclusion of a simplistic instruction sheet that was not intended for consumers is NOT a negative or a reason to downrate the device, the only thing thats important is if it works and how it works.

How it works is an easy question to answer  right out of the box it is easy to figure out where the refill bottle goes and how to screw it to the wall (or use the self-adhesive pad if you prefer, both the pad and a set of screws in included). After that you just walk away and it does its thing and after the refill is empty it gives you a visual alert (there is also the option to have it beep at you, which I think would be extremely annoying in a home bathroom, but again, it was never designed to be used in a home bathroom).  There is also the option of setting how often it sprays the tiny microburst of fragrance, which was logical and easy to figure out  a lot easier than trying to program my microwave. Setup is made easier by a QR to a downloadable Android/iOS light meter app that is so good I decided to keep it on my phone for everyday use.  The unit requires a light level of 300 lux. A nice touch is that if you prefer not to have to use a key to open the unit for aerosol replacement you can replace the key lock with the included manual push button.

If it works is even easier to describe  it works like a charm.  I mounted it in my guest bathroom above the door so it wouldnt accidentally puff on someones clothes if they were standing too close (I found out that is extremely unlikely to happen).  It puffs just enough fragrance that the room maintains a consistently fresh smell 24/7 and the best part is that no one, not me and not my guests, have to do anything ever.

While it should be understood by anyone considering this dispenser that it is NOT designed for home use (hence the word commercial in the product description) that option doesnt need to be ruled out completely. I would just suggest that for the typical home you set the puff rate at the minimum setting so it doesnt get carried away over-freshening your bathroom.

Since this product is not designed for home use I rate it as an excellent choice for the restroom at your business, school or other commercial location. I chose to use it in my home which is technically not how it was intended to be used and when used PROPERLY I am very satisfied with it.
summary: NOT designed for home use, but

reviewText:
I have purchased a FlashForge Creator Pro since 2015 and always struggled with print quality here and there. While the machine is really good which is why I bought it in the first place, I noticed the quality began to deteriorate in the past  6 month. I decided to change the heads and purchased the standard brass heads.  However, this did not really seem to help improve the quality to my liking.  I have been researching metal hotends and decided to upgrade the unit with the Mirco Swiss MK10.  It took me about 1 hour and the instructions were really good.
I use Makerbot and Simplify 3D programs for printing. I must say that I am totally satisfied with the quality of my prints with these new heads. I tested both left and right and they work really great. The Simplify 3D program give me better quality prints.
My advice to you is to get rid of the damn brass head and PTFE tube if your printer has them. Upgrade to metal hotend and you won't regret it. I wish I had done this years ago. Here are a few items I printed with the new head at .20mm resolution. The top of the cap was at the bottom with the raft. I was amazed at how good it came out after removing the raft. I don't have a sample with the older head but I can tell you it would not look anything like this.
summary: While the machine is really good which is why I bought it in the first ...

reviewText:
We have a swimming pool and I bought this "[PH Meter], JellasTM Pocket Size PH Meter Pen Water Quality Tester for Aquariums, Swimming Pools, PH 0-14.0 Measuring Range, 0.01PH Resolution With ATC and Backlit LCD (Yellow)" to help my son doing his swimming pool job easier.

This meter is a rather complicated yet accurate piece of equipment. In order for you to make it work right, you need to go through a tedious process of turning a small screw in the back while dipping the meter in two different liquids. Once you've calibrated it, you're ready to go. The readings claim to be accurate to the plus or minus 0.1 pH. The meter comes with a glowing and easy to read display, a battery, two powder packs for calibration, and a screwdriver also for calibration. All in al,l if you're willing to go through the process of calibration, this is the tool for you.

I received a discount on this product for providing an unbiased and honest review. I review this product as if I had paid full price. I don't have any affiliation with this seller and my opinions are from my personal experience with it. I hope my review can be helpful for a future buyer.
