reviewText:
I unboxed the printer today and noticed an issue...one of the belts was flopping around, and the clamp that held it was broken. That would have been a show stopper to most people, but I happened to have some aluminum bar stock in my workstation, so I cut and drilled a new piece. Once repaired...the printer was AMAZING. I loaded up the filament that I have been having the most trouble with - Carbon Fiber - and let her rip. The test object printed perfectly.

While running, the fan noise is pretty significant, but there is none of the vibration or violent movement that you get from the normal Cartesian printers. The head just floats back and forth, gracefully and silently dispensing its filament.

This is my second printer, the first being a kit built Prusa I3. The do it yourself kit, I now realize, yielded do it yourself results - rough prints, many, many failures. I spent more hours trying to coax that printer into working than I want to remember. With the Hatchbox Alpha, After doing a proper bed leveling and calibration (slipping a piece of paper under the nozzle at the home point, and adjusting the nozzle upward until I could move it through with slight friction), I'm off to the races...and I'm not looking back!

I deducted one star for the broken part, but added a star for ease of repair.

Edit: i've been using this almost non stop since i got it. I got into trouble trying to tweak the printer and broke some parts, and the helpdesk has been magnificent in keeping me up and running.

Regarding rough prints, i was having serious problems with that, along with threading. But i found, through experimentation, that if you print at a lower temp, the results smooth WAY out and threading is minimized. Fantastic printer, easy to use, easy to trust!

Pictures are of prints using Hatchbox woodfill PLA, 170 degrees extruder temp, 75 degrees bed temp, 0.1mm layers.
summary: Delta printers are the way to go!

reviewText:
I have been using the printer for about a month now most every day, I haven't had any major issues yet.  So far I have used both Slic3r and Cura (15.04.6)  and after developing some good printer settings files it works quite well.  As with any printer there is some learning and playing with settings to get it functioning correctly.

I found that calibrating the z axis is very quick, and I check it every week or so (I probably 30-45 hours of use per week).  I am planning on lubricating and checking wiring every month as I do with my other printers, better to check then wait til a failure on a long print.

I say that this is a good printer for intermediate to advanced users, for beginners I would still go with a printer that uses its own software, like flashforge or others.

I will have to see if it holds up well over time compared with my other printers.
summary: Used for a month with no complaints

reviewText: Once I got the setting right for the filament the prints come out great. Extruder fan was rubbing with a small twist it was fixed. Took me a little bit of time to get the retraction settings right. Power supply fan is makes more noise than the printer but is not that bad 12" black vase. Came out good meltink black pla/pha filament minor over extrusions (I almost got this filament dialed in) Birds are in pla filament. Retraction test print up to the fine points with only fine hairs Gold pla filament Lattice cube green pla filament printed before settings were dialed in and printed too fast Switched to slicer and virtually all retraction string disappeared with some setting adjustments Blue lattice cube came out almost perfect. Meltink pla/pha blue filament 1/23/17 Piet .2 layer meltink white pla/pha blend 44 hour print printer still working great no problems
summary: Great print right out of the box

reviewText:
This is not my first 3D printer...it's my 10th.

I've had many 3D printers and have been printing since 2012. Everything from the first roll-your-own Cupcake to a turn-key Mojo. I can usually play with one for only a few minutes and size it up fairly well.

This printer is a seriously good prosumer printer. Worked out of the box (nothing loose or broken). Setup was easy. Comes with tools and a fair manual. Like many NO FILAMENT was included but that's ok...I've got a few dozen rolls.

Software is a Cura version...it's Cura and if you've learned it on one machine it's just about the same on all. I run mine using Simplify 3D.

Loading filament is great compared to other Delta's. This is self loading and unloading version.

First print was a 4-1/2 hour 'gear' vase....came out great with NO banding or Z deformation.

I'm printing a 21 hour job right now and I'll update if my opinion changes.

Fan is kind of loud but it's actually the bases exhaust fan....not the extruder fan.

Kind of big (see pics) but smooooooooooooooooth with almost no vibration transferred to table.

I had a $100 coupon pop up when I bought this on Prime so I'm under $900 shipped....at this price point it's a killer deal.
summary: Bake me, shake me....C'mon and make me....3D Printer par Excellence....

reviewText:
Seldom do I give a 5 star review so when I do I fell it's well deserved.  I don't know where to start with this printer. Out of the box it just worked. It was easy to set up, level, and begin printing quickly. Everything about these just work.  Additionally, the support at hatchbox is awesome. I broke a part on my printer and after experience with another company I was afraid to contact support. The folks at hatchbox are friendly, helpful, and interested in making sure you could get back to printing ASAP.

Now I'm sure you're thinking "this really can't be all that and a bag of chips". Well I'm sure you're right. I've read there are limitations when it comes to printing flexible filaments but that is the only con I've heard or experienced.

To sum this up:
Easy to set up
Fast leveling
Beautiful, quality prints
Huge build capacity (11" round, 14" tall)
and hands down the BEST customer support

If you're thinking about buying one of these stop thinking about it and just do it!!!
summary: It was easy to set up

reviewText:
This brown PLA is a good addition to my filaments. The color is as it looks in the picture. There are no tangles as far as I can tell so far in the spool. The smell is very minimal. The settings I have for PLA is 70c for bed temperature and 200c for extruder temperature.

 The filament has printed quite well on my Flash Forge Pro. I am  pleased with this product and would definitely buy again. I have had no issues with warping so far as well. The bed temperature does not even need to be on and I assume that because the melting point for PLA is very low.

The prints that I made with this filament have a shiny look to them like shiny plastic. Its really good. This is a great product and deserves the five stars.

reviewText:
Update: My main unit is misbehaving badly enough to render it unusable. Need to contact for replacement! I really like DROK components, and I use them in mission critical projects sometimes. One of their bigger CV/CC units is running my super awesome capacitance discharge dual pulse welder I built!

Good, excellent working CC/CV supply. The larger unit I bought works well, but has some quality control issues as outlined in my other review. Make sure you inspect and test your module carefully before using with anything.

Edit: The smaller unit(pictured) is running well so far. Just shocked the hell out of myself at 18v. I designed and 3d printed a desktop half case for the unit since this will be my tinkering CC/CV PS. You can find my design on my thingiverse page, my username is wubwub89.

I also got rid of the factory led plastic, and replaced it with 15% tint. I was tired of seeing the 88:88 in all white.

Fingers still crossed on the other unit, will update after testing. (No news is good news)

EDIT AGAIN: After using this unit as a variable supply for a good while, and carefully monitoring thew component quality and performance, I am please with what you get for this price. the unit is susceptible to 'harmful interference', if you will, in strong magnetic fields, or harmonics generated from high amplitude oscillations (by duty cycle, not absolute), and it may render the controls entirely unresponsive for a short period of time, and it's always temporary.

That being said, this unit will be my new go-to for a cheap digital CC/CV unit, and I am also happy with the larger unit I bought too, that one is running a very powerful capacitive discharge welder of my design controlled by an Atmel processor.

Get these, you will not be disappointed. I reached out to DROK to offer my engineering consultation services to produce official ratings and certification, but they disregarded me. I truly believe these units can replace the older standard of design(using screw pots, no digital feedback) quite thoroughly.
summary: Great

reviewText: Exactly as described! I used these to make my own nicotine-free e-cigarette vape juice. I fill old 30 ml dropper bottles with a 50/50 mix ratio and add just a few drops of alcohol-based LorAnn Oil hard candy flavoring to each bottle. Shake vigorously and you have some really fantastic, high quality DIY vape juice. I do NOT recommend adding nicotine yourself. Pure nicotine is very toxic! It requires gloves and math, and mistakes can be very messy resulting in a trip to the ER or morgue. Keep vaping. Just kick the nicotine.
summary: Makes great high-quality e-cigarette e-liquid vape juice!

I am using these for a fog producing device and the fluids worked well.  I would have second thoughts about using this for vape juice.  With that said, the price was great and it did the job.

reviewText:
So, just for a little background, I'm a long time home brewer. Over 15 years now, though I don't like to admit I'm getting that old. Guess I need to get over that cause I'm literally wearing bifocals for the first time ever today. They're actually pretty awesome :) I've actually brewed competitively off and on for a while and won a couple of medals for wines and meads. It's fair to say I know my way around brewing equipment and have seen more than my share of hydrometers over the years. When I was asked to review this one, I was happy to.

Truthfully, maybe it's just because my local homebrew store hasn't updated what they carry since 1877, but this hydrometer is a breath of fresh air. I LOVE LOVE LOVE the color coding. Not only is this great for beginners, but even with my tired eyes the color coding helps a LOT. Why haven't they been color coded for years?!! The color coded sections are even labeled for "beer start" and finish "wine start" and finish.... such a simple addition but man would I have killed for that back in the days of my first couple of batches.

As you'll see from the photos this unit comes with a very nice case, which if you're new to brewing you might not appreciate but speaking as someone who's broken about 834 of these over the years, the case is NICE. Maybe this baby will stick around for a while in that case? I hope so. The top and bottom of the case have foam inserts and a little instructional handout which is very cool for beginners and awesome reference even for me. I actually giggled a little when I saw they also include a cloth to wipe it down. That's actually a very nice touch and in my mind sort of makes this the Mercedes-Benz of Hydrometers at a Honda price.

You will not be disappointed with this unit. Guaranteed. If you're not quite sure how to use one of these yet just get on youtube and look for How to use a Hydrometer. There are tons of tutorials out there.

I received this product for free or at a discount in exchange for an honest and unbiased review. This review ABSOLUTELY represents my true and honest opinion about this product. If it was crap I would absolutely say so. Check out my other reviews if you doubt :)
summary: Best Hydrometer I've Ever Used.

reviewText:

I did try out the template shapes, but the silicone melted a bit when the hot Pen's tip touched the material. It looks like the Starter pen has a plastic tip. Either way, this kit is still usable with the 3Doodler Create Pen, but if you need refills, I suggest getting the correct refills.

reviewText:
Ok, I admit I am a sucker for tech gadgets.  This is a take off of the 3D printer which I have raved about in past reviews.  This allows you to draw, mold and experiment in a non-toxic plastic.  It certainly doesn't have the precision of a 3D printer but at $99.00 it doesn't have the price tag either.  This set comes with a full complement of different color Eco-Plastic rods that are made entirely from food grade materials, so its completely biodegradable, non-toxic and BPA-free.  This is going to be a major hit with kids and grandkids. Don't base what you can do on my rudimentary peace sign shown on the attached photo.

Later:  my first pen worked twice and the third time it failed.  None of the trouble shooting worked.  I contacted the vendor and they skyped and concluded I had a defective pen. They sent out a new one that worked fine. I made the box over three days to test if the pen would continue to work. It did and they provided good customer support.
summary: SUPER!

reviewText: My kids, 10 and 12, have been using this pen now for a week, after having used the Hatchbox 3D pen for several months HATCHBOX 1.75mm 3D Printing Pen with LCD Screen for ABS and PLA Filaments. They are now fighting over who gets to use the 3Doodler Start pen, for several reasons- according to the kids (in my words): Pros of 3Doodler-Start Pen: - internal usb re-chargeable battery; thus no need to have extra power cord sticking out the back and getting in the way - cool tip, no need to be extra careful - proprietary "Eco-Plastic" is softer after placing, and can be molded for a very short time by finger (cool enough and malleable enough to smooth out some surfaces, for example) -plastic is cool enough to even use directly on the provided paper book stencils- the Eco plastic does not stick to the pages of the book, and comes right off the paper! - less "threading" of filament when taking pen away from project - less jamming (very critical), so no need to have backwards button to remove filament for cleaning- it appears to have an auto clearing feature that moves the filament backwards and forwards to unstick. - one big ON button, and auto flow of filament, so you don't have to keep pressing the forward button to squeeze out plastic continuously as you work (slower flowrate, but they don't mind) -The silicon green circular molds provided in this Mega set are really easy to use, have a lot of useful shapes, and the finished products pop right out. Cons: - you run out of filament quickly, because the provided strands are fairly short- about 6"- exactly the length of a US dollar bill, and you have to keep replacing them into the pen, causing delays. also, one larger project uses up an entire pack of filaments- my son could not complete his (not so large) helicopter project (from the book), for example, and needed to change colors after going through all the red (he did say he used some of the red for his Eiffel tower, however). My daughter pointed out that her one dinosaur used 1/2 the pack of whites. -a negative to the melted Eco plastic not sticking on paper, is that it does not stick on paper!-- thus you can't use the paper to "anchor" a melted blob as easily, and the entire piece may lift up with the pen (but not a major problem) -several examples of projects in the book use colors not provided in this Mega set, which my daughter found annoying. This pen and Mega set are great, hands down, esp. for kids, and the proprietary "Eco" plastic is very beneficial and superior in the several aspects covered above, as well as being non-toxic. Also, there is almost no smell from the melted Eco plastic, vs. when my kids use the PLA or ABS filaments for the Hatchbox pen (I usually open a window). I deducted 1 star, because the cost for these great proprietary Eco plastic filaments is REALLY HIGH ($7.99 for one pack of 24-six inch pieces- 3Doodler Start Eco Plastic Pack: Lemon Zest (Lemon Yellow)). The Eco filaments for this 3Doodler -Start are much thicker than the standard 1.75 mm used by a lot of 3D pens, and i don't want to try using incompatible sizes in the 3Doodler-Start pen. Interestingly, on the 3Doodler-Start Eco filament pack, it says that these Eco plastic filaments are not even compatible with other 3Doodle pens like the 3Doodler 1.0, 2.0, Create, or Pro versions. Perhaps this Eco-plastic filament pretty much only works with this one pen- the 3Doodler-Start. Our Hatchbox pen, which uses the standard 1.75mm filaments that a lot of 3D pens (and 3D desk printers) use, has options to purchase giant rolls of filament weighing 1 Kg (not sure of length cuz they sell by weight). See pic where i have our our glow-in-the-dark filament roll- HATCHBOX 3D PLA-1KG1.75-GLOW PLA 3D Printer Filament, Dimensional Accuracy +/- 0.05 mm, 1 kg Spool, 1.75 mm, Glow in the Dark priced at $23.99 shown next to an Eco pack) for comparison. The pics below are projects my kids did from the book provided in this Mega set, except for the little green guy with antennae sitting next to the Eiffel Tower, which was previously made with PLA plastic and the Hatchbox pen. I'd say this pen is a 5 star for ease of use, good Eco-plastic and convenience, but a 3 star for cost and inconvenience of short pieces of proprietary plastic.
summary: Best 3D Pen for Kids, Very Expensive Proprietary Plastic

reviewText:
I have a love/ hate relationship with this toy. While I like the concept and it certainly is a good foray into all things 3D, it is super frustrating and not at all friendly to anyone who isn't extremely patient and artistically inclined.

We have a 3D printer and had an earlier version of this pen in 2014. That one had problems with the tip clogging and uneven heat. This one has much improved in those areas. We didn't have one clog the entire time we used it. There is a steady stream of filament coming out of the pen, as long as there is some going in.

When first plugged in, the tip starts to heat. We laid it on cardboard on the table and waited. It was only a few minutes before the indicator light said it was ready. It took about 15 seconds before filament started coming out the first time. There are 2 speeds and we only used slow. Fast was kind of crazy and we hardly had the technique down to try and corral all that filament coming fast and furious. Luckily, the low speed was fine. I was continuously tempted to keep my finger pressing the button in order to make it start, but one press was enough. I would have rather gained some control by having a button that you held down in order to use it.

The pen itself is pretty and a lot less clunky than the previous version. It fits in my hand as well as my 9 year old's. He had a great time but got frustrated about 20 minutes in. My 13 year old art-focused daughter tried a little longer. More than anything, we all felt like we used ('wasted') too much filament. I can only imagine how much one would use for a normal sized project. I was tempted to see if my 3D Printer filament worked in this, too, just for kicks.

The pen tip was hot to the touch but the filament cooled almost instantly. I wouldn't give it to a rambunctious child, but even the most heat sensitive person wouldn't be hurt by the filament shortly after coming through the tip.

See the photos I have added to get an idea of what you can do with 30 minutes of practice. Impressed? I didn't think so.
summary: Not for kids, for artsy teens and adults.

reviewText: Wow!!!! How freakin cool is this.  just got my pen today and I'm really excited.  I'm a propmaker for the motion picture industry and have been 3D printing for a couple of years.  This is a toy, for sure, but its more than that for me.  If you're interested in 3D printing this is a must have.  It allows for repair of your prints with the same material you printed.  The filaments included in the package are awesome.  So many colors and options.  This is a great start for into into additive manufacturing.  Kids will get a lot of distance out of this as it's very easy to use and hold.  It's very slim and compact.  Obviously its a heated element so it requires care, but the pen itself stays cool and quiet.  It's robust and would take a drop ok.  The best part is its simplicity.  It's a very simple welcoming package that let me get started right away.  It takes a steady hand to get drawing but then the options are limitless.  Too much fun.
summary: So much fun.

reviewText:
(WARNING- This is an IN DEPTH review to help people make buying decisions. If you want a quick summary, see section marked THE BOTTOM LINE)
Every now and than a really cool new product comes through that is a winner.  Our daughter is a wonderful 3D talented artist.  She does sculpture and has worked with clay since she was about three or four.  Since this arrived, she has been playing with and studying it.

WHAT IS THIS UNIT LIKE?
This is like a teeny glue gun except it is for plastic.  You put the teeny plastic bar on the back and a little auger feeds the plastic stick into the unit at two speeds- slow or fast.  There is also high and low temp. The pack comes with 2 - 25 stick packs of plastic.  One is primary colors, the other is neon- both matte in texture and appearance.  It comes with a screwdriver if you need to remove the maintenance cover.  It also comes with a mini spanner for tightening and removing the nozzle.  There is also an unblocking tool.  That allows for you to unblock if the plastic should be stuck in the unit.

There is a great start up guide that comes with this 3D pen.  It is easy to follow and very thorough.

There are three types of plastics you can use with this.  There is flexy, for flexible plastic you can bend after you make something.  There is ABS which is matte and it is what comes with the kit.  They come in a variety of colors.  PLA is more of a specialty plastic.  It is glossy, metallic, or clear.  You use that at low temp.

The power cord is very short.  You might have to make sure you have an appropriate extension cord for this pen if you plan to use it in a classroom, or in an area away from an outlet.

HOW DOES THIS PERFORM?
The tip of this gets VERY hot, so you have to be careful not to touch it.  Our daughter is a teen, so she is not a small child.  This is NOT a toy nor is it for children, but more for ages 13 and up with parental guidance.  It is a very specialized tool that needs care to operate.  This pen is easy to use, and will take a little time to get the hang of.

If you get this, you should keep in mind it is best to use a color you are not fond of to practice with.  This will give you a chance to learn the tool without wasting your favorite colors.  It is easy to use, but you have to figure out how to use it without it looking overly curly or amateur.  It takes  a LOT of practice to get as nice as the sample photos of things that you see on the promotional materials.

If you plan to use this a lot, it would be a good idea to have a full arsenal of colors and types of plastics to have on hand.  You can not use this for more than two hours, it has to rest, so whatever you do, plan on rest time.

Sometimes the plastic does curl around the top like a hot glue gun, but it shows how to deal with any possible problems very well in the instructions.

You can use templates for 2D objects tracing them on paper so that it is easier to be creative and look professional.

WHAT TYPES OF USES WOULD THIS HAVE?
This is very useful in a variety of crafts such as :
Scrapbooking
3D modeling
Making game pieces
Projects for illustrations such a science projects or presentations
One of a kind art pieces
Jewelry (earrings, etc especially the Flexy)
Many more for the creative mind to come up with.

CONS?
At this point, there seems to be only one small thing about this that is a bit frustrating.  The plug goes into the pen and it is straight out from the pen.  The little plastic bar that goes into the unit is very close to the cord.  If the connector for the power cord had an angled swivel on it, that would make it a little easier to work with when the plastic tube is long on the back of the pen.  Then it would make it not tangle up as you use the pen.  It is not a deal breaker by any means, just a suggestion for improvement, perhaps.

THE BOTTOM LINE
This pen has given many many hours of creativity for my daughter and I, although she has it most of the time and won't let go of it. There are a whole host of projects you can do with this pen.  Having a full selection of plastic bars handy is essential if you plan to use this a lot.  The site is easy to get around, and the instructions are excellent.  This is a fantastic gift for yourself or someone else who is creative and loves to do all sorts of crafts.

FIVE HUGE STARS at this time.  I plan to update this review as often as I can with more ideas and experiences we have had with this fantastic craft tool.

PHOTOS
I am including two photos with this review.
FIRST PHOTO
The tip of the plastic bar when you are done using it if you don't finish the plastic bar and have to remove it.  There is a long end that has to be clipped off.
SECOND PHOTO
 I am also going to show you a 2D object (peacock feather) that my daughter made as one of her first projects.  She used a template and did this on paper.  If you don't do this on paper, it will curl up and around the tip and make you frustrated.
summary: This Year's BEST Gift Idea To Date In Our House!  MUST Have For Crafters Who Like Clay or 3D

reviewText:
I have already begun my journey into 3D pen art with the 3Doddler Start.  It's fun, but has a finite color palette, so I wanted to try this one too. So far, I love it.  There is a lot to say, so I will break it down into pros & cons.
Pros:
It has a slim body, making it easier to handle.  Many of these have rather chunky bodies, so they are tiring to use for any length of time.
It has 2 heat settings, for PLA & ABS plastics.  Not all of these pens do.
It comes with a nice assortment of filament sticks, to start you off.
The company sells a wide array of colors and styles of filaments (including clear, opaque and metallic.)
The included instructions are very clear. (Do read them all the way through before you start.)
The company's website has loads of videos and project plans to teach you to use it and give you ideas. The site is www.the3doodler.com
Cons;
The filament can get jammed (but tools and instructions for unjamming are included.)  To be fair, I suspect this is true with other 3D pens, as well.
It takes 3mm sticks of filament, which means that you are best off using their product and there is only so much of it available in stores. ( I can get some colors at Michael's, but mostly I have to order it.)

Finally, some suggestions;
The tip of this pen (or just about any, but the 3Doddler start, which is made for kids) gets rather hot.  So keep it away from your fingertips.
Also, plan to have a heat-tolerant surface where you can put it down, when you need to.  A silicone pot holder with do nicely.
Check out some of their accessories. I have found the Doodle Pad ( a plastic overlay) and the extra nozzle set especially useful.
Spend some time with their basic instruction videos.  This takes some learning.
The fun is as limitless as imagination!
summary: Fun tool for creativity!!

reviewText:
This is my first 3D doodler and it has a lot of potential for a variety of craft projects. The unit itself is straightforward to operate and the enclosed user guides are clearly written. Basically after plugging it in, slide the switch to the proper position based on the material being used. An LED light changes from red to blue (or green depending upon the filament selection). Insert one of the filaments until it encounters resistance and press the fast once to start the motor.

I was most comfortable working at the slow speed, particularly while becoming accustomed to the process. I began playing with free-form squiggles which made interesting looking earrings. Wire was a material I used in the past to do something similar, and although this is completely different, the plastic is feather light so the earrings are very comfortable to wear and could certainly be made with beads or small charms attached and still maintain a reasonable weight.

I used the pink and yellow filaments first because I liked them least for this purpose so they were good to employ as I learned how to use the device. There are many colors available for purchase separately  some muted shades that will be good choices for jewelry.

Note that the filaments included with this doodler are basically primary colors. As a gauge to estimate how much can be done with a filament, to make the two pairs of earrings pictured, I used two hot pink filaments and one yellow.

The unit itself is similar in concept to a hot glue gun, only the motor drives the material, there are speed options and the device is more finely crafted and. The included AC adapter has a 6 foot cable which conveniently permits some distance from the outlet to the work area. The 2 1/2 x 1 inch wall wart portion of the cable, unlike most, is horizontal so it fits in either the top or bottom outlet without blocking the other opening.

My only small issue with the device is the odor from the melting plastic which reminds me of polymer clay that is baked in the oven. I assume it is not a good idea to breathe the fumes so use in a well-ventilated area.
summary: 3Doodler 3D Pen Butterscotch Color - Creative Tool for Crafting

reviewText:
I'm having fun with my pink 3Doodler Create 3D pen. I have a couple other 3D pens so kind of know how they work. This 3Doodler is easier to write with than my others and has thicker 3.0mm filament.

There is no LCD screen; you turn the switch from off to either hi or low and it heats up, which only takes a few seconds. Once the pen is at the temp then you can put filament in the end by twisting it a little until it gets to the mechanism that feeds the filament into the pen. There's two speeds; I normally use the slower speed except for when I'm filling in areas and then the higher speed works better. It comes with two packages of 25 10" strands in multiple colors and there's plenty to create a few "masterpieces".

It's a little tricky at first to make something; the trickiest part for me is to make the base of whatever object I'm making. I've found that it's easier for me to move the pen in little circles. When you stop at the end of something there's always a little filament left over that's stringy that you can eventually cut off. So far what I've made mostly is birthday cards and wrote with the pen in them. I also used a stencil sheet to make different designs. I haven't done much drawing in the air yet.

My biggest con of this pen is the filament. The 3Doodler takes 3.0mm filament and only comes in short 10" strands so you need to keep stopping to put more filament in. Plus the price is way higher than the 1.75mm filament. It would be nice if it used the same filament as other pens do.
summary: Doodle something

reviewText:
Received this printer as a gift from my son who bought it here on Amazon. I am a tinkerer so the kit was the right choice. I thoroughly enjoyed the build. There are some minor discrepancies in instructions (screw sizes etc) and some missing instructions for some parts in the video but a little common sense gets you through the build. It is a sturdy piece of equipment after building and it has not been powered off for 3 weeks with me playing and building all sorts of things. I highly recommend this 3d printer to anyone looking to explore this hobby/rapid prototyping.
I modified it some by adding a spool holder over it, and changed out the wingnuts for thumb wheels. But that was all personal preference the device is great as is

Also as others have mentioned first class customer service.. I have contacted them multiple times and always receive a prompt (remember they are in china) and useful response. Most friendly and useful customer support I have experienced in a long time.
summary: Great product even better customer service.

reviewText: The service is excellent, prompt responses. The printer is outstanding, won't regret it. I totally recommend it. I add some improvement, to the filament guide and it works charmingly.
summary: The service is excellent, prompt responses

reviewText:
I have purchased and assembled two of these machines.

The first one was an earlier version that had none of the printer assembled, was missing the 8mm nuts, and had a damaged power switch. I contacted Anne at customer service, and she mailed me replacement parts, and shared component STL files so I could print a new set of x-axis parts that hold the z-axis bearings (one had split, when installing the 8mm smooth rod for the x-axis).

The second one was mostly assembled and went together in under 3 hours without a hitch and prints wonderfully.

After receiving the second printer, it had some upgrades that the first one did not. I contacted Anne, and she sent me the STL file for the z-axis motor bases, and sent an upgraded 20Amp Power supply to replace the 15Amp power supply of the older version. This upgrade fixed the problem of the screen flickering while printing.

One of the two machines was to be used at an elementary school for a robotics club that I administer. I wanted the machine to be completely safe around the kids, so I developed some upgrades for the screen cover, and two covers that protect little fingers from getting into the drive pulley and belt pinch points on the y-axis (under the print bed).  See photos.

I am able to get this printer to print at 120 mm/s with flawless prints in ABS, PLA, MakerFlex, Rapter (Maker'sGeek high temp PLA), Crystal PLA, Conductive, and wood. I have yet to try Nylon or Carbon Fiber, but I am sure it will print them just fine. The one functional upgrade I made to the machine was to replace the 214 x 214 x 1 mm thick aluminum base plate for the y-axis bearing mounting (qty:3) with a slightly larger and thicker piece ( 222 x 222 x 2 mm). I was finding that I had to re-adjust the bed leveling a lot as that thin aluminum plate was warping on the left side where there is only a single slide bearing. This was a very easy upgrade, as I used the original as a template to drill the holes for the thicker, larger plate. I am planning on adding a borosilicate glass print surface in a larger size and swapping out the 8mm smooth and threaded rods for the y-axis with longer ones to increase the build volume to 375 mm x 250 mm x 215mm. To make the x- axis bigger will only require moving the belt bearing farther to the right ( I plan on making it adjustable for easier belt tensioning). The z-axis enlargement consists of mounting the print head assembly higher on the x-axis carrier, then lowering the z-axis limit switch. One other upgrade I plan on making is to replace the 3mm Allen head bolts for the heated bed with bevel head bolts and counter sinking them into the surface so they will be flush on top. This will allow my glass build plate to make good thermal contact with the heated bed. I plan on securing the Glass Bed to the existing Hot Bed with magnets, for easy removal.

I recommend lubricating all the linear bearings with light machine oil and cleaning the 8mm smooth rods, and ACME threaded rods regularly to remove debris so the bearings will slide smoothly and will not fail and the z-axis will move without restrictions.

Note that the cover on the right side of the display screen includes a guide slot for making the insertion of the SD card a simple process. I plan on listing the files for these upgrades on thingiverse as soon as I can make time to get it done. (Update: This is now done... search for JGAurora on www. Thingiverse.com).
I have also added a photo of about half of the parts I printed in under a week.
summary: I am very happy with this inexpensive printer.

reviewText: Excellent Quality Prints. Great Customer Service. I had some unusual problems with my kit, but customer service was very responsive. The quality of prints is excellent.
summary: Great Customer Service and Great Quality prints

reviewText: 1st day with printer review, It took 8.5 hours to get running but I had to modify my printer due to adding a very tall magnetic build plate. So it really did go right together and worked right off the bat. The only thing wrong with the one I got is the hole for the USB doesn't line up. Instructions are all over the place, I used vids from them on YouTube but they have a missing section so I used the pics on the SD card they sent. Between all the old and new information I was able to build this fast. And did I say it is printing great on the first print! My first 3d printer had fits for a week until I fixed an prob. from a sagging bar.
summary: Fantastic Printer! easy to up grade

reviewText:
The Idea Builder 1.0 from Dremel was a pretty stellar product when it was first released because it worked and it worked well out of the box. For may, myself included this was our first time using a 3D printer. The Idea Builder 1.0 was the first 3D printer produced by Dremel, and as such it certainly had its problems and annoyances. Dremel listened to the feedback from their customers, in fact at one point I logged a support ticket on their site and later that night I had a conference call with one of their engineers to discuss a clogging issue with the print head and other gripes and Dremel appears to have compiled the feedback from not only me but other Idea Builder 1.0 owners into what they are now calling the next generation of Idea Builders, the 2.0

As an owner of the 1.0 and now the 2.0 I wanted to review the differences in these products and share my thoughts on them.

First off the shipping of the 2.0 is similar to the 1.0, it comes very well packed inside an outer carton so you can have this shipped from Amazon to your home or office and no one will be the wiser what is inside. Simply remove the inner carton and you have the official Dremel box with full artwork. I will say the 1.0 did feature a nifty inner packing where when you removed the lid of the box the sides gave way and it was a display within the packaging which I liked, the 2.0 went for a simpler "box" approach which works just as well, just not as fancy.

The printer is nestled between 2 cardboard sleeves, simply open the top of the box, remove the 2 plastic envelopes which hold power cord, usb cable, build platform, build tape, directions,a usb drive, plastic "removal tool" (a.k.a putty knife.), etc and then lift out the top cardboard sleeve. You then pick the printer up, it is wrapped in plastic, take the bag off of the printer and you'll have more packaging to remove. Peel away the blue tape and pull off the plastic covers from the acrylic top and doors, don't forget the tape on the left side holding the filament storage shut. Once done open the front door and gently raise the build platform with your hands and then the last 2 cardboard inserts pop right out, the last insert you'll remove holds the spool of filament. Overall packaging is very minimal but very secure.

The printer has had some drastic changes from the 1.0. For instance the old printer had a lid that was Dremel blue in color and it lifted right off. The new lid is attached with hinges and is clear acrylic so you can see right into the printer, a pretty cool addition to ensure your printer remains protected yet visible. One thing I like is the hinges are not cheap, the lid will actually stay in an open position at almost any angle so it won't slam shut, a nice touch. It's also thick so it doesn't flex when you lift up on one side.

The front door also saw an improvement and is MUCH larger than the 1.0 door. It also feels stronger in build quality and doesn't flex at all when opened. There is a magnetic closure on the right hand side, part of this magnetic closure is a sensor that tells the printer if the door is open or not, if it is open the printer will still function but it throws a warning message on the little control panel. In fact when you hook the printer up to your online dremel account the website will give you near realtime feedback when you try to send a print to it reminding you the door is open.

One thing that I hated about the 1.0 was the filament path, on my printer the screw always comes loose and the filament channel would fall off causing the filament to jam or break, I would then  have to reattach it and then run the filament and feed it into the head again. The new 2.0 does away with that model and uses a simple clear sleeve up the left side of the printer, then the filament goes from that right into the print head. Very easy, no points of failure to fall of or break causing jams.

Now one significant thing Dremel did differently on the 2.0 is completely revamped the spool loading. In the old version you put the spool on a little plastic adapter inside the printer, for me this meant raising the build platform to the top, opening the door and trying to get the spool situated. Now this wasn't always easy but it worked. And while the original printers spool holder was build for Dremel spools fellow makers were able to upload a file where you could print a replacement spool holder that fit most 3rd party spools. On the 2.0 however that is no more. Spools are now loaded through a round cover on the left side of the printer, you turn the cover counter-clockwise just a little to unlock it and remove the door. Then feed the filament through the plastic tube and insert the spool onto the mount, put the door back on and finish threading the filament into the print head. Overall I like the design better but I am not sure if 3rd party filaments will fit this new spool holder, and since it is a massive upgrade, replacing the filament holder won't be easy, but replacing the spool will be. They do make external filament roll holders, you can also print your own that would sit next to the printer so there is a way around using the onboard holder if you needed/wanted to.

Calibration of the old 1.0 meant sliding a tiny piece of paper between the build platform and the print head until it was the right amount of tension. This annoyed me and I burned/melted more than one leveling sheet in the process. The new 2.0 has an upgraded self leveling system, sure you still need to adjust the dials but the printer auto calibrates and then tells you what to do, and when you are done. If it senses it isn't level it tells you what dial to turn and then as you turn it you hear a victory beep letting you know you succeeded, simply press the confirm button and the printer double checks your work and you are ready to print.

The new 2.0 also features one other major upgrade, WiFi and iOS and Android apps. I didn't test the iOS app but I did use the android and it is very slick. First off when you power the printer on it walks you through country selection and language followed by a EULA. Then it searches for your wifi and you use the touchscreen to enter your password. It's very intuitive. Once done you can download the app and register your printer, you do need to get a token from your printers settings menu to register the app but that is a few pushes on the touchscreen to generate that. After that you can link the account up to the dremel autocad app (all within the same app) and start printing directly from your phone, tablet or even computer wirelessly. I did test saving an STL file from thingverse and uploading it to my dremel account on their site and was able to to trigger a wireless print of an STL file I downloaded from another repository of files.

My initial print was a traffic barrel followed by some sunglasses that say "SUSE" (linux) across the frame, I logged into the app, sorted by print time and found a 12 minute print item and hit the print button. Nothing happened, I realized when I looked at the status in the app it told me my printer door was open, I shut it and about 20 seconds later printing started. The overall build quality was really good considering I just unboxed it, loaded the filament and calibrated it. I didn't tweak any other settings and am very happy with how the build went.  Later I printed a fully functional robot toy with hinges as well as a lighthouse that took over 6 hours to build with supports included, everything worked perfectly with no hiccups.

On board in the internal memory there are the typical Dremel standard prints, a frog, chess pieces, a t-rex head, etc if you want some quick prints without any external app. They produce excellent results, in fact all of the prints I downloaded from Dremels site directly have been very successful, they seem to vet those designs very carefully and ensure they are optimized for their printers. 3rd party download sites do work as well, but those are the ones where your mileage may vary.

Overall the enhancements on the 2.0 are really nice, I dare say "essential" and compared to the 1.0 this is my new go-to printer. The fact I can print wirelessly and have a build queue makes this so much more efficient. Mix that with the new acrylic doors, spool loading process and clog free print head (something 1.0 did NOT have) I really like these changes and it shows Dremel really listened to it's customers.

I will add, one feature missing from this is the heated print bed. The 1.0 didn't have it either but other printers of comparable cost DO feature this. I have not needed that yet and all my builds on the 1.0 turned out good, and so far the initial prints on the 2.0 are even better. There are aftermarket heated beds you can install if you want that, perhaps Dremel will add that and a second filament spool and extruder on the next version. But for now I would say the enhancements on 2.0 make this a worthy contender.
summary: What happens if you take the annoyances of the 1.0 and listen to your customers? You get the Dremel 2.0.

reviewText:
These 2" casters are very nice. Wheels are actually 1-7/8" diameter. Plate is 2" x 2". They come with 16, 1/2" long #10 sheetmetal screws for mounting to wood and even a free screwdriver, but a power driver is a lot easier.

The casters are total lock: when you apply the lever brake, it locks both the wheel turning and rotating. The locking lever is easily applied and released.

The blue polyurethane wheels are a bit harder than the red tread. They therefore don't roll as silently and easily as the softer red urethane tires.
summary: Nice Little Total Lock Casters

reviewText: Here are a couple close-up photos of the 1-1/4 and 1-5/8 screws (black) next to a different brand (gold).  These South Main Bugle Head screws are machined well, without rough spots in the spiral.  So they go in smoother with less resistance, which makes a difference when you're installing hundreds of them.
summary: Sharp spiral

reviewText: Here are a couple close-up photos of the 1-1/4 and 1-5/8 screws (black) next to a different brand (gold).  These South Main Bugle Head screws are machined well, without rough spots in the spiral.  So they go in smoother with less resistance, which makes a difference when you're installing hundreds of them.
summary: Smooth cut

reviewText: Took me a minute to figure out how to use and cut, not the products fault at all. Worked and is still working perfect. I only needed a little price but if I ever needed more I'd buy here again
summary: Does what it's gotta do.

reviewText: Checked all 20 diodes out of the bag using my Fluke 117 True RMS multimeter (diode checker function). The readings were all over the place (like there is a QC issue with the doping of these diodes). Ten of them while testing forward/reverse current "chirped" on the diode function (prob okay, but had a higher impedance). All indicated "open" when reversing the leads. The other ten had a long steady tone (indicating a short...which is fine). Those ten also showed "open" when reversing the leads. From what I can tell...half of these are probably okay, and the other half questionable. Not recommended.
summary: QC issue?

reviewText: These casters are amazing. Great quality and smooth function. The brake stops both the wheel and the swivel. They should roll and last a long time. Highly recommend.
summary: These casters are amazing. Great quality and smooth function

reviewText:
These seem to work ok. They seem to be the correct size for the gauge of wire they're designed to fit. I cant speak on longevity or reliability yet. I bought these for use at work (auto repair), so if I get a bunch of comebacks due to failed butt splice connections, I will update the review. Until then I will just stick with saying they are adequate for the job they were designed.

Made in China. Doesn't say they are UL Listed as you would expect to see. Hmm. Comes in resealable pouch.
summary: They work

reviewText:
I'm writing this review less than 24 hours after receiving the 3D Printer.  Let me start off by saying Im a novice to the world of 3D printing and only stumbled upon it while clicking around on YouTube.  After watching a few videos I was hooked and wanted to buy a printer of my own.  I searched and searched and then search some more, over-analyzing every type and price point of 3D printer on the market.  I looked at $150 DIY kits and $1500+ fully assembled and ready to print machines.  After weeks of research I knew I wanted a machine that was under $1000, had a heated bed for the ability to print a variety of filaments and at least partially assembled.  That brings me to the QIDI line of printers.  Although these printers had a strange name and not a name brand at that, they were striking similar to the Makerbots and they had an average 4+ star review on Amazon.  So I decided on the QIDI brand but now my choice was the QIDI X-One or the QIDI Tech I.  I wanted a larger print area than the X-One offered and didn't give too much thought to dual extrusion at the time.  Another day or two comparing both models and I went for the QIDI Tech I.
The printer arrived yesterday packaged very securely.  Unboxing was easy and wow this thing is heavy and solid. A couple of minutes later I had the extruders, the handles and acrylic shields attached however I wrestled with turbo fan housing for an hour (if only the SD card was packaged on top with a note that said WATCH THE VIDEOS ON THIS CARD BEFORE ASSEMBLY) it would have saved me time and frustration.
After assembly, power up, bed leveling and filament loading I was ready to print!!  Wait software! I have to load software on my computer next. The SD card has two software packages Makerbot Makerware and ReplicatorG.  The instructions suggested I load ReplicatorG for dual extrusion printers so I tried that.  After an hour unsuccessfully able to get the python accelerator (whatever that is) to load I gave up and loaded Makerware.  (If anyone has this printer and was able to get ReplicatorG to successfully load on Windows 10 please reply)

Now with Makerware successfully loaded and the printer assembled and calibrated I was ready to go.  Makerware was extremely straight forward and easy to use.  There are even example files in Makerware that you can download even ones for dual extrusion as well.  I started off printing the 22mm calibration block in ABS then moved to a teapot and finally a two color dual extruded Makerbot pendant using the dual extrusion example.  I have to say the prints came out very good and was amazed how easy it is to print.  I then loaded the PLA filament and printed a series of items as well.
Overall I am very pleased with the purchase so far and even though its only day 2 with the printer I had to write this review because I feel this printer is one of the very best purchases Ive made on Amazon.
The QIDI Tech I is very well built and easy to setup and manage.  For a beginner like me it seems to have the versatility of a heated bed allowing printing in many different types of filament and also the dual extruder makes two color prints a snap.  If you're new to 3D printing and want a printer you can grow into I feel the QIDI Tech I is the very best bang for your buck.
Hopefully I re-post here again in a few months with more positive updates.
summary: Money well spent. You cant go wrong!

reviewText:
So far, I've bought a total of six of these Qidi Tech 3D printers.  The other five are still not assembled, but this 3D printer has been sitting on my desk for a few months and it went through about a month of almost constant printing, largely to test the durability.  I did have one issue.  Two of the four X axis motor wires stretched and broke a couple of inches from the motor, failing with intermittent connections inside the cable after a lot of printing.  It didn't take too long to replace the cable and it's been working well ever since.  The printer is easy to service and repair, and the manufacturer is reported to be very accommodating although I've never contacted them.

The plastic doors are a bit on the flimsy side but they work.  They're needed to prevent air drafts when printing ABS.  The doors are mostly a cosmetic issue.  Ditto for the acrylic top cover.  It should have been vacuum formed from one piece of heated acrylic, but that would have probably required more volume to ship internationally, so the top is assembled by the customer from flat sheets of thin laser cut acrylic.  The acrylic top seems a bit Mickey Mouse.  Also, the cable cutout in the back of the acrylic top is not the correct shape.  I've thought about laser cutting a properly designed replacement.

The steel frame is VERY solid and this, along with the XY gantry that leaves the build platform only moving in the Z axis and the fully enclosed design all contribute to good print quality.

I do wish the memory card slot wasn't in such an inconvenient place, hidden under the right front of the build platform after it lowers at the end of a 3D print session.  I also wish the power switch was on the front panel.  The 3D printer must be power cycled to change memory cards, and that's a hassle when printing new objects.  I plan on moving the power switch to the front.  It really should have been designed that way, or the memory card should be hot swap capable.

I've done significant hot rodding of this 3D printer.  My goal is short run additive manufacturing, so it was worth my time to optimize the 3D printer design a bit more.  I moved the spools to the sides and made new spool rollers so it's much easier to replace filament reels, I redesigned the filament feeders and replaced the carry handles with combo handles and filament tubing mounts, and I made a quick release magnetically attached glass plate.  I hope to find time to document these modifications, probably on Thingiverse.  I also use 12" long stainless .010" thick shims to level the glass print bed instead of the plastic cards that ship with the printer, and I replaced the cheap wing nuts with 3mm knurled stainless nuts for leveling the print bed.

I mostly print ABS onto glass, using Elmer's X-Treme glue stick in the super jumbo 40 gram size, applied as thinly as possible to room temperature glass, then immediately printed with a 110C heated bed and 230C nozzle.
summary: Solid & reliable 3D printer, with good print quality.  A workhorse.

reviewText:
I bought this printer 43 days ago.  Here is my experience:

I had already found an unboxing video from Qidi, they have a YouTube channel so I was ready to get the printer up and running quickly.  Out of the box, the video matched what I needed to do to set the machine up.  I set the machine up and leveled the print bed.  I was printing with the included filament within an hour.  My prints were great.  They did send me the wrong SD card as far as the files loaded on it.  The SD card they sent me was for their other printer they sell.  I emailed tech support and I had a link to the proper files within 24 hours.  I did notice that out of the box this printer's light dimmed at times and there was a slight clicking noise coming from the printer.  The prints were great so I thought this must be normal?  Understand, this is only my second 3D printer and my other 3D printer makes a lot of noise compared to this one out of the box.

I continued to print with great results.  I fixed the occasional jam.. re-level of the build plate.. nothing out of the ordinary.  The clicking noise however did get louder.  I contacted Qidi tech support and they were fast to reply.  They had me send them videos of the noise and in return the sent me a video to try and see if it eliminated the noise.  The steps did not fix the noise.  They told me they would send me parts and instructions on how to replace the parts.  I believe within a week+ I had the new parts and in the meantime I was still printing without much issue.  The video they sent had some difficult steps to follow however I followed them and was able to replace the parts.  The noise continued and the machine still had dimming lights.  I emailed Qidi tech support and again the sent me parts to try and fix my problem.  At this point in time the printer was having major issues.  It would stop extruding plastic at the same layer height each print attempt and cause a jam that would wrap the filament around the gears inside the extruder.  I tried both nozzles and different filament (even though the filament I had used successfully before still jammed) with no luck.

I received the new parts as of yesterday. Everything in the printer is working great again.  The machine does not make any noise and the lights do not flicker.  After the latest fix I am printing better than when I originally received the machine.  I am including a picture of a small print I was unable to print before.  This print is not cleaned up and straight off the bed.  Also, the hulk I printed with this machine before the parts and repair but the boombox is after.

So with the time I spent with Qidi tech support and swapping parts with a new printer you may wonder why I don't rate a 1-3 stars instead of 4 (which will change to 5 if this printer continues to run well), their tech support, even through my frustration, continued to help me until the printer was working properly.  I have to say, they stand by their product.  There is a language barrier there, but I had no issues with the back and forth via email and videos we had to use.  Simply put, they took care of me.

I will keep this review updated as I continue to use the printer.

Update (5.25.17):  Putting the fixed machine through its paces and it is rock solid as of this writing.  Updating the rating to 5/5.
summary: Almost perfect.

reviewText:
My boyfriend got me this printer as a gift and I really like it.  Out of the box it was easy to assemble, although I hate peeling all the plexiglass protective sheets off.  The hood was the hardest part to assemble, you really need a second set of hands to line  up the bolts with the screws.  I've since done several dual extrusion prints and many single extrusion prints (I have run over 1000 meters through this printer in less than 2 months).  Customer support is really good- I'm sure there is a time difference from me in the US to them, but tonight I e-mailed Audrey around 9pm and heard back from her instantly.

I have printed with PLA, PLA+, ABS, and NinjaFlex TPU (not TPE).  It all works perfectly.  The only thing I need to do to get ABS to stick is run a glue stick over the blue sheet.  Anything else sticks fine, sometimes TOO well, which is why I changed out the bed.

The biggest downside to this printer is the bed, but there's an upgrade you can buy for that.  The stock bed is non-removable and I felt like I was going to break either the bed mount or anything I printed trying to remove prints.  I ordered a Maghold bed from Amazon and it's been a game changer.  You swap out the steel bed and then you have a magnetic steel sheet that you can bend and twist to pop prints off.  I put the blue sheet on top of that bendy sheet and it works flawlessly with PLA and ABS.  I would like to get some quieter fans for the printer and find a way to reduce bed shaking/vibration but I also have no complaints about the print quality as is.
summary: Wonderful printer

reviewText:
I have been using this printer for a few months now. So i feel like i can give it a review.

I have over 1000 hours printed on this and i still love it. I have only experienced a 2 jams in all the time i used it but i belive that was a result of cheap filament i purchased online.

I spent a good 2 days calibrating my printer settings to get this to print within +/- 0.1mm tolerance and ever since then this thing is amazing. It prints parts that are to spec.

Pros:
- Great support. I contacted the seller multiple times and they where always willing to help.
- The price is great for what you get.

Cons:
When it arrived there was a lose wire. I managed to fix it with no problems in under 10 mins

Overall i would recommend this printer to anyone that has a small budget but still wants to be able to have great prints
summary: So i feel like i can give it a review

reviewText:
Great printer! I also have a flashforge, but I would have to say it is a better replica. I work with 3D printers professionally, and this is my personal printer. Unlike the name brand, the total metal structure, and many other aspects have been made better. Highly recommend, great customer service, never had a problem.

Update: Officially just bought a second one!! The more I have used this printer the more I fall in love with it. You won't get any better printer for the price. After working proffessionally with over 6 different printers, ranging in the $1000-500,000, this printer holds its own. (ok the 500,000 is very nice, but this printer outperformed the ones I had at the $5000 pricetag). Customer service is unparralleled. If any part malfunctions, I get a response within 30 minutes, and a replacement is at my doorstep within 2 days. Why haven't you purchased this already!?
summary: Great printer, great service, why haven't you bought it yet?

reviewText:
I received the Qidi Tech 3D printer yesterday and so far I am very pleased. Now this printer is a big step up from the crappy mini 3D printer I bought from a crowd funder a year ago.

First, like most have already said, the instructions for setup are not great. But, you know, even though I was worried when I first got it that it might be difficult, I found out quickly that is wasn't. In reality, it was pretty easy to put together. Most of it is already setup, you just have to put the extruders on and the figure out the calibration. Also installing the cooling fan was pretty straight forward. I was a bit confused when I reviewed the instruction for oiling it, and not having any oil. So I did have to go buy some 3-1 oil. Also, you do get a lot of extra parts, but don't panic, they are only extra parts and you didn't miss something when you put it together.

Beyond that, I have had great success. Admitting my own mistake, of buying black ABS instead of black PLA, I had the settings wrong on my first 2 prints, which gummed up the extruder a bit (be patient if this happens, let it cool off, and just pull of the excess dried filament), because the plate heat setting was too low. After raising the heat level, I got a great print even though the printing setting was still on PLA and the filament was ABS. Didn't realize that until this morning.

Why did I give it 5 stars? Right now, I am very pleased. I hope that does not change.

So here is also why.
Price - $500 cheaper than the FlashForger Creator Pro, but just as good (or maybe better).
Extra Special Touches - They include a cooling fan, extra parts and a cool little tool kit.
Customer Service - Even though it is a Chinese company, they tried hard to provide information and instructions in English. And from the printed greeting sheet, you can tell they want to make sure you are happy with your product. They even include a Skype contact. Never seen that before from a company.
Print quality - Very good so far.
Calibration - Very easy. It's not self calibrating, but not hard to do.

I'm sure I could keep going on, but won't. I am happy with the printer and recommend if your in the market for a good 3D printer, give this one a chance.

Update. Added a new picture of some awesome Star Wars items I found on Thingiverse. Sooo cool.

UPDATE: Awesome Customer Service
Recently, I was having a bit of trouble getting large flat prints to stay flat and hold to the heat platform. I contacted Qidi Customer service by email and received a response within a day. Audrey, the customer service representative, was very helpful and patient to explain what I was doing wrong and offered suggestions to correct the issues. Seems I had my temperature settings wrong and after correcting them, I got good flat prints, but still had to alter the settings some.

NOTE: The blue plate should be flat and level, however, I found a strange offset on the back-right and back-left when leveling. She said it was normal. I also asked how to set the proper level height and her response was: "The paper should touch the extruder with a little friction."
This was very helpful as I was never sure of the friction I should have. I also still need to increase the heat about 4c depending on the size of a flat print. The last 3" print I did, I set extruder at 220c and plate at 48c, and did get a flat print but a bit of edge warp on one corner.

Anyways, I was very happy with the customer service of this company.
summary: Very very HAPPY Customer

reviewText:
Great machine for the price.  As with many other reviews, the worst thing about this are the instructions.  They are definitely lacking.  A full assembly video would be really great since it is hard to show some of the details in pictures like the clear top assembly.  I had to ditch the instructions and just look at the parts I had and figure out how they went together.  Fortunately, if you are intuitive and mechanical in nature you should be fine.  Took me a while to figure it out on my own, but I was able to fully assemble my machine and get it running in a few hours.
I recommend downloading the free MakerBot software.  Much better than the software that came on the SD card.  The software that came on the card was hard to figure out what I was getting in terms of supports and rafts until they printed out (wrong the first two tries).
Now that I have a month of printing under my belt, I can try to help some people out as I was getting ready to smash something because my prints were coming out terrible at first.  The biggest thing that really changed my prints from terrible fails to very consistent was the cooling fan.  I am printing mostly in PLA and I was tackling a probably advanced print for my second attempt and here is my advice.  The object was a small ball bearing.  Everything is printed in place.  The problem I was having is the second (not used) extruder head was hitting the print and causing serious issues.  I leveled the platform, checked to make sure the second extruder was the same elevation as the main head, but nothing worked and I couldn't figure out why it was happening over and over.  On my 6th attempt, I finally figured it out.  the cooling fan was not coming on so my edges were curling up.  I had figured the program would activate this fan and control it, but apparently not.  In the menu while the printing is starting, you can manually turn on the cooling fan and it was like night and day.  My raft was coming out very spiky and when I turned the fan on, the rest of the print was very smooth.  After that, all i had to do was tune in my temperatures and I can print pretty successfully now.
Love the machine, I even printed my first dual print this past weekend.  Came out great.  I attached photos of my latest project that I printed out.  Iron Man Arc Reactor.
summary: Great machine for the price

reviewText:
Have used these on several projects on my boat and trailer.  I have found they shrink quite well, and seem to seal well.

When you use the proper crimper they have a very secure hold.  Once crimped it seems there is a small hole created by the crimper but once it shrinks down the hole seems to fill in just fine with no exposed metal.  I used a heat gun to shrink these with no problems.
summary: They shrink well and appear to seal just fine.  Great product, great price.

reviewText:
This is my review of the Neodymium Round Base Magnet (3 PACK) from Pro Magnets.

These arrived shipped in a box with other items protected by air pockets which was sufficient for shipping.

I already have a pair of similar Neodymium magnets that I use to test magnetic properties of items in my studio and workshop. I needed a few more because I have problem with crazy DIY projects and this set was a good bang for my buck.

Opening the box I found the magnets separated by spacers (thankfully), the standard screws that go in my screw bin because I don't plan on attaching these to permanently yet, and a silica packet. I thought the desiccant was a nice added measure of protection which I appreciated. Visual inspection of the magnets showed no signs of manufacturing defects or sharp edges.

Operation of the magnets is relatively straight forward find a ferrous material and stick it to said magnets. If you're foolish enough to stick these together make sure you keep your fingers out from between them and be prepared for a small battle to separate them.

As a child I was fascinated with magnetism and afforded the opportunity to play with some strong magnets but I want to stress THESE ARE NOT TOYS I would discourage unsupervised use of these magnets with youths (or irresponsible adults for that matter) as they can hurt themselves, others, or bring physical damage to property.

These work just fine, I recommend them to anyone looking for proper Neodymium magnets!

I received these at a discount in exchange for a fair and unbiased review.
summary: A veritable multitool in their own right.

reviewText:
Its a bit confusing. The length of the screw is 20mm. The diameter is 1.25in.
Just like most neodymium magnets out there.
summary: Diameter is not 20mm

reviewText: Clearing  was sent a return that seemed to ok.
summary: Clearing was sent a return that seemed to ok.

reviewText: I am happy with this printer.  I didn't think much about the self leveling feature when I purchased but now realize it is really great.  I have printed several items the largest being a 10 inch long preheat duct for my homebuilt airplane using ABS material.  Fiberglass bonds well to ABS if you scuff with 80 grit.  The preheat duct has been thru 50 heat cycles and looks and works great.

reviewText: I can't say enough good things about the Lulzbot TAZ 6. As a 3D printer enthusiast/hacker/printer I love the flexibility of this printer. I have gone ahead and mounted a dedicated Raspberry Pi 3 running OctoPi (Octoprint.org) and a Raspberry Pi Camera V2 which is on a custom printed mount attached to the Z-axis. I also added one Lemonbest 2m Resin Flexible USB LED Lights Strip Ribbon 3528smd 120leds 5V Waterproof Cool White which provides ample and beautiful lighting to the printer. Attached is a photo of my TAZ 6 with my modifications. As well, here is a link to my imgur post which has more detailed information about my aftermarket modifications - [...] Only other thing I want to touch on is the support - you won't get better support with any other 3D printer company (at least in my experience)!
summary: Best 3D printer I have yet to own. Support is phenomenal!

reviewText:
I try not to use butt connectors and opt for soldering whenever possible.
I have seen too many corroded connectors and have had to go back and fix too many jobs where people used butt connectors.
Granted most people use the wrong crimper and apparently don't know how to properly use butt connectors, there still exists the problem with corrosion and wire pulling out.

.... ENTER THE HEAT SHRINK BUTT CONNECTOR....
If you're going to use a butt connector, use a heat shrink one. Also make sure you use the proper crimper : http://amzn.to/1StU7qX
A good heat shrink butt connector uses dual wall (adhesive lined) heat shrink tubing that not only serves to waterproof the connector, it basically glues the whole connector together, wires and all. This solves both the corrosion problem and the wires pulling out problem.

This is a great price on good quality connectors.
I would recommend this pack to anyone needing to restock

Sopoby provided these connectors to GadgetClass for testing and review
summary: Good Quality Dual Wall/Adhesive Lined Heat Shrink Butt Connectors!

reviewText: Worked great. I just used all of my black on the first try. I don't want to try other products, since this one did so well in my MYNT3D pen. I wish we could get SketchPro in boxes of black only or favorite color. This is really a fun hobby.
summary: fun hobby

reviewText:
I've ordered other PLA and ABS filament for my SketchPro 3D Pen, but this is the first filament that came in a box with each of the 20 colors in a separate vacuum packed bag with silica gel and two zip ties holding them together; impressive. Each bag also has a sheet showing the type and size of filament, the color, and the print temperature. What I have done after opening each little bag is to put each filament, silica gel and original bag that shows the info into separate Ziploc bags.

This filament works great; I haven't had any of it break on me. My pen was set on 170 degrees C and it was not easy to get the filament to stick to the bottom. I finally set it to 190 degrees C (the temp it shows on the sheet included with each color), and what a difference; now it sticks much better and is easier to work with. To me it's kind of like drawing or painting.

There are so many colors in this set (even one fluorescent) and 25 ft. per color is a lot of filament. I made my first 3D object using mostly black and silver and there's still lots left. Please don't laugh at my "camera"; I told you it was my first attempt at 3D. :-)

I'm having so much fun with my 3D pen and all the filament I have now! I do a lot of scrapbooking and card making and have been experimenting. It gets easier the more you do it; I may even try another real 3D object. :-)

{Sample provided for review}
summary: Who knew playing with plastic was this much fun!

reviewText:
SketchPro NONTOXIC 3D Pen Filament Refill Kit - 20 Colors - 500 Feet - Universal 1.75mm PLA Filament

Wow! Look at the colors! What a wonderful add-on kit for your 3-D pen. SketchPro has put together a rainbow of color filament for their, and other, 3-D printing pens. The colors will inspire your kids (or your) creativity and motivate you to get to work creating stuff. You can use your stencil papers that came with the pen to really get some colorful creations created.

Each color is packaged in its own sealed bag. Just set the pen to the temperature rating of the filament, load it up and start printing. Just like the original included filaments, there's no smoke and minimal odor created from the process. It goes through the pen smoothly and hardens after printing very quickly. It's a joy to use and the results are fun. If you have kids this makes for a wonderful project with adult supervision. If you have a 3-D pen this kit is a wonderful addition, really a must have.

This product was provided at or nearly no cost for the purpose of evaluation and review.
summary: What a fun colorful addition to your 3-D pen kit.

reviewText:
This bore-scope has great resolution, compared to most others in its class (I have two other similar products). My biggest issues with it are the included "tools" and the dual USB/Micro USB port.

The included tools are nice to have, but the way they're designed to be attached is ridiculous... all of them except the 90 mirror. The magnet and the hook both have a little clip bent into the end of the wire, and a little collar slides over the wire to hold it to the head. Unfortunately, this collar is too small to actually apply any useful force through the hook or magnet, too large to hold those tools in place and just cheap in general... If they screwed into the end of the head like the mirror does, this would not be an issue. Unfortunately, as it stands, tape is the best way to hold them on. I might be able to fabricate something more useful with my 3D pen, but that's not something everyone can do.

The dual USB/Micro USB port is nice in theory, but I think the Micro USB port is too large and not quite in spec. Every time I connect and disconnect it from my phone, I feel like I'm going to break it. The regular USB is fine, but this shouldn't be an issue...

Overall, this is a nice addition to any tool box (hardware, medical, around the house, etc). At $22 the price isn't bad, especially not when considering the image quality I'm getting.

I write reviews to help others make informed decisions when buying. If I helped you make your decision (to buy or not to buy) please rate my review helpful. If you think I left something out, disagree, or have a question, please comment! I will never post a review if it is not my genuine opinion/experience. I will not be bought! As such, I did receive this product in exchange for my honest review, but I strive to review such products as if I had paid full price.
summary: A nice USB Cam, just be careful with the tools and the micro USB port...

reviewText:
This is a great set of heat shrink with solder connectors.
I have already used half of the red band ones with great success.  Not a single failure, except for a burnt finger ; - )
For anyone wondering, the hot air gun got me instead of the connector.  So be careful where you're pointing the hot air gun.

So far I've used them in 2 outdoor LED fixtures to add a longer cord to them.
The solder melts and flowed fine.  All in all I'm very happy with the purchase and will definitely be buying more.
summary: Great solder seal heat shrink connectors!

reviewText:
The short review is that I really like this filament. Why 4 stars instead of 5? Well, this filament doesn't glow as brightly as the green filament. Or at least not as long as the green. That said, the filament is a nice, light blue. The glow is a pleasant blue. I have not experienced any printing issues with this filament, it has printed as nice as any of my other Hatchbox rolls.

Over all, I would actually consider this a 4.5 star review. The only reason for it being lower is the lower glow. That said, it does glow, and it is pretty when it does. I will happily buy more in the future. If you like glow in the dark filament, then don't pass this filament, get some today. :-)

Side Note: I hope that Hatchbox adds more glow in the dark filaments. :-)
summary: The short review is that I really like this filament

reviewText: Highly recomend this upgrade.  I ordered it for my maker select v2 (wanhao i3 clone) and my prints look a lot smoother :)
