reviewText:
This endoscopic camera has so many uses at home. You can see what's inside your drywall prior to deciding where to place additional power outlets, you can see inside your drain pipes, you can see the inside of your air vent system, etc - the applications of this device is quite large. This system works very well on my laptop and Android smartphone. The length of the cable is 16 feet or about five meters. The LED lights can be adjusted for brightness so you can see from a dark place quite well.

A sample was provided for review purposes.

reviewText: The endoscope worked well and still does however when recovering the cable detached from the shell. The gluing is not proper and I where able to reconnect it. Still working but not watertight anymore.

I have limited space to hang garden tools in my garage, so I used 4 of these hooks to hang my shovel and 2 rakes by placing the hooks on the outside border of a flat metal cabinet in my garage. The hooks were able to handle the heavy metal weight of the three tools and the magnets did not move.  Here is a photo.

reviewText:
I received this a day earlier than originally estimated (YEA!).  First reaction, there are a LOT of parts and screws.  I spent ~2 hours a night over 3 days assembling this, making sure everything was aligned as I went.  The parts list (which is a separate PDF from the manual) doesn't really have descriptions for what each part is, so you kind of have to do visual association on some of the extruded pieces.

Before it arrived, I went to Harbor Freight and bought a small parts organizer box.  I then spent an hour sorting all of the small bags of screws into this organizer, transferring the labels from the little baggies as I went.  HIGHLY recommend this step, especially if you have a large dog with a duster for a tail (2yr old Husky/Malamute mix here) that constantly brushes up against the table.

The build overall went very smoothly.  I had also watched all 4 assembly videos from HackAWeek on youtube, although it looks like the manufacture has already made improvements based on his observations (kudos to Hictop for that).  One part I personally recommend, attach the power cord and controller power to the powersupply before mounting the powersupply.  There is plenty of slack, and it is far less awkward.

My first print was the supplied test.gcode.  I didn't have a computer setup for the printer yet, and only had my tablet to download and transfer files to SD, but it worked.  The first try failed when the extruder got caught on the masking tape covering the bed, likely due to me setting the PLA preheat too high or putting the masking tape aligned front to back as opposed to side to side.  Second two false starts were because I didn't have the filament inserted all the way, so it wasn't feeding.  Fourth attempt started off ok, but then the base ripped off the bed, creating a mess.  A quick review of the part 4 video on youtube and some quick adjustments to the autolevel sensor, and I restarted again.  This time, everything started working properly.  I took a brief video (~10 seconds) when it was at 15%, then went to bed.  The next morning, I found a nice 4 leaf clover shaped shot glass (pla) sitting on the print bed, very well detailed and smooth on top.  The sides feel rough due to the slicing and printing (like the pages in a closed book), but that can be smoothed with various post-printing touch up techniques.

I have now setup a computer station for this setup (Intel NUC with Ubuntu 16.04), and am learning about the slicing process.  I have ~18 inches left of PLA from the sample they provide with the kit, after printing the test.gcode file and two spool adapters from Thingiverse (search for HatchBoxSpindleForAluminumFrameHictopPrusa).  These didn't print with anywhere near the quality of the cloverleaf, but I discovered some default gcode settings that I didn't have when I converted the spindles.  Another learning experience.

Pros:
Having played with Erector sets as a kid in the late 70s - early 80s, and working with extruded aluminum assembly for the last 15 years, this wasn't a big deal for me (actually found it enjoyable).  Print quality seems ok.  No glitches.

Cons:
Manual could be improved.  A lot.  Almost of the images are computer generated, but the components tend to blend, especially when they are the same black color.  For example, the stepper motors don't show the connector, and it is only after mounting them that they show the proper orientation.  I had my X axis fully assembled with the belt tensioned when I discovered the power connector was facing the wrong way.  Easily fixed without having to remove the belt (just loosen the screws and rotate the motor).
For belt tensioning, I found a tip that worked very well; tension the belt and ziptie it in place before tightening the stepper motors.  This tightens the belt further by a few mm, which is perfect.
The provided version of Cura on the DVD (even though I am a Linux guy and had to get my own copy) is 2 years old.  Get the latest version from Ultimaker (it still supports this printer).
Calibrating my autolevel seems to be wrong.  I followed along with the included video, and set it to print a new project, but the head decided to engrave the first layer into the table, as opposed to just pushing filament down.  Will recalibrate and try again.  At least the fine groove can be readily covered by tape.

Biggest tips:
Research and read all of the tips from other users.  Learn from others.
I used two old CDs to keep the sample PLA from going everywhere.  Highly recommend this, as the PLA is like a big slinky otherwise.

So, why only 4 stars?  This printer is not for everyone.  I personally know a lot of people that would have given up after organizing the screws.  And there are still improvements that need to happen (manual).  But, being an open hardware design, and seeing the improvements already included Since the assembly videos were made (it would appear that this has the Prussa I3 MK2 improvements already), I think this is an excellent kit for those that want to tinker and learn about the process.  Some of the parts look like they were printed, while others look more refined and were injection molded or laser cut acrylic, suggesting that as parts are refined, they are moved to improved manufacturing processes (the filament sensor housing which is fairly new is a prime example).

I may add additional images later.  Time to change the spool.
summary: First time 3D printing - and having fun doing it!

reviewText:
I looked at various 3D printers for weeks before settling on the Prusa i3 made by HICTOP. I chose this printer because of the frame being made from extruded aluminum, the heated aluminum bed, the integrated controller, and that it has mostly metal parts. I had my doubts about the quality of a printer built from a kit but those doubts were unfounded. I bought this printer with the auto Z option but wanted to review the same printer under this non auto Z version. This printer kit is made from quality parts and the assembled printer is equal to printers that cost $2000. I have seen some of the expensive printer's output and this printer is as good. I'm extremely pleased with the assembled printer and I am very glad I took a chance on this vendor. In addition to a great printer kit, the vendor has answered two of my questions promptly. One of the questions was a request for the controller firmware. They gave me the source code which even included the Arduino Environment. This company deserves much praise for putting together such a fantastic 3D printer kit. I do have to warn you that this kit takes quite a lot of time to assemble and parts of the process are difficult. It took me 12 careful hours to assemble the kit. If you don't think of yourself as mechanically or electrically inclined, this kit might be frustrating. After 12 hours assembling the kit, I turned it on for the first time. The motors whirred, the display lit up and it was ready to go. The first object I printed came out great which does not usually happen. HICTOP is thoughtful enough to supply a G-Code file all ready to go for this printer. You copy the file to a flash card and print from the card. I have run this printer for no less than 40 hours during the last week. It is tough, it is good looking, and it holds its calibration. Below are some details about the various parts of the printer kit.

Frame - The frame is made from 20mm x 20mm extruded aluminum. This frame is stiff and straight. You can't even compare printers with plastic or wood frames to this industrial like chassis. The extrusions are held together with aluminum brackets that are beefy and hold each corner and the uprights true. It does take a bit of fiddling to get each corner flush so that the frame is square. I also had to work on getting the upright frame in the correct position and locked down by the side panels. The side panels are made of heavy gauge steel and hold the controller on one side and the power supply on the other side. I was expecting cheap screw hardware but was delighted to open a bag of hex cap screws which are all nickel or chrome plated. The hardware is so shiny that I can't tell if it is chrome or nickel. The kit also includes tools to assemble the kit. Almost all screws are cap heads which require various sizes of Metric Allen wrenches. The frame does not include end caps for the extrusion but I was able to print them from files found on Thingiverse. You can see my extrusion end caps in some of the photos. This kit is nearly all metal. The frame, the bed, the motor mounts, and the extruder are metal. The parts that are not metal are mostly thick black 8mm ABS  laser cut plastic. The plastic parts are top quality including the few 3D printed parts.

Plastic Hardware - Almost this whole printer kit is made from metal but there are some plastic parts including a few 3D printed parts. The 3D printed parts are the two X axis end pieces, the extruder feed, and the extruder fan shroud. Thats it. Those parts are nice solid 3D prints with no drooping or distortion. The laser cut parts include the bearing rod mounts (X, Y, and Z axis) and the Y axis pulley mounts. The laser cut parts are of beautiful with smooth edges and very precision. I am happy that there are more laser cut plastic parts than 3D printed parts. The quality is a bit better on laser cut parts.

Metal Hardware - All of the motor mounts except the X axis are made from heavy gauge steel.  The LCD display and filament spool rack are metal as are the side panels and most of the extruder. The extruder is mostly metal but it does have a plastic feed mechanism which is one of the few areas I consider a little on the weak side.  All of the screws and various bits of hardware are all top quality. They in fact are nicer than I expected. Many of the metal pieces which attach to the extrusions use special slot fasteners. They are difficult to use at first but once you get the hang of installing them that are easy to use for attaching corner brackets, side panels, spool holder, and LCD display. All bearing rods were cut to the exact length and are chrome polished smooth and straight. The bearings (6) are all house in aluminum holders with threaded holes are beautifully made. I added a little 3in1 oil while assembling the bearing structures and everything moves silky smooth. Many printer kits use 3D printed bearing holders with tie wraps to mount them. The bearings and their mounts on this printer are far better than almost any other printer.

Electronics  I was doubtful of an all in one controller where the motor drivers were on the board. One bad driver and the whole board is useless. So far so good. The controller is very nice quality. I especially like all of the JST connectors for stepper motors, end switches and temperature sensors. You cant plug them in backwards and each of the connectors is a different size based on function. The controller is actually a standard design called the MKS V1.3 and is made by multiple companies so replacements are available. The motor drivers run cool without a fan and I was able to easily establish communication with my computer using the supplied drivers.

Software, CD, and Example Files  Wow! They supplied a CD with everything you need. Cura is the slicer and control software.  They included the driver software. They included assembly documents, Cura setup document, bed leveling instructions, and examples. I found everything I needed. I requested and received the controller firmware. These guys did a great job. There are also videos on YouTube showing much of the same things as the documentation.

Documentation and Assembly Instructions  The main assembly document is 95 pages long and is very detailed. It depends on CAD drawings to show each step. There is little text but I was able to figure it all out without too much trouble. I did not print the document. I placed it on a laptop and flipped through it from there while completing each step. I actually had a lot fun putting this printer together and would not hesitate to help a friend build one. The documentation was weak in that it was mostly CAD snapshots with almost no text and the wiring section was too brief. The supplied pictorial diagram makes up for the lack of step by step wiring instructions.

Tools and Extras  HICTOP supplies a bag of tools needed to assemble the printer and they include all kinds of supplies including masking tape for the heated bed, wire ties, extra screws, and a small amount of filament. You can tell they really want you to be successful building and operating your printer for the first time. Everything you need is in the kit.

Packaging - The printer arrived in a sturdy box with all parts wrapped in plastic and placed in foam pockets. There are two layers with the parts and minimal instructions on the top with a CD with the full instructions and software. I was very glad to see the CD. I was quoted a 4-6 week delivery time but much to my joy, the printer arrived in 4 days!!! Dont count on this happening but its nice to know that they aren't putting kits together after they get an order. I was so happy to open the kit and to see the great quality parts.
No product is perfect including this printer. I really like this printer and would do it all again. I did run into a few problems which I will mention.
The bearing that provides the idler end to the Y axis belt was too tight between its mounting ears. The solution was to leave the screw loose so as to not bind the Y axis action. I consider this a minor issue which I will fix with a modification to the mount.  All of the sheet metal that connects to the extrusions uses M5x8 metric screws which are just a bit too long. They bottom out in the extrusion. The solution is to add a washer. The manual fails to remind you to switch the power supply to 110V for USA operation. I knew about this issue from reading other reviews so I wasn't stumbled by it. The power supply voltage switch setting has caused multiple people to think their printer was malfunctioning. The wiring section of the manual is a little terse but they do supply a great diagram that is enough to get you through it. My extruder nozzle was a 0.8mm not a 0.4mm. This caused me some print quality problems because I entered 0.4mm based on HICTOP's  instructions for Cura. Once I replaced the nozzle with the correct one, my print quality was great. Thats it. If you read the reviews, you will know about the power supply and about the correct extruder nozzle issue from me.  Last, the USB cable is 6 long and is useless so you will need your own USB cable; not a big deal.

Im printing all kinds of things as is typical of new 3D printer owners. I am amazed at how solid this printer is and that it does a great job on prints that run for hours. I successfully printed the MakerBot articulated robot which is used for testing printers. I couldn't be happier with this printer.

Update: January 12, 2016
I have downgrade this product by one star because there are design flaws which must be addressed for this printer to be reliable and accurate. I have addressed the flaws to my satisfaction but others may be expecting a more turnkey experience. This comment explains how some people are happy with this kit and others bash it. I can't emphasize enough that this kit requires a significant investment in your time and that it requires a lot of tweaking to make it a reliable and accurate printer. If you are willing to invest that time, you can make a $400 kit into a 3D printer that equals assembled ones that cost $1500-2000. If you decide to buy one after seeing the comments that people have made, join our group to get information and help with building your new printer. [...]
summary: Excellent Printer that has Output equal to a $1500-2000 3D Printer

reviewText:
I'm no expert in 3D printing, but I've seen a few in operation and decided it was time to get on board and make a purchase. After looking at all the options (fully assembled vs. kit, specs/features, material types supported, price vs. performance, customer support, etc.) I decided on this HICTOP printer. This printer comes as a kit and is similar to the Prusa i3. It was shipped in a well-packaged foam box, which included a CD that contained the necessary software, an instruction guide, hand tools, and assembly video (it also contained several extra fasteners - all metric). The quality of the components appears to be high.

As others have stated, the assembly of this kit requires a medium level of mechanical and electronic aptitude to put it together, get it aligned/calibrated, make the electrical connections, and route the wire harnesses. Taking my time, altogether it took me approx. 6 hours from opening up the box to making the first test print. The first print was terrible (almost no Z-axis travel), as the Z-axis lead screw pitch was mis-configured for the lead screws shipped in the kit. I sent an email to HICTOP and within minutes I had a response and after determining the problem (lead screw pitch - 1mm/rev) I was sent a link to download the correct firmware. Flashing the firmware was a breeze, and about an hour after my contact with HICTOP I make my first successful print. Thanks, Chris - great customer service!

I've since added a couple of items to make printing easier (I'm primarily using PLA filament) such as adding LEDs to illuminate the hot bed print surface as well as placing a sheet of Kapton tape to the hot bed (when cool, the PLA just pops right off). The included Cura software (which drives the printer) is easy to use, and HICTOP provided typical starting point parameters for printing PLA and ABS. After designing and printing several parts, I can see that it will take some time to understand the many variables that go into successful 3D printing (temperatures, print speeds, layer thickness, etc.) - which would be for any printer - but I look forward to dialing in (OK, playing with) this HICTOP 3D printer in the future. In it's stock form, it already makes prints that exceed my expectations.

For anyone that wants to get into 3D printing, has some mechanical and electrical skills, and is willing to assemble a printer (how better to learn how it works than to put it together?), this is a solid printer. I suspect that with time and experience I will make some upgrades and modifications to improve this printer further, but even as stock, I highly recommend it. I think you'll learn a lot, have fun, and be able to make some great prints with this printer. I am very pleased with my decision to purchase this printer.
summary: Great printer for the money!

reviewText: Very disappointed in the specifications of the belt.  Received the belt and it looked a little slim.  I measured it with calipers and it is not a 6mm belt but more like 5.6mm.
summary: Item does not appear to be as described.  Was expecting a 6mm belt and it was 5.6mm

reviewText: The Me Creator 2 is a Good All Around Feature Packed 3D Printer. The chassis design and motor configuration make this a durable and solid printer. Back in the day you either had to shell out a lot of money, or spend a lot of time researching designs and sourcing parts to build your own 3D Printer. Luckily that has changed over the last few years and 3D printing is becoming more and more affordable. GeeeTech/GiantArm are doing a good job positioning themselves as a new leader in the retail 3D printer market. You can see the evolution of their designs and company from the early models to their current offerings which include multi-extruder (multi-color) printers like the Prusa and Rostock printers. I can't wait to get my hands on those! They are constantly improving their products, even adding a part cooling fan to the Me Creator 2 even in the last couple weeks. As far as a 3D printer goes, the Me Creator 2 has the best balance between price, features and component quality that I have seen. Many more expensive printers lack some of the features the Me Creator 2 has. The rigid cube chassis allows one to add on enclosure panels, additional lighting an cooling and other bells and whistles. Having the power supply and control board fully enclosed underneath the printer keep it looking clean while protecting all of the vital electronics. The front LCD PID control output is very nice. Even just being able to preheat the extruder to change filaments without a computer attached makes this an awesome feature, but adding to that full manual control and standalone printing capability is something to be said for a 3D printer in this price range. The default config files they link to in the user manual work pretty good for most situations. Make sure you start with those. The link is on page 44 of the user manual. I ended up doing a lot of tweaking and messing around to get the best possible prints I could on different parts. When it comes to 3D printing, every printer, even every brand or color of filament takes minor adjustments and setting changes. I'm going to do a series of videos on my GadgetClass YouTube channel to cover a lot of the basics. I will post my better Slic3r config files there as well so make sure you check that out if you are having any difficulties with this printer. My only complaints about this printer are: 1: The bottom cooling fan is in the back, right, bottom corner, where the home position is. The little hairs and bits of filament that ooze out can get sucked into the fan 2: I would like to see 4 screws instead of just 3 for leveling the bed. Both of these are minor and all 3D printers have quirks like this I have spent a lot of time every day for the last 3 weeks using and testing this printer to give everyone the best review I could. After all of that time (and filament) I can easily recommend this printer. Whether you are just starting out or need another single extruder printer, this is a good solid option for the price point.
summary: Good Solid and Feature Packed Design for the Price!

reviewText:
First off, I REALLY like this printer!

I have a 3D Delta printer that was very hard to set up, and would not give even slightly decent prints without some pretty serious modifications, so I thought I would try this one.

After I took care of a couple of minor issues created in shipping (more on that later), the printer just works and performs like I hoped it would.  I
received the printer 8 days ago and it has been running pretty much 24 hours a day since then with no problems that weren't of my own creation.  So far I have printed with two colors of PLA filament, and one color of ABS.

The first thing I did was level the bed per the instructions (they are not great, but understandable).  the printer is shipped with a test print on the bed that was very nice.  Getting the first print set up using PLA filament was very easy, and I was very pleased at how well it stuck to the supplied blue tape.  There was an initial issue with the X axis printing (see the right test cube in the picture), but I quickly traced it to a loose pully on the X axis stepper motor and tightened the set screws and got the beautiful test cube on the left.

Quick pros:  Quick Cons:
Very easy to set up  A couple of easily fixed issues from shipping
Makes beautiful prints  The filament holder is a bit cheesy, and allows the filament to tangle a bit easily
Prints PLA and ABS with heated bed

I intend to write much more on this review, but thought I would get it started.  I am posting a few more pictures of things that I have printed (BTW, the Benchy is as good as the print that I did on the $130,000 printer we have at work!).
summary: A very nice printer for the money!

reviewText:
I printed a lot of PLA over the last year, so when Intservo invited me to test a spool of the new eSUN PLA PRO (PLA+) filament in exchange for a comparison review, I agreed.

I'm glad I did.... this PLA PRO (PLA+) will be the filament I buy from now on.

The colors are very close to the old favorite eSUN PLA colors, but the PLUS colors are a bit richer and have a deeper tone, (as near as I can tell on the several colors that I bought for the testing).  But the PLA PRO (PLA+) is a LOT stronger, and more flexible after printing.

To strength-test it, I ran a print with the PLA PRO+ that I had consistently had trouble with just using plain PLA.  The problem print has a latch that would snap under pressure when the support was removed.  (Six times in a row - very frustrating.)  The PLA PRO filament printed at a slightly higher temperature than the regular PLA, and it was.....creamier.  (Sorry...not a terribly masculine word....but that's what it was.)  It was strong enough that I was able to remove the support without breaking the latch off into my hand for the seventh time, and it flexes enough to allow the latch to close and open easily.  No fear of it cracking again.

The support was not overly clingy either, which I would have expected.  But it came away cleaner than regular PLA supports. Definitely a pleasant surprise.

I wanted to test it on overhangs as well, so I put it up against another print that had caused trouble for me with overhang curl and heat pitting on a curved bottom surface.  The underside of the egg shaped print usually developed pitting, (even with support), in PLA.

I absolutely didn't believe the results of this test...which was run with NO SUPPORT for the PLA PRO (PLA+) filament, on a smaller version (heat soak effect magnified), just to see what it would do.  I'll put the pictures below, because otherwise, you won't believe it either.  (Keep in mind, the bottom of the white PLA egg had support underneath it, and it still looks like a mountainside.  The black PLA PRO egg showed a smooth surface with ZERO support, and the top of the egg did NOT collapse!  I've NEVER been able to print that egg without center support.  The PLA PRO printed without it.  (Gonna be reprinting all of those as well in the PLA+.)

I tested a couple of Benchies - the PLA PRO handled them just fine without any added support.  There was no warping or curling.  (I do run a MIC6 plate with a PEI coating, so warp is not usually a problem, except on steep overhangs.)

Finally, I did a test on heat resistance, and there was no significant gain in the PRO filament. Both straightened segments slumped in a 250F (120C) oven, at about the same time.

Bottom line - this is by far the best PLA I've tested. The only thing I noticed was a few absolutely miniscule zits here and there, because I haven't dialed it in yet.  It's slightly shinier than regular PLA, but the shine can be easily and uniformly knocked back with a damp Magic Eraser.

Give it a try and see if you like it as well. It is so easy to print, you'll never go back to the other stuff.

Update:  Just printed a flat box divider that shows the flex on this stuff - the divider is 2.8 mm thick, so it would be pretty stiff (and might break) when bent this much, if it was printed from plain PLA.  The curvature was not imprinted into the divider though - it flattened back out.
summary: This is What PLA is Supposed to Be

reviewText: Printed great! I must however dock a star due the roll having a tangle which botched a 16hr print. I believe this phenomenon can happen to any spool however and will always respool my rolls no matter who I buy from. To be fair, I have another roll from Esun that does not have any tangles, I know because it respooled without issue.
summary: Great filament.

reviewText:
This was the first time I had tried eSUN's PLA PRO - I had tried other brands' variants of "enhanced PLA" and generally liked them. The eSUN printed very nicely, did not shrink or warp at all, and produced a strong part. This color is also lots of fun.

Edit: July 31, 2016

I've attached a picture of a fun print I made with this filament. This is "Medieval Fortress Generator" on Thingiverse.
summary: Great printing, vibrant color

reviewText: Whole roll is cross wound so it's keeps jamming. Communicated with eSun they stood by there product and corrected the issue will give it another try. Just hope this was one off as far as it being tangled. adding more stars if for nothing but there customer support did went out of there way to correct it.
summary: Decent Filament more testing to be done

reviewText: Wow. This stuff is magic. Prints SO SMOOTH. It looks like it's printing with silicon caulking. The white is WHITE. Never printed in white- it's awesome because you can clearly see your prints. UPDATE: Can't believe how strong this stuff is! It's also so very consistent. I got a section of PEI for my bed and it sticks like a magnet and yet is easy to pull off.  I've tried several other types of filament sonce this ine and I ONLY going to buy this PLA Plus and this brand for now on.
summary: Wow. This stuff is Magic! Prints SO SMOOTH! BEST EVER FILAMENT!!!!

reviewText: Seriously the best filament I've ever used. For the price, nothing beats it! I tend to print at 205 degrees centigrade at around a 0.2mm layer height. I use an all metal 3D printer based off the Prusa i3 design. Never had any issues running it through my mk8 nozzle. Also I've experienced little to no issues with bottom layers lifting (I use a heated bed and treat the glass built plate with some glue). All in all, great filament!!!
summary: Bought one roll, got hooked!

reviewText: This stuff, THIS stuff is AMAZING. 15/10 will buy a LOT more. I got this for a few prints I planned on doing, some skulls and such. I however found a much better use of this stuff.
summary: Don't order this, buy stock of it. Stockpile and hoard it.

reviewText:
ESUN is great.  This roll was a little small at 1.72 but is very consistent.  The surface is a little rough which is good for the extruder but prints very well.  As with all filaments,  Measure Your Roll!

I've included a pic of what it looks like if you don't measure your roll for smaller filaments..  Once I adjusted to 1.72  the gaps went away..

The smallness lost a star.  Other than that its very printable.
summary: Woooooot!

reviewText:
UPDATE:  After posting this review, I got an offer from INTSERVO for a free roll of black PLA+ for an honest review.  With the addition of black to the other spools I had already purchased, I had almost every color needed to print a project that caused normal PLA to break during assembly and that is the MakerBot Nutcracker (thing 579567 on Thingiverse).  I made a dozen of these a couple years ago for family as Christmas presents.  I had to file down the assembly tabs since with regular PLA, they would snap when assembling.  I'm happy to report that when I built it out of PLA+, I had no tabs break (well, I ended up with two broken ones but that is because I bent the piece when assembling).  I was able to put the whole thing together without having to glue the parts like I did with PLA.  Once part, the mustache, was extremely hard to get right with PLA because of the overhangs.  I would have to do a lot of cleanup work on it.  With PLA+, I was able to use it as is right off the printer!  I also had problems with stringing between parts with PLA.  Not with PLA+.  The pictures are the PLA+ parts on the printer.  I used the same settings as I did for PLA, but upped the bed temperature from 60 to 65 and the hot end from 205 to 220.

Now if they would just offer a Tan color, I could do it in all PLA+.

I'm going to join in here a sing the praise of eSun's new PLA PRO (PLA+).  I took advantage of the sale price ($3.00/spool - better than nothing) and took a gamble buying 7 rolls untested.  I have used eSun PLA and PETG for some time and have never had any real problems with it so figured the risk was worth it.  Also, when you buy 6 at once, you get another 5% off.

So far I have only printed with the brown and it is coming out perfect.  No build up like I get with PETG after awhile.  I normally print in PLA for most things, but use PETG when I know the object could be subject to some flexing.  In testing the strength, I printed a 2mm thick bar.  If printed in PLA, it would snap after just a few degrees of deflection.  With PETG, I can bend it in half without it breaking.  The PLA+ was in between the two, but closer to PETG.  I was able to bend it to over 90 degrees without it breaking.  At about 135, it did break, but not snapped in two like PLA.

This is going to be my new replacement filament as I use up my PLA stock.
summary: The better PLA

reviewText:
I love this filament. It seems to print cleaner/glossier than the Hatchbox PLA I usually prefer. I had started making the transition to PETG, but the ease with which I have printed both purple and white PLA+ is making me rethink that decision. I think I'll keep the PETG for things that need a little flexibility as well as strength, and use the PLA+ for the fun stuff.

Edit: Yesterday I received and ran prints with the gray, light blue, and peak green. The gray is absolutely a dream. It prints smoothly (smoother than the purple), and seems very carefree. The peak green prints pretty OK, similar to the purple. The light blue however... it's been a real pain in the rear. It strings like nobody's business. And it seems "stretchier" than the others. I have yet to get a clean print after a day of trying.
summary: Prints great!

reviewText: Consistent filament, prints well. I have red, orange, yellow, blue, green, purple, black, dark grey, silver (light grey), brown and pink. The silver is not metallic, but I wasn't expecting it to be.
summary: Nice filament, bright colors

reviewText:
I always been using 1.75mm filament, recently I bought an Ultimaker2+ and since colorfabb and 3mm filament are expensive with regards to this type I decided to try it what the worse could happen right?
Ultimaker printer is $2500 not a cheap printer, and it really print well, it came with 1 PLA spool from Ultimaker that it cost $50.
it worked fine and great, with that filament, I bought this and I use it on ultimaker only took 5min to jam my feeder that I had to take it apart on a new expensive printer to pull it out, it seems that this brand on PLA is very brittle and not uniform in diameter lucky I was able to save my printer and took me 3 hours after midnight to fix it, as this would have damaged the printer I would had to file a lawsuit against this company.
 I don't know if any of you did print with this brand on Ultimaker if you do please let me know how?
summary: I had  nightmares from this

reviewText: eSUN 1.75mm Black PLA PRO (PLA+) prints with an obscene amount of strings. I have used several different colors from eSUN and this Black PLA is the first that produces so many strings in the print process. I have eSUN's Purple and Grey and they both print marvelously. Im using them at 200c-215c with very smooth results. This black PLA strings at all tested temperatures. 190c-215c. I understand some stringing is to be expected on some prjects but just look at the attached picture. Thats standard 15% infill. Look at all them strings.
summary: Way too many strings during prints for my liking.

reviewText:
I have tried lots of different filaments in the past. Only some print flawlessly. And esun is one of them. My problem and reason I only have two stars is because I bought red. But when I got it it was hardly red. It was orange. I don't know if that's just how it is or I had a bad batch or what. I will still be buying esun but I'm just disappointed with the color on this real.
UPDATE... esun contacted me and sent me a free spool for the trouble and told me they are working on a new color for red
summary: I don't know if that's just how it is or I had a bad batch or what

reviewText: I bought here a Safavieh runner made from a very tough textile. It had been rolled up tightly and just did not want to lay flat. I had difficulty getting the ends to stay down as well as parts in the middle wanting to ride up. I was using this tape already on other rugs but it was not working : Optimum Technologies Lok Lift Rug Gripper Slip-Resistant Rug Tape for Rugs and Mats, 2.5-Inches by 25-Feet . So I decided to try this Melca double sided tape. It did not work and I did request a refund for the unused portion, which Amazon approved. The ad claims a few things so I will address them all. I also posted a photo of the floor after taking up the rug - I am not sure how I will get it off, I ordered acetone to try that. The rubber backed rug I put over the tape until I can get it off did not want to come off when I wanted to take the photos. I recommend if you have tile floors to try something else, like the Lok Lift tape I used. It both holds and comes off fine. "Highest viscosity available provides the strongest and longest hold, Leaves absolutely no residue" The tape left no residue on the CARPET but the floor is another story. I used a lot of the tape trying to get the rug to stay down, and when I pulled up rug to return it, the tape all stayed behind. If i walk on it, I cannot get my foot/shoe off without a struggle. What a mess. "Stream out a long strand without it becoming totally stuck and wrapped around something" This is not the case. This is the MOST sticky tape I have ever dealt with. If it touches anything before you get it on the rug or floor, it will stick and does not want to easily come off. "Optimal weight and pliability, the best tape on the market is easy to handle, apply and remove" I already spoke of how it is NOT easy to remove. Maybe they mean from the carpet, but they need to think about tile floors!
summary: not for carpet on tile floors

reviewText:
Exceeds all expectations!  No, really.  As a do-it-yourself Chinese import, my expectations were low.  Acrylic frame, generic Asian parts, and advertisement that seems too good to be trusted.  This is my second 3D printer, with my first being an M3D which needed warranty replacement after just a week.  The first thing that impressed me was certainly not the assembly manuals and videos, but the well-organized packaging, with every nut and bolt clearly labeled.  The second thing that impressed me was the fact that all nuts/bolts/washers are polished and smooth.  And, while technically it does have every tool you need for assembly, I preferred my higher quality tools for this work.  Together with my former skills with building and racing RC trucks, I felt confident in my skills for assembling this kit.

Everything went together as expected.  The instructions left some room for interpretation but the videos included with the DVD were helpful.  I suggest you watch some YouTube videos as well.  And, speaking from my RC experience again, make sure you use threadlocker on ALL parts that fasten metal-to-metal.  This entire machine vibrates as a matter of regular function, so this is vital.  After assembly, a few test prints, and lots of tweaking, I can say I am SO happy with this product that I would recommend this to anyone looking for a budget printer and is not afraid to work your way to perfection.  Keep in mind that this is NOT a plug-n-play 3D printer and real work needs to be done to get great prints.  But, build quality and print quality are far better than I ever expected.  Keep in mind I have only printed PLA and don't expect to move beyond that for a while.

This is not a sponsored endorsement.  I paid full price for this unit and received no special assistance.

[Edit February 2017] Knocked off 1 star.  The driver for the extruder blew out this month, which requires the replacement of the entire controller board.  As I am now out of warranty, this will cost $50USD plus shipping and is out of stock right now on Amazon.  Granted, I've been printing hard-core for two months straight, I wish it had lasted longer.  Perhaps I'll replace the board with another that has individually replaceable stepper drivers.  Other than this, I'm still very happy with this kit.
summary: Exceeds all expectations!

reviewText:
EDIT #2:  Elizabeth from HICTOP e-mailed me asking me to remove this review or else she would be in danger of losing her job.

I am not new to 3D printing.  This actually was my 3rd printer.  It was the first printer I bought that was a complete waste of money from the start.  First of all despite following both the paper guide and the video on wiring the power supply, the first time I plugged it in the room filled with smoke and the power prongs partially melted (see photo).  Luckily my circuit breaker tripped or an electrical fire would have been likely.  I was able to repair this, but really I should have stopped here.  The problem was that both the video and the wiring guide in the instructions showed a slightly different power supply than the one I was sent  - the difference is in the faint metal engravings, otherwise it was identical, but by simply following the instructions I was given I nearly caused a fire as I wasn't expecting a different power supply than the one on the item list.  I should have checked it a bit closer, but both the video and the assembly instructions said to do it this way, so I did.  If they are sending out different power supplies now then those directions need to be updated ASAP.  Second, the screws I was sent for the fan guard > fan > heat sink > extruder (connecting to each other in that order) were too long, but had they been the right size, it wouldn't have mattered as the heat sink didn't have screw holes anyway.  I e-mailed Hictop about this and verbatim their response was "try to do it again and do it slower."  Oookay, thanks for nothing.  I go to Lowe's and get some proper screws and manage to assemble it.  I turn it on and my computer doesn't recognize it (Window's 10).  I download drivers, install a different version of Cura, try a different USB cable, nothing.  I've printed with an SD card before, I'll try it again just to get this calibrated.  Well, you have to unscrew the LCD screen to insert the SD card, since the mounts for the printer filament block it.  Lastly, I attempted to calibrate my printer and was met with a "Heating fail" message on the LCD screen.  Thank goodness for Amazon, because Hictop customer service won't back up their garbage-grade products.

Edit:  After posting this I received an e-mail from the seller.  They apologized for their first e-mail and then told me to attach all those parts by the "upper holes."  They only have lower holes.  Next step was to "install the fan with the label facing inside" followed by a screenshot of their instructions where it literally says "the sticker on the fan facing out."  I know English is not their first language, but this is lazy at best and dangerous at worse.
summary: Garbage, nearly started a small fire, doesn't work properly

reviewText: I'll start off by saying this is my second 3D printer kit. I think that helped in making this one easier to put together and setup because I already had an idea of what needed to be done. With that said though, my first 3D printer never really worked right. I got it 5 or 6 years ago, it was a low quality kit (it used printed plastic as "bearings"!), and I never really got a good print from it after fiddling with it for a long time. It sat in storage for a lot of those years until about a 4 months ago when I decided to pull it out and start fiddling again ultimately leading to me throwing in the towel with it and buying this one. The difference is quite amazing. I've gone from only having a single semi successful print in 5 to 6 years of ownership on the old printer, to already printing 4 things successfully in a few days of ownership with this new one. The quality of the parts is very nice. The acrylic looks great, but be sure not to overtighten the screws or you could crack it. I may upgrade the acrylic to aluminum at some point (I am buliding a CNC that will be capable of cutting aluminum as well hehe), but it's sturdy as is. The instructions where mostly accurate, there were a few spots that were off a little but nothing to hard to figure out. Overall it probably took me about 6 hours of total time working on it to get it assembled and then another 30 minutes to calibrate everything and get my first print. A few issues to note: -The plug that came with the unit is 110v but EU standard coloring. It has no ground and no power switch which I was not crazy about. So I went to lowes and got a grounded 3 plug extension cord, cut off the outlet end to wire it up to the printer power supply, and added a 110v 20amp switch as well to easily cut the power without having to unplug it every time. -There is a design flaw on this model, as other reviews have stated the filament holder support blocks access to the SD card slot on the back of the LCD. The company has a modified part to correct this and they sent me the STL file for it to make my own if I want. You can also get around this if you use a micro sd card and sd card adapter. There is enough room to remove the micro sd card from the adapter. -The guide rail holes in the top pieces are slightly to small. I had to use a drill to open them up a little until the rods would fit through. Careful doing this though, do a little at a time, you don't want wobble in these rails. -The heated bed warps a little when heated, it's thin aluminum, that is what happens. Smaller prints in one area work fine as is, but anything larger you'll probably want to use a sheet of glass over the top of it. -I do have a problem with filament leaking out the top of the heating block. I've tried tightening it but haven't been able to get it to stop, although I'm wondering if it's partially due to the filament. It didn't seem to happen for some white filament I have, but did for the little bit of orange that came with the printer. HICTOP has already said they are sending me a new extruder tip, filament tube, and heating block to try and resolve it as well. -The wires at the control board are a mess!! I'm going to be printing some kind of enclosure to house them soon lol. All of these issues are overall fairly minor. That is why I only deducted one star for them. I also want to comment on the support. I contacted them over a few issues, like a bad print on the turbine fan shroud, and a gouge mark on the heated bed. After sending them a picture of it, they have sent me replacements. I haven't actually gotten them in yet, but they are on the way. The were really responsive with other questions I had and a great help. Also, even though I believe they are based in China, their english is pretty good. So I'm very happy with the level of support I have received thus far from HICTOP. All in all if you are looking for a lower cost 3D printer that works well, I'd highly recommend this one. I will update my review if anything changes, but with about 8 hours of printing on it so far everything is going well.
summary: Great 3D Printer for the price

reviewText:

So far no clogs, and heats good after playing with the position of the cartridge in the heat block.

UPDATED TO 4 STARS
UPDATE REASON: Extruder began to clog consistantly after this review. I completely dismantled it to clean it and check everything. Turns out my extruder came installed with an ALL METAL nozzle throat. So either there was a mixup or the description needs updating as I saw no mention of ALL METAL. The all metal hot end is not good for PLA filament unless it is a very high quality throat. This one may be roughly finished causing my clogs. I swapped it out to a regular ptfe lined and it is much better.

reviewText: Pros: + No fuss, excellent print quality + Simple to use + Very good build volume Cons: - Poor "getting started" instructions - Proprietary filament spools - Software lacks features I've been into 3D printing since 2012, first with the Printrbot (Kickstarter original) and then the Deltaprintr (also Kickstarter). Over the years I have been thrilled to see the prices of 3D printers come down and the ease-of-use get better with each generation. Nowadays there are some very usable printers for under $300, including the XYZprinting DaVinci MiniMaker. The DaVinci Mini looks like a Fisher-Price toy with its bright colors and plastic shell. But inside is a metal-construction printer that is surprisingly capable, once you get it going. Unfortunately, the included setup instructions are lacking. You get a poorly-printed "Quick Guide" which has most of what you need, but the size and quality of the pictures makes it hard to know if you're doing things right. If you go to the XYZprinting web site, you can download a PDF User Guide which has a much clearer version of the setup instructions plus details on how to use the software. Ah, the software. The Quick Guide says only to "go to the XYZprinting official web site" - which you can probably deduce - but it doesn't say what to do there. It turns out that you have to register for an account in order to download anything. When you do so, don't use special characters in your password - it will accept them but you'll be unable to log in. You might be misled by another sheet included that describes additional software you can download. Once you have removed the four plastic clips that secure the mechanism in place, as well as the numerous strips of tape, you should install the software before connecting and powering on the printer. Attach the power supply and connect the USB cable, then flip the power switch on the back to turn it on. The drivers will load, and then you're ready to run the XYZware software, which will require you to log in. You're now left on your own. If you click on the button to print a sample file, you'll get an error. First you have to tell the software which model of printer you have - this is done in the settings menu (gears icon). Assuming you've loaded the filament and attached the printbed sheet (basically a big piece of masking tape), you can now print the sample from the Settings > Printer page. The software will import a standard .stl file - when you want to print it will first save to a proprietary .3w file and you can then commence printing. Note that you can disconnect the USB cable once the software has sent the data to the printer, but of course you can't monitor its progress if you do. Much is made of the auto-leveling function but I didn't see it do much with that. The User Guide shows illustrations of a panel in XYZware where you can see status of the printer and make several adjustments, but it doesn't tell you that this panel isn't visible until you click on the unlabeled button in the lower right of the window! The printer is of the "Bowden" style, where filament is pushed through a flexible PTFE tube to the hotend. In this printer, the hotend itself moves in the X and Z directions, and the Y direction is handled by moving the printbed. It always prints at 203 degrees Celsius - there is no control over this. When you start a print, it first extrudes some filament at the right edge of the printbed to "prime" the hotend. I found the print quality to be excellent and the firmware is smart enough to slow down if the total layer time is short, reducing problems that might be caused by a lack of part cooling. (The hotend itself has a fan.) The design of the hotend is such that you can't really see what it is doing until a lot of layers have been laid down. I've attached photos of the "3DBenchy" demonstration print I made on the DaVinci Mini - it came out very well, as good as my Deltaprintr. Because the room where I have the printer is cool, I had to follow the guide's advice to coat the printbed tape with glue, or else the prints would warp. I brushed on a thin mixture of white glue (Elmer's Glue-All or similar) and water, then let it dry. Others just rub on glue sticks. If you run out of the tape squares, you can use ScotchBlue painter's tape, or possibly BuildTak squares (I like these). 100 meters of filament (a golden-yellow) are supplied. The filament itself is nothing special but the spools have a circuit card inside that identifies the filament to the printer and tracks consumption. When it says you're out of filament, whether or not you are, you have to replace the spool. You can buy the filament at Amazon - make sure you get the spools for the Mini series - but it goes on sale each Tuesday at the XYZprinting web site so you may want to take a look there as well. The XYZmaker software contains the "slicer" function that converts the generic shape information (.stl file) to the printer commands (.3w file). It has some of the options that other slicers do, but not a lot. For example, you can ask for "support", which is used when parts of the print would be hanging in midair - but you can't control what this looks like, or whether support is generated between the buildplate and part or anywhere there are overhangs. You can ask for a brim or a raft, used to enhance adhesion, but can't control the size or makeup of these. I printed an item that required a raft, but the raft couldn't be peeled off the print at all, unlike printing the same part using Cura software and my Deltaprintr. I was impressed by the variety of accessories provided: a print removal tool, two types of cleaning wire (for cleaning the filament path), a brush to clean the extruder gears, several sheets of the printbed tape and a metal block used for calibration should you need it. The printer has a built-in calibration mechanism which is triggered by an option in the printer status display. There is also a clear plastic shield box you can affix to the front to keep prying fingers away - I didn't use that. Although the XYZprinting DaVinci Mini probably won't satisfy advanced users, it is an excellent "starter printer" for seeing how you like the hobby. Once you get it set up, printing is a straightforward, no-fuss affair and it's easy to get consistently good prints. I wish it didn't take the "inkjet cartridge" approach that binds you to buying their filament, but at least you should be assured of good results that way.
summary: Great starter printer, but proprietary filament requirement annoying

reviewText:
Don't buy this printer if you plan to use 3rd party filament. The accompanied software is annoying with ads.
I bought this printer from BH. It came with a cartridge of yellow ABS. XYZ cartridge only contains 0.6Kg of material. I bought a XYZ natural PLA filament 0.6Kg cartridge for $27; what a rip-off. The PLA cartridge talks with the software; its extruder temperature is 145C with platform at 45C. That's very low for PLA. The software that came with the printer, on a CD/DVD, keeps asking you you install update every time running it. As soon as you update, it will absolutely force you to create an account with XYZ and login before you can enter the application - you have no choice. Once you've created an account and login, it won't bother with asking to login again, but keeps popping up with notice of some other software offer FREE and not-so-free from XYZ, along with another pop up telling you 3rd party filament won't give you a good result.
I had to drill the hood of the unit to accept other filament. See attached pictures.
If you happened to run out of filament, good luck with trying to get the stuck filament out. The feeding motor is NOT at the extruder assembly. I had to totally disassemble the extruder to get at the filament.
The 3D scanner is very poor in quality/resloution. You're better off buying a separate 3D scanner on Amazon.
Bad design, annoying software, expensive proprietary filament cartridge, & low quality 3D scanner.
This printer is slower than other brand printer in the same price range. No, I don't get discount or paid for review. Every dime I spent on tech comes from my paycheck.
summary: Don't buy this printer if you plan to use 3rd party filament. The accompanied software is annoying.

reviewText:
I'm not usually a fan of quick taps on wires, as I have had soo many fail on me over the years.
That being said, they are almost a necessary evil in the automotive world. There are many times when either the wire is too short, or time is too short to to a proper soldered splice.

These quick taps are better than the standard style in that the spliced on wire connection is a spade style that can be removed without exposing the wire. The standard style requires the spliced in wire sheath to be pierced just like the primary wire, leaving another point of weak connection or failure. These only need to penetrate the wire insulation on the primary wire.

If you price these at the local auto parts store, you are generally paying about $5 for a pack or 3 or 4. In this pack you get a complete assortment in 3 different wire sizes to make sure you have plenty of splices for any job for quite a while.

The red maroon color in this kit is the same as normal red ones which are for small wire, Blue for Medium, and Yellow for Larger wire.

Installation is easy, just lay the quick splice over the wire then, using a pair of pliers, compress the connector closed. As long as you use the proper color/size, you should end up with a good solid connection. Make sure the connector snaps closed. Then crimp the male spade connector onto the wire to be spliced in and push it into the connector.

If you have any issues, it is possible the wire insulation did not get fully pierced on one or both sides by the tap. Simply unsnap it and look if you can see wire on both sides. If not you may want to try the next size down or try the crimp again.

I have reviewed other wire connectors from Sopoby and have been quite impressed with the quality and value. These are no exception.
Sopoby provided these to GadgetClass for testing and review.
summary: Great Deal with 3 Color-Coded Sizes!

reviewText:

This will be a simple review as this is a simple product. You get a total of 60 connectors.
You get three sets of different connector sets.

Each connector is made of a nice plastic and the metal is copper + nylon. Maximum current for these is as follows. Yellow  24amps, Blue  15amps and Red  10Amps.

Crimp the male spade connector to your device standing wire. Use the quick splice matching connector to snap around the wire you wish to tap into. Then once the quick splice is tapped in, you slide this into the male spade connector.

Just two quick common ways to use these would be speaker wiring or even hard wiring an electronic device in your car to an existing power source without cutting and a ton of leg work. (Quick)

Overall, great little kit and even comes with a plastic storage container to store them in. Even when you use them up, you can still use the container for other screws-nuts as there are a lot of compartments and it comes with plastic inserts to resize the interior compartments as needed.

reviewText:
This is a great pack of assorted bullet connectors.
I use and prefer these over the spade style connectors all the time. I think bullet connectors give better surface area contact than spade connectors and are less likely to loosen up over time. They are also more compact and easier to use.

This 100 pack comes in a nice plastic organizer that will fit nicely in your drawer or electric tool bag.

You get 5 different colors, that don't follow the standard color to size/AWG format (yellow generally being for larger gauge wire). This limits you to 16Ga wire. You may be able to force a 14Ga wire in there if you shave off a few strands.

For the price this is a better deal than you will find at your auto parts store or your big box stores.

I recommend using a dual wall or adhesive lined heat shrink on every connector (see in my pics, I show a clear adhesive lined heat shrink on one of the finished connectors). This helps keep the wire from pulling out and keeps a lot of the major liquid out of the connector.
A kit like this comes in handy: http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00NPBUWRC/?tag=cr38er-20

Conclusion:
  Good value for the price. 5 different colors to match your wires.

I have reviewed other products from Sopoby and have been quite satisfied with their quality and value.
Sopoby provided these to GadgetClass for testing and review.
summary: Good Value! Assorted Colors Not Assorted Sizes!

reviewText:

reviewText: It is a good, durable nylon filament.  Make sure you dry it in a oven before printing with it and I store mine in gallon freezer bags with desiccant.  A vacuum sealer would be even better if you have one.  This prints nicely with great adhesion and strength as long as it is dry (nylon naturally absorbs moisture from the air, so keep it sealed).  I print mine at 260C with layer heights of 60% of my nozzle diameter.  I have had good success with using Elmers craft bond glue sticks on glass @ 70C and I slow my print speeds to 30mm/s on perimeters and 50mm/2 on infill using a Rostock Max v2.
summary: Great Stuff

reviewText:
This is a review of the XFasten Aluminum Foil Tape.

(3.6mil thick, 2 wide and 55 yards long.)

Summary  Aluminum tape is good item to have on hand and I have found this ideal for duct work. I have my dryer vented from inside to outside using pvc based on location of the dryer. The seams of my vents tend to come loose and air leaks at the joints. This is perfect for wrapping your joints. This stuck perfectly and the qualities of this tape as listed below make this a perfect tape for my application. The second way I use this is to assist with controlling my central air. My ducts in my home are older slanted floor style and have no control knob. So to control the amount of how much air comes out of each register, I simply remove the register and place this tape across part of the slotted vent. It adheres great to the underside of my vents and is out of sight  mind. Since it is good for cold and hot, it can be left on even if my system is switched from heat to ac.

Pros

-Can be used on cold and hot air ducts.

reviewText:
I was actually in the process of searching for a wet/dry vacuum cleaner when this Porter Cable wet/dry vacuum cleaner fortuitously became available on Amazon Vine.  I need a wet/dry vacuum cleaner to use in combination with my power sprayer to clean some grout lines inside my house. In case you are not familiar with the century old Porter-Cable company name, it became a subsidiary of Stanley Black & Decker in 2004  via a series of acquisitions and mergers.

This Porter Cable wet/dry vacuum cleaner has several thoughtful convenience features such as tool storage on the four roll around protrusions. That way they don't get misplaced so easily. It is easy to take the upper vacuum assembly off the bucket to access the trash and filters  just press two side latches slightly outward and lift the top off with the convenient wide handle.  And do the opposite to latch it back. It has a 6 foot hose thats nearly 2 inches in diameter to suck in larger pieces of debris. There are two extensions and two accessory pieces included, but no crevice tool. I've located an inexpensive one that looks like it will fit. I'll order it and post it if it fits. You can move the hose to an exhaust port on the upper assembly if you want to use it as a blower.

There are three filters all total: Disposable paper vacuum bag (Part Number 19-3100N) and a pleated central filter to use during dry vacuuming.  A foam filter (Part Number 19-1600) is to be used during wet vacuuming.  My early evaluation sample was missing a foam filter.  I sent an email request Sunday night and on Wednesday afternoon I received the foam filter and a paper filter in my mailbox  shipped from Aurora, Illinois to Houston. They sent the tracking number to me Monday afternoon.  Now thats what I call great customer service.

The advertisement says it has a 4 peak horsepower motor  but thats marketing buzz wording. They all do this. The more truthful number is 8 Amps at 120 Volts or about 960 Watts which equals 1.3 Horsepower on average.  To be certain, my Kill A Watt meter measured exactly 960 Watts. If it ran 4 HP continuously, it would trip your circuit breakers. (1 HP = 745.7 Watts). This vacuum cleaner is not as noisy as my wife thought it would be.  It is so very important to protect your hearing with high quality safety hearing protectors. Once you lose your hearing, its gone forever  cannot ever get it back.  I am living proof.  Thats why I asked my wife's opinion about the noise.

I think this Porter Cable wet/dry vacuum is about the best offering on Amazon in this price range.  I found a Craftsman version that is very similar, but I absolutely do not like the wire clamps they used to hold the top onto the lower bucket  very inconvenient. The Porter Cable version is clearly better and much easier to use in my opinion and it even looks a lot better.  I attached 7 photos, but only two seem to be showing up. I'm reposting it now - maybe I exceeded the limit.

Disclaimer:  I have not used this wet/dry vacuum cleaner extensively, but it appears very well built in my opinion. I only use power tools periodically when I have a new project around the house. I have accumulated a lot of tools over the years, but this is my one and only wet/dry vacuum cleaner.  I think it will be quite durable and certainly last a very long time.
summary: Great Value - Good Quality - Superb Customer Service

reviewText:
This is my review of the BIQU MK10 M7 0.4mm Extruder Brass Nozzle.

Im just getting my feet wet to 3d printing and theres a definite learning curve. Im not even sure I needed a new nozzle but Ive been having issues lately so as a means to help troubleshoot I purchased these. I opted for brass because thats what most people recommend especially for beginners due to its thermal properties, I did consider getting stainless steel; however, I don't have a need for those and they're only supposed to make an already daunting task harder.

Being that these are considered consumable items I was happy to get a pack of five as Im sure at some point Ill need another and besides I have a project now to make a case to hold them. The brass nozzles are clearly marked 40 (.4mm) so if I get different sizes Ill be able to tell them apart. Visual inspection of each showed the interiors free of defects and the threads of all five were clean.

Being that these are brass a soft metal I had concerns about the shipping but they arrivedin a bubble mailer, in an envelope protected by bubble wrap so these were more than safe.

Installation was straightforward for my printer, Ive only run one test print through the nozzle and noticed no issues so far.

If you need a new nozzle or just want some ready spares I recommend these if for you if they fit your 3d printer.

I received these at a discount in exchange for a fair and unbiased review.
summary: Worked exactly as advertised for me.

reviewText: This little button seem to be good. I'm just waiting to try it out. It was smaller than I thought even with the pictures of it. Hope it works out.
