reviewText: Gotta be careful, i bought one of these a year ago and now my workspace is full of 3d printers. This thing hilariously outperforms my cr-10 when printing small objects. The bowden tube is so short that it doesnt mess up retraction typically, and easily handles 50 microns, so i use it for 1/144 and N scale models. I even made some fallout cosplay on it by cutting the models down and glueing them later. Modifications were extremely easy, printed parts for an e3d hotend, new fan housing, re routed wires, and changed the lcd placement. Also make sure you print the hot end carrier immediately, as it will be needed about 2 months in. In fact print everything you can for it just in case. You cant easily get replacement parts without crazy shipping times. There are extra spots on the motherboard for another fan, although soldering skills may be required.. look it up i guess.
summary: Too much fun, really small, easy to tinker with.

reviewText:
Got it for Christmas, it was on sale. The first printer broke about 36 days after we got it. The SD card slot stopped reading and even though there's a plug to plug it into the computer to print directly from the computer - it doesn't work. You NEED the SD card slot to work.

So, Amazon begrudgingly made a very super special exception and let me exchange it. Aside from the warming plate not getting even a little bit warm, and models not sticking, sliding all over, it worked well enough. This one lasted about 2 months before it wouldn't even turn on anymore. All of a sudden the power switch stopped working. So rather than go through Amazon because they made it such a hassle to get help the first time I talked to monoprice directly. I had to ship it back to them, have them repair it, send it back. The whole process took about a month.

I got it back today. They said the wiring in the warming plate was faulty and they replaced it. Now I'm trying to print and everything I print feels like it's glued down. I can't get anything off of the plate. Which wouldn't be SO bad if it was printing correctly. But it's not. It starts to print normally then shifts every model over about an inch. So, every single thing I print is completely useless.

Talking to amazon customer service now. They're blaming me. Saying this is the second time there has been an issue. and want to give me a refund on the sale price. Refusing to exchange it for a working one. Nice. So now I'm out a printer and I spent a bunch of money on all this filament.

This printer is garbage and so is Amazon's customer service. The last 3 times I spoke with (on chat or email, phone has been fine) them they've been rude, unhelpful, and accusatory. I have no idea what happened to their customer service but it's terrible. I may stick around for smaller things but any big purchases like this are going to have to start being made elsewhere. There's no guarantee of anything working and if it doesn't they tell you it's your fault. Ridiculous. The pictures speak for themselves. You're right Amazon. Clearly this is MY fault... The printer works "fine", right?

Stay away from this printer.
summary: Junk

reviewText: Monoprice Select Mini 3D Printer with Heated Build Plate, Includes Micro SD Card and Sample PLA Filament - 121711 - Black Pros: 1. Inexpensive for an assembled 3D printer. 2. All metal construction. 3. Easy to use interface. 4. Easy to read and color interface. 5. Safe power brick. 6. Small footprint. 7. Heated build plate. 8. Version 2 has all metal hot end extruder. Cons: 1: Noisy 2: Version 2 uses smaller stepper motors. 3: Spool holder is in an awkward position. 4: Bent/warped bed. 5: Bed leveling could be easier. Just some personal thoughts, I asked Santa for a 3D Printer and she gave me $200 and said no more than that. So what does $200 get you for an entry level 3D printer? Well you can order a kit from Amazon or China and build it and learn about 3D printing or you can wait for this little gem to go on sale and buy it! You should do your research prior to purchasing any 3D printer and the Monoprice Select Mini is no exception. These are actually pretty complex pieces of engineering despite their inexpensive price tag. They can also burn, pinch, cut and electrocute you! They are not toys! Now that the disclaimers are out of the way why 5 stars. At $220 regular price they are on the cheaper side so they are a great value for what they can do. I've printed PLA, ABS (not recommended indoors!), PET-G and TPU. The Facebook Group is friendly and the online group can help the newest most uneducated person to 3D printing get up and running without making you feel embarrassed for asking the question. Basically your not only buying the printer you get an army of like minded users that'll help you along. My printer came with a warped print bed. I was a bit upset. Looked online and saw it was common. Cheap aluminum bed (cost savings). However, most people switch to glass beds and have detailed instructions on doing it. Costs about $3. The bed wires fray then break. Once again it's a known issue. Detailed instructions for several ways to fix it. It can cost you anywhere from the cost of your PLA to print the parts to rewire the whole bed. The built in WiFi doesn't play well with my mesh system I have installed. Who cares? Octoprint is the way to go! Here comes the monster! I guess the point of this review is in my case if it wasn't DOA (Dead On Arrival) and doing my due diligence by researching various printers and watching videos and asking questions in the community about this printer I knew what to expect and was ready. When I opened the very nicely packaged printer and set it up it worked as it should. Follow the videos Monoprice has on YouTube and they'll walk you through the process. Search Monoprice Select Mini on YouTube and you'll find many videos that'll educate you about the printer. Overall I like mine and the endless creative possibilities it has opened up. Other than the warped bed I haven't had any thing "break". Granted I preempted many of the known failures by just replacing or modifying them right away. There are also many who don't do anything to their printers and they work just fine. I just like to tinker!
summary: Uh Oh, The Wife Created A Monster!

reviewText:
-1 star for poor print bed design, -1 star for customer service

I got this for Christmas, as a CAD operator since 95 I have dreamed of having my own 3D printer since I first saw one at GE 22 years ago, but that one was a 1/4 of a mil.  For the money I think it is a good 3D printer but it has its flaws, especially in customer services.

Heat Bed Problem  See picture(and terrible customer service)
The head bed helps your printer stick to the print bed, without it your print could pop off or it would warp up.  I notice after having my printer for 2 weeks the prints started warping that's when I noticed the bed wasn't heating.  There are 4 wires coming out of the printer to the build plate 2 for heating 2 for temperature reading.  One of the wires got snagged because the bed moves in and out and the wires feed through a grommet.

 I contacted mono price, I emailed them, they never called me.  I tried to use the chat thing and they canceled the chat session, I have the email to prove it.  I didn't want to fix it myself as I was afraid of voiding my warranty.  In the end I had to rewire it, because after I fixed the red wire the black wire snapped.  I ended up by passing the feed, adding wire on the outside of the unit, haven't had a problem sense.

Pros
Its Cheap
Does a good job
Easy to set up

Cons
Its cheap
Terrible customer service (or lack of customer service)
Heat bed is a terrible design
SD card reader only works on FAT, no SDHC cards useable
Very little documentation
Doesnt play nice with USB printing
Leveling the print bed is a PITA (but once leveled you're good)

Bottom Line
If you're thinking about getting into 3D printing and handy with a soldering iron and you don't want to spend much this is the printer for you.  If you have the money though I recommend buying something better.  I plan on using mine for a year but then I will probably sell it and use the cash to buy a bigger and better unit, something not Monoprice, which makes me sad because I am a huge fan of Monoprice and buy lots of things from them, but I never needed tech support in the past.

Tips for New Users
SD Card  the SD card reader is small, its fine but if you want a second one with more storage get a 2g card and format it to FAT.  I wasted too much time to find out that SDHC cards don't work, as there is 0 documentation telling you about the card reader.
Print Bed  The print bed will wear out over time and tear, you have lots of options to replace it, you could use painters tape, or buy a replacement bed or use glass.  A 5x7 picture frame at the dollar store works, clamp it down with binders clip.  On the glass you can use hairspray for a light hold or Elmers Glue Sticks, the glue sticks are made from PLA so PLA prints will hold strong on them.
Removing Prints  Prints are hard to pop off if you have a good stick, the plastic print tool it comes with won't get under most prints.  What I do is I get it started with a razor scraper blade and then use the plastic tool the remove the rest, just be careful to keep a low angle as to not cut into the print bed.  If you move to a glass then is less of an issue, and FYI yes the glass will transfer the heat.

What to print?  If you don't know how to draw in 3D you can download STL sites from many different sites, you will not run out of things to print, and some prints that are 2 big for your print bed you can scale down.

How do you print?  - You get an STL file then then you open it with a slicer program, this printer comes with Cura but there are other ones out there. In the slicer you set up how you want it to print, you can print fine layers for a better looking print or a thick layers for a lower resolution stronger print.  You can say what temperature to print and even how much material you want to print between the shell.  10-20% will be fine for most things.  The slicer program will generate a gcode file, you copy the file onto your SDcard (or you can print straight to your printer with a USB cable (but pray it doesnt fail)) then in the printer you pick the gcode file and tell it to print.

Hope this helps!
summary: Good for a started printer but...

reviewText:
I got this as a gift for Christmas. I had always wanted one but never had a need for one. Well when you get one you suddenly have the need to print all the things for no reason. Print a do hickey you don't need just to watch it go, print a cat just cause, 3d print a 3d printer because you have too many things that need printing.
It's nearly plug and play. Level the bed, download some models, throw them in Cura, hit print and wait. Mine was ready to go right out the box, bed was perfectly leveled and my first print was great. After some tinkering in Cura getting the settings dialed in prints have been spectacular. The settings monoprice recommends are good for starting out with basic prints, but with more detailed you will want to go online and find other select owners and see what they recommend. Biggest hurdle is orientation of the model in Cura and the proper support settings.
This printer since Christmas Eve has been running almost non-stop printing models I plan on painting and stupid useless stuff just cause I think it was neat. My first roll of filament barely has a dent in it.
For the price it makes it easy for anyone to get into 3d printing and I recommend if you have the slightest interest in 3d printing and $300 laying around get it. You won't be sorry.
summary: I love it so much I might have it print me a wedding ring and propose to it.

reviewText: Noting some reviews regarding the heated bed wires, I decided to preemptively wrap the wires in spiral-wrap rather than undertake a serious mod project (no pix, sorry, but it isn't hard to figure out what to do). This is a great beginners printer, IF the beginner has a bit of foreknowledge (i.e. familiar with slicer concepts and tools, understands the basic properties of PLA/ABS/PETG/etc) and manages their expectations (it ain't like a desktop laser printer). Bed calibration is crucial but very easy with a sheet of printer paper. What I did was to screw the front left (0,0,0) corner down until I was sure the hotend would clear when homed, then homed the axes. Put paper on the bed and raise that corner until you can just barely feel resistance as the extruder tip slides across (manually slide the extruder left/right). Then do the diametrically opposed corner, then the others. Lather, rinse, repeat until satisfied. The nozzle should feel about the same anywhere on the bed. When printing, I always use a thin raft, as it allows me the opportunity to fine-tune the bed leveling and temps based on how the first layer is put down. Also I start the print at 0.30625 above the raft - sticks nice for printing, and releases easy when done. So far I have only printed PLA: the translucent white sample, some 'silver/gray', Clear red & green, Copper Fill, and Magnetic Iron without issue. All of my prints (except the red-headed lucky cat) have been at 0.04375mm layer height (yeah, slooow -the Viking took just under 7hr) The default temp (200) worked well enough for the sample filament and demo cat, but I adjusted the temp to 210 when I ran out and switched filament to the red to finish the print. I had to turn the temp up 225 for the magnetic iron on the first few layers, then back to 220 for the remainder of the print. The buildtak-like surface has been great, and holds onto prints like the dickens (especially with thin raft), so use caution when removing your prints to avoid tearing of bubbling. I printed a filament feed guide from thingiverse to assist with TPU, which I haven't tested with yet on this printer.
summary: Loving this little gem!

reviewText:
I had this unit for a couple weeks and got some great prints, especially for something around $200. I'd still recommend this printer to people, and I have friends who purchased one based on my suggestion and are happy with it.

However, I'm returning my unit because the rear fan started making some noise. It comes and goes, but I'd rather return to Amazon while I'm still within my allowed return window.

With that said, I'll be purchasing a CR-10 mini instead. For the beginner, this printer is great, but I found that I quickly became engulfed in the hobby. That's why I'm going to take what would be an otherwise frustrating situation of a noisy fan, and turn it into an opportunity to get something a little more intermediate.

This printer isn't perfectly, but here's my quick list of pros and cons:

Pros
 - Small form factor, requiires very little desk space
- Quality prints
- Pre-assembled, fast setup
- Fairly strong community for support

Cons
- USB connectivity is flaky (You have to disconnect/reconnect upon intial connection)
- SD card support is limited. SDXC SDHC etc do not work, in my experience. You need a <2GB standard SD card, I believe.
- Mods required to print flexible TPU (very easy to fix)
- Bed doesn't stay hot enough for large ABS prints
summary: A good printer for beginners, with a few drawbacks

reviewText: This is my second 3d Printer  i ordered the CR-10  the first time,  this one has a lot smaller build plate, but it's rock solid  No error no mess ups  Hit Print and it makes it, Very nice just as quick and Looks awesome on your desk =)  Thanks
summary: Very nice just as quick and Looks awesome on your desk ...

reviewText: So far this printer is awesome! For those of you who are new to 3-D printing, it will take a research to dial in the settings in Cura to get your prints to look good, but Google is your friend here. I recommend the hatch box filaments. I've not tried Monoprice but they may be good as well. I love printing with wood!
summary: Super cheap and super awesome!

reviewText:
I run a small lab at work to introduce and teach my coworkers about 3D printing. The printers in this lab get almost non-stop usage for 8 - 10 hours a day, 5 days a week. You can get excellent prints from this machine, but it will require a lot of maintenance.

Pros:
* Affordable
* Consistently good prints
* Small - this would fit on a desk next to you while you work
* Offers standalone operation
* Open-source printer allows you to use 3rd party materials, etc.

Cons:
* Major design flaw: Build plate wiring will break over time. *see below
* Bowden feeding system: The feeding system is poorly implemented. *see below
* Inconvenient SD port placement: You may actually end up dropping your SD card in the machine. *see below

Build Plate Wiring:
The wires that lead to the heated build plate and thermal sensor are tightly banded to the printer frame in such a way that the wires are forced to bend sharply as the build plate moves back and forth. This will cause these wires to break internally over time. When this happens you will have to make a choice to either have it repaired and wait for the same thing to happen again, or alter the way the wires are run so they are no longer stressed. We've seen this earlier rather than later just due to the sheer volume of printing we do with this device.
TO BE CLEAR: This is not a matter of *if* this will happen, it is a matter of *when* it will happen.
Symptoms:
* You try to print something and it never starts printing (along with one of the two following symptoms)
* The build plate temperature is 0 degrees (this means the wires to the sensor have broken)
* The build plate does not heat up and sits at around room temperature (this means the wires to the heater have broken)

Bowden feeding system:
NOTE: I am not saying all bowden feeding systems are bad - this one is just poorly implemented.
With this type of 3D printer (FDM/FFF) you will usually see one of two types of feeding systems: bowden or direct. There are pros and cons to each of these systems but generally when someone prefers a bowden system it is because the print head is much lighter when the feeding mechanism are not attached directly to the print head.
This particular system (as you can even see in the product picture) very sharply bends the feeding tube that the filament is pushed through. You will experience the following issues with this implementation:
* Higher resistance on the feeding system during some parts of your prints than others
* Eventual need to replace the bushings holding the feeding tube in place
* Eventual need to replace the bowden tubing (when it starts becoming more creased at these sharp bend points)
* Seemingly random jams.
* Feeder teeth will grind more plastic as it pushes meaning it will need frequent cleanings to avoid degraded performance over time.

Inconvenient SD port placement:
Holy crap! This could have been done way better. There is a little, tiny micro-SD port on this side that you will need to use if you want your printer to operate in standalone mode (without relying on a computer attached to it). The hole cut on the panel exposing this port is 2 times bigger than it needs to be and the actual port is recessed into the body of the printer. This means you may actually miss the port all-together and drop the SD card into the printer. If this happens you have to unscrew the side panel of the printer in order to remove it and recover the memory card.

If you are new to 3D printing you will likely have a frustrating experience later on rather than right away.
If you are an experienced maker / hobbiest then this is actually a really good printer. You just have to keep it running with a little extra love and attention.
summary: Good prints, but high maintenance.

reviewText:
This is a phenomenal printer for the price.  With that said, you will spend the first couple days figuring out what settings to use and how to properly level your bed.  Both the settings and bed leveling are critical to getting a good print.  The first eight hour print I tried failed towards the end because of bed leveling and settings.

Update 9/5/207:  After about 3 weeks of printing, the printer failed.  I read a lot of forum posts and figured out that everyone has the same problem with the wiring in the to the heated bed.  I found that without a heated bed, I couldn't get any prints to stick, so I basically couldn't use it until I fixed it.  I spent a full day getting parts and performing the re-wire.  Attached are a pic of the bad wires, and the upgraded wiring through the back of the unit.  The only reason I am not giving it less than 3 stars is because once you get over the fact that you have to modify/correct the wiring, the printer does work pretty good.

If I were to buy another printer, I think I would go with the Anet A8.  Looks like the same amount of effort to use it, but you won't have to re-wire it and it's got a bigger bed.  https://www.amazon.com/Auto-Levelling-Anet-A8-Printer/dp/B01N4BSWMQ/ref=sr_1_15?ie=UTF8&qid=1504589094&sr=8-15&keywords=anet+a8
summary: Phenomenal price!  Will fail within a few weeks of purchase.  Be Prepared for serious modifications

reviewText: My printer came perfect and ready to use. Follow the easy instructions (which are only a few pages) Also make sure you purchase a spool of good rated/reviewed filament and have a computer and you are good to go. I highly recommend it and would definitely buy it again.... 2 thumbs wayyy up!
summary: Finally, a affordable 3d printer that works!

reviewText: overall I really enjoy this 3D printer. the best one for the price here are my tips and suggestions I'd get at least 2 different colors, i bought blue and grey and now i wish i bought a translucent color too. brand HatchBox some say the little menu knob is irritating to use but it doesn't bug me and you can always print a different one if you don't like it ;) #1 DITCH THE SD CARD THAT COMES WITH IT, 3/4 prints i did with the original sd card would reach 99% and stop there, the printer wouldn't return home and sat on the last spot and froze there causing plastic to drip on the print. after using a name brand sd card the printer works normal and returns home after printing. I use blue painters tape in three strips to completely cover the bed. i do have a 1mm gap between each strip of tape which doesn't affect the print one bit, but over lapping the tape will. i use normal school glue like Elmer's white glue one the bed for bed adhesion which stick on extremely well. do not use hair spray, it leaves a residue and you have to change the tape more often and the chemicals can eat the grease off of the axis rods. when the bed is one degree from the temperature you want then i use the included yellow scraper to spread the glue, if you do it too early it dries up and cools the bed down taking even longer to heat up. remember half the battle is adjusting the slicer settings, it can greatly affect the print quallity, most of the time the printer is not at fault. also sometimes the models you download from thingiverse.com have errors or other issues and are interpreted by the slicer incorrectly causing print errors. i use cura and I've heard simplify 3d works well also. here are my settings in cura layer height 0.2 mm initial layer height 0.25-0.3 mm wall thickness 0.8 mm and sometimes 1.2 mm (must be a multiple of the hot end of 0.4 mm) top/bottom thickness same as above infill density 25% but depends on what you want infill layer thickness 0.2 mm printing temperature 200 or 205 C and i use HatchBox PLA, works great for me build plate temperature 60 C diameter 1.75 mm flow 100% enable retraction yes retraction distance 1-2mm depending on what you print (very important setting and the next one too) retraction speed 25 mm print speed 35-50 mm per second depending on the detail/complexity of your print and i don't recommend anything over 55 maybe 60 max, any higher and it affect the quality of the print infill speed 55 mm per second travel speed 65-70mm per second initial layer speed 15 mm per second 1st layer is the most important and should be slow always print with a skirt just to get the nozzle flowing correctly usually the first lap doesnt stick right so this way it doesnt ruin anything if you have a skirt enabled. if your object is taller id print with a brim. the only thing i do not like about cura is the support is auto generated and you have no control or way to adjust it, but at least all of the prints i did did not need support material also add 10-20 min more to what ever cura estimates for print time i use fusion 360 to build models (see photo for the small robot i designed the frame) its a line follower using a attiny85 micro-controller worked right out of the box, just needed to level the bed. I'd lower the bed before turning the printer on so the hot end doesn't drag and scrape the bed. PROS very accurate printer, I printed a fidget spinner which the center parts are separate and spin (see photo) and there was a 0.4mm gap between the spinner body and the center parts. once printed i didn't even need to break them lose, I've also printed a hing which had a 0.2mm gap between the hinge pin and the central part that hold the pin, after printing it needed a little effort to move and now moves freely. (see photo for the hinge) It's impressive to be able to print a hinge or fidget spinner as "one piece" or at the same time yet each part moves separately. the bed is easy to level easy to load filament heated bed color display hot end has not clogged once on me print quality is very nice the benchy boat printed flawlessly and even created a 8 mm bridge between two pillars to form the window and it doesn't droop down CONS something vibrates while it does the travel moves, which is a bit noisy but does not seem to affect the prints bed takes a bit of time to heat up the cooling fan makes a odd hum but is not noticeable once the the print begins, the fan shroud could use a rubber grommet to stop the vibration the x axis motor gets pretty hot, but having a small fan resting on the z axis arm quickly cools this down and the same probably goes for the driver board and y axis motors but they are inside the case so i can't feel them. the newer version of this printer has a fan built into the case to cool those components and it is possible to add a fan underneath the printer, theres a grill for it but no fan. for longer prints than 2 hr id install a fan underneath just to be safe. this printer can print most of what i need but the bed size can be limiting at times
summary: best printer for the money and great build quality

reviewText: I did a lot shopping before ordering this printer.  I was ready to pay several times more than the price of this printer, but after seeing some reviews, I thought this would do most of what I expected to print.  I believe I made a good choice.  The printer is easy to use and works well.  I did a rough level of the build platform, initially, and fine tuned it after a couple test prints.  I haven't had to level again.  I scratched the masking tape that covered the build platform and replaced it with strips of 1-3/8 inch blue painter tape.  That has worked well.  If a strip becomes worn, I just replace the strip, rather than replacing the entire surface and I haven't had any problems.  I find that it is easier to remove a project from the platform if I print a raft with the model (a raft is a thin layer of material between the model and the platform).  It is easier to get a tool under the raft to release the model and the raft is easily separated from the model.  I have used PLA filament from two manufacturers for all printing.  The two types print at different temperatures (180 and 205) and both work well.  I design most of my projects using Sketchup or openSCAD but have also downloaded and modified some models from thingiverse.  Two software packages are provided with the printer but I have only used the provided Cura software.  So far, it has done everything I needed to do and it is easy to use.  I've printed knobs, motor mounts, Arduino boxes, battery holders, coffee scoops, scroll saw lamp shade and more.
summary: Excellent printer for great price!

reviewText:
I am a 3d printing beginner and didn't want to spend much on my first printer.  I wasn't expecting much from the printer so my expectations weren't high.  I watched as many YouTube videos on setting up the printer as I could.  As soon as I got the printer I flashed the screen and rom as well as changed its settings according to the videos.  I didn't use the filament that came with the printer as there was very little of it.  I bought some Inland PLA filament here on Amazon and loaded that instead.  I started printing the included model of the cat and it came out great.  I started downloading .stl files from Thingiverse and printing them without issue (Using Cura to slice).  All was well and then my prints went to garbage.  I watched more 3d print videos and apparently my bed was out of level.  This is where the fun begins, NOT!  I thought I would have to send the machine back because it seemed no matter what technique I used to level the bed my prints were still garbage.  Finally I watched a video that suggested using a business card for each of the four corners (I had been using a piece of paper)... that did the trick.  After practice, I can level the bed in no time flat.  Again watch videos on leveling.  I also had to clear a filament jam which was interesting.. again, another video to watch.

I started playing with various bed temps as well as filament temps.  I bought other types of filament to see what worked the best.  Let me give you a heads up, if you are going to use ABS... Don't.  It's a headache.. doable but still a headache with all the things you need to do to get it to stick properly.  I did some ABS prints and they came out great but again.. a headache.  I also found that about middle of the road for temperature depending on what the filament calls for is what worked for me.  For PLA 60c (Edit: 40c is fine after the first layer) was perfect and for ABS I sliced whatever I was printing with the bed set to 60.  Once the print would start I would up the bed temp to 80c.  The bed would only get to around 78c.  For ABS to work I had also used an Elmer's glue stick on my blue 3m masking tape covered bed to get it to stick.  Again, stick with PLA.  Oh I failed to mention, when the initial masking tape comes off the bed plate which it will, you can cover it back up with 3M blue masking tape, the same kind you use when you paint.

Since I have played, I can pretty much tell by what I am printing what setting I should use.  I can only suggest that you play around and watch a lot of videos.  At this price and for a single spool of filament you should be having fun and learning.  I have since moved on from using Cura and am now using Simplify3d which is rather pricey but I really like it.

The small build plate is a challenge as a lot of models that you may want to print will be much bigger.  Scaling has its issues.  Trying to take off supports when the part of the model it is connected to can be tricky.

I included a picture of my latest print (Not sure why it shows up on Amazon sideways).  This had to be scaled down significantly from the original and lost some detail in regards to the terminator's hydraulics around the mouth and back of the head.  But if you want to print bigger, you are going to spend a lot more on a printer.  I am pushing this thing to its limits and I am coming out with some great prints.  I have also bought another 3d printer with a larger print bed but I will not give this one up for my smaller projects.
summary: Amazing, inexpensive 3d printer which takes a little patience to get used to.

reviewText:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
UPDATE AFTER 2 MONTHS OF OWNERSHIP:
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Pros:
Still in love with the quality and accuracy of the prints
When it comes to dimensional accuracy of small sized prints this printer beats my other printer, the Printrbot Simple Metal hands down!

CONS
WiFi upload support is really poor

There is no specific pattern or explanation for why some files upload and some don't, but a "cache" file existing on the SD Card seems to be the problem. Each time, I remove this cache file from the SD Card and then try to upload the gcode via WiFi, I have better results. But even this solution is ineffective in case of large prints especially those above 2KB.

Printer stops before printing is completed!

There is no guarantee that larger prints will complete. The printer comes to a sudden stop for no apparent reason.
Just yesterday, this happened to one of my prints at 96% - Pausing and Unpausing the print did nothing to improve the situation

SD Card support is primitive
You have to switch off the printer before you load new prints on to it. If you eject the SD Card when the printer is on, and add files to it and plug it back in, the printer reports a Card read / unrecognized error

**************************
My 60-Day Opinion:
**************************

Still a great printer. I have seen articles on the Web stating that we need to update the firmware, but this is at odds with Monoprice product warranty - therefore, I'm undecided on what the next step should be.

As much as I hate to do this, I've downgraded from 5 Stars to 4. :-(

============================================================================================
ORIGINAL REVIEW

I've owned a Printrbot SimpleMetal for a few years now, and despite spending a bundle on upgrading to a heated bed, endless hours of calibration and bed levelling, the printer continues to throw one or the other tantrum each day I try to get a decent print out of it.

Therefore, this review is geared for users who want to get their projects out the door real quick and not spend hours tinkering and customizing their 3D printers. This is what I wanted to focus on after a seemingly endless and tiresome experience with the Printrbot SimpleMetal.

I bought the Monoprice Mini after reading the other reviews and having received multiple responses to my question on this product (Thanks to all those who responded!) here on Amazon. Less than 2 days I've had it, I say no regrets for having bought one! In addition to the sample lucky cat model, I printed some that I designed and sliced on Repetier host using slic3r and this printer simply continued to deliver one good print after another!

I'm astounded by the out of the box quality of the prints! In the last 24 hours, this little machine has been running for at least 13 hours printing. My family has taken a liking to the cat and I managed to print two of them in a row one for my wife, and another for my son!

However there are a few minor things that you need to look out for:

--------------------
Uneven foot pegs
--------------------

This setback almost made me skeptical about the printer even before I turned it on! My printer came with uneven foot pegs - this is the first thing to check for. There was a visible difference between the foot peg immediately below the LCD panel and the other three. I stuck a few layers of painter tape cut to the shape of the foot peg until the printer stopped wobbling.

--------------------
When slicing, position the object to the middle of the bed on the Slicer software!
--------------------

I simply copied a GCODE file that I sliced in slic3r in Repetier Host. At the time, I moved the model towards the back of the bed before I sliced it. When I printed it in the Mini, the model was spaced so far towards the end of the bed that the print head moved past the edge of the print bed and hit the limit switch making a terrible stuttering noise. The picture shows one such print. The skirt line is printed on the extreme edge of the print bed.

Not good! Therefore, make sure that you slice the model by placing it to the middle of the bed in the slicer software.

--------------------
The factory bed lining won't last very long
--------------------

I printed a GCODE file that was sliced for Printrbot. The bed temperature was set to 62, and the extruder temp was set to 205. This is because the conditions in my room cause a temperature drop during printing. Therefore I had to keep the temperatures a few degrees higher to compensate for the drop.
Printing this GCODE on the Mini caused my PLA part to be nearly welded to the bed, and I had to tear the bed lining to get the part of the bed.

I used Kapton tape as replacement and it's definitely an easier liner to work with. The print sticks to the bed and is easy to take off when completed.

--------------------
The bed is real small - Be careful when dismounting parts!
--------------------

The bed on this printer is so small that you run the risk of running your palm into the printer arm causing it to bend. Exercise care when dismounting parts that are stuck fast to the print bed because the printer arm is real delicate!

--------------------
WiFi is an essential feature, not optional
--------------------
Unless you love moving micro SD cards around, printing models from SD cards is painful. Therefore, enabling WiFi on your Mini will go from being optional to required really quickly.

There are advanced methods to enable WiFi on the Mini, but for Windows users, the Malyan PC App is the quickest and easiest way to enable WiFi on the Mini and upload GCODE to the printer via your browser. No fancy firmware upgrades required!

To get started on WiFi set up, visit mpselectmini DOT com SLASH wifi SLASH windows.
summary: Amazing Printer! But be mindful of a few minor things.

reviewText:
Good morning all,
well, i will be the first to admit, that you sometimes get what you paid for.

In this case, I am conflicted.

When the printer arrived, all looked well.
No manual, no big deal I downloaded it.

Then issues,
I attempted load the printer, only to find it had a piece of filament broke off in the nozzle.
See image

Well, being that i spent a month trying to get another printer to work i knew how to disassemble  and remove the filament.
Thank goodness my existing printer had tools.

You know, that once you remove the extruder, you will need to relevel the bed.
So this was a snap.

Next, time to print.
I loaded some PLA and printed the sample.

I was pleasantly surprise. It completed the print and looked very nice.
In fact, very nice.

Now, it was time for ABS.
Since the bed can only go to 60, this concerned me.
However, I ran the extruder up 220 and was able to print a nice small piece.

On to a bigger piece.
Ugg, 2/3 off the print and the printer was stuck/stopped Im not sure what you would call it.
The piece was with in the height of the printer.
I am hoping for a glitch, perhaps power, perhaps filament gods.

I will rerun the job and let you know.

So for now, 3 stars.
summary: Getting Warmer

reviewText: This is for the people on the fence about this printer. For 200$ everyone should own one of these.i did absolutely nothing other than put my OWN spool of pla in and print the cat g code on the SD card INCLUDED  with the printer and mind blown....damn near perfect print. I can't show the picture because amazon hasn't approved just anyone to do so but I give it 5 stars because for 200$ I was honestly expecting less but this thing is built tough and did better than I expected. I bought a e3d head from the website for if I need it and my next print will be the mounting bracket etc.etc. seriously just buy it and go to monoprice. Com and check out the tab monoprice upgrades and print the extra parts that will eventually break and the others for support brackets and fan upgrades. Huge support groups on the Web and this thing is definitely hackable and has mods already on thingiverse. Small build platform but I already knew that buying it so it's a good one to learn on and if you don't like it or can't figure out the g code or slic3rs or drawing in cad programs you can still print things others have created or send it back I believe 30 days satisfaction is what I read. Anyway long story short this thing is a plug and play printer that will get you hooked and a good idea of what's what in the 3d printer world. Why are you still reading this buy it already!

This is my first 3d printer.  If you are looking to test the waters this is a great machine to do it on.  Setup was a breeze, you just plug it in and feed the filament into it. reviewText: I purchased this printer about 4 months ago and it has been far more fun than I would have expected (and I expected a lot). While this is the best 3D printer you could purchase for what I paid (at the time I bought it), there is some setup and trial and error that should be expected with any 3D printer. You will need to play with the temps a little bit to get the printing down and this will change each time depending on the filament you will use. As I have now purchased two of these (one for my Father In-Law) I have had both power supplies fail. Mine failed after 2 months, the other failed out of the box. So that you are disappointed when you purchase, I highly advise purchasing a better power supply when you purchase this printer - I am running this one with great success, and slightly better prints. ( Winkeyes AC 100-240V to DC 12V 10A Switching Power Supply Adapter + DC Power Splitter Cable 1 Female to 8 Male Connectors for CCTV Camera/ LED Strip Flexible Lights (12V 10A) ). Please don't expect this to be like a typical paper printer, it's going to have some things that need trouble shooting and this will be the case on all 3D printers, this is just a great budget one to get you started. I have well over 400 hours printing as of this review and am currently adding about 40 hours a week. I have purchased several items to help fine tune to my liking but many people find other methods that work well for them. If you are serious about this printer, and you won't regret the purchase, I have learned a lot from the people who have started this webpage ( http://mpselectmini.com/start ) and I am also happy to tell people what I have done to get successful prints. The below items are things I have added on, replaced, or found worked better than the original, but most require slight modification or adjustment of the initial setup.. CycleMore 5PCS Hotend Barrel M6*26MM Teflon Nozzle for MK8 Tube Makerbot 1.75mm 3D Printer Extruder Hot End Reprap Prusa I3 CycleMore 5PCS M6 3D 0.4mm Extruder Brass Nozzle Print Head for 1.75mm J-head/E3D ABS PLA 3D Printer Signstek 3D Printer MK2 MK3 Heated Bed Tempered Borosilicate Glass Plate 213*200*3mm Elmer's Jumbo Glue Stick (3 Pack) 1.4 oz (40g) each - Washable Disappearing Purple
summary: Best purchase I've had all year

reviewText:
UPDATED as of 12/22/2016

I increased the rating from 3-star to 4-star because I was able to resolve the issues caused by Amazon's poor packaging. The poor packing caused the unit to take a lot more abuse than it should have during shipping, so it arrived all outta whack. Part of the initial teething I suffered through was due to  a cracked extruder arm not putting enough pressure on the filament against the feeder gear so it failed to extrude several times. Once I identified the problem I grabbed the model from thingiverse, remixed it to be a bit stronger, and printed a replacement arm out of ABS on my FFC Pro which has worked fine. The extruder arm is known to be a weak link and anyone who has a MP Select Mini would do well to print a replacement arm to keep on hand if the OEM arm breaks. Same with the extruder base plate. Those 2 items are why I didn't give it a 5-star rating.

Now, the thing is so dialed in now that I don't use anything to promote adhesion (a glass plate with glue or hairspray)  I just turn on the power, put in the memory card, select the model to print, go away to do other things or go to sleep, and come back to a 99.75% perfect print. (there's always some sort of clean up to do like removing supports or stuff like that.)

Parts just pop off with gentle persuasion from a spatula. Most times I can just grab the printed item and pull it off with only light pressure.

I included pics of some of the prints and parts. The xmas ornament was printed with 4 lines of brim and no supports...using a speed multiplier of 1.7  The 50mm to 30mm fan adapter required supports but came out incredibly well...again, at speed multiplier of 1.7.

I've modded the printer extensively... I've replaced the external power supply brick with an internal meanwell LRS-150 12 power supply and switch, I upgraded the cooling fan and added 2 cooling fans inside the case, I added a 10mm stabilizing arm to the Z axis gantry which acts as a fulcrum point on which I've mounted a counter-weighted Go Pro camera so I can do time lapse videos of prints without the weight of the camera affecting the print performance. I've added a filament guide and spool spacer and a proper knob on the jog dial.

Since Thanksgiving I've put over 300 hours of use on it and it has worked amazingly well.

I haven't had a single print fail due to the printer. I've had failures...but they turned out to be due to bad models (non manifold, flipped triangles, etc) which, once repaired with NETFAB or S3D, printed beautifully.

Initial review below:
_______________________________________________________________________

Heard it was a good unit. Thought it would take some of the work load off my Replicator 2, Creator X, and Rostock V2. First test print failed. Extruder failed to maintain temperature so the nozzel clogged and it air-printed the last 8% of the "cat" model.

Noticed 8C-10C swings in temperatures while printing. Can't determine if this is soft/hardware-related of if it is due to the completely unsatisfactory packaging it arrived in (The printer was shipped in its box, which was placed into a larger box with crumpled paper for shipping. The larger box didn't work well because Amazon never taped it shut. It arrived with ZERO trace of packaging tape on the larger box and FedEx stated I could place a claim but it's not their fault.

Will adjust settings in Cura to raise print temps to 200C versus the 195C the cat model is set up with.

Will adjust my review accordingly if things so better.
summary: Good printer, horrible shipping from Amazon

reviewText: Normally, when I'm provided a sample device for review, I like to use it for a while before writing something. Personally, I find the "I turned it on. The lights flashed and the house didn't burn down." type of reviews to be pretty worthless. So, after working with this for a month and a half, here are my impressions... 1. If you're used to using litmus paper to measure pH, this will give you a much more accurate and precise reading. That's assuming that you have an adequate sized sample. A couple of ml is sufficient for a test strip. You can get by with less, but 50 ml is about as low as I'd go with this guy. 2. The supplied buffer powders (pH 4.01 and 6.85 when mixed into 250 ml of distilled water) are appropriate for calibrating in the pH meter for hydroponic applications. (Normally a pH range of 5.5-6.2) If you're using this to measure saltwater aquariums (nominal pH of 7.6-8.4, depending on the type of fish), you'll need to pick up a 9.18 pH buffer to calibrate the alkaline range. Here's a link to a set of three: 3-pack pH Meter Buffer Solution Powder Set For Quick and Easy pH Calibration, Packet of 4.00, 6.86 and 9.18 Calibration does drift over time, so you'll need to recalbrate if high accuracy is needed. Interval between necessary calibrations will vary depending on usage and environmental factors. Personally, I was doing it once a week, but I don't have a need for particularly high accuracy. YMMV. 3. Usage couldn't be easier...you rinse the electrode with distilled water, turn the meter on, immerse the end in the solution you're testing, stir it a bit and wait for the reading to stabilize. It takes 15-30 seconds. Rinse the electrode off when finished and replace the cap to keep it from drying out. 4. Readings have a 0.01 pH resolution. Accuracy is +- 0.05 pH, so that last digit doesn't mean very much. If you need to differentiate a pH of 7.02 from 7.05, you need a lab instrument. On the other hand, this works perfectly for most real-world applications where extreme accuracy isn't needed...your crops aren't going to care if their roots are in a 6.02 vs. 6.03 nutrient solution. Summary...this is easy to use, accurate (enough) and inexpensive. If you're looking for a pH meter and don't want to spend for a laboratory version, this is a good way to go. Long story short, it works and works well. (Lastly...If you don't understand pH, here's a brief explanation. pH refers to the hydrogen ion concentration in a solution. Low numbers are acidic. A pH of 7.0 is neutral (pure water). As numbers go up, the solution is increasingly more alkaline. The overall range is from 0-14. Think Sulfuric Acid at one extreme and a concentrated Lye solution at the other. Just for reference, white vinegar (an acetic acid solution) is around 2.4. A baking soda solution is around 9. If you get one of these, you can play around, measure all kinds of stuff and thoroughly annoy your spouse, parents and/or kids. Trust me on that...)
summary: A pocket-sized pH Meter for every day use.

reviewText:
I really like this pH meter. It comes in a case sized perfectly to hold the meter plus a clearly written, easy to follow instruction manual. At first I wasn't sure where the batteries (referred to in the instructions) were because the flat black cap on the top that conceals the battery compartment is not labeled in any way to indicate that's where the batteries go and it required prying it off to get inside. I was a little nervous about doing it the first time because I wasn't sure if the lid was supposed to come off or not. The detachable battery compartment in the cap takes two replaceable button batteries, and it comes with them pre-installed. I really like that you take the battery-holding part completely out to install the batteries because those little suckers are really easy to drop and lose; you want to be able to install them on a tabletop.

Four packets of pH buffer powder are included, and while these don't fit neatly inside the case, they can be folded to fit. These are used for calibrating the tester. The process for determining the pH of a liquid is straightforward and pretty idiot-proof, and if you forget how to do it, you've got the instructions right there stowed in the case. I find this very helpful, unlike some testers I've seen with the instructions on a box that winds up being thrown away soon after the meter is taken out of it.

I've always had trouble understanding pH, and I suspect many people do. Gardeners have to be aware of pH to be able to grow plants well, but it's those who make wine who really have to understand pH. The 0 to 14 range of this meter is suitable for both. I suggest googling "pHiguring out pH"—geared toward winemakers—for a good explanation. This particular pen is designed for measuring water pH, but I'm sure there will be those who are going to want to stick it into their ferments.

I have just one suggestion for improving this product, and that is to add Semos' URL to the nice little translucent info card that is included with it. (It's lying on the top of the case in one of my photos.) That's the kind of card that's great to stick on the fridge or to keep in a wallet in case you need to troubleshoot or need more help. As it stands, it's a thank you card that you don't want to throw away because it's so nice, but then it doesn't have much of a purpose without further contact information included on it. I received this pH meter/pen tester at a discount in exchange for my honest review.
summary: Straightforward and easy to use.

reviewText:
We have a FlashForge 3d Printer Creator Pro and my daughter uses it all the time. But recently she went to her aunt and uncle's house for her vacation. She sent me an email for me to download and print it out for her in the 3d Printer. Because I don't have the skill she has, I had a hard time to take her product out of the printer. She gave me a knife but because it was too short, the handle was in the way. So I ordered the "Synkia 3D Print Removal Tool 3D Printer Pen Tool" and the "Precision Professional Grade 3D Print Removal Tool". I am glad that now I got both. They both have a long blade, so I don't have to worry the handle is in the way.
The Synkia one has very thin thickness of the blade, so it makes the blade go under the printed product easily. Then I have to worry about the pushing forward to take the printed product all the way off because the blade is so thin if the bottom of the printing product  sticking to the printer, the blade starts to bend and makes me worry the blade might snap and be broken.
The Precision tool doesn't bend (much thicker) as much as the other, so once the Synkia lifts up the printed product, I can use the precision tool to push all the way through. That's it.
If my review is helpful, please don't forget to click the "YES" button below. Thank you.
summary: This one works great with Synkia tool, which is much thinner than this one

reviewText:
This is my review of the Precision Professional Grade 3D Print Removal Tool from AMX3d.

So Im new to 3D printing having only had my unit for a few months and for the most part have been using whatever is handy to remove my prints (which isn't bad since most of my prints are still wonky as I get the hang of this). I mean we do everything we can to prep the surface with tape and get good adhesion between the filament and the bed that its going to stick in the end so getting it off (sometimes) has been problematic.

I saw this tool and thought its a much nice alternative than the spatula currently sitting next to my printer. The product arrived in a clear vinyl sleeve in a bubble mailer with no defects. The item meets the specifications set by the item description and I noted this wasn't full tang but its not like Im going to be chopping wood or this is some artisanal knife that I paid top dollar for. The handle is real wood and relatively nondescript. I micd the thickness of the blade and found it less than 1mm, its perfectly true and relatively hardy. I don't want to scratch it to test the hardness/material but it seems more than adequate for my needs.

I tested it today on a small cube I printed and it was overkill allowing the print to come right up with ease. I expect this will be more useful on a larger print but I don't have a need for one at the minute.

Its a great price and great tool if you're looking for easier print removals.

I received this at a discount for a fair and unbiased review.
summary: If you have a use for one this is a great one to get!

reviewText:
My husband and I have a "FlashForge 3d Printer Creator Pro, Metal Frame Structure, Acrylic Covers, Optimized Build Platform, Dual Extruder W/2 Spools, Works with ABS and PLA" to educate our children and ourselves. It turns out to be a great investment. Now our teenager daughter manages to have a small business using the printer. Anyway. my daughter is away and she asked me to print her products out and ship them.

She has been using the small kitchen knife to lift the printing products out from the printer. But with my lack of experience, I had a hard time of inserting the knife underneath them to lift up, so I bought the "Synkia 3D Print Removal Tool 3D Printer Pen Tool" hoping my task easier. To prevent the damage on the surface of the printer, my daughter put the painter's tapes on it and whenever I used the kitchen knife, I tore the tapes and had to replace them with a new layer of the blue tape stripes. I hoped the removal tool might not damage the tapes, so I wouldn't have to change them every time after removing the printed object. The dream didn't come true. Even with the new removal tool, I still change the damaged layers fo the blue tape, but definitely, the job got easier. The tool is very thin and long, so it is  easy to go under the printed objects. So much less tedious to do the job. But be careful not to break it while using it. Although that didn't happen to me, it is so thin and bending well I am very careful using it.

 [...]. Thank you.
summary: Very thin

reviewText:
How many people do you know who have overhead exposed steel beams and girders in their house or place of business?  Then these magnets are for them.  I read another reviewer's post, and I suppose that is how he is using these magnets, but I'll dare to say most people are not attaching their magnets horizontally on an overhead steel beam.  That being said, I did a few tests of my own.  I took a 25lb weight and tried it with one magnet.  Nope.  How about 2 magnets?  Nah.  3 magnets?  No.  4 magnets?  What do you think?  I then when down to a 10lb weight to see if it would stay on the side of a steel locker.  Well, the magnet slid almost 2 the floor, but it did keep the 10lb weight from tipping over and pulling off the strap, once the weight reached the floor.  I did guide the weight and strap with my hand, or the whole thing would have come off the locker.  See photos.  I understand physics a bit.  I get the difference between holding a vertical load and a horizontal load.  I will try it sometime with a horizontal load of 25lbs sometime when I figure out an application for using these hooks for a horizontal load--and I have a horizontal magnetic surface handy.  I suppose if someone had a shop light hooked to an engine hoist / cherry picker and the arm was pretty much horizontal, they could attach a work light in a horizontal fashion and hold it and the hooks in place with these magnets.  I'm not saying they don't work, I'm just saying the advertisement should be more clear about the way the magnets hold a load.  That being said, they are nice looking magnets, and I bought them to hold my keys and carabiners on the side of the fridge.  I also wanted to be able to move them around whenever I wanted.  I wanted these magnets to hold a little bit of weight, but not a huge amount, so they do that.  So, a little more truth in advertising would be nice.  I know it's the seller's job to sell magnets.  I will also do more careful research in the future with my important magnet purchases.  Buy them--just don't expect them to hold much more than your smaller items vertically--and certainly not 25lbs vertically.  I'll report back once I conclude my horizontal experiments, if I can ever think of something practical...

*** UPDATE 9/23/16  ****  I cleaned out a locker, and I TRIED to hang just a 10lb weight from the hook attached horizontally so the magnet had the entire surface of the shelf that is horizontal in the locker from which to draw.  Not even close to holding my 10lb weight.  So, I'm calling a "mythbusting" official BS on these magnets.  Not that anyone else needs to care, but it makes me feel better, lol.  I was skeptical originally that a magnetic surface about the size of a penny could hold 25lbs.  I knew this was something I had to see for myself.  Anyway...these magnets will do a nice job holding my keys on the side of the fridge.  That they will hold...
summary: I'm calling BS on this one -- nice magnets, but not quite as advertised -- not even close - 1 star

reviewText:
Wow. This stuff is incredible. I've actually been using it for a while, even before it was offered for a review.  It's hard to find locally, but you can.  What you have here is a layered product. Duct-Tape is made up of cloth, a thin layer of vinyl, and adhesive. To increase strength, any or all can be thicker. But all can be torn. 10X tape is a thick layer of glue, a checkerboard of interlocked plastic-like strips, and a thick layer of clear plastic on top.  The red/black checkerboard material looks and feels like the stuff used to make those cheap tarps - only thicker.  So picture that stuff with a layer of flexible plastic on one side, and thick/strong glue on the other.  That's why it includes a small disposable knife - the tape is impossible to tear.

I've included a couple of photos where I separated the various parts of the tape so you can see how it's made.  Pretty impressive. Unlike Duck-Tape, you can even nail or staple this, or make emergency straps and put a grommet through it.  I actually have a few rolls around the house.

It's also great when you need to really secure a box for storage or shipping - beats the heck out of traditional strapping tape.
summary: Lots of uses, incredibly strong, great grip. Use for repairs, packing - anything.

reviewText: I've used a lot of filament, and PLA has always been a hit and miss type affair.  I saw this on a facebook group being advertised as stronger than ABS, but prints smooth and glossy.  It really does.  Printing this on my Prusa Research MKII, this prints like a dream.  Perfect first layers, super-smooth surface finish, and zero hiccups in printing.  I've almost gone through the entire roll already.  I'm adding a picture of recent prints in this red, and the same material in the white.  While I've not drop-tested this material, the layers do create a better bond than I'm used to.

reviewText:

reviewText: I would say...if you are considering this unit but seeking another opinion....GO FOR IT! You will not be disappointed! The New Matter MOD-t is a great 1st 3d Printer. I would suggest anyone NEW to 3d printers start with something like this unit. It is super easy to use and you will be able to get a taste of what 3d printing is all about from this unit. It produces quality prints, it prints fast enough to satisfy, it is easy to maintain, and New Matter has excellent customer support for this product. For a seasoned 3d printing veteran or a very advanced user, they might be left wanting a little more, but if you do not know how to build a 3d printer from scratch and do not want to mess with constantly configuring/testing/leveling your printer....then no worries. Pros: - Covered printing bay to prevent young ones from sticking their hands in and burning themselves or messing up a print - All in one unit. This thing is ready to print directly from the New Matter Store as soon as you open - There is no need to learn about slicing/3d modeling programs initially. Just download any items from sites like thingiverse or pinshape and print all you want. - The New Matter Store (which you will want to print from if you are new to 3d printers) already has pre-designed items available to print. Just login to the New Matter Site....select an item you would like to print and hit print - WIFI functionality. The MOD-t does not have to be tethered to the PC by USB cable. You can send prints to your printer wireless over a wireless network - Excellent customer service - It is a unique design and is aesthetically pleasing to look at...so this thing would be fine to have in a home office without looking out of place - Auto alignment process with no worries about leveling due to the unique design. So, never worry about having to configure this printer or constantly fight to keep your settings right. Cons: - You might out grow the print area as it only prints around approx. 6x4x5 inches. - The warranty is only 90 days (but from what I can tell Customer Service is excellent and will most likely assist you even outside of the 90 day warranty) - It is a unique design (which was also a pro in my book) and it might be more challenging for a basic tinkerer to work on as opposed to some of the more popular 3d printers out there (such as the Prusa i3, which has a HUGE following and community to assist with anything really) - The included filament roll stand (which mounts to the back of the unit) is not big enough for most aftermarket filament rolls such as Hatchbox. The included stand is just barely off so you are better off purchasing or printing a stand to accommodate bigger rolls.
summary: The MOD-t is a VERY good choice for a beginner or someone with young children

reviewText:
Great quality and huge load handling.  I am using an MPCNC build  driven by a RAMPS 1.4.  The RAMPS board simply cannot handle large amperage loads (melts the connectors).  It is easy as pie to connect this to your RAMPS (or other bed output)  This works very simply, it is essentially a big solid state relay thats allowing your controller to use very little amperage, and offloading the true high amp load onto itself and the power supply.  This keeps things safe and allows full power to reach your bed heater.

NOTES:
1. Use the largest gauge stranded cable you can fit into the connectors for the bed and power supply connections.  Too small and the wires may overheat.
2. Use the absolute shortest length of wire you can get away with.  High amperage DC loads are best over short wire lengths.
3. Avoid unnecessary splices or connectors in line, thee add resistance and are possible overheating issues.
4. use 24 volt power and bed if possible to lower the overall amperage required.
5.  you must electrically insulate the board from touching any metal surfaces, it will short out!  of course you have a 3d printer so make a base or box!

For me this  board improved warm up times by at least 50% and much more stable.

I've noted some users have had to use different connections.  IN MY CASE... I connected like this: Please note this may differ from your unique setup....
summary: Great Device!  A must for long term reliability and safety. Diagram for RAMPS in Review

reviewText:
I have previously bought a different brand of these rated at 55A for some of my earlier printers.  But one of two of that product failed me a few months after install.  So I decided to try these out, purchasing two of them.  I replaced the bad one and installed one in my newest printer.  I generally only use these on the heat beds.  My printer's hot ends don't pull enough amperage to warrant their own.  So one is now installed on my Monoprice Maker Select Plus and the other on my JGAurora A5 printer.

First they are quite small and aren't using as large of a heat sink as the last brand I got that was rated at 55A.  This model is easier to find a spot for it in my printers than the other model I had bought which was almost two times larger.  This model is rated at 35A max.

The boards I got were silk screened on the board as BIQU version 1.3.  They use a High Amp NPQ030N06 FET power transistor.  (Isn't that 30 amps not 35 amps?)  They will accept either 12VDC or 24VDC as their input and output.  They are rated at 35 Amps but I wonder based on the chip rating of 30 amps.  Hmmm?

The connection to the motherboard and hot bed are listed as not being polarity required.  Of course, the 12VDC or 24VDC from your power supply IS polarity sensitive and must have the plus on the inside and the minus on the outside.  That's crucial as if you do it wrong, you can blow up your printer's power supply, hot bed, motherboard and this board all at once.  Hook it up right the first time.  Don't guess.  If your hot bed and motherboard has marked polarity settings, I advise you keep those polarities hooked up the same even if it doesn't supposedly matter.

You won't get any instructions with these.  So I found a pictorial diagram of the hookup that I attached to this review so you can see how to do it.

When you first install one of these, watch it like a hawk the first few days it's powered up.  These type of high amperage connections can smoke or catch fire if they malfunction badly.  Its doubtful that most printers power supplies will hit the maximum amperage of this chip.  To tell, take the printer's power supply wattage and divide by the voltage supplied.  That will give you a maximum amperage.  So a 350W 24VDC power supply would output up to 14.6 Amps max.  A 250W 12VDC power supply would output about 21 Amps max.  Almost all 24V printers and most 12V printers fall well under the board's rating.  But if you have significantly beefed up your heat bed and power supply, you may need to consider these maximums.  Of course when a power supply or hot bed shorts or badly malfunctions, they could cook these chips still.  Use caution as you can be at fire starting amperage here.

If you have a place you can mount this in front of it's own fan to cool it would be best.  These transistors can produce a good deal of heat, as noted by the large heat sink on the board.  They liberate this heat from the heat sink to the air around them.  So don't put one of these next to your motherboard or other sensitive electronics unless you have something dissipating that heat like a good fan.  You don't want that heat going over your motherboard.  Also you will need to elevate it using stand offs or thick insulative material off of any metal its attached to.  Be sure your chassis grounds are good.  Don't rely on double sided tape or 3D printed plastic to mount it.  When these get hot, they can melt adhesives and plastics like PLA.  Mount them with metal hardware only so they are grounded on your chassis.

Time will tell if these last.  The other brand lasted less than 5 months.  Hopefully these make it longer.  If they don't make it at least a year, I'll come back here and update this review and lower its rating.
summary: Working on 2 printers heat beds AOK.

reviewText:
This is a fairly good product I've used it for a multitude of repairs.  It's great for repairing toys especially.  I've glued my daughters 3" "Kristof" figure who's head broke off.  I've repairs a 3" "Flynn Rider" who had a leg/hip replacement which required a small steel pin and a touch of gorilla glue.  I've also used it on a 3" "Dragons" "Heather" figure who's body broke in two, she too required a steel pin and a drop or two of Gorilla Glue.

This glue doesnt work particularly well in areas which are continually subjected to moisture however I have successfully repaired my daughters watering can as well... Ill post additional photos as Im able to in updates.

TIP: when repairing small figures you will need a heavy/large paper clip, pair of "dyke" pliers which also have a wire cutting edge, a drill with a small drill bit almost the same size of the paper clip in circumference.

From there you will need to drill each direction creating a cavity in the area which you are repairing to allow the pre-measured/cut paper clip piece you've prepared for the "steel pin" used to give extra strength to the figure in the repaired area.  Insert a small drop in each piece of the toy to be rejoined and then run the part under water allowing the water to hit the drop of gorilla glue (water activates the glue), insert the piece of paper clip which you've pre-cut/pre-measured into the cavity which you've placed the drop of Gorilla Glue and connect both parts to be joined.

You will need a small clamp or a piece of strong packing tape to hold the joined pieces together while drying as the glue does EXPAND.  I like to take a wet paper towel after about 5-10 min and when I see the glue expanding outward pack it down with the wet paper towel crushing all the bubbles which start during the activation of the glue as it dries so ther is a smoother area after drying.

I'll at times take a matching sharpie and after the glued area is dry, I will color the glued area with the sharpie to mask the area which was repaired.  SEE MY PHOTOS OF A RECENT REPAIR DONE EARLIER TODAY.

I've also used this glue on floor tiles in a commercial building as a quick repair alternative to adhesive/mortar or mastic etc.  see photos, they aren't pretty until the glue is colored with a black/brown sharpie, then they look ok.

The tile was shattered into many pieces and was loose until I cleaned the area, added some water for activation and then the glue, using a wet paper towel patting it down as it raised and dried.  It was quick and able to be walked on in less than an hour.  Threw a mat over it and It worked ok for a quick fix.

This glue isn't perfect as it doesn't hold well for all repairs.  However it's the best I've used and there are times which a stronger commercial adhesive is best for certain applications.  Good luck with whatever your repairing, take your time these things take patients.

NOTE: If you appreciated this review please give it a thumbs up/like your helping me to continue to give honest/unbiased insight into products Ive used and you may have questions about. Interested in a product but don't know enough about it and would like it reviewed? Please let me know and I'll see what I can do... Thank you
summary: Holds well for Toy Repairs.  SEE PHOTOS AND TIPS within this review.

reviewText:
I purchased this set a few months ago, to complement the larger blades that came with my Fein MM 350Q, in the hopes that it would come in handy some day (it did, big time).

I did some tests to learn how best to use the various attachments and immediately ran into a problem with blade slippage that some others have reported. It was nothing too severe, but I could see that sometimes a securely fastened blade would shift slightly during a cut. I was able to fix the problem with a few simple steps.

I noticed the blade holder had some burrs, so I sanded these off to increase the contact area and to roughen the mating surfaces (using 180 grit sandpaper). I also sanded the contact area of each blade on both sides. Then I cleaned everything with alcohol, including the screws and threads (which appeared to have some grease on them). Since then I haven't had any more slipping of blades and am very satisfied with this set.

I found the cutting blades worked very well in both hard and soft woods, easily as well as the larger regular sized blades. The kerf is quite small, perhaps less than the regular sized blades (I did not measure, so cant say for certain).

I also did some measurements, by tracing around the holder and blades on a piece of graph paper - see the accompanying photo.
1. the blades are held in place by two M4 screws, set about 3/8 apart.
2. all attachments are either 1-5/16 or 1-11/16 long.
3. attachments are 13/16 wide at the connection point
4. cutting blade width is about 3/8 wide on the cutting end.

I used the short wood cutting blade recently to replace a lever operator in a 20+ year old wood window. The mechanism was built-in to the window, and for awhile I thought I would have to completely remove the window and destroy some trim pieces in order to get to the lever. Then I thought of my multimaster and decided I had nothing to loose. I was able to surgically cut out two trim pieces, install the new lever, then simply re-install the trim as the saw kerf was so thin (all with the window in-place on a second story bedroom). Its not 100% perfect, but its close enough that only careful inspect would reveal the cuts. The hours saved on this single job easily pay for the small cost of this set.
summary: Friction is your friend

reviewText:
Yep, it's great. The easiest, fastest high-gloss wood finish I know of. Application doesn't require any special care (although you want to seal pores with dewaxed shellac first) and compared to polyurethanes, the result is almost always defect-free. Sanding between coats is not necessary, but if you need to fix any issues, it can be attempted within 30-60 minutes without taking any risk. After the final coat, the project can be handled within 30-60 minutes, too.

Compare this to having to wait between 6 and 72 hours when using most polyurethanes.

The end result typically exhibits high gloss without any special buffing, but if necessary, it polishes and buffs very easily - more so than most poly coats.

There are just two trade-offs. First of all, the lacquer is solvent-based and uses some fairly aggressive and harmful solvents, so it stinks to high heaven; work outside. Secondly, nitrocellulose finish, although fairly tough, is more vulnerable to abrasion, alcohol, acids, and water than polyurethane or epoxies. In practical terms, this means that it's a good choice for cabinets, boxes, and perhaps some lightly-used salad or fruit bowls. It is a markedly poor choice for kitchen tables, kitchen countertops, and other high-use surfaces.

I attached a photo of a pencil case finished with this lacquer.
summary: A wonderful alternative to finicky polyurethanes
