reviewText:
Review for the Hoover Flair Stickvac Exhaust Filter (a.k.a. secondary or outer filter), Hoover part # 59136022

This filter is a perfect fit, appears to be genuine Hoover part (although there is no official Hoover logo on the package). It includes the custom slits in the filter that fit the Flair Hoover SticVac housing perfectly. I include photos of the filter, housing, and vacuum.

Keep in mind you do NOT have to have replace this filter when it gets dirty. It is the type that can be hand washed, dried, and put back in. But because I have severe allergies I chose to get a new one. People with a little extra know how would also be able to make their own exhaust filter for this vacuum out of similar materials found at many DIY home stores or hardware stores.

~ ~ ~

Additional Information For Curious Consumers:

I purchased this for my Hoover Flair Bagless Stick Vacuum, Model # S2220 although the ad states it also fits Hoover Flair Stick Vac Models: S2201 and S2200.
This vacuum takes three filters; one primary inner filter, and two secondary outer filters (this exhaust filter):

Primary (inner) Filter # 59136-055 or 59136055
Secondary (outer) Filter # 59136-022 or 59136022 (the filter I am reviewing)

I also recommend the Hoover Flair Stick vacuum. Average price is about $60 right now. Its nearly as powerful as my regular Hoover WindTunnel. Its much lighter, maneuvers much easier, gets into tighter spaces (and under the couch), is easier to store, and works on both rugs and hard floors just as well. Its not as good as a Shark, but its the perfect vacuum for my everyday jobs, especially when Im too tired to haul out the big vacuum.

~ ~ ~

This ad says it's Hoover brand with UPC # 700953603166, but most genuine Hoover parts UPC numbers usually start with 073502 - the first numbers are the ones that identify the company in any UPC number. My package did not come with UPC numbers, it only came with a UPC bar code and I of course do not have a scanner to check to see what the number actually is. All of this may not matter to the average customer, but I include it as an FYI for those who want to know. Either way, the filter seems to match the one that came with my vacuum exactly.

But I'm not thrilled that the ad was not clear about having only one filter per package, but I should have known better and read more carefully. My vacuum uses an exhaust filter on each side. I'll be washing the other filter, since there are two in my vacuum, one on each side.

I think this item is a little over priced here (at just under $5 for one exhaust filter) but I choose to buy it at this price so I didn't have to waste money on gas to buy one locally (the shop where they sell them is about two gallons of gas away from my home) so my unhappiness with the price is not reflected in my star rating of the product quality. I only mention it because I feel it's important for consumers to be able to make informed decisions.

Knowing which part to get is sometimes hard, if you don't have your manual because the model number of the vacuum isn't always easy to find. Sometimes you have to look on the bottom of the vacuum. That's what I had to do, to be sure of my vacuum's model number so I knew which filters to buy. I include Hoover contact information for those who may need it because they have questions about which parts to get:

TTI Floor Care North America
7005 Cochran Road
Glenwillow, OH 44139

(800) 944-9200
Monday - Friday 8:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. EST
summary: Perfect Fit. Well worth the price if you can't get it locally.

reviewText:
I generally agree with the other positive reviewers here. But note that the sensors are inside the unit, so response time is slow. Compare to the EL-USB-TP-LCD which uses an external thermistor probe (temperature only, no humidity measurement). Attached pictures show temperatures recorded at a gas forced-air furnace register, using the reviewed unit and the external thermistor one. Bottom line, if you want to see fairly rapid temperature changes, and you don't need humidity measurement, consider the external thermistor model instead.

Edit: The pictures don't show well, if at all. Statistics from the graphing program also tell the story: This unit measured

maximum 94F, minimum 80F, average 87F.

The thermistor unit measured

maximum 107.2F, minimum 69.4F, average 84.3F.

So the fluctuations from the furnace's 5 cycles/hour were considerably damped down in this unit's measurements.
summary: Good unit, but response time is slow

reviewText:
Upon the suggestion of an experienced plumber, I ordered the 0000 super fine grit Steel Wool to clean and polish copper pipe. It enables me to remove the imperfections from the pipe without scratching up the copper. I use it with vinegar and salt to clean the really dirty pipe and fittings as well as Brasso to perform the final cleaning and polish.

I also used it to successfully clean my $400 Ruffoni copper pan. It was extremely tarnished from years of use and I had actually retired it for quite some time as I had been hestitant on using anything to clean it due to concern of ruining it.
summary: Perfect for Cleaning & Polishing Copper!

reviewText:
I was looking for an alternative to soldering or torch welding in order to bind copper pipe for non-potable purposes and figured I would give this a try. (I seriously doubt this is safe on pipe used for water.) I've had positive experiences with Gorilla brand products in the past including the silicone epoxy and wood glue.

The instructions state to mix the resin and binder together for 20 seconds and then use within 5 minutes as it will be the most effective prior to that. It suggests to use the plastic insert packaging to use as a mixer palate. There's a little black plastic tab that's suppose to be used to close the syringe apparatus closed.

This stuff dried out to the point of non-usable well before the 5-minute timeframe. However, I suspect that this figure is infeluenced by environmental conditions. I live in Arizona and since it's non-monsoon summer season, the humidity is very low. (For example, paint dries incredibly quick!) I had to adapt by working fast in order to beat the drying time.

I didn't touch my project for a couple of days. After that, I attempted to pry it apart and was unable to do so. Everything is tight and appears to be bonded permanently!

Good news: It works on copper pipe tubing and fittings!
Bad news: It's messy and dries quickly in a dry/hot climate.
summary: Binds Copper Pipe!

reviewText:
I purchased a ready to assemble table that was missing a couple of threaded inserts.  After speaking with the manufacturers warranty dept. I decided to go the DIY route and fix it myself.  I had installed this style of threaded inserts once before, manually using a screw driver.  It took a little muscle to get them in and all of the inserts ended up cockeyed.  For this job I wanted everything to be perfect.  The insert tool add-on looked interesting.  I could see it working well for manual installation (by hand or with a hand drill) with smaller inserts and softer woods.  But I needed to install the 5/16 insert into hardwood without any mistakes, so I went with the bolt, two nuts, and a drill press method.  This method was perfect.  The drill press kept the insert straight and all I had to do was wrench them in, the threads did the rest.  I think using the add-on tool along with a drill press for alignment would've also worked.

Other thoughts.  The threaded insert for a 5/16 screw needed 1/2 pilot hole, because of the extremely thick walls.  I would've preferred a thinner walled non-slotted insert.
summary: Works Great with the Right Tools

I've also used it on a 3" "Dragons" "Heather" figure who's body broke in two, she too required a steel pin and a drop or two of Gorilla Glue.

This glue doesnt work particularly well in areas which are continually subjected to moisture however I have successfully repaired my daughters watering can as well... Ill post additional photos as Im able to in updates.

TIP: when repairing small figures you will need a heavy/large paper clip, pair of "dyke" pliers which also have a wire cutting edge, a drill with a small drill bit almost the same size of the paper clip in circumference.

From there you will need to drill each direction creating a cavity in the area which you are repairing to allow the pre-measured/cut paper clip piece you've prepared for the "steel pin" used to give extra strength to the figure in the repaired area.  Insert a small drop in each piece of the toy to be rejoined and then run the part under water allowing the water to hit the drop of gorilla glue (water activates the glue), insert the piece of paper clip which you've pre-cut/pre-measured into the cavity which you've placed the drop of Gorilla Glue and connect both parts to be joined.

You will need a small clamp or a piece of strong packing tape to hold the joined pieces together while drying as the glue does EXPAND.  I like to take a wet paper towel after about 5-10 min and when I see the glue expanding outward pack it down with the wet paper towel crushing all the bubbles which start during the activation of the glue as it dries so ther is a smoother area after drying.

I'll at times take a matching sharpie and after the glued area is dry, I will color the glued area with the sharpie to mask the area which was repaired.  SEE MY PHOTOS OF A RECENT REPAIR DONE EARLIER TODAY.

I've also used this glue on floor tiles in a commercial building as a quick repair alternative to adhesive/mortar or mastic etc.  see photos, they aren't pretty until the glue is colored with a black/brown sharpie, then they look ok.

The tile was shattered into many pieces and was loose until I cleaned the area, added some water for activation and then the glue, using a wet paper towel patting it down as it raised and dried.  It was quick and able to be walked on in less than an hour.  Threw a mat over it and It worked ok for a quick fix.

This glue isn't perfect as it doesn't hold well for all repairs.  However it's the best I've used and there are times which a stronger commercial adhesive is best for certain applications.  Good luck with whatever your repairing, take your time these things take patients.

NOTE: If you appreciated this review please give it a thumbs up/like your helping me to continue to give honest/unbiased insight into products Ive used and you may have questions about. Interested in a product but don't know enough about it and would like it reviewed? Please let me know and I'll see what I can do... Thank you
summary: Holds well for Toy Repairs.  SEE PHOTOS AND TIPS within this review.

reviewText:

It operates very quietly, much more so then any shop vac I have ever used thanks to the muffler on the output. The suction is great, it picks up debris with ease. The hose is very long, which provides a good range of motion before the vacuum needs to be moved. It moves easily on the two large back wheels and two front casters. The cord is also long; between the cord and the hose it can easily reach everywhere in a 14'x14' room plugged into a single outlet.
One thing I am really impressed with is the lightweight nature of it. It is much lighter then other shop vacs of a similar size that I have used previously. The construction is strong despite its lightweight nature.
The accessories supplied with it are the standard set you get with any shop vac, nothing exciting there. The pouch it comes with fits everything in it.
My main reason for selecting this particular model was it had excellent reviews, both from professional reviewing sources and actual consumers. I am quite happy with it, it has fulfilled all my expectations.

reviewText:
Excellent bearing for spinners. Bearing spins for about 20 seconds with nothing attached to it. If you attach a weighted spinner around it, you should be able to do 2-8 minutes with it (depends on the design of the spinner [wind drag] and its weight). I've had previously used cheap 608 metal bearings and this ceramic bearing is a significant improvement. Yes, you read that correct, I've gotten 8 1/2 minute spin times from this bearing with a spinner that has a decent amount of heft to it.

Note: Do NOT add lubrication, even thin oils will slow it. The ceramic bearings don't need lube.

Also, before you pass judgement on the bearing, try breaking it in first by installing a spinner on it and then positioning it so a fan blows across the spinner (to keep it spinning). Let it spin overnight and test it in the morning. You might want to flip the spinner over and spin in the other direction too.
summary: Excellent bearing for spinners

reviewText:
If you are buying these for an air compressor in your workshop, or for outdoor use, this review probably won't matter at all. I purchased these for industrial sewing machines, and I will see/touch these sheaves on a regular basis.

I've ordered two of these, and both arrived the same way: in boxes that looked like they were very old, left out in the sun, dirty, and had been re-taped or re-packaged several times. One arrived clearly previously used and scratched up, another looked like it had just been scratched in transit.

While these are heavy nice cast iron, I've noticed the machining is not very precise at all; one of them has a machined surface that only exists on half the face of the pulley, the other half is straight out of the casting. I have no idea how or why that pulley made it past their QC. Also, the AK61 I ordered arrived with a keyway and double grub-screws, which was not what was pictured/described, but will work for my application..

If I had ordered one of the $50-60 versions of these pulleys, I would be upset and this would be a 1 star review.

But for the bigger sizes that are only $15-30, these are an amazing value.
summary: Be prepared to get a used sheave/pulley, but still a great value

reviewText:
I am getting ready to experiment with building my own BLDC motor so I thought a magnetic field viewer would be a great idea.

My suggestion is - don't cheap out.  The idea that this is the size of a credit card is neat, but given the percentage of the viewer material in comparison to the whole, makes this nearly useless.

This is my first magnetic viewer so I wouldn't know exactly what to expect but after fussing with this part that arrived, it seems I wasted more time trying to figure out what I've done wrong as apposed to being productive with a better product.  As another reviewer mentioned, the card is too thick.  It has 2 layers of laminate (one of which would not affect the magnetic field), I assume a printed instruction sheet is just printer paper plus the magnetic material itself.  The first image attached shows a small N45 neodymium magnet and its field.  All the bright colored particles are NOT the magnetic material.  Under a microscope, they seem to be balls of gel.  I don't know how to make this type of material but I believe these balls of gel interfere with the "image" you see,  These balls don't move or change color.  What you see is what you get.  There is also a "speck" of lint or something in the middle of the image.  As another review mentioned, this speck is under the laminate, so it's a permanent fixture in this viewer.  The scratches may or may not have been there upon arrival, but I just got this card today and I don't think I used it that much.  The second photo shows how the product was not even laminated "squarely".  Everything is misaligned and even though it's not a BIG deal, it is bothersome that someone would pay any kind of money for a product that this company didn't care about the assembly or QC of a product before leaving their doors.  Regarding the third photo, I would commend this company by stamping the Made In U.S.A emblem, which makes me happy, but this label nearly kept the laminate from encapsulating the whole thing.  I can imagine this will de-laminate itself in a few weeks with regular use.

I too own my own business and I will also say that my products would never leave my doors with this level of quality.
summary: Not as useful or as expected

reviewText: Nicely constructed stainless hinge.  I ended up cutting it to fit my application.  Instead of cutting one end, I needed the screw holes closer to the edge and had to cut both ends.  I just cut between the hinge knuckles using a cutoff wheel and didn't have a problem. Normally you'd want to cut the knuckle where it's marked by a dot or punch pinch. This hinge has those marks but were not in the spots I needed.  I cut it where needed and it still works fine, the pin is still mounted firmly and I had no problems whatsoever.  I used #6 sized screws but #8 would work too.
summary: Nice Hinge, well made.

Edit: Found another use! I put two small half inch by half inch square on my phones battery backing on either side of my camera. Why you might ask? Well when you walk around at night staring at your phone, You face glows but not much. This way if a car is coming while I walk at night they will get a quick dazzle. So if I'm not paying attention drunk outside at a bar in college town, I have a better chance of not getting run down.

reviewText:
I don't do a lot of metal repair, but I do a huge amount of wood-related repairs at home. For the right kind of tasks, this is an awesome new tool! Other reviewers have already written about the metal rust removal capabilities of this flap disc. I wanted to see how it would work doing surface restoration of my redwood fence. The answer is, it is amazingly great! You can see the photos posted here. The slight angling of the abrasive surface allows you to easily sand flat surfaces. You simply hold the grinder at a slight angle while carefully gliding it along the surface. You have to keep the grinder moving along or it will eat up the board, especially something as soft as the redwood I was working on.

The flaps seem to be long wearing, although redwood may not be a big test of that. It seems like one wheel should be able to take care of two or three fencing sections or more. Don't forget to wear a dust mask as well as goggles and hearing protection. This thing will kick up a lot of dust which you need to avoid inhaling since redwood and others are somewhat toxic if inhaled..

I would buy these again and without hesitation.
summary: Wonderful for heavy wood resurfacing!

reviewText: It works as described. It's sensitive to ambient light. It's able to recognize laser diode lights. Pros: * Easy to wire up * It's sensitive to light (obviously) Cons: * None Here's a recent project I am working on (see video and screenshots below). It's a laser trip alarm system. All of these components are available from Amazon. Laser part: * Laser diode (GeeBat 10pcs Mini Laser Dot Diode Module) * 4 x AA batteries (Eneloop) * Battery Holder (WAYLLSHINE 6 Pcs 4 x 1.5V (6V) AA Battery Spring Clip) * Wires Reader part: * Rfid reader (Gowoops RFID Kit - Mifare RC522 RF IC Card Sensor Module) * Photoresistor (SUNKEE 20pcs Photo Light Sensitive Resistor Photoresistor) * Piezo Buzzer (Piezo Buzzer - PS1240 from Adafruit. Not from Amazon) * NodeMcu (HiLetgo New Version NodeMCU LUA) * Breadboard (Elegoo 3pcs MB-102 Breadboard) Photoresistor Tip: In order for the photoresistor to act as in input in my NodeMcu microcontroller, here's what I did 1. Wire one leg to a 3V/5V rail 2. Wire another leg to the ANALOG input of the microcontroller. It needs to be an ANALOG input! 3. Wire up one leg of a 10K ohm resistor to the GROUND rail 4. Wire up the other leg of the resistor to the leg of the photoresistor that's connected to the ANALOG input (see my screenshots)
summary: It works with my laser diode!

reviewText:
The delivered Item was not as described.
The seller promised a product Provided at the  Image as:
Dual Scale Borosilicate Beaker, 250ml
Brand: Lab Zap
Labeled Borosilicate, 250 ml and market up to 250ml.
The delivered Item is different:
Brand: BOMEX
Labeled 250ml, but market up to 200ml
Not labeled as Borosilicate.
Borosilicate glass is manufactured from two main components, silica and boron oxide.  The mixture of these two components create glass that is resistant to thermal shock due to the very low coefficient of thermal expansion.  Borosilicate glass can withstand severe temperature changes without breaking.  It also has a high resistance to chemicals.
Pyrex marketed by Corning Glass has become a synonym for borosilicate glass.  Kimble also sells its own line of Kimax brand borosilicate glass products.
Brand: Zap Lab  borosilicate Beaker is labeled as Borosilicate. This beaker is made from quality borosilicate glass. As an import, it is less expensive than Corning-made Pyrex. We have noticed variation of wall thickness and make a suggestive comment that Pyrex uniformity might be preferable if using higher heat.
This is the Beaker the seller listed, but delivered a totally different one.
Brand: BOMEX doesn't Label Borosilicate, and we do not know for sure what material it is.
summary: The delivered Item was not as described.

We have a shop in the horse barn that is sort of a dumping ground for stuff that needs repairs or is in the process of being repaired. Currently there's a pressure washer and a mower waiting on parts. My handy man was gone when the mower died, so my husband put one of "Do not use" tags on the pull string. It's easy to see and he was able to write the date and part needed on the tag.

I'm using one of the included locks on our exterior cable and phone line box. We've had a squirrel trying to get in that box twice now for some reason. He got it open both times and I really don't want to lose our tv, phone or Internet because a tree rat is nesting in the wires. The lock fits properly in the holes on the box. I like that the key won't come out while the lock is open - helps prevent loss of the key.

My one star deduction is because the rubber coating over the padlock arch is just peeling away in chunks from one insertion. It won't take long at this rate for the lock to start rusting. The storage box is easy to install and access - we put it on the wall of the shop and added some extra padlocks to it.

reviewText: I am very impressed with this 10x10mm aluminum T slot framing set. Its very versatile and relatively easy to use. Some fiddling around is required until you get the hang of it. But thats to be expected when working with beams and bolts that small. Thats nothing against MakerBeam, just something you have to get used too. In the week or so i have had it, i have made 2 things already with plenty of beams to spare for more projects. I have added pictures of a solder/wire rack i made and a rolling cutter for film and photographic paper. The few things i can ding MakerBeam on are things that really should have been included in the starter kit. I have placed links to the items that a new user should definitely pick up, but again they really should have been included. Makerbeam M3 Bolts with Square Head, 12mm 100 pcs and 25mm 25pcs Makerbeam Openbeam T Bracket (Pack of 12pcs) MakerBeam straight brackets (pack of 12) MakerBeam 25 pieces T-slot nuts inc screws MakerBeam Corner Cube Black 12 pcs MakerBeam Vinyl End Caps, Black ( Pack of 8) Also the case is cute but not really practical. Once you unwrap all of the beams, you need a degree in Tetris to get it close again. Im pretty good at Tetris and i couldn't do it so everything went into a plastic box. Much better way to store it if you ask me. A few things to note, the ends of the beams are a little sharp. They look slightly de-burred but not enough to take the sharp edge off. They really should have included the vinyl end caps or the corner cubes. Its a small thing but it would have been nice. The ends of the beams are threaded which is great. But there is no real way to get them to align. See the picks of the solder/wire holder. None of the horizontal arms could possibly line up with the vertical ones. Its more of a good place to attach things too but not really useful if you need the beams to line up. I didn't so its not a problem. They also don't include an Allen key for the 3mm bolts. But if you buy the T nuts or the bearing kit, its included. The MakerBeam Bearings, bolts and (self locking) nuts (pack of 10) is a pretty neat way to add rolling capability to the Beams. It works really well and I'm happy with it on my rolling cutter design. Another thing to note is that MakerBeam offers the beams separately here on Amazon. I found sizes up to MakerBeam 1500mm beam black anodised (pack of 2), which is pretty neat! I can think of a few projects that could use beams that size. Plus the price is pretty good for those. All in all i am very happy with the purchase. While the kit is pretty expensive, i cant think of another way to accomplish what i need without it.
summary: Its very versatile and relatively easy to use

I ordered a smoke-colored plastic piece from an enterprising person who's marketing an external bezel solution.

reviewText:
After a long time without test equipment, I decided to furnish my basement workshop with some basic electronics gear and have been looking for a decent oscilloscope to handle the occasional need.  This seems to do the trick for me! It came packaged very well.  I let it run for a few hours out of the box to give it a quick 'burn in' before using it.  I've only had this a week, but so far so good!
  I received the machine, did a quick probe calibration (the mini screwdrivers are included with each probe - thank you) and used the built-in function generator to go over the features.  The controls seemed logical and intuitive (however I began to use scopes in the 70's).  Triggering is always an issue, but I had no problems with this device.  The 50% trigger auto-set is nice, and the controls feel fine to me. The screen is great - 7" - and the resolution is adequate to read everything.  It has a built in help function to explain each control (at a surface level).
  Other reviewers complained about the probes, but I thought they were fine for my applications.  Each probe comes with various colored rings to match both ends so you can figure out in the tangle of wires that traditionally occurs which end goes to which channel at a glance - nice touch.
  The scope 'boots up' fairly quickly in a few seconds.  I was impressed with the math functions including FFT in its many variants along with other math functions.  You can also store a waveform as a reference and then use that to compare with the 2 channels of input - nice.  Since it is a digital storage oscilloscope, there are features and drawbacks due to the design of that instrument which I won't discuss here, but this design seems to be well 'executed'.  As most of my work is well below 100mhz, the limitations of this (or ANY) instrument approaching that frequency should not be apparent.  Always buy an instrument well beyond your area of interest so it is working well in it's sweet spot for your measurements.

CONS:  The manual is in 'pigeon English' and even at that it is very brief, not giving anything beyond the basic information.  This could be much improved, and could include application examples for people not familiar with using these devices.  Also the power button is on the top, which makes it difficult if it is in a shelf (as in my setup) to get to the power.  It asks the language each power up, but that takes a second to set with 1 button.

SUMMARY:  Very affordable 100mhz scope with some nice features - great for general hobbyist use!
summary: Decent oscilliscope at very affordable price

reviewText:
The cart is very strong and sturdy.

One complaint:  Made well except for one area of the cart; that is the 'squared punch outs' in the bottom of the cart which are supposed to accept the 'squared' portion on the underside of the Carriage bolts.  That squared punch out is way too large to accept the bolts.  The bolts will only spin when attempting to tighten the nut.  I had to insert the bolt upwards- through the caster wheel flange into the bottom of the cart.  And although, this works, its bad for a few reasons:  namely, the bolts protruding will punch holes in boxes and critical equipment hauled in the bottom of the cart. Secondly, its just a bad design and not how it's supposed to be done.

Other than that, its a great cart.  Love it!
summary: 1 design complaint- flaw

reviewText:
Vacuuming day isn't something you look forward to mainly because dragging around a big tank that keeps pulling your hose back is tiresome. This solves that problem, strap it on your back and carry it with you! You never have to worry about that tank running into anything and getting stuck. Your hands are free to manage the hose, to do the work!

The vac itself is not that heavy, my wife has no problem with this. You need to just make sure you have the straps and belt on correctly.

Now the only issues are the cord - can't wait for the battery pack version. And you also need to be careful turning in tight areas not to bang something. These aren't flaws of the machine itself that's just learning how to use it. With a detached machine that you lug around you'd bang into everything!

This has great power, easy to change bags and plenty of cord - 50 feet! We can get a lot done without pulling the cord out of the socket. Amazingly being right there on your back it is relatively quiet compared to our huge pull alongs. Plenty of attachments - I've included the what's in the box below for convenience.

Overall, we love this thing! We look forward to vacuum day knowing we can easily get it done in less time and effort!

What's In The Box
1. Hose: Flexible hose for better maneuverability.
2. Intercept Micro Filter Bag (2): Paper filter bag to capture dust.
3. 50' extension cord: Plug in once and vacuum entire area.
4. Mesh Storage Bag: Conveniently store all the accessory tools.
5. Crevice Tool (17-inch): Perfect for deep cleaning around corners and tight spaces.
6. Claw Nozzle: An all-purpose tool ideal for upholstery or carpets.
7. Soft Dusting Brush: Gently removes dust and allergens off of blinds, lampshades etc.
8. Hard Floor Tool: Dust pick up on hard surfaces, including hardwood floors, linoleum and tiles
9. Turbo Brush: Easily glides on carpet removing dust, allergens and pet hair
10. Telescoping Wand: Adjustable height for maximum comfort.
summary: No more dragging around that tank

reviewText: The laser is packed well very fun to burn stuff the beam is bright enough to see a few miles away. I bought it with a heatsink and thermal paste powered off a nine volt battery eats them fast but they are low enough not to damage the diode.

reviewText:
Like some have reported, this piece can be bent. Mine was bent very slightly, one with a straight edge held down on one side, the there was a ~1mm  gap on the other side. this isn't a huge deal breaker.
The real reason I removed a star was because of the deep scratch going from one side to the other and the many small scratches along one of the sides.
There is film protecting one side of the sheet and even the protected side has some scratches. Not sure why they didn't protect both sides.

These issues aren't deal breakers for me but it could be for others.
summary: Expect scratches

reviewText:
I bought three packs of these (sixty chips total). I've tested forty (40) so far and of that bunch, eight (8) are dead/unusable, eleven (11) have significant distortion or don't run down to 4V as a LM386-N1 is supposed to do, and the remaining 21 work.  Even within the "working" group there's noticeable variation chip-to-chip in distortion. If I get some time I might quantify the distortion of the meh-level chips, especially compared to a genuine LM386-N1.

These are clearly cast-off chips that didn't meet spec and got resold/rebranded, or counterfeits, or who knows what.  I kinda-sorta figured this would be the case given the price point on these...see photo included comparing a representative sample one from my lot of sixty that I got mailed to an actual one bought from a legitimate vendor.  The chip is not an National Semiconductor chip. It doesn't follow their standardized labeling conventions at all, and the swirly N symbol they use is clearly a fake and intended to mislead.  This is like when you buy those fake Sharpie markers that actually spell out "Shoupie" (which I love by the way). I mean whatever.  I find this sorta fun, but I want this to be known to folks buying these since some of the answers up above say these are "genuine TI chips" or something like that....this is closer to buying a "genuine Coach bag" on the side-streets of New York for 1/10th the cost...nobody really believes that's what they're getting/selling.

If you're using these for a class or need to know exactly what you're getting (since they can be useful for that...), maybe just bite the bullet from a more official dealer like digikey...they will cost more (probably $18.00 for twenty instead of the 8 bucks here)...but with the "good" yields I'm seeing in what I bought here (about 50% of my chips are not good) I might as well have just done that from a price-per-chip angle (esp once you factor in twenty minutes to test, etc...).

If you're buying just to experiment and mess around with for a junk drawer, this is probably a fine price-point and quality level and you'll have an adventure figuring out what you have.
summary: Fakes and low yield, but not necessarily bad at this price

reviewText: First used an item like this at a U-haul center. Now that I own one it makes me wonder how I went so long without one!!!! Assembly was a snap and took less than 10 minutes. It's very sturdy and easily handles all my trailers (open utility 6x12, open utility 4x8, enclosed box trailer 5x8). I like the oversized wheels and the fact that the third center wheel basically spins 360 degrees on itself makes turning and maneuvering my trailers a cinch:-) It would be nice however if it could somehow collapse on itself for storage purposes, but for me, it's not a deal breaker. I've included a short video of me using it one-handed and moving my 12-footer from one truck to another (got pretty close to bumping into the second truck lol). The adjustability of the center ball post makes using this dolly with a variety of trailers easy and only takes a few seconds to adjust for height differences. It really is nice being able to move a trailer, semi loaded or unloaded without putting in a lot of back breaking effort. Physics and leverage is what this tool delivers and as I stated earlier; I'm very happy I finally bought one. Extremely satisfied and I suspect I should get years and years of use out of it.
summary: First used an item like this at a U-haul center

reviewText:
Defective. Where the ribbon from the LCD meets the PCB, it was misaligned and had several solder bridges. The metal bezel that holds the LCD glass down was bent up and didn't seem to be tight.

Amazon, don't remove this - this next part is NOT part of packaging feedback. Electrostatic Discharge (ESD) protection is a part of the item itself.

Additionally, this had no ESD protection bag. It should have been in a silvery grey static shielding bag, instead it was wrapped in staticky foam then wrapped in packing tape. Shame on you.
summary: Misaligned ribbon cable, solder bridges, no ESD protection. Bezel bent and loose.

reviewText: Very bright and good quality. Nice white light. Light is concentrated out of the top but still puts a good amount of light to the sides. I used them for my sons Master Chief helmet and they work great! 4 of them are almost too bright to look directly at when your close up.

reviewText:
Apparently, Tapecase can't cut/convert a roll of tape correctly. Or someone was hammered at the die cutter that day, either way, this is getting real annoying considering the typical high-cost of these products.

As measured with a caliper, roll measured .3795 inches on top, which is close enough to what was ordered, HOWEVER the bottom measured .5155 inches with a roll that goes from correct width, to nearly 75% above the correct size. WTF? Can we please learn to cut correctly and stop pawning off your B-stock to Amazon and wasting our time? This one is a first, but not the first time I've seen garbage come out of Tapecase converting 3M stock on Amazon.

reviewText: Great material! I printed it at 205 degrees. I typically use Hatchbox but it was not available. I print with it at 195. So I had to use a higher temperature but loved the color and final print quality. There wasn't any issues with clogs or size inconsistencies. Perfect material. reviewText: The dimensions given in the product description are false, plain and simple. The outer diameter, including sheath, is 1.6mm. The conductor diameter is 0.3mm, which means it's 28AWG wire. If you're working with some project that requires VERY light current, fine. Anything more, I wouldn't dream of using it myself. I bought it connect the hotend on a 3D printer and this lightweight wire is completely useless for that.
summary: Uber-cheap China product

reviewText:
The filament has inconsistent material properties.
I've purchased well over 10 rolls of just black esun ABS and kept finding a small change in the print quality.
I kept blaming my printer thinking something was loose or out of tune. Then I started saving the last bit of filament to test between filament changes and sure enough, between rolls using the same model, bed location, printer and sliced g code the print significantly changed between rolls that were delivered just two days apart.
Attached are two square test cubes both printed with the same file, on the same printer and with black abs esun filament that was delivered two days apart from each other. The bottom cube is from a roll I had been printing with over the past two days. The top cube is from a roll that was delivered today. I had dealt with poor rolls of esun in the past that had moisture content build up over several days when i started using them and since keep all rolls in a separate desiccant filled container. I also print in an enclosed container with a hygrometer to measure moisture. If it wasn't for the fact that I've wasted so much time tuning the printer to a roll, only to tune it again each time a go through the roll I would recommend esun. But the fact it has such a wide range of print quality is of concern. Good thing i didn't order bulk quantity from Esun as I had planned.
summary: Inconsistent material and print results.

reviewText:
This White ABS filament feels odd to me.  It has an odd, kind of chalky, texture and seems brittle after printing.  For example, print an object with a brim and then hold the brim in your hand and crumple it.  It kind of breaks and crumbles instead of just flexing and bending.

Now, the reason I'm writing this review is that, today, I started a long print job on a large item.  The total job was going take about 5.5 hours.  I started the job in the morning before heading to work as I use OctoPrint to remotely manage my printer.  About an hour into the job, I noticed that after the first layer, and about half way into the second layer, it looked like filament was no longer being extruded.  I had assumed that the print head had a jam (which is weird for me as it would be the first ever), so I canceled the job and went back to work (hey, I gotta do SOME work at work).  When I went home for lunch to examine the printer, I noticed that the filament had been yanked out of the print head.  I inspected the filament path and immediately noticed that I couldn't draw any more filament from the spool when pulled on.  Upon closer examination of the spool, it became evident that the spool had a cross-over.  Somehow my roll of filament, several yards into the spool, had been crossed under another loop.  It could only have been done by a human, IMHO, so I'm guessing that some helpful eSun guy had the spool unroll on him so he locked the filament in place under another loop, and then rolled and taped the end of the remaining filament over it.  Now I have to wait until I get home tonight to set the printer up again.  So, I guess I don't feel confident that there's not another filament lock somewhere further into the spool?  That in addition to the aforementioned weird texture of the product makes me think I'll be avoiding this brand in the future.
summary: Cost me some time and sanity.

reviewText: Very accurate and smooth filament, extremely pleased with the quality.  Very nice pink color.  Printed many full plates with no issue.
summary: Excellent Pink!

reviewText:
I just have to say that for me this was a pretty easy build, and although not familiar with 3d printers it has a lot of things in common with the type of machines I work on. One thing I will note here is there is no power switch. You basically plug it in to use it. What I did was plug it into a small power strip with an on/off switch, and it is surge protected now.
Some issues I ran into were the limit switches. One was bad and  two needed to be re-soldered. Once the frame is together, these are some of the first electrical components to go into place, and with the tiny wires having to be moved around during the rest of the assembly, the wires most likely
broke at the solder points. Taping in place may have helped. Next thing I did was break on of the uprights for the spool holder when tightening it down. My fault as it was not pushed in all the way and I tried to draw it in with the bolt. A little ca glue solved this and I really may not use it anyway.
Once assembled I re-homed everything and found the broken limit switch. Luckily there was a spare in the kit which was a great thing. My first print started out OK, then I noticed the print was not in the center of the bed. I aborted that job and tried another. Better but nothing to show for it. Now after screwing around for close to 12 hours with the printer, (Drivers, 3D files, connecting to my laptop etc.) I gave up.  I'll skip right to the biggest hurdle... When I hooked this up to my laptop with the usb cable it would not recognize the printer. It showed up in the devices menu, but would not communicate. I installed the drivers from the included dvd with no luck. Searching for a resolution yielded no success, so for now I use the sd card slot which is very limiting. Just can't understand what is going here and never had this type of issue before??
Overall I am happy with this Printer and I have a better understanding of the machine buying this kit rather than a plug and play. Sure it might have been easier, but where's the fun in that? I also made some small mods as I moved along. 1 thing I fixed was the bearing on the "Y" axis belt in the front. the bearing was just flopping around so I made 2 thin nylon washers to go on either side of the bearing and it works great. 2nd was putting brass washers between the bed and the springs and an extra nut to hold the bold in place while turning the wing nuts to level the bed. Works great! Now my 3rd small mod was to use a small piece of kydex on the limit switch for the "Z" Axis. I didn't want the nuts digging into the frame in the back so this small plate will allow me to adjust this easier if needed. Last thing I will say is, tidy up the wiring as you go. It saved me a lot of untangling later on and it just looks nicer! I also traced the frame pieces onto heavy paper to make a second frame from for a scratch built printer as a project down the road.. Overall It was a good experience for me as I enjoy building stuff. I only used the photos on the dvd to do this assembly and if you've ever built stuff from a box, this is really no different. I might upgrade the board in the near future to see if it will connect to my laptop. Not sure if it's the board or me missing something, but for now it works with just the sd card so...
Day 3 finally yielded me some good results although I screwed up the print at around the 20% mark. I had a minor shift in the "Y" axis due to the belt being too loose.
summary: Nice Project!!

reviewText: Prints great in my Dremel 3D20! Comes out as a somewhat/almost translucent like. Very nice color. Only downfall is that your paying a lot for half the filament compared to other filament brands. Dremel would sell a lot more if their filament prices were more competitive.

reviewText:
I purchase this filament from B&H.
Very poor quality printing. It comes in a cartridge with contacts to communicate with the XYZ 3D printer.
The XYZPrinting software automatically set the printing parameter for extruder and bed temperature. I tested it against the MonoPrice natural PLA filament on the same XYZ Pro 3-in-1 printer with matching parameters. The result clearly shows the XYZ nature filament is rougher.

reviewText:
I am specifically reviewing the BLACK Glass(PETG) here. It's really quite bad.

You won't be able to calibrate with this filament because it is of inconsistent diameter. It measures anywhere from 1.68mm to 1.91mm in the 3 foot area I tested it with; most of time it measured on the high side. PETG is finicky stuff as it is and requires you to underextrude ever so slightly. It's not possible to calculate your flow rate with this stuff because it is so inconsistent. So you end up with goobers between your layers and strings all over the place.

When I bought this it had 3.5 stars. I'm reviewing it to save some other people the headache it's caused me. I've uploaded an image of a print I did at .2mm layer height, 250C nozzle temp at 30mm/sec on a 0.4mm nozzle.
summary: Do not cheap out and get this filament, you'll regret it.

reviewText: I've gotten a couple reels of this filament and it's consistent, which is honestly one of the most attractive qualities in a filament. The color is a true white. It has never broken, or cracked, or clogged, or caused the print to fail in any way. It's easy to work with and my Makerbot Replicator 2 likes it.
summary: Absolutely consistent.

reviewText: I used this to build a new smoker rolling dryer bench, worked great just as advertised. Directions were clear and easy to follow. Rolls the entire bench with ease.

reviewText: A really great-looking blue color.  Prints wonderfully and it does a great job at hiding layer lines.  See for yourself in my pictures!

Absolutely fantastic stuff.
Prints great on my MP MakerSelect plus with all metal hot end at 200 degrees at the the hot end and 50 degrees on the bed.

summary: Five Stars

reviewText: As advertised
summary: Five Stars

reviewText:
This is edited to change the rating to one star.  After using these I determined that these spire nuts were indeed hard but the screws were too soft to use with the nuts. Later, while trying to remove fasteners from the nuts, I found it nearly impossible to do it without causing all sorts of destruction and damage. The screws just would not back out. Then I looked closer (see the picture attached). These spire nuts are malformed. The thread gripping ears are dead level, not twisted to approximate the spiral of a screw or coarse bolt, and they will dig into the fastener threads and wedge it from reversing. I was expecting a removable system; if I wanted a rivet I would have bought one.

This is just plain junk and should not continue to be foisted off on us paying customers.
summary: MIS-MANUFACTURED

reviewText: Nice gauge, works good. Smooth operation. The only thing I don't like is the way they have you cut the plug on top to release the pressure after installing. Other brands have a pin you pull out half way to release the pressure and can actually reseal if you remove. If you ever have to move, you must make sure you keep it up right or the glycerin will leak out. Other than that it works nice.
summary: Nice Vacuum gauge

reviewText: It is a great way to check amperage on home appliances (measuring the strength of electrical current in amperes). As for the device I purchased, it works perfectly and the prong wires being tested are correctly labeled. However, there is something strange about the product photo accompanying the product description. The "L" or Line side and the "N" or Neutral side are labeled for the wrong side. Also, the photo shows the splitter is rated for a MAX 250V / 15A (which it is), while at the bottom it indicates being rated for 600V CAT III. A rating of CAT III/600 V = 6000V test voltage @ 2 ohms. No matter though. The splitter being sold does match the text description. I have attached a photo of my purchased splitter, and a photo supporting my point regarding the labeling. In short, I love this device!
summary: Great way to check amperage on home appliances

reviewText: You get what you pay for, and this PLA delivers!  I have a new favorite PLA.  Very predictable and accurate prints.  I was skeptical about the strength claims, but it is stronger and forms better layer to layer adhesion than typical PLA.  I print it on a Flashforge Dreamer at 210 C, and a bed temp of 35 C.  I only use Elmers Washable Glue Stick (the purple one) on my bed.  I haven't tried their other types and i'm not sure I want to after using this.  I'm spoiled now.
summary: I have a new favorite PLA. Very predictable and accurate prints

reviewText:
I got the assembled version. Everything came in the box as expected, so I was up and running in under 10 minutes with my first print.

This printer was not originally priced at $250, and I was always tempted but wouldn't go for such a small build space for the money. Now they don't make them any more, they've lowered the price and for $250 this is an excellent buy. Most of the prints I do day to day are not going to exceed the tiny build envelope, so printing practical parts in a 100mm(4")x100mm(4")x130mm(5") area is very doable.

As for the printer itself, it's not hitting in the same league as my flashforge or prusa. It's on par with my tronxy, flsun i3 and tarantula I would say. A little bit more tuning and tinkering and I bet I would have this producing some decent little prints. But for now, I want it for practical components, not model quality parts. It can print all manner of filaments, as long as they don't require a heated bed, the hotend is all metal.

Pros;
  - Solid
  - Consistent print quality
  - Easy to get started

Cons
 - No attached screen, has to be tethered
 - Noisy

I would not recommend a Printrbot as a first printer, it's just a little too difficult, and after reading some of these reviews it does seem their quality control can be a little lax sometimes. I've seen the replacement for this printer, the smalls, in kit form. And after watching it be built, it's not for the feint of heart. The Prusa i3 MKS2 is a much simpler prospect to build (but twice the cost).

The design of this printer is excellent, it's solid and well thought out. I've spent $25 on buying the upgraded z screw, see if I can't make this a little better, but out of the box I'm extremely happy. This is well worth the $250 I paid for it and you can still get the upgrades from Printrbot to make it a little better.

Update:
I've added a picture. Using toner plastics PLA, printed a rocket and a vase. The print came out excellent, and this printer is dealing with anything I can throw at it so far. My only complaint is the noise, it is not a quiet printer.
summary: Excellent Printer for the cost

reviewText: Awesome filament!  Defiantly one of my favorite filaments and hands down my most consistent prints come from 3D Solutech. Highly recommend you won't be disappointed.

reviewText: I used the same PETG profile for my other brand filament and it prints as well, or even better than my other spools of PETG. The gears I printed with it have great definition, the teeth are all well formed and the long bridging on the underside didn't sag or break. The parts and layer bonding are very strong. Had no tangles. Had no jams. Printed good every time. I do print it hot (225*C) so it's nice and shiny. I printed it on a 45*C bed with a textured (LokBuild) surface. reviewText: Overall, the filament performs well.  I ran into problems towards the end of the spool because of bad winding. reviewText: I got very good results on first try. PEI bed at 70c, 0.4mm nozzle at 425C, and 0.1mm layers. Very good layer adhesion, smooth surface and almost no stringing. Dropping two stars though to 'It's OK' for the color. If you are looking for relatively pale red this is the filament for you. If you are looking for deeper (and darker) red then look somewhere else, for example this Amolen https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B071GX6KDK which is more for my liking (see attached picture)
summary: It's reddish, not red, pale red, almost orange.

reviewText:
Unfortunately I bought the 3mm bowden version. Not recommended.
Like the other negative reviews, I'd encountered not a total clog, but enough resistance that it will end up shredding the extruder end of the bowden tube. This is quite bad.
At first it will be "okay" and extrude a few millimeters just fine. Then when you print, it'll print the skirt fine and then nothing will come out of the nozzle.
Then you'll look up and the bowden tube will have committed suicide. (Picture attached of one of many times it shredded itself in the push fittings)
I'm not sure if the heatbreak is bad or if the bowden tube is too weak/thin, but it's not really worth repairing/modding.
summary: Shredding the tube.

reviewText: and they seem solid. though they won't handle lots of voltage they'll work for my projects
summary: all with in tolerance

reviewText:
I installed this on my Qidi Tech I in less than half an hour.  I put the blue sheet that I've always used on top and started printing.  I tested it with some low, flat objects that I normally cannot remove without damaging them and this worked perfectly.  My old build plate was not removable and this one I remove the magnetic sheet, bend, and the prints pop right off.

My only complaint is the screws to attach the magnetic bed to the printer are slightly off.  If the front two are in their holes the back one is slightly too far forward.  You can wiggle it all in but it does effect bed leveling if you aren't careful.

Be sure to completely tighten your bed down before leveling for the first time.  This is likely thicker than your old bed and the extruder will drag on the bed and scratch it up if you don't.
summary: Quick installation and works perfectly!

reviewText:
AccuMaster product description said "LCD Display Resolution 0.01 degrees at 0-1 and 89-90 degrees; 0.05 degrees at the rest."  However, the AccuMaster that I received (Model 7434 v1.1) has an actual display resolution of 0.1 degrees (see photo).  In contrast, the similar Neoteck Level Box NTK034 actually does have a display resolution of 0.01 degrees (I bought both -- see photo).  I prefer to see 0.01 degrees of resolution as on the Neoteck and do the rounding myself.

User calibration was required on both units.

Both units stay on for about 3 minutes after the last "movement".  However, the Accumaster keeps the backlight on for the full time (until 3 minutes have elapsed after the last "movement"), whereas the Neoteck turns off the backlight after 30 seconds without motion (its backlight comes back on if any motion occurs).  For both units, power consumption was about 16mA with the backlight on, and Neoteck consumed 7mA with the backlight dimmed.  The Neoteck unit is more sensitive to motion, so tends to stay on in cases where the AccuMaster turns off.

Neither the AccuMaster nor the Neoteck Level Box have perfectly square plastic sides, so expect slight inconsistencies if measuring using the top or side surfaces.  Also, magnets are only on the bottom.

The AccuMaster will not shut off if "Err" is on the display when the On/Off button is held.  The Neoteck does not have this minor issue.

Without batteries, the AccuMaster weights about 73g and the Neoteck about 70g.

The AccuMaster is said to come with a 2-year warranty, but Amazon isn't listed as an authorized dealer on Calculated Industries website.  Neoteck only has an 18-month warranty but the Neoteck company is located in China.  (Both units are made in China)

I've reduced the number of stars for the AccuMaster because of the incorrect product description, and lower display resolution, but otherwise I'm happy with the functionality of both units.
summary: LCD display resolution not as described, compare to Neoteck

reviewText: I am in the camp of this Filament was a pain to work with, no matter what I tried I could not get it to stop stringing. As stated in other reviews Its a high temp filament. Treat it like ABS. Structurally it is very week. I was purchasing this to make corner braces for a new DIY built printer. with a lot of work I have gotten some Ok prints out of it. So purchase this only if you are ready to put a lot of work in to Dial it in. I still have not mastered this filament.
summary: Hard to master..

reviewText: Decent grey silver color, printed well on my Creality CR10s. This was the 1st filament I have ever printed with and I am pleased. I ran it about 210 to 215 on some of the prints. The plastic feels strong, expecially a firearm bracket mount that I made and the bed leveling adjustment wheels. I have found to run Inland filament a little hotter for added strength.
summary: Nice grey color, not too terribly shiny, printed well on a Creality CR-10s

reviewText: PETG is my favorite filament and I only purchase Hatchbox quality filaments.  I have not experienced another PETG filament because Hatchbox never lets me down.  PETG is my favorite plastic due to its balance of printability and end use durability. Once I got setting dialed in, Ive had nothing but success with all of hatch boxs PETG colors. The green in my photo is also hatchbox PETG.
summary: To heck with ABS

reviewText:
I'm new to 3d printing and have less than 1 week of experience.  This is the only filament I have worked with thus far and I have been able to achieve a 90% success rate through 3/4 of the spool. All of my failures occurred within the first  layer of printing.  Once I dialed in my 1st layer settings I have had nothing but success with this filament.
First layer needs about 75% slower speed and 105% extrusion.  I used glue stick on the print bed for increased adhesion. My bed temperature is 90-120c depending upon the part size I am printing.  Nozzle temperature is 230-245c.  Once first layer is laid down successfully, I then encase my printer with a garbage bag to increase the ambient temps.  I then wake up to successfully printed parts, with little, if any print defects or blemishes. I am using a prusa i3 mk2s that I built from a kit.
This filament has great end use properties and is very tough and resistant to higher temperatures, unlike PLA. I left a part in my vehicle (Texas summer) to test this and it did not warp or deform to my surprise.  It is food safe and hydrophobic, which is nice because most filaments absorb moisture if not stored correctly. Only downside is increased "stringing", but through research I learned this is a common side effect of PETG.
I have no other PETG filament experience, but given that I am extremely new to 3d printing and was able to achieve success beyond my expectations, I give this product 5 stars. I look forward to the results I will achieve as I get more and more experienced in 3d printing.
summary: 3D Printing Rookie Getting "Pro" Results

reviewText: I have printed with all the available Hatchbox PETG colors, and green is by far my favorite color.  It prints incredibly smooth and hides imperfections well due to its color shade.  Green also appears the least shiny out of all the Hatchbox PETG filament colors.  Will definitely purchase more in the future.
summary: Beautiful Green Color

reviewText:
I have used hatchbox PETG in green, blue, white, orange, yellow and red. This is my first 4 star experience. I believe my filament has moisture present and the silver color used having a brittling effect.  During printing the first layer of wraps on the spool were bubbly caused by moisture boil off. It went away for the most part, however it intermittently will occur.

UPDATE: I believe I found the solution to the airy brittle nature of this filament. Unlike the other hatchbox PETG, this filament has a much narrower operating range. I noticed when I extruded at 240c the bubbles went away and bonding and flexibility increased. I believe whatever material that is needed for the silver color has a lower boil temperature than other colors and that is where the bubbles come from, which may be mistaken for moisture in filament. I eliminated the possibility of moisture by low heating in a vacuum chamber for a month.
summary: Silver a little funky

reviewText: I used this along with a 12v wall power supply and solid state relay to control a hot tub heater. It controls the heater very well. I just turn on the heater and the display shows the tub temperature as it rises to set point. It remembers the last setting when power is cut and it fits a standard wall outlet box mounted horizontally.
summary: Good hot tub controller

reviewText: Prints perfect, just like my other Hatchbox ABS materials.  I used this on my Flash Forge Creator Pro to print parts for my Hictop CR-10 printer, it was perfect shade of blue to match my new printer and I wanted to use ABS for accessories/mods for that printer so they last and hold up to higher heats.  I needed zero extrusion multipliers for this material, it was sized +/- .01mm in diameter from the 1.75mm size.  Run at 230 C extruder and 110 C bed, if you use painters tape I recommend to either spray with unscented aqua net hair spray or make some ABS and Acetone slurry, if your using PEI it should stick well with nothing, and if you just have glass, use the hairspray mentioned directly on the glass but not too much.  Pictures of some accessories for my CR-10 I printed are included.
summary: Perfect blue color for my Hictop CR-10 mods.  Works great at 230 C extruder and 110 C Bed temps.

reviewText:
I used a few of these brackets to make and mount adjustable limit switches for a prototype I am putting together. I figured these would be easy to work with and even if they are not in the final design, they would do a good job of mounting the switches for testing and proof of concept. Let me tell you, this bracket is really heavy duty. The metal is thick enough to make them rigid and it has 3 punches on the 90 degree that makes it very strong and will not bend out of shape. The edges are rounded (not sharp) and it is easy to drill if you need to like I did to much the switch mount holes.

Great item to have around for your DIY projects.

reviewText:
While I don't have much experience with any 'premium' filaments, I'm all about the cheap stuff, and this filament is A-OK.

I received the filament and immediately loaded it into my printer. Every print was as good as it could be (any rough edges were due to me putting off tuning my printer) and the stuff sands very easily.

I guess I should say that I generally 'finish' my 3D prints, so the print quality doesn't really matter because any problems will be fixed with filler primer and spot putty.

Update - Something I've noticed is that if I don't use my printer for a week or so and the filament is still loaded up, it will eventually snap off. I've never had this happen with any other filaments. It hasn't happened during printing so it hasn't been a problem, but I guess it's something to look out for.
summary: Yellow... It's Me.

reviewText: Great product second review on this manufacturer, first review was for the orange pla.. I have little experience with 3D printing but this stuff worked great right from the start. It flows well and has great table and layer to layer adhesion. The only reason for 4 stars is some of the loops are over each other.. It hasn't caused me a problem yet but it is something I will watch. As your extruder wears in this little momentary bind may cause slipping. See pics of product results below

reviewText:
I used this vac to clean my fireplace just now- new for me, since i normally sweep it clean with a handbroom and dustpan. i attached pics showing how the vac came out of the box, and a pic of the intro instruction page. a few things to note.  this title says wet dry vac...however, the instruction manual clearly says, "It should not be used to pick up liquids."  so...NOT a wet vac, at least according to it's manual, pg. 6.  The instructions show that one screw driver is required as a tool for set-up. however, you only need the screw driver to tighten the nozzle to the extension wand, or to disassemble/ add batteries to the nozzle/wand flashlight portion (will talk about that later). it took me all of 30 seconds to snap together the hose and two nozzles to the bucket, and snap in the four casters.  The filter was already assembled and attached to the lid when i got it.  The construction of the vac is sturdy, well-made, and fully metal in the "belly" where it counts, with the non-metal portions being the filter on the underside of the lid, the hose and the area where the hose snaps into the side of the metal bucket, the tray the entire bucket sets on, that you snap the casters into, and that yellow handle and casing on top. the capacity is 5 gal, but you could realistically have maybe 3 gal. ash pickup tops, without getting too close to the filter.

The nice thing is, the entire bottom portion of the inside is metal, so any slightly hot ashes should be held safely, provided they are not hot enough to spark the filter at the top of the inner lid. The warning on pg. 2 of the instruction manual also clearly says, "This vacuum is intended to pick up COLD ash..." (caps in the instruction manual). I really like that the instruction manual is very detailed, and well-written in English (and Spanish and French). The company is Emerson Electric, and their workshop appears to be in St. Louis. I don't know where the item is made, however.

As a vacuum itself, it's not exceptionally powerful (sounds like a regular hair dryer), and my normal vacuum has much more suction. However, it easily picked up light ash from the fireplace. i could smell some amt. of the ash in the air after vacuuming, but i guess that is to be expected with something as fine as ash. this isn't a Dyson, but as far as i know, Dyson does not make metal canisters to hold dust, so this does have use.  One interesting feature, is a flashlight at the section where the handle meets the extension nozzle- i've attached a pic of the single bulb. This was useful for the fireplace, where it's dark, so you can better see what you're doing. it came with the battery installed, and worked when i tried the switch. overall, i would recommend this item, esp. for outdoor metal fire pit cleanup, or the inner section of your big grill, where it's hard to reach.  for the inside fireplace, though, i think i'll stick to my handbroom and dustpan, cuz it's easy enough by hand, and i found it a hassle to dump the ashes (lift off lid, pick up canister, dump)- ash fluffs all over.  gotta dump outside, not in the garage.
summary: Not a Wet Vac, but picks up Ash well.

reviewText: If you're considering whether or not to buy this multimeter, then I credit you with knowing the product or having done some research... Otherwise you'd be looking at cheeper models. If you're a professional electrician then you no doubt no how this little gem stacks up against the competition. There are meters of all flavors and features, and in numerous brands. What this CL800 can accomplish with it's amazing features is a bargain for this price. And no need buy a carrying case, because it comes with one. I ended up buying an additional case, following the recommendation that a carrying case was frequently bought with it. I use the extra case to put cables and accessories in. So, it worked out anyway. I'm not an electrician, but the electrical repairs I do around my house saves me $$$. The meter pays for itself. I love it!
summary: It's no Fluke that I bought this - OK, don't hit me for saying that.

reviewText:
Update 8-11-18.
Started having heating issues so I moved everything out of the base in a box I printed. Also install 8825 type stepper drivers. Now printer is almost silent. No loud whine.

update 8-10-18  Ok, I now have Marlin 1.1.8 installed on the board and it is working great.  There is a place on thingiverse that has a page that shows you how to set it up and get it working with the auto bed leveling!  It is working great!  Anycubic version of the firmware on the system is a 1.5 star and the new version is 5!  so many head aches solved.  It has a very good walk through that will get the printer up and running quickly.  Follow the direction on the page and also watch the youtube video that he made.
search thingiverse for this
Marlin 1.1.8 firmware for Anycubic Kossel(mini & plus), delta calibration circle

it will make a very big difference in you printer.  One thing to remember, I had to change the default arm length.  If you do it by the lcd, you will get to a point where it won't let you add anymore.  Just save the setting, and keep adding till you get to the amount you need.  Mine was 249.xxx.  Send me a message if you need some help

Update 8-7-18. Well this sucks. Had to reload the software and that was a chore!  I managed to get Marlin 1.1.7 running on it with the auto level!  Still running into problems but cal cube car out x20.19y20.20z20.20 mm. Still testing but having some ghosting on it

OK so this is not my first 3-D printer but it is my first Delta 3-D printer. I simply took about an hour went to checked everything all the ball joints were nice and tight everything fit together well I did like the included ball Allens even though they were cheap they did get the job done so I got to give them credit for that all the extra tools with it were a nice plus. One thing that I wouldve liked was better cooling on the main board for the  stepper drivers, I am planning on making something for that and using a 40 mm fan to add some cooling. When I first started the calibration process it was nothing but problems. Every time I hit the store nothing would happen. I just about given up hope and was looking at ordering a whole new board but a 32 bit one when I tried one more time and when I pressed and held the knob to store after second or two there Was a beep! That made all the difference in the world everything started storing after I held the button and waited for the beep.  So if you're having problems with yours and its not storing the Settings try pressing and holding the button and waiting for the beep to see if it improves.  One problem that I am having is the extruder temperature is fluctuating significantly and causing some minor issues so it looks like Ill have to go to into in the P ID for it to make it better. I do like the black plastic cover for the heated bed Ive never used anything like that Ive always used to borosilicate glass and hairspray or glue stick but this stuff works great .
summary: Better than I expected!! (After getting rid of Anycubic's firmware)

reviewText:
For those who care, empty spool weight is 184g.  There was slightly more than 1kg of filament on the spool (minus the spool, of course).  Density seems to be about 1.28g/cm^3.

I decided to wait until I finished the spool before writing a review.  I didn't run into any issues with this with a .4mm nozzle, starting with a Geeetech hotend and later upgrading to an E3D v6.  It's SUPER bright yellow and glows brightly when you shine a UV light on it although it's not a glow-in-the-dark filament.  Light passes through it pretty easily.  It took me about a month to use it all up, and during that time it didn't become brittle even though I didn't keep it in a dry box.  The parts I made from it are quite strong and almost completely inflexible.  The only issues I ran into were caused by incorrect settings.  It seems happier when you print at the upper end of the listed range (200-220C), or at least the layers stick together better.
summary: It's SUPER bright yellow and glows brightly when you shine a ...

reviewText:
This is a great product, but one bag barely covered the cracks in our steps - which weren't that big- and it dried so fast we lost a few inches of concrete from drying in the bucket. I'm not sure if you can tell by the photo, but a bunch of mix dried in one side. I tried using extra water to loosen to use, but that did not work well at all.

The instructions are clear and it is easy to mix.

However, It is extremely expensive if you have a big job. We used this on very small cracks/holes in older stairs. We have some larger jobs, but will need to find something more affordable.

I like the product, but for the cost - and product let due to drying - I'll price shop for other bags.
summary: Good, but dries fast in the bucket

reviewText: I purchased another board since my first one burn the connector for the heated bed.  I understand this to be an inherent problem due to too much current draw from the heated bed coupled with vibration rattling connectors loose.  I read on forums that if you purchase an automotove relay, you can eliminate the massive current draw that would cause the failure. I purchased a relay (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00MKWACVI/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1) and my new board has been holding up just fine.  The quality of these boards seem good, its just a design flaw that leads to premature failure.  If you are replacing this board on your reprap or other printer, be sure to buy a relay as well.
summary: Connector will fail if you don't buy a relay.

reviewText:
I'll start out by saying it took a bit to dial in the settings for this filament, but once I did I was rewarded with absolutely beautiful prints. Surfaces are buttery smooth and have an excellent shine to them, right off the print bed.  Don't be alarmed when you first start priming your extruder and the filament hangs under it like a banana, as it won't coil up like other filament does. It will expand to slightly more than the diameter it started out as. You will be able to do thin wall prints, so don't worry.

Take your time to get the first layer right, ensuring you really smash it down good. I've seen that other reviewers have had problems with bed adhesion, but I've had zero problems printing on a PEI coated steel sheet (Prusa MK3 and MK2.5 upgrade). Just make sure the bed is clean and squish that first layer down. See the picture of the key print - perfection bed adhesion assured a successful print.

I highly recommend calibrating your extrusion multiplier for this filament (well, for all your filaments for that matter), as you really want to avoid over extruding this filament - you'll have a mess. I've had the best luck using Slic3rPE with this filament. I prefer Simplify3D, but anything sliced for this filament has zits all over it and I haven't taken the time to track it down yet. If you are having problems with zits calibrate your extrusion multiplier and try different slicing software.

Turn your speed down, you won't break any speed records printing with this filament - besides, you'll get a better shine. Set your max speed for 50mm/sec and drop other speeds down for 1st layer, perimeters, etc, accordingly. Set it up for a short, fast retraction with a .6 mm z-hop - mine is set for .8 distance at 35mm/sec speed. I've got my temp set for 210C. Once dialed in, you'll easily get prints like you see in my pictures - just stick with it until you do.

So to sum it up, print it low, print it slow and you'll enjoy great prints. Prints with this filament do not seem as strong as other types of PLA, so I wouldn't recommend using it for parts that receive a lot of abuse, but it's for printing pretty stuff anyway ;)
I highly recommend this filament, take the time to dial it in and you'll soon agree.

Chief
summary: Beautiful shine without post processing, highly recommended

reviewText:
A budget magnetic base that can hold a dial gauge reasonably well for the price.

Pros:
1. The magnetic base is strong enough to hold a large dial gauge upside down and sideways (as pictured) as long as the metal does not have too smooth of a coating.  I tried it on the side of my refrigerator and it could not hold itself and slid down slowly.  But it worked fine attached to all different parts of my car.
2. The small size of the base keeps it out of the way most of the time.
3. The arms are easy to adjust.
4. Fits all of the dial gauges I have

Cons:
1. The arms are a little shorter then similar holders and limits its use / placement.
2. For the price, the plastic knobs feel cheap.
3. The small mag base is not very strong.
summary: A budget magnetic base for holding dial gauges.

reviewText: I already owned a caliper set, but when I was offered the chance to review the Calculated Industries AccuMaster, I figured since I had a new Sawstop SawStop PCS175-TGP252 1.75-HP Professional Cabinet Saw Assembly with 52-Inch Professional T-Glide Fence System, Rails and Extension Table on the way with an upgraded Kreg Miter Gauge Kreg KMS7102 Table Saw Precision Miter Gauge System calibration was in my near future! I primarily work with wood, constantly building something or other for the shop or for the home. The 1/64 scale cames in handy. My last caliper set was calibrated to 1/128 which made me have to do a lot of the math that I was not too keen on. You can convert between Millimeters, decimals or fractions at the push of a button. All of which I find handy. When calibrating equipment that can cut off my fingers, that fraction can make a big difference. The cost to quality ratio is great. It uses a standard CR2032 Battery which is the norm. Long lasting, nothing to complain about. I take it out and put it back in the case when I am not working on a project. You can not go wrong with this digital caliper. Easy to use, very accurate and affordable.
summary: Woodworker? You need this!
