reviewText:
Hold on a minute. These bad reviews must be of something other than what I got in the mail. These are made normally, they hold to the spade normally, and they crimp normally. The attached pic shows three crimps, all holding securely. The first is very thin 24 gauge cat wire. The second is 18 gauge stranded speaker wire. The third is 12(!) gauge stranded automotive wire; it wouldn't fit twisted but it just barely fit in when I left the strands straight. If anyone is having a problem attaching any wire to these terminals then they need decent pliers. I use Channelock 909 (B00004SBDI) crimpers; they work no muss no fuss and have good leverage.

PS: never STAKE insulated terminals using the NON area in the picture. Always use the INSUL area of the pliers.
summary: good quality, good price

reviewText:
This was easy to install, if you take your time. I found out the hard way it doesnt work with standard nozzles.

Once installed, everything must be recalibrated, especially the temperatures. The directions state that PLA will need much higher temperatures. I found 10 to 40 degrees C hotter produces outstanding results, even from lesser quality filaments.

I also discovered my firmware would not allow the higher temperatures possible. A quick update solved this.

The photos are a temperature calibration stick using a quality ABS. Before installing this all metal hot end, this filament had a habit of layer separation.

Also, I changed my slicing engine to idea maker to take advantage of different temperatures & fan settings based on build height. Highly recommended.
summary: Great hot end & nozzle, but requires tweaking.

reviewText: Just on putting on the rod the ball bearing fell out when the cap came off the second one when I removed the rod to make and ajustment the ball bearings spilled out with the cap on! Very disappointed and waste of my time ad money.
summary: Bad bearings

reviewText: The description can be a little misleading since this board is not FOR numerical control but is controlled digitally (numerically)  by using the buttons on the board.  With the buttons, you set the constant output voltage and the maximum current.  There may also be a way of using it for a constant current supply, haven't tried.  It works perfectly and a great deal.  The meters show the output voltage and current or the input voltage and current.  There are four buttons that are used for the settings and three leds to show whether the output is on or off and whether the meters are showing the input voltage and current or the output voltage and current.  The only downside of this board is that you might need a "cheat sheet" to remind you of the button sequences and what the leds mean (see pic of my cheat sheet, I hope is correct.  If you cannot read or is incorrect, let me know.  You might have a better one).  Using buttons was clearly a way to save money.  DROK has other models that are easier to set and enclosed but much more expensive, so you have a choice (I have both).  The other thing is that since everyone is on one board, it is a little difficult to put in a case.  I removed the two input and output terminal blocks and added separate binding posts and I jumpered other separate buttons which I mounted on the box front panel.  I then cut a rectangular hole in box so the display is visible and mounted the board on some standoffs. I then pasted the cheat sheet on the top of the box.  For a power supply to feed the board, I used a left over laptop power supply (or you can buy one $10).  I also added a couple of inexpensive digital readouts so I could see the input and output at the same time (why not for $4 for both?)  I put two of these in one box using just one laptop supply for an inexpensive dual bench power supply for a fraction of the price.  Plus it was fun (for me!)  All this was no problem for me since I have been doing this stuff for fifty years (yup) but others might be better off paying more to get the unit with a knob and is enclosed.  Thank you DROK.
summary: Great for building a power supply and a good value.  Read review for some tips

reviewText:
Complete project description follows but the keys for the Ultrasonic Distance Sensor:  1) it's been running in a plastic box, outside, for almost a month with no problem.  The Arduino wakes us every 15 minutes and takes a measurement, transmits it, then goes back to sleep.  2) it is measuring the distance TO WATER!  I even turned the swim jets in my pool on to test turbulence and it works fine.

Green Pond Bridge Boat Clearance

At very low tide the clearance under Green Pond Bridge in Cape Cod is 66 or less and that is too low for the boat I use.  The tide charts for Falmouth, MA are theoretical and can vary as much as 18 from what is actually happening at the bridge.  This system monitors the clearance and transmits the information on the internet.
All of these parts were purchased from Amazon.

Transmitter

An (Arduino) Elegoo UNO R3 board is connected to an Elegoo HC-SR04 Ultrasonic Distance Sensor.  The UNO and the sensor calculate the distance from a fixed dock to the sea level, then transmit that data using a MakerFocus NRF24L01 Wireless Transceiver to the Receiver described below.  The Transmitter sits on the end of a dock where there is no power, so the UNO, Transceiver and Distance Sensor are powered by the energyShield 2.  This battery has special capabilities  it wakes everything up every 15 minutes.  The system takes a couple readings of the distance to the water then transmits that data, then the battery shuts it all off.  The data transmitted includes information from the battery  time, date, and voltage.

I have been testing this unit at home (in Dallas) and it has been operating outside, for about 20 days.  Based on battery drain it looks like it will operate for about 4-5 months before it needs a recharge.  When the temperature drops below zero the system still works fine but the voltage reported in the battery seems low.

All of this is housed in a plastic box printed for the purpose with a FlashForge 3d Printer Creator Pro, using eSun White ABS+ filament
Picture below.

Receiver

An (Arduino) Elegoo MEGA 2560 R3 is connected to another NRF24 Transceiver to receive the data.  The MEGA does the math to convert the distance from the dock to the water, to the bridge clearance.  Then the information is displayed on an Elegoo UNO R3 Touch Screen (that also works fine on the Mega).
Picture below.  A small plastic frame for the Receiver was also printed on the 3d printer

Web Server

Finally, the information in the MEGA is transmitted over a serial bus to a Hiletgo ESP8266 NodeMCU ESP-12E Internet WIFI Development Board (Also operates using Arduino IDE programming).  This board is connected to the MEGA via the XCSOURCE Logic Level Converter and powered by a UCEC MB102 Breadboard Power Supply Module.  All mounted on an Elegoo Breadboard.  The ESP8266 is programmed to be a web server.  It connects to the internet through the modem/router provided by AT&T.

Picture of my cell phone below.
summary: Measures distance to water accurately.  I'm using it to caclulate bridge clearance. Works OUTSIDE! (in a plastic box)

reviewText:
Honestly speaking, I do not remember having bought PLA filaments from a Chinese manufacturer before. But when I got my latest 3D printer from China, the quality of the parts turned out using the sample filament that came with the printer got me thinking if I should give these products a chance. Ironically, the US made PLA filament which I had purchased a few months ago was over-sized and caused the extruder to constantly slip leading to a clicking noise so annoying that I had to kill the print!

Therefore,  I decided to take a chance and order this filament from eSun. And to my surprise, did it deliver! The pictures speak for themselves!

To be fair, this review applies only to this shade of Green eSun filament!

------------------------
Print Settings:
------------------------

I printed the part in the pictures with a temperature of 210-deg-C and the bed heated to 65-deg-C. A bit on the higher side, but for the combination of the printer location and air circulation, this is what works for me.

With the print speed set to 50 mm/s, shell thickness to 1.2 mm, 20% infill and Raft enabled, this print took about 6.5 hours to complete. Better a slow and steady good print than a hurriedly delivered crappy print!  In addition, I dabbed the print bed with a popular non-toxic washable glue stick when the extruder reached 209-deg-C (see note below).

------------------------
Observations:
------------------------

First, I have never had a print where the Raft looks as good as the print does.
Second, the Raft peeled clean off the print without that tacky sound you usually hear when removing the raft.
Third, finish on the underside of the print looked a lot better than my prints from my stock of other filaments, and the top-side of the print had an excellent finish.
Fourth and final, the color of finished part fluctuates between different shades of Green - the bright Green looks best under sunlight or bright White light.

I have another roll of eSun Orange and I'm yet to test it out. I would be really shocked if it does not turn out as good.

FOOTNOTE ON GLUE APPLICATION :

In most 3D printers, the bed heats up first, followed by the extruder tip because it's faster to heat the tip once the bed gets to the set temperature. Therefore, it's recommended to wait until the extruder reaches closer to the set temperature before dabbing on the glue because you don't want the glue to go dry. In my case, I wait until 209-deg-C because the print kicks off at 210-deg-C as soon as the extruder reaches the temperature.

Also, I buy myself some time to apply the glue by *Not* homing the printer before kicking off the print. I do so by usually moving the Z axis 30 - 50 mm above the bed before I hit the print button. This gives me time to dab on the glue as the printer slowly auto-homes. Obviously, these methods work best on open-bed printers where there's less obstruction to on the bed.

And plenty of caution is recommended when working around moving printer parts and high temperatures!
summary: Excellent PLA filament! The best quality parts I have every printed!

reviewText: Here are some pictures of the nozzles. I'll update my review after getting installed and tested. They are 2 mm taller (shoulder to tip, note not shown in photos), so I will have to re-adjust & recalibrate my Z probe (a BL Touch Smart). The thread is about 1 mm longer too (see photos), so this will also upset your extruder setup, plan accordingly. They are also much heavier than a standard brass nozzle, so already know the nozzle warm up time will be longer. The throat has a smaller chamfer, so I plan on touching up with a drill bit to allow filament to feed in easier.
summary: Some photos if you are on the fence for these...

reviewText: This Apera Instruments EC20 Value Conductivity tester is simple to use, and it read my drinking water within a few seconds.  I followed the instructions to calibrate out of the box, using the 1 point calibration only, w the 1413 microsiemens/cm calibration fluid as shown, and i got a reading of 1427, which was accurate enough for my home purposes. I tested my filtered water, and it read 0.05 millisiemens/cm, which I compared to the readings of the same water from my TDS meter, and found my TDS meter to be fairly close as well, reading 22 ppm (0.05 millisiemens/cm converts to 25ppm on its 500 scale -I used a conversion calculator online).  I'm pretty happy w this device, and it gives me some peace of mind w my drinking water.  It is built well, comes with a nice lanyard  to hang around your neck if you are measuring frequently for your job, and the protective box w handle and snap lid is very convenient for keeping all your solutions together w the tester.
summary: Easy to Use, Was Calibrated Well Out of the Box

reviewText: Taulman BRIDGE Filament, 1.75 mm, BLACK Holy smokes this stuff is STRONG and easy to print!
summary: Best Nylon I've used!

reviewText: 2nd spool ive bought im new to 3D printing my first spool was straight from monoprice and it was ok a bit on the brittle side but i thought that is just how pla is but after using this im seeing more flexibility in the brim and the part. This is printing just fine for me at 205c and bed temp at 60c and slow printing at Fine max quality with very little to no warp with the 26650 cell holders im printing which is why i bought the 3d printer. I just recently printed a battery holder as well that i made in blender. Im not using glass just the heat bed with the factory build tack and i have to have the tip extremely close or the filament will not stick to the build tack from what ive seen on youtube its a must for it to be very close but in my case a sheet of paper is to thick it must be closer to the point of the filament being partially transparent on the first line that is set down for making the parts. If your bed is warped and extruder is to far away you will have problems I know i sure do and i just replaced my heat bed not to long ago i bought the printer refurbished but they left the heat bed and it was awful completely warped all 4 corners and the center at least monoprice sent me one for free but i had to void the 90 day warranty to do so. To me that was a better option than doing the whole exchange process with the printer working fine just the bed being horrible.
summary: Will buy this again

reviewText:
This is exactly what I needed.  It works great for popping prints off build plates.  Yes, I realize it's just a re-purposed cake icing knife, but those were the same price or more so ... whatever.

The only slightly critical thing I can say is it is blunt.  However if you're in possession of more than 3 brain cells, you'll simply sharpen it like any other knife and then it works great for sliding right under your prints.

Blade length is the advertised 7" despite what some reviewers might say (see my pic).  And the tang goes down halfway down the hilt as you can clearly see by the placement of rivets and the split in the hilt visible in vendor's photos.

reviewText:
This is my first time using this brand of filament.  I am pretty happy with this filament as far as the print.  Color is nice and better than expected.  Printed well and didn't have any jams or anything like that.  Granted I have only printed a few things so far.  But so far so good. I will update this review if that changes.

The only reason this didn't get a full 5 stars is because the spool hole diameter is SO much smaller than any spool I have used so far.  I have printed and gone through probably 50+ spools of all kinds of colors, materials, and brands.  This is the first I have run into that wouldn't fit any of my spool holders.  I had to actually break out my old ball bearing spool roller in order to use this spool.  Just be aware of this when buying.  I didn't see it listed anywhere in the description about the smaller than normal inner diameter.  They should probably list that in the description.

Other than that, I really like it. I will buy it again (actually already have another one coming).  See the attached photo for comparison to the whole size of most my other spools.
summary: Great filament, but non-standard spool size!

reviewText: Prints like butter!  While it is slightly transparent at thin layers, it definitely has a nice rich color if printed thick enough.

reviewText: Replaced the old thermometer in my YongHeng compressor because it was broken. The old one was with batteries, that one here is powered via USB. Not a big deal since I have a power outlet near to the compressor with integrated USB ports. It temp measured seems to be correct, the probe fits perfectly in the cylinder head of the compressor. For my use the probe cable is way too long. I do like that it shows the temp range with green, yellow, red which also matches the operating ranges of my compressor. You can switch between Fahrenheit and Celsius via a jumper on the backside. I gave 1 star less because the display is not good to read from a 45degree angle (the lower the angle the more faint the reading gets). Reading the display from 90degree angle its crystal clear.
summary: Good thermometer

reviewText: I purchased this PLA because it was Prime fast shipping.  I can say that this filament works great on both of my printers Robo and Prusa.  Different extruders seems to take this PLA just fine.  I printed with support and in 0.1 to 0.3mm layer height without issues.  I measured it with my digital caliper at 1.72mm which was much better than most PLA I've used.  I did have to run hotter that a few other filaments at around 200-210C. Other PLA I normally use 185C-200C.  Still printed all my models fine.  It came vacuum sealed and boxed and shipped by Amazon in a few days.  I'd buy again more if the prices are more competitive.
summary: Excellent PLA that works.

reviewText:
This is a very nice shade of Blue.  I really like it a lot.

All of the Green and Blue items that you see in these photos were printed with LabelPros filament.  The ridge on the Blue fan duct is due to the lack of a functioning fan duct during printing (chicken and egg scenario, the fan duct that came with the printer was not good).

I print on glass and the bottom layer of PLA comes out glass smooth.  Sides and top are quite smooth too.  Very impressed and happy with this.  I use a glue stick and have No problems getting this to stick to the build plate.

I have also used LabelPro's White and Green filaments and been equally happy with them.  I have done some strength testing on the white filament and it is very strong, great layer adhesion, a connector that I made supported ~200 pounds.  My expectation is that the strength of the other colors are similar.

I have never heard of LabelPros  before buying some filament from them, they definitely deserve to be better known.  This is as good as or better than anything I have purchased from the big name suppliers.
summary: Execellent Quality Filament, lovely Shade of Blue, Strong and has good layer adhesion

reviewText:
Great printing filament as long as you have sub twenty pricing. Unfortunately for me, running production, I purchased 3 spools of the blue. All 3 were a different color from the others. One was very much lighter. Using the same file on the same printer yielded different results in sheen as well.
Two were darker blue but one was shinier and the other was dull. Either they are using different manufacturing houses or not controlling their quality as closely as every other brand says they are...
summary: Great printing, inconsistent color.

reviewText: Product is not polished like in photo. It is instead more of a brushed aluminum. One of my dampers had an unattractive gouge. They do flex as they should though, and installed properly, reduce vibrations in the printer system. I recommend especially for the price.
